115,[' Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

116,"[' Riley was turning over the leaves of the book, and she could make nothing of his face, with its high-arched eyebrows; but he presently looked at her, and said,-3 ""Come, come and tell me something about this book; here are some pictures,-3I want to know what they mean.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
117,"['"" Maggie, with deepening color, went without hesitation to Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

118,"[' Riley\'s elbow and looked over the book, eagerly seizing one corner, and tossing back her mane, while she said,-3 ""Oh, I\'ll tell you what that means.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

119,"[' He\'s the Devil really"" (here Maggie\'s voice became louder and more emphatic), ""and not a right blacksmith; for the Devil takes the shape of wicked men, and walks about and sets people doing wicked things, and he\'s oftener in the shape of a bad man than any other, because, you know, if people saw he was the Devil, and he roared at \'em, they\'d run away, and he couldn\'t make \'em do what he pleased.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
120,"['"" Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
121,"["" Tulliver had listened to this exposition of Maggie's with petrifying wonder.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
122,"[' ""The \'History of the Devil,\' by Daniel Defoe,-3not quite the right book for a little girl,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
123,[' Riley.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
124,"[' ""How came it among your books, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
125,[' Tulliver?'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
126,"['"" Maggie looked hurt and discouraged, while her father said,-3 ""Why, it\'s one o\' the books I bought at Partridge\'s sale.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
127,"[' I read in it often of a Sunday"" (Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

128,"[' Tulliver felt somehow a familiarity with that great writer, because his name was Jeremy); ""and there\'s a lot more of \'em,-3sermons mostly, I think,-3but they\'ve all got the same covers, and I thought they were all o\' one sample, as you may say.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
129,"["" This is a puzzlin' world.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
130,"['"" ""Well,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

131,"[' Riley, in an admonitory, patronizing tone as he patted Maggie on the head, ""I advise you to put by the \'History of the Devil,\' and read some prettier book.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
132,[' Have you no prettier books?'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
133,"['"" ""Oh, yes,"" said Maggie, reviving a little in the desire to vindicate the variety of her reading.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
135,"['\'"" ""Ah, a beautiful book,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
136,"[' Riley; ""you can\'t read a better.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

137,"['"" ""Well, but there\'s a great deal about the Devil in that,"" said Maggie, triumphantly, ""and I\'ll show you the picture of him in his true shape, as he fought with Christian.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

138,"['"" Maggie ran in an instant to the corner of the room, jumped on a chair, and reached down from the small bookcase a shabby old copy of Bunyan, which opened at once, without the least trouble of search, at the picture she wanted.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
139,"[' ""Here he is,"" she said, running back to Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

140,"[' Riley, ""and Tom colored him for me with his paints when he was at home last holidays,-3the body all black, you know, and the eyes red, like fire, because he\'s all fire inside, and it shines out at his eyes.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
141,"['"" ""Go, go!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
142,"['"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

143,"[' Tulliver, peremptorily, beginning to feel rather uncomfortable at these free remarks on the personal appearance of a being powerful enough to create lawyers; ""shut up the book, and let\'s hear no more o\' such talk.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
144,"[' Go, go and see after your mother.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

145,"['"" Maggie shut up the book at once, with a sense of disgrace, but not being inclined to see after her mother, she compromised the matter by going into a dark corner behind her father\'s chair, and nursing her doll, toward which she had an occasional fit of fondness in Tom\'s absence, neglecting its toilet, but lavishing so many warm kisses on it that the waxen cheeks had a wasted, unhealthy appearance.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
146,"[' ""Did you ever hear the like on\'t?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
147,"['"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
148,"[' Tulliver, as Maggie retired.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

149,"[' It\'s the wonderful\'st thing""-3here he lowered his voice-3""as I picked the mother because she wasn\'t o\'er \'cute-3bein\' a good-looking woman too, an\' come of a rare family for managing; but I picked her from her sisters o\' purpose, \'cause she was a bit weak like; for I wasn\'t agoin\' to be told the rights o\' things by my own fireside.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

150,"["" But you see when a man's got brains himself, there's no knowing where they'll run to; an' a pleasant sort o' soft woman may go on breeding you stupid lads and 'cute wenches, till it's like as if the world was turned topsy-turvy.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
151,"["" It's an uncommon puzzlin' thing.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
152,"['"" Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
153,"[' Riley\'s gravity gave way, and he shook a little under the application of his pinch of snuff before he said,-3 ""But your lad\'s not stupid, is he?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

154,"["" But he's slow with his tongue, you see, and he reads but poorly, and can't abide the books, and spells all wrong, they tell me, an' as shy as can be wi' strangers, an' you never hear him say 'cute things like the little wench.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

155,"["" Not but what, if the world had been left as God made it, I could ha' seen my way, and held my own wi' the best of 'em; but things have got so twisted round and wrapped up i' unreasonable words, as aren't a bit like 'em, as I'm clean at fault, often an' often.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

156,"["" I know I should have tried to do so by a son of mine, if I'd had one, though, God knows, I haven't your ready money to play with, Tulliver; and I have a houseful of daughters into the bargain.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
157,"['"" ""I dare say, now, you know of a school as \'ud be just the thing for Tom,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
158,"[' Tulliver, not diverted from his purpose by any sympathy with Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
159,"["" Riley's deficiency of ready cash.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
160,[' Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
161,"[' Riley took a pinch of snuff, and kept Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

162,"[' Tulliver in suspense by a silence that seemed deliberative, before he said,-3 ""I know of a very fine chance for any one that\'s got the necessary money and that\'s what you have, Tulliver.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
163,"[' ""He\'s an Oxford man,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
164,"[' Riley, sententiously, shutting his mouth close, and looking at Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
165,[' Tulliver to observe the effect of this stimulating information.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
166,"[' ""Yes, and an M.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
167,['A.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
168,"[' The bishop, I understand, thinks very highly of him: why, it was the bishop who got him his present curacy.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
169,"['"" ""Ah?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
170,"['"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
171,"[' Tulliver, to whom one thing was as wonderful as another concerning these unfamiliar phenomena.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
172,"[' ""But what can he want wi\' Tom, then?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

173,"['"" ""Why, the fact is, he\'s fond of teaching, and wishes to keep up his studies, and a clergyman has but little opportunity for that in his parochial duties.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
174,"["" The boys would be quite of the family,-3the finest thing in the world for them; under Stelling's eye continually.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
175,"['"" ""But do you think they\'d give the poor lad twice o\' pudding?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
176,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
177,"[' Tulliver, who was now in her place again.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
178,"[' ""He\'s such a boy for pudding as never was; an\' a growing boy like that,-3it\'s dreadful to think o\' their stintin\' him.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
179,"['"" ""And what money \'ud he want?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
180,"['"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
181,"[' Tulliver, whose instinct told him that the services of this admirable M.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
182,['A.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
183,[' would bear a high price.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
184,"[' I know, on good authority, that one of the chief people at Oxford said, Stelling might get the highest honors if he chose.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
185,"["" I never thought o' paying so much as that.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
186,"['"" ""A good education, let me tell you, Tulliver,-3a good education is cheap at the money.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
187,"["" I'll write to him about it, if you like.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
188,"['"" Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
189,"[' Tulliver rubbed his knees, and looked at the carpet in a meditative manner.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
190,"["" It 'ud break my heart to send Tom where there's a housekeeper, an' I hope you won't think of it, Mr.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
191,[' Tulliver.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
192,"['"" ""You may set your mind at rest on that score, Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
193,"[' Tulliver,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
194,"[' Riley, ""for Stelling is married to as nice a little woman as any man need wish for a wife.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
195,"[' But I think he would have no objection to take your son; I think he would not, on my representation.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
196,"['"" ""I don\'t know what he could have against the lad,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
197,"[' Tulliver, with a slight touch of motherly indignation; ""a nice fresh- skinned lad as anybody need wish to see.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
198,"['"" ""But there\'s one thing I\'m thinking on,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
199,"[' Tulliver, turning his head on one side and looking at Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
200,"[' Riley, after a long perusal of the carpet.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
201,"["" And that isn't what I want for Tom.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

202,"["" I want him to know figures, and write like print, and see into things quick, and know what folks mean, and how to wrap things up in words as aren't actionable.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
203,"[' It\'s an uncommon fine thing, that is,"" concluded Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
204,"[' Tulliver, shaking his head, ""when you can let a man know what you think of him without paying for it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
205,"['"" ""Oh, my dear Tulliver,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
206,"[' Riley, ""you\'re quite under a mistake about the clergy; all the best schoolmasters are of the clergy.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
207,"["" You talk of figures, now; you have only to say to Stelling, 'I want my son to be a thorough arithmetician,' and you may leave the rest to him.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
208,"['"" Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
209,"[' Riley paused a moment, while Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
210,"[' Tulliver, some-what reassured as to clerical tutorship, was inwardly rehearsing to an imaginary Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
211,"[' Stelling the statement, ""I want my son to know \'rethmetic.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
212,"['"" ""You see, my dear Tulliver,"" Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
213,"[' Riley continued, ""when you get a thoroughly educated man, like Stelling, he\'s at no loss to take up any branch of instruction.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
214,"[' When a workman knows the use of his tools, he can make a door as well as a window.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
215,"['"" ""Ay, that\'s true,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
216,"[' Tulliver, almost convinced now that the clergy must be the best of schoolmasters.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

217,"["" I'll see Stelling's father-in-law, or drop him a line when I get back to Mudport, to say that you wish to place your boy with his son-in-law, and I dare say Stelling will write to you, and send you his terms.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
218,"['"" ""But there\'s no hurry, is there?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
219,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
220,"[' Tulliver; ""for I hope, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
221,"["" Tulliver, you won't let Tom begin at his new school before Midsummer.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
222,"["" He began at the 'cademy at the Lady-day quarter, and you see what good's come of it.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
223,"['"" ""Ay, ay, Bessy, never brew wi\' bad malt upo\' Michael-masday, else you\'ll have a poor tap,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
224,"[' Tulliver, winking and smiling at Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
225,"[' Riley, with the natural pride of a man who has a buxom wife conspicuously his inferior in intellect.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
226,"[' ""But it\'s true there\'s no hurry; you\'ve hit it there, Bessy.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
227,"['"" ""It might be as well not to defer the arrangement too long,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
228,"[' Riley, quietly, ""for Stelling may have propositions from other parties, and I know he would not take more than two or three boarders, if so many.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

229,"["" If I were you, I think I would enter on the subject with Stelling at once: there's no necessity for sending the boy before Midsummer, but I would be on the safe side, and make sure that nobody forestalls you.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
230,"['"" ""Ay, there\'s summat in that,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
231,[' Tulliver.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
232,"[' ""Ask Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
233,[' Riley; he knows.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
234,"['"" Maggie came round promptly in front of Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
235,"[' Riley, and said, ""How far is it, please, sir?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

236,"['"" ""Oh, a long, long way off,"" that gentleman answered, being of opinion that children, when they are not naughty, should always be spoken to jocosely.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
237,"[' ""You must borrow the seven-leagued boots to get to him.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
238,"['"" ""That\'s nonsense!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
239,"['"" said Maggie, tossing her head haughtily, and turning away, with the tears springing in her eyes.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
240,"[' But,"" added Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
241,"[' Tulliver, who had her own alarm awakened, ""is it so far off as I couldn\'t wash him and mend him?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
242,"['"" ""About fifteen miles; that\'s all,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
243,[' Riley.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
244,"["" Or-3Stelling is a hospitable, pleasant man-3he'd be glad to have you stay.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
245,"['"" ""But it\'s too far off for the linen, I doubt,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
246,"[' Tulliver, sadly.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

247,"["" We live from hand to mouth, most of us, with a small family of immediate desires; we do little else than snatch a morsel to satisfy the hungry brood, rarely thinking of seed-corn or the next year's crop.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
248,[' But he believed Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

249,"["" Stelling to be an excellent classic, for Gadsby had said so, and Gadsby's first cousin was an Oxford tutor; which was better ground for the belief even than his own immediate observation would have been, for though Mr.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

250,"[' Riley had received a tincture of the classics at the great Mudport Free School, and had a sense of understanding Latin generally, his comprehension of any particular Latin was not ready.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
251,[' Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

252,"[' Riley liked such men, quite apart from any money which might be diverted, through their good judgment, from less worthy pockets into his own; and it would be a satisfaction to him to say to Timpson on his return home, ""I\'ve secured a good pupil for your son-in-law.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
253,"['"" Timpson had a large family of daughters; Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

254,"["" Riley felt for him; besides, Louisa Timpson's face, with its light curls, had been a familiar object to him over the pew wainscot on a Sunday for nearly fifteen years; it was natural her husband should be a commendable tutor.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
255,[' Thus Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

256,"[' Riley, knowing no harm of Stelling to begin with, and wishing him well, so far as he had any wishes at all concerning him, had no sooner recommended him than he began to think with admiration of a man recommended on such high authority, and would soon have gathered so warm an interest on the subject, that if Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
257,"[' Tulliver had in the end declined to send Tom to Stelling, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
258,"[' Riley would have thought his ""friend of the old school"" a thoroughly pig-headed fellow.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

259,"[' Consider, too, that all the pleasant little dim ideas and complacencies-3of standing well with Timpson, of dispensing advice when he was asked for it, of impressing his friend Tulliver with additional respect, of saying something, and saying it emphatically, with other inappreciably minute ingredients that went along with the warm hearth and the brandy-and-water to make up Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
260,"["" Riley's consciousness on this occasion-3would have been a mere blank.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

261,"[' - IV TOM IS EXPECTED It was a heavy disappointment to Maggie that she was not allowed to go with her father in the gig when he went to fetch Tom home from the academy; but the morning was too wet, Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
262,"[' Tulliver said, for a little girl to go out in her best bonnet.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

263,"[' Maggie took the opposite view very strongly, and it was a direct consequence of this difference of opinion that when her mother was in the act of brushing out the reluctant black crop Maggie suddenly rushed from under her hands and dipped her head in a basin of water standing near, in the vindictive determination that there should be no more chance of curls that day.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
264,"["" I'll tell your aunt Glegg and your aunt Pullet when they come next week, and they'll never love you any more.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
265,"["" Folks 'ull think it's a judgment on me as I've got such a child,-3they'll think I've done summat wicked.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

266,"['"" Before this remonstrance was finished, Maggie was already out of hearing, making her way toward the great attic that run under the old high-pitched roof, shaking the water from her black locks as she ran, like a Skye terrier escaped from his bath.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

267,"[' Maggie tossed her hair back and ran downstairs, seized her bonnet without putting it on, peeped, and then dashed along the passage lest she should encounter her mother, and was quickly out in the yard, whirling round like a Pythoness, and singing as she whirled, ""Yap, Yap, Tom\'s coming home!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
268,"['"" while Yap danced and barked round her, as much as to say, if there was any noise wanted he was the dog for it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

269,"[' you\'ll make yourself giddy, an\' tumble down i\' the dirt,"" said Luke, the head miller, a tall, broad-shouldered man of forty, black-eyed and black-haired, subdued by a general mealiness, like an auricula.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
270,"[' Maggie paused in her whirling and said, staggering a little, ""Oh no, it doesn\'t make me giddy, Luke; may I go into the mill with you?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

271,"['"" Maggie loved to linger in the great spaces of the mill, and often came out with her black hair powdered to a soft whiteness that made her dark eyes flash out with new fire.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

272,"[' The resolute din, the unresting motion of the great stones, giving her a dim, delicious awe as at the presence of an uncontrollable force; the meal forever pouring, pouring; the fine white powder softening all surfaces, and making the very spidernets look like a faery lace-work; the sweet, pure scent of the meal,-3all helped to make Maggie feel that the mill was a little world apart from her outside every-day life.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

273,"["" I've not got any very pretty books that would be easy for you to read; but there's 'Pug's Tour of Europe,'-3that would tell you all about the different sorts of people in the world, and if you didn't understand the reading, the pictures would help you; they show the looks and ways of the people, and what they do.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
274,"["" There's fools enoo, an' rogues enoo, wi'out lookin' i' books for 'em.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

275,"['"" ""Oh, well,"" said Maggie, rather foiled by Luke\'s unexpectedly decided views about Dutchmen, ""perhaps you would like \'Animated Nature\' better; that\'s not Dutchmen, you know, but elephants and kangaroos, and the civet-cat, and the sunfish, and a bird sitting on its tail,-3I forget its name.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
276,"["" Shouldn't you like to know about them, Luke?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
277,"['"" ""Nay, Miss, I\'n got to keep count o\' the flour an\' corn; I can\'t do wi\' knowin\' so many things besides my work.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
278,"["" An' they're mostly lies, I think, what's printed i' the books: them printed sheets are, anyhow, as the men cry i' the streets.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
279,"['"" ""Why, you\'re like my brother Tom, Luke,"" said Maggie, wishing to turn the conversation agreeably; ""Tom\'s not fond of reading.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
280,"["" But I think Tom's clever, for all he doesn't like books; he makes beautiful whipcord and rabbit-pens.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
281,"['"" ""Ah,"" said Luke, ""but he\'ll be fine an\' vexed, as the rabbits are all dead.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
282,"['"" ""Dead!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
283,"['"" screamed Maggie, jumping up from her sliding seat on the corn.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
284,"[' ""Oh dear, Luke,"" said Maggie, in a piteous tone, while the big tears rolled down her cheek; ""Tom told me to take care of \'em, and I forgot.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
285,"["" He remembers nothing but his own inside-3an' I wish it'ud gripe him.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
286,"['"" ""Oh, Luke, Tom told me to be sure and remember the rabbits every day; but how could I, when they didn\'t come into my head, you know?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
287,"["" Master Tom 'ull know better nor buy such things another time.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

288,"[' Maggie actually forgot that she had any special cause of sadness this morning, as she stood on a chair to look at a remarkable series of pictures representing the Prodigal Son in the costume of Sir Charles Grandison, except that, as might have been expected from his defective moral character, he had not, like that accomplished hero, the taste and strength of mind to dispense with a wig.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

289,"[' But the indefinable weight the dead rabbits had left on her mind caused her to feel more than usual pity for the career of this weak young man, particularly when she looked at the picture where he leaned against a tree with a flaccid appearance, his knee- breeches unbuttoned and his wig awry, while the swine apparently of some foreign breed, seemed to insult him by their good spirits over their feast of husks.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
290,"[' ""For he was very sorry, you know, and wouldn\'t do wrong again.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
291,"['"" ""Eh, Miss,"" said Luke, ""he\'d be no great shakes, I doubt, let\'s feyther do what he would for him.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
292,"['"" That was a painful thought to Maggie, and she wished much that the subsequent history of the young man had not been left a blank.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

293,"["" - V TOM COMES HOME Tom was to arrive early in the afternoon, and there was another fluttering heart besides Maggie's when it was late enough for the sound of the gig-wheels to be expected; for if Mrs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
294,"[' Tulliver had a strong feeling, it was fondness for her boy.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

295,"[' At last the sound came,-3 that quick light bowling of the gig-wheels,-3and in spite of the wind, which was blowing the clouds about, and was not likely to respect Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

296,"["" Tulliver's curls and cap-strings, she came outside the door, and even held her hand on Maggie's offending head, forgetting all the griefs of the morning.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
297,"["" he's got never a collar on; it's been lost on the road, I'll be bound, and spoilt the set.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
298,"['"" Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

299,"[' Tulliver stood with her arms open; Maggie jumped first on one leg and then on the other; while Tom descended from the gig, and said, with masculine reticence as to the tender emotions, ""Hallo!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

300,"["" He was one of those lads that grow everywhere in England, and at twelve or thirteen years of age look as much alike as goslings,-3a lad with light-brown hair, cheeks of cream and roses, full lips, indeterminate nose and eyebrows,-3a physiognomy in which it seems impossible to discern anything but the generic character to boyhood; as different as possible from poor Maggie's phiz, which Nature seemed to have moulded and colored with the most decided intention.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

301,"[' ""Maggie,"" said Tom, confidentially, taking her into a corner, as soon as his mother was gone out to examine his box and the warm parlor had taken off the chill he had felt from the long drive, ""you don\'t know what I\'ve got in my pockets,"" nodding his head up and down as a means of rousing her sense of mystery.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
302,[' Is it marls (marbles) or cobnuts?'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
303,"['"" Maggie\'s heart sank a little, because Tom always said it was ""no good"" playing with her at those games, she played so badly.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
304,"[' ""I can see nothing but a bit of yellow.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
305,"['"" ""Why, it\'s-3a-3new-3guess, Maggie!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
306,"['"" ""Oh, I can\'t guess, Tom,"" said Maggie, impatiently.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
307,"[' ""Don\'t be a spitfire, else I won\'t tell you,"" said Tom, thrusting his hand back into his pocket and looking determined.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
308,"[' ""No, Tom,"" said Maggie, imploringly, laying hold of the arm that was held stiffly in the pocket.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
309,[' Please be good to me.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
310,"['"" Tom\'s arm slowly relaxed, and he said, ""Well, then, it\'s a new fish- line-3two new uns,-3one for you, Maggie, all to yourself.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
311,"["" And you shall catch your own fish, Maggie and put the worms on, and everything; won't it be fun?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

312,"['"" Maggie\'s answer was to throw her arms round Tom\'s neck and hug him, and hold her cheek against his without speaking, while he slowly unwound some of the line, saying, after a pause,-3 ""Wasn\'t I a good brother, now, to buy you a line all to yourself?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
313,"["" You know, I needn't have bought it, if I hadn't liked.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
314,"['"" ""Yes, very, very good-3I do love you, Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
315,"['"" Tom had put the line back in his pocket, and was looking at the hooks one by one, before he spoke again.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

316,"[' no,"" said Tom, putting up the hooks again, taking out a large pocket-knife, and slowly opening the largest blade, which he looked at meditatively as he rubbed his finger along it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

317,"[' Then he added,-3 ""I gave Spouncer a black eye, I know; that\'s what he got by wanting to leather me; I wasn\'t going to go halves because anybody leathered me.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
318,"['"" ""Oh, how brave you are, Tom!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
319,"["" If there came a lion roaring at me, I think you'd fight him, wouldn't you, Tom?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
320,"['"" ""How can a lion come roaring at you, you silly thing?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
321,[' I can show it you in the book where I read it.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
322,"['"" ""Well, I should get a gun and shoot him.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

323,"['"" ""But if you hadn\'t got a gun,-3we might have gone out, you know, not thinking, just as we go fishing; and then a great lion might run toward us roaring, and we couldn\'t get away from him.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
324,"["" What's the use of talking?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
325,"['"" ""But I like to fancy how it would be,"" said Maggie, following him.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
326,"[' ""Just think what you would do, Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
327,"['"" ""Oh, don\'t bother, Maggie!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

328,"["" She dared not tell the sad truth at once, but she walked after Tom in trembling silence as he went out, thinking how she could tell him the news so as to soften at once his sorrow and his anger; for Maggie dreaded Tom's anger of all things; it was quite a different anger from her own.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
329,"["" I'll ask mother to give it you.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
330,"['"" ""What for?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
331,"['"" said Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
332,"["" I don't want any more.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
333,"['"" ""Oh, but, Tom, they\'re all dead.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
334,"['"" Tom stopped immediately in his walk and turned round toward Maggie.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
335,"[' ""Yes, but I forgot-3and I couldn\'t help it, indeed, Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
336,"[' I\'m so very sorry,"" said Maggie, while the tears rushed fast.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
337,"[' ""You\'re a naughty girl,"" said Tom, severely, ""and I\'m sorry I bought you the fish-line.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
338,"["" I don't love you.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
339,"['"" ""Oh, Tom, it\'s very cruel,"" sobbed Maggie.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
340,"[' ""I\'d forgive you, if you forgot anything-3I wouldn\'t mind what you did-3I\'d forgive you and love you.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
341,"['"" ""Yes, you\'re silly; but I never do forget things, I don\'t.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

342,"['"" ""Oh, please forgive me, Tom; my heart will break,"" said Maggie, shaking with sobs, clinging to Tom\'s arm, and laying her wet cheek on his shoulder.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
343,"[' Tom shook her off, and stopped again, saying in a peremptory tone, ""Now, Maggie, you just listen.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

344,"[' ""Didn\'t I think about your fish-line all this quarter, and mean to buy it, and saved my money o\' purpose, and wouldn\'t go halves in the toffee, and Spouncer fought me because I wouldn\'t?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
345,"['"" ""Ye-ye-es-3and I-3lo-lo-love you so, Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
346,"['"" ""But you\'re a naughty girl.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

347,"["" Last holidays you licked the paint off my lozenge-box, and the holidays before that you let the boat drag my fish-line down when I'd set you to watch it, and you pushed your head through my kite, all for nothing.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
348,"['"" ""But I didn\'t mean,"" said Maggie; ""I couldn\'t help it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
349,"['"" ""Yes, you could,"" said Tom, ""if you\'d minded what you were doing.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
350,"["" And you're a naughty girl, and you sha'n't go fishing with me to-morrow.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
351,"['"" With this terrible conclusion, Tom ran away from Maggie toward the mill, meaning to greet Luke there, and complain to him of Harry.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

352,"[' Maggie stood motionless, except from her sobs, for a minute or two; then she turned round and ran into the house, and up to her attic, where she sat on the floor and laid her head against the worm- eaten shelf, with a crushing sense of misery.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
353,"[' Tom was come home, and she had thought how happy she should be; and now he was cruel to her.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
354,"[' Maggie soon thought she had been hours in the attic, and it must be tea-time, and they were all having their tea, and not thinking of her.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

355,"["" Thus Maggie thought in the pride of her heart, as she crept behind the tub; but presently she began to cry again at the idea that they didn't mind her being there.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

356,"["" Tom had been too much interested in his talk with Luke, in going the round of the premises, walking in and out where he pleased, and whittling sticks without any particular reason,-3except that he didn't whittle sticks at school,-3to think of Maggie and the effect his anger had produced on her.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
357,"[' But when he had been called in to tea, his father said, ""Why, where\'s the little wench?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
358,"['"" and Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
359,"[' Tulliver, almost at the same moment, said, ""Where\'s your little sister?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
360,"['""-3both of them having supposed that Maggie and Tom had been together all the afternoon.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
361,"[' ""I don\'t know,"" said Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
362,"[' He didn\'t want to ""tell"" of Maggie, though he was angry with her; for Tom Tulliver was a lad of honor.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
363,"[' ""She\'d been thinking o\' nothing but your coming home.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
364,"['"" ""I haven\'t seen her this two hours,"" says Tom, commencing on the plumcake.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
365,"[' ""Goodness heart; she\'s got drownded!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
366,"['"" exclaimed Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
367,"[' Tulliver, rising from her seat and running to the window.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
368,"[' ""I think she\'s in the house.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
369,"['"" ""Perhaps up in that attic,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
370,"[' Tulliver, ""a-singing and talking to herself, and forgetting all about meal-times.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
371,"['"" ""You go and fetch her down, Tom,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

372,"[' Tulliver, rather sharply,-3his perspicacity or his fatherly fondness for Maggie making him suspect that the lad had been hard upon ""the little un,"" else she would never have left his side.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
373,"["" Else I'll let you know better.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
374,"['"" Tom never disobeyed his father, for Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

375,"["" Tulliver was a peremptory man, and, as he said, would never let anybody get hold of his whip-hand; but he went out rather sullenly, carrying his piece of plumcake, and not intending to reprieve Maggie's punishment, which was no more than she deserved.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

376,"["" It was Tom's step, then, that Maggie heard on the stairs, when her need of love had triumphed over her pride, and she was going down with her swollen eyes and dishevelled hair to beg for pity.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
377,"[' At least her father would stroke her head and say, ""Never mind, my wench.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

378,"['"" It is a wonderful subduer, this need of love,-3this hunger of the heart,-3as peremptory as that other hunger by which Nature forces us to submit to the yoke, and change the face of the world.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
379,"[' He only stood still at the top of the stairs and said, ""Maggie, you\'re to come down.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

380,"['"" But she rushed to him and clung round his neck, sobbing, ""Oh, Tom, please forgive me-3I can\'t bear it-3I will always be good-3always remember things-3do love me-3please, dear Tom!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
381,"['"" We learn to restrain ourselves as we get older.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

382,"["" Maggie and Tom were still very much like young animals, and so she could rub her cheek against his, and kiss his ear in a random sobbing way; and there were tender fibres in the lad that had been used to answer to Maggie's fondling, so that he behaved with a weakness quite inconsistent with his resolution to punish her as much as she deserved.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
383,"[' ""Come along, Magsie, and have tea,"" said Tom at last, when there was no more cake except what was down-stairs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

384,"[' So ended the sorrows of this day, and the next morning Maggie was trotting with her own fishing-rod in one hand and a handle of the basket in the other, stepping always, by a peculiar gift, in the muddiest places, and looking darkly radiant from under her beaver- bonnet because Tom was good to her.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

385,"[' Maggie thought this sort of knowledge was very wonderful,-3much more difficult than remembering what was in the books; and she was rather in awe of Tom\'s superiority, for he was the only person who called her knowledge ""stuff,"" and did not feel surprised at her cleverness.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

386,"["" Tom, indeed, was of opinion that Maggie was a silly little thing; all girls were silly,-3they couldn't throw a stone so as to hit anything, couldn't do anything with a pocket-knife, and were frightened at frogs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

387,"["" The sight of the old favorite spot always heightened Tom's good humor, and he spoke to Maggie in the most amicable whispers, as he opened the precious basket and prepared their tackle.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
388,"["" Maggie thought it probable that the small fish would come to her hook, and the large ones to Tom's.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
389,"[' But she had forgotten all about the fish, and was looking dreamily at the glassy water, when Tom said, in a loud whisper, ""Look, look, Maggie!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
390,"['"" and came running to prevent her from snatching her line away.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

391,"[' Maggie was frightened lest she had been doing something wrong, as usual, but presently Tom drew out her line and brought a large tench bouncing on the grass.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
392,[' She never knew she had a bite till Tom told her; but she liked fishing very much.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

393,"[' They trotted along and sat down together, with no thought that life would ever change much for them; they would only get bigger and not go to school, and it would always be like the holidays; they would always live together and be fond of each other.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

394,"[' And the mill with its booming; the great chestnut-tree under which they played at houses; their own little river, the Ripple, where the banks seemed like home, and Tom was always seeing the water-rats, while Maggie gathered the purple plumy tops of the reeds, which she forgot and dropped afterward; above all, the great Floss, along which they wandered with a sense of travel, to see the rushing spring-tide, the awful Eagre, come up like a hungry monster, or to see the Great Ash which had once wailed and groaned like a man, these things would always be just the same to them.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
395,"[' - VI THE AUNTS AND UNCLES ARE COMING It was Easter week, and Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
396,"["" Tulliver's cheesecakes were more exquisitely light than usual.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

397,"[' ""A puff o\' wind \'ud make \'em blow about like feathers,"" Kezia the housemaid said, feeling proud to live under a mistress who could make such pastry; so that no season or circumstances could have been more propitious for a family party, even if it had not been advisable to consult sister Glegg and sister Pullet about Tom\'s going to school.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
398,"[' ""I\'d as lief not invite sister Deane this time,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
399,"[' Tulliver, ""for she\'s as jealous and having as can be, and\'s allays trying to make the worst o\' my poor children to their aunts and uncles.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
400,"['"" ""Yes, yes,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
401,"[' Tulliver, ""ask her to come.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
402,[' My children need be beholding to nobody.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
403,"['"" ""That\'s what you allays say, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
404,"["" Tulliver; but I'm sure there's nobody o' your side, neither aunt nor uncle, to leave 'em so much as a five-pound note for a leggicy.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

405,"["" And there's sister Glegg, and sister Pullet too, saving money unknown, for they put by all their own interest and butter-money too; their husbands buy 'em everything.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
406,"['"" Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
407,"[' Tulliver was a mild woman, but even a sheep will face about a little when she has lambs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
408,"["" And your sister Deane won't get 'em to leave all to one, I reckon, and make the country cry shame on 'em when they are dead?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
409,"['"" ""I don\'t know what she won\'t get \'em to do,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
410,"[' Tulliver, ""for my children are so awk\'ard wi\' their aunts and uncles.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
411,"["" Maggie's ten times naughtier when they come than she is other days, and Tom doesn't like 'em, bless him!""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
412,"[""-3though it's more nat'ral in a boy than a gell.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

413,"["" I can't help loving the child as if she was my own; and I'm sure she's more like my child than sister Deane's, for she'd allays a very poor color for one of our family, sister Deane had.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
414,"['"" ""Well, well, if you\'re fond o\' the child, ask her father and mother to bring her with \'em.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
415,"["" And won't you ask their aunt and uncle Moss too, and some o' their children?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
416,"['"" ""Oh, dear, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

417,"["" Tulliver, why, there'd be eight people besides the children, and I must put two more leaves i' the table, besides reaching down more o' the dinner-service; and you know as well as I do as my sisters and your sister don't suit well together.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
418,"['"" ""Well, well, do as you like, Bessy,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
419,"[' Tulliver, taking up his hat and walking out to the mill.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
420,[' Few wives were more submissive than Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

421,"[' Tulliver on all points unconnected with her family relations; but she had been a Miss Dodson, and the Dodsons were a very respectable family indeed,-3as much looked up to as any in their own parish, or the next to it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

422,"[' She was thankful to have been a Dodson, and to have one child who took after her own family, at least in his features and complexion, in liking salt and in eating beans, which a Tulliver never did.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

423,"[' In other respects the true Dodson was partly latent in Tom, and he was as far from appreciating his ""kin"" on the mother\'s side as Maggie herself, generally absconding for the day with a large supply of the most portable food, when he received timely warning that his aunts and uncles were coming,-3a moral symptom from which his aunt Glegg deduced the gloomiest views of his future.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

424,"[' Tom and Maggie made several inroads into the kitchen, and, like other marauders, were induced to keep aloof for a time only by being allowed to carry away a sufficient load of booty.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
425,"[' ""Tom,"" said Maggie, as they sat on the boughs of the elder-tree, eating their jam-puffs, ""shall you run away to-morrow?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
426,"['"" ""No,"" said Tom, slowly, when he had finished his puff, and was eying the third, which was to be divided between them,-3""no, I sha\'n\'t.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
427,"['"" ""Why, Tom?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
428,"["" Because Lucy's coming?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
429,"['"" ""No,"" said Tom, opening his pocket-knife and holding it over the puff, with his head on one side in a dubitative manner.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
430,"["" She's only a girl,-3she can't play at bandy.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
431,"['"" ""Is it the tipsy-cake, then?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
432,"['"" said Maggie, exerting her hypothetic powers, while she leaned forward toward Tom with her eyes fixed on the hovering knife.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
433,"[' At last he said,-3 ""Shut your eyes, Maggie.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
434,"['"" ""What for?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
435,"['"" ""You never mind what for.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
436,"[' ""Now, which\'ll you have, Maggie,-3right hand or left?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
437,"['"" ""I\'ll have that with the jam run out,"" said Maggie, keeping her eyes shut to please Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
438,[' Ha-a-a!'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
439,"['"" said Tom, in a tone of exasperation, as Maggie peeped.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
440,"[' ""You keep your eyes shut, now, else you sha\'n\'t have any.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

441,"['"" Maggie\'s power of sacrifice did not extend so far; indeed, I fear she cared less that Tom should enjoy the utmost possible amount of puff, than that he should be pleased with her for giving him the best bit.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
442,"[' So she shut her eyes quite close, till Tom told her to ""say which,"" and then she said, ""Left hand.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
443,"['"" ""You\'ve got it,"" said Tom, in rather a bitter tone.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
444,[' the bit with the jam run out?'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
445,"['"" ""No; here, take it,"" said Tom, firmly, handing, decidedly the best piece to Maggie.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
446,"[' But Tom had finished first, and had to look on while Maggie ate her last morsel or two, feeling in himself a capacity for more.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
447,"["" Maggie didn't know Tom was looking at her; she was seesawing on the elder- bough, lost to almost everything but a vague sense of jam and idleness.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
448,"[' ""Oh, you greedy thing!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
449,"['"" said Tom, when she had swallowed the last morsel.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
450,"[' You might have thought of it without, when you knew I gave you the best bit.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
451,"['"" ""But I wanted you to have it; you know I did,"" said Maggie, in an injured tone.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
452,"["" But if I go halves, I'll go 'em fair; only I wouldn't be a greedy.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
453,"['"" With this cutting innuendo, Tom jumped down from his bough, and threw a stone with a ""hoigh!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

454,"['"" as a friendly attention to Yap, who had also been looking on while the eatables vanished, with an agitation of his ears and feelings which could hardly have been without bitterness.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

455,"[' The tears flowed so plentifully that Maggie saw nothing around her for the next ten minutes; but by that time resentment began to give way to the desire of reconciliation, and she jumped from her bough to look for Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
456,"[' He was no longer in the paddock behind the rickyard; where was he likely to be gone, and Yap with him?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

457,"[' There was Tom; but her heart sank again as she saw how far off he was on his way to the great river, and that he had another companion besides Yap,-3naughty Bob Jakin, whose official, if not natural, function of frightening the birds was just now at a standstill.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

458,"["" Maggie felt sure that Bob was wicked, without very distinctly knowing why; unless it was because Bob's mother was a dreadfully large fat woman, who lived at a queer round house down the river; and once, when Maggie and Tom had wandered thither, there rushed out a brindled dog that wouldn't stop barking; and when Bob's mother came out after it, and screamed above the barking to tell them not to be frightened, Maggie thought she was scolding them fiercely, and her heart beat with terror.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

459,"["" Maggie thought it very likely that the round house had snakes on the floor, and bats in the bedroom; for she had seen Bob take off his cap to show Tom a little snake that was inside it, and another time he had a handful of young bats: altogether, he was an irregular character, perhaps even slightly diabolical, judging from his intimacy with snakes and bats; and to crown all, when Tom had Bob for a companion, he didn't mind about Maggie, and would never let her go with him.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

460,"[' Such qualities in an inferior, who could always be treated with authority in spite of his superior knowingness, had necessarily a fatal fascination for Tom; and every holiday-time Maggie was sure to have days of grief because he had gone off with Bob.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
461,[' Well!'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

462,"[' there was no hope for it; he was gone now, and Maggie could think of no comfort but to sit down by the hollow, or wander by the hedgerow, and fancy it was all different, refashioning her little world into just what she should like it to be.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

463,"[' Meanwhile Tom, forgetting all about Maggie and the sting of reproach which he had left in her heart, was hurrying along with Bob, whom he had met accidentally, to the scene of a great rat- catching in a neighboring barn.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

464,"[' ""I know the chap as owns the ferrets,"" said Bob, in a hoarse treble voice, as he shuffled along, keeping his blue eyes fixed on the river, like an amphibious animal who foresaw occasion for darting in.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
465,"["" I see it myself, I did, at the rot-catchin' i' your feyther's barn.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

466,"['"" Yap, feeling the withering influence of this scorn, tucked his tail in and shrank close to Tom\'s leg, who felt a little hurt for him, but had not the superhuman courage to seem behindhand with Bob in contempt for a dog who made so poor a figure.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
467,"["" I'll have regular good dogs for rats and everything, when I've done school.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

468,"['"" ""Hev ferrets, Measter Tom,"" said Bob, eagerly,-3""them white ferrets wi\' pink eyes; Lors, you might catch your own rots, an\' you might put a rot in a cage wi\' a ferret, an\' see \'em fight, you might.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

469,"[' That\'s what I\'d do, I know, an\' it \'ud be better fun a\'most nor seein\' two chaps fight,-3if it wasn\'t them chaps as sold cakes an\' oranges at the Fair, as the things flew out o\' their baskets, an\' some o\' the cakes was smashed-3But they tasted just as good,"" added Bob, by way of note or addendum, after a moment\'s pause.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
470,"[' ""But, I say, Bob,"" said Tom, in a tone of deliberation, ""ferrets are nasty biting things,-3they\'ll bite a fellow without being set on.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
471,"['"" ""Lors!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
472,"[' there he is,"" said Tom, clapping his hands, as the little black snout made its arrowy course to the opposite bank.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
473,[' you coward!'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
474,"['"" said Tom, and kicked him over, feeling humiliated as a sportsman to possess so poor-spirited an animal.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
475,"[' ""Why, last \'ear, the meadows was all one sheet o\' water, they was.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

476,"['"" ""Ay, but,"" said Tom, whose mind was prone to see an opposition between statements that were really accordant,-3""but there was a big flood once, when the Round Pool was made.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
477,"[' And the sheep and cows all drowned, and the boats went all over the fields ever such a way.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
478,"['"" ""I don\'t care about a flood comin\',"" said Bob; ""I don\'t mind the water, no more nor the land.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
479,"["" I'd swim, I would.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
480,"['"" ""Ah, but if you got nothing to eat for ever so long?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
481,"['"" said Tom, his imagination becoming quite active under the stimulus of that dread.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
482,"[' ""I\'d divide fair to begin with, and then we\'d see who\'d win.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
483,"['"" ""I\'ve got a halfpenny o\' my own,"" said Bob, proudly, coming out of the water and tossing his halfpenny in the air.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

484,"["" The pain from Yap's teeth, instead of surprising Bob into a relaxation of his hold, gave it a fiercer tenacity, and with a new exertion of his force he pushed Tom backward and got uppermost.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

485,"[' But now Yap, who could get no sufficient purchase before, set his teeth in a new place, so that Bob, harassed in this way, let go his hold of Tom, and, almost throttling Yap, flung him into the river.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

486,"[' But Tom was not to be provoked into turning round, and Bob\'s voice began to falter a little as he said,-3 ""An\' I\'n gi\'en you everything, an\' showed you everything, an\' niver wanted nothin\' from you.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

509,"["" Glegg chose to wear her bonnet in the house to-day,-3united and tilted slightly, of course-3a frequent practice of hers when she was on a visit, and happened to be in a severe humor: she didn't know what draughts there might be in strange houses.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

511,"["" Glegg's slate-colored silk gown must have been; but from certain constellations of small yellow spots upon it, and a mouldy odor about it suggestive of a damp clothes-chest, it was probable that it belonged to a stratum of garments just old enough to have come recently into wear.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

515,"[' ""It used to be the way in our family for one to be as early as another,-3I\'m sure it was so in my poor father\'s time,-3and not for one sister to sit half an hour before the others came.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
516,"["" But if the ways o' the family are altered, it sha'n't be my fault; I'll never be the one to come into a house when all the rest are going away.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

517,"["" But if you'll take my advice, Bessy, you'll put the dinner forrard a bit, sooner than put it back, because folks are late as ought to ha' known better.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

526,"['"" ""Yes, yes, I know how it is with husbands,-3they\'re for putting everything off; they\'ll put the dinner off till after tea, if they\'ve got wives as are weak enough to give in to such work; but it\'s a pity for you, Bessy, as you haven\'t got more strength o\' mind.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

550,"[' As the tears subside a little, and with her head leaning backward at the angle that will not injure her bonnet, she endures that terrible moment when grief, which has made all things else a weariness, has itself become weary; she looks down pensively at her bracelets, and adjusts their clasps with that pretty studied fortuity which would be gratifying to her mind if it were once more in a calm and healthy state.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

560,"['"" ""Well, Sophy, it\'s a mercy she\'s gone, then, whoever she may be,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

569,"['"" ""Sophy,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

588,"["" Glegg's sisterly compassion: Bessy went far too well dressed, considering; and she was too proud to dress her child in the good clothing her sister Glegg gave her from the primeval strata of her wardrobe; it was a sin and a shame to buy anything to dress that child, if it wasn't a pair of shoes.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

597,"[' Tulliver\'s absence, that the Tulliver blood did not mix well with the Dodson blood; that, in fact, poor Bessy\'s children were Tullivers, and that Tom, notwithstanding he had the Dodson complexion, was likely to be as ""contrairy"" as his father.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

608,"["" Maggie had thrown her bonnet off very carelessly, and coming in with her hair rough as well as out of curl, rushed at once to Lucy, who was standing by her mother's knee.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

609,"[' Lucy put up the neatest little rosebud mouth to be kissed; everything about her was neat,-3her little round neck, with the row of coral beads; her little straight nose, not at all snubby; her little clear eyebrows, rather darker than her curls, to match hazel eyes, which looked up with shy pleasure at Maggie, taller by the head, though scarcely a year older.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

610,"["" She was fond of fancying a world where the people never got any larger than children of their own age, and she made the queen of it just like Lucy, with a little crown on her head, and a little sceptre in her hand-3only the queen was Maggie herself in Lucy's form.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
611,"[' Oh, kiss her, Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

612,"['"" Tom, too, had come up to Lucy, but he was not going to kiss her-3 no; he came up to her with Maggie, because it seemed easier, on the whole, than saying, ""How do you do?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
613,"['"" to all those aunts and uncles.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
614,"[' ""Do little boys and gells come into a room without taking notice of their uncles and aunts?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
615,"["" That wasn't the way when I was a little gell.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
616,"['"" ""Go and speak to your aunts and uncles, my dears,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
617,"[' Tulliver, looking anxious and melancholy.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
618,"["" And I hope you're good children, are you?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

619,"['"" said Aunt Glegg, in the same loud, emphatic way, as she took their hands, hurting them with her large rings, and kissing their cheeks much against their desire.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
620,[' Look at me now.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
621,"['"" Tom declined that pleasure apparently, for he tried to draw his hand away.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
622,"[' ""Put your hair behind your ears, Maggie, and keep your frock on your shoulder.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

623,"['"" Aunt Glegg always spoke to them in this loud, emphatic way, as if she considered them deaf, or perhaps rather idiotic; it was a means, she thought, of making them feel that they were accountable creatures, and might be a salutary check on naughty tendencies.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
624,"["" Don't you think so, sister Deane?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
625,"['"" ""I can\'t say, I\'m sure, sister,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
626,"[' Deane, shutting her lips close again, and looking at Maggie with a critical eye.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
627,"["" But it 'ud be as well if Bessy 'ud have the child's hair cut, so as it 'ud lie smooth.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

628,"['"" A dreadful resolve was gathering in Maggie\'s breast, but it was arrested by the desire to know from her aunt Deane whether she would leave Lucy behind.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
629,"[' ""You wouldn\'t like to stay behind without mother, should you, Lucy?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
630,"['"" ""Yes, please, mother,"" said Lucy, timidly, blushing very pink all over her little neck.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
631,"[' Let her stay, Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
632,"[' Deane, let her stay,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

633,"[' Deane, a large but alert-looking man, with a type of physique to be seen in all ranks of English society,-3bald crown, red whiskers, full forehead, and general solidity without heaviness.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
634,[' No man was thought more highly of in St.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
635,"["" Ogg's than Mr.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

636,"[' Deane; and some persons were even of opinion that Miss Susan Dodson, who was once held to have made the worst match of all the Dodson sisters, might one day ride in a better carriage, and live in a better house, even than her sister Pullet.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
637,"[' There was no knowing where a man would stop, who had got his foot into a great mill-owning, shipowning business like that of Guest & Co.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
638,"[', with a banking concern attached.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
639,[' And Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

640,"[' Deane, as her intimate female friends observed, was proud and ""having"" enough; she wouldn\'t let her husband stand still in the world for want of spurring.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
641,"[' ""Maggie,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

642,"[' Tulliver, beckoning Maggie to her, and whispering in her ear, as soon as this point of Lucy\'s staying was settled, ""go and get your hair brushed, do, for shame.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
643,"[' I told you not to come in without going to Martha first, you know I did.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
644,"['"" ""Tom come out with me,"" whispered Maggie, pulling his sleeve as she passed him; and Tom followed willingly enough.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
645,"[' ""There\'s something I want to do before dinner.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
646,"['"" ""There\'s no time to play at anything before dinner,"" said Tom, whose imagination was impatient of any intermediate prospect.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
647,"[' ""Oh yes, there is time for this; do come, Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
648,"['"" Tom followed Maggie upstairs into her mother\'s room, and saw her go at once to a drawer, from which she took out a large pair of scissors.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
649,"[' ""What are they for, Maggie?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
650,"['"" said Tom, feeling his curiosity awakened.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
651,"["" went the great scissors again while Tom was speaking, and he couldn't help feeling it was rather good fun; Maggie would look so queer.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
652,"[' ""Here, Tom, cut it behind for me,"" said Maggie, excited by her own daring, and anxious to finish the deed.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
653,"[' ""You\'ll catch it, you know,"" said Tom, nodding his head in an admonitory manner, and hesitating a little as he took the scissors.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
654,"[' ""Never mind, make haste!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
655,"['"" said Maggie, giving a little stamp with her foot.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
656,"[' ""Oh, Maggie,"" said Tom, jumping round her, and slapping his knees as he laughed, ""Oh, my buttons!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

657,"["" She had thought beforehand chiefly at her own deliverance from her teasing hair and teasing remarks about it, and something also of the triumph she should have over her mother and her aunts by this very decided course of action; she didn't want her hair to look pretty,-3that was out of the question,-3she only wanted people to think her a clever little girl, and not to find fault with her.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
658,"["" She looked in the glass, and still Tom laughed and clapped his hands, and Maggie's cheeks began to pale, and her lips to tremble a little.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
659,"[' ""Oh, Maggie, you\'ll have to go down to dinner directly,"" said Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
660,"[' ""Oh, my!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
661,"['"" ""Don\'t laugh at me, Tom,"" said Maggie, in a passionate tone, with an outburst of angry tears, stamping, and giving him a push.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
662,[' I shall go down: I can smell the dinner going in.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
663,"['"" He hurried downstairs and left poor Maggie to that bitter sense of the irrevocable which was almost an every-day experience of her small soul.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

664,"[' She could see clearly enough, now the thing was done, that it was very foolish, and that she should have to hear and think more about her hair than ever; for Maggie rushed to her deeds with passionate impulse, and then saw not only their consequences, but what would have happened if they had not been done, with all the detail and exaggerated circumstance of an active imagination.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

665,"[' Tom never did the same sort of foolish things as Maggie, having a wonderful instinctive discernment of what would turn to his advantage or disadvantage; and so it happened, that though he was much more wilful and inflexible than Maggie, his mother hardly ever called him naughty.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
666,"[' But if Tom did make a mistake of that sort, he espoused it, and stood by it: he ""didn\'t mind.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
667,"['"" If he broke the lash of his father\'s gigwhip by lashing the gate, he couldn\'t help it,-3the whip shouldn\'t have got caught in the hinge.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

668,"[' But Maggie, as she stood crying before the glass, felt it impossible that she should go down to dinner and endure the severe eyes and severe words of her aunts, while Tom and Lucy, and Martha, who waited at table, and perhaps her father and her uncles, would laugh at her; for if Tom had laughed at her, of course every one else would; and if she had only let her hair alone, she could have sat with Tom and Lucy, and had the apricot pudding and the custard!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

669,"[' Is there any one who can recover the experience of his childhood, not merely with a memory of what he did and what happened to him, of what he liked and disliked when he was in frock and trousers, but with an intimate penetration, a revived consciousness of what he felt then, when it was so long from one Midsummer to another; what he felt when his school fellows shut him out of their game because he would pitch the ball wrong out of mere wilfulness; or on a rainy day in the holidays, when he didn\'t know how to amuse himself, and fell from idleness into mischief, from mischief into defiance, and from defiance into sulkiness; or when his mother absolutely refused to let him have a tailed coat that ""half,"" although every other boy of his age had gone into tails already?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
670,"[' ""Miss Maggie, you\'re to come down this minute,"" said Kezia, entering the room hurriedly.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
671,"[' ""Go away!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

672,"['"" ""But I tell you you\'re to come down, Miss, this minute; your mother says so,"" said Kezia, going up to Maggie and taking her by the hand to raise her from the floor.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
673,"[' ""Get away, Kezia; I don\'t want any dinner,"" said Maggie, resisting Kezia\'s arm.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
674,"[' ""Maggie, you little silly,"" said Tom, peeping into the room ten minutes after, ""why don\'t you come and have your dinner?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

675,"[' He was not inclined to cry, and did not feel that Maggie\'s grief spoiled his prospect of the sweets; but he went and put his head near her, and said in a lower, comforting tone,-3 ""Won\'t you come, then, Magsie?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
676,"["" Shall I bring you a bit o' pudding when I've had mine, and a custard and things?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
677,"['"" ""Ye-e-es,"" said Maggie, beginning to feel life a little more tolerable.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
678,"[' ""Very well,"" said Tom, going away.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
679,"[' But he turned again at the door and said, ""But you\'d better come, you know.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
680,"["" There's the dessert,-3nuts, you know, and cowslip wine.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
681,"['"" Maggie\'s tears had ceased, and she looked reflective as Tom left her.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
682,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

683,"[' Tulliver gave a little scream as she saw her, and felt such a ""turn"" that she dropped the large gravy-spoon into the dish, with the most serious results to the table-cloth.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
684,"["" For Kezia had not betrayed the reason of Maggie's refusal to come down, not liking to give her mistress a shock in the moment of carving, and Mrs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

685,"[' Tulliver thought there was nothing worse in question than a fit of perverseness, which was inflicting its own punishment by depriving Maggie of half her dinner.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
686,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

687,"[' Tulliver\'s scream made all eyes turn towards the same point as her own, and Maggie\'s cheeks and ears began to burn, while uncle Glegg, a kind-looking, white-haired old gentleman, said,-3 ""Heyday!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
688,"["" Is it some little gell you've picked up in the road, Kezia?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
689,"['"" ""Why, she\'s gone and cut her hair herself,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
690,[' Tulliver in an undertone to Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
691,"[' Deane, laughing with much enjoyment.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
692,[' Did you ever know such a little hussy as it is?'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

693,"['"" ""Why, little miss, you\'ve made yourself look very funny,"" said Uncle Pullet, and perhaps he never in his life made an observation which was felt to be so lacerating.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
694,"[' ""Little gells as cut their own hair should be whipped and fed on bread and water,-3not come and sit down with their aunts and uncles.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

695,"['"" ""Ay, ay,"" said uncle Glegg, meaning to give a playful turn to this denunciation, ""she must be sent to jail, I think, and they\'ll cut the rest of her hair off there, and make it all even.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

696,"['"" ""She\'s more like a gypsy nor ever,"" said aunt Pullet, in a pitying tone; ""it\'s very bad luck, sister, as the gell should be so brown; the boy\'s fair enough.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
697,"["" I doubt it'll stand in her way i' life to be so brown.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
698,"['"" ""She\'s a naughty child, as\'ll break her mother\'s heart,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
699,"[' Tulliver, with the tears in her eyes.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

700,"[' Maggie never forgot any of these moments when her father ""took her part""; she kept them in her heart, and thought of them long years after, when every one else said that her father had done very ill by his children.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
701,"[' ""How your husband does spoil that child, Bessy!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
702,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
703,"[' Glegg, in a loud ""aside,"" to Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
704,[' Tulliver.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
705,"["" My father never brought his children up so, else we should ha' been a different sort o' family to what we are.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
706,"['"" Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
707,"["" Tulliver's domestic sorrows seemed at this moment to have reached the point at which insensibility begins.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

708,"[' With the dessert there came entire deliverance for Maggie, for the children were told they might have their nuts and wine in the summer-house, since the day was so mild; and they scampered out among the budding bushes of the garden with the alacrity of small animals getting from under a burning glass.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

709,"[' The children were used to hear themselves talked of as freely as if they were birds, and could understand nothing, however they might stretch their necks and listen; but on this occasion Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

710,"[' Tulliver manifested an unusual discretion, because she had recently had evidence that the going to school to a clergyman was a sore point with Tom, who looked at it as very much on a par with going to school to a constable.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
711,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

712,"["" Tulliver had a sighing sense that her husband would do as he liked, whatever sister Glegg said, or sister Pullet either; but at least they would not be able to say, if the thing turned out ill, that Bessy had fallen in with her husband's folly without letting her own friends know a word about it.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
713,"[' ""Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
714,"[' Tulliver,"" she said, interrupting her husband in his talk with Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
715,"[' Deane, ""it\'s time now to tell the children\'s aunts and uncles what you\'re thinking of doing with Tom, isn\'t it?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
716,"['"" ""Very well,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
717,"[' Tulliver, rather sharply, ""I\'ve no objections to tell anybody what I mean to do with him.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
