718,"[' I\'ve settled,"" he added, looking toward Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
719,[' Glegg and Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
720,"[' Deane,-3""I\'ve settled to send him to a Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
721,"["" Stelling, a parson, down at King's Lorton, there,-3an uncommon clever fellow, I understand, as'll put him up to most things.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

722,"['"" There was a rustling demonstration of surprise in the company, such as you may have observed in a country congregation when they hear an allusion to their week-day affairs from the pulpit.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
723,"[' As for uncle Pullet, he could hardly have been more thoroughly obfuscated if Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

724,"[' Tulliver had said that he was going to send Tom to the Lord Chancellor; for uncle Pullet belonged to that extinct class of British yeoman who, dressed in good broadcloth, paid high rates and taxes, went to church, and ate a particularly good dinner on Sunday, without dreaming that the British constitution in Church and State had a traceable origin any more than the solar system and the fixed stars.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

725,"["" I know it is difficult for people in these instructed times to believe in uncle Pullet's ignorance; but let them reflect on the remarkable results of a great natural faculty under favoring circumstances.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
726,"[' ""Why, what can you be going to send him to a parson for?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
727,"['"" he said, with an amazed twinkling in his eyes, looking at Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
728,[' Glegg and Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
729,"[' Deane, to see if they showed any signs of comprehension.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
730,"[' ""Why, because the parsons are the best schoolmasters, by what I can make out,"" said poor Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
731,"[' Tulliver, who, in the maze of this puzzling world, laid hold of any clue with great readiness and tenacity.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
732,"["" do you think the parson'll teach him to know a good sample o' wheat when he sees it, neighbor Tulliver?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
733,"['"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

734,"[' Glegg, who was fond of his jest, and having retired from business, felt that it was not only allowable but becoming in him to take a playful view of things.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
735,"[' ""Why, you see, I\'ve got a plan i\' my head about Tom,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
736,"[' Tulliver, pausing after that statement and lifting up his glass.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
737,"[' ""Well, if I may be allowed to speak, and it\'s seldom as I am,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
738,"[' Glegg, with a tone of bitter meaning, ""I should like to know what good is to come to the boy by bringin\' him up above his fortin.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
739,"['"" ""Why,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
740,"[' Tulliver, not looking at Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
741,"[' Glegg, but at the male part of his audience, ""you see, I\'ve made up my mind not to bring Tom up to my own business.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

742,"["" I mean to put him to some business as he can go into without capital, and I want to give him an eddication as he'll be even wi' the lawyers and folks, and put me up to a notion now an' then.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
743,"['"" Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
744,"[' Glegg emitted a long sort of guttural sound with closed lips, that smiled in mingled pity and scorn.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
745,"[' ""He won\'t take more than two or three pupils, and so he\'ll have the more time to attend to \'em, you know.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

746,"['"" ""Ah, and get his eddication done the sooner; they can\'t learn much at a time when there\'s so many of \'em,"" said uncle Pullet, feeling that he was getting quite an insight into this difficult matter.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
747,"[' ""But then, you know, it\'s an investment; Tom\'s eddication \'ull be so much capital to him.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
748,"['"" ""Ay, there\'s something in that,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
749,[' Glegg.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
750,"[' But us that have got no learning had better keep our money, eh, neighbor Pullet?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
751,"['"" Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
752,"[' Glegg rubbed his knees, and looked very pleasant.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
753,"[' ""It\'s very unbecoming in a man o\' your age and belongings.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
754,"['"" ""What\'s unbecoming, Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
755,[' G.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
756,['?'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
757,"['"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
758,"[' Glegg, winking pleasantly at the company.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
759,"["" I say it's unbecoming to be making a joke when you see your own kin going headlongs to ruin.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
760,"['"" ""If you mean me by that,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
761,"[' Tulliver, considerably nettled, ""you needn\'t trouble yourself to fret about me.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
762,[' I can manage my own affairs without troubling other folks.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
763,"['"" ""Bless me!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
764,"['"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

765,"[' Deane, judiciously introducing a new idea, ""why, now I come to think of it, somebody said Wakem was going to send his son-3the deformed lad-3to a clergyman, didn\'t they, Susan?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
766,"['"" (appealing to his wife).']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
767,"[' ""Well,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
768,"[' Tulliver, speaking all the more cheerfully, that Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

769,"[' Glegg might see he didn\'t mind her, ""if Wakem thinks o\' sending his son to a clergyman, depend on it I shall make no mistake i\' sending Tom to one.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
770,"["" Ay, ay, tell me who's Wakem's butcher, and I'll tell you where to get your meat.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
771,"['"" ""But lawyer Wakem\'s son\'s got a hump-back,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
772,"[' Pullet, who felt as if the whole business had a funereal aspect; ""it\'s more nat\'ral to send him to a clergyman.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
773,"['"" ""Yes,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
774,"[' Glegg, interpreting Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
775,"[' Pullet\'s observation with erroneous plausibility, ""you must consider that, neighbor Tulliver; Wakem\'s son isn\'t likely to follow any business.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
776,"["" Wakem 'ull make a gentleman of him, poor fellow.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
777,"['"" ""Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
778,"[' Glegg,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
779,[' G.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

780,"[', in a tone which implied that her indignation would fizz and ooze a little, though she was determined to keep it corked up, ""you\'d far better hold your tongue.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
781,"["" There's folks in the world as know better than everybody else.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
782,"['"" ""Why, I should think that\'s you, if we\'re to trust your own tale,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
783,"[' Tulliver, beginning to boil up again.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
784,"[' ""My advice has never been asked, and I don\'t give it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
785,"['"" ""It\'ll be the first time, then,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
786,[' Tulliver.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
787,"[' ""It\'s the only thing you\'re over-ready at giving.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
788,"['"" ""I\'ve been over-ready at lending, then, if I haven\'t been over-ready at giving,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
789,[' Glegg.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
790,"[' ""You\'ve got a bond for it, I reckon,"" he said; ""and you\'ve had your five per cent, kin or no kin.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
791,"['"" ""Sister,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
792,"[' Tulliver, pleadingly, ""drink your wine, and let me give you some almonds and raisins.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
793,"['"" ""Bessy, I\'m sorry for you,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
794,"[' Glegg, very much with the feeling of a cur that seizes the opportunity of diverting his bark toward the man who carries no stick.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
795,"[' ""It\'s poor work talking o\' almonds and raisins.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
796,"['"" ""Lors, sister Glegg, don\'t be so quarrelsome,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
797,"[' Pullet, beginning to cry a little.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

798,"[' ""You may be struck with a fit, getting so red in the face after dinner, and we are but just out o\' mourning, all of us,-3and all wi\' gowns craped alike and just put by; it\'s very bad among sisters.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
799,"['"" ""I should think it is bad,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
800,[' Glegg.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
801,"[' ""Things are come to a fine pass when one sister invites the other to her house o\' purpose to quarrel with her and abuse her.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
802,"['"" ""Softly, softly, Jane; be reasonable, be reasonable,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
803,[' Glegg.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
804,[' I should never want to quarrel with any woman if she kept her place.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
805,"['"" ""My place, indeed!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
806,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
807,"[' Glegg, getting rather more shrill.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
808,"[' ""There\'s your betters, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

809,"["" Tulliver, as are dead and in their grave, treated me with a different sort o' respect to what you do; though I've got a husband as'll sit by and see me abused by them as 'ud never ha' had the chance if there hadn't been them in our family as married worse than they might ha' done.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
810,"['"" ""If you talk o\' that,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
811,"[' Tulliver, ""my family\'s as good as yours, and better, for it hasn\'t got a damned ill-tempered woman in it!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
812,"['"" ""Well,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
813,"[' Glegg, rising from her chair, ""I don\'t know whether you think it\'s a fine thing to sit by and hear me swore at, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
814,"["" Glegg; but I'm not going to stay a minute longer in this house.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
815,"["" You can stay behind, and come home with the gig, and I'll walk home.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
816,"['"" ""Dear heart, dear heart!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
817,"['"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
818,"[' Glegg in a melancholy tone, as he followed his wife out of the room.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
819,"[' ""Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
820,"[' Tulliver, how could you talk so?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
821,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
822,"[' Tulliver, with the tears in her eyes.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
823,"[' ""Let her go, and the sooner the better; she won\'t be trying to domineer over me again in a hurry.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
824,"['"" ""Sister Pullet,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
825,"[' Tulliver, helplessly, ""do you think it \'ud be any use for you to go after her and try to pacify her?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
826,"['"" ""Better not, better not,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
827,[' Deane.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
828,"[' ""You\'ll make it up another day.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
829,"['"" ""Then, sisters, shall we go and look at the children?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
830,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
831,"[' Tulliver, drying her eyes.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

832,"["" They could exchange their views concerning the Duke of Wellington, whose conduct in the Catholic Question had thrown such an entirely new light on his character; and speak slightingly of his conduct at the battle of Waterloo, which he would never have won if there hadn't been a great many Englishmen at his back, not to speak of Blucher and the Prussians, who, as Mr.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

833,"[' Tulliver had heard from a person of particular knowledge in that matter, had come up in the very nick of time; though here there was a slight dissidence, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

834,"[' Deane remarking that he was not disposed to give much credit to the Prussians,-3the build of their vessels, together with the unsatisfactory character of transactions in Dantzic beer, inclining him to form rather a low view of Prussian pluck generally.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

835,"[' TULLIVER SHOWS HIS WEAKER SIDE ""Suppose sister Glegg should call her money in; it \'ud be very awkward for you to have to raise five hundred pounds now,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
836,"[' Tulliver to her husband that evening, as she took a plaintive review of the day.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
837,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

838,"[' Tulliver had lived thirteen years with her husband, yet she retained in all the freshness of her early married life a facility of saying things which drove him in the opposite direction to the one she desired.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
839,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

840,"[' Tulliver was an amiable fish of this kind, and after running her head against the same resisting medium for thirteen years would go at it again to-day with undulled alacrity.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
841,[' This observation of hers tended directly to convince Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
842,[' Tulliver that it would not be at all awkward for him to raise five hundred pounds; and when Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

843,"[' Tulliver became rather pressing to know how he would raise it without mortgaging the mill and the house which he had said he never would mortgage, since nowadays people were none so ready to lend money without security, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
844,"[' Tulliver, getting warm, declared that Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
845,"[' Glegg might do as she liked about calling in her money, he should pay it in whether or not.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
846,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

847,"[' Tulliver cried a little in a trickling, quiet way as she put on her nightcap; but presently sank into a comfortable sleep, lulled by the thought that she would talk everything over with her sister Pullet to-morrow, when she was to take the children to Garum Firs to tea.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
848,[' Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

849,"[' Tulliver, when under the influence of a strong feeling, had a promptitude in action that may seem inconsistent with that painful sense of the complicated, puzzling nature of human affairs under which his more dispassionate deliberations were conducted; but it is really not improbable that there was a direct relation between these apparently contradictory phenomena, since I have observed that for getting a strong impression that a skein is tangled there is nothing like snatching hastily at a single thread.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
850,[' It was owing to this promptitude that Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
851,[' Tulliver was on horseback soon after dinner the next day (he was not dyspeptic) on his way to Basset to see his sister Moss and her husband.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
852,[' For having made up his mind irrevocably that he would pay Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

853,"[' Glegg her loan of five hundred pounds, it naturally occurred to him that he had a promissory note for three hundred pounds lent to his brother-in-law Moss; and if the said brother-in-law could manage to pay in the money within a given time, it would go far to lessen the fallacious air of inconvenience which Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

854,"["" Tulliver's spirited step might have worn in the eyes of weak people who require to know precisely how a thing is to be done before they are strongly confident that it will be easy.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
855,[' For Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

856,"[' Tulliver was in a position neither new nor striking, but, like other every-day things, sure to have a cumulative effect that will be felt in the long run: he was held to be a much more substantial man than he really was.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

857,"["" That was not altogether his own fault, since one of the thousand pounds was his sister's fortune, which he had to pay on her marriage; and a man who has neighbors that will go to law with him is not likely to pay off his mortgages, especially if he enjoys the good opinion of acquaintances who want to borrow a hundred pounds on security too lofty to be represented by parchment.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
858,[' Our friend Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

859,"[' Tulliver had a good-natured fibre in him, and did not like to give harsh refusals even to his sister, who had not only come in to the world in that superfluous way characteristic of sisters, creating a necessity for mortgages, but had quite thrown herself away in marriage, and had crowned her mistakes by having an eighth baby.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
860,[' On this point Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

861,[' Tulliver was conscious of being a little weak; but he apologized to himself by saying that poor Gritty had been a good- looking wench before she married Moss; he would sometimes say this even with a slight tremulousness in his voice.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

862,"[' But this morning he was in a mood more becoming a man of business, and in the course of his ride along the Basset lanes, with their deep ruts,-3lying so far away from a market-town that the labor of drawing produce and manure was enough to take away the best part of the profits on such poor land as that parish was made of,-3he got up a due amount of irritation against Moss as a man without capital, who, if murrain and blight were abroad, was sure to have his share of them, and who, the more you tried to help him out of the mud, would sink the further in.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

863,"[' It would do him good rather than harm, now, if he were obliged to raise this three hundred pounds; it would make him look about him better, and not act so foolishly about his wool this year as he did the last; in fact, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

864,"[' Tulliver had been too easy with his brother-in-law, and because he had let the interest run on for two years, Moss was likely enough to think that he should never be troubled about the principal.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
865,[' But Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

866,"["" Tulliver was determined not to encourage such shuffling people any longer; and a ride along the Basset lanes was not likely to enervate a man's resolution by softening his temper.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

867,"[' The muddy lanes, green or clayey, that seemed to the unaccustomed eye to lead nowhere but into each other, did really lead, with patience, to a distant high-road; but there were many feet in Basset which they led more frequently to a centre of dissipation, spoken of formerly as the ""Markis o\' Granby,"" but among intimates as ""Dickison\'s.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
868,"['"" A large low room with a sanded floor; a cold scent of tobacco, modified by undetected beer-dregs; Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

869,"["" Dickison leaning against the door-post with a melancholy pimpled face, looking as irrelevant to the daylight as a last night's guttered candle,-3all this may not seem a very seductive form of temptation; but the majority of men in Basset found it fatally alluring when encountered on their road toward four o'clock on a wintry afternoon; and if any wife in Basset wished to indicate that her husband was not a pleasure- seeking man, she could hardly do it more emphatically than by saying that he didn't spend a shilling at Dickison's from one Whitsuntide to another.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
870,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
871,"[' Moss had said so of her husband more than once, when her brother was in a mood to find fault with him, as he certainly was to-day.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
872,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

873,"["" Moss heard the sound of the horse's feet, and, when her brother rode up, was already outside the kitchen door, with a half-weary smile on her face, and a black-eyed baby in her arms.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
874,"[' ""Your husband isn\'t in the house, I suppose?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
875,"['"" added Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
876,"[' Tulliver after a grave pause, during which four children had run out, like chickens whose mother has been suddenly in eclipse behind the hen- coop.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
877,"[' I must be going home again directly,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
878,"[' Tulliver, looking at the distance.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
879,"[' ""And how\'s Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
880,[' Tulliver and the children?'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
881,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
882,"[' Moss, humbly, not daring to press her invitation.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
883,"["" It's bad work for me, lying out o' my money.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
884,"['"" ""I wish you\'d be so good as let the children come and see their cousins some day.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
885,"["" And I know she likes to come, for she's a loving child, and how quick and clever she is, to be sure!""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
886,"['"" If Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

887,"[' Moss had been one of the most astute women in the world, instead of being one of the simplest, she could have thought of nothing more likely to propitiate her brother than this praise of Maggie.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
888,"[' In spite of himself, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
889,"[' Tulliver\'s eyes got milder, and he did not look away from his sister as he said,-3 ""Ay; she\'s fonder o\' you than o\' the other aunts, I think.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
890,"["" She takes after our family: not a bit of her mother's in her.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
891,"['"" ""Moss says she\'s just like what I used to be,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
892,"[' Moss, ""though I was never so quick and fond o\' the books.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
893,"[' Come here, Lizzy, my dear, and let your uncle see you; he hardly knows you, you grow so fast.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

894,"['"" Lizzy, a black-eyed child of seven, looked very shy when her mother drew her forward, for the small Mosses were much in awe of their uncle from Dorlcote Mill.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
895,"[' ""Ay, they\'re a bit alike,"" he said, looking kindly at the little figure in the soiled pinafore.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
896,"["" They've got a brother apiece.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
897,"['"" ""Ah, but they must turn out and fend for themselves,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

898,"[' Tulliver, feeling that his severity was relaxing and trying to brace it by throwing out a wholesome hint ""They mustn\'t look to hanging on their brothers.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

899,"['"" ""No; but I hope their brothers \'ull love the poor things, and remember they came o\' one father and mother; the lads \'ull never be the poorer for that,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
900,"[' Moss, flashing out with hurried timidity, like a half-smothered fire.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
901,[' Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
902,"[' Tulliver gave his horse a little stroke on the flank, then checked it, and said angrily, ""Stand still with you!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
903,"['"" much to the astonishment of that innocent animal.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

904,"[' But she turned toward her brother again to say, ""Not but what I hope your boy \'ull allays be good to his sister, though there\'s but two of \'em, like you and me, brother.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
905,"['"" The arrow went straight to Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
906,"["" Tulliver's heart.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

907,"["" He had not a rapid imagination, but the thought of Maggie was very near to him, and he was not long in seeing his relation to his own sister side by side with Tom's relation to Maggie.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
908,"[' ""I\'m not denying that, brother, and I\'m noways ungrateful,"" said poor Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
909,"[' Moss, too fagged by toil and children to have strength left for any pride.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
910,"["" Won't you 'light, Mr.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
911,[' Tulliver?'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
912,"['"" ""Well, I\'ll just get down and have a bit o\' talk with you in the garden,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
913,"[' Tulliver, thinking that he should be more likely to show a due spirit of resolve if his sister were not present.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
914,[' Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

915,"[' Tulliver sat down on the bench, and tapping the ground curiously here and there with his stick, as if he suspected some hollowness, opened the conversation by observing, with something like a snarl in his tone,-3 ""Why, you\'ve got wheat again in that Corner Close, I see; and never a bit o\' dressing on it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
916,"["" You'll do no good with it this year.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
917,"['"" Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

918,"[' Moss, who, when he married Miss Tulliver, had been regarded as the buck of Basset, now wore a beard nearly a week old, and had the depressed, unexpectant air of a machine-horse.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

919,"[' He answered in a patient-grumbling tone, ""Why, poor farmers like me must do as they can; they must leave it to them as have got money to play with, to put half as much into the ground as they mean to get out of it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
920,"['"" ""I don\'t know who should have money to play with, if it isn\'t them as can borrow money without paying interest,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
921,"[' Tulliver, who wished to get into a slight quarrel; it was the most natural and easy introduction to calling in money.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
922,"[' ""I know I\'m behind with the interest,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
923,"[' Moss, ""but I was so unlucky wi\' the wool last year; and what with the Missis being laid up so, things have gone awk\'arder nor usual.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
924,"['"" ""Ay,"" snarled Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
925,"[' Tulliver, ""there\'s folks as things \'ull allays go awk\'ard with; empty sacks \'ull never stand upright.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
926,"['"" ""Well, I don\'t know what fault you\'ve got to find wi\' me, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
927,"[' Tulliver,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
928,"[' Moss, deprecatingly; ""I know there isn\'t a day- laborer works harder.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
929,"['"" ""What\'s the use o\' that,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
930,"[' Tulliver, sharply, ""when a man marries, and\'s got no capital to work his farm but his wife\'s bit o\' fortin?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
931,"["" And I can't lie out o' my money any longer, for I've got to pay five hundred o' Mrs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
932,"["" Glegg's, and there'll be Tom an expense to me.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
933,[' You must look about and see how you can pay me the three hundred pound.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
934,"['"" ""Well, if that\'s what you mean,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

935,"[' Moss, looking blankly before him, ""we\'d better be sold up, and ha\' done with it; I must part wi\' every head o\' stock I\'ve got, to pay you and the landlord too.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
936,"['"" Poor relations are undeniably irritating,-3their existence is so entirely uncalled for on our part, and they are almost always very faulty people.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
937,[' You must raise it as quick as you can.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
938,"['"" Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
939,"[' Tulliver walked abruptly out of the arbor as he uttered the last sentence, and, without looking round at Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

940,"[' Moss, went on to the kitchen door, where the eldest boy was holding his horse, and his sister was waiting in a state of wondering alarm, which was not without its alleviations, for baby was making pleasant gurgling sounds, and performing a great deal of finger practice on the faded face.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
941,"[' ""Won\'t you come in, brother?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
942,"['"" she said, looking anxiously at her husband, who was walking slowly up, while Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
943,[' Tulliver had his foot already in the stirrup.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
944,"[' ""No, no; good-by,"" said he, turning his horse\'s head, and riding away.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

945,"[' No man could feel more resolute till he got outside the yard gate, and a little way along the deep-rutted lane; but before he reached the next turning, which would take him out of sight of the dilapidated farm-buildings, he appeared to be smitten by some sudden thought.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

946,"[' He checked his horse, and made it stand still in the same spot for two or three minutes, during which he turned his head from side to side in a melancholy way, as if he were looking at some painful object on more sides than one.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
947,"["" she'll have nobody but Tom, belike, when I'm gone.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
948,"['"" Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
949,"["" Tulliver's return into the yard was descried by several young Mosses, who immediately ran in with the exciting news to their mother, so that Mrs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
950,[' Moss was again on the door-step when her brother rode up.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

951,"[' She had been crying, but was rocking baby to sleep in her arms now, and made no ostentatious show of sorrow as her brother looked at her, but merely said: ""The father\'s gone to the field, again, if you want him, brother.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
952,"['"" ""No, Gritty, no,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
953,"[' Tulliver, in a gentle tone.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
954,"["" I'll allays be a good brother to you.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
955,"['"" ""Thank you for that word, brother,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
956,"[' Moss, drying her tears; then turning to Lizzy, she said, ""Run now, and fetch the colored egg for cousin Maggie.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
957,"['"" Lizzy ran in, and quickly reappeared with a small paper parcel.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

958,"[' It had come across his mind that if he were hard upon his sister, it might somehow tend to make Tom hard upon Maggie at some distant day, when her father was no longer there to take her part; for simple people, like our friend Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

959,"[' Tulliver, are apt to clothe unimpeachable feelings in erroneous ideas, and this was his confused way of explaining to himself that his love and anxiety for ""the little wench"" had given him a new sensibility toward his sister.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

960,"["" - IX TO GARUM FIRS While the possible troubles of Maggie's future were occupying her father's mind, she herself was tasting only the bitterness of the present.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

961,"["" The pleasure of having Lucy to look at, and the prospect of the afternoon visit to Garum Firs, where she would hear uncle Pullet's musical box, had been marred as early as eleven o'clock by the advent of the hair- dresser from St.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

962,"[' Ogg\'s, who had spoken in the severest terms of the condition in which he had found her hair, holding up one jagged lock after another and saying, ""See here!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
963,"[' Moreover, the preparation for a visit being always a serious affair in the Dodson family, Martha was enjoined to have Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

964,"["" Tulliver's room ready an hour earlier than usual, that the laying out of the best clothes might not be deferred till the last moment, as was sometimes the case in families of lax views, where the ribbon-strings were never rolled up, where there was little or no wrapping in silver paper, and where the sense that the Sunday clothes could be got at quite easily produced no shock to the mind.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
965,"["" Already, at twelve o'clock, Mrs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

966,"[' Tulliver had on her visiting costume, with a protective apparatus of brown holland, as if she had been a piece of satin furniture in danger of flies; Maggie was frowning and twisting her shoulders, that she might if possible shrink away from the prickliest of tuckers, while her mother was remonstrating, ""Don\'t, Maggie, my dear; don\'t make yourself so ugly!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

967,"['"" and Tom\'s cheeks were looking particularly brilliant as a relief to his best blue suit, which he wore with becoming calmness, having, after a little wrangling, effected what was always the one point of interest to him in his toilet: he had transferred all the contents of his every-day pockets to those actually in wear.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

968,"[' As for Lucy, she was just as pretty and neat as she had been yesterday; no accidents ever happened to her clothes, and she was never uncomfortable in them, so that she looked with wondering pity at Maggie, pouting and writhing under the exasperating tucker.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

969,"[' Maggie would certainly have torn it off, if she had not been checked by the remembrance of her recent humiliation about her hair; as it was, she confined herself to fretting and twisting, and behaving peevishly about the card-houses which they were allowed to build till dinner, as a suitable amusement for boys and girls in their best clothes.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
970,[' It was always so with the things that Maggie made; and Tom had deduced the conclusion that no girls could ever make anything.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
971,[' I like Lucy better than you; I wish Lucy was my sister.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

972,"['"" ""Then it\'s very wicked and cruel of you to wish so,"" said Maggie, starting up hurriedly from her place on the floor, and upsetting Tom\'s wonderful pagoda.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

973,"[' She really did not mean it, but the circumstantial evidence was against her, and Tom turned white with anger, but said nothing; he would have struck her, only he knew it was cowardly to strike a girl, and Tom Tulliver was quite determined he would never do anything cowardly.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

974,"[' Maggie stood in dismay and terror, while Tom got up from the floor and walked away, pale, from the scattered ruins of his pagoda, and Lucy looked on mutely, like a kitten pausing from its lapping.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
975,"[' ""Oh, Tom,"" said Maggie, at last, going half-way toward him, ""I didn\'t mean to knock it down, indeed, indeed I didn\'t.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

976,"['"" Tom took no notice of her, but took, instead, two or three hard peas out of his pocket, and shot them with his thumbnail against the window, vaguely at first, but presently with the distinct aim of hitting a superannuated blue-bottle which was exposing its imbecility in the spring sunshine, clearly against the views of Nature, who had provided Tom and the peas for the speedy destruction of this weak individual.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
977,"[' Lucy had said, ""Maggie, shouldn\'t you like one?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
978,"['"" but Tom was deaf.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

979,"["" Then there were white railings and white gates all about, and glittering weathercocks of various design, and garden-walks paved with pebbles in beautiful patterns,-3nothing was quite common at Garum Firs; and Tom thought that the unusual size of the toads there was simply due to the general unusualness which characterized uncle Pullet's possessions as a gentleman farmer.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

980,"[' Uncle Pullet had seen the expected party approaching from the window, and made haste to unbar and unchain the front door, kept always in this fortified condition from fear of tramps, who might be supposed to know of the glass case of stuffed birds in the hall, and to contemplate rushing in and carrying it away on their heads.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
981,"[' Aunt Pullet, too, appeared at the doorway, and as soon as her sister was within hearing said, ""Stop the children, for God\'s sake!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
982,"["" Bessy; don't let 'em come up the door-steps; Sally's bringing the old mat and the duster, to rub their shoes.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
983,"['"" Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
984,"["" Pullet's front-door mats were by no means intended to wipe shoes on; the very scraper had a deputy to do its dirty work.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

985,"["" He felt it as the beginning of the disagreeables incident to a visit at aunt Pullet's, where he had once been compelled to sit with towels wrapped round his boots; a fact which may serve to correct the too-hasty conclusion that a visit to Garum Firs must have been a great treat to a young gentleman fond of animals,-3fond, that is, of throwing stones at them.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
986,"["" Sophy's weakness about these polished stairs was always a subject of bitter remonstrance on Mrs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
987,"["" Glegg's part; but Mrs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
988,"[' Tulliver ventured on no comment, only thinking to herself it was a mercy when she and the children were safe on the landing.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
989,"[' ""Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
990,"[' Gray has sent home my new bonnet, Bessy,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
991,"[' Pullet, in a pathetic tone, as Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
992,[' Tulliver adjusted her cap.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
993,"[' ""Has she, sister?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
994,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
995,"[' Tulliver, with an air of much interest.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
996,"[' ""And how do you like it?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
997,"['"" ""It\'s apt to make a mess with clothes, taking \'em out and putting \'em in again,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
998,"[' Pullet, drawing a bunch of keys from her pocket and looking at them earnestly, ""but it \'ud be a pity for you to go away without seeing it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
999,"["" There's no knowing what may happen.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1000,"['"" Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1001,"[' Pullet shook her head slowly at this last serious consideration, which determined her to single out a particular key.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1002,"[' ""I\'m afraid it\'ll be troublesome to you getting it out, sister,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1003,"[' Tulliver; ""but I should like to see what sort of a crown she\'s made you.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1004,"['"" Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1005,"[' Pullet rose with a melancholy air and unlocked one wing of a very bright wardrobe, where you may have hastily supposed she would find a new bonnet.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1006,"[' ""You must come with me into the best room,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1007,[' Pullet.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1008,"[' ""May the children come too, sister?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1009,"['"" inquired Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1010,"[' Tulliver, who saw that Maggie and Lucy were looking rather eager.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1011,"[' ""Well,"" said aunt Pullet, reflectively, ""it\'ll perhaps be safer for \'em to come; they\'ll be touching something if we leave \'em behind.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1012,"['"" So they went in procession along the bright and slippery corridor, dimly lighted by the semi-lunar top of the window which rose above the closed shutter; it was really quite solemn.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1013,"[' Aunt Pullet paused and unlocked a door which opened on something still more solemn than the passage,-3a darkened room, in which the outer light, entering feebly, showed what looked like the corpses of furniture in white shrouds.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1014,"[' She looked all round it in silence for some moments, and then said emphatically, ""Well, sister, I\'ll never speak against the full crowns again!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1015,"['"" It was a great concession, and Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1016,[' Pullet felt it; she felt something was due to it.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1017,"[' ""I\'ll open the shutter a bit further.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1018,"['"" ""Well, if you don\'t mind taking off your cap, sister,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1019,[' Tulliver.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1020,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1021,"["" Pullet took off her cap, displaying the brown silk scalp with a jutting promontory of curls which was common to the more mature and judicious women of those times, and placing the bonnet on her head, turned slowly round, like a draper's lay-figure, that Mrs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1022,[' Tulliver might miss no point of view.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1023,"[' ""I\'ve sometimes thought there\'s a loop too much o\' ribbon on this left side, sister; what do you think?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1024,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1025,[' Pullet.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1026,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1027,"[' Tulliver looked earnestly at the point indicated, and turned her head on one side.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1028,"[' ""Well, I think it\'s best as it is; if you meddled with it, sister, you might repent.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1029,"['"" ""That\'s true,"" said aunt Pullet, taking off the bonnet and looking at it contemplatively.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1030,"[' ""How much might she charge you for that bonnet, sister?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1031,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1033,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1034,"[' Pullet screwed up her mouth and shook her head, and then whispered, ""Pullet pays for it; he said I was to have the best bonnet at Garum Church, let the next best be whose it would.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1035,"['"" She began slowly to adjust the trimmings, in preparation for returning it to its place in the wardrobe, and her thoughts seemed to have taken a melancholy turn, for she shook her head.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1036,"[' ""Ah,"" she said at last, ""I may never wear it twice, sister; who knows?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1037,"['"" ""Don\'t talk o\' that sister,"" answered Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1038,[' Tulliver.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1039,"["" Cousin Abbott may go, and we can't think o' wearing crape less nor half a year for him.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1040,"['"" ""That would be unlucky,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1041,"[' Tulliver, entering thoroughly into the possibility of an inopportune decease.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1042,"[' ""There\'s never so much pleasure i\' wearing a bonnet the second year, especially when the crowns are so chancy,-3never two summers alike.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1043,"['"" ""Ah, it\'s the way i\' this world,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1044,"[' Pullet, returning the bonnet to the wardrobe and locking it up.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1045,"[' Then, beginning to cry, she said, ""Sister, if you should never see that bonnet again till I\'m dead and gone, you\'ll remember I showed it you this day.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1046,"['"" Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1047,"["" Tulliver felt that she ought to be affected, but she was a woman of sparse tears, stout and healthy; she couldn't cry so much as her sister Pullet did, and had often felt her deficiency at funerals.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1048,"["" Maggie, looking on attentively, felt that there was some painful mystery about her aunt's bonnet which she was considered too young to understand; indignantly conscious, all the while, that she could have understood that, as well as everything else, if she had been taken into confidence.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1049,"[' With Tom the interval had seemed still longer, for he had been seated in irksome constraint on the edge of a sofa directly opposite his uncle Pullet, who regarded him with twinkling gray eyes, and occasionally addressed him as ""Young sir.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1050,"['"" ""Well, young sir, what do you learn at school?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1051,"['"" was a standing question with uncle Pullet; whereupon Tom always looked sheepish, rubbed his hands across his face, and answered, ""I don\'t know.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1053,"["" Not that Tom was in awe of his uncle's mental superiority; indeed, he had made up his mind that he didn't want to be a gentleman farmer, because he shouldn't like to be such a thin- legged, silly fellow as his uncle Pullet,-3a molly-coddle, in fact.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1054,"["" In very tender years, when he still wore a lace border under his outdoor cap, he was often observed peeping through the bars of a gate and making minatory gestures with his small forefinger while he scolded the sheep with an inarticulate burr, intended to strike terror into their astonished minds; indicating thus early that desire for mastery over the inferior animals, wild and domestic, including cockchafers, neighbors' dogs, and small sisters, which in all ages has been an attribute of so much promise for the fortunes of our race.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1055,"[' So that Tom was not without strong reasons when, in confidential talk with a chum, he had described uncle Pullet as a nincompoop, taking care at the same time to observe that he was a very ""rich fellow.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1057,"[' The appearance of the little girls suggested to uncle Pullet the further solace of small sweet-cakes, of which he also kept a stock under lock and key for his own private eating on wet days; but the three children had no sooner got the tempting delicacy between their fingers, than aunt Pullet desired them to abstain from eating it till the tray and the plates came, since with those crisp cakes they would make the floor ""all over"" crumbs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1058,"["" Lucy didn't mind that much, for the cake was so pretty, she thought it was rather a pity to eat it; but Tom, watching his opportunity while the elders were talking, hastily stowed it in his mouth at two bites, and chewed it furtively.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1059,"[' As for Maggie, becoming fascinated, as usual, by a print of Ulysses and Nausicaa, which uncle Pullet had bought as a ""pretty Scripture thing,"" she presently let fall her cake, and in an unlucky movement crushed it beneath her foot,-3a source of so much agitation to aunt Pullet and conscious disgrace to Maggie, that she began to despair of hearing the musical snuff-box to-day, till, after some reflection, it occurred to her that Lucy was in high favor enough to venture on asking for a tune.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1060,"[' So she whispered to Lucy; and Lucy, who always did what she was desired to do, went up quietly to her uncle\'s knee, and blush-all over her neck while she fingered her necklace, said, ""Will you please play us a tune, uncle?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1061,"['"" Lucy thought it was by reason of some exceptional talent in uncle Pullet that the snuff-box played such beautiful tunes, and indeed the thing was viewed in that light by the majority of his neighbors in Garum.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1062,"[' Perhaps the suspense did heighten Maggie\'s enjoyment when the fairy tune began; for the first time she quite forgot that she had a load on her mind, that Tom was angry with her; and by the time ""Hush, ye pretty warbling choir,"" had been played, her face wore that bright look of happiness, while she sat immovable with her hands clasped, which sometimes comforted her mother with the sense that Maggie could look pretty now and then, in spite of her brown skin.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1063,"[' But when the magic music ceased, she jumped up, and running toward Tom, put her arm round his neck and said, ""Oh, Tom, isn\'t it pretty?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1064,"['"" Lest you should think it showed a revolting insensibility in Tom that he felt any new anger toward Maggie for this uncalled-for and, to him, inexplicable caress, I must tell you that he had his glass of cowslip wine in his hand, and that she jerked him so as to make him spill half of it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1065,"[' ""Little gells mustn\'t come to see me if they behave in that way,"" said aunt Pullet.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1066,"[' ""Why, you\'re too rough, little miss,"" said uncle Pullet.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1067,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1068,"[' Tulliver, foreseeing nothing but misbehavior while the children remained indoors, took an early opportunity of suggesting that, now they were rested after their walk, they might go and play out of doors; and aunt Pullet gave permission, only enjoining them not to go off the paved walks in the garden, and if they wanted to see the poultry fed, to view them from a distance on the horse-block; a restriction which had been imposed ever since Tom had been found guilty of running after the peacock, with an illusory idea that fright would make one of its feathers drop off.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1069,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1070,"["" Tulliver's thoughts had been temporarily diverted from the quarrel with Mrs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1071,"["" Glegg by millinery and maternal cares, but now the great theme of the bonnet was thrown into perspective, and the children were out of the way, yesterday's anxieties recurred.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1072,"[' ""It weighs on my mind so as never was,"" she said, by way of opening the subject, ""sister Glegg\'s leaving the house in that way.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1073,"["" I'm sure I'd no wish t' offend a sister.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1074,"['"" ""Ah,"" said aunt Pullet, ""there\'s no accounting for what Jane \'ull do.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1075,"["" I've said so to Pullet often and often, and he knows it.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1076,"['"" ""Why, you said so last Monday was a week, when we came away from drinking tea with \'em,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1077,"[' Pullet, beginning to nurse his knee and shelter it with his pocket-hand-kerchief, as was his way when the conversation took an interesting turn.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1078,"[' ""Very like I did,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1079,"[' Pullet, ""for you remember when I said things, better than I can remember myself.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1080,"[' ""Ah, perhaps it \'ud be better for sister Glegg if she\'d go to the doctor sometimes, instead o\' chewing Turkey rhubard whenever there\'s anything the matter with her,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1081,"[' Tulliver, who naturally saw the wide subject of medicine chiefly in relation to Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1082,[' Glegg.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1083,"[' ""It\'s dreadful to think on,"" said aunt Pullet, raising her hands and letting them fall again, ""people playing with their own insides in that way!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1084,"["" The pill-boxes are in the closet in my room,-3you'll remember that, sister,-3but there's nothing to show for the boluses, if it isn't the bills.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1085,"['"" ""Don\'t talk o\' your going, sister,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1086,"[' Tulliver; ""I should have nobody to stand between me and sister Glegg if you was gone.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1087,"["" And there's nobody but you can get her to make it up with Mr.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1088,"["" Tulliver, for sister Deane's never o' my side, and if she was, it's not to be looked for as she can speak like them as have got an independent fortin.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1089,"['"" ""Well, your husband is awk\'ard, you know, Bessy,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1090,"["" Pullet, good-naturedly ready to use her deep depression on her sister's account as well as her own.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1091,"[' ""He\'s never behaved quite so pretty to our family as he should do, and the children take after him,-3the boy\'s very mischievous, and runs away from his aunts and uncles, and the gell\'s rude and brown.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1092,"["" It's your bad luck, and I'm sorry for you, Bessy; for you was allays my favorite sister, and we allays liked the same patterns.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1093,"['"" ""I know Tulliver\'s hasty, and says odd things,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1094,"[' Tulliver, wiping away one small tear from the corner of her eye; ""but I\'m sure he\'s never been the man, since he married me, to object to my making the friends o\' my side o\' the family welcome to the house.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1095,"['"" ""I don\'t want to make the worst of you, Bessy,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1096,"[' Pullet, compassionately, ""for I doubt you\'ll have trouble enough without that; and your husband\'s got that poor sister and her children hanging on him,-3and so given to lawing, they say.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1097,"["" Not as I'd have it said out o' the family.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1098,"['"" This view of her position was naturally far from cheering to Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1099,[' Tulliver.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1100,"["" I allays offer it along with the sherry, though sister Glegg will have it I'm so extravagant; and as for liking to have my clothes tidy, and not go a fright about the house, there's nobody in the parish can say anything against me in respect o' backbiting and making mischief, for I don't wish anybody any harm; and nobody loses by sending me a porkpie, for my pies are fit to show with the best o' my neighbors'; and the linen's so in order as if I was to die to-morrow I shouldn't be ashamed.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1101,[' A woman can do no more nor she can.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1102,"['"" ""But it\'s all o\' no use, you know, Bessy,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1103,"[' Pullet, holding her head on one side, and fixing her eyes pathetically on her sister, ""if your husband makes away with his money.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1104,"[' ""But what can I do, sister?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1105,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1106,[' Tulliver.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1107,"["" I could never see into men's business as sister Glegg does.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1108,"['"" ""Well, you\'re like me in that, Bessy,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1109,"[' Pullet; ""and I think it \'ud be a deal more becoming o\' Jane if she\'d have that pier-glass rubbed oftener,-3there was ever so many spots on it last week,-3 instead o\' dictating to folks as have more comings in than she ever had, and telling \'em what they\'re to do with their money.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1110,"["" You like a spot too, Bessy; we allays hung together i' that.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1111,"['"" ""Yes, Sophy,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1112,"[' Tulliver, ""I remember our having a blue ground with a white spot both alike,-3I\'ve got a bit in a bed-quilt now; and if you would but go and see sister Glegg, and persuade her to make it up with Tulliver, I should take it very kind of you.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1113,[' You was allays a good sister to me.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1114,"['"" ""But the right thing \'ud be for Tulliver to go and make it up with her himself, and say he was sorry for speaking so rash.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1115,"[' If he\'s borrowed money of her, he shouldn\'t be above that,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1116,"[' Pullet, whose partiality did not blind her to principles; she did not forget what was due to people of independent fortune.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1117,"[' ""It\'s no use talking o\' that,"" said poor Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1118,"[' Tulliver, almost peevishly.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1119,"[' ""If I was to go down on my bare knees on the gravel to Tulliver, he\'d never humble himself.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1120,"['"" ""Well, you can\'t expect me to persuade Jane to beg pardon,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1121,[' Pullet.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1122,"[' ""Her temper\'s beyond everything; it\'s well if it doesn\'t carry her off her mind, though there never was any of our family went to a madhouse.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1123,"['"" ""I\'m not thinking of her begging pardon,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1124,[' Tulliver.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1125,"[' ""But if she\'d just take no notice, and not call her money in; as it\'s not so much for one sister to ask of another; time \'ud mend things, and Tulliver \'ud forget all about it, and they\'d be friends again.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1126,"['"" Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1127,"["" Tulliver, you perceive, was not aware of her husband's irrevocable determination to pay in the five hundred pounds; at least such a determination exceeded her powers of belief.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1128,"[' ""Well, Bessy,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1129,"[' Pullet, mournfully, ""I don\'t want to help you on to ruin.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1130,"["" And I don't like it said among acquaintance as we've got quarrels in the family.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1131,[' After a little further discussion as to whether it would not be better for Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1132,"[' Tulliver to accompany them on a visit to sister Glegg, Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1133,"[' Pullet, observing that it was tea-time, turned to reach from a drawer a delicate damask napkin, which she pinned before her in the fashion of an apron.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1134,"[' The door did, in fact, soon open, but instead of the tea-tray, Sally introduced an object so startling that both Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1135,[' Pullet and Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1136,"[' Tulliver gave a scream, causing uncle Pullet to swallow his lozenge-3for the fifth time in his life, as he afterward noted.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1137,"[' - X MAGGIE BEHAVES WORSE THAN SHE EXPECTED The startling object which thus made an epoch for uncle Pullet was no other than little Lucy, with one side of her person, from her small foot to her bonnet-crown, wet and discolored with mud, holding out two tiny blackened hands, and making a very piteous face.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1138,"["" To account for this unprecedented apparition in aunt Pullet's parlor, we must return to the moment when the three children went to play out of doors, and the small demons who had taken possession of Maggie's soul at an early period of the day had returned in all the greater force after a temporary absence.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1139,"[' All the disagreeable recollections of the morning were thick upon her, when Tom, whose displeasure toward her had been considerably refreshed by her foolish trick of causing him to upset his cowslip wine, said, ""Here, Lucy, you come along with me,"" and walked off to the area where the toads were, as if there were no Maggie in existence.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1140,"["" Still Lucy wished Maggie to enjoy the spectacle also, especially as she would doubtless find a name for the toad, and say what had been his past history; for Lucy had a delighted semibelief in Maggie's stories about the live things they came upon by accident,-3how Mrs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1141,"[' Earwig had a wash at home, and one of her children had fallen into the hot copper, for which reason she was running so fast to fetch the doctor.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1142,"["" Tom had a profound contempt for this nonsense of Maggie's, smashing the earwig at once as a superfluous yet easy means of proving the entire unreality of such a story; but Lucy, for the life of her, could not help fancying there was something in it, and at all events thought it was very pretty make-believe.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1143,[' Do come and see!'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1144,"['"" Maggie said nothing, but turned away from her with a deeper frown.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1145,"["" As it was, she was actually beginning to think that she should like to make Lucy cry by slapping or pinching her, especially as it might vex Tom, whom it was of no use to slap, even if she dared, because he didn't mind it.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1146,"[' Tickling a fat toad who is not highly sensitive is an amusement that it is possible to exhaust, and Tom by and by began to look round for some other mode of passing the time.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1147,"[' ""I say, Lucy,"" he began, nodding his head up and down with great significance, as he coiled up his string again, ""what do you think I mean to do?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1148,"['"" ""What, Tom?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1149,"['"" said Lucy, with curiosity.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1150,"[' ""Oh, never mind; they won\'t be cross with you,"" said Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1151,"[' Anger and jealousy can no more bear to lose sight of their objects than love, and that Tom and Lucy should do or see anything of which she was ignorant would have been an intolerable idea to Maggie.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1152,"[' So she kept a few yards behind them, unobserved by Tom, who was presently absorbed in watching for the pike,-3a highly interesting monster; he was said to be so very old, so very large, and to have such a remarkable appetite.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1153,"[' Maggie had drawn nearer and nearer; she must see it too, though it was bitter to her, like everything else, since Tom did not care about her seeing it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1154,"[' At last she was close by Lucy; and Tom, who had been aware of her approach, but would not notice it till he was obliged, turned round and said,-3 ""Now, get away, Maggie; there\'s no room for you on the grass here.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1155,[' Nobody asked you to come.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1157,"[' Then Tom could not restrain himself, and gave Maggie two smart slaps on the arm as he ran to pick up Lucy, who lay crying helplessly.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1158,"[' ""I shall tell mother, you know, Miss Mag,"" said Tom, loudly and emphatically, as soon as Lucy was up and ready to walk away.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1159,"[' She could never have guessed what she had done to make Maggie angry with her; but she felt that Maggie was very unkind and disagreeable, and made no magnanimous entreaties to Tom that he would not ""tell,"" only running along by his side and crying piteously, while Maggie sat on the roots of the tree and looked after them with her small Medusa face.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1160,"[' ""Sally,"" said Tom, when they reached the kitchen door, and Sally looked at them in speechless amaze, with a piece of bread-and-butter in her mouth and a toasting-fork in her hand,-3""Sally, tell mother it was Maggie pushed Lucy into the mud.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1161,"['"" ""But Lors ha\' massy, how did you get near such mud as that?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1162,"['"" said Sally, making a wry face, as she stooped down and examined the corpus delicti.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1163,"[' Sally, as you are aware, lost no time in presenting Lucy at the parlor door, for to have so dirty an object introduced into the house at Garum Firs was too great a weight to be sustained by a single mind.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1164,"["" Don't bring her off the oil-cloth, whatever you do.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1165,"['"" ""Why, she\'s tumbled into some nasty mud,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1166,"[' Tulliver, going up to Lucy to examine into the amount of damage to clothes for which she felt herself responsible to her sister Deane.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1167,"[' ""If you please, \'um, it was Miss Maggie as pushed her in,"" said Sally; ""Master Tom\'s been and said so, and they must ha\' been to the pond, for it\'s only there they could ha\' got into such dirt.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1168,"['"" ""There it is, Bessy; it\'s what I\'ve been telling you,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1169,"[' Pullet, in a tone of prophetic sadness; ""it\'s your children,-3there\'s no knowing what they\'ll come to.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1170,"['"" Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1171,"[' Tulliver was mute, feeling herself a truly wretched mother.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1172,"[' As usual, the thought pressed upon her that people would think she had done something wicked to deserve her maternal troubles, while Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1173,[' Pullet began to give elaborate directions to Sally how to guard the premises from serious injury in the course of removing the dirt.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1174,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1175,"[' Tulliver went out to speak to these naughty children, supposing them to be close at hand; but it was not until after some search that she found Tom leaning with rather a hardened, careless air against the white paling of the poultry-yard, and lowering his piece of string on the other side as a means of exasperating the turkey-cock.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1176,"[' ""Tom, you naughty boy, where\'s your sister?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1177,"['"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1178,"[' Tulliver, in a distressed voice.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1179,"[' ""I don\'t know,"" said Tom; his eagerness for justice on Maggie had diminished since he had seen clearly that it could hardly be brought about without the injustice of some blame on his own conduct.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1180,"["" You know she'll do mischief if there's mischief to be done.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1181,"['"" It was Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1182,"["" Tulliver's way, if she blamed Tom, to refer his misdemeanor, somehow or other, to Maggie.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1183,[' The idea of Maggie sitting alone by the pond roused an habitual fear in Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1184,"["" Tulliver's mind, and she mounted the horse-block to satisfy herself by a sight of that fatal child, while Tom walked-3not very quickly-3on his way toward her.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1185,[' I wish that river was far enough.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1186,"['"" But when she not only failed to discern Maggie, but presently saw Tom returning from the pool alone, this hovering fear entered and took complete possession of her, and she hurried to meet him.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1187,"[' ""Maggie\'s nowhere about the pond, mother,"" said Tom; ""she\'s gone away.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1188,"['"" You may conceive the terrified search for Maggie, and the difficulty of convincing her mother that she was not in the pond.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1189,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1190,"[' Pullet observed that the child might come to a worse end if she lived, there was no knowing; and Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1191,"[' Pullet, confused and overwhelmed by this revolutionary aspect of things,-3the tea deferred and the poultry alarmed by the unusual running to and fro,-3took up his spud as an instrument of search, and reached down a key to unlock the goose-pen, as a likely place for Maggie to lie concealed in.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1192,"[' Tom, after a while, started the idea that Maggie was gone home (without thinking it necessary to state that it was what he should have done himself under the circumstances), and the suggestion was seized as a comfort by his mother.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1193,"[' Aunt Pullet was quite willing to take the shortest means of restoring her premises to order and quiet, and it was not long before Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1194,"[' Tulliver was in the chaise, looking anxiously at the most distant point before her.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1195,"[' The resolution that gathered in her mind, after Tom and Lucy had walked away, was not so simple as that of going home.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1196,"[' That was by no means a new idea to Maggie; she had been so often told she was like a gypsy, and ""half wild,"" that when she was miserable it seemed to her the only way of escaping opprobrium, and being entirely in harmony with circumstances, would be to live in a little brown tent on the commons; the gypsies, she considered, would gladly receive her and pay her much respect on account of her superior knowledge.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1197,"[' She had once mentioned her views on this point to Tom and suggested that he should stain his face brown, and they should run away together; but Tom rejected the scheme with contempt, observing that gypsies were thieves, and hardly got anything to eat and had nothing to drive but a donkey.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1198,"[' To-day however, Maggie thought her misery had reached a pitch at which gypsydom was her refuge, and she rose from her seat on the roots of the tree with the sense that this was a great crisis in her life; she would run straight away till she came to Dunlow Common, where there would certainly be gypsies; and cruel Tom, and the rest of her relations who found fault with her, should never see her any more.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1199,"[' She thought of her father as she ran along, but she reconciled herself to the idea of parting with him, by determining that she would secretly send him a letter by a small gypsy, who would run away without telling where she was, and just let him know that she was well and happy, and always loved him very much.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1200,"[' Maggie soon got out of breath with running, but by the time Tom got to the pond again she was at the distance of three long fields, and was on the edge of the lane leading to the highroad.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1201,"[' She stopped to pant a little, reflecting that running away was not a pleasant thing until one had got quite to the common where the gypsies were, but her resolution had not abated; she presently passed through the gate into the lane, not knowing where it would lead her, for it was not this way that they came from Dorlcote Mill to Garum Firs, and she felt all the safer for that, because there was no chance of her being overtaken.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1202,"["" Maggie had a sixpence in her pocket,-3her uncle Glegg's present,-3which she immediately drew out and gave this poor man with a polite smile, hoping he would feel very kindly toward her as a generous person.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1203,"[' ""Thank you, little miss,"" said the man, in a less respectful and grateful tone than Maggie anticipated, and she even observed that he smiled and winked at his companion.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1204,"[' Suddenly it occurred to her that they might think she was an idiot; Tom had said that her cropped hair made her look like an idiot, and it was too painful an idea to be readily forgotten.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1205,"["" It was clear that she was not likely to make a favorable impression on passengers, and she thought she would turn into the fields again, but not on the same side of the lane as before, lest they should still be uncle Pullet's fields.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1206,"[' It was still broad daylight, for aunt Pullet, retaining the early habits of the Dodson family, took tea at half-past four by the sun, and at five by the kitchen clock; so, though it was nearly an hour since Maggie started, there was no gathering gloom on the fields to remind her that the night would come.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1207,[' For poor little Maggie had at once the timidity of an active imagination and the daring that comes from overmastering impulse.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1208,"[' Maggie looked up in the new face rather tremblingly as it approached, and was reassured by the thought that her aunt Pullet and the rest were right when they called her a gypsy; for this face, with the bright dark eyes and the long hair, was really something like what she used to see in the glass before she cut her hair off.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1209,"[' Why, what a nice little lady you are, to be sure!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1210,"['"" said the gypsy, taking her by the hand.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1211,"[' An old gypsy woman was seated on the ground nursing her knees, and occasionally poking a skewer into the round kettle that sent forth an odorous steam; two small shock-headed children were lying prone and resting on their elbows something like small sphinxes; and a placid donkey was bending his head over a tall girl, who, lying on her back, was scratching his nose and indulging him with a bite of excellent stolen hay.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
