1212,"[' It was a little confusing, though, that the young woman began to speak to the old one in a language which Maggie did not understand, while the tall girl, who was feeding the donkey, sat up and stared at her without offering any salutation.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1213,[' Sit ye down and tell us where you come from.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1214,"['"" It was just like a story; Maggie liked to be called pretty lady and treated in this way.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1215,"["" I'll live with you if you like, and I can teach you a great many things.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1216,"['"" ""Such a clever little lady,"" said the woman with the baby sitting down by Maggie, and allowing baby to crawl; ""and such a pretty bonnet and frock,"" she added, taking off Maggie\'s bonnet and looking at it while she made an observation to the old woman, in the unknown language.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1217,"[' ""I don\'t want to wear a bonnet,"" she said; ""I\'d rather wear a red handkerchief, like yours"" (looking at her friend by her side).']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1218,"[' ""Oh, what a nice little lady!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1219,"['-3and rich, I\'m sure,"" said the old woman.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1220,"["" The gypsies themselves were not without amazement at this talk, though their attention was divided by the contents of Maggie's pocket, which the friend at her right hand had by this time emptied without attracting her notice.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1221,"[' ""Is that where you live, my little lady?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1222,"['"" said the old woman, at the mention of Columbus.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1223,"[' ""Oh, no!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1224,"['"" said Maggie, with some pity; ""Columbus was a very wonderful man, who found out half the world, and they put chains on him and treated him very badly, you know; it\'s in my Catechism of Geography, but perhaps it\'s rather too long to tell before tea-3I want my tea so.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1225,"['"" The last words burst from Maggie, in spite of herself, with a sudden drop from patronizing instruction to simple peevishness.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1226,"["" Where's your home?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1227,"['"" ""It\'s Dorlcote Mill, a good way off,"" said Maggie.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1228,"[' ""No,"" said Maggie, ""I\'m only thinking that if she isn\'t a very good queen you might be glad when she died, and you could choose another.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1229,"["" If I was a queen, I'd be a very good queen, and kind to everybody.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1230,"['"" ""Here\'s a bit o\' nice victual, then,"" said the old woman, handing to Maggie a lump of dry bread, which she had taken from a bag of scraps, and a piece of cold bacon.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1231,"[' ""Thank you,\' said Maggie, looking at the food without taking it; ""but will you give me some bread-and-butter and tea instead?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1232,"[' ""We han\'t got no treacle,"" said the old woman, crossly, whereupon there followed a sharp dialogue between the two women in their unknown tongue, and one of the small sphinxes snatched at the bread-and-bacon, and began to eat it.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1233,"[' Meanwhile the tall girl gave a shrill cry, and presently came running up the boy whom Maggie had passed as he was sleeping,-3a rough urchin about the age of Tom.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1234,"[' He stared at Maggie, and there ensued much incomprehensible chattering.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1235,"[' The elder of the two carried a bag, which he flung down, addressing the women in a loud and scolding tone, which they answered by a shower of treble sauciness; while a black cur ran barking up to Maggie, and threw her into a tremor that only found a new cause in the curses with which the younger man called the dog off, and gave him a rap with a great stick he held in his hand.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1236,"[' At last the younger woman said in her previous deferential, coaxing tone,-3 ""This nice little lady\'s come to live with us; aren\'t you glad?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1237,"['"" ""Ay, very glad,"" said the younger man, who was looking at Maggie\'s silver thimble and other small matters that had been taken from her pocket.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1238,"["" He returned them all except the thimble to the younger woman, with some observation, and she immediately restored them to Maggie's pocket, while the men seated themselves, and began to attack the contents of the kettle,-3a stew of meat and potatoes,-3which had been taken off the fire and turned out into a yellow platter.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1239,"[' Maggie began to think that Tom must be right about the gypsies; they must certainly be thieves, unless the man meant to return her thimble by and by.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1240,"[' ""We\'ve got nothing nice for a lady to eat,"" said the old woman, in her coaxing tone.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1241,"[' ""And she\'s so hungry, sweet little lady.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1242,"['"" ""Here, my dear, try if you can eat a bit o\' this,"" said the younger woman, handing some of the stew on a brown dish with an iron spoon to Maggie, who, remembering that the old woman had seemed angry with her for not liking the bread-and-bacon, dared not refuse the stew, though fear had chased away her appetite.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1243,"[' Maggie Tulliver, you perceive, was by no means that well trained, well-informed young person that a small female of eight or nine necessarily is in these days; she had only been to school a year at St.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1244,"["" Ogg's, and had so few books that she sometimes read the dictionary; so that in travelling over her small mind you would have found the most unexpected ignorance as well as unexpected knowledge.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1245,"["" From having considered them very respectful companions, amenable to instruction, she had begun to think that they meant perhaps to kill her as soon as it was dark, and cut up her body for gradual cooking; the suspicion crossed her that the fierce- eyed old man was in fact the Devil, who might drop that transparent disguise at any moment, and turn either into the grinning blacksmith, or else a fiery-eyed monster with dragon's wings.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1246,"[' It was no use trying to eat the stew, and yet the thing she most dreaded was to offend the gypsies, by betraying her extremely unfavorable opinion of them; and she wondered, with a keenness of interest that no theologian could have exceeded, whether, if the Devil were really present, he would know her thoughts.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1247,"[' you don\'t like the smell of it, my dear,"" said the young woman, observing that Maggie did not even take a spoonful of the stew.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1248,"[' ""Try a bit, come.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1249,"['"" ""No, thank you,"" said Maggie, summoning all her force for a desperate effort, and trying to smile in a friendly way.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1250,"[' I think I must go home now, and come again another day, and then I can bring you a basket with some jam-tarts and things.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1251,"['"" Maggie rose from her seat as she threw out this illusory prospect, devoutly hoping that Apollyon was gullible; but her hope sank when the old gypsy-woman said, ""Stop a bit, stop a bit, little lady; we\'ll take you home, all safe, when we\'ve done supper; you shall ride home, like a lady.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1252,"['"" Maggie sat down again, with little faith in this promise, though she presently saw the tall girl putting a bridle on the donkey, and throwing a couple of bags on his back.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1253,"[' ""Now, then, little missis,"" said the younger man, rising, and leading the donkey forward, ""tell us where you live; what\'s the name o\' the place?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1254,"['"" ""Dorlcote Mill is my home,"" said Maggie, eagerly.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1255,"["" a big mill a little way this side o' St.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1256,"["" Ogg's?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1257,"['"" ""Yes,"" said Maggie.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1258,"[' ""Here\'s your pretty bonnet,"" said the younger woman, putting that recently despised but now welcome article of costume on Maggie\'s head; ""and you\'ll say we\'ve been very good to you, won\'t you?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1259,"[' When the woman had patted her on the back, and said ""Good-by,"" the donkey, at a strong hint from the man\'s stick, set off at a rapid walk along the lane toward the point Maggie had come from an hour ago, while the tall girl and the rough urchin, also furnished with sticks, obligingly escorted them for the first hundred yards, with much screaming and thwacking.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1260,"[' And there was a finger-post at the corner,-3she had surely seen that finger-post before,-3""To St.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1261,"["" Ogg's, 2 miles.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1262,"['"" The gypsy really meant to take her home, then; he was probably a good man, after all, and might have been rather hurt at the thought that she didn\'t like coming with him alone.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1263,"[' ""Why, what\'s the meaning o\' this?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1264,"['"" he said, checking his horse, while Maggie slipped from the donkey and ran to her father\'s stirrup.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1265,"["" It's a good way to come after being on the tramp all day.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1266,"['"" ""Oh yes, father, he\'s been very good to bring me home,"" said Maggie,-3""a very kind, good man!']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1267,"['"" ""Here, then, my man,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1268,"[' Tulliver, taking out five shillings.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1269,"["" I couldn't afford to lose the little wench; here, lift her up before me.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1270,"['"" ""Why, Maggie, how\'s this, how\'s this?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1271,"['"" he said, as they rode along, while she laid her head against her father and sobbed.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1272,"[' ""How came you to be rambling about and lose yourself?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1273,"['"" ""Oh, father,"" sobbed Maggie, ""I ran away because I was so unhappy; Tom was so angry with me.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1274,"["" I couldn't bear it.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1275,"['"" ""Pooh, pooh,"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1276,"[' Tulliver, soothingly, ""you mustn\'t think o\' running away from father.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1277,"["" What 'ud father do without his little wench?""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1278,"['"" ""Oh no, I never will again, father-3never.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1279,"['"" Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1280,"[' Tulliver spoke his mind very strongly when he reached home that evening; and the effect was seen in the remarkable fact that Maggie never heard one reproach from her mother, or one taunt from Tom, about this foolish business of her running away to the gypsies.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1281,[' GLEGG AT HOME In order to see Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1282,[' and Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1283,"[' Glegg at home, we must enter the town of St.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1284,"["" Ogg's,-3that venerable town with the red fluted roofs and the broad warehouse gables, where the black ships unlade themselves of their burthens from the far north, and carry away, in exchange, the precious inland products, the well-crushed cheese and the soft fleeces which my refined readers have doubtless become acquainted with through the medium of the best classic pastorals.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1285,"[' It is one of those old, old towns which impress one as a continuation and outgrowth of nature, as much as the nests of the bower-birds or the winding galleries of the white ants; a town which carries the traces of its long growth and history like a millennial tree, and has sprung up and developed in the same spot between the river and the low hill from the time when the Roman legions turned their backs on it from the camp on the hillside, and the long-haired sea- kings came up the river and looked with fierce, eager eyes at the fatness of the land.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1286,"[' It is a town ""familiar with forgotten years.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1287,"['"" The shadow of the Saxon hero-king still walks there fitfully, reviewing the scenes of his youth and love-time, and is met by the gloomier shadow of the dreadful heathen Dane, who was stabbed in the midst of his warriors by the sword of an invisible avenger, and who rises on autumn evenings like a white mist from his tumulus on the hill, and hovers in the court of the old hall by the river-side, the spot where he was thus miraculously slain in the days before the old hall was built.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1288,"[' It was the Normans who began to build that fine old hall, which is, like the town, telling of the thoughts and hands of widely sundered generations; but it is all so old that we look with loving pardon at its inconsistencies, and are well content that they who built the stone oriel, and they who built the Gothic façade and towers of finest small brickwork with the trefoil ornament, and the windows and battlements defined with stone, did not sacreligiously pull down the ancient half-timbered body with its oak-roofed banqueting-hall.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1289,"[' Yet it was witnessed in the floods of aftertime, that at the coming on of eventide, Ogg the son of Beorl was always seen with his boat upon the wide-spreading waters, and the Blessed Virgin sat in the prow, shedding a light around as of the moon in its brightness, so that the rowers in the gathering darkness took heart and pulled anew.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1290,"['"" This legend, one sees, reflects from a far-off time the visitation of the floods, which, even when they left human life untouched, were widely fatal to the helpless cattle, and swept as sudden death over all smaller living things.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1291,"[' Everywhere the brick houses have a mellow look, and in Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1292,"["" Glegg's day there was no incongruous new-fashioned smartness, no plate-glass in shop- windows, no fresh stucco-facing or other fallacious attempt to make fine old red St.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1293,"["" Ogg's wear the air of a town that sprang up yesterday.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1294,"[' Surely the time was gone forever when the broad river could bring up unwelcome ships; Russia was only the place where the linseed came from,-3the more the better,-3making grist for the great vertical millstones with their scythe-like arms, roaring and grinding and carefully sweeping as if an informing soul were in them.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1295,[' Public spirit was not held in high esteem at St.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1296,"["" Ogg's, and men who busied themselves with political questions were regarded with some suspicion, as dangerous characters; they were usually persons who had little or no business of their own to manage, or, if they had, were likely enough to become insolvent.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1297,[' This was the general aspect of things at St.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1298,"["" Ogg's in Mrs.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1299,"["" Glegg's day, and at that particular period in her family history when she had had her quarrel with Mr.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1300,[' Tulliver.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1301,"[' It was a time when ignorance was much more comfortable than at present, and was received with all the honors in very good society, without being obliged to dress itself in an elaborate costume of knowledge; a time when cheap periodicals were not, and when country surgeons never thought of asking their female patients if they were fond of reading, but simply took it for granted that they preferred gossip; a time when ladies in rich silk gowns wore large pockets, in which they carried a mutton- bone to secure them against cramp.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1302,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1303,"[' Glegg carried such a bone, which she had inherited from her grandmother with a brocaded gown that would stand up empty, like a suit of armor, and a silver- headed walking-stick; for the Dodson family had been respectable for many generations.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1304,[' Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1305,[' Glegg had both a front and a back parlor in her excellent house at St.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1306,"["" Ogg's, so that she had two points of view from which she could observe the weakness of her fellow-beings, and reinforce her thankfulness for her own exceptional strength of mind.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1307,"[' From her front window she could look down the Tofton Road, leading out of St.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1308,"[' Ogg\'s, and note the growing tendency to ""gadding about"" in the wives of men not retired from business, together with a practice of wearing woven cotton stockings, which opened a dreary prospect for the coming generation; and from her back windows she could look down the pleasant garden and orchard which stretched to the river, and observe the folly of Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1309,"[' Glegg in spending his time among ""them flowers and vegetables.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1310,"['"" For Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1311,"[' Glegg, having retired from active business as a wool-stapler for the purpose of enjoying himself through the rest of his life, had found this last occupation so much more severe than his business, that he had been driven into amateur hard labor as a dissipation, and habitually relaxed by doing the work of two ordinary gardeners.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1312,"[' On the one hand, he surprised himself by his discoveries in natural history, finding that his piece of garden-ground contained wonderful caterpillars, slugs, and insects, which, so far as he had heard, had never before attracted human observation; and he noticed remarkable coincidences between these zoological phenomena and the great events of that time,-3as, for example, that before the burning of York Minster there had been mysterious serpentine marks on the leaves of the rose-trees, together with an unusual prevalence of slugs, which he had been puzzled to know the meaning of, until it flashed upon him with this melancholy conflagration.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1313,[' There was no humbug or hypocrisy about Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1314,"[' Glegg; his eyes would have watered with true feeling over the sale of a widow\'s furniture, which a five-pound note from his side pocket would have prevented; but a donation of five pounds to a person ""in a small way of life"" would have seemed to him a mad kind of lavishness rather than ""charity,"" which had always presented itself to him as a contribution of small aids, not a neutralizing of misfortune.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1315,[' And Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1316,"["" Glegg was just as fond of saving other people's money as his own; he would have ridden as far round to avoid a turnpike when his expenses were to be paid for him, as when they were to come out of his own pocket, and was quite zealous in trying to induce indifferent acquaintances to adopt a cheap substitute for blacking.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1317,"[' This inalienable habit of saving, as an end in itself, belonged to the industrious men of business of a former generation, who made their fortunes slowly, almost as the tracking of the fox belongs to the harrier,-3it constituted them a ""race,"" which is nearly lost in these days of rapid money-getting, when lavishness comes close on the back of want.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1318,[' Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1319,"["" Glegg was one of these men, found so impracticable by chancellors of the exchequer; and knowing this, you will be the better able to understand why he had not swerved from the conviction that he had made an eligible marriage, in spite of the too-pungent seasoning that nature had given to the eldest Miss Dodson's virtues.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1320,"[' A man with an affectionate disposition, who finds a wife to concur with his fundamental idea of life, easily comes to persuade himself that no other woman would have suited him so well, and does a little daily snapping and quarrelling without any sense of alienation.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1321,[' Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1322,"[' Glegg, being of a reflective turn, and no longer occupied with wool, had much wondering meditation on the peculiar constitution of the female mind as unfolded to him in his domestic life; and yet he thought Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1323,"["" Glegg's household ways a model for her sex.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1324,"[' Still, he went in to breakfast with some slight hope that, now Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1325,"[' Glegg had ""slept upon it,"" her anger might be subdued enough to give way to her usually strong sense of family decorum.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1326,[' But the absence of that cloud only left it more apparent that the cloud of severity remained; and Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1327,"[' Glegg, perceiving this, as he sat down to his milkporridge, which it was his old frugal habit to stem his morning hunger with, prudently resolved to leave the first remark to Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1328,"["" Glegg, lest, to so delicate an article as a lady's temper, the slightest touch should do mischief.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1329,"["" If this is the way I'm to be treated, I'd better ha' known it before my poor father died, and then, when I'd wanted a home, I should ha' gone elsewhere, as the choice was offered me.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1330,"['"" Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1331,"[' Glegg paused from his porridge and looked up, not with any new amazement, but simply with that quiet, habitual wonder with which we regard constant mysteries.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1332,"["" But I've allays heard as it's the husband's place to stand by the wife, instead o' rejoicing and triumphing when folks insult her.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1333,"['"" ""Now, what call have you to say that?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1334,"['"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1335,"[' Glegg, rather warmly, for though a kind man, he was not as meek as Moses.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1336,"["" I'd sooner you'd tell me to my face as you make light of me, than try to make out as everybody's in the right but me, and come to your breakfast in the morning, as I've hardly slept an hour this night, and sulk at me as if I was the dirt under your feet.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1337,"['"" ""Sulk at you?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1338,"['"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1339,"[' Glegg, in a tone of angry facetiousness.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1340,"[' It makes you look very small, though you can\'t see yourself,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1341,"[' Glegg, in a tone of energetic compassion.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1342,"[' ""The best sense I can talk to you is what I said last night,-3as you\'re i\' the wrong to think o\' calling in your money, when it\'s safe enough if you\'d let it alone, all because of a bit of a tiff, and I was in hopes you\'d ha\' altered your mind this morning.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1343,"[' ""I\'ll thank you for my cup o\' tea, now, Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1344,[' G.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1345,"[',"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1346,"[' Glegg, seeing that she did not proceed to give it him as usual, when he had finished his porridge.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1347,"["" Not but what I've allays conducted myself civil to your kin, and there isn't one of 'em can say the contrary, though my equils they aren't, and nobody shall make me say it.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1348,"['"" ""You\'d better leave finding fault wi\' my kin till you\'ve left off quarrelling with you own, Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1349,[' G.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1350,"[',"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1351,"[' Glegg, with angry sarcasm.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1352,"["" But, let me tell you, it's your disgrace.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1353,"['"" ""Did ever anybody hear the like i\' this parish?']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1354,"['"" said Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1355,"[' Glegg, getting hot.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1356,[' Mr.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1357,"[' Glegg pushed his tea from him, and tapped the table with both his hands.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1358,"[') ""Well, Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1359,"[' Glegg, if those are your feelings, it\'s best they should be known,"" said Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1360,"[' Glegg, taking off her napkin, and folding it in an excited manner.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1361,"[' And as to my being like a mad dog, it\'s well if you\'re not cried shame on by the county for your treatment of me, for it\'s what I can\'t bear, and I won\'t bear-3-3"" Here Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1362,"["" Glegg's voice intimated that she was going to cry, and breaking off from speech, she rang the bell violently.""]",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1363,[' I shall have gruel.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1364,"['"" Mrs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1365,"[' Glegg walked across the room to the small book-case, and took down Baxter\'s ""Saints\' Everlasting Rest,"" which she carried with her up-stairs.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1366,"[' It was the book she was accustomed to lay open before her on special occasions,-3on wet Sunday mornings, or when she heard of a death in the family, or when, as in this case, her quarrel with Mr.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1367,[' Glegg had been set an octave higher than usual.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19
1368,[' But Mrs.'],George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

1369,"[' Glegg carried something else up-stairs with her, which, together with the ""Saints\' Rest"" and the gruel, may have had some influence in gradually calming her feelings, and making it possible for her to endure existence on the ground-floor, shortly before tea- time.']",George Eliot,The Mill on the Floss,19

163,"[' The only sailor whose eyes could have been called green was a tall man who amused the crowd on the quay by calling out cheerfully every time the planks fell: ""All right!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
164,[' Mahony looked regretfully at his catapult and I had to suggest going home by train before he regained any cheerfulness.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
165,[' The sun went in behind some clouds and left us to our jaded thoughts and the crumbs of our provisions.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
166,[' When we had lain on the bank for some time without speaking I saw a man approaching from the far end of the field.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
167,[' When he passed at our feet he glanced up at us quickly and then continued his way.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
168,[' We followed him with our eyes and saw that when he had gone on for perhaps fifty paces he turned about and began to retrace his steps.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
169,"[' He walked towards us very slowly, always tapping the ground with his stick, so slowly that I thought he was looking for something in the grass.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
170,[' We answered him and he sat down beside us on the slope slowly and with great care.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
171,"[' He began to talk of the weather, saying that it would be a very hot summer and adding that the seasons had changed gready since he was a boy--a long time ago.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
172,"["" He said that the happiest time of one's life was undoubtedly one's schoolboy days and that he would give anything to be young again.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
173,[' While he expressed these sentiments which bored us a little we kept silent.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
174,[' Then he began to talk of school and of books.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
175,[' He asked us whether we had read the poetry of Thomas Moore or the works of Sir Walter Scott and Lord Lytton.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
176,"[' I pretended that I had read every book he mentioned so that in the end he said: ""Ah, I can see you are a bookworm like myself.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
177,"[' Now,"" he added, pointing to Mahony who was regarding us with open eyes, ""he is different; he goes in for games.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
178,"['"" He said he had all Sir Walter Scott\'s works and all Lord Lytton\'s works at home and never tired of reading them.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
179,"[' ""Of course,"" he said, ""there were some of Lord Lytton\'s works which boys couldn\'t read.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
180,"['"" Mahony asked why couldn\'t boys read them--a question which agitated and pained me because I was afraid the man would think I was as stupid as Mahony.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
181,"[' The man, however, only smiled.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
182,[' The man asked me how many I had.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
183,[' He did not believe me and said he was sure I must have one.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
184,"[' ""Every boy,"" he said, ""has a little sweetheart.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
185,"['"" His attitude on this point struck me as strangely liberal in a man of his age.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
186,[' In my heart I thought that what he said about boys and sweethearts was reasonable.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

187,"[' He began to speak to us about girls, saying what nice soft hair they had and how soft their hands were and how all girls were not so good as they seemed to be if one only knew.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
188,"[' There was nothing he liked, he said, so much as looking at a nice young girl, at her nice white hands and her beautiful soft hair.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

189,"[' He gave me the impression that he was repeating something which he had learned by heart or that, magnetised by some words of his own speech, his mind was slowly circling round and round in the same orbit.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

190,"[' At times he spoke as if he were simply alluding to some fact that everybody knew, and at times he lowered his voice and spoke mysteriously as if he were telling us something secret which he did not wish others to overhear.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

191,"[' He stood up slowly, saying that he had to leave us for a minute or so, a few minutes, and, without changing the direction of my gaze, I saw him walking slowly away from us towards the near end of the field.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
192,"["" Look what he's doing!""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
193,"['"" As I neither answered nor raised my eyes Mahony exclaimed again: ""I say.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
194,['.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
195,['.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
196,"["" He's a queer old josser!""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
197,"['"" ""In case he asks us for our names,"" I said ""let you be Murphy and I\'ll be Smith.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
198,"['"" We said nothing further to each other.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
199,[' I was still considering whether I would go away or not when the man came back and sat down beside us again.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
200,[' The man and I watched the chase.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
201,"[' Desisting from this, he began to wander about the far end of the field, aimlessly.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
202,[' After an interval the man spoke to me.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
203,[' He said that my friend was a very rough boy and asked did he get whipped often at school.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
204,"[' I was going to reply indignantly that we were not National School boys to be whipped, as he called it; but I remained silent.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
205,[' He began to speak on the subject of chastising boys.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
206,[' He said that when boys were that kind they ought to be whipped and well whipped.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
207,[' A slap on the hand or a box on the ear was no good: what he wanted was to get a nice warm whipping.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
208,[' As I did so I met the gaze of a pair of bottle-green eyes peering at me from under a twitching forehead.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
209,[' I turned my eyes away again.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
210,[' The man continued his monologue.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

211,[' He said that if ever he found a boy talking to girls or having a girl for a sweetheart he would whip him and whip him; and that would teach him not to be talking to girls.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

212,"[' He would love that, he said, better than anything in this world; and his voice, as he led me monotonously through the mystery, grew almost affectionate and seemed to plead with me that I should understand him.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
213,"[' Lest I should betray my agitation I delayed a few moments pretending to fix my shoe properly and then, saying that I was obliged to go, I bade him good-day.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
214,[' I went up the slope calmly but my heart was beating quickly with fear that he would seize me by the ankles.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
215,"[' When I reached the top of the slope I turned round and, without looking at him, called loudly across the field: ""Murphy!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
216,"['"" My voice had an accent of forced bravery in it and I was ashamed of my paltry stratagem.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
217,[' How my heart beat as he came running across the field to me!'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
218,[' And I was penitent; for in my heart I had always despised him a little.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

219,"[' An uninhabited house of two storeys stood at the blind end, detached from its neighbours in a square ground The other houses of the street, conscious of decent lives within them, gazed at one another with brown imperturbable faces.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
220,"[' The former tenant of our house, a priest, had died in the back drawing-room.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
221,"[' Air, musty from having been long enclosed, hung in all the rooms, and the waste room behind the kitchen was littered with old useless papers.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
222,[' He had been a very charitable priest; in his will he had left all his money to institutions and the furniture of his house to his sister.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
223,[' When the short days of winter came dusk fell before we had well eaten our dinners.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
224,[' When we met in the street the houses had grown sombre.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

225,"[' The career of our play brought us through the dark muddy lanes behind the houses where we ran the gauntlet of the rough tribes from the cottages, to the back doors of the dark dripping gardens where odours arose from the ashpits, to the dark odorous stables where a coachman smoothed and combed the horse or shook music from the buckled harness.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
226,[' When we returned to the street light from the kitchen windows had filled the areas.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
227,[' If my uncle was seen turning the corner we hid in the shadow until we had seen him safely housed.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
228,"["" Or if Mangan's sister came out on the doorstep to call her brother in to his tea we watched her from our shadow peer up and down the street.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
229,"[' She was waiting for us, her figure defined by the light from the half-opened door.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
230,[' Her brother always teased her before he obeyed and I stood by the railings looking at her.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
231,[' Every morning I lay on the floor in the front parlour watching her door.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
232,"[' I kept her brown figure always in my eye and, when we came near the point at which our ways diverged, I quickened my pace and passed her.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
233,[' On Saturday evenings when my aunt went marketing I had to go to carry some of the parcels.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

234,"["" We walked through the flaring streets, jostled by drunken men and bargaining women, amid the curses of labourers, the shrill litanies of shop-boys who stood on guard by the barrels of pigs' cheeks, the nasal chanting of street- singers, who sang a come-all-you about O'Donovan Rossa, or a ballad about the troubles in our native land.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
235,[' My eyes were often full of tears (I could not tell why) and at times a flood from my heart seemed to pour itself out into my bosom.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
236,[' I thought little of the future.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
237,"[' I did not know whether I would ever speak to her or not or, if I spoke to her, how I could tell her of my confused adoration.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
238,[' One evening I went into the back drawing-room in which the priest had died.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
239,[' It was a dark rainy evening and there was no sound in the house.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
240,[' I was thankful that I could see so little.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

241,"[' All my senses seemed to desire to veil themselves and, feeling that I was about to slip from them, I pressed the palms of my hands together until they trembled, murmuring: ""O love!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
242,[' When she addressed the first words to me I was so confused that I did not know what to answer.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
243,"[' It would be a splendid bazaar, she said she would love to go.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
244,"[' She could not go, she said, because there would be a retreat that week in her convent.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
245,"[' The light from the lamp opposite our door caught the white curve of her neck, lit up her hair that rested there and, falling, lit up the hand upon the railing.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
246,"[' ""If I go,"" I said, ""I will bring you something.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
247,"['"" What innumerable follies laid waste my waking and sleeping thoughts after that evening!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
248,[' At night in my bedroom and by day in the classroom her image came between me and the page I strove to read.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
249,[' I asked for leave to go to the bazaar on Saturday night.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
250,"["" I watched my master's face pass from amiability to sternness; he hoped I was not beginning to idle.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
251,"[' He was fussing at the hallstand, looking for the hat-brush, and answered me curtly: ""Yes, boy, I know.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
252,"['"" As he was in the hall I could not go into the front parlour and lie at the window.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
253,[' I left the house in bad humour and walked slowly towards the school.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
254,[' I sat staring at the clock for some time and.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

256,[' From the front window I saw my companions playing below in the street.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
257,"[' Their cries reached me weakened and indistinct and, leaning my forehead against the cool glass, I looked over at the dark house where she lived.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

258,"[' I may have stood there for an hour, seeing nothing but the brown-clad figure cast by my imagination, touched discreetly by the lamplight at the curved neck, at the hand upon the railings and at the border below the dress.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

262,"["" Mercer stood up to go: she was sorry she couldn't wait any longer, but it was after eight o'clock and she did not like to be out late as the night air was bad for her.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
263,"[' When she had gone I began to walk up and down the room, clenching my fists.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
264,"[' My aunt said: ""I\'m afraid you may put off your bazaar for this night of Our Lord.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
265,"['"" At nine o\'clock I heard my uncle\'s latchkey in the halldoor.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
266,[' When he was midway through his dinner I asked him to give me the money to go to the bazaar.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

268,"[' My aunt said to him energetically: ""Can\'t you give him the money and let him go?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
269,"["" You've kept him late enough as it is.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
270,"['"" My uncle said he was very sorry he had forgotten.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

284,"['"" ""Yes.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

290,"['"" Observing me the young lady came over and asked me did I wish to buy anything.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
291,"[' I looked humbly at the great jars that stood like eastern guards at either side of the dark entrance to the stall and murmured: ""No, thank you.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
292,"['"" The young lady changed the position of one of the vases and went back to the two young men.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
293,[' They began to talk of the same subject.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
294,[' Once or twice the young lady glanced at me over her shoulder.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
295,[' Then I turned away slowly and walked down the middle of the bazaar.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
296,[' I heard a voice call from one end of the gallery that the light was out.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
297,[' Gazing up into the darkness I saw myself as a creature driven and derided by vanity; and my eyes burned with anguish and anger.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
298,[' EVELINE SHE sat at the window watching the evening invade the avenue.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

299,[' The man out of the last house passed on his way home; she heard his footsteps clacking along the concrete pavement and afterwards crunching on the cinder path before the new red houses.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
300,"["" One time there used to be a field there in which they used to play every evening with other people's children.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
301,[' Then a man from Belfast bought the field and built houses in it--not like their little brown houses but bright brick houses with shining roofs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
302,"[' The children of the avenue used to play together in that field --the Devines, the Waters, the Dunns, little Keogh the cripple, she and her brothers and sisters.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

303,[' Her father used often to hunt them in out of the field with his blackthorn stick; but usually little Keogh used to keep nix and call out when he saw her father coming.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
304,[' That was a long time ago; she and her brothers and sisters were all grown up her mother was dead.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
305,"[' Now she was going to go away like the others, to leave her home.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
306,"[' She looked round the room, reviewing all its familiar objects which she had dusted once a week for so many years, wondering where on earth all the dust came from.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
307,[' He had been a school friend of her father.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
308,"[' Whenever he showed the photograph to a visitor her father used to pass it with a casual word: ""He is in Melbourne now.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
309,"['"" She had consented to go away, to leave her home.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
310,"[' O course she had to work hard, both in the house and at business.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
311,"[' ""Miss Hill, don\'t you see these ladies are waiting?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
312,"['"" ""Look lively, Miss Hill, please.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
313,"['"" She would not cry many tears at leaving the Stores.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
314,"[' But in her new home, in a distant unknown country, it would not be like that.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

315,"["" When they were growing up he had never gone for her like he used to go for Harry and Ernest, because she was a girl but latterly he had begun to threaten her and say what he would do to her only for her dead mother's sake.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
316,[' She always gave her entire wages--seven shillings--and Harry always sent up what he could but the trouble was to get any money from her father.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

317,"["" He said she used to squander the money, that she had no head, that he wasn't going to give her his hard-earned money to throw about the streets, and much more, for he was usually fairly bad on Saturday night.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
318,"["" In the end he would give her the money and ask her had she any intention of buying Sunday's dinner.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

319,"[' Then she had to rush out as quickly as she could and do her marketing, holding her black leather purse tightly in her hand as she elbowed her way through the crowds and returning home late under her load of provisions.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

320,[' She had hard work to keep the house together and to see that the two young children who had been left to hr charge went to school regularly and got their meals regularly.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
321,[' She was to go away with him by the night-boat to be his wife and to live with him in Buenos Ayres where he had a home waiting for her.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
322,[' How well she remembered the first time she had seen him; he was lodging in a house on the main road where she used to visit.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
323,"[' He was standing at the gate, his peaked cap pushed back on his head and his hair tumbled forward over a face of bronze.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
324,[' Then they had come to know each other.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
325,[' He took her to see The Bohemian Girl and she felt elated as she sat in an unaccustomed part of the theatre with him.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
326,[' He was awfully fond of music and sang a little.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
327,"[' People knew that they were courting and, when he sang about the lass that loves a sailor, she always felt pleasantly confused.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
328,[' First of all it had been an excitement for her to have a fellow and then she had begun to like him.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
329,"[' He had fallen on his feet in Buenos Ayres, he said, and had come over to the old country just for a holiday.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
330,"[' ""I know these sailor chaps,"" he said.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
331,"[' Her father was becoming old lately, she noticed; he would miss her.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
332,"[' Not long before, when she had been laid up for a day, he had read her out a ghost story and made toast for her at the fire.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
333,[' She remembered her father putting on her mothers bonnet to make the children laugh.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
334,"[' Her time was running out but she continued to sit by the window, leaning her head against the window curtain, inhaling the odour of dusty cretonne.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
335,[' Down far in the avenue she could hear a street organ playing.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

336,"[' She knew the air Strange that it should come that very night to remind her of the promise to her mother, her promise to keep the home together as long as she could.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

337,"["" She remembered the last night of her mother's illness; she was again in the close dark room at the other side of the hall and outside she heard a melancholy air of Italy.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
338,"[' She trembled as she heard again her mother\'s voice saying constantly with foolish insistence: ""Derevaun Seraun!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
339,"[' He held her hand and she knew that he was speaking to her, saying something about the passage over and over again.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
340,"[' She felt him seize her hand: ""Come!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
341,"['"" All the seas of the world tumbled about her heart.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
342,"[' She set her white face to him, passive, like a helpless animal.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
343,[' Ebd E-BooksDirectory.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
344,"['com AFTER THE RACE THE cars came scudding in towards Dublin, running evenly like pellets in the groove of the Naas Road.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

345,[' Segouin was in good humour because he had unexpectedly received some orders in advance (he was about to start a motor establishment in Paris) and Riviere was in good humour because he was to be appointed manager of the establishment; these two young men (who were cousins) were also in good humour because of the success of the French cars.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
346,"[' He was about twenty-six years of age, with a soft, light brown moustache and rather innocent-looking grey eyes.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
347,[' He had made his money as a butcher in Kingstown and by opening shops in Dublin and in the suburbs he had made his money many times over.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
348,[' Jimmy did not study very earnestly and took to bad courses for a while.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
349,[' He had money and he was popular; and he divided his time curiously between musical and motoring circles.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
350,[' Then he had been sent for a term to Cambridge to see a little life.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
351,"[' Such a person (as his father agreed) was well worth knowing, even if he had not been the charming companion he was.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

352,[' Decidedly Villona was in excellent spirits; he kept up a deep bass hum of melody for miles of the road The Frenchmen flung their laughter and light words over their shoulders and often Jimmy had to strain forward to catch the quick phrase.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
353,"[' This was not altogether pleasant for him, as he had nearly always to make a deft guess at the meaning and shout back a suitable answer in the face of a high wind.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
354,[' He had been seen by many of his friends that day in the company of these Continentals.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

355,"[' At the control Segouin had presented him to one of the French competitors and, in answer to his confused murmur of compliment, the swarthy face of the driver had disclosed a line of shining white teeth.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

356,"[' Segouin, perhaps, would not think it a great sum but Jimmy who, in spite of temporary errors, was at heart the inheritor of solid instincts knew well with what difficulty it had been got together.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

357,"[' Of course, the investment was a good one and Segouin had managed to give the impression that it was by a favour of friendship the mite of Irish money was to be included in the capital of the concern.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
358,"["" Jimmy set out to translate into days' work that lordly car in which he sat.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

359,[' The journey laid a magical finger on the genuine pulse of life and gallantly the machinery of human nerves strove to answer the bounding courses of the swift blue animal.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
360,[' Near the Bank Segouin drew up and Jimmy and his friend alighted.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
361,[' A little knot of people collected on the footpath to pay homage to the snorting motor.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
362,"["" The party was to dine together that evening in Segouin's hotel and, meanwhile, Jimmy and his friend, who was staying with him, were to go home to dress.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
363,[' The car steered out slowly for Grafton Street while the two young men pushed their way through the knot of gazers.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

364,"[' They walked northward with a curious feeling of disappointment in the exercise, while the city hung its pale globes of light above them in a haze of summer evening.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

365,"[' Jimmy, too, looked very well when he was dressed and, as he stood in the hall giving a last equation to the bows of his dress tie, his father may have felt even commercially satisfied at having secured for his son qualities often unpurchaseable.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

366,"[' His father, therefore, was unusually friendly with Villona and his manner expressed a real respect for foreign accomplishments; but this subtlety of his host was probably lost upon the Hungarian, who was beginning to have a sharp desire for his dinner.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
367,[' The party was increased by a young Englishman named Routh whom Jimmy had seen with Segouin at Cambridge.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
368,[' The young men supped in a snug room lit by electric candle lamps.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
369,[' They talked volubly and with little reserve.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
370,[' The five young men had various tastes and their tongues had been loosened.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
371,"[' Villona, with immense respect, began to discover to the mildly surprised Englishman the beauties of the English madrigal, deploring the loss of old instruments.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
372,"[' Jimmy, under generous influences, felt the buried zeal of his father wake to life within him: he aroused the torpid Routh at last.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
373,[' At the corner of Grafton Street a short fat man was putting two handsome ladies on a car in charge of another fat man.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
374,[' The car drove off and the short fat man caught sight of the party.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
375,"[' They took the train at Westland Row and in a few seconds, as it seemed to Jimmy, they were walking out of Kingstown Station.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
376,"[' The ticket-collector saluted Jimmy; he was an old man: ""Fine night, sir!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

567,"["" He was a shabby stooped little drunkard with a white face and a white moustache white eyebrows, pencilled above his little eyes, which were veined and raw; and all day long he sat in the bailiff's room, waiting to be put on a job.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
568,[' Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
569,"[' Mooney, who had taken what remained of her money out of the butcher business and set up a boarding house in Hardwicke Street, was a big imposing woman.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
570,"[' Her house had a floating population made up of tourists from Liverpool and the Isle of Man and, occasionally, artistes from the music halls.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
571,"[' She governed the house cunningly and firmly, knew when to give credit, when to be stern and when to let things pass.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

573,[' Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
574,"["" Mooney's young men paid fifteen shillings a week for board and lodgings (beer or stout at dinner excluded).""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
575,"["" Jack Mooney, the Madam's son, who was clerk to a commission agent in Fleet Street, had the reputation of being a hard case.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
576,"["" He was fond of using soldiers' obscenities: usually he came home in the small hours.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

583,"["" Mooney had first sent her daughter to be a typist in a corn-factor's office but, as a disreputable sheriff's man used to come every other day to the office, asking to be allowed to say a word to his daughter, she had taken her daughter home again and set her to do housework.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
584,[' As Polly was very lively the intention was to give her the run of the young men.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

587,"[' Mooney, who was a shrewd judge, knew that the young men were only passing the time away: none of them meant business.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
588,[' Things went on so for a long time and Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
589,[' Mooney began to think of sending Polly back to typewriting when she noticed that something was going on between Polly and one of the young men.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

591,[' Mooney did not intervene.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

597,[' Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
598,[' Mooney sat in the straw arm-chair and watched the servant Mary remove the breakfast things.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

599,"[' When the table was cleared, the broken bread collected, the sugar and butter safe under lock and key, she began to reconstruct the interview which she had had the night before with Polly.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

600,"["" She had been made awkward by her not wishing to receive the news in too cavalier a fashion or to seem to have connived and Polly had been made awkward not merely because allusions of that kind always made her awkward but also because she did not wish it to be thought that in her wise innocence she had divined the intention behind her mother's tolerance.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
601,[' Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

602,"["" Mooney glanced instinctively at the little gilt clock on the mantelpiece as soon as she had become aware through her revery that the bells of George's Church had stopped ringing.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
603,[' It was seventeen minutes past eleven: she would have lots of time to have the matter out with Mr.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
604,[' Doran and then catch short twelve at Marlborough Street.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
605,"[' She had allowed him to live beneath her roof, assuming that he was a man of honour and he had simply abused her hospitality.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

606,"[' He was thirty-four or thirty-five years of age, so that youth could not be pleaded as his excuse; nor could ignorance be his excuse since he was a man who had seen something of the world.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
607,"[' It is all very well for the man: he can go his ways as if nothing had happened, having had his moment of pleasure, but the girl has to bear the brunt.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

642,"["" The music-hall artiste, a little paler than usual, kept smiling and saying that there was no harm meant: but Jack kept shouting at him that if any fellow tried that sort of a game on with his sister he'd bloody well put his teeth down his throat, so he would.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
643,"[' Polly sat for a little time on the side of the bed, crying.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

655,"["" Little Chandler's thoughts ever since lunch-time had been of his meeting with Gallaher, of Gallaher's invitation and of the great city London where Gallaher lived.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
656,"[' He was called Little Chandler because, though he was but slightly under the average stature, he gave one the idea of being a little man.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
657,"[' His hands were white and small, his frame was fragile, his voice was quiet and his manners were refined.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
658,"["" As he sat at his desk in the King's Inns he thought what changes those eight years had brought.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
659,[' He turned often from his tiresome writing to gaze out of the office window.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

660,[' It cast a shower of kindly golden dust on the untidy nurses and decrepit old men who drowsed on the benches; it flickered upon all the moving figures-- on the children who ran screaming along the gravel paths and on everyone who passed through the gardens.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

661,"[' He had bought them in his bachelor days and many an evening, as he sat in the little room off the hall, he had been tempted to take one down from the bookshelf and read out something to his wife.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
662,[' When his hour had struck he stood up and took leave of his desk and of his fellow-clerks punctiliously.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
663,[' They stood or ran in the roadway or crawled up the steps before the gaping doors or squatted like mice upon the thresholds.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
664,[' Little Chandler gave them no thought.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

665,[' He picked his way deftly through all that minute vermin-like life and under the shadow of the gaunt spectral mansions in which the old nobility of Dublin had roystered.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
666,[' He knew that people went there after the theatre to eat oysters and drink liqueurs; and he had heard that the waiters there spoke French and German.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
667,"[' Walking swiftly by at night he had seen cabs drawn up before the door and richly dressed ladies, escorted by cavaliers, alight and enter quickly.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
668,"[' Their faces were powdered and they caught up their dresses, when they touched earth, like alarmed Atalantas.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
669,[' He had always passed without turning his head to look.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

670,[' It was his habit to walk swiftly in the street even by day and whenever he found himself in the city late at night he hurried on his way apprehensively and excitedly.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

671,"[' He chose the darkest and narrowest streets and, as he walked boldly forward, the silence that was spread about his footsteps troubled him, the wandering, silent figures troubled him; and at times a sound of low fugitive laughter made him tremble like a leaf.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
672,[' He turned to the right towards Capel Street.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
673,"[' Still, now that he reviewed the past, Little Chandler could remember many signs of future greatness in his friend.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
674,"[' People used to say that Ignatius Gallaher was wild Of course, he did mix with a rakish set of fellows at that time.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
675,"["" Even when he was out at elbows and at his wits' end for money he kept up a bold face.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

676,"[' Little Chandler remembered (and the remembrance brought a slight flush of pride to his cheek) one of Ignatius Gallaher\'s sayings when he was in a tight corner: Half time now, boys,"" he used to say light-heartedly.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
677,[' Little Chandler quickened his pace.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
678,[' For the first time in his life he felt himself superior to the people he passed.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
679,[' For the first time his soul revolted against the dull inelegance of Capel Street.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
680,[' As he crossed Grattan Bridge he looked down the river towards the lower quays and pitied the poor stunted houses.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

681,"[' They seemed to him a band of tramps, huddled together along the riverbanks, their old coats covered with dust and soot, stupefied by the panorama of sunset and waiting for the first chill of night bid them arise, shake themselves and begone.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
682,[' He was not sure what idea he wished to express but the thought that a poetic moment had touched him took life within him like an infant hope.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
683,[' A light began to tremble on the horizon of his mind.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
684,[' His temperament might be said to be just at the point of maturity.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
685,[' If he could give expression to it in a book of poems perhaps men would listen.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
686,[' He could not sway the crowd but he might appeal to a little circle of kindred minds.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
687,[' He pursued his revery so ardently that he passed his street and had to turn back.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
688,"["" As he came near Corless's his former agitation began to overmaster him and he halted before the door in indecision.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

689,"[' He looked about him, but his sight was confused by the shining of many red and green wine-glasses The bar seemed to him to be full of people and he felt that the people were observing him curiously.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

690,"[' He glanced quickly to right and left (frowning slightly to make his errand appear serious), but when his sight cleared a little he saw that nobody had turned to look at him: and there, sure enough, was Ignatius Gallaher leaning with his back against the counter and his feet planted far apart.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

774,"['"" Little Chandler blushed and smiled.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
775,"[' ""Yes,"" he said.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
776,"[' ""I was married last May twelve months.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

824,"["" The adventure of meeting Gallaher after eight years, of finding himself with Gallaher in Corless's surrounded by lights and noise, of listening to Gallaher's stories and of sharing for a brief space Gallaher's vagrant and triumphant life, upset the equipoise of his sensitive nature.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
825,"["" He felt acutely the contrast between his own life and his friend's and it seemed to him unjust.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

826,"[' He was sure that he could do something better than his friend had ever done, or could ever do, something higher than mere tawdry journalism if he only got the chance.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
827,[' Little Chandler pushed one glass towards his friend and took up the other boldly.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
828,"[' ""Who knows?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
829,"['"" he said, as they lifted their glasses.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
830,"[' ""When you come next year I may have the pleasure of wishing long life and happiness to Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

833,"['"" Ignatius Gallaher in the act of drinking closed one eye expressively over the rim of his glass.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
834,"[' When he had drunk he smacked his lips decisively, set down his glass and said: ""No blooming fear of that, my boy.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
835,"["" I'm going to have my fling first and see a bit of life and the world before I put my head in the sack -- if I ever do.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
836,"['"" ""Some day you will,"" said Little Chandler calmly.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

862,"["" How he had suffered that day, waiting at the shop door until the shop was empty, standing at the counter and trying to appear at his ease while the girl piled ladies' blouses before him, paying at the desk and forgetting to take up the odd penny of his change, being called back by the cashier, and finally, striving to hide his blushes as he left the shop by examining the parcel to see if it was securely tied.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

863,[' When he brought the blouse home Annie kissed him and said it was very pretty and stylish; but when she heard the price she threw the blouse on the table and said it was a regular swindle to charge ten and elevenpence for it.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
