1092,"[""com CLAY THE matron had given her leave to go out as soon as the women's tea was over and Maria looked forward to her evening out.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1093,[' The kitchen was spick and span: the cook said you could see yourself in the big copper boilers.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1094,[' These barmbracks seemed uncut; but if you went closer you would see that they had been cut into long thick even slices and were ready to be handed round at tea.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1095,"[' She talked a little through her nose, always soothingly: ""Yes, my dear,"" and ""No, my dear.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1096,"['"" She was always sent for when the women quarrelled Over their tubs and always succeeded in making peace.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1097,"[' One day the matron had said to her: ""Maria, you are a veritable peace-maker!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1098,"['"" And the sub-matron and two of the Board ladies had heard the compliment.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1099,"["" Often he had wanted her to go and live with them;-but she would have felt herself in the way (though Joe's wife was ever so nice with her) and she had become accustomed to the life of the laundry.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1100,"[' She had nursed him and Alphy too; and Joe used often say: ""Mamma is mamma but Maria is my proper mother.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1101,"['"" After the break-up at home the boys had got her that position in the Dublin by Lamplight laundry, and she liked it.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1102,"[' She used to have such a bad opinion of Protestants but now she thought they were very nice people, a little quiet and serious, but still very nice people to live with.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1103,[' Then she had her plants in the conservatory and she liked looking after them.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1104,"["" There was one thing she didn't like and that was the tracts on the walks; but the matron was such a nice person to deal with, so genteel.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1105,"["" When the cook told her everything was ready she went into the women's room and began to pull the big bell.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1106,"[' In a few minutes the women began to come in by twos and threes, wiping their steaming hands in their petticoats and pulling down the sleeves of their blouses over their red steaming arms.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1107,"["" Lizzie Fleming said Maria was sure to get the ring and, though Fleming had said that for so many Hallow Eves, Maria had to laugh and say she didn't want any ring or man either; and when she laughed her grey-green eyes sparkled with disappointed shyness and the tip of her nose nearly met the tip of her chin.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1108,"["" Then Ginger Mooney lifted her mug of tea and proposed Maria's health while all the other women clattered with their mugs on the table, and said she was sorry she hadn't a sup of porter to drink it in.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1109,"[' And Maria laughed again till the tip of her nose nearly met the tip of her chin and till her minute body nearly shook itself asunder because she knew that Mooney meant well though, of course, she had the notions of a common woman.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1110,"["" But wasn't Maria glad when the women had finished their tea and the cook and the dummy had begun to clear away the tea- things!""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1111,"[' She went into her little bedroom and, remembering that the next morning was a mass morning, changed the hand of the alarm from seven to six.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1112,[' Then she took off her working skirt and her house-boots and laid her best skirt out on the bed and her tiny dress-boots beside the foot of the bed.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1113,"[' She changed her blouse too and, as she stood before the mirror, she thought of how she used to dress for mass on Sunday morning when she was a young girl; and she looked with quaint affection at the diminutive body which she had so often adorned, In spite of its years she found it a nice tidy little body.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1114,[' When she got outside the streets were shining with rain and she was glad of her old brown waterproof.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1115,"[' The tram was full and she had to sit on the little stool at the end of the car, facing all the people, with her toes barely touching the floor.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1116,[' She arranged in her mind all she was going to do and thought how much better it was to be independent and to have your own money in your pocket.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1117,[' She was sure they would but she could not help thinking what a pity it was Alphy and Joe were not speaking.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1118,[' They were always falling out now but when they were boys together they used to be the best of friends: but such was life.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1119,"["" She went into Downes's cake-shop but the shop was so full of people that it was a long time before she could get herself attended to.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1120,[' It was hard to know what to buy and all she could think of was cake.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1121,"["" She decided to buy some plumcake but Downes's plumcake had not enough almond icing on top of it so she went over to a shop in Henry Street.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1122,"[' Here she was a long time in suiting herself and the stylish young lady behind the counter, who was evidently a little annoyed by her, asked her was it wedding-cake she wanted to buy.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1123,"[' That made Maria blush and smile at the young lady; but the young lady took it all very seriously and finally cut a thick slice of plumcake, parcelled it up and said: ""Two-and-four, please.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1124,"['"" She thought she would have to stand in the Drumcondra tram because none of the young men seemed to notice her but an elderly gentleman made room for her.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1125,[' He was a stout gentleman and he wore a brown hard hat; he had a square red face and a greyish moustache.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1126,[' Maria thought he was a colonel-looking gentleman and she reflected how much more polite he was than the young men who simply stared straight before them.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1127,[' He supposed the bag was full of good things for the little ones and said it was only right that the youngsters should enjoy themselves while they were young.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1128,"[' He was very nice with her, and when she was getting out at the Canal Bridge she thanked him and bowed, and he bowed to her and raised his hat and smiled agreeably, and while she was going up along the terrace, bending her tiny head under the rain, she thought how easy it was to know a gentleman even when he has a drop taken.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1129,"[' Everybody said: ""0, here\'s Maria!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1130,"['"" when she came to Joe\'s house.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1131,"[' Joe was there, having come home from business, and all the children had their Sunday dresses on.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1132,[' There were two big girls in from next door and games were going on.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1133,"[' Maria gave the bag of cakes to the eldest boy, Alphy, to divide and Mrs.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1134,"[' Donnelly said it was too good of her to bring such a big bag of cakes and made all the children say: ""Thanks, Maria.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1135,"['"" But Maria said she had brought something special for papa and mamma, something they would be sure to like, and she began to look for her plumcake.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1136,"[' Then she asked all the children had any of them eaten it--by mistake, of course--but the children all said no and looked as if they did not like to eat cakes if they were to be accused of stealing.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1137,[' Everybody had a solution for the mystery and Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1138,[' Donnelly said it was plain that Maria had left it behind her in the tram.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1139,[' At the thought of the failure of her little surprise and of the two and fourpence she had thrown away for nothing she nearly cried outright.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1140,"["" But Joe said it didn't matter and made her sit down by the fire.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1141,"[' He told her all that went on in his office, repeating for her a smart answer which he had made to the manager.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1142,[' Maria did not understand why Joe laughed so much over the answer he had made but she said that the manager must have been a very overbearing person to deal with.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1143,"["" Joe said he wasn't so bad when you knew how to take him, that he was a decent sort so long as you didn't rub him the wrong way.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1144,[' Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1145,[' Donnelly played the piano for the children and they danced and sang.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1146,[' Then the two next-door girls handed round the nuts.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1147,[' Nobody could find the nutcrackers and Joe was nearly getting cross over it and asked how did they expect Maria to crack nuts without a nutcracker.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1148,"["" But Maria said she didn't like nuts and that they weren't to bother about her.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1149,[' Then Joe asked would she take a bottle of stout and Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1150,[' Donnelly said there was port wine too in the house if she would prefer that.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1151,"["" Maria said she would rather they didn't ask her to take anything: but Joe insisted.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1152,[' So Maria let him have his way and they sat by the fire talking over old times and Maria thought she would put in a good word for Alphy.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1153,[' But Joe cried that God might strike him stone dead if ever he spoke a word to his brother again and Maria said she was sorry she had mentioned the matter.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1154,[' Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1155,[' Donnelly told her husband it was a great shame for him to speak that way of his own flesh and blood but Joe said that Alphy was no brother of his and there was nearly being a row on the head of it.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1156,[' But Joe said he would not lose his temper on account of the night it was and asked his wife to open some more stout.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1157,[' Maria was delighted to see the children so merry and Joe and his wife in such good spirits.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1158,[' One got the prayer- book and the other three got the water; and when one of the next- door girls got the ring Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1159,"[' Donnelly shook her finger at the blushing girl as much as to say: 0, I know all about it!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1160,[' They led her up to the table amid laughing and joking and she put her hand out in the air as she was told to do.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1161,[' She felt a soft wet substance with her fingers and was surprised that nobody spoke or took off her bandage.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1162,"[' Somebody said something about the garden, and at last Mrs.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1163,[' Donnelly said something very cross to one of the next-door girls and told her to throw it out at once: that was no play.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1164,[' After that Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1165,"["" Donnelly played Miss McCloud's Reel for the children and Joe made Maria take a glass of wine.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1166,[' Soon they were all quite merry again and Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1167,[' Donnelly said Maria would enter a convent before the year was out because she had got the prayer- book.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1168,"[' Maria had never seen Joe so nice to her as he was that night, so full of pleasant talk and reminiscences.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1169,[' She said they were all very good to her.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1170,"[' At last the children grew tired and sleepy and Joe asked Maria would she not sing some little song before she went, one of the old songs.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1171,[' Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1172,"[' Donnelly said ""Do, please, Maria!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1173,"['"" and so Maria had to get up and stand beside the piano.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1174,[' Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1175,"["" Donnelly bade the children be quiet and listen to Maria's song.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1176,"[' Then she played the prelude and said ""Now, Maria!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1177,"['"" and Maria, blushing very much began to sing in a tiny quavering voice.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1178,"[' She sang I Dreamt that I Dwelt, and when she came to the second verse she sang again: I dreamt that I dwelt in marble halls With vassals and serfs at my side And of all who assembled within those walls That I was the hope and the pride.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1179,"[' He said that there was no time like the long ago and no music for him like poor old Balfe, whatever other people might say; and his eyes filled up so much with tears that he could not find what he was looking for and in the end he had to ask his wife to tell him where the corkscrew was.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1180,"[' JAMES DUFFY lived in Chapelizod because he wished to live as far as possible from the city of which he was a citizen and because he found all the other suburbs of Dublin mean, modern and pretentious.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1181,[' He lived in an old sombre house and from his windows he could look into the disused distillery or upwards along the shallow river on which Dublin is built.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1182,"[' He had himself bought every article of furniture in the room: a black iron bedstead, an iron washstand, four cane chairs, a clothes- rack, a coal-scuttle, a fender and irons and a square table on which lay a double desk.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1183,[' A little hand-mirror hung above the washstand and during the day a white-shaded lamp stood as the sole ornament of the mantelpiece.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1184,"["" In the desk lay a manuscript translation of Hauptmann's Michael Kramer, the stage directions of which were written in purple ink, and a little sheaf of papers held together by a brass pin.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1185,"[' His face, which carried the entire tale of his years, was of the brown tint of Dublin streets.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1186,[' On his long and rather large head grew dry black hair and a tawny moustache did not quite cover an unamiable mouth.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1187,"[' His cheekbones also gave his face a harsh character; but there was no harshness in the eyes which, looking at the world from under their tawny eyebrows, gave the impression of a man ever alert to greet a redeeming instinct in others but often disappointed.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1188,"[' He lived at a little distance from his body, regarding his own acts with doubtful side-glasses.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1189,"["" At midday he went to Dan Burke's and took his lunch--a bottle of lager beer and a small trayful of arrowroot biscuits.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1190,"["" He dined in an eating-house in George's Street where he felt himself safe from the society o Dublin's gilded youth and where there was a certain plain honesty in the bill of fare.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1191,"["" His liking for Mozart's music brought him sometimes to an opera or a concert: these were the only dissipations of his life.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1192,"[' The house, thinly peopled and silent, gave distressing prophecy of failure.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1193,"[' The lady who sat next him looked round at the deserted house once or twice and then said: ""What a pity there is such a poor house tonight!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1194,"["" It's so hard on people to have to sing to empty benches.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1195,"['"" He took the remark as an invitation to talk.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1196,[' When he learned that the young girl beside her was her daughter he judged her to be a year or so younger than himself.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1197,"[' Their gaze began with a defiant note but was confused by what seemed a deliberate swoon of the pupil into the iris, revealing for an instant a temperament of great sensibility.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1198,[' This was the first of many meetings; they met always in the evening and chose the most quiet quarters for their walks together.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1199,[' Mr.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1200,"[' Duffy, however, had a distaste for underhand ways and, finding that they were compelled to meet stealthily, he forced her to ask him to her house.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1201,"["" Captain Sinico encouraged his visits, thinking that his daughter's hand was in question.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1202,[' As the husband was often away and the daughter out giving music lessons Mr.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1203,"["" Duffy had many opportunities of enjoying the lady's society.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1204,[' He told her that for some time he had assisted at the meetings of an Irish Socialist Party where he had felt himself a unique figure amidst a score of sober workmen in a garret lit by an inefficient oil-lamp.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1205,"["" The workmen's discussions, he said, were too timorous; the interest they took in the question of wages was inordinate.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1206,"[' No social revolution, he told her, would be likely to strike Dublin for some centuries.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1207,[' She asked him why did he not write out his thoughts.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1208,[' He went often to her little cottage outside Dublin; often they spent their evenings alone.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1209,"[' Many times she allowed the dark to fall upon them, refraining from lighting the lamp.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1210,"["" He thought that in her eyes he would ascend to an angelical stature; and, as he attached the fervent nature of his companion more and more closely to him, he heard the strange impersonal voice which he recognised as his own, insisting on the soul's incurable loneliness.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1211,"[' The end of these discourses was that one night during which she had shown every sign of unusual excitement, Mrs.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1212,[' Sinico caught up his hand passionately and pressed it to her cheek.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1213,[' As he did not wish their last interview to be troubled by the influence of their ruined confessional they meet in a little cakeshop near the Parkgate.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1214,"[' They agreed to break off their intercourse: every bond, he said, is a bond to sorrow.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1215,"[' When they came out of the Park they walked in silence towards the tram; but here she began to tremble so violently that, fearing another collapse on her part, he bade her good-bye quickly and left her.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1216,[' Some new pieces of music encumbered the music-stand in the lower room and on his shelves stood two volumes by Nietzsche: Thus Spake Zarathustra and The Gay Science.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1217,"[' One of his sentences, written two months after his last interview with Mrs.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1218,"[' Sinico, read: Love between man and man is impossible because there must not be sexual intercourse and friendship between man and woman is impossible because there must be sexual intercourse.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1219,"["" And still every morning he went into the city by tram and every evening walked home from the city after having dined moderately in George's Street and read the evening paper for dessert.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1220,[' One evening as he was about to put a morsel of corned beef and cabbage into his mouth his hand stopped.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1221,[' His eyes fixed themselves on a paragraph in the evening paper which he had propped against the water-carafe.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1222,"[' Then he drank a glass of water, pushed his plate to one side, doubled the paper down before him between his elbows and read the paragraph over and over again.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1223,[' The girl came over to him to ask was his dinner not properly cooked.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1224,[' He said it was very good and ate a few mouthfuls of it with difficulty.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1225,"[' When he reached his house he went up at once to his bedroom and, taking the paper from his pocket, read the paragraph again by the failing light of the window.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1226,[' This was the paragraph: DEATH OF A LADY AT SYDNEY PARADE A PAINFUL CASE Today at the City of Dublin Hospital the Deputy Coroner (in the absence of Mr.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1227,[' Leverett) held an inquest on the body of Mrs.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1228,"[' Emily Sinico, aged forty-three years, who was killed at Sydney Parade Station yesterday evening.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1229,"["" The evidence showed that the deceased lady, while attempting to cross the line, was knocked down by the engine of the ten o'clock slow train from Kingstown, thereby sustaining injuries of the head and right side which led to her death.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1230,"["" On hearing the guard's whistle he set the train in motion and a second or two afterwards brought it to rest in response to loud cries.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1231,[' He had the body taken to the waiting-room pending the arrival of the ambulance.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1232,[' Dr.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1233,"[' Halpin, assistant house surgeon of the City of Dublin Hospital, stated that the deceased had two lower ribs fractured and had sustained severe contusions of the right shoulder.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1234,"[' The company had always taken every precaution to prevent people crossing the lines except by the bridges, both by placing notices in every station and by the use of patent spring gates at level crossings.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1235,"[' The deceased had been in the habit of crossing the lines late at night from platform to platform and, in view of certain other circumstances of the case, he did not think the railway officials were to blame.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1236,[' They had been married for twenty-two years and had lived happily until about two years ago when his wife began to be rather intemperate in her habits.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1237,[' Miss Mary Sinico said that of late her mother had been in the habit of going out at night to buy spirits.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1238,"[' The Deputy Coroner said it was a most painful case, and expressed great sympathy with Captain Sinico and his daughter.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1239,[' Mr.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1240,[' Duffy raised his eyes from the paper and gazed out of his window on the cheerless evening landscape.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1241,[' The river lay quiet beside the empty distillery and from time to time a light appeared in some house on the Lucan road.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1242,[' As the light failed and his memory began to wander he thought her hand touched his.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1243,[' When he came to the public-house at Chapelizod Bridge he went in and ordered a hot punch.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1244,[' He sat a long time over it.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1245,"[' As he sat there, living over his life with her and evoking alternately the two images in which he now conceived her, he realised that she was dead, that she had ceased to exist, that she had become a memory.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1246,"[' Now that she was gone he understood how lonely her life must have been, sitting night after night alone in that room.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1247,"[' At moments he seemed to feel her voice touch his ear, her hand touch his.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1248,"[' When he gained the crest of the Magazine Hill he halted and looked along the river towards Dublin, the lights of which burned redly and hospitably in the cold night.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1249,"[' He looked down the slope and, at the base, in the shadow of the wall of the Park, he saw some human figures lying.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1250,"[' One human being had seemed to love him and he had denied her life and happiness: he had sentenced her to ignominy, a death of shame.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1251,"[' He turned his eyes to the grey gleaming river, winding along towards Dublin.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1252,"[' Beyond the river he saw a goods train winding out of Kingsbridge Station, like a worm with a fiery head winding through the darkness, obstinately and laboriously.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1253,"[' He turned back the way he had come, the rhythm of the engine pounding in his ears.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1254,[' He could not feel her near him in the darkness nor her voice touch his ear.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1255,[' IVY DAY IN THE COMMITTEE ROOM OLD JACK raked the cinders together with a piece of cardboard and spread them judiciously over the whitening dome of coals.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1256,"[' When the dome was thinly covered his face lapsed into darkness but, as he set himself to fan the fire again, his crouching shadow ascended the opposite wall and his face slowly reemerged into light.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1257,"["" It was an old man's face, very bony and hairy.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1258,"[' The moist blue eyes blinked at the fire and the moist mouth fell open at times, munching once or twice mechanically when it closed.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1259,"[' When the cinders had caught he laid the piece of cardboard against the wall, sighed and said: ""That\'s better now, Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1260,"["" O'Connor.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1261,"['"" Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1262,"["" O'Connor, a grey-haired young man, whose face was disfigured by many blotches and pimples, had just brought the tobacco for a cigarette into a shapely cylinder but when spoken to he undid his handiwork meditatively.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1263,"["" Then he began to roll the tobacco again meditatively and after a moment's thought decided to lick the paper.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1264,"[' ""He didn\'t say.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1265,"['"" Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1266,"["" O'Connor put his cigarette into his mouth and began search his pockets.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1267,"[' ""I\'ll get you a match,"" said the old man.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1268,"[' ""Never mind, this\'ll do,"" said Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1269,"["" O'Connor.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1270,[' Mr.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1271,"["" O'Connor had been engaged by Tierney's agent to canvass one part of the ward but, as the weather was inclement and his boots let in the wet, he spent a great part of the day sitting by the fire in the Committee Room in Wicklow Street with Jack, the old caretaker.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1272,"[' The old man watched him attentively and then, taking up the piece of cardboard again, began to fan the fire slowly while his companion smoked.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1273,"[' ""Ah, yes,"" he said, continuing, ""it\'s hard to know what way to bring up children.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1274,"["" Now who'd think he'd turn out like that!""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1275,"[' ""Only I\'m an old man now I\'d change his tune for him.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1276,"[' The mother, you know, she cocks him up with this and that.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1277,['.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1278,['.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1279,['.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1280,"['"" ""That\'s what ruins children,"" said Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1281,"["" O'Connor.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1282,"[' ""To be sure it is,"" said the old man.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1283,"["" What's the world coming to when sons speaks that way to their fathers?""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1284,"['"" ""What age is he?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1285,"['"" said Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1286,"["" O'Connor.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1287,"[' ""Nineteen,"" said the old man.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1288,"["" 'You must get a job for yourself.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1289,"[""' But, sure, it's worse whenever he gets a job; he drinks it all.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1290,"['"" Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1291,"["" O'Connor shook his head in sympathy, and the old man fell silent, gazing into the fire.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1292,"[' Someone opened the door of the room and called out: ""Hello!']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1293,"["" Is this a Freemason's meeting?""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1294,"['"" ""Who\'s that?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1295,"['"" said the old man.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1296,"[' ""What are you doing in the dark?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1297,"['"" asked a voice.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1298,"[' ""Is that you, Hynes?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1299,"['"" asked Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1300,"["" O'Connor.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1301,"[' ""Yes.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1302,[' What are you doing in the dark?'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1303,"['"" said Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1304,[' Hynes.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1305,"[' He was a tall, slender young man with a light brown moustache.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1306,[' Imminent little drops of rain hung at the brim of his hat and the collar of his jacket-coat was turned up.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1307,"[' ""Well, Mat,"" he said to Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1308,"[' O\'Connor, ""how goes it?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1309,"['"" Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1310,"["" O'Connor shook his head.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20

1311,[' The old man left the hearth and after stumbling about the room returned with two candlesticks which he thrust one after the other into the fire and carried to the table.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1312,[' A denuded room came into view and the fire lost all its cheerful colour.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1313,[' In the middle of the room was a small table on which papers were heaped.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1314,[' Mr.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1315,"[' Hynes leaned against the mantelpiece and asked: ""Has he paid you yet?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1316,"['"" ""Not yet,"" said Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1317,"["" O'Connor.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1318,"[' Never fear,"" he said.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1319,"[' ""I hope he\'ll look smart about it if he means business,"" said Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1320,"["" O'Connor.""]",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1321,"[' ""What do you think, Jack?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1322,"['"" said Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1323,[' Hynes satirically to the old man.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1324,"[' The old man returned to his seat by the fire, saying: ""It isn\'t but he has it, anyway.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1325,[' Not like the other tinker.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1326,"['"" ""What other tinker?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1327,"['"" said Mr.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1328,[' Hynes.'],James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1329,"[' ""Colgan,"" said the old man scornfully.']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
1330,"[' ""It is because Colgan\'s a working--man you say that?']",James Joyce,Dubliners,20
