0,"['It was usual to adorn the front of your cap with a party badge, and in addition nearly every man wore a red or red and black handkerchief round his throat.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1,[' A militia column at that time was an extraordinary- looking rabble.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
2,[' I hate to think of what the militiamen must have gone through in the earlier months before anything was organized.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
3,[' I remember coming upon a newspaper of only about two months earlier in which one of the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

4,"[' The recruits were mostly boys of sixteen or seventeen from the back streets of Barcelona, full of revolutionary ardour but completely ignorant of the meaning of war.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

5,"[' The lieutenant who instructed us was a stout, fresh-faced, pleasant young man who had previously been a Regular Army officer, and still looked like one, with his smart carriage and spick-and- span uniform.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

6,"[' I had been told that foreigners were not obliged to attend -instruction-(the Spaniards, I noticed, had a pathetic belief that all foreigners knew more of military matters than themselves), but naturally I turned out with the others.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
7,[' I was very anxious to learn how to use a machine-gun; it was a weapon I had never had a chance to handle.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

8,"[' The so-called instruction was simply parade-ground drill of the most antiquated, stupid kind; right turn, left turn, about turn, marching at attention in column of threes and all the rest of that useless nonsense which I had learned when I was fifteen years old.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

10,"[' Yet this mob of eager children, who were going to be thrown into the front line in a few days-time, were not even taught how to fire a rifle or pull the pin out of a bomb.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
11,[' At the time I did not grasp that this was because there were no weapons to be had.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

12,[' militia the shortage of rifles was so desperate that fresh troops reaching the front always had to take their rifles from the troops they relieved in the line.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

13,"[' After a few days, though still a complete rabble by any ordinary standard, we were considered fit to be seen in public, and in the mornings we were marched out to the public gardens on the hill beyond the Plaza de Espana.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
14,"[' This was the common drill- ground of all the party militias, besides the Carabineros and the first contingents of the newly formed Popular Army.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

15,"[' Down every path and alley-way, amid the formal flower-beds, squads and companies of men marched stiffly to and fro, throwing out their chests and trying desperately to look like soldiers.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

17,"[' Several days passed and the recruits learned to march in step and spring to attention almost smartly, but if they knew which end of a rifle the bullet came out of, that was all they knew.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
18,[' One day an armed Carabinero strolled up to us when we were halting and allowed us to examine his rifle.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
19,"[' It turned out that in the whole of my section no one except myself even knew how to load the rifle, much less how to take aim.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
20,[' All this time I was having the usual struggles with the Spanish language.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
21,[' Things were not made easier for me by the fact that when my companions spoke to one another they generally spoke in Catalan.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
22,[' But I would sooner be a foreigner in Spain than in most countries.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

23,"[' How easy it is to make friends in Spain I Within a day or two there was a score of militiamen who called me by my Christian name, showed me the ropes, and overwhelmed me with hospitality.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

24,"[' The whole militia-system had serious faults, and the men themselves were a mixed lot, for by this time voluntary recruitment was falling off and many of the best men were already at the front or dead.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

25,[' Some of the journalists and other foreigners who travelled in Spain during the war have declared that in secret the Spaniards were bitterly jealous of foreign aid.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
26,[' I remember that a few days before I left the barracks a group of men returned on leave from the front.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
29,[' An Englishman would cut his hand off sooner than say a thing like that.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

30,[' Every foreigner who served in the militia spent his first few weeks in learning to love the Spaniards and in being exasperated by certain of their characteristics.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
31,"[' The Spaniards are good at many things, but not at making war.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
32,"[' In Spain nothing, from a meal to a battle, ever happens at the appointed time.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

33,"[' A train which is due to leave at eight will normally leave at any time between nine and ten, but perhaps once a week, thanks to some private whim of the engine-driver, it leaves at half past seven.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
34,[' Such things can be a little trying.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

36,"[' It was rather humiliating that I had to be shown how to put on my new leather cartridge-boxes by a Spanish girl, the wife of Williams, the other English militiaman.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

37,"[' She was a gentle, dark-eyed, intensely feminine creature who looked as though her life-work was to rock a cradle, but who as a matter of fact had fought bravely in the street-battles of July.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
38,[' At this time she was carrying a baby which was born just ten months after the outbreak of war and had perhaps been begotten behind a barricade.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
39,"[' 2 B A R B A S T R O , though a long way from the front line, looked bleak and chipped.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
40,[' It appeared that even in Barcelona there were hardly any bullfights nowadays; for some reason all the best matadors were Fascists.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

41,"[' Sietamo had been fought over three times before the Anarchists finally took it in October, and parts of it were smashed to pieces by shell-fire and most of the houses pockmarked by rifle-bullets.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

42,[' Between Sietamo and Alcubierre the lorry-driver lost his way (this was one of the regular features of the war) and we were wandering for hours in the mist.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
44,[' Alcubierre had never been shelled and was in a better state than most of the villages immediately behind the line.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

45,"[' They are built like fortresses, a mass of mean little houses of mud and stone huddling round the church, and even in spring you see hardly a flower anywhere; the houses have no gardens, only back-yards where ragged fowls skate over the beds of mule-dung.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

46,"[' It did not possess and never had possessed such a thing as a lavatory or a drain of any kind, and there was not a square yard anywhere where you could tread without watching your step.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
47,[' Two days passed and no rifles were issued to us.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
49,[' Up in the front line things were obviously quiet; very few wounded were coming in.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
50,"[' The chief excitement was the arrival of Fascist deserters, who were brought under guard from the front line.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

51,"[' Many of the troops opposite us on this part of the line were not Fascists at all, merely wretched conscripts who had been doing their military service at the time when war broke out and were only too anxious to escape.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
52,[' Occasionally small batches of them took the risk of slipping across to our lines.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

54,[' I think he still half-believed that we were bloodthirsty -Reds-and were going to shoot him as soon as he had finished his meal; the armed man who guarded him kept stroking his shoulder and making reassuring noises.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
55,[' I got a shock of dismay when I saw the thing they gave me.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
56,"[' Most of the rifles were equally bad, some of them even worse, and no attempt was made to give the best weapons to the men who knew how to use them.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
57,"[' The best rifle of the lot, only ten years old, was given to a half-witted little beast of fifteen, known to everyone as the maricóon (Nancy-boy).']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
58,"[' Many of the militiamen had never had a gun in their hands before, and very few, I imagine, knew what the sights were for.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

59,"[' Cartridges were handed out, fifty to a man, and then the ranks were formed and we strapped our kits on our backs and set out for the front line, about three miles away.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

60,"[' At the head of the column, beside the red flag, Georges Kopp, the stout Belgian commandante, was riding a black horse; a little way ahead a youth from the brigand-like militia cavalry pranced to and fro, galloping up every piece of rising ground and posing himself in picturesque attitudes at the summit.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

61,"[' The splendid horses of the Spanish cavalry had been captured in large numbers during the revolution and handed over to the militia, who, of course, were busy riding them to death.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
62,"[' We were getting near the front line now, near the bombs, the machine-guns, and the mud.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

63,"[' I knew the line was quiet at present, but unlike most of the men about me I was old enough to remember the Great War, though not old enough to have fought in it.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
65,"[' I admit, too, that I felt a kind of horror as I looked at the people I was marching among.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
67,[' As we neared the line the boys round the red flag in front began to utter shouts of -Visca P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
68,[' !'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
69,['--Fascistas-maricones!'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
71,[' It seemed dreadful that the defenders of the Republic should be this mob of ragged children carrying worn-out rifles which they did not know how to use.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

72,[' I remember wondering what would happen if a Fascist aeroplane passed our way whether the airman would even bother to dive down and give us a burst from his machine-gun.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
73,[' As the road struck into the sierra we branched off to the right and climbed a narrow mule-track that wound round the mountain-side.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
74,"[' They had been three months in the line; their uniforms were caked with mud, their boots falling to pieces, their faces mostly bearded.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
75,"[' He was a short youth of about twenty-five, with stiff black hair and a pale eager face which at this period of the war was always very dirty.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
76,[' There were thirty or forty dug-outs running into the ground like rat-holes.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
77,[' He had fired his rifle and had somehow managed to blow out the bolt; his scalp was torn to ribbons by the splinters of the burst cartridge-case.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
78,[' In the afternoon we did our first guard and Benjamin showed us round the position.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
79,"[' There were twelve sentries, placed at various points in the trench and behind the inner parapet.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
80,"[' I peered cautiously through a loophole, trying to find the Fascist trench.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
81,[' -Over zere.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
83,[') -But where?'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
84,['-According to my ideas of trench warfare the Fascists would be fifty or a hundred yards away.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

86,"[' I could see the Fascists, tiny as ants, dodging to and fro behind their parapet, and sometimes a black dot which was a head would pause for a moment, impudently exposed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
87,"[' But presently the sentry on my left, leaving his post in the typical Spanish fashion, sidled up to me and began urging me to fire.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
88,[' I tried to explain that at that range and with these rifles you could not hit a man except by accident.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
89,[' It was the first time in my life that I had fired a gun at a human being.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
90,"[' A little while later, however, a bullet shot past my ear with a vicious crack and banged into the parados behind.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

91,"[' All my life I had sworn that I would not duck the first time a bullet passed over me; but the movement appears to be instinctive, and almost everybody does it at least once.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
92,"[' 3 I N trench warfare five things are important: firewood, food, tobacco, candles, and the enemy.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
93,[' I ought to say in passing that all the time I was in Spain I saw very little fighting.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
94,"[' In March there was heavy fighting round Huesca, but I personally played only a minor part in it.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

95,"[' Later, in June, there was the disastrous attack on Huesca in which several thousand men were killed in a single day, but I had been wounded and disabled before that happened.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
96,[' The things that one normally thinks of as the horrors of war seldom happened to me.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

97,"[' No aeroplane ever dropped a bomb anywhere near me, I do not think a shell ever exploded within fifty yards of me, and I was only in hand-to-hand fighting once (once is once too often, I may say).']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
98,"[' Of course I was often under heavy machine-gun fire, but usually at longish.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
99,"[' Fascist or Loyalist, a knot of ragged, dirty men shivering round their flag and trying to keep warm.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
100,[' And all day and night the meaningless bullets wandering across the empty valleys and only by some rare improbable chance getting home on a human body.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
101,[' The inconclusiveness of such a kind of war!'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

102,"[' Earlier, about October, there had been savage fighting for all these hills; then, because the lack of men and arms, especially artillery, made any large-scale operation impossible, each army had dug itself in and settled down on the hill-tops it had won.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
103,[' position faced a taller spur with several small Fascist posts dotted on its peaks.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

104,"[' flags were red, those of the Anarchists red and black; the Fascists generally flew the monarchist flag (red-yellow-red), but occasionally they flew the flag of the Republic (red-yellow- purple).']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

105,"[' The only birds one saw at any time were a kind of magpie, and the coveys of partridges that startled one at night with their sudden whirring, and, very rarely, the flights of eagles that drifted slowly over, generally followed by rifle-shots which they did not deign to notice.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
106,"[' At night and in misty weather, patrols were sent out in the valley between ourselves and the Fascists.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

107,[' In the huge jagged ravines there were no paths or tracks of any kind; you could only find your way about by making successive journeys and noting fresh landmarks each time.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
108,"[' As the bullet flies the nearest Fascist post was seven hundred metres from our own, but it was a mile and a half by the only practicable route.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
109,[' It was rather fun wandering about the dark valleys with the stray bullets flying high overhead like redshanks whistling.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

110,"[' Better than night-time were the heavy mists, which often lasted all day and which had a habit of clinging round the hill-tops and leaving the valleys clear.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
112,[' It was only at the third or fourth attempt that I managed to find my way to the Fascist lines.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
113,[' I could hear the Fascists talking and singing inside.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
115,"[' I had been made a corporal, or cabo, as it was called, as soon as we reached the front, and was in command of a guard of twelve men.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

116,"[' Here and there in the militia you came across children as young as eleven or twelve, usually refugees from Fascist territory who had been enlisted as militiamen as the easiest way of providing for them.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

117,"[' As a rule they were employed on light work in the rear, but sometimes they managed to worm their way to the front line, where they were a public menace.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
118,"[' Boys of this age ought never to be used in the front line, because they cannot stand the lack of sleep which is inseparable from trench warfare.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
119,[' At the beginning it was almost impossible to keep our position properly guarded at night.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

120,"[' The wretched children of my section could only be roused by dragging them out of their dug-outs feet foremost, and as soon as your back was turned they left their posts and slipped into shelter; or they would even, in spite of the frightful cold, lean up against the wall of the trench and fall fast asleep.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
121,[' At this time and until much later the Catalan militias were still on the same basis as they had been at the beginning of the war.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

123,"[' When the Popular Army, which was a -non-political-army organized on more or less ordinary lines, was raised at the beginning of 1937, the party militias were theoretically incorporated in it.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

124,"[' But for a long time the only changes that occurred were on paper; the new Popular Army troops did not reach the Aragon front in any numbers till June, and until that time the militia-system remained unchanged.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
125,[' The essential point of the system was social equality between officers and men.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
126,"[' If you wanted to slap the general commanding the division on the back and ask him for a cigarette, you could do so, and no one thought it curious.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

127,"[' Of course there was no perfect equality, but there was a nearer approach to it than I had ever seen or than I would have thought conceivable in time of war.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
128,[' How on earth could the war be won by an army of this type?'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

129,"[' A modern mechanized army does not spring up out of the ground, and if the Government had waited until it had trained troops at its disposal, Franco wouKt-never have been resisted.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

130,"[' Later it became the fashion to decry the militias, and therefore to pretend that the faults which were due to lack of training and weapons were the result of the equalitarian system.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

131,"[' Actually, a newly raised draft -of militia was an undisciplined mob not because the officers called the private -Comrade-but because raw troops are always an undisciplined mob.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
133,[' The discipline of even the worst drafts of militia visibly improved as time went on.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
134,"[' In May for a short while I was acting-lieutenant in command of about thirty men, English and Spanish.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

135,"[' We had all been under fire for months, and I never had the slightest difficulty in getting an order obeyed or in getting men to volunteer for a dangerous job.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

136,[' The journalists who sneered at the militia-system seldom remembered that the militias had to hold the line while the Popular Army was training in the rear.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
138,"[' Yet the militias held the line, though God knows they won very few victories, and even individual desertions were not common.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
139,"[' militia I only heard of four men deserting, and two of those were fairly certainly spies who had enlisted to obtain information.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

140,"[' At the beginning the apparent chaos, the general lack of training, the fact that you often had to argue for five minutes before you could get an order obeyed, appalled and infuriated me.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

141,"[' The temperature was not exceptionally low, on many nights it did not even freeze, and the wintry sun often shone for an hour in the middle of the day; but even if it was not really cold, I assure you that it seemed so.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
143,"[' For days together clothes, boots, blankets, and rifles were more or less coated with mud.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

144,"[' There was a kind of dried-up reed that was very good for starting fires with, but these grew only on the hill-top to the left of the position, and you had to go under fire to get them.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
145,[' If the Fascist machine-gunners saw you they gave you a drum of ammunition all to yourself.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

146,"[' Generally their aim was high and the bullets sang overhead like birds, but sometime they crackled and chipped the limestone uncomfortably close, whereupon you flung yourself on your face.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
148,"[' Some of the militiamen habitually defecated in the trench, a disgusting thing when one had to walk round it in the darkness.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
149,[' Dirt is a thing people make too much fuss about.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
151,"[' In eighty nights I only took my clothes off three times, though I did occasionally manage to get them off in the daytime.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
152,"[' At that time it was still possible to buy candles, and I had brought several pounds of them with me.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
154,"[' -This is not a war,-he used to say, -it is a comic opera with an occasional death.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
156,[' In our own position or most of those round us a dozen men with two machine-guns could have held off a battalion.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

157,"[' The Fascists did occasionally manage to bring a gun or two from Zaragoza and fire a very few shells, so few that they never even found the range and the shells plunged harmlessly into the empty ravines.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
159,[' It needs an effort to realize how badly the militias were armed at this time.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
160,[' in England is far more like a modern army than we were.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
161,[' For this sector of the front the entire artillery consisted of four trench-mortars with fifteen rounds for each gun.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
162,"[' There were machine-guns at the rate of approximately one to fifty men; they were oldish guns, but fairly accurate up to three or four hundred yards.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

163,"[' These were more popular than the others because they were lighter to carry and less nuisance in a trench, also because they were comparatively new and looked efficient.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
164,"[' These were nice to shoot with, but they were wildly inaccurate, and as their cartridges had no clips they could only be fired one shot at a time.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
165,"[' Ammunition was so scarce that each man entering the line was only issued with fifty rounds, and most of it was exceedingly bad.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
166,[' The Spanish-made cartridges were all refills and would jam even the best rifles.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

167,[' But in practice when the emergency came I seldom fired my rifle; I was too frightened of the beastly thing jamming and too anxious to reserve at any rate one round that would go off.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
168,"[' We had no tin hats, no bayonets, hardly any revolvers or pistols, and not more than one bomb between five or ten men.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
169,[' The bomb in use at this time was a frightful object known as the -F .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

171,"[' Spain has never been fully surveyed, and the only detailed maps of this area were the old military ones, which were almost all in the possession of the Fascists.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

172,"[' You greased your rifle with olive oil, when you could get hold of it; at different times I have greased mine with vaseline, with cold cream, and even with bacon-fat.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

174,"[' As time went on, and the desultory rifle-fire rattled among the hills, I began to wonder with increasing scepticism whether anything would ever happen to bring a bit of life, or rather a bit of death, into this cock-eyed war.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
175,"[' It was pneumonia that we were fighting against, not against men.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
177,[' Some of them had a nasty trick of going off if the butt was tapped on the ground; I saw a man shoot himself through the hand owing to this.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
179,[' Another time I had gone out on patrol in the mist and had carefully warned the guard commander beforehand.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

180,"[' But in coming back I stumbled against a bush, the startled sentry called out that the Fascists were coming, and I had the pleasure of hearing the guard commander order everyone to open rapid fire in my direction.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
181,"[' Once, rather later than this, I was photographing some machine-gunners with their gun, which was pointed directly towards me.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
183,[' The difficult passwords which the army was using at this time were a minor source of danger.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
184,"[' A little while later he was stumbling up the trench in the darkness, and the sentry challenged him: -Alto!']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
185,[' Cataluña!'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
186,['--Valiente!'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
187,"['-yelled Jaime, certain that he was saying the right thing.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
188,"[' 4 W H E N I had been about three weeks in the line a contingent of twenty or thirty men, sent out from England by the I .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
189,"[' They went into the ground for prodigious distances, and inside they were pitch dark and so low that you could not even kneel in them, let alone stand.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
190,"[' At night you could watch the lamps of our supply-lorries winding out from Alcubierre and, simultaneously, those of the Fascists coming from Zaragoza.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
192,"[' It says a lot for the Spanish character that the English and the Spaniards always got on well together, in spite of the language difficulty.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

193,"[' Once again there was nothing happening all along the line: only the random crack of bullets and, very rarely, the crash of a Fascist mortar that sent everyone running to the top trench to see which hill the shells were bursting on.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
194,"[' The enemy was somewhat closer to us here, perhaps three or four hundred yards away.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
195,"['Their nearest position was exactly opposite ours, with a machine-gun nest whose loopholes constantly tempted one to waste cartridges.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
196,"[' The Fascists seldom bothered with rifle-shots, but sent bursts of accurate machine-gun fire at anyone who exposed himself.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

198,"[' A mile or two to the left of us the line ceased to be continuous and there was a tract of country, lower-lying and thickly wooded, which belonged neither to the Fascists nor ourselves.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
199,"[' It was not bad fun in a Boy Scoutish way, though I never saw a Fascist patrol nearer than several hundred yards.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

200,"[' By a lot of crawling on your belly you could work your way partly through the Fascist lines and could even see the farm-house flying the monarchist flag, which was the local Fascist headquarters.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
201,[' Occasionally we gave it a rifle-volley and then slipped into cover before the machine-guns could locate us.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

202,"[' I hope we broke a few windows, but it was a good eight hundred metres away, and with our rifles you could not make sure of hitting even a house at that range.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
203,[' Coming off guard in the small hours we used to rake together what was left of the cook-house fire and then stand in the red-hot embers.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

204,"[' But sometimes the dawn breaking behind the hill-tops in our rear, the first narrow streaks of gold, like swords slitting the darkness, and then the growing light and the seas of carmine cloud stretching away into inconceivable distances, were worth watching even when you had been up all night, when your legs were numb from the knees down, and you were sullenly reflecting that there was no hope of food for another three hours.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
205,[' I was beginning to suffer a little from the lack of sleep which is inevitable even in the quietest kind of war.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

207,[' In my first three or four months in the line I do not suppose I had more than a dozen periods of twenty-four hours that were completely without sleep; on the other hand I certainly did not have a dozen nights of full sleep.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
208,"[' All food seemed good, even the eternal haricot beans which everyone in Spain finally learned to hate the sight of.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
209,"[' Our water, what there was of it, came from miles away, on the backs of mules or little persecuted donkeys.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

210,"[' When you had any olive oil, which was not often, these things would burn with a smoky flicker, about a quarter candle power, just enough to find your rifle by.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
211,[' When we left Monte Pocero I had counted my cartridges and found that in nearly three weeks I had fired just three shots at the enemy.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
212,"[' They say it takes a thousand bullets to kill a man, and at this rate it would be twenty years before I killed my first Fascist.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
213,"[' At Monte Oscuro the lines were closer and one fired oftener, but I am reasonably certain that I never hit anyone.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
214,"[' As a matter of fact, on this front and at this period of the war the real weapon was not the rifle but the megaphone.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
216,"['-On the Government side, in the party militias, the shouting of propaganda to undermine the enemy morale had been developed into a regular technique.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
217,"[' In every suitable position men, usually machine-gunners, were told off for shouting-duty and provided with megaphones.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

218,"[' Generally they shouted a set-piece, full of revolutionary sentiments which explained to the Fascist soldiers that they were merely the hirelings of international capitalism, that they were fighting against their own class, etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
219,"[', etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
220,"[', and urged them to come over to our side.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
221,[' There is very little doubt that it had its effect; everyone agreed that the trickle of Fascist deserters was partly caused by it.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
223,['-ringing again and again through the darkness is bound to make an impression on him.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
224,[' Of course such a proceeding does not fit in with the English conception of war.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

225,"[' In ordinary trench warfare, when there is no artillery, it is extremely difficult to inflict casualties on the enemy without receiving an equal number yourself.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

226,"[' If you can immobilize a certain number of men by making them desert, so much the better; deserters are actually more useful to you than corpses, because they can give information.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
227,[' But at the beginning it dismayed all of us; it made us fed that the Spaniards were not taking this war of theirs sufficiently seriously.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
228,"[' Sometimes, instead of shouting revolutionary slogans he simply told the Fascists how much better we were fed than they were.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
229,[' Lovely slices of buttered toast!'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

230,"['-I do not doubt that, like the rest of us, he had not seen butter for weeks or months past, but in the icy night the news of buttered toast probably set many a Fascist mouth watering.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
231,[' One day in February we saw a Fascist aeroplane approaching.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
232,"[' As usual, a machine-gun was dragged into the open and its barrel cocked up, and everyone lay on his back to get a good aim.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
233,"[' Our isolated positions were not worth bombing, and as a rule the few Fascist aeroplanes that passed our way circled round to avoid machine-gun fire.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

234,"[' This time the aeroplane came straight over, too high up to be worth shooting at, and out of it came tumbling not bombs but white glittering things that turned over and over in the air.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
235,[' That night the Fascists made a sort of abortive attack.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
237,"['-I grabbed my rifle and slithered up to my post, which was at the top of the position, beside the machine-gun.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

238,"[' The fire of, I think five machine-guns was pouring upon us, and there was a series of heavy crashes caused by the Fascists flinging bombs over their own parapet in the most idiotic manner.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
239,"[' Down in the valley to the left of us I could see the greenish flash of rifles where a small party of Fascists, probably a patrol, were chipping in.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
240,"[' A few shells came whistling over, but they fell nowhere near us and (as usual in this war) most of them failed to explode.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
242,[' .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
243,"['Presently our own machine-gun jammed, as it always did jam with those vile cartridges, and the ramrod was lost in the impenetrable darkness.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
245,"[' They were in fact not attacking, merely wasting cartridges and making a cheerful noise to celebrate the fall of Malaga.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
246,[' The chief importance of the affair was that it taught me to read the war news in the papers with a more disbelieving eye.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
247,[' A day or two later the newspapers and the radio published reports of a tremendous attack with cavalry and tanks (up a perpendicular hill-side!'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
248,[') which had been beaten off by the heroic English.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

249,"[' When the Fascists told us that Malaga had fallen we set it down as a lie, but next day there were more convincing rumours, and it must have been a day or two later that it was admitted officially.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

251,"[' The news sent a sort of chill all along the line, for, whatever the truth may have been, every man in the militia believed that the loss of Malaga was due to treachery.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
252,"[' It set up in my mind the first vague doubts about this war in which, hitherto, the rights and wrongs had seemed so beautifully simple.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
253,[' Four kilometres from our new trenches Huesca glittered small and clear like a city of dolls-houses.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
255,['-It turned out that he was mistaken.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
256,[' If I ever go back to Spain I shall make a point of having a cup of coffee in Huesca.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

257,"[' When the Fascists were driven back into Huesca the Republican Army troops who held this part of the line had not been over-zealous in their advance, so that the line formed a kind of pocket.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
258,"[' As a matter of fact there were things in this period that interested me greatly, and I will describe some of them later.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
259,[' But I shall be keeping nearer to the order of events if I try here to give some account of the internal political situation on the Government side.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
260,"[' At the beginning I had ignored the political side of the war, and it was only about this time that it began to force itself upon my attention.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
261,[' But at the same time it would be quite impossible to write about the Spanish war from a purely military angle.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
262,[' It was above all things a political war.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

263,"[' No event in it, at any rate during the first year, is intelligible unless one has some grasp of the inter-party struggle that was going on behind the Government lines.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
264,"[' When I came to Spain, and for some time afterwards, I was not only uninterested in the political situation but unaware of it.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

265,"[' If you had asked me why I had joined the militia I should have answered: -To fight against Fascism,-and if you had asked me what I was fighting for, I should have answered: -Common decency.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

266,['-I had accepted the News Chronicle- New Statesman version of the war as the defence of civilization against a maniacal outbreak by an army of Colonel Blimps in the pay of Hitler.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
267,"[' The revolutionary atmosphere of Barcelona had attracted me deeply, but I had made no attempt to understand it.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
268,[' militia rather than any other because I happened to arrive in Barcelona with I .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
269,"[' papers), but I did not realize that there were serious differences between the political parties.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
270,"[' At Monte Pocero, when they pointed to the position on our left and said: -Those are the Socialists-(meaning the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

273,"['-This of course was the correct-anti-Fascist-attitude which had been carefully disseminated by the English newspapers, largely in order to prevent people from grasping the real nature of the struggle.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
275,[' To understand the alignment on the Government side one has got to remember how the war started.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
276,[' When the fighting broke out on 18 July it is probable that every anti-Fascist in Europe felt a thrill of hope.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
277,"[' But when Franco tried to overthrow a mildly Left-wing Government the Spanish people, against all expectation, had risen against him.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

282,"[' The Government had made little or no attempt to forestall the rising, which had been foreseen for a long time past, and when the trouble started its attitude was weak and hesitant, so much so, indeed, that Spain had three premiers in a single day.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

283,"['[1] Moreover, the one step that could save the immediate situation, the arming of the workers, was only taken unwillingly and in response to violent popular clamour.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

284,"[' However, the arms were distributed, and in the big towns of eastern Spain the Fascists were defeated by a huge effort, mainly of the working class, aided by some of the armed forces (Assault Guards, etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
285,[') who had remained loyal.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
287,['e.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
288,[' believed that they were fighting for something better than the status quo.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
289,[' In the various centres of revolt it is thought that three thousand people died in the streets in a single day.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
290,[' Men and women armed only with sticks of dynamite rushed across the open squares and stormed stone buildings held by trained soldiers with machine-guns.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
291,[' Machine-gun nests that the Fascists had placed at strategic spots were smashed by rushing taxis at them at sixty miles an hour.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
292,"[' Even if one had heard nothing of the seizure of the land by the peasants, the setting up of local Soviets, etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

293,"[', it would be hard to believe that the Anarchists and Socialists who were the backbone of the resistance were doing this kind of thing for the preservation of capitalist democracy, which especially in the Anarchist view was no more than a centralized swindling machine.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
294,"[' (Even a year later it was computed that the Anarcho- Syndicalists in Catalonia possessed 30,000 rifles.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
295,[') The estates of the big pro-Fascist landlords were in many places seized by the peasants.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

296,"[' Along with the collectivization of industry and transport there was an attempt to set up the rough beginnings of a workers-government by means of local committees, workers-patrols to replace the old pro- capitalist police forces, workers-militias based on the trade unions, and so forth.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

297,"[' In a few places independent Anarchist communes were set up, and some of them remained in being till about a year later, when they were forcibly suppressed by the Government.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

298,"[' In Catalonia, for the first few months, most of the actual power was in the hands of the Anarcho-syndicalists, who controlled most of the key industries.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
299,"[' The thing that had happened in Spain was, in fact, not merely a civil war, but the beginning of a revolution.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
300,[' It is this fact that the anti-Fascist press outside Spain has made it its special business to obscure.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

301,"[' In England, where the Press is more centralized and the public more easily deceived than elsewhere, only two versions of the Spanish war have had any publicity to speak of: the Right-wing version of Christian patriots versus Bolsheviks dripping with blood, and the Left-wing version of gentlemanly republicans quelling a military revolt.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

303,"[' But the main reason was this: that, except for the small revolutionary groups which exist in all countries, the whole world was determined, upon preventing revolution in Spain.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
304,"[' In particular the Communist Party, with Soviet Russia behind it, had thrown its whole weight against the revolution.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

305,"[' It was the Communist thesis that revolution at this stage would be fatal and that what was to be aimed at in Spain was not workers-control, but bourgeois democracy.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
306,[' It hardly needs pointing out why -liberal-capitalist opinion took the same line.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

307,"[' The Barcelona Traction Company, for instance, represented ten millions of British capital; and meanwhile the trade unions had seized all the transport in Catalonia.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
308,"[' If the revolution went forward there would be no compensation, or very little; if the capitalist republic prevailed, foreign investments would be safe.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
309,"[' And since the revolution had got to be crushed, it greatly simplified things to pretend that no revolution had happened.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

310,[' In this way the real significance of every event could be covered up; every shift of power from the trade unions to the central Government could be represented as a necessary step in military reorganization.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
311,[' Outside Spain few people grasped that there was a revolution; inside Spain nobody doubted it.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

313,"[' And meanwhile the Communist press in foreign countries was shouting that there was no sign of revolution anywhere; the seizure of factories, setting up of workers-committees, etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

316,"[' On the other hand, Juan López, a member of the Valencia Government, declared in February 1937 that -the Spanish people are shedding their blood, not for the democratic Republic and its paper Constitution, but for .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
317,['.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
318,['.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
319,[' So it would appear that the downright lying scoundrels included members of the Government for which we were bidden to fight.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

320,"[' In six months in Spain I only saw two undamaged churches, and until about July 1937 no churches were allowed to reopen and hold services, except for one or two Protestant churches in Madrid.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
321,"[' But, after all, it was only the beginning of a revolution, not the complete thing.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

322,"[' Even when the workers, certainly in Catalonia and possibly elsewhere, had the power to do so, they did not overthrow or completely replace the Government.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

323,"[' The peasants had most of the land, and they were likely to keep it, unless Franco won; all large industries had been collectivized, but whether they remained collectivized, or whether capitalism was reintroduced, would depend finally upon which group gained control.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

324,[' At the beginning both the Central Government and the Generalite de Cataluña (the semi-autonomous Catalan Government) could definitely be said to represent the working class.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
325,"[' The Government was headed by Caballero, a Left-wing Socialist, and contained ministers representing the U .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
326,[' The Catalan Generalite was for a while virtually superseded by an anti-Fascist Defence Committee[2] consisting mainly of delegates from the trade unions.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
327,[' Later the Defence Committee was dissolved and the Generalite was reconstituted so as to represent the unions and the various Left- wing parties.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

329,"[' was turned out of the Generalite; finally, a year after the outbreak of war and revolution, there remained a Government composed entirely of Right-wing Socialists, Liberals, and Communists.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
330,[' began to supply arms to the Government and power began to pass from the Anarchists to the Communists.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

331,"[' Except Russia and Mexico no country had had the decency to come to the rescue of the Government, and Mexico, for obvious reasons, could not supply arms in large quantities.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

332,"[' It has been denied that any direct pressure was exerted by the Russian Government, but the point is not of great importance, for the Communist parties of all countries can be taken as carrying out Russian policy, and it is not denied that the Communist Party was the chief mover first against the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

334,"[' To begin with, gratitude to Russia for the arms and the fact that the Communist Party, especially since the arrival of the International Brigades, looked capable of winning the war, immensely raised the Communist prestige.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

335,"[' Secondly, the Russian arms were supplied via the Communist Party and the parties allied to them, who saw to it that as few as possible got to their political opponents.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
336,"['[3] Thirdly, by proclaiming a non-revolutionary policy the Communists were able to gather in all those whom the extremists had scared.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
338,"[', etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

339,"[' The fight against Franco had to continue, but the simultaneous aim of the Government was to recover such power as remained in the hands of the trade unions.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
340,"[' There was no general and obvious counter-revolutionary move, and until May 1937 it was scarcely necessary to use force.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

341,"[' The workers could always be brought to heel by an argument that is almost too obvious to need stating: -Unless you do this, that, and the other we shall lose the war.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

342,"['-In every case, needless to say, it appeared that the thing demanded by military necessity was the surrender of something that the workers had won for themselves in 1936.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

343,"[' But the argument could hardly fail, because to lose the war was the last thing that the revolutionary parties wanted; if the war was lost democracy and revolution.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
344,"[' The Anarchists, the only revolutionary party that was big enough to matter, were obliged to give way on point after point.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

345,"[' The process of collectivization was checked, the local committees were got rid of, the workers patrols were abolished and the pre-war police forces, largely reinforced and very heavily armed, were restored, and various key industries which had been under the control of the trade unions were taken over by the Government (the seizure of the Barcelona Telephone Exchange, which led to the May fighting, was one incident in this process); finally, most important of all, the workers-militias, based on the trade unions, were gradually broken up and redistributed among the new Popular Army, a -non-political-army on semi-bourgeois lines, with a differential pay rate, a privileged officer-caste, etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
346,"[', etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

347,[' In the special circumstances this was the really decisive step; it happened later in Catalonia than elsewhere because it was there that the revolutionary parties were strongest.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
348,[' Obviously the only guarantee that the workers could have of retaining their winnings was to keep some of the armed forces under their own control.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

349,"[' It would, however, have been quite possible to reorganize the militias and make them more efficient while keeping them under direct control of the trade unions; the main purpose of the change was to make sure that the Anarchists did not possess an army of their own.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

353,"[' The whole process is easy to understand if one remembers that it proceeds from the temporary alliance that Fascism, in certain forms, forces upon the bourgeois and the worker.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

355,"[' In reality this should cause no surprise, because the tactics of the Communist Party elsewhere, especially in France, have made it clear that Official Communism must be regarded, at any rate for the time being, as an anti- revolutionary force.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
356,"[' The alliance is of little use to Russia unless French capitalism is strong, therefore Communist policy in France has got to be anti- revolutionary.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

357,"[' It is less than three years since Thorez, the Secretary of the French Communist Party, was declaring that the French workers would never be bamboozled into fighting against their German comrades;[4] he is now one of the loudest-lunged patriots in France.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

358,"[' In England, for instance, the position is still uncertain, hence the English Communist Party is still hostile to the National Government, and, ostensibly, opposed to rearmament.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

359,"[' , the English Communist, like the French Communist, will have no choice but to become a good patriot and imperialist; there are premonitory signs of this already.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
361,[' In reality it was the Communists above all others who prevented revolution in Spain.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

362,"[' Later, when the Right-wing forces were in full control, the Communists showed themselves willing to go a great deal further than the Liberals in hunting down the revolutionary leaders.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

363,"['[5] I have tried to sketch the general course of the Spanish revolution during its first year, because this makes it easier to understand the situation at any given moment.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

364,"[' To begin with, the things that most enlightened me had not yet happened, and in any case my sympathies were in some ways different from what they are now.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
366,['e.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
367,[' the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

368,"[' For weeks on end, during the dull period when nothing was happening round Huesca, I found myself in the middle of a political discussion that practically never ended.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
369,"[' Among the Spaniards it was the same, and most of the newspapers we saw made the inter-party feud their chief feature.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
370,"[' From the point of view of political theory there were only three parties that mattered, the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
371,"[' first, as being the most important; it was the party that finally triumphed, and even at this time it was visibly in the ascendant.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

373,"[' (Partido Socialista Unificado de Cataluña) was the Socialist Party of Catalonia; it had been formed at the beginning of the war by the fusion of various Marxist parties, including the Catalan Communist Party, but it was now entirely under Communist control and was affiliated to the Third International.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

374,"[' Elsewhere in Spain no formal unification between Socialists and Communists had taken place, but the Communist viewpoint and the Right-wing Socialist viewpoint could everywhere be regarded as identical.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
375,[' The membership of these unions throughout Spain now numbered about a million and a half.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

376,"[' They contained many sections of the manual workers, but since the outbreak of war they had also been swollen by a large influx of middle-class members, for in the early -revolutionary-days people of all kinds had found it useful to join either the U .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

378,"[' We must have a strong central government in place of local committees, and we must have a properly trained and fully militarized army under a unified command.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

379,"[' Clinging on to fragments of workers-control and parroting revolutionary phrases is worse than useless; it is not merely obstructive, but even counterrevolutionary, because it leads to divisions which can be used against us by the Fascists.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

380,"[' Whoever tries to turn the civil war into a social revolution is playing into the hands of the Fascists and is in effect, if not in intention, a traitor.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
381,['-The P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
382,"[' -line-differed from this on every point except, of course, the importance of winning the war.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
384,['e.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
385,"[' to the change, real or apparent, in Communist policy.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
386,"[' It was made up partly of ex- Communists and partly of an earlier party, the Workers-and Peasants-Bloc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

387,"[' Numerically it was a small party,[6] with not much influence outside Catalonia, and chiefly important because it contained an unusually high proportion of politically conscious members.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
388,"[' The workers-militias and police-forces must be preserved in their present form and every effort to ""bourgeoisify"" them must be resisted.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
389,[' The war and the revolution are inseparable.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
390,['-The Anarchist viewpoint is less easily defined.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

391,"[' Especially since the beginning of the war they had moved more in the direction of ordinary Socialism, because circumstances had forced them to take part in centralized administration and even to break all their principles by entering the Government.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
392,"[' Nevertheless they differed fundamentally from the Communists in so much that, like the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
393,"[' stood for: (i) Direct control over industry by the workers engaged in each industry, e.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
394,['g.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
395,"[' transport, the textile factories, etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

396,['; (2) Government by local committees and resistance to all forms of centralized authoritarianism; (3) Uncompromising hostility to the bourgeoisie and the Church.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
397,[' Anarchism is deeply rooted in Spain and is likely to outlive Communism when the Russian influence is withdrawn.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

398,"[' During the first two months of the war it was the Anarchists more than anyone else who had saved the situation, and much later than this the Anarchist militia, in spite of their indiscipline, were notoriously the best fighters among the purely Spanish forces.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

399,"[' , and the Left wing of the Socialists had had the sense to combine at the start and press a realistic policy, the history of the war might have been different.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
400,"[' But in the early period, when the revolutionary parties seemed to have the game in their hands, this was impossible.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
401,"[' joined in the disastrous fighting in Barcelona in May, it was mainly from an instinct to stand by the C .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
402,"[' was suppressed, the Anarchists were the only people who dared to raise a voice in its defence.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

403,"[' , and a section of the Socialists, standing for workers-control: on the other side the Right-wing Socialists, Liberals, and Communists, standing for centralized government and a militarized army.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
404,"[' It is easy to see why, at this time, I preferred the Communist viewpoint to that of the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

405,"[' The Communists had a definite practical policy, an obviously better policy from the point of view of the common sense which looks only a few months ahead.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
407,[' This was the general feeling at the time.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

408,"[' The Communists had gained power and a vast increase of membership partly by appealing to the middle classes against the revolutionaries, but partly also because they were the only people who looked capable of winning the war.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
409,[' The Russian arms and the magnificent defence of Madrid by troops mainly under Communist control had made the Communists the heroes of Spain.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
410,"[' After all, the one thing that mattered was to win the war.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
411,[' At this time the newspapers I saw most often were the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

412,"[' Unlike the Communists, they had no footing in any press outside their own country, and inside Spain they were at an immense disadvantage because the press censorship was mainly under Communist control, which meant that the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

413,"[' Their large coloured posters, designed for a wider public (posters are important in Spain, with its large illiterate population), did not attack rival parties, but were simply anti-Fascist or abstractedly revolutionary; so were the songs the militiamen sang.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
414,[' The Communist attacks were quite a different matter.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
415,[' Here I can only give a brief indication of the Communist line of attack.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

416,"[' propaganda divided and weakened the Government forces and thus endangered the war; again, though finally I do not agree, a good case could be made out for this.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

417,"[' was declared to be no more than a gang of disguised Fascists, in the pay of Franco and Hitler, who were pressing a pseudo-revolutionary policy as a way of aiding the Fascist cause.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

418,"[' This implied that scores of thousands of working-class people, including eight or ten thousand soldiers who were freezing in the front-line trenches and hundreds of foreigners who had come to Spain to fight against Fascism, often sacrificing their livelihood and their nationality by doing so, were simply traitors in the pay of the enemy.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
419,"[' And this story was spread all over Spain by means of posters, etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
420,"[', and repeated over and over in the Communist and pro-Communist press of the whole world.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

421,"[' It is not a nice thing to see a Spanish boy of fifteen carried down the line on a stretcher, with a dazed white face looking out from among the blankets, and to think of the sleek persons in London and Paris who are writing pamphlets to prove that this boy is a Fascist in disguise.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

422,"[' One of the most horrible features of war is that all the war-propaganda, all the screaming and lies and hatred, comes invariably from people who are not fighting.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

423,"[' militiamen whom I knew in the line, the Communists from the International Brigade whom I met from time to time, never called me a Trotskyist or a traitor; they left that kind of thing to the journalists in the rear.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

424,"[' The people who wrote pamphlets against us and vilified us in the newspapers all remained safe at home, or at worst in the newspaper offices of Valencia, hundreds of miles from the bullets and the mud.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
426,[' One of the dreariest effects of this war has been to teach me that the Left-wing press is every bit as spurious and dishonest as that of the Right.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
428,[' The fighting had barely started when the newspapers of the Right and Left dived simultaneously into the same cesspool of abuse.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
430,[' The people who write that kind of stuff never fight; possibly they believe that to write it is a substitute for fighting.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

431,"[' It is the same in all wars; the soldiers do the fighting, the journalists do the shouting, and no true patriot ever gets near a front-line trench, except on the briefest of propaganda-tours.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
432,"[' Perhaps when the next great war comes we may see that sight unprecedented in all history, a jingo with a bullet-hole in him.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
433,"[' As far as the journalistic part of it went, this war was a racket like all other wars.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

434,"[' But there was this difference, that whereas the journalists usually reserve their most murderous invective for the enemy, in this case, as time went on, the Communists and the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
435,[' came to write more bitterly about one another than about the Fascists.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

436,[' I grasped that the Communists and Liberals had set their faces against allowing the revolution to go forward; I did not grasp that they might be capable of swinging it back.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
437,"[' All this time I was at the front, and at the front the social and political atmosphere did not change.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
440,[' I did not realize that more or less by chance I was isolated among the most revolutionary section of the Spanish working class.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

441,"[' So, when my more politically educated comrades told me that one could not take a purely military attitude towards the war, and that the choice lay between revolution and Fascism, I was inclined to laugh at them.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
443,"[' were right, or at any rate righter than the Communists, it was not altogether upon a point of theory.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

444,[' On paper the Communist case was a good one; the trouble was that their actual behaviour made it difficult to believe that they were advancing it in good faith.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
445,"[' militiaman, who honestly thought that the revolution could continue when the war had been won, was eyewash.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

446,"[' The thing for which the Communists were working was not to postpone the Spanish revolution till a more suitable time, but to make sure that it never happened.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

447,"[' This became more and more obvious as time went on, as power was twisted more and more out of working- class hands, and as more and more revolutionaries of every shade were flung into jail.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

448,"[' Every move was made in the name of military necessity, because this pretext was, so to speak, ready-made, but the effect was to drive the workers back from an advantageous position and into a position in which, when the war was over, they would find it impossible to resist the reintroduction of capitalism.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
449,[' But those were not the men who were directing party policy.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
450,"[' But, finally, the war was worth winning even if the revolution was lost.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
451,"[' And in the end I came to doubt whether, in the long run, the Communist policy made for victory.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
452,[' Very few people seem to have reflected that a different policy might be appropriate at different periods of the war.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

453,"[' The Anarchists probably saved the situation in the first two months, but they were incapable of organizing resistance beyond a certain point; the Communists probably saved the situation in October-December, but to win the war outright was a different matter.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

455,"[' In order to check every revolutionary tendency and make the war as much like an ordinary war as possible, it became necessary to throw away the strategic opportunities that actually existed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

456,"[' There is very little doubt that arms were deliberately withheld lest too many of them should get into the hands of the Anarchists, who would afterwards use them for a revolutionary purpose; consequently the big Aragon offensive which would have made Franco draw back from Bilbao, and possibly from Madrid, never happened.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

457,[' What was more important was that once the war had been narrowed down to a -war for democracy-it became impossible to make any large- scale appeal for working-class aid abroad.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
458,[' If we face facts we must admit that the working class of the world has regarded the Spanish war with detachment.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
461,[' No such thing ever even began to happen.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
463,[' For years past the Communists themselves had been teaching the militant workers in all countries that -democracy-was a polite name for capitalism.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

465,"[' As everyone knows, with a hostile population at your back it is impossible to keep an army in the field without an equally large army to guard your communications, suppress sabotage, etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
467,"[' Franco was trying to set up an infamous dictatorship, and the Moors actually preferred him to the Popular Front Government!']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

468,"[' The palpable truth is that no attempt was made to foment a rising in Morocco, because to do so would have meant putting a revolutionary construction on the war.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
469,[' The best strategic opportunity of the war was flung away in the vain hope of placating French and British capitalism.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
470,"[' The whole tendency of the Communist policy was to reduce the war to an ordinary, non-revolutionary war in which the Government was heavily handicapped.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
471,"[' For a war of that kind has got to be won by mechanical means, i.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
472,['e.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

475,"[' I have given my reasons for thinking that the Communist anti-revolutionary policy was mistaken, but so far as its effect upon the war goes I do not hope that my judgement is right.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
476,[' A thousand times I hope that it is wrong.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
478,"[' I let the above opinions stand, and time will show how far I am right or wrong.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

502,"[' Up here on the plateau the March days were mostly like an English March, with bright blue skies and nagging winds.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

503,"[' The winter barley was a foot high, crimson buds were forming on the cherry trees (the line here ran through deserted orchards and vegetable gardens), and if you searched the ditches you could find violets and a kind of wild hyacinth like a poor specimen of a bluebell.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
504,"[' Immediately behind the line there ran a wonderful, green, bubbling stream, the first transparent water I had seen since coming to the front.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
506,"[' The only danger was from stray bullets, which, as the lines curved forward on either side, came from several directions.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
507,"[' Arthur Clinton got a mysterious bullet that smashed his left shoulder and disabled his arm, permanently, I am afraid.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
508,[' The Fascists never dropped their shells on our parapet.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

509,"[' A few hundred yards behind us there was a country house, called La Granja, with big farm-buildings, which was used as a store, headquarters, and cook-house for this sector of the line.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

510,"[' It was this that the Fascist gunners were trying for, but they were five or six kilometres away and they never aimed well enough to do more than smash the windows and chip the walls.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
511,"[' You were only in danger if you happened to be coming up the road when the firing started, and the shells plunged into the fields on either side of you.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

514,"[' The Fascist guns were of the same make and calibre as our own, and the unexploded shells were often reconditioned and fired back.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

532,[' The captain who led them was one of those Regular Army officers of doubtful loyalty whom the Government persisted in employing.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
533,[' Either from fright or treachery he warned the Fascists by flinging a bomb when they were two hundred yards away.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
534,"[' Once we kept a dug-out fire burning for two days mainly with boots, which are not bad fuel.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

535,"[' By this time my wife was in Barcelona and used to send me tea, chocolate, and even cigars when such things were procurable, but even in Barcelona everything was running short, especially tobacco.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
538,"[' I was there ten days, part of the time in bed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

539,"[' Later, in the hospital at Barcelona, an American who had come to join the International Column on a ship that was torpedoed by an Italian submarine, told me how he was carried ashore wounded, and how, even as they lifted him into the ambulance, the stretcher-bearers pinched his wrist-watch.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
540,[' While my arm was in the sling I spent several blissful days wandering about the country-side.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

541,"[' Monflorite was the usual huddle of mud and stone houses, with narrow tortuous alleys that had been churned by lorries till they looked like the craters of the moon.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
542,"[' Later on, to get firewood for the troops farther back, parties of men were sent in lorries to wreck the place systematically.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
543,"[' La Granja, our store and cook- house, had possibly at one time been a convent.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

544,"[' The country-houses in that part of Spain are of no interest architecturally, but their farm-buildings, of lime- washed stone with round arches and magnificent roof-beams, are noble places, built on a plan that has probably not altered for centuries.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
545,[' Sometimes it gave you a sneaking sympathy with the Fascist ex-owners to see the way the militia treated the buildings they had seized.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

546,[' It is typical of the utter vagueness in which the Spanish agrarian revolution is wrapped that I could not even discover for certain whether the land here was collectivized or whether the peasants had simply divided it up among themselves.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

547,"[' To some of the older ones the war must have seemed meaningless, visibly it produced a shortage of everything and a dismal dull life for everybody, and at the best of times peasants hate having troops quartered upon them.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
549,[' Civil war is a queer thing.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
550,"[' Spades, among a people who seldom possessed boots, were unknown; they did their digging with a clumsy hoe like those used in India.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
551,[' There was a kind of harrow that took one straight back to the later Stone Age.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

552,"[' It was made of boards joined together, to about the size of a kitchen table; in the boards hundreds of holes were morticed, and into each hole was jammed a piece of flint which had been chipped into shape exactly as men used to chip them ten thousand years ago.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
554,"[' It made me sick to think of the work that must go into the making of such a thing, and the poverty that was obliged to use flint in place of steel.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

556,"[' It is curious that all the time I was in Spain I never once saw a person cross himself; yet you would think such a movement would become instinctive, revolution or no revolution.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
