557,"[' Obviously the Spanish Church will come back (as the saying goes, night and the Jesuits always return), but there is no doubt that at the outbreak of the revolution it collapsed and was smashed up to an extent that would be unthinkable even for the moribund C.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
558,"[' To the Spanish people, at any rate in Catalonia and Aragon, the Church was a racket pure and simple.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

559,"[' It was the day I came back from hospital that we advanced the line to what was really its proper position, about a thousand yards forward, along the little stream that lay a couple of hundred yards in front of the Fascist line.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
560,"[' The point of doing it now was that the Anarchists were attacking on the Jaca road, and to advance on this side made them divert troops to face us.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

562,"[' In seven hours six hundred men constructed twelve hundred metres of trench and parapet, at distances of from a hundred and fifty to three hundred yards from the Fascist line, and all so silently that the Fascists heard nothing, and during the night there was only one casualty.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
563,[' And then the dawn coming up and the Fascists suddenly discovering that we were there.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

564,"[' The square white block of the Casa Francesa, though it was two hundred yards away, seemed to tower over us, and the machine-guns in its sandbagged upper windows seemed to be pointing straight down into the trench.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
566,"[' Casualties were happening all along the line, but nothing to what there would have been if they had caught us on the move during the night.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
567,[' A deserter told us afterwards that five Fascist sentries were shot for negligence.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
568,"[' One had to carry wounded men a long distance, a mile or more, for even when a road existed the ambulances never came very near the front line.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
570,"[' And then, next night, waiting at Torre Fabián for an attack that was called off at the last moment by wireless.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
571,[' And then waiting fifty or sixty yards from the Fascist parapet for the order to attack.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
572,[' A long line of men crouching in an irrigation ditch with their bayonets peeping over the edge and the whites of their eyes shining through the darkness.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
573,"[' ) who had been posted only about forty yards from the Fascist parapet, were caught by the dawn and unable to escape.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
574,"[' All day they had to lie there, with only tufts of grass for cover, the Fascists shooting at them every time they moved.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
575,"[' And then, for many mornings to follow, the sound of the Anarchist attacks on the other side of Huesca.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

577,"[' By degrees the firing would spread all round the lines that encircled Huesca, and we would stumble out into the trench to lean sleepily against the parapet while a ragged meaningless fire swept overhead.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
578,[' The Fascists were shooting well that morning; perhaps there were German gunners on the job.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
579,[' As the days went on the unseen but audible guns began each to assume a distinct personality.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
580,[' guns which fired from close in our rear and which somehow evoked in my mind the picture of a fat man hitting a golf-ball.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

581,"[' Behind Monflorite were two very heavy guns which fired a few times a day, with a deep, muffled roar that was like the baying of distant chained-up monsters.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

582,"[' Up at Mount Aragon, the medieval fortress which the Government troops had stormed last year (the first time in its history, it was said), and which guarded one of the approaches to Huesca, there was a heavy gun which must have dated well back into the nineteenth century.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
583,[' A shell from this gun sounded like nothing so much as a man riding along on a bicycle and whistling.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

584,"[' Their shells are really a kind of winged torpedo, shaped like the darts thrown in public- houses and about the size of a quart bottle; they go off with a devilish metallic crash, as of some monstrous globe of brittle steel being shattered on an anvil.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

585,"[' The shell-bursts from the Fascist anti-aircraft guns dotted the sky like cloudlets in a bad water-colour, but I never saw them get within a thousand yards of an aeroplane.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
586,"[' When an aeroplane swoops down and uses its machine-gun the sound, from below, is like the fluttering of wings.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
587,"[' Two hundred yards to the right of us, where the Fascists were on higher ground, their snipers picked off a few of our comrades.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

588,"[' Two hundred yards to the left, at the bridge over the stream, a sort of duel was going on between the Fascist mortars and the men who were building a concrete barricade across the bridge.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
589,[' A hundred yards away you could stand in perfect safety and watch the columns of earth and black smoke leaping into the air like magic trees.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
590,[' The poor devils round the bridge spent much of the daytime cowering in the little man-holes they had scooped in the side of the trench.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

591,"[' But there were less casualties than might have been expected, and the barricade rose steadily, a wall of concrete two feet thick, with embrasures for two machine-guns and a small field gun.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
592,[' The attack on the Fascist redoubt which had been called off on the previous occasion was to be carried out tonight.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

593,"[' I oiled my ten Mexican cartridges, dirtied my bayonet (the things give your position away if they flash too much), and packed up a hunk of bread, three inches of red sausage, and a cigar which my wife had sent from Barcelona and which I had been hoarding for a long time.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
594,[' The Spanish Government had at last succeeded in producing a decent bomb.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

595,"[' Its chief disadvantage was that one pin was very stiff and the other very loose, so that you had the choice of leaving both pins in place and being unable to pull the stiff one out in a moment of emergency, or pulling out the stiff one beforehand and being in a constant stew lest the thing should explode in your pocket.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
596,[' In the pitch darkness and sheeting rain in the farm-yard a dim mass of men was waiting.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
597,"[' Kopp addressed us, first in Spanish, then in English, and explained the plan of attack.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
598,[' The Fascist line here made an L-bend and the parapet we were to attack lay on rising ground at the corner of the L.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

599,"[' About thirty of us, half English, and half Spanish, under the command of Jorge Roca, our battalion commander (a battalion in the militia was about four hundred men), and Benjamin, were to creep up and cut the Fascist wire.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

600,"[' Jorge would fling the first bomb as a signal, then the rest of us were to send in a rain of bombs, drive the Fascists out of the parapet, and seize it before they could rally.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
603,['-There was an hour or two to put in.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
604,"[' Instead, they called us together, ranged us into single file, and then Jorge and Benjamin set off rapidly into the darkness, the rest of us following.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
605,[' Long before we got to the place where we were to leave our own parapet everyone had fallen several times and our rifles were coated with mud.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
606,"[' At the parapet a small knot of men, our reserves, were waiting, and the doctor and a row of stretchers.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
607,[' The Fascist parapet was about a hundred and fifty yards away.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
608,"[' When I glanced back I could see the men who were nearest to me, a bunch of humped shapes like huge black mushrooms gliding slowly forward.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
609,[' I knew by experiment that on a dark night you can never see a man at twenty paces.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
610,[' Sounds would carry a long way.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
611,[' There was a dreadful moment when I kicked against a tin and thought every Fascist within miles must have heard it.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
612,"[' But no, not a sound, no answering shot, no movement in the Fascist lines.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
613,"[' At such a time you have not even any fear, only a tremendous hopeless longing to get over the intervening ground.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
614,"[' I knew the ground well, it was barely a hundred and fifty yards, and yet it seemed more like a mile.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

615,"[' When you are creeping at that pace you are aware as an ant might be of the enormous variations in the ground; the splendid patch of smooth grass here, the evil patch of sticky mud there, the tall rustling reeds that have got to be avoided, the heap of stones that almost makes you give up hope because it seems impossible to get over it without noise.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
616,[' We had been creeping forward for such an age that I began to think we had gone the wrong way.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
617,[' It was the outer wire (the Fascists had two lines of wire).'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
618,[' It might be fifty yards to the Fascist parapet now.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

619,"[' But the men behind, who were spread out, had to form into single file to get through the narrow gap in the wire, and just as this moment there was a flash and a bang from the Fascist parapet.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
620,"[' At once, far more promptly than one would have thought possible, a roar of fire, ten or twenty rifles, burst out from the Fascist parapet.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
621,[' Men too far back were flinging their bombs and some of them were falling short of the parapet.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

623,"[' You cannot conceive the horror of these things till you have seen one burst close to you in darkness; in the daytime there is only the crash of the explosion, in the darkness there is the blinding red glare as well.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
624,"[' The bomb burst over to the right, outside the parapet; fright had spoiled my aim.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
625,"[' Just at this moment another bomb burst right in front of me, so close that I could feel the heat of the explosion.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
626,[' I flattened myself out and dug my face into the mud so hard that I hurt my neck and thought that I was wounded.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
628,"['-The bomb had, in fact, wounded several people round about me without touching myself.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
629,"[' The Fascists were firing, our people behind were firing, and I was very conscious of being in the middle.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
630,[' I felt the blast of a shot and realized that a man was firing from immediately behind me.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
632,"['-At this moment I saw that Benjamin, ten or fifteen yards to my right, was motioning to me with his arm.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

634,"[' Benjamin was kneeling on one knee with a pleased, devilish sort of expression on his face and firing carefully at the rifle-flashes with his automatic pistol.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
635,"[' The bomb crashed inside the parapet, at the corner, just by the machine-gun nest.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
637,[' I took it for granted that there would be a Fascist waiting for me at the top.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
638,[' With a vague feeling of relief I found that it was a low parapet and the sand- bags gave a good foothold.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
639,"[' I thought they would be lurking somewhere underground, and shouted in English (I could not think of any Spanish at the moment): -Come on out of it!']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
640,"[' Then a man, a shadowy figure in the half-light, skipped over the roof of one of the ruined huts and dashed away to the left.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

642,"[' But for fear of shooting one another we had been ordered to use only bayonets once we were inside the parapet, and in any case I never even thought of firing.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
644,"[' Of course, he knew the ground better than I and had soon slipped away from me.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
645,[' When I came back the position was full of shouting men.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
646,"[' The Fascists were still pouring a heavy fire at us from three sides, but it was coming from a greater distance.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

647,"[' Looking over the right-hand parapet you could see innumerable greenish rifle-flashes stabbing the darkness; but they were a long way back, a hundred or two hundred yards.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
648,"[' I had a tiny electric torch which my wife had managed to buy in Barcelona, otherwise we had no light of any description between us.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
649,[' A few men with good rifles began a desultory fire at the flashes in the distance.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
650,"[' A number of wounded, English and Spanish, were lying outside.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
652,['-We began searching the position.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
653,[' The thing I was after was the machine-gun.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

654,"[' No doubt they were acting under orders, but it was a stupid and cowardly thing to do, for if they had kept the gun in place they could have slaughtered the whole lot of us.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
655,[' It was impossible not to be struck by the bare misery of the Fascist dug-outs.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

656,"[' The litter of spare clothes, books, food, petty personal belongings that you saw in our own dug- outs was completely absent; these poor unpaid conscripts seemed to own nothing except blankets and a few soggy hunks of bread.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
657,[' Up at the far end there was a small dug-out which was partly above ground and had a tiny window.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

658,"[' We dashed round and got in at the doorway, to find that the thing in the leather case was not a machine-gun but something which, in our weapon-starved army, was even more precious.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
659,[' At this moment someone shouted that the Fascists were closing in.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
661,[' If they had any sense at all they would come at us from inside the line.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
662,"[' The position was roughly horseshoe- shaped, with the dug-outs in the middle, so that we had another parapet covering us on the left.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
663,[' They must be coming from the other Fascist position farther up the line; evidently the Shock Troopers had not captured it after all.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

664,"[' It was the unbroken, drum-like roar of massed rifles which I was used to hearing from a little distance; this was the first time I had been in the middle of it.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
665,"[' And by now, of course, the firing had spread along the line for miles around.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
666,"[' Douglas Thompson, with a wounded arm dangling useless at his side, was leaning against the parapet and firing one-handed at the flashes.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

667,"[' The fire was high at present, but they might lower it at any moment; by the flashes all round I could see that we had a hundred or two hundred men against us.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

669,"[' They did not know the ground and in the darkness had been led to the wrong place, where they were caught on the Fascist wire and numbers of them were shot down.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
670,"[' The Germans did not speak a word of English, French, or Spanish.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
671,[' With difficulty and much gesticulation we explained what we were doing and got them to help us in building the barricade.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
672,[' The Fascists had brought up a machine-gun now.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
673,"[' You could see it spitting like a squib a hundred or two hundred yards away; the bullets came over us with a steady, frosty crackle.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

674,[' Before long we had flung enough sand-bags into place to make a low breastwork behind which the few men who were on this side of the position could lie down and fire.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

675,"[' Now that we had finished wrestling with those beastly sand- bags it was not bad fun in a way; the noise, the darkness, the flashes approaching, our own men blazing back at the flashes.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
676,[' One even had time to think a little.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
677,"[' There was no doubt about it this time, the rifle- flashes were much nearer.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
678,[' Obviously they were working their way up the communication-trench.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
679,"[' Bob Smillie, the blood running down his face from a small wound, sprang to his knee and flung a bomb.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
680,[' I had no bombs left except the Fascist ones and I was not certain how these worked.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
681,[' By one of those strokes of luck that happen about once in a year I had managed to drop the bomb almost exactly where the rifle had flashed.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
683,"[' The next rifle-flashes we saw were a long way off, a hundred yards or more.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
684,[' With a sub-machine-gun or twenty men with clean rifles we could hold this place against a battalion.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
685,"[' At this moment Paddy Donovan, who was second-in- command to Benjamin and had been sent back for orders, climbed over the front parapet.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
686,[' Back to our own lines double-quick.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
687,['-People were already climbing over the front parapet.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

688,"[' But at this moment I saw that the four Shock Troopers, acting I suppose on some mysterious orders they had received beforehand, had begun running up the communication-trench.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
691,[' As soon as we got away from the shelter of the Fascist parapet we were under a devilish fire that seemed to be coming at us from every direction.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
692,"[' Part of it, I do not doubt, came from our own side, for everyone was firing all along the line.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
693,[' Whichever way we turned a fresh stream of bullets swept past; we were driven this way and that in the darkness like a flock of sheep.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
695,"[' In a few minutes, although the distance from parapet to parapet was not two hundred yards and most of us knew the ground, we were completely lost.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
696,"[' We slithered onwards, changing our direction several times and taking it in turns to haul at the ammunition- box.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
697,[' Kopp was waiting inside the parapet with a few Spaniards.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
698,"[' It appeared that all the wounded had been got in except Jorge and one of our own men, Hiddlestone by name, who were missing.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

699,[' Even the fat folds at the back of his neck were pale; he was paying no attention to the bullets that streamed over the low parapet and cracked close to his head.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
700,"[' Suddenly he turned to us and asked for five volunteers, two English and three Spanish, to go and look for the missing men.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
701,[' As we got outside the Spaniards murmured that it was getting dangerously light.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
702,[' There was a tremendous noise of excited voices coming from the Fascist redoubt.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

703,"[' We were sixty or seventy yards from the parapet when they must have seen or heard us, for they sent over a heavy burst of fire which made us drop on our faces.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
706,"[' I knew, however, that in a half light one man is invisible where five are clearly visible, so I went back alone.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

708,"[' Later he told me that he had worked his way some distance lying on his back, then had clutched hold of a wounded Spaniard and they had helped one another in.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
709,"[' Along the line for miles around a ragged meaningless fire was thundering, like the rain that goes on raining after a storm.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
710,[' When I got back to my dug-out the three men I shared it with were already fast sleep.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
711,"[' It was merely a raid to make the Fascists divert troops from the other side of Huesca, where the Anarchists were attacking again.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

712,"[' I had judged that the Fascists had thrown a hundred or two hundred men into the counter-attack, but a deserter told us later on that it was six hundred.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

713,"[' The current explanation was that they had run away from Malaga so fast that they had forgotten to stop at Valencia; but this, of course, came from the Catalans, who professed to look down on the Andalusians as a race of semi- savages.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
715,"[' They thought they were Anarchists, but were not quite certain; perhaps they were Communists.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

716,"[' The issue of cigarettes had ceased, but in Monflorite it was occasionally possible to buy packets of the cheapest kind of tobacco, which in appearance and texture was very like chopped chaff.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

719,"[' They had managed to establish themselves close enough on either side to bring the road itself under machine-gun fire and make it impassable for traffic; but the gap was a kilometre wide and the Fascists had constructed a sunken road, a sort of enormous trench, along which a certain number of lorries could come and go.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
720,[' Probably it would have been impossible to take it with the fifteen thousand ill-armed men who were available.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

721,"[' Later, in June, the Government brought troops from the Madrid front and concentrated thirty thousand men on Huesca, with an enormous quantity of aeroplanes, but still the town did not fall.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

722,"[' When we went on leave I had been a hundred and fifteen days in the line, and at the time this period seemed to me to have been one of the most futile of my whole life.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

723,"[' I had joined the militia in order to fight against Fascism, and as yet I had scarcely fought at all, had merely existed as a sort of passive object, doing nothing in return for my rations except to suffer from cold and lack of sleep.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

725,"[' They formed a kind of interregnum in my life, quite different from anything that had gone before and perhaps from anything that is to come, and they taught me things that I could not have learned in any other way.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

727,"[' The workers-militias, based on the trade unions and each composed of people of approximately the same political opinions, had the effect of canalizing into one place all the most revolutionary sentiment in the country.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

728,"[' Up here in Aragon one was among tens of thousands of people, mainly though not entirely of working- class origin, all living at the same level and mingling on terms of equality.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

729,[' In every country in the world a huge tribe of party-hacks and sleek little professors are busy -proving-that Socialism means no more than a planned state- capitalism with the grab-motive left intact.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

730,"[' The thing that attracts ordinary men to Socialism and makes them willing to risk their skins for it, the -mystique-of Socialism, is the idea of equality; to the vast majority of people Socialism means a classless society, or it means nothing at all.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

731,"[' In that community where no one was on the make, where there was a shortage of everything but no privilege and no boot-licking, one got, perhaps, a crude forecast of what the opening stages of Socialism might be like.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

732,"[' Partly, perhaps, this was due to the good luck of being among Spaniards, who, with their innate decency and their ever-present Anarchist tinge, would make even the opening stages of Socialism tolerable if they had the chance.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
733,[' Of course at the time I was hardly conscious of the changes that were occurring in my own mind.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

734,"[' It is all bound up in my mind with the winter cold, the ragged uniforms of militiamen, the oval Spanish faces, the morse-like tapping of machine-guns, the smells of urine and rotting bread, the tinny taste of bean-stews wolfed hurriedly out of unclean pannikins.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
735,"[' I am stumbling up the mucky trench, through the mist that swirls round me like cold steam.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
736,"[' I am lying hidden among small fir-trees on the low ground west of Monte Oscuro, with Kopp and Bob Edwards and three Spaniards.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
737,[' Up the naked grey hill to the right of us a string of Fascists are climbing like ants.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
738,[' Close in front a bugle-call rings out from the Fascist lines.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
739,"[' I am in the mucky yard at La Granja, among the mob of men who are struggling with their tin pannikins round the cauldron of stew.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
741,"[' On 25 April, after the usual mañanas, another section relieved us and we handed over our rifles, packed our kits, and marched back to Monflorite.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

742,"[' The lice were multiplying in my trousers far faster than I could massacre them, and for a month past I had had no socks and my boots had very little sole left, so that I was walking more or less barefoot.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

743,"[' I wanted a hot bath, clean clothes, and a night between sheets more passionately than it is possible to want anything when one has been living a normal civilized life.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
744,"[' Getting back to Barcelona, after three and a half months at the front, reminded me of this.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

745,"[' In the train, all the way to Barcelona, the atmosphere of the front persisted; the dirt, the noise, the discomfort, the ragged clothes the feeling of privation, comradeship, and equality.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

747,[' The militiamen shouted revolutionary songs which drowned the rattle of the train and kissed their hands or waved red and black handkerchiefs to every pretty girl along the line.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

749,"[' Next to me a black-eyed boy of fifteen was recounting sensational and, I do not doubt, completely untrue stories of his own exploits at the front to two old leather-faced peasants who listened open-mouthed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

750,"[' But when the train had rolled through Sabadell and into Barcelona, we stepped into an atmosphere that was scarcely less alien and hostile to us and our kind than if this had been Paris or London.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

751,"[' Everyone who has made two visits, at intervals of months, to Barcelona during the war has remarked upon the extraordinary changes that took place in it.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

752,"[' And curiously enough, whether they went there first in August and again in January, or, like myself, first in December and again in April, the thing they said was always the same: that the revolutionary atmosphere had vanished.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

753,"[' No doubt to anyone who had been there in August, when the blood was scarcely dry in the streets and militia were quartered in the smart hotels, Barcelona in December would have seemed bourgeois; to me, fresh from England, it was liker to a workers-city than anything I had conceived possible.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
754,"[' Once again it was an ordinary city, a little pinched and chipped by war, but with no outward sign of working-class predominance.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
755,"[' (It appeared that there were still no private cars; nevertheless, anyone who -was anyone-seemed able to command a car.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
756,"[') The officers of the new Popular Army, a type that had scarcely existed when I left Barcelona, swarmed in surprising numbers.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

757,"[' A certain number of these officers had served in the militia and been brought back from the front for technical instruction, but the majority were young men who had gone to the School of War in preference to joining the militia.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

758,"[' Their relation to their men was not quite the same as in a bourgeois army, but there was a definite social difference, expressed by the difference of pay and uniform.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
760,[' As we made our way up the street I noticed that people were staring at our dirty exteriors.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
761,"[' Of course, like all men who have been several months in the line, we were a dreadful sight.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
762,"[' But it dismayed me a little, and brought it home to me that some queer things had been happening in the last three months.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
764,[' It horrified people who came to Barcelona from Madrid or even from Valencia.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

765,"[' Partly it was due to the remoteness of Barcelona from the actual fighting; I noticed the same thing a month later in Tarragona, where the ordinary life of a smart seaside town was continuing almost undisturbed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

766,"[' The war was only six months old or thereabouts when the Spanish Government had to resort to conscription, which would be natural in a foreign war, but seems anomalous in a civil war.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
767,[' Undoubtedly it was bound up with the disappointment of the revolutionary hopes with which the war had started.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

768,"[' The trade union members who formed themselves into militias and chased the Fascists back to Zaragoza in the first few weeks of war had done so largely because they believed themselves to be fighting for working-class control; but it was becoming more and more obvious that working-class control was a lost cause, and the common people, especially the town proletariat, who have to fill the ranks in any war, civil or foreign, could not be blamed for a certain apathy.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
769,[' When is it going to end?'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
770,['-Politically conscious people were far more aware of the internecine struggle between Anarchist and Communist than of the fight against Franco.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
771,[' To the mass of the people the food shortage was the most important thing.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

772,[' -The front-had come to be thought of as a mythical far-off place to which young men disappeared and either did not return or returned after three or four months with vast sums of money in their pockets.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
773,[' (A militiaman usually received his back pay when he went on leave.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
774,"[') Wounded men, even when they were hopping about on crutches, did not receive any special consideration.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

775,"[' As I discovered later, when buying my kit before going back to the front, certain things that one badly needed at the front were very difficult to procure.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
776,[' Meanwhile there was going on a systematic propaganda against the party militias and in favour of the Popular Army.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

777,"[' Since February the entire armed forces had theoretically been incorporated in the Popular Army, and the militias were, on paper, reconstructed along Popular Army lines, with differential pay-rates, gazetted rank, etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
778,"[', etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

780,"[' Until June very few Popular Army troops reached the Aragon front, and in consequence the militias were able to retain their separate structure and their special character.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
782,"[', etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

784,"[' For the time being, however, the militias were holding the line while the Popular Army was training in the rear, and this fact had to be advertised as little as possible.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
785,[' Drafts of militia returning to the front were no longer marched through the streets with drums beating and flags flying.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

786,"[' A few drafts of the Popular Army were now beginning to leave for the front, and these, as before, were marched ceremoniously through the streets; but even they, owing to the general waning of interest in the war, met with comparatively little enthusiasm.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
787,"[' The fact that the militia troops were also, on paper.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
788,"[' Any credit that happened to be going was automatically handed to the Popular Army, while all blame was reserved for the militias.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
790,[' When I first reached Barcelona I had thought it a town where class distinctions and great differences of wealth hardly existed.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

791,[' In the first months of revolution there must have been many thousands of people who deliberately put on overalls and shouted revolutionary slogans as a way of saving their skins.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

792,"[' The smart restaurants and hotels were full of rich people wolfing expensive meals, while for the working-class population food-prices had jumped enormously without any corresponding rise in wages.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

793,"[' The restaurants and hotels seemed to have little difficulty in getting whatever they wanted, but in the working-class quarters the queues for bread, olive oil, and other necessaries were hundreds of yards long.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

794,[' Outside the delicatessen shop at the top of the Ramblas gangs of barefooted children were always waiting to swarm round anyone who came out and clamour for scraps of food.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
795,[' The workers-patrols had been ordered to dissolve and the pre-war police forces were back on the streets.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
796,"[' One result of this was that the cabaret show and high-class brothels, many of which had been closed by the workers-patrols, had promptly reopened.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

797,['[8] A small but significant instance of the way in which everything was now orientated in favour of the wealthier classes could be seen in the tobacco shortage.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
798,[' For the mass of the people the shortage of tobacco was so desperate that cigarettes filled with sliced liquorice-root were being sold in the streets.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
799,[' (A lot of people tried them once.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

800,"[') Franco held the Canaries, where all the Spanish tobacco is grown; consequently the only stocks of tobacco left on the Government side were those that had been in existence before the war.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

801,"[' These were running so low that the tobacconists-shops only opened once a week; after waiting for a couple of hours in a queue you might, if you were lucky, get a three-quarter-ounce packet of tobacco.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

802,"[' Theoretically the Government would not allow tobacco to be purchased from abroad, because this meant reducing the gold-reserves, which had got to be kept for arms and other necessities.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
804,"[' This open contrast of wealth and poverty would have been impossible a few months earlier, when the working class still were or seemed to be in control.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
805,"[' Partly it was a result of the safety of life in Barcelona, where there was little to remind one of the war except an occasional air-raid.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
806,[' In Madrid the common danger forced people of almost all kinds into some sense of comradeship.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

807,"[' A fat man eating quails while children are begging for bread is a disgusting sight, but you are less likely to see it when you are within sound of the guns.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
809,[' And I remember feeling a vague horror and amazement that money could still be wasted upon such things in a hungry war-stricken country.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

810,"[' After several months of discomfort I had a ravenous desire for decent food and wine, cocktails, American cigarettes, and so forth, and I admit to having wallowed in every luxury that I had money to buy.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
811,"[' During that first week, before the street-fighting began, I had several preoccupations which interacted upon one another in a curious way.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
812,"[' I would feel a little unwell, go to bed for half a day, get up and eat another excessive meal, and then feel ill again.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

814,"[' The Government issued them to policemen and Popular Army officers, but refused to issue them to the militia; you had to buy them, illegally, from the secret stores of the Anarchists.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
815,[' I had told everyone for a long time past that I was going to leave the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
816,[' As far as my purely personal preferences went I would have liked to join the Anarchists.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
817,"[' If I wanted to go to Madrid I must join the International Column, which meant getting a recommendation from a member of the Communist Party.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
818,"[' I sought out a Communist friend, attached to the Spanish Medical Aid, and explained my case to him.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

819,"[' Quite possibly I should have been sent to Albacete before the Barcelona fighting started; in which case, not having seen the fighting at close quarters, I might have accepted the official version of it as truthful.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

820,"[' On the other hand, if I had been in Barcelona during the fighting, under Communist orders but still with a sense of personal loyalty to my comrades in the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
821,[' (The entire Spanish army had failed to produce a pair of boots big enough to fit me.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
822,[') I told my Communist friend that I would make definite arrangements later.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
823,[' The political atmosphere ought to have warned me that that was not the kind of thing one could do nowadays.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

824,"[' For under the surface-aspect of the town, under the luxury and growing poverty, under the seeming gaiety of the streets, with their flower-stalls, their many-coloured flags, their propaganda-posters, and thronging crowds, there was an unmistakable and horrible feeling of political rivalry and hatred.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
826,['-The danger was quite simple and intelligible.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
828,"[' As I have pointed out earlier, the move to break up the party militias was at bottom a manoeuvre towards this end.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
829,[' At the same time the pre-war armed police forces.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
830,"[' Civil Guards, and so forth, had been brought back into use and were being heavily reinforced and armed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

831,"[' The Civil Guards, in particular, were a gendarmerie of the ordinary continental type, who for nearly a century past had acted as the bodyguards of the possessing class.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

832,"[' Throughout this time there were rumours, always vague and contradictory owing to newspaper censorship, of minor clashes that were occurring all over Catalonia.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
833,[' In various places the armed police forces had made attacks on Anarchist strongholds.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

834,"[' At Puigcerda, on the French frontier, a band of Carabineros were sent to seize the Customs Office, previously controlled by Anarchists and Antonio Martin, a well-known Anarchist, was killed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

835,"[' members had been murdering one another for some time past; on several occasions the murders were followed by huge, provocative funerals which were quite deliberately intended to stir up political hatred.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
836,"[' At the end of April, just after I got to Barcelona, Roldan, a prominent member of the U .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

837,"[' The Government ordered all shops to close and staged ah enormous funeral procession, largely of Popular Army troops, which took two hours to pass a given point.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
838,[' It was obvious that the so-called funeral was merely a display of strength; a little more of this kind of thing and there might be bloodshed.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
839,"[' The same night my wife and I were woken by a fusillade of shots from the Plaza de Cataluña, a hundred or two hundred yards away.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
841,"[' Barcelona, the so-called revolutionary city, was probably the only city in non-Fascist Europe that had no celebrations that day.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
842,[' The last thing I wished for was to be mixed up in some meaningless street- fight.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
844,[' ________ [8] The workers-patrols are said to have closed 75 per cent of the brothels.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
846,['-For some reason I paid no attention to it at the time.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
847,"[' That afternoon, between three and four, I was half-way down the Ramblas when I heard several rifle-shots behind me.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

848,"[' I turned round and saw some youths, with rifles in their hands and the red and black handkerchiefs of the Anarchists round their throats, edging up a side-street that ran off the Ramblas northward.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
852,[' But the knot of Anarchists round the opening of the side-street were motioning the people back and shouting to them not to cross the line of fire.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
854,[' I saw two Popular Army officers retreating cautiously from tree to tree with their hands on their revolvers.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

855,"[' It appeared that he had been in the Plaza de Cataluña when several lorry-loads of armed Civil Guards had driven up to the Telephone Exchange, which was operated mainly by C .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
856,"[' I gathered that the -trouble-earlier in the day had been a demand by the Government to hand over the Telephone Exchange, which, of course, was refused.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
857,[' It was full of Anarchists with rifles in their hands.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

858,"[' When we got to the Hotel Falcón, which was at the bottom of the Ramblas, a crowd of people was seething in the entrance-hall; there was a great confusion, nobody seemed to know what we were expected to do, and nobody was armed except the handful of Shock Troopers who usually acted as guards for the building.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

859,"[' A tall, pale, rather handsome man of about thirty, in civilian clothes, was trying to restore order and handing out belts and cartridge-boxes from a pile in the corner.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
860,"[' Presently, from an inner office, the tall man and some others began bringing out armfuls of rifles and handing them round.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
861,[' There was a sound of firing in the distance and the streets were completely empty of people.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
862,[' The Civil Guards had seized buildings in commanding positions and were letting fly at everyone who passed.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

863,"[' I would have risked it and gone back to the hotel, but there was a vague idea floating round that the Comité Local was likely to be attacked at any moment and we had better stand by.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
864,"[' All over the building, on the stairs, and on the pavement outside, small knots of people were standing and talking excitedly.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

865,[' All I could gather was that the Civil Guards had attacked the Telephone Exchange and seized various strategic spots that commanded other buildings belonging to the workers.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
866,[' There was a general impression that the Civil Guards were -after-the C .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

867,"[' The poorer classes in Barcelona looked upon the Civil Guards as something rather resembling the Black and Tans, and it seemed to be taken for granted that they had started this attack on their own initiative.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
868,[' Once I heard how things stood I felt easier in my mind.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
870,[' A long time passed and nothing seemed to be happening at our end of the town.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

872,"[' Predominantly they were people of the poorest class, from the back-streets down by the quays; there was a number of women among them, some of them carrying babies, and a crowd of little ragged boys.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
873,[' The office upstairs was ceaselessly besieged by a crowd of people who were demanding rifles and being told that there were none left.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

874,"[' The younger militia boys, who seemed to regard the whole affair as a kind of picnic, were prowling round and trying to wheedle or steal rifles from anyone who had them.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
875,[' It was not long before one of them got my rifle away from me by a clever dodge and immediately made himself scarce.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
876,"[' The streets were utterly dark and silent, not a soul stirring, steel shutters drawn over all the shop windows, but no barricades built yet.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
877,[' When we got back I learned that the Telephone Exchange was working and went to the telephone in the office upstairs to ring up my wife.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

878,"[' Characteristically, there was no telephone directory in the building, and I did not know the number of the Hotel Continental; after a searching from room to room for about an hour I came upon a guide-book which gave me the number.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

880,"[' They had placed armed guards at most of the windows, and in the street below a little group of Shock Troopers were stopping and questioning the few passers-by.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
881,[' Beside the driver a beautiful dark-haired girl of about eighteen was nursing a sub-machine-gun across her knees.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
882,"[' I spent a long time wandering about the building, a great rambling place of which it was impossible to learn the geography.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
883,"[' I did not know how this affair was going to turn out, and I badly wanted a weapon.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
885,['A.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
886,['I.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
887,"[' alike, were hoarding arms in Barcelona, that I could not believe that two of the principal P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
888,[' buildings contained only the fifty or sixty rifles that I had seen.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
889,"[' All we found there were about two dozen small-bore rifles of an obsolete pattern and a few shot-guns, with no cartridges for any of them.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
890,"[' My sleep was disturbed, I remember, by the thought of those beastly bombs, which might blow me into the air if I rolled on them too vigorously.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
891,"[' At three in the morning the tall handsome man who seemed to be in command woke me up, gave me a rifle, and put me on guard at one of the windows.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
892,"[' He told me that Salas, the Chief of Police responsible for the attack on the Telephone Exchange, had been placed under arrest.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
893,[' Nevertheless the news confirmed the general impression that the Civil Guards had acted without orders.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
894,"[') As soon as it was dawn the people downstairs began building two barricades, one outside the Comite Local and the other outside the Hotel Falcón.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

895,"[' The Barcelona streets are paved with square cobbles, easily built up into a wall, and under the cobbles is a kind of shingle that is good for filling sand-bags.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
896,[' The building of those barricades was a strange and wonderful sight; I would have given something to be able to photograph it.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

897,"[' With the kind-of passionate energy that Spaniards display when they have definitely decided to begin upon any job of work, long lines of men, women, and quite small children were tearing up the cobblestones, hauling them along in a hand-cart that had been found somewhere, and staggering to and fro under heavy sacks of sand.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
898,[' A very few stalls had opened; they were besieged by a crowd of people from the working-class quarters south of the Ramblas.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

899,"[' Just as we got there, there was a heavy crash of rifle-fire outside, some panes of glass in the roof were shivered, and the crowd went flying for the back exits.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
900,[' At the street-corner where I had seen the Anarchists begin.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
901,[' firing the day before a barricade was now standing.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
902,[' The Civil Guards in the church tower were firing indiscriminately at everyone who passed.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

904,"[' There were trees and a newspaper kiosk between myself and the building (streets of this type in Spain have a broad walk running down the middle), and I could not see what they were pointing at.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
905,[' Executive Building (it was about a hundred yards down the street) to ask for orders.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
906,[' By this time the roar of rifle and machine-gun fire from various directions was almost comparable to the din of a battle.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
907,"[' Actually it was only hand-grenades, which make double their usual noise when they burst among stone buildings.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
908,"[' The bombs were bursting twenty yards away with a frightful, ear-splitting crash which was mixed up with the banging of rifles.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

910,"[' The day before twenty or thirty armed Civil Guards had entered the café and then, when the fighting started, had suddenly seized the building and barricaded themselves in.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
911,"[' Early in the morning they had attempted to come out, shots had been exchanged, and one Shock Trooper was badly wounded and a Civil Guard killed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
912,"[' The Civil Guards had fled back into the café, but when the American came down the street they had opened fire on him, though he was not armed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
913,"[' The American had flung himself behind the kiosk for cover, and the Shock Troopers were flinging bombs at the Civil Guards to drive them indoors again.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

914,"[' Kopp took in the scene at a glance, pushed his way forward and hauled back a red-haired German Shock Trooper who was just drawing the pin out of a bomb with his teeth.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
915,"[' Then he stepped out on to the pavement and, in sight of the Civil Guards, ostentatiously took off his pistol and laid it on the ground.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
916,"[' Two Spanish militia officers did the same, and the three of them walked slowly up to the doorway where the Civil Guards were huddling.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
917,"[' They were walking, unarmed, up to men who were frightened out of their wits and had loaded guns in their hands.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
918,"[' A Civil Guard, in shirt- sleeves and livid with fright, came out of the door to parley with Kopp.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
919,[' Kopp came back and told us we had better touch the bombs off.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
920,"[' I asked him to give me his rifle, knelt down and let fly at the second bomb.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

922,"[' Immediately opposite there was a cinematograph, called the Poliorama, with a museum above it, and at the top, high above the general level of the roofs, a small observatory with twin domes.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
923,"[' The domes commanded the street, and a few men posted up there with rifles could prevent any attack on the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

924,"[' As for the Civil Guards in the Café Moka, there would be no trouble with them; they did not want to fight and would be only too glad to live and let live.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
925,[' Kopp repeated that our orders were not to fire unless we were fired on ourselves or our buildings attacked.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
926,"[' leaders were furious at being dragged into this affair, but felt that they had got to stand by the C .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

927,"[' The next three days and nights I spent continuously on the roof of the Poliorama, except for brief intervals when I slipped across to the hotel for meals.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
928,"[' I think few experiences could be more sickening, more disillusioning, or, finally, more nerve-racking than those evil days of street warfare.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
930,"[' And the whole huge town of a million people was locked in a sort of violent inertia, a nightmare of noise without movement.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
931,[' Nothing was happening except the streaming of bullets from barricades and sand-bagged windows.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

932,[' Not a vehicle was stirring in the streets; here and there along the Ramblas the trams stood motionless where their drivers had jumped out of them when the fighting started.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
933,"[' And all the while the devilish noise, echoing from thousands of stone buildings, went on and on and on, like a tropical rainstorm.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
934,"[' What the devil was happening, who was fighting whom, and who was winning, was at first very difficult to discover.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

935,[' The people of Barcelona are so used to street- fighting and so familiar with the local geography that they knew by a kind of instinct which political party will hold which streets and which buildings.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
936,"[' Looking out from the observatory, I could grasp that the Ramblas, which is one of the principal streets of the town, formed a dividing line.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

937,"[' To the right of the Ramblas the working-class quarters were solidly Anarchist; to the left a confused fight was going on among the tortuous by-streets, but on that side the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

938,"[' Up at our end of the Ramblas, round the Plaza de Cataluña, the position was so complicated that it would have been quite unintelligible if every building had not flown a party flag.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

939,[' In a window near the last 0 but one in the huge -Hotel Colón-that sprawled across its face they had a machine-gun that could sweep the square with deadly effect.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
940,"[' On the Telephone Exchange, the starting-point of all the trouble, the Catalan national flag and the Anarchist flag were flying side by side.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
941,"[' Some kind of temporary compromise had been arrived at there, the exchange was working uninterruptedly and there was no* firing from the building.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

942,"[' Later half a dozen of them came on to the roof, opposite to ourselves, and built another barricade of mattresses, over which they hung a Catalan national flag.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
943,[' In return Kopp had actually given them one of our rifles to make up for one they had somehow lost on the previous day.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

944,"[' Sometimes I was merely bored with the whole affair, paid no attention to the hellish noise, and spent hours reading a succession of Penguin Library books which, luckily, I had bought a few days earlier; sometimes I was very conscious of the armed men watching me fifty yards away.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

946,"[' We placed a man on guard in each of the observatory towers, and the rest of us sat on the lead roof below, where there was no cover except a stone palisade.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
947,[' I was well aware that at any moment the Civil Guards might receive telephone orders to open fire.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
948,"[' Only once, however, did trouble look like starting.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
949,[' One of the Civil Guards opposite knelt down and began firing across the barricade.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
950,[' I was on guard in the observatory at the time.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
952,['-He motioned with his rifle towards the side-street that ran past the bottom of our building.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
953,"[' Sure enough, a youth in blue overalls, with a rifle in his hand, was dodging round the corner.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
954,[' Evidently he had just taken a shot at the Civil Guards on the roof.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
955,[' I shouted across: -Have you got any more beer left?'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
957,"['-The same day, for no apparent reason, a man in the J .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
958,[' building farther down the street suddenly raised his rifle and let fly at me when I was leaning out of the window.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
959,[' Though he was only a hundred yards away the bullet went so wide that it did not even hit the roof of the observatory.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
960,[' I was fired at several times from this building.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
961,"[' But so far as I could see, and from all I heard, the fighting was defensive on both sides.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
962,[' People simply remained in their buildings or behind their barricades and blazed away at the people opposite.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
963,[' About half a mile away from us there was a street where some of the main offices of the C .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
964,[' I passed down that street the day after the fighting was over and the panes of the shop-windows were like sieves.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

965,"[' (Most of the shopkeepers in Barcelona had their windows criss-crossed with strips of paper, so that when a bullet hit a pane it did not shiver to pieces.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
966,[') Sometimes the rattle of rifle and machine-gun fire was punctuated by the crash of hand-grenades.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

967,"[' And at long intervals, perhaps a dozen times in all, there were tremendously heavy explosions which at the time I could not account for; they sounded like aerial bombs, but that was impossible, for there were no aeroplanes about.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

969,"[' I was listening for this, for if the guns began to fire it would mean that the affair was becoming serious (artillery is the determining factor in street warfare).']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

970,"[' Afterwards there were wild tales in the newspapers about batteries of guns firing in the streets, but no one was able to point to a building that had been hit by a shell.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

971,[' With difficulty and under cover of darkness (for the Civil Guards were constantly sniping into the Ramblas) food was brought from the Hotel Falcón for the fifteen or twenty militiamen who were in the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
972,"[' Executive Building, but there was barely enough to go round, and as many of us as possible went to the Hotel Continental for our meals.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
973,[' No sooner had the fighting started than the hotel filled to the brim with a most extraordinary collection of people.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

974,"[' There were foreign journalists, political suspects of every shade, an American airman in the service of the Government, various Communist agents, including a fat, sinister-looking Russian, said to be an agent of the Ogpu, who was nicknamed Charlie Chan and wore attached to his waist-band a revolver and a neat little bomb, some families of well-to-do Spaniards who looked like Fascist sympathizers, two or three wounded men from the International Column, a gang of lorry drivers from.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

975,"[' some huge French lorries which had been carrying a load of oranges back to France and had been held up by the fighting, and a number of Popular Army officers.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

976,"[' The Popular Army, as a body, remained neutral throughout the fighting, though a few soldiers slipped away from the barracks and took part as individuals; on the Tuesday morning I had seen a couple of them at the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

977,"[' At the beginning, before the food-shortage became acute and the newspapers began stirring up hatred, there was a tendency to regard the whole affair as a joke.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
978,"[' This was the kind of thing that happened every year in Barcelona, people were saying.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

979,[' I remember his remarking that the Barcelona paving-stones ought to be numbered; it would save such a lot of trouble in building and demolishing barricades.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

980,"[' And I remember a couple of men from the International Column sitting in my room at the hotel when I came in tired, hungry, and dirty after a night on guard.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

981,"[' If they had been good party-men they would, I suppose, have urged me to change sides, or even have pinioned me and taken away the bombs of which my pockets were full; instead they merely commiserated with me for having to spend my leave in doing guard-duty on a roof.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

983,['-In spite of the extent of the fighting and the number of casualties I believe this was nearer the truth than the official version which represented the affair as a planned rising.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

984,"[' A very few pedestrians, forced abroad for one reason or another, crept to and fro, flourishing white handkerchiefs, and at a spot in the middle of the Ramblas that was safe from bullets some men were crying newspapers to the empty street.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

985,"[' On Tuesday Solidaridad Obrera, the Anarchist paper, had described the attack on the Telephone Exchange as a -monstrous provocation-(or words to that effect), but on Wednesday it changed its tune and began imploring everyone to go back to work.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

986,"[' paper, which was not defended, had been raided and seized by the Civil Guards at about the same time as the Telephone Exchange, but the paper was being printed, and a few copies distributed, from another address.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
987,[' People were divided in their minds and wondering uneasily how the devil this was going to end.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

988,"[' I doubt whether anyone left the barricades as yet, but everyone was sick of the meaningless fighting, which could obviously lead to no real decision, because no one wanted this to develop into a full-sized civil war which might mean losing the war against Franco.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
989,[' So far as one could gather from what people were saying at the time the C .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

990,"[' rank and file wanted, and had wanted from the beginning, only two things: the handing back of the Telephone Exchange and the disarming of the hated Civil Guards.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

991,"[' If the Generalite had promised to do these two things, and also promised to put an end to the food profiteering, there is little doubt that the barricades would have been down in two hours.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
992,"[' It was said that the Valencia Government was sending six thousand men to occupy Barcelona, and that five thousand Anarchist and P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
993,"[' Douglas Moyle, who had been a sailor, said that they looked like British destroyers.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

994,[' That evening we heard that on the Plaza de Espana four hundred Civil Guards had surrendered and handed their arms to the Anarchists; also the news was vaguely filtering through that in the suburbs (mainly working-class quarters) the C .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

995,"[' But the same evening Kopp sent for me and, with a grave face, told me that according to information he had just received the Government was about to outlaw the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

996,"[' If the Government declared war upon us we had no choice but to defend ourselves, and here at the Executive building we could be certain that the Civil Guards next door would get orders to attack us.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
997,[' Kopp was waiting for orders on the telephone; if we heard definitely that the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

998,"[' Counting the six rifles that were on the roof of the Poliorama opposite, we had twenty-one rifles, one of them defective, about fifty rounds of ammunition for each rifle, and a few dozen bombs; otherwise nothing except a few pistols and revolvers.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
999,"[' About a dozen men, mostly Germans, had volunteered for the attack on the Café Moka, if it came off.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1000,"[' We should attack from the roof, of course, some time in the small hours, and take them by surprise; they were more numerous, but our morale was better, and no doubt we could storm the place, though people were bound to be killed in doing so.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1001,"[' We had no food in the building except a few slabs of chocolate, and the rumour had gone round that -they-were going to cut off the water supply.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1003,"[') We spent a long time filling up every basin in the lavatories, every bucket we could lay hands on, and, finally, the fifteen beer bottles, now empty, which the Civil Guards had given to Kopp.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1004,[' My wife had come down from the hotel in case a nurse should be needed.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1006,[' And the next thing I remember is waking up with a jerk to find my wife standing beside me.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1007,"[' It was broad daylight, nothing had happened, the Government had not declared war on the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1008,[' The firing died away and with surprising suddenness the streets filled with people.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1009,[' The Civil Guards were still behind their barricades in the Moka; on neither side were the fortified buildings evacuated.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1013,"[' When you are taking part in events like these you are, I suppose, in a small way, making history, and you ought by rights to feel like a historical character.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1015,"[' I had been a hundred and fifteen days in the line and had come back to Barcelona ravenous for a bit of rest and comfort; and instead I had to spend my time sitting on a roof opposite Civil Guards as bored as myself, who periodically waved to me and assured me that they were -workers-(meaning that they hoped I would not shoot them), but who would certainly open fire if they got the order to do so.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1017,"[' Various people were infected with spy mania and were creeping round whispering that everyone else was a spy of the Communists, or the Trotskyists, or the Anarchists, or what-not.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1018,[' The fat Russian agent was cornering all the foreign refugees in turn and explaining plausibly that this whole affair was an Anarchist plot.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1020,[' There was something repulsive in the parody of smart hotel life that was still going on behind shuttered windows amid the rattle of rifle-fire.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1022,[' This shortage of food went on for several days after the fighting was over.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1024,"[' At any other time the little snob of a hotel manager would have done his best to make them uncomfortable, in fact would have refused to have them on the premises, but at present they were popular because, unlike the rest of us, they had a private store of bread which everyone was trying to cadge from them.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1025,"[' I spent that final night on the roof, and the next day it did really look as though the fighting was coming to an end.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1026,"[' No one seemed to know for certain whether the troops from Valencia were really coining; they arrived that evening, as a matter of fact.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1027,"[' The Government was broadcasting half-soothing, half-threatening messages, asking everyone to go home and saying that after a certain hour anyone found carrying arms would be arrested.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1028,"[' From every side you heard the same remark: -We have no more food, we must go back to work.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1029,"['-On the other hand the Civil Guards, who could count on getting their rations so long as there was any food in the town, were able to stay at their posts.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1031,"[' The Civil Guards were still holding the Café Moka and had not taken down their barricades, but some of them brought chairs out and sat on the pavement with their rifles across their knees.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1032,"[' I winked at one of them as I went past and got a not unfriendly grin; he recognized me, of course.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1034,[' But at the time I was not interested in that aspect of things.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1035,"[' All I felt was a profound relief that the devilish din of firing was over, and that one could buy some food and have a bit of rest and peace before going back to the front.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1036,"[' They were the Assault Guards, another formation similar to the Civil Guards and the Carabineros (i.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1037,['e.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1038,"[' a formation intended primarily for police work), and the picked troops of the Republic.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1040,"[' The six rifles which we had used for the guard in the observatory towers were still lying there, and by hook or by crook we had got to get them back to the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1042,"[' It was easy enough to dodge the Assault Guard patrols; the danger was the Civil Guards in the Moka, who were well aware that we had rifles in the observatory and might give the show away if they saw us carrying them across.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1043,[' Outside the picture-house I saw a group of people staring at me with great interest as I crept along at tortoise-speed.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1044,"[' Next day the Assault Guards were everywhere, walking the streets like conquerors.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1045,[' There was no doubt that the Government was simply making a display of force in order to overawe a population which it already knew would not resist; if there had been any real fear of further outbreaks the Assault Guards would have been kept in barracks and not scattered through the streets in small bands.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1047,"[' I was used to the ragged, scarcely- armed militia on the Aragon front, and I had not known that the Republic possessed troops like these.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1048,[' All of them were armed with brand-new rifles of the type known as -the Russian rifle-(these rifles were sent to Spain by the U .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1049,"[' The Civil Guards and Carabineros, who were not intended for the front at all, were better armed and far better clad than ourselves.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1051,[' On the whole the Assault Guards got on very well with the population after the first day or two.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1053,"[' This led to scuffles with armed Anarchists, and one or two people were killed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1054,[' The Barcelona fighting had given the Valencia Government the long-wanted excuse to assume fuller control of Catalonia.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1056,[' Evidently the official version of the Barcelona fighting was already fixed upon: it was to be represented as a -fifth column-Fascist rising engineered solely by the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1057,"[' The posts were working again, the foreign Communist papers were beginning to arrive, and their accounts of the fighting were not only violently partisan but, of course, wildly inaccurate as to facts.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1058,"[' I think some of the Communists on the spot, who had seen what was actually happening, were dismayed by the interpretation that was being put upon events, but naturally they had to stick to their own side.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1060,"[' After all, you were only acting under orders.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1061,['-I had to tell him that after this affair I could not join any Communist-controlled unit.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1062,[' Sooner or later it might mean being used against the Spanish working class.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1063,"[' One could not tell when this kind of thing would break out again, and if I had to use my rifle at all in such an affair I would use it on the side of the working class and not against them.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1064,"[' After the fighting was over the Anarchists had, of course, released their prisoners, but the Civil Guards had not released theirs, and most of them were thrown into prison and kept there without trial, in many cases for months on end.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1065,"[' As usual, completely innocent people were being arrested owing to police bungling.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1066,"[' Afterwards we had lost touch with him, as usually happened when a man was wounded, for wounded men were frequently moved from one hospital to another.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
