1067,[' Actually he was at Tarragona hospital and was sent back to Barcelona about the time when the fighting started.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1068,"[' On the Tuesday morning I met him in the street, considerably bewildered by the firing that was going on all round.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1069,[' I shall go back to my hotel and stay there.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1070,"['-He went back to his hotel, but unfortunately (how important it is in street-fighting to understand the local geography!']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1071,[') it was a hotel in a part of the town controlled by the Civil Guards.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1072,"[' The place was raided and Thompson was arrested, flung into jail, and kept for eight days in a cell so full of people that nobody had room to lie down.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1073,"[' Numerous foreigners with doubtful political records were on the run, with the police on their track and in constant fear of denunciation.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1074,"[' It was worst for the Italians and Germans, who had no passports and were generally wanted by the secret police in their own countries.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1077,"[' The long nightmare of the fighting, the noise, the lack of food and sleep, the mingled strain and boredom of sitting on the roof and wondering whether in another minute I should be shot myself or be obliged to shoot somebody else had put my nerves on edge.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1078,[' I had got to the point when every time a door banged I grabbed for my pistol.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1080,['-I ran into the street to find that it was only some Assault Guards shooting a mad dog.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1081,"[' No one who was in Barcelona then, or for months later, will forget the horrible atmosphere produced by fear, suspicion, hatred, censored newspapers, crammed jails, enormous food queues, and prowling gangs of armed men.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1082,[' I have tried to give some idea of what it felt like to be in the middle of the Barcelona fighting; yet I do not suppose I have succeeded in conveying much of the strangeness of that time.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1083,"[' One of the things that stick in my mind when I look back is the casual contacts one made at the time, the sudden glimpses of non-combatants to whom the whole thing was simply a meaningless uproar.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1084,"[' I remember the fashionably-dressed woman I saw strolling down the Ramblas, with a shopping-basket over her arm and leading a white poodle, while the rifles cracked and roared a street or two away.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1085,"[' And the man I saw rushing across the completely empty Plaza de Cataluña, brandishing a white handkerchief in each hand.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1086,[' And the large party of people all dressed in black who kept trying for about an hour to cross the Plaza de Cataluña and always failing.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1087,[' Every time they emerged from the side-street at the corner the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1090,['-And the people in the shoe-shop who were making my marching-boots.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1091,"[' I went there before the fighting, after it was over, and, for a very few minutes, during the brief armistice on 5 May.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1092,"[' It was an expensive shop, and the shop- people were U .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1093,"[' There must have been quantities of people, perhaps a majority of the inhabitants of Barcelona, who regarded the whole affair without a nicker of interest, or with no more interest than they would have felt in an air-raid.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1095,[' So much political capital has been made out of the Barcelona fighting that it is important to try and get a balanced view of it.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1096,"[' Nearly all the newspaper accounts published at the time were manufactured by journalists at a distance, and were not only inaccurate in their facts but intentionally misleading.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1097,[' Like everyone who was in Barcelona at the time.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1098,"[' As before, if you are not interested in political controversy and the mob of parties and sub-parties with their confusing names (rather like the names of the generals in a Chinese war), please skip.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1099,[' It is a horrible thing to have to enter into the details of inter-party polemics; it is like diving into a cesspool.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1100,"[' 11 I T will never be possible to get a completely accurate and unbiased account of the Barcelona fighting, because the necessary records do not exist.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1101,[' In earlier chapters of this book I have given some account of the struggle between Communists and Anarchists.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1102,[' By May 1937 things had reached a point at which some kind of violent outbreak could be regarded as inevitable.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1104,[' In addition there was a certain amount of resentment among the working classes because of the growing contrast of wealth and poverty and a general vague feeling that the revolution had been sabotaged.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1105,[' Many people were agreeably surprised when there was no rioting on i May.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1106,"[' On 3 May the Government decided to take over the Telephone Exchange, which had been operated since the beginning of the war mainly by C .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1107,"[' Salas, the Chief of Police (who may or may not have been exceeding his orders), sent three lorry-loads of armed Civil Guards to seize the building, while the streets outside were cleared by armed police in civilian clothes.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1108,[' At about the same time bands of Civil Guards seized various other buildings in strategic spots.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1109,"[' The word flew round the town that the workers-buildings were being attacked, armed Anarchists appeared on the streets, work ceased, and fighting broke out immediately.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1110,"[' forces held the working-class suburbs, and the armed police-forces and the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1111,"[' On 6 May there was an armistice, but fighting soon broke out again, probably because of premature attempts by Civil Guards to disarm C .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1112,"[' Next morning, however, the people began to leave the barricades of their own accord.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1113,"[' had had the better of it, and large numbers of Civil Guards had surrendered.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1115,"[' That evening six thousand Assault Guards, sent by sea from Valencia, arrived and took control of the town.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1116,"[' The Government issued an order for the surrender of all arms except those held by the regular forces, and during the next few days large numbers of arms were seized.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1117,[' The casualties during the fighting were officially given out as four hundred killed and about a thousand wounded.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1118,"[' There is no evidence that the outbreak had any direct effect upon the course of the war, though obviously it must have had if it continued even a few days longer.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1119,"[' It was made the excuse for bringing Catalonia under the direct control of Valencia, for hastening the break-up of the militias, and for the suppression of the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1120,[' But we may take it as certain that these things would have happened in any case.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1121,[' workers who came into the street gained or lost by showing fight on this occasion.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1122,[' The seizure of the Barcelona Telephone Exchange was simply one incident in a long process.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1123,"[' Since the previous year direct power had been gradually manoeuvred out of the hands of the syndicates, and the general movement was away from working-class control and towards centralized control, leading on to State capitalism or, possibly, towards the reintroduction of private capitalism.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1124,"[' A year after the outbreak of war the Catalan workers had lost much of their power, but their position was still comparatively favourable.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1125,"[' The people came into the streets and their political leaders followed reluctantly, or did not follow at all.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1126,"[' The only people who even talked in a revolutionary strain were the Friends of Durruti, a small extremist group within the F .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1127,"[' The Friends of Durruti distributed some kind of revolutionary leaflet, but this did not appear until 5 May and cannot be said to have started the fighting, which had started of its own accord two days earlier.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1130,"[' There can be no certainty about this, but it was at least inherently likely that the British Government, which had not raised a finger to save the Spanish Government from Franco, would intervene quickly enough to save it from its own working class.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1131,"[' leaders did not disown the affair, in fact they encouraged their followers to remain at the barricades and even gave their approval (in La Batalla, 6 May) to the extremist leaflet issued by the Friends of Durruti.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1132,"[' From comparison of various reports I should say that the leaflet called for (i) The formation of a revolutionary council (junta), (ii) The shooting of those responsible for the attack on the Telephone Exchange, (iii) The disarming of the Civil Guards.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1135,"['-(In other words, it merely demanded what was happening already.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1136,[') But in reality the attitude of the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1137,"[' They had never been in favour of insurrection until the war against Franco was won; on the other hand the workers had come into the streets, and the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1138,[' leaders took the rather pedantic Marxist line that when the workers are on the streets it is the duty of the revolutionary parties to be with them.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1139,"[' They never, for instance, ordered an attack on any building; they merely ordered their followers to remain on guard and, as I mentioned in the last chapter, not to fire when it could be avoided.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1140,"[' leaders at the time (I myself was not) have told me that they were in reality dismayed by the whole business, but felt that they had got to associate themselves with it.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1141,[' From the propaganda point of view this may have been the right line; certainly the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1144,"[' However, we may be certain that the Communist press would have said this in any case.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1145,"[' So far as one could judge from what people were saying at the time, there was no real revolutionary intention anywhere.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1146,"[' workers among them, and what they were attempting was not to overthrow the Government but to resist what they regarded, rightly or wrongly, as an attack by the police.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1148,[' It is significant that something very similar (seizure of the Telephone Exchange by armed police acting under orders from Barcelona) happened in Tarragona two days later.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1149,"[' adherents seized buildings in strategic spots, if not actually before the fighting started, at any rate with surprising promptitude.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1150,[' But what one has got to remember is that these things were happening in Spain and not in England.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1151,[' Barcelona is a town with a long history of street-fighting.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1152,"[' In such places things happen quickly, the factions are ready-made, everyone knows the local geography, and when the guns begin to shoot people take their places almost as in a fire-drill.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1154,[' There are two reasons why I do not believe that either side had made preparations for large-scale fighting: (i) Neither side had brought troops to Barcelona beforehand.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1155,"[' The fighting was only between those who were in Barcelona already, mainly civilians and police.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1156,[' Anyone who has served in Spain knows that the one operation of war that Spaniards really perform really well is that of feeding their troops.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1157,[' It is most unlikely that if either side had contemplated a week or two of street-fighting and a general strike they would not have stored food beforehand.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1158,"[' A tremendous dust was kicked up in the foreign anti-Fascist press, but, as usual, only one side of the case has had anything like a hearing.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1160,[' Undoubtedly when you are at war with a deadly enemy it is better not to begin fighting among yourselves; but it is worth remembering that it takes two to make a quarrel and that people do not begin building barricades unless they have received something that they regard as a provocation.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1162,[' In the English press this was translated into English terms and took this form: that arms were desperately needed on the Aragon front and could not be sent there because the unpatriotic Anarchists were holding them back.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1163,[' To put it like this is to ignore the conditions actually existing in Spain.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1164,"[' were hoarding arms, and when the fighting broke out in Barcelona this was made clearer still; both sides produced arms in abundance.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1165,"[' , politically the main power in Catalonia, would still retain theirs; and this in fact was what happened after the fighting was over.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1166,"[' Meanwhile actually visible on the streets, there were quantities of arms which would have been very welcome at the front, but which were being retained for the -non-political-police forces in the rear.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1167,"[' And underneath this there was the irreconcilable difference between Communists and Anarchists, which was bound to lead to some kind of struggle sooner or later.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1168,"[' Since the beginning of the war the Spanish Communist Party had grown enormously in numbers and captured most of the political power, and there had come into Spain thousands of foreign Communists, many of whom were openly expressing their intention of -liquidating-Anarchism as soon as the war against Franco was won.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1169,[' In the circumstances one could hardly expect the Anarchists to hand over the weapons which they had got possession of in the summer of 1936.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1170,[' The seizure of the Telephone Exchange was simply the match that fired an already existing bomb.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1171,"[' Company, the Catalan President, is said to have declared laughingly a few days earlier that the Anarchists would put up with anything.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1172,['[10] But certainly it was not a wise action.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1173,[' For months past there had been a long series of armed clashes between Communists and Anarchists in various parts of Spain.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1174,"[' Catalonia and especially Barcelona was in a state of tension that had already led to street affrays, assassinations, and so forth.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1175,[' Suddenly the news ran round the city that armed men were attacking the buildings that the workers had captured in the July fighting and to which they attached great sentimental importance.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1176,[' One must remember that the Civil Guards were not loved by the working-class population.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1177,"[' had been simply an appendage of the landlord and the boss, and the Civil Guards were doubly hated because they were suspected, quite justly, of being of very doubtful loyalty against the Fascists.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1178,['[11] It is probable that the emotion that brought people into the streets in the first few hours was much the same emotion as had led them to resist the rebel generals at the beginning of the war.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1179,"[' But, after all, there was a war on, and they had no business to start a fight behind the lines.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1180,['-Here I agree entirely.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1181,[' The Government may or may not have had the right to seize the Telephone Exchange; the point is that in the actual circumstances it was bound to lead to a fight.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1183,['-It was not common sense to expect anything but resistance.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1184,[' The reason why a one-sided version has been accepted is simply that the Spanish revolutionary parties have no footing in the foreign press.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1185,"[' In the English press, in particular, you would have to search for a long time before finding any favourable reference, at any period of the war, to the Spanish Anarchists.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1186,"[' I have tried to write objectively about the Barcelona fighting, though, obviously, no one can be completely objective on a question of this kind.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1187,"[' It is very difficult to write accurately about the Spanish war, because of the lack of non- propagandist documents.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1188,[' But it will be seen that the account I have given is completely different from that which appeared in the foreign and especially the Communist press.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1189,"[' It is necessary to examine the Communist version, because it was published all over the world, has been supplemented at short intervals ever since, and is probably the most widely accepted one.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1190,[' In the Communist and pro-Communist press the entire blame for the Barcelona fighting was laid upon the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1304,"[' For a while the Communist Press of the whole world was flaming with this kind of thing (Daily Worker, 21 June, summarizing various Spanish Communist papers): S P A N I S H T R O T S K Y I S T S P L O T W I T H F R A N C O Following the arrest of a large number of leading Trotskyists in Barcelona and elsewhere .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1305,"[' leaders were transmitting military secrets to General Franco by radio, were in touch with Berlin, and were acting in collaboration with the secret Fascist organization in Madrid.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1306,"[' Had they really been guilty of espionage they would have been tried and shot in a week, as so many Fascist spies had been previously.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1307,[' Recently the cabinet decided by five to two in favour of releasing anti-Fascist political prisoners; the two dissentients being the Communist ministers.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1308,"[' leaders to be responsible for the May fighting in Barcelona, but dismissed the idea of their being Fascist spies.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1309,"[' leaders was not decided upon by the Government, and the police carried out these arrests on their own authority.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1310,"[' Those responsible are not the heads of the police, but their entourage, which has been infiltrated by the Communists according to their usual custom.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1311,['-He cited other cases of illegal arrests by the police.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1312,[' Irujo likewise declared that the police had become -quasi- independent-and were in reality under the control of foreign Communist elements.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1313,[' Prieto hinted fairly broadly to the delegation that the Government could not afford to offend the Communist Party while the Russians were supplying arms.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1315,[' -We have received aid from Russia and have had to permit certain actions which we did not like.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1316,"['-As an illustration of the autonomy of the police, it is interesting to learn that even with a signed order from the Director of Prisons and the Minister of Justice, McGovern and the others could not obtain admission to one of the -secret prisons-maintained by the Communist Party in Barcelona.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1317,['[12] I think this should be enough to make the matter clear.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1319,"[' was really a Fascist spying organization, unless one also believes that Maxton, Mc-Govern, Prieto, Irujo, Zugazagoitia, and the rest are all in Fascist pay together.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1321,[' When the war broke out the foreign Trotskyists who came to Spain (fifteen or twenty in number) worked at first for the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1322,"[' , as the party nearest to their own viewpoint, but without becoming party-members; later Trotsky ordered his followers to attack the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1323,"[' policy, and the Trotskyists were purged from the party offices, though a few remained in the militia.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1325,"[' by the amalgamation of various Opposition Communists with an earlier party, the Workers-and Peasants-Bloc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1329,['e.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1330,[' that the whole Trotskyist organization is simply a Fascist spying-machine.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1331,"[' -Trotskyism-only came into public notice in the time of the Russian sabotage trials, and to call a man a Trotskyist is practically equivalent to calling him a murderer, agent provocateur, etc.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1332,[' But at the same time anyone who criticizes Communist policy from a Left-wing standpoint is liable to be denounced as a Trotskyist.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1335,"[' The reason, of course, is simply that several sharp lessons have given the English Communist press a wholesome dread of the law of libel.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1336,"[' Compared with the huge miseries of a civil war, this kind of internecine squabble between parties, with its inevitable injustices and false accusations, may appear trivial.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1337,"[' I believe that libels and press- campaigns of this kind, and the habits of mind they indicate, are capable of doing the most deadly damage to the anti-Fascist cause.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1338,[' Anyone who has given the subject a glance knows that the Communist tactic of dealing with political opponents by means of trumped-up accusations is nothing new.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1339,"[' It is only six or seven years since the Russian State trials -proved-that the leaders of the Second International, including, for instance, Leon Blum and prominent members of the British Labour Party, were hatching a huge plot for the military invasion of the U .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1340,"[' Yet today the French Communists are glad enough to accept Blum as a leader, and the English Communists are raising heaven and earth to get inside the Labour Party.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1341,"[' I doubt whether this kind of thing pays, even from a sectarian point of view.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1343,[' are driven back into the terribly sterile position of being mere anti-Communist parties.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1344,"[' A few more libels against life-long Socialists, a few more frame-ups like the charges against the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1345,[' The Communists hold that Fascism can be beaten by alliance with sections of the capitalist class (the Popular Front); their opponents hold that this manoeuvre simply gives Fascism new breeding-grounds.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1346,[' But so long as no argument is produced except a scream of -Trotsky-Fascist!'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1347,['-the discussion cannot even begin.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1349,"[' If he followed his party -line* dutifully he would have to declare that I am lying or, at best, that I am hopelessly misled and that anyone who glanced at the Daily Worker headlines a thousand miles from the scene of events knows more of what was happening in Barcelona than I do.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1350,[' What purpose is served by saying that men like Maxton are in Fascist pay?'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1352,['O.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1353,['U.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1354,['M.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1355,[' troops to leave the front!'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1356,[' The point can easily be settled by referring to La Batalla of the date named.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1357,['[back] [10] New Statesman (14 May).'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1358,['[back] [11] At the outbreak of war the Civil Guards had everywhere sided with the stronger party.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1359,"[' On several occasions later in the war, e.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1360,['g.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1361,"[' at Santander, the local Civil Guards went over to the Fascists in a body.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1363,['[back] 12 I T must have been three days after the Barcelona fighting ended that we returned to the front.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1365,"[' My mind went back to the newspaper correspondent whom I had met my first day in Barcelona, and who said to me: -This war is a racket the same as any other.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1366,"['-The remark had shocked me deeply, and at that time (December) I do not believe it was true; it was not true even now, in May; but it was becoming truer.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1367,"[' The fact is that every war suffers a kind of progressive degradation with every month that it continues, because such things as individual liberty and a truthful press are simply not compatible with military efficiency.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1368,[' One could begin now to make some kind of guess at what was likely to happen.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1369,"[' It was easy to see that the Caballero Government would fall and be replaced by a more Right-wing Government with a stronger Communist influence (this happened a week or two later), which would set itself to break the power of the trade unions once and for all.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1370,"[' No one in his senses supposed that there was any hope of democracy, even as we understand it in England or France, in a country so divided and exhausted as Spain would be when the war was over.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1372,"[' The only alternatives were an infinitely worse dictatorship by Franco, or (always a possibility) that the war would end with Spain divided up, either by actual frontiers or into economicszones.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1373,[' But it did not follow that the Government was not worth fighting for as against the more naked and developed Fascism of Franco and Hitler.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1377,[' The Government in control at the end of the war would at any rate be anti- clerical and anti-feudal.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1379,"[' Since 1930 the Fascists had won all the victories; it was time they got a beating, it hardly mattered from whom.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1380,"[' If we could drive Franco and his foreign mercenaries into the sea it might make an immense improvement in the world situation, even if Spain itself emerged with a stifling dictatorship and all its best men in jail.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1381,[' This was how I saw things at the time.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1383,"[' It has kept up the difficult fight with splendid courage, and it has shown more political tolerance than anyone expected.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1385,"[' We had just reached the front when we heard that Bob Smillie, on his way back to England, had been arrested at the frontier, taken down to Valencia, and thrown into jail.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1386,[' It was some time before we could discover what he had been arrested for.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1389,"[' The Barcelona fighting had only just ended and the authorities were, at that moment, extremely anxious not to let anyone out of Spain who was in a position to contradict the official version.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1390,"[' But the trouble is that, in Spain, once you are in jail you generally stay there, with or without trial.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1391,"[' We were still at Huesca, but they had placed us further to the right, opposite the Fascist redoubt which we had temporarily captured a few weeks earlier.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1393,"[' The Government could not, of course, dispense with the militia officers, but it was not confirming any of them in a higher rank than major, presumably in order to keep the higher commands for Regular Army officers and the new officers from the School of War.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1394,"[' As a result, in our division, the agth, and no doubt in many others, you had the queer temporary situation of the divisional commander, the brigade commanders, and the battalion commanders all being majors.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1395,[' The battle round the Jaca road had died away and did not begin again till mid June.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1396,"[' The Fascist trenches were more than a hundred and fifty yards away, but they were on higher ground and were on two sides of us, our line forming a right-angle salient.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1397,[' From time to time the Fascists let fly at us with a rifle-grenade or some similar weapon.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1399,"[' The nights were pleasantly warm, the days blazing hot, the mosquitoes were becoming a nuisance, and in spite of the clean clothes we had brought from Barcelona we were almost immediately lousy.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1400,"[' For two days there were torrential rains, the dug-outs flooded, and the parapet sank a foot; after that there were more days of digging out the sticky clay with the wretched Spanish spades which have no handles and bend like tin spoons.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1402,"[' By crawling a hundred yards you could get to a ditch, hidden by tall grasses, which commanded a gap in the Fascist parapet.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1403,[' If you waited long enough you generally saw a khaki-clad figure slip hurriedly across the gap.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1405,"[' But it was rather fun, the Fascists did not know where the shots were coming from, and I made sure I would get one of them sooner or later.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1407,"[' This was always a dangerous time, because we had the dawn at our backs, and if you stuck your head above the parapet it was clearly outlined against the sky.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1409,"[' I knew immediately that I was hit, but because of the seeming bang and flash I thought it was a rifle nearby that had gone off accidentally and shot me.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1410,"[' I knew that there was one in my pocket and tried to get it out, but discovered that my right arm was paralysed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1411,"[' This ought to please my wife, I thought; she had always wanted me to be wounded, which would save me from being killed when the great battle came.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1412,"[' As they lifted me up a lot of blood poured out of my mouth, and I heard a Spaniard behind me say that the bullet had gone clean through my neck.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1413,"[' I felt the alcohol, which at ordinary times would sting like the devil, splash on to the wound as a pleasant coolness.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1416,"[' I reflected that as he was a Fascist I would have killed him if I could, but that if he had been taken prisoner and brought before me at this moment I would merely have congratulated him on his good shooting.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1417,[' They had just got me on to the stretcher when my paralysed right arm came to life and began hurting damnably.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1418,"[' At the time I imagined that I must have broken it in falling; but the pain reassured me, for I knew that your sensations do not become more acute when you are dying.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1419,"[' I knew what a sweat it was, having helped to carry a wounded man down a day or two earlier.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1420,"[' The leaves of the silver poplars which, in places, fringed our trenches brushed against my face; I thought what a good thing it was to be alive in a world where silver poplars grow.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1421,"[' But all the while the pain in my arm was diabolical, making me swear and then try not to swear, because every time I breathed too hard the blood bubbled out of my mouth.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1422,"[' The hospitals at Sietamo were hurriedly constructed wooden huts where the wounded were, as a rule, only kept for a few hours before being sent on to Barbastro or Lerida.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1424,[' Presently two comrades who had got permission to leave the line for a few hours appeared at my bedside.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1426,"[' It used to be said that in this war you got well if you were wounded in the extremities, but always died of a wound in the abdomen.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1427,[' No one who was liable to bleed internally could have survived those miles of jolting over metal roads that had been smashed to pieces by heavy lorries and never repaired since the war began.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1428,[' It took me back to my early childhood and a dreadful thing called the Wiggle-Woggle at the White City Exhibition.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1429,"[' I had enough strength in my left arm to hang on, but one poor wretch was spilt on to the floor and suffered God knows what agonies.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1430,"[' An English- speaking Dutch Communist, having heard that there was an Englishman in the hospital, befriended me and brought me English newspapers.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1431,"[' He had been ter-ribly wounded in the October fighting, and had somehow managed to settle down at Lerida hospital and had married one of the nurses.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1432,"[' Two militiamen on leave, whom I had met my first week at the front, came in to see a wounded friend and recognized me.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1433,"[' They stood awkwardly beside my bed, trying to think of something to say, and then, as a way of demonstrating that they were sorry I was wounded, suddenly took all the tobacco out of their pockets, gave it to me, and fled before I could give it back.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1435,"[' The tremendous shock of a bullet prevents sensation locally; a splinter of shell or bomb, which is jagged and usually hits you less hard, would probably hurt like the devil.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1437,"[' But there were two bad faults on account of which, I have no doubt, hundreds or thousands of men have died who might have been saved.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1438,[' One was the fact that all the hospitals anywhere near the front line were used more or less as casualty clearing-stations.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1439,"[' In theory most of the wounded were sent straight to Barcelona or Tarragona, but owing to the lack of transport they were often a week or ten days in getting there.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1440,"[' Men with dreadful shell wounds, smashed bones, and so forth, were swathed in a sort of casing made of bandages and plaster of Paris; a description of the wound was written in pencil on the outside, and as a rule the casing was not removed till the man reached Barcelona or Tarragona ten days later.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1442,['-There were always rumours that the hospital train was leaving for Barcelona mañana.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1443,"[' Apparently there was no supply of trained nurses in Spain, perhaps because before the war this work was done chiefly by nuns.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1444,[' I remember one poor devil with a smashed arm telling me that he had been three weeks without having his face washed.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1445,[' Even more in Spain than elsewhere it seemed to be the tradition to stuff sick people with heavy food.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1447,[' One morning it was announced that the men in my ward were to be sent down to Barcelona today.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1448,"[' I managed to send a wire to my wife, telling her that I was coming, and presently they packed us into buses and took us down to the station.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1449,"[' It was only when the train was actually starting that the hospital orderly who travelled with us casually let fall that we were not going to Barcelona after all, but to Tarragona.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1450,"[' They had put us into ordinary third-class carriages with wooden seats, and many of the men were badly wounded and had only got out of bed for the first time that morning.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1451,"[' The hospital orderly threaded his way among the corpse-like forms that sprawled everywhere, carrying a large goatskin bottle full of water which he squirted into this mouth or that.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1452,"[' As our train drew into the station a troop-train full of men from the International Column was drawing out, and a knot of people on the bridge were waving to them.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1453,"[' It was a very long train, packed to bursting-point with men, with field-guns lashed on the open trucks and more men clustering round the guns.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1456,[' We heard afterwards that these were some of the troops who won the great victory at Guadalajara in March; they had been on leave and were being transferred to the Aragon front.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1457,[' The men who were well enough to stand had moved across the carriage to cheer the Italians as they went past.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1459,"[' They had a way of treating certain wounds which I suppose was in accordance with the latest medical practice, but which was peculiarly horrible to look at.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1460,[' There was one man wounded in the face and throat who had his head inside a sort of spherical helmet of butter-muslin; his mouth was closed up and he breathed through a little tube that was fixed between his lips.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1461,"[' My strength was coming back, and one day, by going slowly, I managed to walk down as far as the beach.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1462,[' It was queer to see the seaside life going on almost as usual; the smart cafés along the promenade and the plump local bourgeoisie bathing and sunning themselves in deck-chairs as though there had not been a war within a thousand miles.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1463,"[' Finally, eight or nine days after leaving the front, I had my wound examined.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1466,"['-After doing this till my tongue was bleeding and my eyes running with water, he told me that one vocal cord was paralysed.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1467,"[' It was a shooting pain like neuralgia, and it went on hurting continuously for about a month, especially at night, so that I did not get much sleep.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1470,"[' With the fall of the Caballero Government the Communists had come definitely into power, the charge of internal order had been handed over to Communist ministers, and no one doubted that they would smash their political rivals as soon as they got a quarter of a chance Nothing was happening as yet, I myself had not even any mental picture of what was going to happen; and yet there was a perpetual vague sense of danger, a consciousness of some evil thing that was impending.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1471,"[' However little you were actually conspiring, the atmosphere forced you to feel like a conspirator.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1472,[' You seemed to spend all your time holding whispered conversations in corners of cafés and wondering whether that person at the next table was a police spy.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1473,"[' At the time I was inclined to believe this, for the Fascists were closing in on Bilbao and the Government was visibly doing nothing to save it.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1475,[' was distributing in huge numbers a leaflet saying: -Be on your guard!'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1477,"[' Earlier, when we went back to the front, I had seen the powerful defences that were being constructed scores of miles behind the front line, and fresh bomb-proof shelters were being dug all over Barcelona.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1478,"[' There were frequent scares of air-raids and sea-raids; more often than not these were false alarms, but every time the sirens blew the lights all over the town blacked out for hours on end and timid people dived for the cellars.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1481,[' Foreigners from the International Column and other militias were getting into jail in larger and larger numbers.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1482,"[' A few months earlier anyone enlisting in the militia had been told that he was a volunteer and could, if he wished, get his discharge papers at any time when he was due for leave.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1483,"[' Now it appeared that the Government had changed its mind, a militiaman was a regular soldier and counted as a deserter if he tried to go home.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1484,"[' Later the number of foreign -deserters-in jail swelled into hundreds, but most of them were repatriated when a fuss was made in their own countries.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1485,"[' Bands of armed Assault Guards roamed everywhere in the streets, the Civil Guards were still holding cafés and other buildings in strategic spots, and many of the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1486,[' At various points in the town there were posts manned by Civil Guards of Carabineros who stopped passers-by and demanded their papers.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1488,[' There was a new rule that censored portions of a newspaper must not be left blank but filled up with other matter; as a result it was often impossible to tell when something had been cut out.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1489,"[' There was an acute shortage of olive oil, which Spaniards use for half a dozen different purposes.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1491,"[' The silver had been withdrawn and as yet no new coinage had been issued, so that there was nothing between the ten- centime piece and the note for two and a half pesetas, and all notes below ten pesetas were very scarce.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1492,['[13] For the poorest people this meant an aggravation of the food shortage.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1494,"[' It is not easy to convey it because, at the moment, the thing essential to such an atmosphere does not exist in England.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1497,"[' Some of the English visitors who flitted briefly through Spain, from hotel to hotel, seem not to have noticed that there was anything wrong with the general atmosphere.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1498,"[' It was in the suburbs near Tibidabo, the queer-shaped mountain that rises abruptly behind Barcelona and is traditionally supposed to have been the hill from which Satan showed Jesus the countries of the earth (hence its name).']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1499,[' The house had previously belonged to some wealthy bourgeois and had been seized at the time of the revolution.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1501,"[' There were several other Englishmen there: Williams, with a damaged leg, and Stafford Cottman, a boy of eighteen, who had been sent back from the trenches with suspected tuberculosis, and Arthur Clinton, whose smashed left arm was still strapped on to one of those huge wire contraptions, nicknamed aeroplanes, which the Spanish hospitals were using.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1502,"[' My wife was still staying at the Hotel Continental, and I generally came into Barcelona in the daytime.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1504,"[' I was extremely weak, my voice was gone, seemingly for good, and the doctors told me that at best it would be several months before I was fit to fight.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1505,"[' I had got to start earning some money sooner or later, and there did not seem much sense in staying in Spain and eating food that was needed for other people.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1507,"[' The Government had brought troops from the Madrid front and were concentrating thirty thousand men, with aeroplanes in huge numbers.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1508,[' The Italians I had seen going up the line from Tarragona had attacked on the Jaca road but had had heavy casualties and lost two tanks.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1509,[' The attack was a frightful mess-up and led to nothing except an orgy of lying in the newspapers.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1510,[') Meanwhile Kopp had to go down to Valencia for an interview at the Ministry of War.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1512,[' It was five days before I got back to Barcelona.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1513,"[' headquarters they lined us up and began handling out rifles and cartridges, before even taking our names.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1514,[' It seemed that the attack was beginning and they were likely to call for reserves at any moment.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1516,"[' However, there was a bit of mañana, as usual, we were not called out after all, and next morning I produced my hospital ticket and went in search of my discharge.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1519,[' As soon as you got away from the railroad there was no way of travelling except by jumping chance lorries.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1520,"[' When finally you struck a lorry that was not chock full of men, loaves of bread, or ammunition-boxes the bumping over the vile roads wallowed you to pulp.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1521,"[' In the next bed to me there was an Assault Guard, wounded over the left eye.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1522,[' It was queer how the general spirit seemed to change when you got anywhere near the front line.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1523,[' That kind of thing belonged in Barcelona or in places even remoter from the war.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1524,"[' Down in Barcelona they were lords of the street, but up here they were quintos (rookies) and palled up with militia children of fifteen who had been in the line for months.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1525,"[' I was free to go back to England; consequently I felt able, almost for the first time, to look at Spain.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1527,"[' Wandering through it I became aware of pleasant tortuous streets, old stone bridges, wine shops with great oozy barrels as tall as a man, and intriguing semi-subterranean shops where men were making cartwheels, daggers, wooden spoons, and goatskin water-bottles.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1529,"[' And in Lerida there were old crumbling buildings upon whose cornices thousands upon thousands of swallows had built their nests, so that at a little distance the crusted pattern of nests was like some florid moulding of the rococo period.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1530,[' It was queer how for nearly six months past I had had no eyes for such things.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1531,"[' For almost the first time I felt that I was really in Spain, in a country that I had longed all my life to visit.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1534,"[' It seemed a pity that when at last I had managed to come here I had seen only this north-eastern corner, in the middle of a confused war and for the most part in winter.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1536,"[' She got up and came towards me in what struck me as a very unconcerned manner; then she put an arm round my neck and, with a sweet smile for the benefit of the other people in the lounge, hissed in my ear: -Get out!']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1537,['--What?'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1538,['--Get out of here at once!'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1539,['--What?'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1541,"[' On 15 June the police had suddenly arrested Andrés Nin in his office, and the same evening had raided the Hotel Falcón and arrested all the people in it, mostly militiamen on leave.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1542,"[' was declared an illegal organization and all its offices, book-stalls, sanatoria, Red Aid centres, and so forth were seized.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1543,[' Meanwhile the police were arresting everyone they could lay hands on who was known to have any connexion with the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1545,[' There was no way of discovering how many people had been arrested.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1546,[' I have since thought that even at that time the numbers must have been greater.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1547,[' In some cases the police had even gone to the length of dragging wounded militiamen out of the hospitals.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1551,"[' , in any Barcelona papers, Communist, Anarchist, or Republican.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1557,"[' After his arrest Nin was transferred to Valencia and thence to Madrid, and as early as 21 June the rumour reached Barcelona that he had been shot.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1558,[' Later the rumour took a more definite shape: Nin had been shot in prison by the secret police and his body dumped into the street.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1569,[' His men sent a delegation to protest at the Ministry of War.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1571,"[' In the whole business the detail that most sticks in my throat, though perhaps it is not of great importance, is that all news of what was happening was kept from the troops at the front.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1572,"[' militia headquarters, Red Aid centres, and so forth were functioning as usual, and as late as 20 June and as far down the line as Lerida, only about 100 miles from Barcelona, no one had heard what was happening.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1573,"[' All word of it was kept out of the Barcelona papers (the Valencia papers, which were running the spy stories, did not reach the Aragon front), and no doubt one reason for arresting all the P .']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1574,"[' I am still puzzled to know how the thing was kept secret, for the supply lorries and so forth were still passing to and fro; but there is no doubt that it was kept secret, and, as I have since learned from a number of others, the men in the front line heard nothing till several days later.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1575,"[' militia was still a separate unit, and it was probably feared that if the men knew what was happening they would refuse to fight.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1576,[' In the intervening days there must have been numbers of men who were killed without ever learning that the newspapers in the rear were calling them Fascists.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1577,[' This kind of thing is a little difficult to forgive.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1578,"[' I know it was the usual policy to keep bad news from the troops, and perhaps as a rule that is justified.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1579,"[' But it is a different matter to send men into battle and not even tell them that behind their backs their party is being suppressed, their leaders accused of treachery, and their friends and relatives thrown into prison.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1580,[' I thought he was in Valencia.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1582,"[' had been suppressed, of course, but probably it did not occur to him that the police could be such fools as to arrest him when he was on his way to the front on an urgent military mission.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1583,"[' He had come round to the Hotel Continental to fetch his kit-bags; my wife had been out at the time, and the hotel people had managed to detain him with some lying story while they rang up the police.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1585,"[' By leaving Belgium without permission and joining a foreign army while he was on the Belgian Army reserve, and, earlier, by helping to manufacture munitions illegally for the Spanish Government, he had piled up years of imprisonment for himself if he should ever return to his own country.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1586,"[' He had been in the line since October 1936, had worked his way up from militiaman to major, had been in action I do not know how many times, and had been wounded once.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1600,[' My wife went back to the hotel and I wandered off into the darkness to find somewhere to sleep.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1613,[' militiamen who had come down the line on the previous day to find that the P .'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1629,"[' People were penned together in small rooms where there was barely space for them to lie down, and often they were kept in cellars and other dark places.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1634,"[' Here was this brave and gifted boy, who had thrown up his career at Glasgow University in order to come and fight against Fascism, and who, as I saw for myself, had done his job at the front with faultless courage and willingness; and all they could find to do with him was to fling him into jail and let him die like a neglected animal.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1635,[' I know that in the middle of a huge and bloody war it is no use making too much fuss over an individual death.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1636,[' One aeroplane bomb in a crowded street causes more suffering than quite a lot of political persecution.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1641,"[' And the first person we saw inside was an American militiaman who had left for home a few days earlier; his papers were in good order, but they had arrested him at the frontier all the same, probably because he was still wearing corduroy breeches and was therefore identifiable as a militiaman.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1642,"[' For months, had shared a dug-out with him, he had helped to carry me down the line when I was wounded; but it was the only thing one could do.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1644,[' The place had been used as a dump for political prisoners for months past.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1645,"[' This was the visiting hour, and the place was so packed with people that it was difficult to move.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1646,[' You saw women undoing pitiful packets of food which they had brought for their imprisoned men-folk.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20
1647,"[' His plump fresh-coloured face looked much as usual, and in that filthy place he had kept his uniform neat and had even contrived to shave.']",George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

1648,[' A bullet had entered my own body recently and the feeling of it was fresh in my memory; it is not nice to think of that happening to anyone you know well.'],George Orwell,HOMAGE TO CATALONIA,20

3261,['And he was the first to get up.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3262,[' Poirot did not answer.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3263,"[' -It is queer,I said in a low voice.']",Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3264,[' -You must admit it is queer.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3265,['-Eh?'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3266,['-I said it was queer-4about Ross and thirteen.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3267,"[' Poirot, what are you thinking about?']",Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3268,"['To my utter amazement and, I must admit, somewhat to my disgust, Poirot began suddenly to shake with laughter.']",Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3269,[' -What the devil are you laughing at?'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3270,['I said sharply.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3271,"[' What is it that has two legs, feathers, and barks like a dog?']",Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3272,"['-A chicken, of course,I said wearily.']",Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3273,[' -I knew that in the nursery.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3274,"['-You are too well informed, Hastings.']",Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3275,"[' You should say, -I do not know.']",Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3276,"['-d And then me, I say, -A chicken,-d and then you say, -But a chicken does not bark like a dog,-d and I say, -Ah!']",Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3277,[' I put that in to make it more difficult.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3278,"['-d Supposing, Hastings, that there we have the explanation of the letter D?']",Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3279,['-What nonsense!'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3280,"['-Yes, to most people, but to a certain type of mind.']",Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20

3281,"[' People were streaming out of it discussing their own affairs, their servants, their friends of the opposite sex, and just occasionally, the picture they had just seen.']",Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3282,[' The way he rode down the cliff and got there in time with the papers.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3283,['Her escort was less enthusiastic.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3284,[' If they-9d just had the sense to ask Ellis right away.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3285,[' Reaching the pavement I turned back to see Poirot standing in the middle of the road with buses bearing down on him from either side.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3286,[' In a dignified manner Poirot walked to the kerb.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20
3287,[' He looked like a man walking in his sleep.'],Agatha Christie,Lord Edgware Dies-Berkley,20

0,"['He told us that when Vesputius had sailed away, he, and his companions that stayed behind in New Castile, by degrees insinuated themselves into the affections of the people of the country, meeting often with them and treating them gently; and at last they not only lived among them with- out danger, but conversed familiarly with them, and got so far into the heart of a prince, whose name and country I have forgot, that he both furnished them plentifully with all things necessary, and also with the conveniences of travelling, both boats when they went by water, and waggons when they trained over land: he sent with them a very faithful guide, who was to introduce and recommend them to such other princes as they had a mind to see: and after many days-9 jour- ney, they came to towns, and cities, and to commonwealths, that were both happily governed and well peopled.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

1,"[' Under the equator, and as far on both sides of it as the sun moves, there lay vast deserts that were parched with the perpetual heat of the sun; the soil was withered, all things looked dis- mally, and all places were either quite uninhabited, or abounded with wild beasts and serpents, and some few men, that were neither less wild nor less cruel than the beasts them- selves.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

2,"[' But, as they went farther, a new scene opened, all things grew milder, the air less burning, the soil more verdant, and even the beasts were less wild: and, at last, there were nations, towns, and cities, that had not only mutual commerce among themselves and with their neighbours, but traded, both by sea and land, to very remote countries.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

3,"[' - 13 12 bottomed, their sails were made of reeds and wicker, woven close together, only some were of leather; but, afterwards, they found ships made with round keels and canvas sails, and in all respects like our ships, and the seamen understood both as- tronomy and navigation.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

4,"[' They sailed before with great caution, and only in summer time; but now they count all seasons alike, trusting wholly to the loadstone, in which they are, perhaps, more secure than safe; so that there is reason to fear that this discovery, which was thought would prove so much to their advantage, may, by their imprudence, become an occasion of much mischief to them.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

5,"[' But it were too long to dwell on all that he told us he had observed in every place, it would be too great a digression from our present purpose: whatever is necessary to be told concerning those wise and prudent institutions which he observed among civilised na- tions, may perhaps be related by us on a more proper occa- sion.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

6,"[' We asked him many questions concerning all these things, to which he answered very willingly; we made no in- quiries after monsters, than which nothing is more common; for everywhere one may hear of ravenous dogs and wolves, and cruel men- eaters, but it is not so easy to find states that are well and wisely governed.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

7,"[' As he told us of many things that were amiss in those new- discovered countries, so he reckoned up not a few things, from which patterns might be taken for correcting the errors of these nations among whom we live; of which an account may be given, as I have already promised, at some other time; for, at present, I intend only to relate those particulars that he told us, of the manners and laws of the Utopians: but I will begin with the occasion that led us to speak of that common- wealth.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

8,"[' After Raphael had discoursed with great judgment on the many errors that were both among us and these na- tions, had treated of the wise institutions both here and there, and had spoken as distinctly of the customs and government of every nation through which he had past, as if he had spent his whole life in it, Peter, being struck with admiration, said, -cI wonder, Raphael, how it comes that you enter into no king-9s service, for I am sure there are none to whom you would not be very acceptable; for your learning and knowledge, both of men and things, is such, that you would not only entertain them very pleasantly, but be of great use to them, by the examples you could set before them, and the advices you could give them; and by this means you would both serve your own interest, and be of great use to all your friends.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

9,"['-cAs for my friends,-answered he, -cI need not be much concerned, having already done for them all that was incumbent on me; for when I was not only in good health, but fresh and young, I distrib- uted that among my kindred and friends which other people do not part with till they are old and sick: when they then unwillingly give that which they can enjoy no longer them- Sir Thomas More.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16
10,[' - 15 14 selves.'],More Thomas,Utopia,16
11,"[' I think my friends ought to rest contented with this, and not to expect that for their sakes I should enslave myself to any king whatsoever.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16
12,['-cSoft and fair!'],More Thomas,Utopia,16
13,"['-said Peter; -cI do not mean that you should be a slave to any king, but only that you should assist them and be useful to them.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16
14,"['-cThe change of the word,-said he, -cdoes not alter the matter.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

15,"['-cBut term it as you will,-replied Peter, -cI do not see any other way in which you can be so useful, both in private to your friends and to the public, and by which you can make your own condition happier.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16
16,['-cHappier?'],More Thomas,Utopia,16
17,"['-answered Raphael, -cis that to be compassed in a way so abhorrent to my genius?']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

18,"[' Now I live as I will, to which I believe, few courtiers can pretend; and there are so many that court the favour of great men, that there will be no great loss if they are not troubled either with me or with others of my temper.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

19,"['-Upon this, said I, -cI per- ceive, Raphael, that you neither desire wealth nor greatness; and, indeed, I value and admire such a man much more than I do any of the great men in the world.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

20,"[' Yet I think you would do what would well become so generous and philo- sophical a soul as yours is, if you would apply your time and thoughts to public affairs, even though you may happen to find it a little uneasy to yourself; and this you can never do with so much advantage as by being taken into the council of some great prince and putting him on noble and worthy ac- tions, which I know you would do if you were in such a post; for the springs both of good and evil flow from the prince over a whole nation, as from a lasting fountain.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

21,"[' So much learning as you have, even without practice in affairs, or so great a practice as you have had, without any other learning, would render you a very fit counsellor to any king whatso- ever.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16
22,"['-cYou are doubly mistaken,-said he, -cMr.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

23,"[' More, both in your opinion of me and in the judgment you make of things: for as I have not that capacity that you fancy I have, so if I had it, the public would not be one jot the better when I had sacrificed my quiet to it.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

24,"[' For most princes apply themselves more to affairs of war than to the useful arts of peace; and in these I neither have any knowledge, nor do I much desire it; they are generally more set on acquiring new kingdoms, right or wrong, than on governing well those they possess: and, among the ministers of princes, there are none that are not so wise as to need no assistance, or at least, that do not think themselves so wise that they imagine they need none; and if they court any, it is only those for whom the prince has much personal favour, whom by their fawning and flatteries they endeavour to fix to their own interests; and, indeed, nature has so made us, that we all love to be flattered and to please ourselves with our own notions: the old crow loves his young, and the ape her cubs.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

25,"[' Now if in such a court, made up of persons who envy all others and only admire themselves, a person should but propose anything that he had either read in history or observed in his travels, the rest would think that the reputation of their wisdom would sink, and that their Sir Thomas More.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

26,"[' - 17 16 interests would be much depressed if they could not run it down: and, if all other things failed, then they would fly to this, that such or such things pleased our ancestors, and it were well for us if we could but match them.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16
27,"[' -cI was then much obliged to that reverend prelate, John Morton, Archbishop of Canterbury, Cardinal, and Chancel- lor of England; a man,-said he, -cPeter (for Mr.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

28,"[' More knows well what he was), that was not less venerable for his wisdom and virtues than for the high character he bore: he was of a middle stature, not broken with age; his looks begot reverence rather than fear; his conversation was easy, but serious and grave; he sometimes took pleasure to try the force of those that came as suitors to him upon business by speaking sharply, though decently, to them, and by that he discovered their spirit and presence of mind; with which he was much de- lighted when it did not grow up to impudence, as bearing a great resemblance to his own temper, and he looked on such persons as the fittest men for affairs.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

29,"[' When I was in England the King depended much on his counsels, and the Govern- ment seemed to be chiefly supported by him; for from his youth he had been all along practised in affairs; and, having passed through many traverses of fortune, he had, with great cost, acquired a vast stock of wisdom, which is not soon lost when it is purchased so dear.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

30,"[' One day, when I was dining with him, there happened to be at table one of the English lawyers, who took occasion to run out in a high commenda- tion of the severe execution of justice upon thieves, -8who,-9 as he said, -8were then hanged so fast that there were sometimes twenty on one gibbet!']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

31,"['-9 and, upon that, he said, -8he could not wonder enough how it came to pass that, since so few es- caped, there were yet so many thieves left, who were still rob- bing in all places.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

32,"['-9 Upon this, I (who took the boldness to speak freely before the Cardinal) said, -8There was no reason to wonder at the matter, since this way of punishing thieves was neither just in itself nor good for the public; for, as the severity was too great, so the remedy was not effectual; simple Sir Thomas More.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

33,"[' - 19 18 theft not being so great a crime that it ought to cost a man his life; no punishment, how severe soever, being able to restrain those from robbing who can find out no other way of liveli- hood.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

34,"[' There are dreadful punishments enacted against thieves, but it were much better to make such good provisions by which every man might be put in a method how to live, and so be preserved from the fatal necessity of stealing and of dying for it.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

35,"['-9 -8There has been care enough taken for that,-9 said he; -8there are many handicrafts, and there is husbandry, by which they may make a shift to live, unless they have a greater mind to follow ill courses.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

36,"['-9 -8That will not serve your turn,-9 said I, -8for many lose their limbs in civil or foreign wars, as lately in the Cornish rebellion, and some time ago in your wars with France, who, being thus mutilated in the service of their king and country, can no more follow their old trades, and are too old to learn new ones; but since wars are only accidental things, and have intervals, let us consider those things that fall out every day.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

37,"[' This, indeed, is the only instance of their frugality, for in all other things they are prodigal, even to the beggaring of themselves; but, besides this, they carry about with them a great number of idle fellows, who never learned any art by which they may gain their living; and these, as soon as either their lord dies, or they themselves fall sick, are turned out of doors; for your lords are readier to feed idle people than to take care of the sick; and often the heir is not able to keep together so great a family as his predecessor did.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

38,"[' For when, by wandering about, they have worn out both their health and their clothes, and are tattered, and look ghastly, men of quality will not entertain them, and poor men dare not do it, knowing that one who has been bred up in idleness and pleasure, and who was used to walk about with his sword and buckler, despising all the neighbourhood with an insolent scorn as far below him, is not fit for the spade and mattock; nor will he serve a poor man for so small a hire and in so low a diet as he can afford to give him.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

39,"['-9 To this he answered, -8This sort of men ought to be particularly cher- ished, for in them consists the force of the armies for which we have occasion; since their birth inspires them with a no- bler sense of honour than is to be found among tradesmen or ploughmen.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

40,"['-9 -8You may as well say,-9 replied I, -8that you must cherish thieves on the account of wars, for you will never want the one as long as you have the other; and as robbers prove sometimes gallant soldiers, so soldiers often prove brave rob- bers, so near an alliance there is between those two sorts of Sir Thomas More.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16
41,[' - 21 20 life.'],More Thomas,Utopia,16

42,"[' In France there is yet a more pestiferous sort of people, for the whole country is full of soldiers, still kept up in time of peace (if such a state of a nation can be called a peace); and these are kept in pay upon the same account that you plead for those idle retainers about noblemen: this being a maxim of those pretended states- men, that it is necessary for the public safety to have a good body of veteran soldiers ever in readiness.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

43,"[' They think raw men are not to be depended on, and they sometimes seek occasions for making war, that they may train up their sol- diers in the art of cutting throats, or, as Sallust observed, -cfor keeping their hands in use, that they may not grow dull by too long an intermission.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16
44,['-But France has learned to its cost how dangerous it is to feed such beasts.'],More Thomas,Utopia,16

45,"[' The fate of the Ro- mans, Carthaginians, and Syrians, and many other nations and cities, which were both overturned and quite ruined by those standing armies, should make others wiser; and the folly of this maxim of the French appears plainly even from this, that their trained soldiers often find your raw men prove too hard for them, of which I will not say much, lest you may think I flatter the English.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

46,"[' Every day-9s experience shows that the mechanics in the towns or the clowns in the country are not afraid of fighting with those idle gentlemen, if they are not disabled by some misfortune in their body or dispirited by extreme want; so that you need not fear that those well- shaped and strong men (for it is only such that noblemen love to keep about them till they spoil them), who now grow feeble with ease and are softened with their effeminate man- ner of life, would be less fit for action if they were well bred and well employed.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16
47,"[' But I do not think that this necessity of stealing arises only from hence; there is another cause of it, more peculiar to England.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16
48,['-9 -8What is that?'],More Thomas,Utopia,16

49,"['-9 said the Cardinal: -8The increase of pasture,-9 said I, -8by which your sheep, which are naturally mild, and easily kept in order, may be said now to devour men and unpeople, not only villages, but towns; for wherever it is found that the sheep of any soil yield a softer and richer wool than ordinary, there the nobility and gentry, and even those holy men, the dobots!']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

50,"[' not contented with the old rents which their farms yielded, nor thinking it enough that they, living at their ease, do no good to the public, resolve to do it hurt instead of good.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

51,"[' As if forests and parks had swallowed up too little of the land, those worthy countrymen turn the best inhabited places into solitudes; for when an insatiable wretch, who is a plague to his country, resolves to enclose many thousand acres of ground, Sir Thomas More.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

52,"[' - 23 22 the owners, as well as tenants, are turned out of their posses- sions by trick or by main force, or, being wearied out by ill usage, they are forced to sell them; by which means those miserable people, both men and women, married and unmar- ried, old and young, with their poor but numerous families (since country business requires many hands), are all forced to change their seats, not knowing whither to go; and they must sell, almost for nothing, their household stuff, which could not bring them much money, even though they might stay for a buyer.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16

53,"[' and if they do this they are put in prison as idle vagabonds, while they would willingly work but can find none that will hire them; for there is no more occasion for country labour, to which they have been bred, when there is no arable ground left.']",More Thomas,Utopia,16
