70,"[' I was shocked by her carelessness, but secretly rather glad at the thought of gazing again at Miss Butler, all alone.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

71,"[' For my trip to the theatre the night before I had worn a rather ordinary dress; now, however - it had been a slow day in the Parlour, and Father let us shut the shop at six - I put on my Sunday frock, the frock I usually wore to go out walking in with Freddy.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
72,[' Davy whistled when I came down all dressed up; and there were one or two boys who tried to catch my eye all through the ride to Canterbury.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

73,"[' When I reached the Palace I nodded to the ticket-girl, as usual; but then I left my favourite gallery seat for someone else to sweat in, and made my way to the side of the stage, to a chair of gilt and scarlet plush.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
74,"["" This time, when she called 'Hallo!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
75,"[""' the crowd replied with a great, genial roar: word must have spread, I think, of her success.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
76,"[' The boxes at the Palace were very close to the stage: all the time she sang, she was less than twenty feet away from me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

77,"[' I could make out all the lovely details of her costume - the watch-chain, looped across the buttons of her waistcoat, the silver links that fastened her cuffs - that I had missed from my old place up in the gallery.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
78,"[' I saw that her teeth were creamy-white; and that her eyes were brown as chocolate, like her hair.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

79,"[' Because I knew what to expect from her set - and because I spent so much time watching her, rather than listening to her songs - it seemed over in a moment.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

80,"[' This time I saw who caught it: a girl in the third row, a girl in a straw hat with feathers on it, and a dress of yellow satin that was cut at the shoulders and showing her arms.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
81,[' A lovely girl I had never seen before but felt ready at that moment to despise!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
82,[' I looked back to Kitty Butler.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
83,"[' I spelled the words in my head in scarlet letters, as the husband of the mentalist had advised, and sent them burning into her forehead like a brand.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

84,"[' Her eyes flicked once my way, as if to note only that the box, empty last night, was occupied now; and then she ducked beneath the dropping crimson of the curtain and was gone.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
85,"["" 'Well,' said Alice a little later, as I stepped into our parlour - our real parlour, not the oyster-house downstairs - 'and how was Kitty Butler tonight?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
86,"[""' 'Just the same as last night, I should think,' said Father.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
87,"["" 'Not at all,' I said, pulling off my gloves.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
88,"["" If she carries on like that, just think how good she'll be by Saturday!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
89,"[""' Alice gazed at me, her lip twitching.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
90,"["" 'I can,' I said with a show of carelessness, 'but I'm not sure that I shall.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
91,"[""' I turned to my mother, who sat sewing by the empty grate.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
92,[' She had raised her head and now regarded me with a little puzzled frown.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
93,"["" 'Well, we are told it is Kitty Butler,' he said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
94,"["" 'If you ask me' - and here he winked and rubbed his nose - 'I think there's a young chap in the orchestra pit what she's got her eye on .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
95,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
96,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
97,"['"" Fred was the last person I wanted at my side, the next time I saw Kitty Butler.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
98,"["" I said, 'Oh he won't want to see an act like that!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
99,"[' No, I shall go on my own.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

100,"[""' I said it rather firmly, as if going to the Palace every night was some chore I had been set to do and I had generously decided to do it with the minimum of bother and complaint.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
101,"["" 'Let's hope poor Frederick don't catch on to it, then .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
102,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
103,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
104,"['"" At that, everybody looked my way, and I blushed - and so seemed, I suppose, to prove my father\'s words.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
105,"[' I let her - I let them all think just what they liked - and said nothing; and soon, as before, the talk turned to other matters.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
106,"["" Then Father said, 'You are a funny little thing, Nancy.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
107,[' All the way to Canterbury in the sweltering heat - and not even to wait for a glimpse of Gully Sutherland when you get there!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
108,"[""' And at that, everybody laughed, and the second's awkwardness passed, and the conversation turned to other things.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

109,"[' There were more cries of disbelief, however, and more smiles, when I came home from my third trip to the Palace and announced, shyly, my intention of returning there a fourth time, and a fifth.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
110,"["" 'Is there a feller you've got your eye on, at the Palace?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
111,"[""' she asked me later, when the rest of the house lay hushed and sleeping.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
112,"["" 'Of course not,' I said quietly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
113,"["" 'It's just Miss Butler, then, that you go to see?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
114,"[""' 'Yes.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
115,"[""' 'What's all this?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
116,"[""' he said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
117,"["" I saw in the gleam of starlight that Alice's eyes were open.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
118,"["" 'Nancy's mashed out on that Kitty Butler, at the Palace,' said Davy.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
119,"["" 'Imagine that, Uncle Joe - being mashed on a masher!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
120,"[""' I said, 'You shut up.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
121,"[""' Mother looked sharp.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
122,"["" 'Kitty Butler?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
123,"[""' he said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
124,"["" 'Pooh, Nancy, the real thing not good enough for you any more?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
125,"[""' 'You're rather keen on her, ain't you?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
126,"[""' she said then.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
127,"["" 21 22 I looked away, and didn't answer her at once.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
128,"["" 'When I see her,' I said, 'it's like -I don't know what it's like.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
129,"["" It's like I never saw anything at all before.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
130,[' Then she walks on the stage and - she is so pretty; and her suit is so nice; and her voice is so sweet.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
131,"["" 'I never saw a girl like her before.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
132,[' I never knew that there were girls like her .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

133,"["" I opened my eyes and looked at Alice - and knew at once that I shouldn't have spoken; that I should have been as dumb and as cunning with her as with the rest of them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

134,"[' I felt as if my admiration for Kitty Butler had lit a beacon inside me, and opening my unguarded mouth had sent a shaft of light into the darkened room, illuminating all.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
135,"["" Alice's eyes held my own for a moment longer, then her lashes fluttered and fell.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

136,"["" They called as often, now, for tea and lemonade, as for plaice and mackerel, and for hours at a time I would leave Mother and Alice to work the shop, and run down to the beach to ladle out cockles and crab-meat and whelks, and bread-and-butter, at Father's stall.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

137,"[' For I made my nightly trips all through that week, and sat - as Tony put it - with the Plushes, and gazed at Kitty Butler as she sang; and I never once grew tired of her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

138,"[' It was only, always, marvellous to step again into my little scarlet box; to gaze at the bank of faces, and the golden arch above the stage, and the velvet drapes and tassels, and the stretch of dusty floorboard with its row of lights - like open cockle shells, I always thought them - before which I would soon see Kitty stride and swagger and wave her hat .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

139,"[' There were nearly twelve of us in all - more by the time we reached the theatre and took our seats, for we met friends and neighbours on the train and at the ticket-booth, and they attached themselves to our gay party, like barnacles.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
140,"["" My seat was between Fred and Alice with Davy and his girl, Rhoda, on Alice's left, and Mother and Father behind.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

141,"[' It was crowded in the hall and still very hot - though cooler than it had been on the previous, sweltering Monday night; but I, who had had a box to myself for a week, with the draught from the stage to chill me, seemed to feel the heat more than anyone.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

142,"["" Fred's hand upon mine, or his lips at my cheek, I found unbearable, like blasts of steam rather than caresses; even the pressure of Alice's sleeve against my arm, and the warmth of Father's face against my neck as he leaned to ask us our opinion of the show, made me flinch, and sweat, and squirm in my seat.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
143,"["" As Kitty Butler's appearance grew more imminent, I became ever more agitated and more wretched.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

144,"[' I could not but long for her to step upon the stage again; but I wished, too, that I might be alone when she did so - alone in my little box with the door shut fast behind me - rather than seated in the midst of a crowd of people to whom she was nothing, and who thought my particular passion for her only queer, or quaint.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

145,"["" They had heard me sing 'Sweethearts and Wives' a thousand times; they had heard me tell the details of her costume, of her hair and voice; I had burned all week to have them see her, and pronounce her marvellous.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

146,"[' I was sure that when she stepped upon the stage it would be like putting a match to the wick, and I would flare up, golden and incandescent but somehow painfully and shamefully bright; and my family and my beau would shrink away from me, appalled.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

147,"["" I saw Davy look my way and give a wink, and heard Father's whisper: 'Here's the very gal, then, at last'; but when I glowed and sparkled it was evidently with a dark and secret flame which no one - except Alice, perhaps -looked for or saw.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
148,"[' As I had feared, however, I felt horribly far from Miss Butler that night.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

149,"[' Her voice was as strong, her face as lovely, as before; but I had been used to hearing the breaths she drew between the phrases, used to catching the glimmer of the limes upon her lip, the shadow of her lashes on her powdered cheek.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
150,"["" Davy called, 'Stone me, if she ain't just as wonderful as Nancy painted her!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

151,"[""' - then he leaned across Alice's lap to wink and add, Though not so wonderful that I'd spend a shilling a week on train tickets to come and see her every night!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
152,"[""' I didn't answer him.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

153,"[' Kitty Butler had come back for her encore, and had already drawn the rose from her lapel; but it was no comfort to me at all to know my family liked her - indeed, it made me more wretched still.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
154,"[' His hair was plastered to his forehead, his lip was dark where he was letting whiskers grow; his cheek was red and had a pimple on it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
155,"[' Behind me I heard Mother ask, How did the lady in the evening dress read all those numbers with a blindfold on?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
156,[' Kitty Butler had looked for me - had raised her head and looked for me; and I was lost and sitting with strangers.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
157,"[' I spent the next day, Sunday, at the cockle-stall; and when Freddy called that night to ask me out walking, I said I was too tired.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
158,"[' Father came back to the Parlour full-time, and I spent the day in the kitchen, gutting and filleting.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

159,"[' We worked till almost seven: I had just enough time between the closing of the shop and the leaving of the Canterbury train to change my dress, to pull on a pair of elastic-sided boots and to sit down with Father and Mother, Alice, Davy and Rhoda for a hasty supper.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

160,"["" They thought it more than strange, I knew, that I should be returning to the Palace yet again; Rhoda, in particular, seemed greatly tickled by the story of my 'mash'.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
161,"["" But at Rhoda's words I saw Mother look me over and grow thoughtful.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
162,"["" 27 28 Mother said, 'Nancy, do you really think -?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
163,"[""' But as she spoke the clock on the mantel gave a ting!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
164,"["" I said, 'Good-bye!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

165,"[' When I reached the Palace the show had begun: I took my seat to find the acrobats already on the stage forming their loop, their spangles gleaming, their white suits dusty at the knees.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

166,"["" There was clapping; Tricky rose to say -what he said every night, so that half the audience smiled and said it with him - that You couldn't get many of those to the pound!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

167,"["" Then - as if it were part of the overture to her routine and she could not work without it -I gripped my seat and held my breath, while he raised his gavel to beat out Kitty Butler's name.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
168,"[' I had thought that, when she walked on to the stage, she had glanced my way - as much as to say, the box is filled again.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
169,"[' Now, as she wheeled before the footlights, I thought I saw her look at me again.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

170,"[' The idea was a fantastic one - and yet every time her gaze swept the crowded hall it seemed to brush my own, and dally with it a little longer than it should.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
171,"[' I saw her leave the stage -again, her gaze met mine - and then return for her encore.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
172,"[' Instead, she took a step to her left, towards the box in which I sat.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

173,"[' In a moment she had reached the corner of the stage, and stood facing me; she was so close I could see the glint of her collar-stud, the beat of the pulse in her throat, the pink at the corner of her eye.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

174,"[' She stood there for what seemed to be a small eternity; then her arm came up, the flower flashed for a second in the beam of the lime - and my own hand, trembling, rose to catch it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
175,"[' She held my flustered gaze with her own more certain one, and made me a little bow.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
176,"["" I sat for a moment as if stunned, my eyes upon the flower in my hand, which had been so near, so recently, to Kitty Butler's cheek.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

177,"[' I wanted to raise it to my own face - and was about to, I think, when the clatter of the hall pierced my brain at last, and made me look about me and see the inquisitive, indulgent looks that were turned my way, and the nods and the chuckles and the winks that met my up- turned gaze.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
178,"[' With my back turned to the bank of prying eyes I slipped the rose into the belt of my dress, and pulled on my gloves.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

179,"[' My heart, which had begun to pound when Miss Butler had stepped towards me across the stage, was still 29 30 beating painfully hard; but as I left my box and made my way towards the crowded foyer and the street beyond, it began to feel light, and glad, and I began to want to smile.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
180,"[' I had to place a hand before my lips so as not to appear an idiot, smiling to myself as if at nothing.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
181,"[' Just as I was about to step into the street, I heard my name called.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
182,"[' I turned, and saw Tony, crossing the lobby with his arm raised to catch my eye.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
183,"[' I took the hand away, and grinned like a monkey.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
184,"["" 'Hey, hey,' he said breathlessly when he reached my side, 'someone's merry, and I know why!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
185,"[' How come girls never look so gay as that, when / give them roses?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
186,"[""' I blushed again, and returned my fingers to my lips, but said nothing.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
187,"["" 'Someone to see you.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
188,"[""' I raised my eyebrows; I thought perhaps Alice or Freddy were here, come to meet me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
189,"["" 'Miss Butler,' he said, 'would like a word.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
190,"[""' My own grin faded at once.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
191,"["" 'A word?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
192,"[""' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
193,"[' She asked Ike, the fly-man, who was the girl that sat in the box every night, on her own, and Ike said you was a pal of mine, and to ask me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
194,"[' Tony prised my fingers from his sleeve, and held my hand.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
195,"["" 'Just that you like her,' he said simply.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

196,"[' So I said nothing, but let him lead me away from the great glass doors with the blue, cool, Canterbury night behind them, past the archway that led to the stalls, and the staircase to the gallery, towards an alcove in the far corner of the foyer, with a curtain across it, and a rope before it, and a sign swinging from the rope, marked Private.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

197,"[' We passed one doorway that led, I knew, to the stage itself: I caught a glimpse of ladders and ropes and trailing gas-pipes; of boys in caps and aprons, wheeling baskets, manoeuvring lights.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

198,"[' I had the sensation then - and I felt it again in the years that followed, every time I made a similar trip back stage - that I had stepped into the workings of a giant clock, stepped through the elegant casing to the dusty, greasy, restless machinery that lay, all hidden from the common eye, behind it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

199,"[' They wore hats and carried overcoats and bags; they were sallow- faced and poor-looking, with a patina of flashness - I thought they might be salesmen carrying sample-cases.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

200,"[' Only when they had moved on, and I heard them sharing a joke with the stage door-keeper, did I realise that they were 31 32 the trio of tumblers taking their leave for the night, and that their bags contained their spangles.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

201,"[' I had a sudden fear that Kitty Butler might after all be just like them: plain, unremarkable, almost I unrecognisable as the handsome girl I had seen swaggering in the glow of the footlights.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

202,"[' I very nearly called to Tony to take me back; but he had descended the staircase, and when I caught up with him in the passageway below he was at a door, and had already turned its handle.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

203,"[' The door was one of a row of others, indistinguishable from its neighbours but for a brass figure 7, very old and scratched, that was screwed at eye level upon its centre panel, and a hand-written card that had been tacked below.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
204,"[' Miss Kitty Butler, it said.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

205,"["" I found her seated at a little table before a looking-glass; she had half-turned - to reply, I suppose, to Tony's knock - but at my approach she rose, and reached to shake my hand.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
206,"["" 'Aha,' she said, when Tony had left us - there was a hint, still, of her footlight manner in her voice - 'my mystery admirer!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
207,[' I was sure it must be Gully you came to see; then someone said you never stay beyond the interval.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
208,[' I never had a fan before!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

209,"[""' As she spoke she leaned quite comfortably against the table - it was cluttered, I now saw, with jars of cream and sticks of grease-paint, with playing cards and half-smoked cigarettes and filthy tea-cups - and crossed her legs at the ankle, and folded her arms.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
210,"[' She was dressed in the trousers and the shoes that she had worn for her act, but she had removed the jacket, the waistcoat, and, of course, the hat.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
211,"["" 'I do like your act,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
212,"["" 'I should think you do, you come to it so often!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
213,"[""' I smiled.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
214,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
215,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
216,"[""' That made her laugh: her tongue looked very pink, her teeth extraordinarily white, against her painted lips.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
217,"["" 'What I mean is,' I said, 'Tony lets me have the box.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
218,"[' For I do so like your act, Miss Butler, so very, very much.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
219,"[""' Now she did not laugh, but she tilted her head a little.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
220,"["" 'I like your costume,' I said at last.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
221,"["" 'I like your songs, and the way you sing them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
222,[' I like the way you talk to Tricky.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

223,"["" There was a second's almost awkward silence - then, suddenly, as if from somewhere very near at hand, there came the sound of music - the blast of a horn and the pulse of a drum - and a cheer, like the roaring of the wind in some vast sea-shell.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
224,"[' I gave a jump, and looked about me; and she laughed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
225,"[' \'The second half,"" she said.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
226,"[' After a moment the cheering stopped; the music, however, went on pulsing and thumping like a great heart-beat.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
227,"[' I shook my head, and shook it again when 33 34 she took up a packet of cigarettes from amongst the dirty cups and playing cards, and held it to me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

228,"[' With the fag at the side of her lip, her eyes screwed up against the flame, she looked like a boy again; when she took the cigarette away, however, the cork was smudged with crimson.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
229,"["" It's not very polite, I know, but I must get ready rather quick; my room is needed later by another girl.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
230,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
231,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
232,"['"" I did as she asked, and sat and watched her smear her cheeks with cream, then take a cloth to them.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
233,"[' She worked quickly and carefully, but distractedly; and as she rubbed at her face she held my gaze in the glass.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
234,"["" She looked at my new hat and said, 'What a pretty bonnet!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
235,"[""' Then she asked how I knew Tony - was he my beau?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
236,"["" 'I work in an oyster-house,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
237,"["" 'As I was going down Bishopgate Street, An oyster-girl I happened to meet -' A swipe at the crimson of her lip, the black of her lashes.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
238,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
239,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

240,"[""' She sang on; then opened one eye very wide, and leaned close to the glass to remove a stubborn crumb of spit-black - her mouth stretching wide, out of a kind of sympathy with her eyelids, and her breath misting the mirror.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

241,"[' She wiped her breath from the glass, then, and gave me a wink, and asked me more about myself; and because it was somehow easier to talk to her reflection than to her face, I began at last to chat with her quite freely.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
242,"[' At first she answered as I thought an actress should - comfortably, rather teasingly, laughing when I blushed or said a foolish thing.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

243,"["" At last - she gave a yawn, and rubbed her knuckles in her eyes - at last her voice was just a girl's: melodious and strong and clear, but just a Kentish girl's voice, like my own.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
244,"[' Soon her face was wiped quite bare, and her cigarette smoked to the filter; and then she rose and put her fingers to her hair.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
245,"["" 'I had better change,' she said, almost shyly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
246,"[' I took 35 36 the hint, and said that I should go, and she walked the couple of steps with me to the door.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
247,"[' I said, Oh yes, I should like that very much, and she nodded with something like satisfaction.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
248,"[' Then she made me another little bow, and we said good-night; and she closed the door and was gone.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
249,"["" 'Thank you, Miss Astley,' she said - she already had my name from Tony - 'for coming to see me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

250,"[""' She held out her hand to me, and I lifted my own in response - then remembered my glove - my glove with the lavender bows upon it, to match my pretty hat - and quickly drew it off and offered her my naked fingers.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
251,"[' I stood quite still, facing the little 7, the hand-written card, Miss Kitty Butler.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

252,"[' I flushed with pleasure - until I saw her nostrils quiver, and knew, suddenly, what she smelled: those rank sea-scents, of liquor and oyster-flesh, crab-meat and whelks, which had flavoured my fingers and those of my family for so many years we had all ceased, entirely, to notice them.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
253,"["" Now I had thrust them beneath Kitty Butler's nose!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
254,"[' I made, at once, to pull my hand away; but she held it fast in her own, still pressed to her lips, and laughed at me over the knuckles.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
255,[' There was a look in her eye I could not quite interpret.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
256,"["" 'Not at all like a herring,' she said gently.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
257,"["" 'But perhaps, maybe, like a mermaid .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
258,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
259,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
260,"['"" And she kissed my fingers properly, and this time I let her; and at last my blush faded, and I smiled.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

261,"[' Watching Miss Butler perform upon the stage after having spoken to her, and been smiled at by her, and had her lips upon my hand, was a strange experience, at once more and less thrilling than it had been before.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

262,"[' Her lovely voice, her 37 38 elegance, her swagger: I felt I had been given a kind of secret share in them, and pinked complacently every time the crowd roared their welcome or called her back on to the stage for an encore.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

263,"[' But I know she saw me in my box, for I felt her eyes upon me, sometimes, as she sang; and always, when she left the stage, there was that sweep of her hat for the hall, and a nod, or a wink, or the ghost of a smile, just for me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

264,"[' So though I went as often as I was able to my box at the Palace, and watched and applauded her as she sang, and received those secret looks and tokens, it was a full week before I made my way again back stage, and presented myself, all pale, sweating and uncertain, at her dressing- room door.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

265,"[' But when I did so, she received me with such kindness, and chided me so sincerely for having left her unvisited so long; and we fell again to chatting so easily about her life in the theatre, and mine as an oyster-girl in Whitstable, that all my old qualms quite left me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
266,"[' I went nowhere else that month but to the Palace; saw no one else - not Freddy, not my cousins, not even Alice, hardly - but her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

267,"["" Mother had begun to frown about it; but when I went home and said that I had gone back stage at Miss Butler's invitation, and been treated by her like a friend, she was impressed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

268,"["" Now every working day ended, for me, with a lightning change, and a hasty supper, and a run to the station for the Canterbury train; and every trip to Canterbury ended in Kitty Butler's dressing-room.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

269,"[' I spent more time in her company than I did watching her perform upon the stage, and saw her more often without her make- up, and her suit, and her footlight manner, than with them.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
270,"[' \'You must call me ""Kitty"",\' she said early on, \'and I shall call you - what?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

271,"[' I nodded and smiled like an idiot: for the thrill of being addressed by her I would gladly have lost all of my old name, and taken a new one, or gone nameless entirely.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
272,[' !'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
273,"[""' that; and, increasingly, it was 'Be a love, Nan, and fetch me my stockings .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
274,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
275,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

276,"['"" She was still too shy to change her clothes before me, but one night when I arrived I found that she had had a little folding screen set up, and ever afterwards she used to step behind it while we talked, and hand me articles of her suit as she undressed, and have me 39 40 pass her the pieces of her ladies\' costume from the hook that she had hung them on before the show.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

277,"[' Each item came to me warm from her body, and with its own particular scent; each seemed charged with a strange kind of power, and tingled or glowed (or so I imagined) beneath my hand.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

278,"["" Her petticoats and dresses were cold and did not tingle; but I still blushed to handle them, for I couldn't help but think of all the soft and secret places they would soon enclose, or brush against, or warm and make moist, once she had donned them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

279,"[' Every time she stepped from behind the screen, clad as a girl, small and slim and shapely, a false plait smothering the lovely, ragged edges of her crop, I had the same sensation: a pang of disappointment and regret that turned instantly to pleasure and to aching love; a desire to touch, to embrace and caress, so strong I had to turn aside or fold my arms for fear that they would fly about her and press her close.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

280,"[' At length I grew so handy with her costumes she suggested that I visit her before she went on stage, to help her ready herself for her act, like a proper dresser.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

281,"[' She said it with a kind of studied carelessness, as if half-fearful that I might not wish to; she could not have known, I suppose, how dreary the hours were to me, that I must pass away from her .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

282,"[' Soon I never stepped into the auditorium at all, but headed, every night, back stage, a half-hour before she was due before the footlights, to help her re-don the shirt and waistcoat and trousers that I had taken from her the night before; to hold the powder-box while she dusted out her freckles, to dampen the brushes with which she smoothed out the curl in her hair, to fasten the rose to her lapel.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

283,"[' The first time I did all this I walked with her to the stage afterwards, and stood in the wing while she went through her set, gazing in wonder at the limes-men who strode, nimble as acrobats, across the battens in the fly-gallery; seeing nothing of the hall, nothing of the stage except a stretch of dusty board with a boy at the other end of it, his arm upon the handle that turned the rope that brought the curtain down.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

284,"[' After that, I passed the twenty minutes or so that she was gone each night alone, in her room, listening to the beat of her songs through the ceiling and walls, happier to hear the cheers of the audience from a distance.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

285,"[' I would make tea for her - she liked it brewed in the pan with condensed milk, dark as a walnut and thick as syrup; I knew by the changing tempos of her set just when to set the kettle on the hearth, so the cup would be ready for her return.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

286,"[' While the tea simmered I would wipe her little table, and empty her ashtrays, and dust down the glass; I would tidy the cracked and faded old cigar-box in which she kept her sticks of 41 42 grease-paint.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

287,"[' They were acts of love, these humble little ministrations, and of pleasure - even, perhaps, of a kind of self-pleasure, for it made me feel strange and hot and almost shameful to perform them.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

288,"[' While she was being ravished by the admiration of the crowd, I would pace her dressing-room and gaze at her possessions, or caress them, or almost caress them - holding my fingers an inch away from them, as if they had an aura, as well as a surface, that might be stroked.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

289,"[' I loved everything that she left behind her - her petticoats and her perfumes, and the pearls that she clipped to the lobes of her ears; but also the hairs on her combs, the eyelashes that clung to her sticks of spit-black, even the dent of her fingers and lips on her cigarette-ends.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
290,"[' The world, to me, seemed utterly transformed since Kitty Butler had stepped into it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

291,"["" She had taken her first bows before the footlights at the age of twelve, as 'Kate Straw, the Little Singing Wonder', and had known a bit of success in penny-gaffs and public-houses, and the smaller kinds of halls and theatres.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
292,"["" But it was a miserable sort of life, she said - 'and soon I wasn't even little any more.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

293,"["" Every time a place came up there was a crush of girls queuing for it at the stage door, all just the same as me, or prettier, or perter - or hungrier, and so more willing to kiss the chairman for the promise of a season's work, or a week's, or even a night's.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

294,"[""' Her grandmother had died; she had joined a dancing troupe and toured the seaside towns of Kent and the South Coast, doing end-of-pier shows three times a night.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

295,"[' She frowned when she spoke about these times, and her voice was bitter, or weary; she would place a hand beneath her chin, and rest her head upon it, and close her eyes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
296,[' By the time she returned to her dressing-room I would have everything tidy and still.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
297,"[' Her tea, as I have said, would be ready; sometimes, too, I would have a cigarette lit for her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
298,"["" 'They wouldn't let me leave!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
299,"['\' Or, \'A slow one tonight, Nan; I believe I was half-way through ""Good Cheer, Boys, Good Cheer"" before they realised I was a girl!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
300,"[""' 'Oh, it was hard,' she'd say, 'so hard .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
301,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
302,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

303,"[""' The thought of Kitty weeping brought the tears to my own eyes; and seeing me so affected, she'd give a smile, and a wink, and a stretch, and say in her best swell accent: 'But those days are all behind me now, don't you know, and I am on the path to fame and fortune.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
304,"[' 43 44 became a masher the whole world loves me; and Tricky Reeves loves me most of all, and pays me like a prince, to prove it!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

305,"[""' And then we would smile together, because we both knew that if she really were a masher Tricky's wages would barely keep her in champagne; but my smile would be a little troubled for I knew, too, that her contract was due to expire at the end of August, and then she would have to move to another theatre - to Margate, perhaps, she said, or Broadstairs, if they would have her.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

306,"[' It was reassuring for them that it was a real friendship, and not just a schoolgirl mash, that had me travelling so often to the Palace, and spending all my savings on the train fare; and yet, I thought I heard them ask themselves, what manner of friendship could there be between a handsome, clever music-hall artiste, and the girl in the crowd that admired her?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

307,"[' When I said that Kitty had no young man (for I had found this out, early on, amongst the pieces of her history) Davy said that I should bring her home, and introduce her to my handsome brother - though he only said it when Rhoda was near, to tease her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
308,"["" When I spoke of brewing her pans of tea and tidying her table, Mother narrowed her eyes: 'She's doing all right out of you by the sound of it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
309,"["" It's a little more help with the tea and the tables we could do with, from you, home here .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
310,"[' The truth was, I think, that she was squeamish of mentioning Kitty now - and by that alone I knew that it was she, more than any of them, who was uneasy.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
311,"[' I had said nothing of my new, strange, hot desire to anyone.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

312,"[' But she saw me, of course, as I lay in my bed; and, as anyone will tell you who has been secretly in love, it is in bed that you do your dreaming - in bed, in the darkness, where you cannot see your own cheeks pink, that you ease back the mantle of restraint that keeps your passion dimmed throughout the day, and let it glow a little.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

313,"[' How Kitty would have blushed, to know the part she played in my fierce dreamings - to know how shamelessly I took my memories of her, and turned them to my own improper advantage!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

314,"[' Each night at the Palace she kissed me farewell; in my dreams her lips stayed at my cheek - were hot, were tender -moved to my brow, my ear, my throat, my mouth .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
315,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

316,"["" I was used to standing close to her, to fasten her collar- studs or brush her lapels; now, in my reveries, I did what I longed to do then - I leaned to place my lips upon the edges of her hair; I slid my hands beneath her coat, to where her breasts pressed warm against her stiff gent's shirt and rose to meet my strokings .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
317,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
318,"["" All this with Alice's breath upon my cheek, or her hot limbs pressed against mine; or with her eyes shining cold and dull, with starlight and suspicion.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

319,"[' But she said nothing; she asked me nothing; and to the rest of the family, at least, my continuing friendship with Kitty 45 46 became in time a source not of wonder, but of pride.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
320,"["" 'Our youngest girl is very thick with Kitty Butler, the star of the show .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
321,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
322,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

323,"['"" By the end of August, when the oyster season had started again and we were back in the shop full-time, they began to press me to bring Kitty home with me, that they might meet her for themselves.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
324,"["" 'You are always saying as how she is your pal,' said Father one morning at breakfast.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
325,"[' You bring her over here, before she goes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

326,"[""' The idea of asking Kitty to sup with my family seemed a horrible one; and because my father spoke so carelessly about the fact that she would soon have left for a new hall, I made him a stinging reply.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
327,[' A little later Mother took me aside.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
328,"["" Was my father's house not good enough for Miss Butler, she said, that I couldn't invite her here?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
329,"[' Her words made me gloomy; I was quiet and sad with Kitty that night, and when after the show she asked me why, I bit my lip.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
330,"["" 'My parents want me to ask you over,' I said, 'for tea tomorrow.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
331,"["" But I promised them I'd ask you; and now,' I finished miserably, 'I have.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
332,"[""' She took my hand.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
333,"["" 'But Nan,' she said in wonder, 'I should love to come!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
334,"[' You know how dull it is for me in Canterbury, with no one but Mrs Pugh, and Sandy, to talk to!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

335,"[""' Mrs Pugh was the landlady of Kitty's rooming-house; Sandy was the boy who shared her landing: he played in the band at the Palace, but drank, she said, and was sometimes silly and a bore.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

336,"["" 'Oh, how nice it would be,' she continued, 'to sit in a proper parlour again, with a proper family - not just a room with a bed in it, and a dirty rug, and a bit of newspaper on the table for a cloth!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
337,"[' And how nice to see where you live and work; and to catch your train; and to meet the people that love you, and have you with them all day .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
338,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
339,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

340,"[""' It made me fidget and swallow to hear her talk like this, all unself-consciously, of how she liked me; tonight, however, I had no time even to blush: for as she spoke there came a knock at her door - a sharp, cheerful, authoritative knock that made her blink and stiffen, and look up in surprise.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

341,"[' In all the evenings I had spent with her, she had had no visitors but the call-boy - who came to tell her when she was wanted in the wing - and Tony, who sometimes put his head around the door to wish us both good-night.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
342,"["" She had no beau, as I have said; she had no other 'fans' - no friends at all, it seemed, but me; and I had always been rather glad of it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
343,"[' Now I watched her step to the door, and bit my lip.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
344,"[' I only felt piqued, that our time alone together - which I thought little enough!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
345,"[' He had a silk I hat on his head which - seeing her, and then me lurking in the little room behind her - he removed, and held to his bosom.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
346,"["" 'Miss Butler, I believe,' he said; and when she nodded, he gave a bow: 'Walter Bliss, ma'am.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
347,"["" In the second or so it took Kitty to gaze at it and give a little 'Oh!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
348,"[""' of surprise, I studied him.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
349,"[' When Kitty returned his card to him, he asked if he might speak with her a moment, and at once she stood aside to let him pass.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
350,"[' With him in it, the little room seemed very full and hot.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

351,"["" I rose, reluctantly, and put on my gloves and my hat, and said that I should go; and then Kitty introduced me - 'My friend, Miss Astley,' she called me, which made me feel a little gayer - and Mr Bliss shook my hand.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
352,"["" Tell your Mother,' said Kitty as she showed me to the door, 'that I shall come tomorrow, any time she likes.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
353,"[""' 'Come at four,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
354,"["" 'Four it is, then!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
355,"[""' She briefly took my hand again, and kissed my cheek.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
356,"[' Over her shoulder I saw the flashy gentleman fingering his whiskers, but with his eyes turned, politely, away from us.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
357,"[' I can hardly say what a curious mix of feelings mine were, the Sunday afternoon when Kitty came to call on us in Whitstable.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

358,"[' She was more to me than all the world; that she should be visiting me in my own home, and supping with my family, seemed both a delight too lovely to be borne and a great and and walked like a girl, with her plait fastened to the back of her head and a parasol over her arm, I felt a little pang of disappointment.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
359,"[' This swiftly turned, however - as always - to desire, and then to pride, for she looked terribly smart and handsome on that dusty Whitstable platform.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
360,"[' She kissed my cheek when I went up to her, and took my arm, and let me lead her from the station to our house, across the sea-front.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
361,"[' Here, look, on this step, I once fell down and cut my chin, and my sister held her handkerchief to it, the whole way home .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
362,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
363,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
364,"['"" So I talked and pointed, and Kitty nodded, biting her lip.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

365,"["" Kitty shook hands with everyone, and had a word for them all, such as, 'You must be Davy, who works in the smack', and 'You must be Alice, who Nancy talks about so often, and is so proud of.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
366,"["" 'Well, well, Miss Butler,' he said when he took her hand, nodding at her skirts, 'this is rather a change, ain't it, from your usual gear?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

367,"[""' She smiled and said it was; and when he added, with a wink, 'And something of an improvement, too - if you don't mind a gentleman saying so', she laughed and said that, since 49 50 gentlemen were usually of that opinion, she was quite used to it, and did not mind a bit.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

368,"["" All in all she made herself so pleasant, and answered their questions about herself, and the music hall, so sweetly and cleverly, that no one - not even Alice, or spiteful Rhoda - could dislike her; and I - watching her gaze from the windows at Whitstable Bay, or incline her head to catch a story of my father's, or compliment my mother on some ornament or picture (she admired the shawl, above the fireplace!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
369,"[') -I fell in love with her, all over again.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
370,"[' She had come for tea, and presently we all sat down to it - Kitty marvelling, as we did so, at the table.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
371,"[' It was set for a real oyster-supper, with a linen cloth, and a little spirit-lamp with a plate of butter on it, waiting to be melted.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
372,"[' Kitty and I sat close, our elbows almost touching, our shoes side by side beneath the table.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
373,"["" When Mother cried, 'Do move along a bit, Nancy, and give Miss Butler some room!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

374,"[""', Kitty said that she was quite all right, Mrs Astley, really; and I shifted a quarter of an inch to my right, but kept my foot pressed against hers, and felt her leg, all hot, against my own.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
375,"[' Father handed out the oysters, and Mother offered beer or lempnade.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
376,"[' Kitty picked up a shell with one hand and her oyster-knife with the other, and brought them together rather ineffectually.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
377,"[' Father saw, and gave a shout.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
378,"[' Davy, you take that knife and show the lady how - else she might just job the blade into her hand, and give herself a nasty cut.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
379,"[""' 'I can do it,' I said quickly; and I took the oyster from her, and the knife, before my brother could get his fingers on them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
380,"["" 'You do it like this,' I said to her.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
381,"["" 'You must hold the oyster in your palm so that the flat shell is uppermost - like this.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
382,"[""' I held the shell to show her, and she gazed at it rather gravely.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
383,"["" 'This here,' I said, pointing with my knife, 'is called the beard; you must trim that away.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
384,"[""' I gave the blade a flick, and the beard was severed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
385,[' And now you may eat it.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
386,"[""' I slipped the shell carefully into her hand, and felt her fingers warm and soft against my own as she cupped them to receive it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
387,"[' She raised the oyster to her lips and held it for a second before her mouth, her eyes on mine, unblinking.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
388,"["" When I took my eyes from Kitty's I saw a ring of faces turned my way, and blushed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
389,"["" 'No bolting him down whole now, Miss Butler,' he said, 'like the gormays do.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
390,[' You go on and give him a real good chew.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
391,"[""' He said it kindly, and Kitty laughed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
392,"["" 'You will make the poor girl sick,' said Mother.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
393,"["" 'Now,' he said, confidentially, 'tell the truth: have you ever tasted an oyster such as that, before, or have you not?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

394,"[""' Kitty said that she had not, and Davy gave a cheer; and for a while there was no sound at all but the delicate, diminutive sounds of good oyster-supper: the creak of hinges, the slap of discarded beards, the trickle of liquor and butter and beer.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
395,"[' I opened no more shells for Kitty, for she managed them herself.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
396,"["" 'Look at this one!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
397,"[""' she said, when she had handled half-a-dozen or so.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
398,"["" 'You're a bit of an oyster, then, yourself, Kitty,' he said with a smirk.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
399,"[' She looked for a moment rather uncertain, but then she smiled.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
400,"["" 'Why, I suppose I am,' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
401,"["" I've never been likened to a fish before.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
402,"[""' 'Well, don't take it the wrong way, Miss Butler,' said Mother, 'for spoken in this house, it is something of a compliment.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
403,"[""' Tony laughed, and Father said, 'Oh, it was, it was!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
404,"[""' Kitty still smiled.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
405,"[' Then she half-rose to reach a pepper castor; and when she sat again she drew her feet beneath her chair, and I felt my thigh grow cool.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

406,"[' When the oyster-barrel was quite empty, and the lemonade and the Bass had all been drunk, and Kitty declared that she had never had a finer supper in all her life, we moved our chairs away from the table, and the men lit cigarettes, and Alice and Rhoda set out cups, for tea.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
407,"[' There was more talk, and more questions for Kitty to answer.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
408,[' She said she had no time for it.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

409,"[' 53 54 Mother tut-tutted over that, and said it was a shame; Davy said she could help herself to some of our relations, if she liked, for we had more than we knew what to do with.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
410,"["" 'Oh yes?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
411,"[""' said Kitty.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
412,"["" 'Yes,' said Davy.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

413,"["" 'You must have heard the song: 'There's her uncle, and her brother, and her sister, and her mother, And her auntie, and another, who is cousin to her mother.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
414,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
415,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

416,"['"" No sooner had he finished the verse, indeed, than there was the sound of our street-door opening, and a shout up the stairs; and three of our cousins themselves appeared, followed by Uncle Joe and Aunt Rosina - all got up in their Sunday best, and all just popped in, they said, for a \'peek\' at Miss Butler, if Miss Butler had no objection.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
417,"[' More chairs were brought up, and more cups; a fresh round of introductions was made, and the little room grew stuffy with heat and smoke and laughter.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
418,"["" Kitty blushed, and said she couldn't; and everyone cried, 'Oh please, Miss Butler, do!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
419,"[""' 'What do you think, Nan,' she said to me, 'should I shame myself?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
420,"[""' 'You know you won't,' I said, pleased that she had turned to me at the last, and used my special name before them all.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
421,"[' A little space was cleared for her, and Rlioda ran down to her house, to fetch her sisters to come and watch.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

422,"["" Then she whispered to George and to me, and I fetched her a hat of Father's and a walking-cane, and she sang us a couple of masher songs, and ended with the ballad with which she finished her set at the Palace, about the sweetheart and the rose.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
423,"["" Davy said, 'How about a song from you now, Nance?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
424,"[""' I gave him a look.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
425,[' Kitty looked at me curiously.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
426,"["" 'Nancy's got the prettiest voice, Miss Butler,' said one of the cousins, 'you ever heard.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
427,"[""' 'Yes, go on, Nance, be a sport!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
428,"[""' said another.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
429,"[' Makes your heart turn over, to hear her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
430,"[""' There were murmurs of agreement throughout the room, and I saw Kitty look blinkingly my way.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
431,[' Kitty looked bemused.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
432,"["" She asked then, 'Who is Freddy?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
433,"[""' 'Freddy is Nancy's young feller,' said Davy.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
434,"["" She must've boasted about him to you?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
435,"[""' 'No,' said Kitty, 'she has not.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
436,"[""' She said it lightly, but I glanced up and saw that her eyes were strange, and almost 55 56 sad.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
437,"[' The fact was, I barely thought of him as my beau these days, for since her arrival in Canterbury I had had no evenings spare to spend with him.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
438,"[' I poured a little water out and carried it to her, for her to wash her hands and splash her face.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
439,"[' The water spotted her dress, and dampened the fringe of her hair into dark little points.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
440,"["" She said, 'I am sure your mother would disapprove, but I'm just about busting for a smoke.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
441,"[""' She lit the cigarette, and drew upon it heavily.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
442,"["" 'You first,' she said, and drew again upon her fag.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

443,"["" While they quarrelled and swore, Kitty leaned towards me and said softly, 'Will you take me to your room, Nan, or somewhere quiet, for a bit - just you and me?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
444,"[""' She looked so grave suddenly I feared that she might faint.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

445,"["" I got up, and made a path for her across the crowded room, and told my mother I was taking her upstairs; and Mother - who was gazing trou-bledly at Rhoda's sister, not knowing whether to laugh at her or to scold - gave us a nod, distractedly, and we escaped.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
446,"["" 'I was just going to say, how funny it is to have you here, like this.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
447,"[""' 'And I,' she said, 'was going to say how funny it is to be here!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
448,[' And your bed?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
449,"[""' She looked about her, as if in wonder - as if I might have taken her to a stranger's chamber, and be trying to pass it off as my own - and I nodded.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
450,"[' The window was raised, and Kitty crossed to it at once and placed her arms upon the sill.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

451,"["" I thought, with a little thrill, that I knew what it was; but when she spoke again it wasn't about the contract, but about my family -about how kind they were, and how much they loved me, and how lucky I was to have them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
452,"["" I remembered that she was an orphan, of sorts, and bit back 'Are you poorly?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
453,"[""' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
454,"[' At last, when her cigarette was finished and thrown into the grate, she took a breath and said what I had been waiting for.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
455,"["" 'Nan, I have something to tell you - a piece of good news, and you must promise to be happy for me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

456,"[""' She went talking on, saying how Mr Bliss had friends at the London halls, and had promised her a season at them all; how he had said she was too good for the provincial stage; that she would find fame in the city, where all the big names worked, and all the money was .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
457,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
458,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
459,"[' At length I placed a hand before my eyes, and bowed my head, and she grew silent.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
460,"["" I had been longing to smile about it all afternoon, and now I laughed and said, 'Oh Kitty, I know your news already!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
461,"[""' She seemed to frown then, so I went on quickly, 'You mustn't be cross with Tony, but he told me - just today.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
462,"[""' 'Told you what?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
463,"[""' 'That Tricky wants you to stay on, at the Palace; that you will be here till Christpas at least!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
464,"[""' 'You're not happy for me, after all,' she said quietly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
465,"[' She looked at me rather strangely, then lowered her gaze and gave an awkward little laugh.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
466,"["" 'That's not my news,' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
467,"["" Tricky does want me to stay on - but I've turned him down.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
468,"[""' 'I am,' I said - my voice was thick - 'but I am more unhappy, for myself.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

469,"[""' There was a silence then, broken only by the sound of laughter and scraping chairs from the parlour below, and the shriek of gulls outside the open window.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
470,"["" 'Do you remember the gentleman who called on me last night,' she said,' - Mr Bliss?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
471,"[""' I nodded.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
472,"["" Now she went on: 'Mr Bliss is a manager - not a theatre manager, like Tricky, but a manager for artistes: an agent.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
473,"[' He saw my turn and - oh, Nan!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
474,"[""' - she couldn't help but be excited now - 'he saw my turn and liked it so much, he has offered me a contract, at a music hall in London!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
475,"[""' I heard her take a step.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
476,"["" 'I have something to ask you.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
477,"[""' I looked at her; her face was pale, except for its cloud of freckles, and her eyes seemed large.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
478,"["" 'Do you think that I look handsome today?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
479,"[""' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
480,[' Do you think your parents like me?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
481,"[""' Her words seemed wild.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
482,"["" 'I came,' she said, 'to make them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

483,"["" I thought, they 59 60 might be the meanest and most miserable family in all of Kent; yet I will work so hard at being nice, they'll trust me like a daughter.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
484,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
485,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
486,"[""' 'When you threw this to me,' I said to her, 'my life changed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
487,"[' Do you think I could give that up, now, so easily?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
488,"[""' My heart seemed to stop - and then to pound, like a piston.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
489,"[' She looked away from me, about the room, and ran her tongue over her lips.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
490,"["" 'And all of them, downstairs?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
491,"[""' she said, nodding towards the door.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
492,"["" 'Your mother and father, your brother, Alice, Freddy?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
493,"[""' As she spoke there came a shout, and the sound of voices raised in friendly argument.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
494,[' But how?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
495,"[""' 'As my dresser,' she said, 'if you'd care to.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
496,"[' I have spoken to Mr Bliss: he says there will not be much money for you at first - but enough, if you share my diggings.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
497,"[""' 'Why?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
498,"[""' I said then.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
499,"["" It doesn't give you long.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
500,"[""' 'And you truly thought,' I said slowly, 'that I would say no?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
501,"[""' I said it would be long enough; and she placed the faded rose upon the bed, and seized my hands and squeezed them hard.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
502,"[' Last night, and this morning, I believed - Oh, it was so different in the dressing-room, when it was just the two of us!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
503,"["" We'll have such times together, I promise you!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
504,"[""' As she spoke, she flung my hands aside and gripped me in a fierce embrace, and laughed with pleasure, so that I felt her body shudder in my arms.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
505,[' I drew my hand away from hers and got to my feet.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
506,"[' I walked to the head of the bed, where there was a little cabinet, with a drawer in it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
507,"["" 'Do you know this?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
508,"[""' I said, and she smiled.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
509,"["" There was more noise from below, then the sound of a door opening, followed by the thud of feet upon the staircase, 61 62 and a cry: 'Nancy!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
510,"[""' It was Alice.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
511,"["" 'Mother says will Miss Butler just step down for a moment, please, for them to say good-bye.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
512,"[""' I looked at Kitty.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
513,"["" 'You go on,' I said, 'without me, and I shall come down in a minute.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
514,"["" I'll talk to them about it, later on.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
515,"[""' She nodded, and gave my hand another squeeze; then she opened the door and joined Alice on the landing, and I heard them step below, together.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

516,"[' I had taken to scrubbing my hands very carefully, since meeting Kitty Butler; and if they were ever a little stained at the creases now, it was as much with paint and hot-black and blanc-de-perle, as with vinegar.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
517,"["" How would it be, I thought, to surrender my family, my home, all my oyster-girl's ways?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
518,"["" And how would it be to live at Kitty's side, brim-full of a love so quick, and yet so secret, it made me shake?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

519,"["" - 3 I wish, for sensation's sake, I could say that my parents heard one word of Kitty's proposal and forbade me, absolutely, to refer to it again; that when I pressed the matter, they cursed and shouted; that my mother wept, my father struck me; that I was obliged, in the end, to climb from a window at dawn, with my clothes in a rag at the end of a stick, and a streaming face, and a note pinned to my pillow saying Do not try to follow me .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
520,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
521,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
522,"[' But if I said these things, I would be lying.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

523,"[' They loved me, and they feared for me; the idea of allowing their youngest daughter to travel in the care of an actress and a music-hall manager to the grimmest, wickedest city in England was, they knew, a mad one, that no sane parent should entertain for longer than a second.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

524,"["" Anyone with half an eye could see that my heart lay all with Kitty Butler now; anyone might guess that, having once been offered the chance of a future at her side, and kept from it, I could never return to my father's kitchen and be happy there, as I had been before.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

525,"["" So when, an hour or so after Kitty's departure, I nervously put her plan before my parents, and argued and pleaded for their blessing, they listened to me wonderingly, but carefully; and when, the next day, Father stopped me on my way down to the kitchen to draw me into the parlour where it was quiet and still, his face was sad and serious, but kind.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

526,"["" He said, if I was quite decided, then Mother and he could not keep me; that I was a grown-up woman, almost, and should be allowed to know my own mind; that they had thought to see me marry a Whitstable boy, and settle close at hand, and so have a share in my little happinesses and troubles - but that now, he supposed, I would go and hitch up with some London fellow, who wouldn't understand their ways at all.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

527,"[' I had never seen him weep either; but now as he spoke his eyes glistened, and he blinked, twice or thrice, to hold the tears back, and his voice grew thin.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
528,[' I placed my head against his shoulder and let my own tears rise and spill.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

529,"["" And that, if things don't turn out as you might, quite, wish them, you won't be too proud to come home to those that love you -' Here his voice failed utterly, and he shuddered; and I could only nod against his neck and say, 'I will, I will; I promise you, I will.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
530,"[""' But oh!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
531,"[' hard-hearted daughter that I was, when he had left me my tears dried at once, and I felt the return of all my gladness of the night before.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

532,"["" Then quickly, before I should be missed, I ran to the post office and sent Kitty a card at the Palace - a picture of a Whitstable oyster-smack, upon whose sail I inked 'To London', and on the deck of which I drew two girls with bags and trunks and outsize, smiling faces.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

533,"[' I had to be glad only in snatches that day, for the scene that I had passed with Father, after breakfast, had to be undergone again with Mother - who hugged me to her, and cried that they must be fools to let me go; and Davy - who said, quite absurdly, that I was too little to go to London, and would be run down by a tram in Trafalgar Square the minute I set foot in it; and Alice - who said nothing at all when she heard the news, but ran from the kitchen in tears, and could not be persuaded to take up her duties in the Parlour until lunch-time.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

534,"[' I spent my evenings in calling on friends and family, and bidding them farewell; and in washing and patching and packing my dresses, and sorting out which little items to take with me, which to leave behind.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

535,"[' I visited the Palace only once, and that was in the company of my parents, who came to reassure themselves that Miss Butler was still sensible and good, and to ask for further particulars of the shadowy Walter Bliss.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
536,"[' I had Kitty to myself for no more than a minute, while Father chatted with Tony and Tricky, after the show.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

537,"[' Every night, almost, I had woken sweating from dreams in which I presented myself at her door, with my bags all packed and my hat upon my head, and she looked 65 66 at me in wonder, and frowned, or laughed with derision; or else I arrived too late at the station, and had to chase the train along the track while Kitty and Mr Bliss gazed at me from their carriage window, and would not lean outside to pull me in .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
538,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
539,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
540,"[' That night at the Palace, however, she led me to one side, and pressed my hand, and was quite as kind and excited as she had been before.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
541,"["" 'I've had a letter from Mr Bliss,' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
543,"[""' Grease-Paint Avenue!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

544,"["" I saw it instantly and it was marvellous, a street set out like a make-up box, with narrow, gilded houses, each one with a different coloured roof; and ours would be number 3 - with a chimney the colour of Kitty's carmined lips!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
545,"["" And I'm due to start the very next day at the Star Music Hall, in Bermondsey.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
546,"[""' The Star,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
547,"["" Oh, Nan, let's only hope so!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

549,"["" By eleven o'clock I felt as penned and as stifled as a rat in a box, and made Alice walk with me to the beach, and hold my shoes and stockings while I stood at the water's edge one final time.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

550,"[' No matter how hard I studied it, how fiercely I thought, I shall not gaze at you again for months and months, it looked just as it always did; and at last I turned my eyes away, and walked sadly home.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
551,"[' But it was the same there: nothing that I gazed at or touched was as special as I thought it should be, or changed by my going in any way.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
552,"[' Nothing, that is, except the faces of my family; and these were so grave, or so falsely merry and stiff, that I could hardly bear to look at them at all.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

553,"["" Father wouldn't let me take the little train to Canterbury, but said I must be driven, and hired a gig from the ostler at the Duke of Cumberland Hotel, to take me there himself.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
554,"["" I kissed Mother, and Alice, and let my brother hand me to my seat at Father's side and place my luggage at my feet.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

555,"[' He had bought it new, and had my initials painted on the lid in swooning yellow capitals; and inside it he had pasted a map of Kent, with Whitstable marked on it with an arrow - to remind me, he said, where home was, in case I should forget.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
556,"[' At the station we found the train already in and steaming, and Kitty, her own bags and baskets at her side, frowning over her watch.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
557,"["" It wasn't like my anxious dreams at all: she gave a great wave when she saw us, and a smile.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
558,"[' Here Kitty found a porter to help us with our bags and boxes, and while he loaded them on to a trolley we looked round anxiously for Mr Bliss.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
559,"["" At last, 'There he is!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
560,"[""' cried Kitty, and her pointing finger showed him striding up the platform, his whiskers and his coat-tails flying and his face very red.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
561,"["" 'I thought you might have changed your mind,' she cried, 'at the very last moment.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
562,"[""' And I shook my head - in wonder that she could still think such a thing, after all I'd said!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
563,"["" At the last moment, as I leaned from the carriage to embrace him, he drew a little chamois bag from his 'Miss Butler!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
564,"[""' he cried when he reached us.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
565,"["" 'Miss Astley - late of Whitstable, I believe?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
566,"[""' He took my hand and gripped it briefly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
567,"[' pocket and placed it in my hand, and closed my fingers over it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

568,"[' It held coins - sovereigns - six of them, and more, I knew, than he could afford to part with; but by the time I had drawn open the neck of the bag and seen the gleam of the gold inside it, the train had begun to move, and it was too late to thrust them back.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

569,"[' Instead, I could only shout my thanks, and kiss my fingers to him, and watch as he raised his hat and waved it; then place my cheek against the window-glass when he was gone from sight, and wonder when I should see him next.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

570,"[' I felt safer in the carriage, and only rather queer, to be so close to a gentleman I did not know, being transported I knew not where, in a city that was vaster and smokier and more alarming than I could have thought possible.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

571,"[' I did not wonder for long, I am afraid to say, for the thrill of being with Kitty - of hearing her talk again of the rooms we were to share, and the kind of life we were to have together in the city, where she was to make her fortune - soon overcame my grief.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
572,"[' My family would have thought me cruel, I know, to see me laugh while they were sad at home without me; but oh!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

573,"[' Mr Bliss had suggested we take in the sights a little before we headed for Brixton, so now we rolled into Trafalgar Square - towards 69 70 Nelson on his pillar, and the fountains, and the lovely, bone-coloured front of the National Gallery, and the view down Whitehall to the Houses of Parliament.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
