574,"["" 'My brother,' I said, as I pressed my face to the window to gaze at it all, 'said I would be run down by a tram in Trafalgar Square, if ever I came to London.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
575,"[""' Mr Bliss looked grave.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
576,"["" That night in Kitty's dressing-room I had thought him almost middle-aged; now I guessed him to be one- or two-and-thirty, at the most.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

577,"[' He was an impressive, rather than a handsome, man, but for all his flash and his speeches, rather homely: I thought he must have a little wife who loved him, and a baby; and that if he did not - which, in fact, was the case - that he should have.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

578,"["" I knew nothing, then, of his history, but learned later that he came from an old, respectable, theatrical family (his real name was no more Bliss, of course, than Kitty's was Butler); that he had left the legitimate stage when he was still a young man, in order to work the halls as a comic singer; and that he managed, now, a dozen artistes, but still, on occasion, took a turn before the footlights - as 'Walter Waters, Character Baritone' - for sheer love of the profession.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
579,[' I knew none of this that day in the brougham - but I began to guess a little of it.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

580,"[' For we had reached Pall Mall and turned into the Haymarket, where the theatres and the music halls begin; and as we rumbled past them he raised his hand and tilted the brim of his hat in a kind of salute.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
581,"["" 'Her Majesty's,' he said, nodding to a handsome building on his left: 'my father saw Jenny Lind, the Swedish Nightingale, make her debut there.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

582,"[' \'And finally,"" he said - and here he removed his hat entirely, and held it in his lap - \'finally, the Empire and the Alhambra, the handsomest music halls in England, where every artiste is a star, and the audience is so distinguished that even the gay girls in the gallery - if you\'ll pardon my French, Miss Butler, Miss Astley - wear furs, and pearls, and diamonds.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
583,"[""' He tapped on the ceiling of the brougham, and the driver drew to a halt at a corner of the little garden in the middle of the square.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

584,"[' There were newcomers to the city, gazing about them as dazed and confounded as I; and there were people curled on steps and benches, people in clothes that were crumpled or stained, who looked as if they spent all their daylit hours here - and all their dark ones, too.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
585,"[' I gazed at Kitty, and my face, I suppose, showed my amazement, for she laughed, and stroked my cheek, then seized my hand and held it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
586,"["" 'We are at the heart of London,' said Mr Bliss as she did so, 'the very heart of it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

587,"["" Over there' - he nodded to the Alhambra -'and all around us' - and here he swept his hand across the square itself - 'you see what makes that great heart beat: Variety!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
588,"[' Variety, Miss Astley, which age cannot wither, nor custom stale.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
589,"[""' Now he turned to Kitty.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

590,"[' Tomorrow, Miss Butler - tomorrow, or next week, or next month, perhaps, but soon, soon, I promise you - you will stand within it, your feet upon its stage.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
591,"[' You that makes the throats of the city shout, ""Brava!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
592,"['""\' As he spoke he lifted his hat, and punched the air with it; one or two passers-by turned their faces towards us, then looked away quite unconcerned.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

593,"[' His words, I thought, were marvellous ones - and I knew Kitty thought so, too, for she gripped my hand at the sound of them, and gave a little shudder of delight; and her cheeks were flushed, as mine were, and her eyes, like mine, were shining and wide.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

594,"["" Mr Bliss hailed a boy, and gave him a shilling to fetch us three foaming glasses from the sherbet-seller, and we sat for a minute in Shakespeare's shadow, sipping our drinks and gazing at the people who passed us by, and at the notices outside the Empire, where Kitty's name, we knew, would soon be pasted in letters three feet high.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

595,"[' But when our glasses were empty, he slapped his hands together and said we must be off, for Brixton and Mrs Dendy - our new landlady - awaited; and he led us back to the brougham and handed us to our seats.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
596,"[' I felt my eyes, that had been so wide and dazzled, grow small again in the gloom of the coach, and I began to feel, not thrilled, but rather nervous.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

597,"[' The houses and the people here were smart, but rather uniform, as if all Grafted by the same unimaginative hand: 73 74 there was none of that strange glamour, that lovely, queer variety of Leicester Square.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

598,"[' Soon, too, the streets ceased even to be smart, and became a little shabby; each corner that we passed, each public house, each row of shops and houses, seemed dingier than the one before.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
599,"[' Beside me, Kitty and Mr Bliss had fallen into conversation; their talk was all of theatres and contracts, costumes and songs.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
600,"[' I kept my face pressed to the window, wondering when we should ever leave behind these dreary districts and reach Greasepaint Avenue, our home.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

601,"["" We were met at the door by Mrs Dendy herself - a white-haired, rather portly lady, who greeted Mr Bliss like a friend, calling him 'Wal', and offering him her cheek to kiss - and shown into her parlour.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
602,[' When the door was closed behind her Mrs Dendy gave us a smile.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
604,"[' I do hope that your stay with me will be a happy, and a lucky one.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
605,"[""' Here she nodded to Kitty.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
606,"["" 'Mr Bliss tells me that I'm to have quite a little star twinkling beneath my eaves, Miss Butler.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

607,"[""' At last, when we had turned into a street of tall, flat-roofed houses, each with a line of blistered railings before it and a set of sooty blinds and curtains at its windows, Mr Bliss broke off his talk to peer outside and say that we were almost there.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
608,"[' I had to look away from his kind and smiling face, then, to hide my disappointment.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

609,"[' I knew that my first, excited vision of Brixton - that row of golden make-up sticks, our house with the carmine-coloured roof - was a foolish one; but this street looked so very grey and mean.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
610,"[' As we stepped from the carriage I glanced at Kitty to see if she, too, felt any stirrings of dismay.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

611,"[' But her colour was as high, and her eyes as damp and shining, as before; she only gazed at the house to which our chaperon now led us, and gave a little, tight-lipped smile of satisfaction.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
612,"[' I understood, suddenly - what I had only half perceived before - that she had spent her life in plain, anonymous houses like this one, and knew no better.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
613,"[' The thought gave me a little courage - and made me ache, as usual, with sympathy and love.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
614,"["" Kitty said modestly that she didn't know about that, and Mrs Dendy gave a chuckle that turned into a throaty cough.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
615,"[' For a long moment the cough seemed to quite convulse her, and Kitty and I sat up, exchanging glances of alarm and dismay.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

616,"[' She drew a handkerchief from her sleeve, and wiped her lips and eyes with it; then she reached for a packet of Woodbines from the table at her elbow, offered us each a cigarette, and took one for herself.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
617,"[' After a moment the tea things appeared, and while Kitty and Mrs Dendy busied themselves with the tray I looked about me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
618,"["" There was much to look at, for Mrs Dendy's parlour was rather extraordinary.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
619,"["" 'I dare say you would like to see your rooms, and give your faces a bit of a splash,' she said pleasantly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

620,"["" 'I can see you are quite taken with my little collection,' said Mrs Dendy as she handed me my tea-cup, and I blushed to find all eyes suddenly turned my way.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
621,"["" 'All old tenants of mine, my dear,' she said; 'and some of them, as you will see, rather famous.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
622,"[""' I looked at the pictures again.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
623,"[' Kind thoughts, Good wishes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
624,"[' I marvelled to think that they had all stayed here, in Ginevra Road, with comely Mrs Dendy as their host.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

625,"[' At the top of these steps there was a door, and behind this a very small room - not a bed-sitting room as I had expected, but a tiny parlour with a pair of ancient, sagging armchairs set before a hearth, and a shallow, old-fashioned dresser.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

626,"[' Kitty and I stepped to its threshold and stood, side by side, gazing at what lay beyond: a wash-hand stand; a lyre- backed chair; an alcove with a curtain before it; and a bed - a bed with a high, thick mattress and an iron bedstead, and beneath it a chamberpot - a bed rather narrower than the one I was used to sharing with my sister at home.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
627,"["" 'You won't mind doubling up, of course,' said Mrs Dendy, who had followed us to the bedroom.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
628,[' But Mr Bliss did insist on a decent bit of space for the two of you.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
629,"[""' She smiled at me, and I looked away.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

630,"[' Kitty, however, said very We talked until the tea was drunk, and our landlady had smoked two or three more cigarettes; then she slapped her knees and got slowly to her feet.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
631,"["" Miss Astley and I will be as cosy here as two peg-dolls in a dolls' house - won't we, Nan?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

632,"[""' She smiled, then bent to tug at the straps of the basket at her feet; and after a moment of idling in the armchair, watching her busy herself with dresses and books and bonnets, I rose to help her.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
633,"[' Her cheeks, I saw, had grown a little pink - but that might have been from the climb up from the parlour.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
634,"["" I said, 'We will', and lowered my gaze again; then moved to take a box from Mr Bliss.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

635,"[' My own few poor frocks and shoes and underclothes took up little enough space, and were stowed away in a moment; but Kitty, of course, had not only her everyday dresses and boots to unpack and brush and straighten, but also her suits and toppers.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
636,"["" I said, 'You must let me take charge of your costumes now, you know.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
637,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
638,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
639,"[""' Mr Bliss himself did not stay long after that - as if he thought it indelicate to linger in a lady's chamber, even one he was paying for himself.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

640,"[' He exchanged a few words with Kitty regarding her appointment on the morrow at the Bermondsey Star - for she had to meet the manager, and rehearse with the orchestra, in the morning, in preparation for her first appearance in the evening - then he shook her hand, and mine, and bade us farewell.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
641,"[' I felt as anxious, suddenly, at the thought of him leaving us, as I had done a few hours before at the prospect of meeting him at all.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
642,[' I looked up at last to find her watching me; and when I caught her eye she winked and blushed at once.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
643,"["" 'You cannot know,' she said then, 'how horribly smug I feel.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
644,"[' Every second-rate serio longs to have a dresser, Nan.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

645,"[' Every hopeful, tired little actress who ever set foot upon a provincial stage aches to play the London halls - to have two nice rooms, instead of one, miserable one - to have a carriage to take her to the show at night, and drive her home, afterwards, while other, poorer, artistes must take the tram.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
646,"[""' She was standing beneath the slope of the ceiling, her face in shadow and her eyes dark and large.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

647,"["" 'And now, suddenly, I have all these things, that I have But when he had gone - and when Mrs Dendy, too, had closed the door on us and wheezed and coughed her way downstairs behind him -I lowered myself into one of the armchairs and closed my eyes, and felt myself ache with pleasure and relief simply to be alone at last with someone who was more to me than a stranger.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

648,"[' I heard Kitty step across the luggage, and when I opened my eyes she was at my side and had raised a hand to tug at a lock of hair which had come loose from my plait and was falling over my brow.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
649,"["" Do you know how that must feel, Nan, to be given your heart's desire, like that?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
650,"[""' I did.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

651,"["" It was a wonderful feeling - but a fearful one, too, for you felt all the time that you didn't deserve your own good fortune; that you had received it quite by error, in someone else's place - and that it might be taken from you while your gaze was turned elsewhere.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
652,"[' I knew that Kitty and I felt just the same - only, of course, about different things.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
653,"[' We unpacked, as I have said, for an hour, and while we worked I caught the sound of various shouts and stirrings in the rest of the house.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

655,"[""' It was Mrs Dendy, come to tell us that there was a bit of dinner for us, if we wanted it, in the downstairs parlour - and 'quite a crowd, besides, that'd like to meet you'.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

656,"["" I was hungry, but also weary, and sick of shaking hands and smiling into strangers' faces; but Kitty whispered that we had better go down, or the other lodgers would think us proud.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

657,"[' So we called to Mrs Dendy to give us a moment, and while Kitty changed her dress I combed and re-plaited my hair, and beat the dust from the hem of my skirt into the fireplace, and washed my hands; and then we made our way downstairs.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

658,"[' The table had been opened out and pulled into the centre of the room, and set for dinner; more importantly, it was ringed with faces, every one of which looked up as we appeared and broke into a smile -the same quick, well-practised smile which shone from all the pictures on the walls.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
659,[' It was as if half-a- dozen of the portraits had come to life and stepped from behind their dusty panes to join Mrs Dendy for supper.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

661,"[' Mrs Dendy herself was seated at the head of the table; she was in the process of dishing out slices from a plate of cold meats, but half rose when she saw us, to bid us make ourselves at home, and to gesture, with her fork, to the other diners - first to an elderly gentleman in a velvet waistcoat who sat opposite to her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
662,"["" It has been many years since I last stood before a hushed and gaping crowd, guessing at the contents of a lady's purse.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
663,"[""' He smiled, then sat rather heavily.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
664,[' Kitty said that she was very pleased to know him.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
665,"["" Mrs Dendy pointed next to a thin, red-headed boy on the Professor's right.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
666,"["" 'Corner Man -' 'Corner Man Extraordinary, of course,' he said quickly, leaning to shake our hands.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
667,"["" He's also extraordinary.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

668,"[""' As he spoke Percy gave a wink and, as if to prove his brother's words, caught up a pair of spoons from the side of 81 82 his plate, and set them rattling upon the tablecloth in a wonderful tattoo.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
669,"["" I've seen that happen.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
670,"[""' Mrs Dendy cleared her throat above the noise, then gestured to the pretty, pink-lipped girl who had the seat next to Sims.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
671,"["" 'And not forgetting Miss Flyte, our ballerina.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
672,"[""' Take her from me?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
673,"[""' said Kitty with a smile.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
674,[' It is Nan that brings me my good luck .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
675,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
676,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
677,"['"" The girl gave a simper.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
678,"["" 'You must call me Lydia,' she said, extending a hand, 'which is what I am known as at - do cheese it, Percy!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
680,"[' Or Monica, if you prefer, which is my real name.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

681,"[""' I looked at my plate, and felt myself redden, until Mrs Dendy, still busy with her platter, held a piece of quivering meat my way and coughed: 'A bit of tongue, Miss Astley dear?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
682,"[""' 'Or Tootsie,' added Sims, 'which is what her pals all call her - and if you've read Ally Sloper's I'll leave you to work out why.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

683,"[' Only let me say, Miss Butler, that she was in half a panic when Walter told us he was moving you in, lest you turn out to he some flashy show-girl with a ten-inch waist.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
684,"[' When she learned you were a male impersonator, why, she turned quite gentle with relief.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
685,"[""' The supper-talk was all, of course, theatrical tittle-tattle, and terribly dense and strange to my ears.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

686,"[' Even plain little Minnie - the eighth member of our party, the girl who had brought us tea on our arrival and had returned now to help Mrs Dendy dish and serve and clear the plates - even she belonged to a ballet troupe, and had a contract at a concert hall in Lambeth.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

687,"["" Why, even the dog, Bransby, which soon nosed its way into the parlour to beg for scraps, and to lean his slavering jaw against Professor Emery's knee -even he was an old artiste, and had once toured the South Coast in a dancing dog act, and had a stage name: 'Archie'.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
688,"[' I am very pleased to have another girl about the place - two girls, I should say - flashy or otherwise.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

689,"[""' As she spoke she gave me a quick, satisfied glance that showed plain enough which kind she thought I was; then - as Kitty took the seat beside her, leaving me with Percy for a neigh-hour - she went on: 'Walter says you will be very big, Miss Butler.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

690,"["" At seven o'clock there was a knock upon the door, and a girl came halloo-ing her way into the house with a dress of tulle and satin and a gilt tiara: she was a friend of Tootsie's from the ballet at the Pav come to ask Mrs Dendy's opinion of her costume.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
691,"["" Do call me Kitty 'And what about you, Miss Astley?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
692,"[""' asked Percy as they chatted.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
693,"["" 'You could play Wagner on it, and I swear it would come out sounding like a sea-shanty or a jig!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
694,"[""' - but the tune was gay and it made Kitty smile.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

695,"["" I didn't look at her or say her name, and she didn't greet me, only moved very quietly about the room - assuming, I suppose, I was asleep, for I was lying very straight on my side and had my eyes hard shut.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
696,"[' There was a little noise from the rest of the house - a laugh, and the closing of a door, and the rushing of water through distant pipes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

697,"["" 'I know this,' she said to me; and since she knew it she couldn't help but sing it, and had soon stepped over the sparkling frock upon the floor to lift her voice for the chorus at Sims's side.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
698,"["" 'I am in the queerest-looking parlour you ever saw,' I wrote, 'and everybody is extremely kind.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
699,"["" I knew that if I opened my eyes now, and tilted my face, I should see her clad in nothing but shadows and the candle- flame's amber glow.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

700,"[' It was very cosy on the sofa, with everyone about me so gay; hut at half-past ten or so Kitty yawned - and at that I gave a jump, and rose, and said it was my bedtime.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

701,"[' But I was not sleepy at all; it was only that I wanted to be safely abed before Kitty appeared - safely still and calm and ready for that moment that must shortly come, when she would be beside me in the dark, and there would be nothing but the two flimsy lengths of our cotton nightgowns to separate her own warm limbs from mine.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
702,[' I felt her breath upon my neck and knew that she was gazing at me.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
703,"["" 85 86 She said, 'Do you miss your home, and Alice?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
704,"[""' I shook my head.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
705,"["" 'Not just a little?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
706,"[""' 'Well .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
707,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
708,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
709,"['"" I felt her smile.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

710,"[' Very gently - but quite matter-of-factly - she moved her hand to my wrist, pulled my arm above the bedclothes, and ducked her head beneath it to place her temple against my collar-bone, my arm about her neck.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
711,"["" 'How your heart beats!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

713,"["" She sighed again - this time her mouth was at the opening of my nightgown, and I felt her breath upon the naked skin beneath - she sighed and said, 'So many times I lay in that dull room at Mrs Pugh's and thought of you and Alice in your little bed beside the sea.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
714,"[' I, too, was thinking back to that little bed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
715,"[' How hard it had been, having to lie next to slumbering Alice, my heart and my head all filled with Kitty.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
716,"[' Kitty spoke on, not minding my silence.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
717,"["" 'Yes, I -' She seemed to hesitate; then, 'You see,' she went on, 'I never had a sister like other girls did .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
718,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
719,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
720,"[""' She let go of my hand, and placed her arm over my middle, curling her fingers around the hollow of my waist.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
721,"[' Then I turned my face away - quite dazed, with mixed relief and disappointment.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
722,"["" I said, 'Oh yes, Kitty,' and she squeezed me tighter.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
723,"[' I knew that I would not, after all, pack my bags in the morning and bid Kitty farewell; I knew that, having come so far, I could not.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
724,"["" But if I were to stay with her, then it must be as she said; I must learn to swallow my queer and inconvenient lusts, and call her 'sister'.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

725,"["" - 4 The Star, when we reached it at noon the next day, turned out to be not a tenth as smart as those marvellous West End halls before which we had leaned, with Mr Bliss, to dream of Kitty's triumph; even so, however, it was quite alarmingly handsome and grand.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

726,"["" Its manager at this time was a Mr Ling; he met us at the stage door and took us to his office, to read aloud the terms of Kitty's contract and 87 88 secure her signature upon it; but then he rose and shook our hands and shouted for the call-boy, and had us shown, rather briskly, to the stage.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
727,"[' Here, self-conscious and awkward, I waited while Kitty spoke with the conductor and ran through her songs with the band.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
728,"["" 'I'm waiting for Miss Butler,' I said, my voice as thin as a whistle.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
729,"[' Go on, now.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

730,"[""' And I moved away, blushing horribly, and had to stand in a corridor while boys with baskets and ladders and pails of sand lumbered by me, looking me over, or cursing when I blocked their path.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
731,"[' Our return visit, however, in the evening, was an easier one, for then we went straight to the dressing-room, where I knew my part a little better.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

732,"[' Even so, when we entered the room I felt my spirits tumble rather, for it was nothing like the cosy little chamber at the Canterbury Palace, which Kitty had had all to herself, and which I was used to keeping so neat and nice.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

733,"[' Instead it was dim and dusty, with benches and hooks for a dozen artistes, and one greasy sink that must be shared by all, and a door that must be propped shut or left to sag and let in every glance of every stage- hand and visitor that might be idling in the passageway beyond.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

734,"["" They looked up when we arrived, and smiled, most of them; and when Kitty took out her packet of Weights and a match, someone cried, 'Thank God, a woman with a cigarette!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
735,"["" I'm quite broke till pay-day.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
736,"[""' Kitty was booked to appear that night, a little way into the first half of the show.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

737,"[' While I helped her with her collar and her neck-tie and her rose, I felt quite steady; but when we walked to the wing to wait for her number to go up, to gaze from the shadows at the unfamiliar theatre and its vast and careless crowd, I felt myself begin to tremble.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
738,[' I looked at Kitty.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

739,"[' With no other motive, I swear, than to comfort her - so mindful was I of that new resolve, to play her sister and nothing more - I took her hand, and pressed it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
740,"[' When the stage-manager finally gave her his nod, however, I had to turn my eyes away.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

741,"[' There was no chairman at this hall to bring the crowd to order, and the act Kitty had to follow was a popular one - a comedian, who had been called back upon the stage four times, and who had had to plead with the audience, in the end, to let him make his exit.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
742,"["" They had done so grudgingly; they were disappointed and distracted now when the orchestra struck up with the first bars of Kitty's opening song.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
743,"["" When Kitty herself stepped out into the glare of the footlights to wave her hat and call 'Hallo!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

744,"[""', there was no answering roar from the gallery, only a half-hearted ripple of applause from the boxes and stalls - for the sake, I suppose, of her costume.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

745,"[' When I forced my gaze at last into the hall I saw that the audience was restless - that people were on their feet, heading for the bar or the lavatory; that boys were perched upon the gallery rail with their backs to us; that girls were calling to friends three rows away, or gossiping with their neighbours, looking 89 90 everywhere but at the stage, where Kitty - lovely, clever Kitty - sang and strode and sweated.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
746,"["" When she finished her first song a man leaned from a balcony to shout, 'Now bring Nibs back on!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
747,"[""' - meaning Nibs Fuller, the comedian whom Kitty had replaced.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
748,"["" Kitty didn't blink; while the band played the warm-up to her next number she raised her hat to the man and called, 'Why, does he owe you money?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
749,"[""' The crowd laughed -and listened more carefully to her next song, and clapped more briskly when she finished it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

750,"[' When, a little later, another man tried to call for Nibs, he was shushed by his neighbours; and by the time Kitty got round to her ballad and her bit of business with the rose the hall was on her side, attentive and appreciative.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
751,"[' When she stepped into the wing, weary and flushed, and her place was taken by a comic singer, I put my hand upon her arm and pressed it hard.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

752,"["" They had been watching from the front, and looked very satisfied; the former took Kitty's hand in both of his and shook it, crying, 'A triumph, Miss Butler!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
753,"["" He gave Kitty a nod, then said, 'Well done, my dear.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
754,"[' I had brought a towel with me from the change-room, and this she now caught up, and pressed to her face.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
755,"[' Then she took her jacket off, and handed it to me, and unfastened the bow-tie at her throat.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
756,"["" 'It wasn't so good,' she said at last, 'as I might have wished it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
757,[' Soon they will be buying tickets just for you!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
758,"[""' At that I saw the manager glance his way through narrowed eyes; but Kitty, at least, allowed herself to smile.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
759,"["" 'That's better,' said Mr Bliss then.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
760,"["" 'And now, if you'll permit me, ladies, I believe a light little supper would be welcome.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
761,"[' A light little supper - and, perhaps, a heavy large glass with some of that fizz in it, Miss Butler, that you seem so keen on.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

762,"[""' The restaurant to which he took us was a theatre people's one, not very far away, and filled with gentlemen in fancy waistcoats just like himself, and with girls and boys like Kitty, with streaks of greasepaint on their cuffs and crumbs of spit-black in the corners of their eyes.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

763,"["" I am going to ask you to go about the city - and you must assist her, Miss Astley,' he added when he saw me looking - 'you must both of you go about the city and study the men!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
764,"[""' I gazed at Kitty and blinked, and she smiled back uncertainly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
765,"["" 'Study the men?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
766,"[""' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
767,"["" 'Scrutinise 'em!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
768,"[""' said Mr Bliss, sawing at a piece of cutlet.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
769,"["" 'You must know it; and you must copy them, and make your audience know it in their turn.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
770,"[""' 'Do you mean, then,' I asked, not understanding, 'to change Kitty's act?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
771,"[""' 'I mean, Miss Astley, to broaden Kitty's repertoire.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
772,"[' Her masher is a very fine fellow; but she cannot walk the Burlington Arcade, in lavender gloves, for ever.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
773,"[""' He gazed at Kitty again, then wiped his mouth with a napkin and spoke in a more confiding tone.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

774,"["" 'Only imagine, Miss Astley, all the handsome gentlemen's toggery that languishes, at this very minute, at the bottom of some costumier's hamper, waiting, simply waiting, for Kitty Butler to step inside it and lend it life!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
775,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
776,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
777,"[""' He paused at last, and Kitty smiled.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
778,"["" 'Mr Bliss,' she said, 'I do believe you could persuade a one-armed man into a juggling turn, the way you talk.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

779,"[""' He laughed, and struck the table with his hand so that the cutlery rattled: it turned out that he had a one-armed juggler for a client, and was billing him - with great success - as 'The Second Cinquevalli: Half the Capacity, Double the Skill!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
780,"[""' And it was all quite as he promised and directed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

781,"["" He sent us to costumiers and tailors, and had Kitty decked out in a dozen different gentlemanly guises; and when the suits were made he sent us to photographers, to have her likeness taken as she held a policeman's whistle to her lip, or shouldered a rifle or a sailor's rope.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

782,"["" He found songs to fit the costumes, and brought them round to Ginevra Road himself, to strike them out on Mrs Dendy's terrible old piano for Kitty to try, and for the rest of us to listen to and consider.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

783,"["" Now she did not change into her ordinary girl's clothes when she finished her act at the Star; instead, I stood with her coat 93 94 and her basket ready, and when she stepped from before the footlights we ran together to the stage door, to where our brougham waited to lumber fitfully with us through the city traffic to the next theatre.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

784,"[' Now, instead of wearing one suit for the whole of her turn she wore three or four; and I was her dresser in real earnest, helping her tear at buttons and links while the orchestra played between the songs, and the audience waited, half-way between expectation and impatience, for her to reappear.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

785,"[' The hours we kept now, of course, were rather strange ones, for as long as Kitty continued to work two, three or four halls a night we would arrive back at Ginevra Road at half- past twelve or one, weary and aching but still giddy and hot from our moonlit criss-crossings of the city, our anxious waits in dressing-rooms and wings.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

786,"["" Here we would find Sims and Percy, and Tootsie and her girl- and boy-friends, all fresh and flushed and gay as we, making tea and cocoa, Welsh rabbit and pancakes, in Mrs Dendy's kitchen.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

787,"[' Then Mrs Dendy herself would appear - for she had kept theatrical lodgers for so long she had begun to keep theatrical hours, too - and suggest a game of cards, or a song or a dance.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

788,"[' It could not long be kept secret, in that house, that I liked to sing and had a pretty voice, and so sometimes I might raise a chorus or two, along with Kitty.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
789,"["" I sent them cards, as I have said; I sent them notices of Kitty's shows, and gossip from the theatre.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

790,"[' They sent me letters in return, and little parcels - and, of course, barrels of oysters, which I passed on to my landlady to let her dish to us all at supper.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
791,"[' The weeks passed, the season changed; the nights grew longer and darker and cold.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
792,"["" It was not that I didn't think of Father and Mother, of Alice and Davy and my cousins - just that I thought of Kitty, and my new life, more .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
793,"["" I was Kitty's dresser, but I was also her friend, her adviser, her companion in all things.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

794,"["" When she let herself be guided by the clever Mr Bliss - or 'Walter' I should call him, for so, by now, he had become to us, just as we were 'Kitty' and 'Nan' to him - when she let herself be guided by Walter, and spent hours as he had advised in shops and market squares and stations studying the men, I went with her; and we learned together the constable's amble, the coster's weary swagger, the smart clip of the off-duty soldier.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

795,"[' And as we did so we seemed to learn the ways and manners of the whole unruly city; and I grew as easy, at last, with London, as with Kitty herself- as easy, and as endlessly fascinated and charmed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

796,"["" We strolled the West End; we sat and gazed at all the marvellous sights - not just the grand, celebrated sights of London, the palaces and monuments and picture galleries, but also the smaller, swifter dramas: the overturning of a carriage; the escape of an eel from an eel-man's barrow; the picking of a pocket; the snatching of a purse.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

797,"[' We visited the river - stood on London Bridge, and Battersea Bridge, and all the bridges in between, just so that we might look, and marvel, at the great, stinking breadth of it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

798,"[' It gave me an odd little thrill, as I stood gazing at the pleasure-boats beneath Lambeth Bridge, to know that I had journeyed against the current - had made the trip from palpitating metropolis to mild, uncomplicated Whitstable in reverse.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

799,"[' And while we strolled and gazed and grew ever more sisterly and content, the year drew to a close; we continued to labour over the act, and Kitty herself became something of a success.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

800,"[' Now she had admirers - gentlemen, who sent her flowers and dinner invitations (which - to my secret relief- she only laughed over and put aside); boys, who asked for her picture; girls, who gathered at the stage door to tell her how handsome she was - girls I hardly knew whether to pity, patronise or fear, so closely did they resemble me, so easily might they have had my role, I theirs.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

801,"["" The halls she worked remained the suburban ones, and the better class of East End ones (and once or twice the not-so- nice ones - Foresters, and the Sebright, where the crowd threw boots and trotter-bones at the acts they didn't like).""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
802,[' Her name never rose much or grew larger on the music-hall notices; her songs were never hummed or whistled about the streets.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
803,"[' The problem, Walter said, lay not with Kitty herself but with the nature of her act.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
804,"["" 'Why does every young lady who wants to do her bit of business on the stage these days want to do it in trousers?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
805,"[""' he asked us, exasperated, when yet another male impersonator made her debut on the London circuit.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
806,"[' Kitty, you were born to play the boy, any fool can see it; were you an actress on the legitimate stage you would be Rosalind, or Viola, or Portia.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

807,"["" It makes me rage' - he was seated in our little parlour as he spoke, and here he slapped the arm of his chair, so that the ancient seams gave a fart of 97 98 dust and hair - 'it makes me rage to see girls with a tenth of your talent getting all the bookings that should be yours - and worse!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
808,[' all the fame.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
809,"[""' He stood, and placed his hands upon Kitty's shoulders.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
810,"["" 'You are on the very edge of stardom,' he said, giving her a little push so that she had to grasp his arms to stop herself from falling.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

811,"[' She might buy a house - we should have to leave Ginevra Road and all our new friends in it; we should have to leave our little sitting-room; we should have to leave our bed, and take separate chambers.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
812,"[' I did not hold my breath in wonder when I opened my eyes upon her face, still and shadowed in the thin grey light of dawn.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

813,"[' I was as familiar with her body, now, as with my own - more so, indeed, because her head, her neck, her wrists, her back, her limbs (which were as smooth and as rounded and as freckled as her cheek), her skin (which she wore with a marvellous, easy grace, as if it were another kind of handsome suit, perfectly tailored and pleasant to wear), were, I thought, so much lovelier and more fascinating than my own.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

814,"["" But, however hard we worked, we could not find it; and meanwhile Kitty continued at the lesser theatres, in the humbler districts - Islington, Marylebone, Battersea, Peckham, Hackney - circling Leicester Square, crossing the West End on her nightly trips from hall to hall, but never entering those palaces of her and Walter's dreams: the Alhambra, and the Empire.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
815,"["" I was sorry, for Kitty's sake, that her great new London career was not quite so great as she had hoped for; but I was also, privately, relieved.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

816,"[' I knew how clever and charming and lovely she was, and while a part of me wanted, like Walter, to share the knowledge with the world, a greater part longed only to hug it to myself, to keep it secret and secure.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

817,"["" I didn't like it when her fans sent flowers, or clamoured at the stage door for photographs and kisses; more fame would bring more flowers, more kisses - and I could not believe that she would go on laughing at the gentlemen's invitations, could not believe that one day, amongst all those admiring girls, there wouldn't be one she would like better then me .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

818,"["" Inevitably, we had spent so many hours with Walter - working upon songs at Mrs Dendy's piano, or supping with him after shows - that we had begun to look upon him less as Kitty's agent and more as a friend, to both of us.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

819,"["" In time it wasn't only working-days that we were spending with him, but Sundays, too; eventually, indeed, Sundays with Walter became the rule rather than the exception, and we 99 100 began to listen out for the rumble of his carriage in Ginevra Road, the pounding of his boots upon our attic stairs, his rap upon our parlour door, his foolish, extravagant greetings.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

820,"[' He would bring bits of news and gossip; we would drive into town, or out of it; we would stroll together - Kitty with her hand in the crook of one of his great arms, me with mine in the crook of the other, Walter himself like a blustering uncle, loud and lively and kind.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
821,"[' I thought nothing of it, except that it was pleasant, until one morning as I sat eating my breakfast beside Kitty and Sims and Percy and Tootsie.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

822,"["" It was a Sunday, and Kitty and I were rather tardy; when Sims heard who it was that we were rushing for, he gave a cry: 'My word, Kitty, but Walter must be expecting marvellous things of you!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
823,[' Anyone would think he was your beau!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
824,"[""' He seemed to say it guilelessly enough; but as he did so I saw Tootsie smile and give a sideways glance at Percy - and, worse!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
825,"[' saw Kitty blush and turn her face away - and all at once I understood what they all knew, and cursed to think I had not guessed it sooner.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
826,"["" A half-hour later, when Walter presented himself at the parlour door, offering a gleaming cheek to Kitty and crying 'Kiss me, Kate!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
827,"[""', I didn't smile, but only bit my lip, and wondered.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

828,"[' I saw how he seized every foolish opportunity to kiss her hand, or pluck her sleeve, or place his arm, heavy and clumsy with desire, about her slender shoulders; I heard his voice catch, sometimes, or grow thick, when he addressed her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

829,"[' And if I still longed yet feared to hold her - well, as I have said, the fact that Walter felt the same showed that both my reticence and my love were only natural and proper.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
830,"[' She was a star - my private star - and I would be content, I thought, like Walter, to fly about her on my stiff and distant orbit, unswervingly, for ever.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

831,"["" By now it was December - a cold December to match the sweltering August, so cold that the little skylight above our staircase at Ma Dendy's was thick with ice for days at a time; so cold that when we woke in the mornings our breath showed grey as smoke, and we had to pull our petticoats into bed with us and dress beneath the sheets.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

832,"[' I remember my brother Davy sitting at our parlour fire on January evenings, and weeping, simply weeping with pain, as the life returned to his split and frozen hands, his chilblained feet.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
833,"["" At Mrs Dendy's, however, everybody loved the winter months; and the colder they were, they said, the better.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

834,"["" But we didn't worry much over the frozen babies at Mrs Dendy's house that winter; we were merely glad and careless, because ticket sales were high and we were all in work and a little richer than before.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
835,"[' At the beginning of December Kitty got a spot on the bill at a hall in Marylebone, and played there twice a night, all month.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
836,"[' But I knew, too, what Christmas dinner would be like at home.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

837,"[' There would be such a fuss and stir they could not possibly, I thought, miss me - but I knew that Kitty would if I left her for them; and I knew, besides, that I should miss her horribly and only make the occasion miserable for everybody else.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

838,"["" So she and I spent it together - with Walter, as ever, in attendance - at Mrs Dendy's table, eating goose, and drinking toast after toast to the coming year with champagne and pale ale.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

839,"[' Of course, there were gifts: presents from home, which Mother forwarded with a stiff little note that I refused to let shame me; presents from Walter (a brooch for Kitty, a hat- pin for me).']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

840,"["" I sent parcels to Whitstable, and gave gifts at Ma Dendy's; and for Kitty I bought the loveliest thing that I could find: a pearl - a single flawless pearl that was mounted on silver and hung from a chain.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
841,"["" 'Pearls for tears,' she said, and shook her head: she was very superstitious.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

842,"[' Kitty, however, thought it beautiful, and had me fasten it about her neck at once, and seized a mirror to watch it swinging there, an inch beneath the hollow of her lovely throat.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
843,"["" 'I'll never take 103 104 it off,' she said; and she never did, but wore it ever after - even on the stage, beneath her neck-ties and cravats.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

844,"[' It came in a box with a bow, and wrapped in tissue, and turned out to be a dress: the most handsome dress I had ever possessed, a long, slim evening dress of deepest blue, with a cream satin sash about the waist, and heavy lace at the bosom and hem; a dress, I knew, that was far too fine for me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
845,"["" 'It's beautiful,' I said to Kitty, 'but how can I keep it?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
846,"["" It's too expensive.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
847,"[""' But Kitty, who had watched me handle it with dark and shining eyes, only laughed to see me so uneasy.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
848,"["" 'It's about time you started wearing some decent frocks, instead of those awful old schoolgirlish things you brought with you from home.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
849,"["" 'Kitty,' I said, 'I really cannot.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
850,"["" 'And, besides' - she fingered the pearl that I had so recently placed about her neck, and looked away - 'I am doing so well, now.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
851,"["" It ain't quite the thing, now is it?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
852,"[""' She said it lightly - but all at once I saw the truth of her words.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
853,"["" And so I kept the dress for Kitty's sake; and wore it, for the first time, a few nights later.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
854,"[' Kitty had a new frock of her own made for it, a lovely, low-necked, short-sleeved gown of China satin, pink as the warm pink heart of a rose-bud.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

855,"[' I held it for her to step into, and helped her fasten it; then watched her as she pulled her gloves on - aching all the time with the prettiness of her, for the blush of the silk made her red lips all the redder, her throat more creamy, her eyes and hair all the browner and more rich.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
856,"[' But Kitty could have worn anything - a string of bottle-tops about her neck - and still, I thought, look like a queen.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
857,[' Helping Kitty with her buttons made me slow with my own dressing; I said that she should go on down without me.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
858,"[' When she had done so I pulled on the lovely gown that she had given me, then stepped to the glass to study myself - and to frown at what I saw.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

859,"[' In the half-light it was dark as midnight; my eyes appeared bluer above it than they really were, and my hair paler, and the long skirt, and the sash, made me seem taller and thinner than ever.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
860,"["" I did not look at all like Kitty had, in her pink frock; I looked more like a boy who had donned his sister's ball-gown for a lark.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
861,"[' It would have to do - and would have the merit, I supposed, of making Kitty look all the daintier at my side.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
862,"[' Sims turned my way, then, and looked at me as if he had never seen me before, a forkful of food suspended on its journey to his open mouth.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
863,"[' Mrs Dendy followed his gaze, then gave a tremendous cough.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
864,"["" 'Well, Nancy!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
865,"[""' she said, 'and look at you!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
866,[' You have become quite the handsome young lady - and right beneath our noses!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

867,"[""' And at that, Kitty herself turned to me - and showed me such a look of wonder and confusion that it was as if, just for a second, she had never seen me before; and I do not know whose cheeks at that moment were the pinker - mine, or hers.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
868,[' Then she gave a tight little smile.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

869,"["" 'Very nice,' she said, and looked away; so that I thought, miserably, that the dress must suit me even less than I had hoped, and readied myself for a wretched party.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

870,"[' The manager had had to build a platform from the end of the stage to the back of the pit, to carry us all, and he had hired the orchestra to play reels and waltzes, and set tables in the wings bearing pastries and jellies, and barrels of beer and bowls of punch, and row upon row of bottles of wine.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

871,"["" We were much complimented, Kitty and I, on our new dresses; and over me, in particular, people smiled and exclaimed - mouthing at me across the noisy hall, 'How fine you look!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
872,"[""' One woman - the conjuror's assistant - took my hand and said, 'My dear, you're so grown-up tonight, I didn't recognise you!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
873,"[""': just what Mrs Dendy had said an hour before.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

874,"[' Kitty and I stood side by side all evening but when, some time after midnight, she moved away to join a group that had gathered about the champagne tables, I hung back, rather pensive.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

875,"["" I wasn't used to thinking of myself as a grown-up woman, but now, clad in that handsome frock of blue and cream, satin and lace, I began at last to feel like one -and to realise, indeed, that I was one: that I was eighteen, and had left my father's house perhaps for ever, and earned my own living, and paid rent for my own rooms in London.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

876,"[' I watched myself as if from a distance - watched as I supped at my wine as if it were ginger beer, and chatted and larked with the stage-hands, who had once so frightened me; watched as I took a cigarette from a fellow from the orchestra, and lit it, and drew upon it with a sigh of satisfaction.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
877,"["" I had grown so used to holding Kitty's fag for her while she changed suits, that gradually I had taken up the habit myself.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
878,"[' 107 108 The musician - I believe he played the cornet - took a small, insinuating step my way.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
879,"["" 'Are you a friend of the manager's, or what?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
880,"[""' he said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
881,"["" I'm Nancy, Kitty Butler's dresser.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
882,"[""' He raised his eyebrows, and leaned away to look me up and down.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
883,"[' But here, just now, I took you for an actress, or a dancer.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
884,"[""' I smiled, and shook my head.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
885,"["" I've had too much cham.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
886,"[""' He laughed: 'All the better!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
887,"[""' He put his drink aside, gripped his cigarette between his lips, then put his hands on my waist and lifted me up.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
888,"[' I gave a shriek; he began to turn and dip, in a clownish approximation of a waltz-step.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
889,"[' A dozen people looked our way, and smiled and clapped.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
890,"["" 'You've made me giddy as a fish, and' - I felt at the front of my dress - 'you have spoiled my sash!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
891,"[""' 'I'll fix that for you,' he said, reaching for my waist again.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

892,"[' Being tickled always makes me laugh, however little I care for the tickler; but after several more minutes of this kind of thing he at last gave up on me, and went back to his pals in the band.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
893,"[' I made my way first to the lavatory, then headed downstairs to the change- room.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

894,"[' This had been opened tonight only so that the ladies should have a place to hang their coats, and it was cold and empty and rather dim; but it had a looking-glass: and it was to this that I now stepped, squinting and tugging at my dress to pull it straight.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
895,"[' I turned my head to see who was there, and found that it was Kitty.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
896,"["" Her face was turned towards me and I couldn't see her rope of hair, or the swell of her breasts.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
897,"["" 'Wot cheer, Kitty,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
898,"["" 'Seen something you fancy?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
899,"[""' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
900,"[' I turned to her again in surprise, and she took a step into the room.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
901,"["" 'What?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
902,"['\' 109 110 \'I said, ""Seen something you fancy, Nancy?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
903,"['"" Everybody else here tonight seems to have.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
904,[' His hands were all over you.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
905,"[""' 'Oh Kitty, they weren't!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
906,"[""' My voice almost trembled.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
907,"["" 'I shall take the dam' dress off right here and you shall have it back,' I said, 'if that's how you feel about it!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
908,"[""' At that she took another step towards me and seized my arm.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
909,[' Kitty took hold of me again; soon we were almost tussling.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
910,"["" If you just knew -' I put my hand to the back of my collar; her fingers followed my own, her face came close.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
911,"[' Now I knew only that her arm was about me, her hand on mine, her breath hot upon my cheek.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
912,[' Her eyes were round and dark as jet; I felt her fingers leave my hand and move against my neck.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
913,"[' Kitty started in my arms as if a pistol had been fired, and took a half-dozen steps, very rapidly, away.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
914,"["" She said: 'Kitty, Nan, you won't believe it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
915,"[""' She reached for her handkerchief, and put it to her mouth.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

916,"["" They are saying Gully Sutherland is there' - this was the comic singer who had appeared with Kitty at the Canterbury Palace - 'they are saying Gully is there - that he has got drunk, and shot himself dead!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
917,"[""' It was true - we all heard, next day, how horribly true it was.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
918,[' He never finished a show without calling into a public-house on his way home; and on the night of our party he had been drinking at Fulham.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
919,"[' The bar-man said that when Gully heard this he went to the man and shook him by the hand, and bought him a beer, then he bought beer for everyone.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

920,"["" We didn't know all of this that night at Marylebone, we knew only that Gully had had a kind of fit, and taken his life; but the news put an end to our party and left us all, like Esther, nervous and grave.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

921,"[' Kitty and I, on hearing the news, went up to the stage - she seizing my hand as we stumbled up the steps, but in grief now, I thought, rather than anything warmer.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

922,"[' The manager had had all the house-lights lit, and the band had lain their instruments aside; some people were weeping, the cornet-player who had tickled me had his arm about a trembling girl.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

923,"["" I couldn't think of Gully at all: my thoughts were still with Kitty, and with that moment in the change-room, when I had felt her hand on me and seemed to feel a kind of understanding leap between us.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
924,"["" She hadn't looked at me since then, and now she had gone to talk to one of the boys who had brought the news of Gully's suicide.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

925,"[' After a moment, however, I saw her shake her head and step away, and seem to search for me; and when she saw me - waiting for her, in the shadows of the wing - she came and sighed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
926,[' They say his heart was shot right through .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
927,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
928,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
929,"['"" \'And to think,\' I said, \'it was for Gully\'s sake that I first went to Canterbury and saw you .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
930,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
931,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
932,"['"" She looked at me, then, and trembled; and put a hand to her cheek, as if made weak with sorrow.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
933,[' When I said that we should go - since other people were now leaving - she nodded.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
934,"[' We returned to the change-room for our coats: its jets were all flaring now, and there were white-faced women in it with handkerchiefs before their eyes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

935,"["" It was two o'clock or later before we started on our journey home; and then we sat, on different seats, in silence - Kitty repeating only, now and then: 'Poor Gully!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

936,"["" The roads were foggy, and thick with ice: every so often I felt the wheels of our carriage slide a little, and caught the sound of the horse's slithering, uncertain step, and the driver's gentle curses.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

937,"[' For long stretches, ours was the only vehicle on the streets at all; the horse, the driver, Kitty and I might have been the only wakeful creatures in a city of stone and ice and slumber.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
938,"[' 113 114 At length we reached Lambeth Bridge, where Kitty and I had stood only a few weeks before and gazed at the pleasure-boats below.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

939,"[' Now, with our faces pressed to the carriage window, we saw it all transformed - saw the lights of the Embankment, a belt of amber beads dissolving into the night; and the great dark jagged bulk of the Houses of Parliament looming over the river; and the Thames itself, its boats all moored and silent, its water grey and sluggish and thick, and rather strange.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
940,"[' Kitty shivered, and shook her head.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
941,"[' It was this last which made Kitty pull the window down, and call to the driver, in a high, excited voice, to stop.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
942,"[' Then she pushed the carriage door open, pulled me to the iron parapet of the bridge, and seized my hand.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
943,[' At last Kitty gave a whisper.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
944,[' I placed the hand against my cheek; it did not warm it.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

945,"[' With my eyes all the time on the water below I pulled at the button at her wrist, then drew the mitten from her, and held her fingers against my lips to warm them with my breath.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
946,"[' It seemed a little miracle, done just for Kitty and me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
947,[' Would you walk across it?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
948,"[""' I sighed, gently, against her knuckles; then turned the hand, and breathed upon her palm.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
949,"["" Then, 'Nan,' she said, very low.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
950,"[' 115 116 I looked at her, her hand still held to my mouth and my breath still damp upon her fingers.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
951,"[' Her face was raised to mine, and her gaze was dark and strange and thick, like the water below.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
952,"[' I let my hand drop; she kept her fingers upon my lips, then moved them, very slowly, to my cheek, my ear, my throat, my neck.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
953,"["" Then her features gave a shiver and she said in a whisper: 'You won't tell a soul, Nan - will you?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
954,"[""' I think I sighed then: sighed to know - to know for sure, at last!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

955,"[' Her mouth was chill, at first, then very warm - the only warm thing, it seemed to me, in the whole of the frozen city; and when she took her lips away - as she did, after a moment, to give a quick, anxious glance towards our hunched and nodding driver - my own felt wet and sore and naked in the bitter January breezes, as if her kiss had flayed them.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
956,"[' Here we stepped together, and kissed again: I placed my arms about her shoulders, and felt her own hands shake upon my back.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
957,"[' We stood like this for a minute, maybe longer; then the carriage gave a creak as the driver shifted in his seat, and Kitty stepped quickly away.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

958,"["" I could not take my hands from her, but she seized my wrists and kissed my fingers and gave a kind of nervous laugh, and a whisper: 'You will kiss the life out of me!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
959,"[""' She moved into the carriage, and I clambered in behind her, trembling and giddy and half-blind, I think, with agitation and desire.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
960,"[' She put her hands to my face again, and I shivered, so that my jaws jumped beneath her fingers.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

961,"["" But she didn't kiss me again: rather, she leaned against me with her face upon my neck, so that her mouth was out of reach of mine, but hot against the skin below my ear.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

962,"[' When the brougham swayed I felt her lips, her fingers, her thigh come ever more heavy, ever more hot, ever more close upon me, until I longed to squirm beneath the pressing of her, and cry out.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

963,"[' At last, however, we felt the carriage turn, then slow, and finally stop, and heard the driver thump upon the roof with the butt of his whip to tell us we were home: we were so quiet, perhaps he thought we slumbered.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

964,"["" I remember a little of our entry into Mrs Dendy's - the fumbling at the door with the latch-key, the mounting of the darkened stairs, our passage through that still and sleeping 117 118 house.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

965,"["" I remember pausing on the landing beneath the skylight, where the stars showed very small and bright, and silently pressing my lips to Kitty's ear as she bent to unlock our chamber door; I remember how she leaned against it when she had it shut fast behind us, and gave a sigh, and reached for me again, and pulled me to her.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
966,"[' I stripped quickly to my drawers and chemise, then heard Kitty cursing over the buttons of her gown, and stepped to help her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

967,"[' For a moment - my fingers tugging at hooks and ribbons, her own tearing at the pins which kept her plait of hair in place -we might have been at the side of a stage, making a lightning change between numbers.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

968,"[' At last she was naked, all except for the pearl and chain about her neck; she turned in my hands, stiff and pimpled with cold, and I felt the brush of her nipples, and of the hair between her thighs.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

969,"["" Then she moved away, and the bed- springs creaked; and at that, I didn't wait to pull the rest of my own clothes off but followed her to the bed and found her shivering there, beneath the sheets.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
970,"["" 'Oh Nan,' she said, 'I think I shall die if you don't!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
971,"[""' Tentatively, then, I raised my hand, and dipped my fingers into her hair.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

972,"[' Here, shy again, I let my hand linger - until, with her face still tilted from my own and her eyes hard shut, she took my wrist and gently led my fingers to her breasts.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

973,"[' I had never, of course, touched anyone like this before - except, sometimes, myself; but it was as if I touched myself now, for the slippery hand which stroked her seemed to stroke me: I felt my drawers grow damp and warm, my own hips jerk as hers did.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
974,"[' She bucked, and the bed gave an answering creak; her own hands began to chafe distractedly at the flesh of my shoulders.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
975,"[' I felt her heart beating wildly in her breast; and when it had calmed a little she stirred, and sighed, and put a hand to her cheek.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
976,"["" 'Not really, Kitty?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
977,"[""' 'Yes, really.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

978,"[""' She gave a twitch that was half laughter, half a sob, then rubbed at her eyes again, and when I took her fingers from her face I could feel the tears upon them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
979,"[' Did I hurt you, Kitty?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
980,"[""' She shook her head, and sniffed, and laughed more freely.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

981,"[' And I studied her face, where it showed creamy pale in the darkness, and thought She loves me, She loves me - like a fool with a daisy-stalk, endlessly exclaiming over the same last browning petal.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
982,"[' The next morning we were shy together, at first - and Kitty, I think, was the shyest of all.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
983,"["" 'How much we drank, last night!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

984,"[""' she said, not gazing at me; and for a terrible second I thought it might really have been only the champagne that made her cling to me, and say that she loved me, so very very much .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
985,"["" I said, before I could stop myself: 'If you unsay all those things you said last night, oh Kitty, I'll die!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
986,"[""' and that made her raise her eyes to mine, and I saw that she had simply been anxious, that I might only have been drunk .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
987,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

988,"[' We had lived and slept and laboured, side by side, for half a year; but there had been a kind of veil between us, that our cries and whispers of the night before had quite torn down.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

989,"[' She looked flushed, washed - new-born; so that I could hardly press her skin, for fear of marking it - so that I feared, almost, to kiss her lips again in case they bruised.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

990,"[' But I did kiss them; and then I lay, quite at my leisure, and watched as she splashed water on her face and arms, and fastened on her underclothes and frock, and buttoned her shoes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

991,"[' As she worked at her hair I lit a cigarette: I struck the match and let it burn almost to my fingers, gazing at the flame as it ate its way along the wood.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
992,"["" I said, 'When I first knew you, I used to think that, whenever I thought of you, I was all lit up, like a lamp.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
993,"["" 'Didn't you know,' I said then, 'didn't you know, that I loved you?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
994,"[""' 'I'm not sure,' she answered; then she sighed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
995,"["" 'It seemed easier to be your friend 'But Kitty, that's just what I thought!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
996,"[' But I thought, that if you knew I liked you as a, as a sweetheart - well, I never heard of such a thing before, did you?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

997,"[""' She moved to the glass to work again at the pins in her plait, and now, without turning, she said, 'It's true I never cared for any other girl, like I care for you .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
998,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
999,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1000,"[""' As she said 121 122 it I saw her neck and ears grow pink, and felt myself grow weak and warm and silly in response; but I caught a glimpse of something, too, behind her words.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1001,"[' But the fact was, I loved her too much to want to fret for very long about the other girls she might have kissed before me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1002,"["" 'When was it,' I asked next, 'that you began to think of me like .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1003,[' When did you begin to think that you might learn to - to love me?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1004,"[""' Now she did turn, and smiled.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1005,"["" 'I remember a hundred little times,' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1006,"["" 'I remember how you made my dressing- room so nice and neat; I remember your blushes as I kissed you good-night.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1007,"["" I remember how you opened an oyster for me at your father's table -but then, I think I loved you then, already.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1008,"["" Indeed, I'm ashamed to say, that it must have been that moment, at the Canterbury Palace, when I first smelled the oyster-liquor on your fingers, that I began to think of you as -as I shouldn't have.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1009,"[""' 'Oh!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1010,"[""' 'And I'm even more ashamed to say,' she went on in a slightly different tone, 'that it wasn't until last night - when I saw you larking with that boy, and was so jealous - that I learned how much, how much .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1011,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1012,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1013,"['"" \'Oh, Kitty .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1014,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1015,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1016,"['"" I swallowed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1017,"["" 'I'm glad you learned it, at last.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1018,"[""' She looked away, then came to me and took my fag, and gave me one brisk kiss.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1019,"["" I said, 'Must we really get up?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1020,"[""' and Kitty nodded.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1021,"[' I had not forgotten - but had had no time and no desire, yet, to think of ordinary things.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1022,"["" Now, at the mention of Walter's name, I grew thoughtful.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1023,"["" As if Kitty knew what I was thinking, she said, 'You will be sensible with Walter, won't you, Nan?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1024,"[""' Then she repeated what she had said the night before upon the bridge: 'You won't let on, will you, to anyone?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1025,"["" You will be careful - won't you?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1026,"[""' I silently cursed her for being so prudent; but took her hand and kissed it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1027,"[' I shall go on being careful for ever, if you like - so long as I might be a bit reckless, sometimes, when we are quite alone.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1028,"[""' Her smile, when she gave it, was a little distracted.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1029,"["" 'After all,' she said, 'things have not changed, so very much.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1030,"[""' But I knew that everything had changed - everything.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1031,"[' At length I rose too, and washed and dressed and used the chamber-pot, while Kitty went downstairs.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1032,"["" She came back with a tray of tea and toast - 'I could hardly look Ma Dendy in the eye!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1033,"[""' she said, all shy and red again - and we had our breakfast in our own parlour, before the fire, kissing the crumbs and butter from one another's lips.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1034,"["" There was a hamper of suits beneath the window, that we had had sent over from a costumier's and not yet properly examined; and now, as we waited for Walter, Kitty began 123 124 rather idly to sort through it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1035,"[' She slipped it on over her dress, and did a stiff little dance; then she began, very lightly, to sing.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1036,"["" I wouldn't exchange the girl I love, There's bliss in every look.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1037,"["" To see her dance the polka, I could faint with radiant love, 'In a house, in a square, in a quadrant,' she sang, 'In a street, in a lane, in a road; Turn to the left, on the right hand, You see there my true love's abode.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1038,"[""' May the Monument a hornpipe dance, If ever I cease to love!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1039,"[' It was a silly, nonsensical, but rather infectious kind of song, and Kitty sang it all the sweeter for singing it so softly and carelessly.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
