1040,"[' Kitty had left the door ajar, and Walter stood at it watching us, his eyes as wide as if he had had some sort of fright.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1041,"["" I felt Kitty's gaze follow mine; she gripped my arm, then dropped it sharply.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1042,"["" And swearing on my bended knee, If ever I cease to love, May sheep's heads grow on apple trees, While I still wondered, Walter spoke.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1043,"[' Instead he broke into a great beaming smile, and slapped his hands together, and stepped into the room to seize us both excitedly by the shoulders.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1045,"[""' May the moon be turned into green cheese, If ever I cease to love.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1046,"[""' We laughed, then sang louder.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1047,"[' I found a hat in the hamper, and tossed it to Kitty, then pulled out a jacket and a boater for myself, and a walking-cane.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1049,"["" 'For all the money that's in the bank, For the title of lord or duke, 125 126 A; first, the prospect of joining Kitty upon the stage, in a profession for which I had never been trained, never yearned, and had - as I thought - no special talent, filled me with dismay.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1050,"[' She looked from me to Walter, then back to me again, and narrowed her eyes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1051,"["" 'It might work,' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1052,"["" 'No,' I said to Walter that afternoon, when at last I understood him.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1053,"[' You, of all people, should know what a fool I would make of myself - and of Kitty!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1054,"[""' I stamped my foot.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1055,[' Four months ago I was an oyster-girl in Whitstable!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1056,"[""' But Walter wouldn't listen.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1057,[' It will be a sensation!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1058,"[""' 'Four months before Bessie Bellwood made her debut,' Walter replied, .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1059,"[""'she was a rabbit-skinner in the New Cut!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1060,['1 He put his hand upon my arm.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1061,"["" 'Nan,' he said kindly, 'I am not pressing you, but let us see if this thing will work, at least.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1062,"["" And then we'll see what the two of you look like, side by side.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1063,"[""' 'It might be a sensation,' I said, 'with two Kitty Butlers in it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1064,"["" But Kitty Butler and Nancy Astley, her dresser, who never sang a song in her life -' I turned to Kitty.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1065,"[' It seems strange to think that, in all my weeks of handling so many lovely costumes, I had never thought to try one on myself; but I had not.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1066,"["" The piece of sport with the jacket and the boater had been a novel one, born of the gaiety of that marvellous morning; until then Kitty's suits had seemed too handsome, too special - above all, too peculiarly hers, too fundamental to her own particular magic and swank - for me to fool with.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1067,"[' Now I found myself half-naked in our chilly bedroom, with Kitty beside me with a costume in her hand, and our roles quite reversed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1068,"["" Kitty had found a morning-suit of black and grey for me to wear, and 'We have all heard you sing,' said Walter, 'a thousand times - and very prettily, too.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1069,"[""' 'Who never danced -' I went on.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1070,[' Any fool with half a leg can do it.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1071,"[""' 'Who never raised her voice before a crowd -' 'Patter!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1072,"[""' he said carelessly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1073,"["" 'Kitty,' I said now, 'for goodness' sake, tell him what madness he is talking!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1074,"[""' 127 128 had a similar costume ready for herself.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1075,"["" 'You must take your drawers off,' she said quietly - the door was shut fast, but Walter was audibly pacing the little parlour beyond it - 'or else they'll bunch, beneath the trousers.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1076,"[""' I blushed, then slid the drawers down my thighs and kicked them off, so that I stood clad only in the shirt and a pair of stockings, gartered at the knee.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1077,"["" That, however, had been many years before; it was quite different, now, to pull Kitty's handsome trousers up my naked hips, and button them over that delicate place that Kitty herself had so recently set smarting.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1078,[' That thought - and the soundless kiss which followed it - made the trousers feel still stranger.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1079,"[' When Kitty stepped away to see to her own suit, I looked at her a little wonderingly.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1080,"["" I said, 'How can you dress like this, before a hall of strangers, every night, and not feel queer?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1081,"[""' She fastened the clip of her braces, and shrugged.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1082,"["" I meant - well, if I were to be beside you, in these' - I took another couple of steps - 'oh Kitty, I don't think I should be able to keep from kissing you!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1083,"[""' She put a finger to her lips; then pushed at the fringe of her hair.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1084,"["" She said, 'You will have to get used to it, for Walter's plan to work.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1085,"["" I said, 'It won't do, will it, Kitty?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1086,"[' He had us stand together, with our arms linked; then he made us turn, and do again the little stiff-legged dance that he had caught us at before.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1087,"[' And all the time he walked about us with narrowed eyes, stroking his chin and nodding.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1088,"["" 'We shall need a suit for you, of course,' he said to me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1089,[' But that we can easily arrange.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1090,"[""' He took my hat from my head, and my plait fell down upon my shoulder.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1091,"["" 'Something must he done about your hair; but the colour, at least, is perfect - a wonderful contrast with Kitty's, so the folk in the gallery will have no trouble telling you apart.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1092,"[""' He winked, then stood surveying me a little longer with his hands behind his head.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1093,"["" I said, 'You really mean it, Walter?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1094,"[""' and he nodded: 'Nancy, I do.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1095,"[""' 129 130 He kept us busy, that day, all through the afternoon.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1096,"["" The house being empty, we worked at Mrs Dendy's piano, quite as hard as if it were a weekday morning - except that now I sang too, and not to save Kitty's voice, as I had sometimes done before, but to try out my own alongside it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1097,"["" We sang again the song that Walter had caught us singing, 'If Ever I Cease to Love' - but, of course, we were self-conscious now, and it sounded terribly lame.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1098,"["" Then we tried some of Kitty's songs, that I had heard her sing at Canterbury and knew by heart; and they went a little better.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1099,"[' And finally we tried a new song, one of the West End songs that were fashionable then - the one about strolling through Piccadilly with a pocket so full of sovereigns all the ladies look, and smile, and wink their eyes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1100,"["" It is sung by mashers even now; but it was Kitty and I who had it first, and when we tried it out together that afternoon - changing the author's T to 'we', linking our arms, and promenading over the parlour-rug with our voices raised in a harmony -well, it sounded sweeter and more comical than I could have thought possible.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1101,"[' I looked at Kitty and remembered that I had another, more pressing, reason to be gay and giddy, and I began to wish that Walter would leave us.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1102,"[' So very soon he did leave; and when the door was closed on him I rose and went to Kitty, and put my arms about her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1103,"["" She wouldn't let me kiss her in the parlour; but after a moment she led me up through the darkening house, back to our bedroom.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1104,"[' Here the suit - which I had, indeed, grown rather used to while strolling in it for Walter - began to feel strange again.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1105,[' When Kitty undressed I pulled her to me; and it was lewd to feel her naked hip come pressing in between my trousered legs.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1106,"[' She ran her hand once, very lightly, over my buttons, until I began to shake with the wanting of her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1107,"["" We lay until the front door slammed, and we heard Mrs Dendy's cough, and Tootsie laughing on the stair.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1108,"[' Then Kitty said we should rise, and dress, or the others might wonder; and for the second time that day I lay and watched her wash, and pull on stockings and a skirt, through lazy eyes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1109,"[' Kitty heard, and saw my stricken face, and came to me; then she moved my hand away and placed her lips, very softly, over my heart.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1110,"["" We did not see Walter, and there was no more talk about his plan to put me on the stage at Kitty's side until two 131 132 evenings later, when he arrived at Mrs Dendy's with a parcel, marked Nan Astley.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1111,"["" 'To their new partnership, that will bring fame and fortune to us all in 1889, and ever after!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1112,"[""' We were at the parlour-table with Ma Dendy and the Professor, and now we joined our voices with his, and took up his toast; but Kitty and I exchanged one swift, secret glance, and I thought - with a little thrill of pleasure and triumph that I couldn't quite suppress - poor man!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1113,"["" But I knew already that it would hold: a suit, a stage suit of serge and velvet, cut to my size to the pattern of one of Kitty's - but blue to match my eyes, where hers was brown.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1114,"["" Just you trot upstairs and slip that on, and then we'll see what Mrs Dendy has to say about it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1115,"[""' I did as he asked; then paused for a moment to study myself in the glass.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1116,"[' I looked a little like my brother Davy - only, perhaps, rather handsomer.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1117,"[' Four nights before I had stood in the same spot, marvelling to see myself dressed as a grown-up woman.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1118,"[' When I stood turning upon the rug, however, Walter was rather subdued, and Mrs Bendy thoughtful.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1119,"["" When, at their request, I took Kitty's arm and we sang a quick chorus, Walter stood back, frowned, and shook his head.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1120,"["" 'It grieves me to say it, but - it just won't do.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1121,"[""' I turned, in dismay, to Kitty.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1122,"["" She said, There is something queer about it; but I can't say what.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1123,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1124,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1125,"['"" I gazed down at myself.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1126,"[' I took my hands from my pockets and folded my arms, and Walter shook his head again.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1127,"["" Take a step,' she said to me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1128,"["" 'She's too real,' she said at last, to Walter.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1129,[' She looks like a boy.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1130,"[' Which I know she is supposed to - but, if you follow me, she looks like a real boy.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1131,[' I looked at Kitty and she gave a nervous kind of laugh.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1132,"["" Walter, however, had lost his frown, and his eyes looked blue and wide as a child's.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1133,"["" 133 134 'Damn it, Ma,' he said, 'but you're right!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1134,"[""' He put his hand to his brow, then stepped to the door: we heard his heavy, rapid tread upon the stairs, heard footsteps in the room above our heads -Sims's and Percy's room - and then the slam of a door, higher up.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1135,"["" When he returned he held a strange assortment of objects: a pair of gentleman's shoes, a sewing-basket, a couple of ribbons, and Kitty's make-up box.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1136,"["" The jacket he handed to Kitty, along with the sewing-basket: 'Put a few tucks down the inside of that waist,' he said, pointing to the seam.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1138,"["" Next he seized my head and tilted it back, and worked upon my lips and lashes with carmine and spit-black from Kitty's box: he did this gently as a girl.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1139,[' Finally he turned to Kitty and snapped his fingers.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1140,"["" My new shoes looked quaint and girlish, like a principal boy's in a pantomime.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1141,"[' The jacket flared a little, above and below the waist, quite as if I had hips and a bosom - but it felt tighter than before, and not a half as comfortable.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1142,"["" My face, of course, I could not see: I had to turn and squint into a picture over the hearth, and saw it reflected there - all eyes and lips - over the red nose and whiskers of 'Rackity Jack'.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1143,"[' Kitty did not look at all nervous, now.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1144,"[' The very next day Walter sent my costume to a seamstress, and had it properly re-sewn; within a week he had borrowed a hall and a band from a manager who owed him a favour, and had Kitty and I, in our matching suits, practising upon the stage.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1145,"["" It was not at all like singing in Mrs Dendy's parlour.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1146,"[' The strangers, the dark and empty hall, disconcerted me; I was still and awkward, quite unable to master the few simple strolling steps that Kitty and Walter tried patiently to teach me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1147,"[' At last Walter handed me a cane, and said I should just stand and lean upon it, and let Kitty dance; and that was better, and I grew easier, and the song began to sound funny again.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1148,"[' Kitty sat and took a cup of tea, then; but Walter led me off to a seat in the stalls, away from the others, and looked grave.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1149,"["" 135 136 'Nan,' he began, 'I told you when all this started that I would not press you, and I meant it; I would give up the business altogether before I forced a girl upon the stage against her will.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1150,"["" He'll find space for you in his programme; and if they like you, he'll keep you there.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1151,"[""' Tonight.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1152,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1153,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1154,"['"" I looked at Walter in dismay.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1155,"[' I thought of the hall, hot and bright and filled with jeering faces.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1156,"["" Haven't you worked, these past six months - harder than Kitty, almost?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1157,"["" He said: 'You know, of course, that we cannot throw over the idea of the double act, now that we have hit upon it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1158,"["" If you don't wish to partner Kitty, there'll be some other girl who does.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1159,"["" You mustn't feel that you are letting Kitty down 'I don't know,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1160,"["" All my life I've loved the music hall, but I never thought of getting up upon the stage, myself.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1161,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1162,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1163,"['"" \'Didn\'t you?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1164,"[""' he said then.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1165,"["" 'Didn't you, really?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1166,"[""' Every time you saw some little serio-comic captivate the crowd, at that Palace of yours, in Canterbury, didn't you wish that it was you?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1168,"[""' I looked from him to the stage, where Kitty herself sat on the edge of a beam of limelight, sipping at her cup, swinging her legs, and smiling at some word of the conductor's.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1169,"["" The thought that she might take another partner - might stroll before the footlights with another girl's arm through hers, another girl's voice rising and blending with her own - had not occurred to me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1170,"["" 'The very stuff thai stages are made of.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1171,"[""' 'Where would we start?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1172,"[""' I said then.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1173,"["" 'Who would offer us a spot?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1174,"[""' So when Kitty stood in the wing of the theatre that night, waiting for the chairman's cry, I stood beside her, sweating beneath a layer of grease-paint, biting my lips so hard I thought they would bleed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1175,"["" Kitty said once, very low, 'I love you!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1176,"[""' - and I felt myself half-pulled, half-thrust beneath the rising curtain, and knew that I must somehow saunter and sing.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1177,"["" When at last I stepped for a second out of the glare of lime, and saw all the faces that were turned my way, I almost faltered and lost my place - and would have done, I think, had not Kitty at that moment pressed my arm and murmured, 'We have them!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1178,"[' At once, I remembered the foolish dance that I had failed, all day, to learn, and left off leaning on my stick to join Kitty in her stroll before the footlights.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1179,"[' I understood, too, what Walter had wanted of us in the wing: as the new song drew to a close I advanced with Kitty to the front of the stage, drew out the coins that he had tipped into my pocket - they were only chocolate sovereigns, of course, but covered in foil to make them glitter - and cast them into the laughing crowd.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1180,[' The next act - a couple of trick- cyclists - was pushed hurriedly on to take our place; but even at the end of their set there were still one or two voices calling for us.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1181,"["" Back stage, with Kitty's lips upon my cheek, Walter's arm about my shoulders, and exclamations of delight and praise greeting me from every corner, I stood quite stunned, unable either to smile at the compliments or modestly disclaim them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1182,"["" The hair I had barbered at a house in Battersea, by the same theatrical hairdresser who cut Kitty's.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1184,"["" For our debut at Camberwell we had thought that our ordinary names would do as well as any, and had been billed by the chairman as 'Kitty Butler and Nancy Astley'.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1185,"["" Now, however, we were a hit: Walter's manager friend had offered us a four-week contract, and needed to know the names he should have printed on the posters.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1186,"["" We knew we must keep Kitty's, for the sake of her successes of the past half-year; but Walter said 'Astley' was rather too common, and could we think of a better one?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1187,"["" I didn't mind, only said I should like to keep 'Nan' -since Kitty herself had re- christened me that; and we took our lunch, in consequence, with everybody volunteering names they thought would match it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1188,"["" Tootsie said 'Nan Love', Sims 'Nan Sergeant'.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1189,"["" Percy said, 'Nan Scarlet - no, Nan Silver - no, Nan Gold .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1190,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1191,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1192,"['"" Every name seemed to offer me some new and marvellous version of myself; it was like standing at the costumier\'s rail and shrugging on the jackets.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1193,"["" He had not clipped the hair as short as Kitty's, but had left it long and falling, Bohemian-like, quite to my collar; and here, without the weight of the plait to pull it flat and lank, it sprang into a slight, surprising curl.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1194,[' When I fingered them - when I turned and tilted my head -I felt my cheeks grow crimson.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1195,"["" The man said then, 'You see, you will find it queer,' and he showed me how I might wear my severed plait, as Kitty wore hers, to disguise his barbering.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1196,"[' I had blushed because - just as I had done when I first pulled on a pair of trousers - I had felt myself stir, and grow warm, and want Kitty.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1197,"["" None, however, seemed to fit - till the Professor tapped the table, cleared his throat, and said: 'Nan King'.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1198,"["" And although I should like to be able to say - as other artistes do - that there was some terribly clever or romantic story behind the choosing of my stage-name - that we had opened a special book at a certain place, and found it there; that I had heard the word 'King' said in a dream, and quivered at it - I can give no better account of the matter than the truth: which was only that we needed a name, and the Professor said 'Nan King', and I liked it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1199,"["" 'That's more like it,' she said, when I stood and brushed my skirts down.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1200,"["" 'What a fright you looked in short hair and a frock!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1201,"[""' Back at Ginevra Road we found Walter waiting for us, and Mrs Dendy dishing up lunch; and it was here that I was given a new name, to match my bold new crop.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1202,"["" It was as 'Kitty Butler and Nan King', therefore, that we returned to Camberwell that evening - to renew, and improve upon our success of the night before.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1203,"[' It may just have been, as Walter had foreseen, that we were novel: for though in later years we were rather freely imitated, there was certainly no other act like ours in the London halls in 1889.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1204,"[' We did, I know, go handsomely together - Kitty with her nut-brown crop, me with my head blonde and smooth and gleaming; she raised a little on her one-inch slippers, me in my flat effeminate shoes, my cleverly tailored suits that masked the slender angularity of my frame with girlish curves.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1205,"["" Our wages rose; we worked three halls a night - four, sometimes - and now, when our brougham was caught in traffic, our driver would yell, 'I've got Kitty Butler and Nan King in here, due at the Royal, Holborn, in fifteen minutes!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1206,"["" Clear a way there, can't you?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1207,"[""' -and the other drivers would shift a little to let us through, and smile and raise their hats to the windows as we passed!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1208,"[' It took me weeks to understand that it was really happening, and to me; weeks to let myself believe in it, and to trust the crowd that liked me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1209,"[' I had been content till now to stand in the wings, looking on while Kitty dallied, in the lime-light, with the vast, rumbustious crowd.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1210,"[' I had kept my promise: I never kissed her, touched her, said a loving thing, when there was anyone to glimpse or overhear us.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1211,"[' How could it be easy to stand cool and distant from her in the day, when we had spent all night with our naked limbs pressed hot and close together?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1212,"[' How could it be easy to veil my glances when others watched, bite my tongue because others listened, when I passed all our private hours gazing at her till my eyes ached of it, calling her every kind of sweet name until my throat was dry?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1213,"["" Sitting beside her at supper at Mrs Dendy's, standing near her in the green-room of a theatre, walking with her through the city streets, I felt as though I was bound and fettered with iron bands, chained and muzzled and blinkered.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1214,"[' Kitty had given me leave to love her; the world, she said, would never let me be anything to her except her friend.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1215,"[' You will not believe me, but making love to Kitty - a thing done in passion, but always, too, in shadow and in silence, and with an ear half-cocked for the sound of footsteps on the stairs - making love to Kitty, and posing at her side in a shaft of limelight, before a thousand pairs of eyes, to a script I knew by heart, in an attitude I had laboured for hours to perfect - these things were not so very different.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1216,"[' A double act is always twice the act the audience thinks it: beyond our songs, our steps, our bits of business with coins and canes and flowers, there was a private language, in which we held an endless, delicate exchange of which the crowd knew nothing.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1218,"["" As Kitty had said, when I had whispered that wearing trousers upon the stage would only make me want to kiss her: 'What a show that would be!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1219,"[""' But, that was our show; only the crowd never knew it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1220,"[' They looked on, and saw another turn entirely.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1221,"[' These girls sent letters - letters, like their stage door manners, full of curious excesses or ellipses; letters that awed, repelled and drew me, all at once.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1222,"["" 'I hope you will forgive my writing to say that you are very handsome,' wrote one girl; another wrote: 'Miss King, I am 145 146 in love with you!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1223,"[""' Someone named Ada King wrote to ask if we were cousins.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1224,"["" She said: 'I do so admire you and Miss Butler, but especially you.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1225,"[' I would like to have a picture of you, beside my bed .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1226,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1227,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1228,"['"" The card I sent her was a favourite of mine, a picture of Kitty and me in Oxford bags and boaters, in which Kitty stood with her hands in her pockets and I leaned with my arm through hers, a cigarette between my fingers.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1229,"[' I signed it \'To Ada, from one ""King"" to another""; and it was very odd to think that it would be pinned to a wall, or put in a frame, so that unknown girl might gaze at it while she fastened her frock or lay dreaming.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1230,"["" 'Throw them away,' Kitty would say when I showed her these letters.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1231,"["" 'They're cracked, those girls, and you mustn't encourage them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1232,"[""' But I knew that the girls were not cracked, as she said; they were only as I had been, a year before - but braver or more reckless.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1233,"[' That, in itself, impressed me; what astonished and thrilled me now was the thought that girls might look at me at all - the thought that in every darkened hall there might be one or two female hearts that beat exclusively for me, one or two pairs of eyes that lingered, perhaps immodestly, over my face and figure and suit.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1234,"[' Above all, when they saw me stride across the stage in trousers, singing of girls whose eyes I had sent winking, whose hearts I had broken, what did they see?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1235,"["" 'They had better not!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1236,"[""' said Kitty, when I put my idea to her; and though she laughed as she said it, the laughter was a little strained.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1237,"["" She didn't like it, either, when one night in the change-room of a theatre we met a pair of women - a comic singer and her dresser - who, I thought, were rather like ourselves.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1238,"[' Her maid was an older woman in a plain brown dress; I saw her tugging at the frock, and thought nothing of it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1239,"["" But when she had the hooks fastened tight, she leaned and gently blew upon the singer's throat, where the power had clogged; and then she whispered something to her, and they laughed together with their heads very close .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1240,"[' and I knew, as surely as if they had pasted the words upon the dressing-room wall, that they were lovers.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1241,"[' I looked at Kitty, and saw that she had caught the gesture, too; her eyes, however, were lowered, and her mouth was tight.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1242,"["" When the comic singer passed us on her way to the stage, she gave me a wink: 'Off to please the public,' she said, and her dresser laughed again.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1243,"[' When she came back and took her make-up off, she wandered over with a cigarette and asked for a light; then, as she drew on her fag, she looked me over.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1244,[' You come along with Ella and me: you and your friend.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1245,"[""' Here she nodded - 147 148 very pleasantly, I thought - to Kitty.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1246,"[' But Kitty, who had had her head bent all this time, working at the fastenings of her skirt, now looked up and gave a prim little smile.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1247,"["" 'How nice of you to ask,' she said; 'but we are spoken for tonight.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1248,"["" 'You don't want to leave your pal to her agent, and come on alone, with me and Ella?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1249,"[""' 'Miss King will be busy with Mr Bliss,' said Kitty, before I could answer; and she said it so tightly the singer gave a sniff, then turned and went over to where her dresser waited with their baskets.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1250,"[' When we returned to the theatre the next night, Kitty chose a hook that was far from theirs; and on the night after that, they had moved on to another hall.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1251,"[' At home, in bed, I said I thought it was a shame.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1252,"["" 'Why did you tell them Walter was coming?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1253,"[""' I asked Kitty.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1254,[' They were - like us.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1255,"[""' I had my arm about her, and felt her stiffen at my words.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1256,[' She pulled away from me and raised her head.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1257,"[' We had left a candle burning and her face, I saw, was white and shocked.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1258,"[' Now, when Kitty said it, she flinched.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1259,"["" We're not like that!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1260,"[""' 'Aren't we?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1261,"[""' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1262,"["" I'd give up the stage in a flash.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1263,"[""' I tried to pull her to me again, but she knocked my hand away.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1265,"[""' But what were we like?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1266,"["" We're just - ourselves.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1267,"[""' 'But if we're just ourselves, why do we have to hide it?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1268,"[""' 'Because no one would know the difference between us and - women like that!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1269,"[""' I laughed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1270,"["" 'It's the same thing,' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1271,"[' Then she fell back upon her pillow and closed her eyes, and turned her face away.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1272,"[' I touched her cheek, and moved a little closer to her; then I took my hand from her face and passed it, hesitantly, down her night-dress, over 149 150 her breasts and belly.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1273,"[' She moved away, and I slowed - but did not stop - my searching fingers; and soon, as if despite itself, I felt her body slacken in assent.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1274,"["" I said, 'Oh Kitty, how can this be wrong?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1275,"[""' But she did not answer, only moved her lips to mine at last, and when I felt the tug of her kiss I let my weight fall heavily upon her, and gave a sigh.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1276,"["" It was true, I suppose, what she said - that I didn't understand her.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1277,"[' The next day, while Kitty still slept, I rose and made my noiseless way into our parlour.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1278,"["" I had told them, once, that I had joined the act; but I had rather played the matter down - I feared they wouldn't think the life a decent one for their own daughter.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1279,"[' They had sent me back a brief, half-hearted, puzzled note; they had talked of travelling to London, to reassure themselves that I was quite content - and at that I had written at once to say, they must not think of coming, I was too busy, my rooms were too small.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1280,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1281,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1282,"[' I wrote to tell her what had happened between Kitty and me - to tell her that we loved each other, not as friends, but as sweethearts; that we had made our lives together; and that she must be glad for me, for I was happier than I had ever thought it possible to be.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1283,"[' This came a few days later - came while Kitty and I were at breakfast, and had to stay unopened in my pocket until I could make time to be alone and read it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1284,"[' It was, I saw at once, very neat; and knowing Alice to be no great pen woman, I guessed that this must be the last of several versions.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1285,"["" 'Your letter was both a shock to me and no surprise at all, for I have been expecting to receive something very like it 151 152 from you, since the day you left us.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1286,"["" Of the latter, we acquired so many that we found we couldn't manage them without help, and took on a girl to do my old job - to mend the suits and to help us dress in them, at the side of the stage.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1287,"["" At the Star, in Bermondsey, Kitty had started on a couple of pounds a week, and I had thought my own, small dresser's share of that quite grand enough.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1288,"[' He negotiated our contracts, our publicity, and held our money for us; he paid Kitty and she, as before, gave me whatever little cash I needed, when I asked her for it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1289,"["" Father, Mother and Davy know nothing of this, and won't from my lips, since I would rather die of shame than tell them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1290,"["" 'Alice.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1291,"[""' She must have kept her word about not telling our parents, for their letters to me continued as before - still cautious, still rather fretful, but still kind.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1292,"[' But now I got even less pleasure from them; only kept thinking, What would they write, if they knew?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1293,"[' It was rather strange with Walter, now that Kitty and I had grown so close.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1294,"["" We saw him quite as often as we had before; we still went driving with him; we still spent long hours with him at Mrs Dendy's piano (though the piano 153 154 itself had been changed, to a more expensive one).""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1295,"["" He was as kind and as foolish as ever - but a little dimmed, somehow, a little shadowy, now that the blaze of Kitty's charms was more decidedly turned my way.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1297,"[' It was on the Saturday night of the second week that the trouble came - on a Saturday night at the end of September, a night of fog - one of those grey-brown evenings, when all the streets and buildings of the city seem to waver a little at the edges.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1298,"["" A van had overturned; a dozen boys had rushed to sit upon the horse's head, to stop the beast from rising; and our own carriage could not pass for half an hour or more.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1299,"[' Some poor artiste had been sent on to sing a comic song and keep them occupied, but they had started to heckle him quite mercilessly; at last - the fellow had begun a clog dance - two roughs had jumped upon the stage and pulled the boots from him, and tossed them up to the gallery.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1300,"[' The conductor and a couple of stage-hands had hold of the roughs, and were trying to pull them into the wings.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1301,"["" We didn't mind a rowdy crowd, as a rule, for it could be unnerving to work the prim West End theatres, where the ladies were too gentle or well-dressed to bang their hands together or to stamp, and where only the drunken swells of the promenade really whistled and shouted as a proper music-hall audience should.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1302,"[' There the crowd had been humble and gay - working-people, women with babies in their arms - the kind of audience I liked best of all, because it was the kind of which, until very recently, I had myself been a member.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1303,"["" 'If they hurl something,' she said quickly, 'we'll duck.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1304,"[""' Then she took a step, and nodded for me to follow.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1305,"["" 'Wot cheer, Kitty?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1306,"[""' someone shouted, as we danced our way into the beam of the limes.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1307,"["" 'Did you lose your way in the fog, then, or what?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1308,"[""' 'Shocking awful traffic,' she called back - the first verse was about to begin, and she was slipping further into character with every step she took - 'but not so bad as a road my friend and I were a-walking on the other afternoon.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1309,"[' Kitty looked at me, then nodded.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1310,"["" 'He's right,' she said to Walter.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1311,"[' Then, to the manager: Tell them to put our number up.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1312,"[""' The manager pocketed his handkerchief and stepped smartly away before she could change her mind; but Walter still looked grave.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1313,"[' Walter kept his distance, but clasped his hands together before his chest when we emerged, and shook them, in a gesture of triumph.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1314,"["" Our second number - a song called 'Scarlet Fever', for which we dressed in guardsmen's uniforms (red jackets and caps, white belts, black trousers, very smart) - went down a treat; it was during the next routine that all turned sour.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1315,"["" There was a man in the stalls: I had noticed him earlier, for he was large, and clearly very drunk; he slept noisily in his seat, with his knees spread wide, his mouth open and his 'You don't have to do it,' Walter went on.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1316,"[' Now he stood, peering up at us, with his hands over his eyes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1317,"[' A few people turned away from us to look at him, and to titter or tut-tut.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1318,"[' I exchanged a glance with Kitty, but kept my voice and steps in time with hers, my eyes still bright, my smile still broad.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1319,"[' I caught her eye, and tipped my hat - it was a boater; we were wearing the Oxford bags and boaters, now - and saw her blush.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1320,"[' A boy stepped up to him, but was knocked away; I saw the fellows in the orchestra begin to gaze a little wildly over the tops of their instruments.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1321,"[' Half a dozen hands waved and pointed to where the man leaned over the footlights, his whiskers fluttering in the heat.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1322,"[' I suppressed an urge to dance up to him and stamp upon his wrist (for, apart from anything else, I thought he was quite capable of seizing my ankle and dragging me into the stalls.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1323,"[') Instead, I took my cue from Kitty.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1324,"[' At any moment, I thought, she would slow the song, launch into the man, or call for the door-men to come and remove him.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1325,"["" Why, they're nothing but a couple of- a couple of tomsl' He put the whole force of his voice into it - the word that Kitty had once whispered to me, flinching and shuddering as she said it!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1326,"["" It sounded louder at that moment than the blast of a cornet - seemed to bounce from one wall of the hall to another, like a bullet from a sharp-shooter's act gone wrong.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1327,"[' Kitty shifted, then seemed to see for the first time that our arms were joined.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1328,"[' Then she put her hand to her eyes and stepped, with her head bowed, into the wing.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1329,[' Kitty had run to Walter: he had his arm about her shoulders and looked grave.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1330,"[' A knot of stage-hands and fly-men looked on, whispering amongst themselves.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1331,"[' I stepped up to Kitty and reached for her arm; she flinched as if I had raised my hand to strike her, and instantly I fell back.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1332,"["" I should like to know why a drunken fool is allowed to interfere with Miss Butler's performance for ten minutes, while your men gather their scattered wits together, and make up their minds to remove him.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1333,"[""' But the melody affected neither Kitty nor the audience.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1334,"[' Two girls in suits, their hair close-clipped, their arms entwined.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1335,"["" I didn't listen to it, only looked at Kitty.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1336,"[' Finally Walter gave a snort, and waved the blustering manager away.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1337,"["" He said, 'Nan, I am taking Kitty home, at once.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1338,[' I should like to get Kitty back to Ginevra Road as swiftly as possible.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1339,"[""' I hesitated, then looked at Kitty again.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1340,"["" Walter took up his cloak, and - though it was far too large for her, and trailed upon the dusty floor - he placed it over Kitty's slender shoulders.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1341,"[' She clasped it tight at the throat, then let him usher her away, past the angry manager and the knot of whispering boys.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1342,"["" By the time I reached Ginevra Road - after having gathered our boxes and bags together at Deacon's, and delivered Flora to her own house in Lambeth - Walter had gone, our rooms were dark, and Kitty was in bed, apparently asleep.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1343,"[' Instead, I simply undressed, and lay close beside her, and placed my hand upon her heart -which beat on, very fiercely, through her dreams.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1344,"["" The disastrous night at Deacon's brought changes with it, and made some things a little strange.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1345,"[' Kitty became choosier about the theatres we worked at; she began to question Walter, too, about the other acts that we must share the bills with.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1346,"[' I thought the act was a good one; but when Kitty saw him work, she made us cancel.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1347,"["" I have spoken of the curious dimming of Walter's brightness, of the subtle new distance that had grown between us, since Kitty and I had become sweethearts.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1348,"["" He remained kind, but his kindness was tempered by a surprising kind of stiffness; in Kitty's presence, in particular, he grew easily flustered and self-conscious - and then jolly, with a horrible, forced kind of jolliness, as if ashamed of himself for being so awkward.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1349,"[' At last we saw him only to rehearse new songs, or in the company of the other artistes we sometimes took supper or drinks with.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1350,"["" I missed him, and wondered at his change of heart - but didn't wonder very hard, I must confess, because I thought I knew what had caused it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1351,"["" That night at Islington he had learned the truth at last - had heard that drunken man's shout, seen Kitty's terrible, terrified response, and understood.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1352,"[' He had driven her home - I did not know what had passed between them then, for neither of them seemed 163 164 at all inclined to discuss any part of that dreadful evening - he had driven her home, but that tender gesture of his, to place his cloak about her trembling shoulders and see her safely to her door, had been his last.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1353,"["" Had we remained very long at Mrs Dendy's house, I think our friends there would have noticed Walter's absence, and quizzed us over it; but at the end of September came the biggest change of all.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1354,"[' We said good-bye to our landlady and Ginevra Road, and moved.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1355,"[' It was the house in which we had first kissed, first declared our love; it was, I thought, our honeymoon house - and for all that it was so cramped and plain, for all that our costumes now took up more space in the bedroom than our bed, I was terribly loath to leave it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1356,"[' But Kitty said it looked queer, us still sharing a room, and a bed, when we had the money to live somewhere ten times the size; and she had a house agent look about for rooms for us, somewhere more seemly.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1357,"[' It was to Stamford Hill that we moved, in the end - Stamford Hill, far across the river, in a bit of London I hardly knew (and thought, privately, a little dull).']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1358,"[' We had a farewell supper at Ginevra Road, with everyone saying how sorry they were to see us go - Mrs Dendy herself even wept a little, and said her house would never be the same.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1359,"[' Sims and Percy were doing well, and planned to take our rooms when we had left them; but Percy had found a sweetheart, too, and the girl made quarrels between them -I learned later that they split the act, and found spots as minstrels in rival troupes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1360,"["" It's the way of theatrical houses, I suppose, to break up and refashion themselves; but I was almost sadder, on my last day at Ginevra Road, than I had been on leaving Whitstable.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1361,"[' I sat in the parlour - my portrait was upon the wall, now, along with all the others - and thought how much had changed since I had sat there first, a little less than thirteen months before; and for a moment I wondered if all the changes had been good ones, and wished that I could be plain Nancy Astley again, whom Kitty Butler loved with an ordinary love she was not afraid to show to all the world.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1362,"[' Our neighbours, I think, were city men; their wives stayed at home all day, and their children had nurses, who wheeled them, puffing, up and down the garden steps in great iron perambulators.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1363,"[' We had the top two floors of a house close to the station; our landlady and her husband lived beneath us, but they were not connected to the business, and we rarely saw them.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1364,"[' There were three 165 166 bedrooms, and one of them was mine - which meant only, of course, that I kept my dresses in its closet, my brushes and combs upon its wash-hand stand, and my nightgown beneath the pillow of its bed-this was for the sake of the girl who came to clean for us, three days a week.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1365,"["" My nights were really spent in Kitty's chamber, the great front bedroom with its great high bed that the house-builders had meant for a husband and wife.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1366,"["" For though we were at liberty at last to be as saucy and as clamorous as we chose, we found we couldn't break ourselves of our old habits: we still whispered our love, and kissed beneath the counterpane, noiselessly, like mice.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1367,"[' We were working six nights a week now, and there was no Sims and Percy and Tootsie to keep us lively after shows; often we would arrive back at Stamford Hill so weary we would simply fall into the bed and snore.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1368,[' By November we were both so tired Walter said we must take a holiday.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1369,"[' The pantomime was Cinderella, and Kitty and I were wanted for the First and Second Boy roles; and the offer was too flattering to resist.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1370,"["" My music-hall career, though brief enough, had been a happy one; but I do not think that I was ever so content as I was that winter, playing Dandini to Kitty's Prince, at the Britannia.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1371,"[' Your dressing-room is large and private and warm - for you are really expected to change and make-up in it, not arrive, breathless, at the stage door, having buttoned on your costume in your brougham.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1372,"[' You are handed lines to speak, and you speak them, steps to take, and you take them, costumes to wear - the most wonderful costumes you ever saw in your life, costumes of fur and satin and velvet - and you wear them, then pass them back to the wardrobe- mistress and let her worry about mending them and keeping them neat.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1373,"["" The title role was taken by Dolly Arnold -a lovely girl with a voice like a linnet's, and a waist so slim her trademark was to wear a necklace as a belt.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1374,"[' It was rather odd to see Kitty spooning with her upon the stage, kissing her while the clock showed a minute-to- midnight - though it was odder still, perhaps, to think that 167 168 no one in the audience called out Toms!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1375,"[' now, or even appeared to think it: they only cheered when the Prince and Cinderella were united at the end, and drawn on stage, by half-a-dozen pygmy horses, in their wedding-car.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1378,"["" Standing at Kitty's side while the fountains played, the fairies swooped, and the pigmy horses pranced and trotted, I was never sure I had not died on my way to the theatre and woken up in paradise.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1379,"[' I was only extraordinarily glad to have a place in such a business, and with my true love at my side; and everything that Kitty said or did only seemed to show that she felt just the same.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1381,"[' He was a black fellow, who had run away from a sailing family in Wapping to join a minstrel troupe; not having the voice for it, however, he had become a stage-hand instead.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1382,"[' He loved the theatre more than any of us, and spent all his hours there, playing cards with the door-men and the carpenters, hanging about in the flies, twitching ropes, turning handles.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1383,"[' He was good-looking, and Flora was very keen on him; he spent a deal of time, in consequence, at our dressing-room door, waiting to take her home after the show -and so we came to know him very well.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1384,"["" I liked him because he came from the river, and had left his family for 169 170 the theatre's sake, as I had.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1385,"[' Sometimes, in the afternoons or late at night, he and I would leave Kitty and Flora fussing over the costumes and take a stroll through the dim and silent theatre, just for the pleasure of it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1386,"[' Once or twice he led me up the great high ladders at the side of the stage, into the flies: here we would stand with our chins upon the rails, sharing a cigarette, gazing at the ash as it fluttered through the web of ropes and platforms to the boards, sixty feet below us.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1388,"["" I lifted the lid - and found Davy's map of Kent pasted on the underside, with Whitstable marked with a faded arrow, 'To show me where home was, in case I forgot.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1389,"[""' He had meant it as a joke; they had none of them thought I really would forget them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1390,"["" It was quite like being at Mrs Dendy's again, with all our friends around us - except, of course, that Walter wasn't one of them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1391,"["" He came only occasionally to the Brit, and hardly at all to Stamford Hill; when he did, I couldn't bear to see him so ill at ease, and so found business of my own to keep me occupied elsewhere, and left Kitty to deal with him.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1392,"[' She, I noticed, was as awkward and self-conscious as he when he came calling, I and seemed to prefer his letters to his person - for he sent his news to her by post, these days, so drastically had our old friendship dwindled.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1393,"["" But she said she did not mind, and I understood she didn't wish to talk of something that was painful to her.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1394,"[' I knew it must be very hard for her, to think that Walter had guessed her secret, and hated it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1395,[' Not tears?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1396,"[""' 'I thought of home,' I said, between my sobs, 'and wanted to go there, suddenly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1397,"[""' She touched my cheek, then put her fingers to her lips and licked them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1398,"["" I'm amazed you have managed to survive this long away from the sea, without shrivelling up like a bit of old seaweed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1399,[' I should never have taken you away from Whitstable Bay.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1400,[' Miss Mermaid .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1401,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1402,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1403,"['"" - 7 171 172 I smiled, at last, to hear her use a name I thought she had forgotten; then I sighed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1404,"["" 'I would like to go back,' I said, 'for a day or two .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1405,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1406,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1407,"['"" Urged on by Kitty - for she had grown suddenly gallant about letting me go - I took my chance.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1408,"[' I wrote to Mother and told her that, if I was still welcome, I should be home the following day - that was Sunday - and would stay till Wednesday night.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1409,"[' Then I went shopping, to buy presents for the family: there was something thrilling after all, I found, about the idea of returning to Whitstable after so long, with a parcel of gifts from London .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1410,[' I shall die without you!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1411,"[""' She laughed, and looked away; and I guessed that she was only partly joking, for in all the months that we had spent together, we had not been separated for so much as a night.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1412,[' She raised her hands to hold my face; but again she turned her gaze away.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1413,"["" 'You won't be lonely here?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1414,"[""' 'You must go,' she said, 'if it makes you sad like this.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1415,[' I expect you will come back and find me dead from loneliness!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1416,"[""' 'I shall hate it too,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1417,"["" 'And anyway, I shan't be able to go until we close at Hoxton - and that is weeks away.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1418,"[""' She nodded, and looked thoughtful.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1419,"["" We might catch a later train -' 'No, Nan; you should see your family without me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1420,"[""' It was weeks away, for Cinderella was not due to finish until Easter; in the middle of February, however, I found myself suddenly and unexpectedly at liberty.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1421,"[' There were always fires in theatres in those days - halls were regularly being burned to the ground, then built up again, better than before, and no one thought anything of it; and the fire at the Brit had been small enough, and no one got injured.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1422,"[' But the theatre had had to be evacuated, and there had been problems with the exits; afterwards an inspector came, looked at the building, and said a new escape door must be added.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1423,"[' He closed the theatre while the work was done: tickets were returned, apologies pasted up; and for a whole half-week we found ourselves on holiday.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1424,"["" 'I shall think about you every minute.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1425,"[""' 'And I shall think of you 'Oh, Kitty .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1426,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1427,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1428,"['"" She had been tapping at her tooth with the pearl of her necklace; when I put my mouth upon hers I felt it, cold and smooth and hard, between our lips.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1429,"[' She let me kiss her, then moved her head so that our cheeks touched; then she put her arms about my waist and held me to her rather fiercely - quite as if she loved me more than anything.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1430,"[' I leaned from the carriage window to gaze at it all, and so saw Father and Davy, at the station, a moment or two before they saw me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1431,"[' Even they looked different - I 173 174 felt a rush of aching love and strange regret, to think it - Father a little older, a little shrunken, somehow; Davy slightly stouter, and redder in the face.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1432,"[' Davy, meanwhile, took my hand, then kissed my cheek through the mesh of my veil.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1433,"["" 'Just look at you,' he said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1434,"["" 'Just look at you,' he said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1435,"["" 'Just look at you,' he said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1436,"[' Father straightened, and looked me over, then gave a wide smile that seemed to pull, somewhat, at the corners of his eyes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1437,"["" 'Your mother won't know you, hardly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1438,"[""' I did indeed, I suppose, look a little dressy, but I had not thought about it until that moment.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1439,"["" All my clothes were good ones, these days, for I had long ago got rid of those girlish hand-me-downs with which I'd first left home.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1440,"["" The self-consciousness did not diminish as I walked, on Father's arm, the little distance to our oyster-shop.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1441,"[' I had expected Mother and Alice to be waiting for me; they were - but so were half-a-dozen other people, each one of whom exclaimed when I appeared, and stepped forward (except for Alice) to embrace me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1442,"["" Rhoda - still my brother's sweetheart - was there, looking perter than ever; Aunty Ro, too, had come along to welcome me back, together with her son, my cousin George, and her daughter, Liza, and Liza's baby - except that the baby was not a baby at all now, but a little boy in frills.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1443,"[' I took off my hat once all the welcomes had been said, and my heavy coat with it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1444,"["" She said, 'My goodness, Nance, how tall and fine you look!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1445,"["" I do believe you're taller, almost, than your Father.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1446,"[""' I did feel tall in that tiny, overcrowded room; but I could hardly, I thought, have really grown.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1447,"[' 175 176 Father asked after Kitty, and I said that she was well.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1448,"[' Rosina said, there had been talk that I had gone upon the stage myself -?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1449,"[' It was, I think, because the act - as I have said - was so entangled with my love: I could not bear to have them pry at it, or frown at it, or pass the idea of it on to others, carelessly .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1450,"["" It was, I suppose now, a kind of priggishaess; indeed, I hadn't been amongst them more than half-an-hour before George, my cousin, gave a cry: 'What's happened to your accent, Nance?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1451,"["" You've gone all lardy-dah.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1452,"[""' I looked at him in real surprise, then listened hard next time I spoke.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1453,"[' I sounded rather like Kitty - occasionally, even like Walter.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1454,"["" 'Your Aunty Nance will think you a real cry-baby.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1455,"[""' She took him from me, then held him near my face: 'Shake hands!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1456,"[""' She seized his arm and waved it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1457,"["" 'Shake hands with Aunty Nancy, like a proper little gent!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1458,"[""' He jerked at her hip, like some great swollen pistol that at any second might go off; but I dutifully took his fingers in my own, and squeezed them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1459,"[' I looked at Alice, and she glanced away.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1460,"["" She said, 'Nancy, you won't have heard our bit of good news.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1461,"[""' I looked at her properly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1462,"["" 'No sign of a ring on your finger yet, Nance?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1463,"[""' I saw Alice shift in her seat, and shook my head: 'Not yet, no.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1464,"[""' Father opened his mouth to speak; I could not bear, however, for the conversation to run down that particular road.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1465,"["" 'I've bought you all some things,' I said, 'from London.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1466,"[""' 177 178 There were murmurs and little interested 'Oh's at that.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1467,"["" Mother said I shouldn't have, but reached for her spectacles and looked expectant.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1468,"["" I went all around the crowded room, and finished up at Alice: 'This is for you.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1469,"[""' Her parcel - a hat, in a hat box - was the biggest.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1470,"[' She took it from me with the smallest, straightest, stiffest smile you ever saw, and began slowly and self- consciously to pull at its ribbons.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1471,"[' I sat and watched as they tore at their packages, chewing at my knuckle and smiling into my hand.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1472,"["" 'My word, Nancy,' said Father at last, 'you have done us proud.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1473,"[""' I had bought him a watch-guard, thick and bright as the one that Walter wore; he held it in his hand, and it seemed brighter than ever against the red of his palm, the faded wool of his jacket.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1474,"["" He laughed: 'I shall look quite the thing in this, now, shan't I?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1475,"[""' The laugh, however, didn't sound quite natural.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1476,"[' I thought at once - what had never occurred to me in Oxford Street - how queer they would look beside her cheap coloured perfume bottles, her jar of cold-cream, on her old chest of drawers with its chipped glass handles.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1477,"[' She caught my eye, and I saw that she had thought the same.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1478,"[' For Davy I had bought a pair of shoes, hand-sewn and soft as butter: now he rapped on their soles with his knuckles, then stepped over the discarded paper and strings to kiss my cheek.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1479,"["" 'What a little star you are,' he said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1480,"["" 'I shall save these for my wedding-day and be the best-shod bloke in Kent.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1481,"[""' His words seemed to remind everybody of their manners, and suddenly they all rose to kiss and thank me, and there was a general, embarrassed shuffling.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1482,[' I looked over their shoulders to where Alice still sat.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1483,"["" 'Oh, what a beautiful hat!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1484,"[""' said Rhoda.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1485,"[' What shade of red do they call that, Nancy?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1486,"['\' \'""Buffalo Red"",\' I said miserably; I could not have felt more of a fool if I had given them all a pile of trash - cotton-reels and candle-stubs, toothpicks and pebbles - wrapped up in tissue and ribbons and silks.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1487,"["" 'Nancy'll think you don't like it, otherwise.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1488,"[""' 'It's all right,' I said quickly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1489,"["" 'Let her try it later.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1490,"[""' But George had jumped over to Alice's chair, taken the hat from her, and now tried to set it on her head.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1491,"["" 'I want to see if you look like a buffalo in it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1492,"[""' 'Leave off!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1493,"[""' said Alice.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1494,"[' I closed my eyes, heard the rip of stitches, and when next I looked my sister had the bonnet in her lap, and George had half the ostrich feather in his fingers.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1495,[' Poor George began to gulp and cough; Rosina said sternly that she hoped that he was satisfied.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1496,"["" Liza took the hat and the feather and tried awkwardly to reunite them: 'Such a pretty bonnet,' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1497,"[' Alice started to sniff, then placed her hands before her eyes and hurried from the room.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1498,"["" Father said, 'Well, now!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1499,"[""'; he still held his gleaming watch- guard.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1500,[' Mother looked at me and shook her head.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1501,"["" 'Oh Nancy, what a shame!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1502,"[""' In time Rosina and the cousins left, and Alice, still rather swollen-eyed, went out to call on a friend.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1503,"[' I took my bags up to my old room, and washed my face; when I came down a little later, the presents I had brought had all been tidied out of sight, and Rhoda was helping Mother peel and boil potatoes in the kitchen.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1504,"[' They shooed me away when I offered to join them, and said I was a guest; and so I sat with Father and Davy - who seemed to think that keeping to their usual habits, and hiding themselves behind the Sunday papers, would put me at my ease.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1505,"[' Later there was tea, after which more cousins appeared, to thank me for their presents and to beg for a look at my handsome new clothes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1506,"["" Alice, I learned - they were surprised she hadn't told me this - had finished with Tony Reeves from the Palace, and had started stepping out with a boy who worked at the shipyard; he was much taller, they said, than Tony, but not as funny.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1507,"[' Freddy, my old beau, was also seeing a new girl, and seemed likely to marry her .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1508,"["" When they asked me, again, if I was courting, I said I wasn't; but I hesitated over it, and they smiled.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1509,[' He played the cornet in an orchestra .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1510,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1511,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1512,"['"" I looked away, as if it made me sad to think of him, and felt them exchange significant glances.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1513,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1514,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1515,"[""' I hated myself for saying it - but thought, too, How Kitty will laugh at this, when I tell her!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1516,"[' Davy saw Rhoda home, and Alice bade the rest of us good- 181 182 night.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1517,"["" 'It's been a treat for us, Nance, to have you home again - and you grown into such a beauty!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1518,"[""' I took off the rest of my clothes, then pulled my night-gown over my head - then remembered my hair.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1519,"[' I glanced towards Alice again - she had paled at my words, but still watched - then pulled at the hairpins until the chignon came loose.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1520,[' From the corner of my eye I saw her mouth fall open.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1521,"[' Then Mother smiled at me - the first real smile that I had seen upon her face that day; and I knew then how really glad I was to be at home, amongst them all.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1522,"[' In a few minutes more I said my own good-nights, and found myself alone, at last, with Alice, in our - her - room.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1523,"[' I did not undress, but stood with my back to the door, quite still, until she looked at me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1524,"["" I said: 'You can't tell, can you, that it's a false one?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1525,"[""' Now Alice sat up with the blankets gripped before her.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1526,"["" 'You needn't look so horrified,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1527,"[' Singing, dancing.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1528,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1529,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1530,"['"" \'I\'m sorry about the hat,\' she said.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1531,"["" She said, 'You never wrote it like it was really true.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1532,"["" I don't believe you.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1533,"[""' I pulled a face: 'I wish I hadn't.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1534,"[""' I stepped out of the shoes, kicked them to one side, and started on the hooks of my dress.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1535,"[' I slowed my hand, and looked at her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1536,"["" I don't want to talk about any of that,' she answered quickly, turning away.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1537,"[' and show your legs, on stage, for all the world to look at!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1538,"[""' 'Neither have I.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1539,"[""' I tugged harder at the hooks and stepped free of the dress, then slung it over the back of the chair.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1540,"[' I went to one of my bags and got out a cigarette, and when I struck the match to light it Alice raised her head.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1541,"["" I shrugged: 'Another nasty little habit Kitty taught me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1542,"[""' I sounded just like some hard-faced bitch of a ballet-girl.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1543,"["" 'You thought it good enough when Kitty did it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1544,"[""' 'Nothing she did was ever good!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1545,"[' I wondered, again, what Kitty was doing; and sent a mental message through the night, to Stamford Hill, to make her pause - whatever her business was just then - and remember to think of me, in Whitstable.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1546,"["" She lay down, pulled the blankets to her chin, and wept; and since I don't know a girl who is not moved to tears by the sight of her own sister weeping, I climbed in beside her, and my own eyes began to sting.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1547,"["" I didn't fall asleep, that first night, until very late, but the next morning I woke when Alice woke, at half-past six, and forced myself to rise and eat my breakfast with the others, at the parlour-table.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1548,"["" Then, however, I didn't know whether to offer to take up my old duties in the kitchen, with the oyster-knife - I couldn't tell whether they would like it or expect it, or even whether I could bear to try it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1549,"[' But the water chilled and stung me, and soon I preferred to sit and watch - then I closed my eyes and placed my head upon my arms, and listened to the hum of gossip from the restaurant, and the bubble of the pans .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1550,"[' She said it with such real passion, such horror and grief, I could do nothing but what she asked, and let her lie at the cold edge of the bed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1551,"[' Soon she ceased her shaking, and fell silent; and my own eyes dried, and my face grew hard again.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1552,"[' I reached for the lamp, and put it out; then lay on my back and said nothing.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1553,[' Then I began to wish that Alice was Kitty.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1554,"[' I remembered all the times that I had lain here and pictured similar things, before Kitty and I had ever even kissed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1555,"["" Now Alice's body felt strange to me; it seemed queer and wrong, somehow, to lie so close to someone and not kiss and stroke them .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1556,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1558,"["" But I do miss her; and she was a lovely looker - though not quite as lovely, if you don't mind my saying so, as her sister has gone and turned out.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1559,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1560,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1561,"['"" The next day, if anything, was worse.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1562,"[' Mother said straight out that I must not think of spoiling my dress and hurting my hands by trying to help them in the kitchen; that I was here to have a holiday, not to work.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1563,"["" I had read the Police News from cover to cover: all there was now was Father's Fish Trades Gazette, and I couldn't bear the thought of a day upstairs with that.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
