1564,"["" At last, desperate for some amusement, I took the train to Canterbury - and while my parents and sister laboured in the oyster-house, I passed the day as a tourist, wandering about the cloisters of a cathedral which, in all the years that I had lived so near to it, I'd never cared to visit.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1565,"["" 'I gather you and she've teamed up properly now.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1566,"[""' I stared, then felt my cheeks grow red; but he only meant, of course, the act: 'I hear you're working the halls together; and are quite a pair, by all accounts.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1567,"[""' Now I smiled.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1568,"[' It looked very different to me, now that I had an eye for halls; and when I stepped up to the posters to look at the bill, I saw that all the acts were rather second-rate.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1569,"["" The doors, of course, were closed, and the foyer dark; but I couldn't resist it, and wandered round to the stage door and asked for Tony Reeves.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1570,"[' When he knew me at last, however, he smiled and kissed my hand.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1571,"[' I said, too, that I was sorry to hear about him and Alice.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1572,"["" I shrugged, then hesitated; then, 'Alice doesn't care for Kitty .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1573,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1574,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1575,"['"" I said.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1576,"["" 'It's not so far.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1577,"[""' 'Far enough,' she said, 'to keep you from us for a year and a half.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1578,"[""' He seemed only to be flirting again; but I had the queerest impression, too, that he knew more than he was letting on - and didn't care a fig about it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1579,"[' It is very nice to get your parcels; it was very nice to get those gifts; but we would rather have you, than, a hairbrush or a pair of boots.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1580,"[""' I looked away, abashed; I still felt foolish when I thought about the presents.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1581,"[' It had been good to talk of Kitty - so good that, seated at the supper-table later, between silent Alice and nasty Rhoda with her tiny, flashing sapphire, I missed her all the more.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1582,"[' I was due to spend another day with them, but now I thought I could not face it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1583,"["" I said, as we started on our puddings, that I had changed my mind and would take the morning, rather than the evening train tomorrow - that I had remembered things that I must do at the theatre, that I shouldn't put off till Thursday.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1584,"[' Davy was kind, and made me promise I would come home for his wedding, and said I might bring Kitty if I liked, which made me love him all the more.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1585,"[' Only Father hugged me to him as if really loath to get me go; and when he said that he would miss me, I knew he meant it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1586,"["" They didn't seem surprised, though Father said it was a shame.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1587,"["" There you are,' he said, 'back up to London in the morning, and I've barely had time for a proper look at you.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1588,"[""' I smiled.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1589,"["" I didn't look at Whitstable, or the sea, as my train pulled away from it; I certainly did not think, I shan't see you again, for years and years - and if I had, I am ashamed to say it would not much have troubled 'Oh yes.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1590,"[""' 'And you will take care of yourself, in London?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1591,"[""' asked Mother.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1592,[' I thought only of Kitty.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1593,"["" It was still only half-past seven; she wouldn't rise, I knew, till ten, and I planned to surprise her - to let myself into our rooms at Stamford Hill, and creep into her bed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1594,"[' I merely sat and thought of her warm, slumbering body that I would soon embrace; I imagined her pleasure, her surprise, her rising love, at seeing me returned so soon.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1595,"["" I reached Kitty's door, and put my ear to it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1596,"[' Disappointed, but gay with the expectation of seeing her, I caught hold of the door-handle and entered the room.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1597,[' At a little wash- hand stand at the foot of the bed there was another figure.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1598,"[' He gazed at me in sheer surprise, his hands lifted, the water running from them into his sleeves; then his face gave a kind of twitch, horrible to behold - and at the same time, from the corner of my eye, I saw Kitty twitch, too, beneath the bedclothes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1599,"["" 'What's this?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1600,"[""' I said, and laughed a little, nervously.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1601,"["" I looked at Kitty, waiting for her to join in my laughter - to say, 'Oh, Nan!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1602,"["" 'Nan,' he said hesitantly -I had never heard his voice so dry and bare - 'Nan, you have surprised us.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1603,"["" We didn't look for you until tonight.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1604,"[""' He took up a towel and rubbed at his face with it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1605,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1606,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1607,"[""' My mouth, like his, had dried; my voice, in consequence, sounded slow and thick.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1608,"[' How long, Walter, have you been here?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1609,"[""' He shook his head, as if the question pained him, and took a step towards me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1610,[' ?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1611,"[""' There was a silence, broken only by the sound of my ragged breathing, and Kitty's gentle weeping: just so had I seen my sister weep, three days before.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1612,"["" I placed my cheek upon the counterpane where it covered Kitty's thighs, and closed my eyes.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1613,"["" 'Oh tell me, tell me - say it ain't true!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1614,"[""' She wouldn't look at me, only placed her hands before her eyes and began to weep.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1615,"["" 'You made me think he was your friend,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1616,"["" He was only my friend; and then, and then -' Walter came closer and put his hand upon my arm.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1617,[' Kitty?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1618,"[""' I knelt beside her, took her hand from her face, and held it to my own lips.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1619,"["" At Kitty's words I saw that the pain of my love was not a tenth, not a hundredth, not a thousandth part of the pain I should suffer, at her hands, now.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1620,"["" I gave a start, and a moan - then heard her shriek, felt Walter's fingers grip my shoulders, and realised that I had bitten her, like a dog.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1621,[' She pulled her hand away and gazed at me in horror.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1622,[' Kitty herself looked ill and frightened.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1623,"["" I said, 'And the - kisses: when did they start?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1624,"[""' But even as I asked it, I guessed the answer: That night, at Deacon's .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1625,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1626,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1627,"['"" \'You are not yourself, Nan -\' \'Get out!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1628,"[""' She hesitated - then nodded; and I saw it all again, and understood it all: the awkwardness, the silences, the letters.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1629,"["" 'I shall go beyond the door- no further.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1630,"[""' Then he looked at Kitty, and when she nodded he left, closing the door behind him very gently.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1631,"["" Too much like a boy - yet, you'd rather go with Walter!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1632,"["" 'How could you?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1633,"[""' I said through my tears: I sounded like a stage husband in some penny gaff.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1634,[' She looked away.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1635,[' She looked away.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1636,[' She looked away.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1637,"["" 'He's very - kind,' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1638,"["" 'And so you had him come, while I was gone; and he was kind to you, in our bed .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1639,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1640,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1641,"['"" I got to my feet, suddenly conscious of the soiled sheets and mattress; of her bare flesh, that he had put his hands upon, his mouth .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1642,"[' Would you let me kiss you, after him?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1644,"[""' she said miserably.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1645,"["" 'At times I could hardly bear it -' 'I thought you loved me!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1646,"[' You said we would be together, for ever!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1647,"[""' She reached for me, to seize my hand.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1648,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1649,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1650,"[""' 'I never said -' 'You let me think it!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1651,"[' You said, so many times, how glad you were.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1652,[' ?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1653,"[""' There was something queer about the way she said it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1654,"["" We are known; we are looked at -' She took her hand away.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1655,"["" I don't want to be looked at, if not by you, Kitty .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1656,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1657,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1658,"['"" She pressed my hand.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1659,"["" I said, 'You have killed me, Kitty.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1660,"[""' My voice sounded strange even to my own ears; I believe it frightened her, for she glanced a little wildly to the door, and began to speak, very fast, but in a kind of shrill whisper.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1661,"[' But you will see, in time - we shall be friends again, the three of us!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1662,"[""' She reached for me; her voice grew shriller yet quieter still.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1663,"["" With Walter as my husband, who would think, who would say -' I pulled away; she gripped me tighter - then cried at last, in a kind of panic: 'Oh, you don't think, do you, that I'll let him take me from you?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1664,"[""' At that I pushed her, and she fell back against her pillow.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1665,"[' I remembered kissing it, three days before; perhaps, last night or this morning, Walter had felt it chill and hard against his own tongue.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1666,"[' At any rate, the door now opened and he appeared, white-faced above his ginger whiskers, and with his braces still dangling below the hem of his jacket, his collarless shirt still flapping at his throat.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1667,"[' He ran to the other side of the bed, and took Kitty in his arms.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1668,[' And leave you to marry a corpse!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1669,"[""' 'You have gone mad,' he said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1670,[' Do you know - has she told you - what we are - what we were - to one another?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1671,"[""' 'Nan!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1672,"[""' said Kitty quickly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1673,"["" 'I know,' he said slowly, 'that you were - sweethearts, of a kind.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1674,"[""' 'Of a kind.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1675,"["" Didn't she tell you that I fuck her?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1676,"[""' He flinched - and so did I, for the word sounded terrible: I had never said it before, and had not known I was about to use it now.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1677,"[' His gaze, however, remained steady: I saw, with increasing misery, that he knew it all, and did not care; that perhaps - who knows?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1678,"[' It said, That was not fucking, as the world knows it!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1679,"[' I took a step away from the bed, and then another.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1680,"["" Kitty swallowed, her head still upon Walter's great breast.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1681,"[' Her 197 198 eyes were large and lustrous with unshed tears, her lip red where she had bitten it; her cheeks were pale, and the freckles very dark upon them - there were freckles, too, upon the flesh of her shoulder and chest, where it showed above the blankets.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1682,"[' I thought of that night, when Kitty and I had stood above the Thames, and she had let me kiss her .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1683,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1684,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1685,"[' I placed my hands upon the iron rail: I believe that, for a second, I really considered heaving myself over it, and making my escape that way.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1686,"[' Good-bye, I thought - then I turned and fled.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1687,"["" I ran past the open parlour-door; past the hat-stand, where my coat hung next to Walter's; past the suitcase I had brought from Whitstable.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1688,"[' I ran to the door and pulled it open, then left it wide behind me as I hurried down the steps and into the street.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1689,"[' I could not bear the thought of that brown water sucking at my skirts, washing over my head, filling up my mouth.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1690,"[' I turned away and put my hands before my eyes, and forced my brain to stop its dreadful whirling.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1691,"[' The Britannia Theatre was nearby; and there was money, I knew, in our dressing-room.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1692,"[' People must have stared as I passed by them; I believe one or two fellows reached out to pluck me by the arm; but I saw and heard them not, simply hurried, stumbling over my skirts, until sheer exhaustion made me slow my pace and look about me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1693,"[' I knew him well, and had often stopped to chat with him; today, however, I only nodded to him as I took my key, and hurried by without a smile.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1694,"[' The theatre, of course, was still shut up: there were sounds of hammering from the hall as the carpenters finished their work, but apart from that the corridors, the green-room - all were quiet.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1695,"[' I 199 200 walked very fast but very quietly to the dressing-rooms, until I reached the door that said Miss Butler and Miss King.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1696,"[' Then very stealthily - for I half-feared, in my fevered state, that Kitty might be on the other side, awaiting me - I unlocked the door and pushed it open.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1697,"[' I held the card between my fingers for a moment; then I returned it to its box and placed the paper sheet above it, as before.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1698,"[' I opened the tin box at last, and took, without counting it, all the money that lay inside - about twenty pounds, as it would turn out, and only a fraction, of course, of my total earnings of the past twelve months; but I felt so dazed and ill at that moment I could hardly imagine what I would ever need money for, again.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1699,"[' The room beyond it was dark: I stepped across it in the light from the corridor, struck a match and lit a gas-jet, then closed the door as softly as I could.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1700,"["" In a cupboard beneath Kitty's table there was a little tin box with a pile of coins and notes in it - a portion of our wages went there every week, for us to draw on as we chose.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1701,"["" I hadn't glanced about me, yet, at all; now, however, I took a last look round.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1702,"["" They were all here, the suits that I had worn upon the stage at Kitty's side - the velvet breeches, the shirts, the serge jackets, the fancy waistcoats.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1703,"[' I took a step towards them, and ran my hand along the line of sleeves.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1704,"["" There were a couple of old sailors' bags nearby - giant great things that we had used once or twice to rehearse with, in the afternoons, when the Britannia stage was quiet and clear.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1705,"["" Then I stepped to the rail, and began to tear my costumes from it - not all of them, but the ones I could not bear to part with, the blue serge suit, the Oxford bags, the scarlet guardsman's uniform - and stuffed them into the bag.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1706,"["" Only when I reached the stage door did I see a face that I was rather glad to see: Billy-Boy sat in the doorman's office, quite alone, with a cigarette between his fingers.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1707,"[' He looked up when I approached, and gazed in wonder at my bag, my swollen eyes, my mottled cheeks.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1708,"["" 'Lord, Nan,' he said, getting to his feet.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1709,"["" 'You don't look right, at all,' he said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1710,"["" 'Where's Kitty?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1711,"[""' I drew on the fag again, and handed it hack to him.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1712,"["" I heard Billy-Boy's voice, lifted in anxiety and alarm, but the closing door shut off his words.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1713,"[' I raised my bag a little higher on my shoulder, and began to walk.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1714,"[' - 8 I walked for something like an hour before I rested again; but the course I took was a random one that sometimes doubled back upon itself: my aim was less to run from Kitty than to hide from her, to lose myself in the grey anonymous spaces of the city.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1715,"[' I saw myself entering it and covering my head, like some burrowing or hibernating creature, a wood-louse or a rat.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1716,"["" Still I had given no thought to the people about me - to the men and the children who stared, or sometimes laughed, to see me trudging, blank-faced, with my sailor's load.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1717,"[' My head was bowed, my eyes half-closed; but I became aware now that I had entered some kind of square -grew conscious of a bustle, a hum of business close at hand; grew conscious, too, of a smell: some rank, sweet, sickening odour I vaguely recognised but could not name.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1718,"[' I walked more slowly, and felt the road begin to pull, a little stickily, at the soles of my shoes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1719,"[' I looked up, and saw a graceful iron building filled with vans and barrows and porters, all bearing carcases.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1720,"["" Close at hand there was a tobacconist's booth: I went to it and bought a tin of cigarettes and some matches; and when the boy handed me 203 204 my change I asked him if there were any lodging-houses nearby, that might have rooms to spare.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1721,"["" He gave me the names of two or three -adding, in a warning sort of way: 'They ain't werry smart, miss, the lodgings round these parts.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1722,"[""' I only nodded, and turned away; then walked on, to the first address that he had mentioned.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1723,"["" Above the mantel there was one small looking-glass, as cloudy and as speckled as the back of an old man's hand.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1724,"[' It was all about as different from our house at Stamford Hill as it was possible for any room to be: that, at least, gave me a dreary kind of satisfaction and relief.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1725,"[' All I really saw, however, was the bed - a horrible old down mattress, yellow at the edges and blackened in the middle with an ancient bloodstain the size of a saucer - and the door.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1726,"[' My knock was answered by a pale little girl who stared hard at me while I enquired after the vacant rooms, then turned and called into the darkness behind her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1727,"[' After a second, a lady came; and she, too, looked me over.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1728,"[' I thought then of how I must appear, in my expensive dress but hatless and gloveless, and with red eyes and a running nose.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1729,"[' She said her name was Mrs Best, that she had one room left for rent; that the charge was five shillings a week - or seven, with attendance; and that she liked her rent in advance.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1730,"[' I told Mrs Best therefore that I should like to take the room at once, and drew out the envelope that held my money.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1731,"[' When she saw that, she sniffed -I think she took me for a gay girl.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1732,"["" 'It is only fair to tell you now,' she said, 'that the house I keep here is a tidy one; and I like my lodgers ditto.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1733,"["" I don't care what you do or who you see outside my house; but one thing I won't have, that's men-friends in a single lady's room .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1734,"[' I gave a quick, half-hearted show of calculation - I felt quite incapable of serious thought - then said that they would.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1735,"["" All my London friends - Mrs Dendy, Sims and Percy, Billy-Boy and Flora - were also Kitty's friends.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1736,"[' They would only be glad, to know that Kitty and Walter were lovers at last!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1737,"[' I had come away from there so recently, and been so proud; and it seemed as if they had all been promising I would be humbled from the very day I left them.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1738,"[' So, though I imagined their letters arriving at Stamford Hill, and lying there unopened and unanswered; though I guessed that, recalling my archness, they would think that I had turned my back on them, and soon stop writing at all, I could not help it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1739,"["" If I remembered the things I had left behind me - my women's clothes, and my wages; my letters and cards from fans and admirers; my old tin trunk with my initials on it - I remembered them dully, as if they were the pieces of some other person's history.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1741,"[' The only faces I saw were those of Mrs Best, and Mary - the little skivvy who had opened the door to me, who changed my pot and brought me coal and water, and who I sometimes sent on errands to buy me cigarettes and food.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1742,"[' For all that I liked to watch the carcases being towed about at Smithfield, the thought of meat upon my tongue made me nauseous, and I had stomach for none but the blandest of foods.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1743,"["" Mrs Best's son found a sweetheart, and brought her to the house: she was given tea and sandwiches in the downstairs parlour; she sang songs, while someone played on the piano.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1744,"["" I had been at Mrs Best's for about seven or eight weeks, and had not once stepped beyond her door.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1745,"[' I still ate only what Mary brought me; and though I only ever sent her off, as I have said, for bread and tea and milk, she sometimes came with more substantial foods, to try and tempt me into eating them.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1746,"["" 'You'll perish, miss,' she would say, 'if you don't get your wittles'; and she'd hand me baked potatoes, and pies, and eels in jelly, which she bought hot from the stalls and pie-shops on the Farringdon Road, and had bound with layers of newsprint into tight little parcels, steaming and damp.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1747,"[' I would do this in the same dull spirit in which I gazed from my window at the streets of East London; but one evening, as I smoothed a piece of newspaper over my knee and brushed the crumbs of pastry from its creases, I saw a name I knew.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1748,"["" The words appeared in a kind of banner, held aloft by cherubs; but beneath them there were three or four smaller headlines -they said things like Ben and Milly Announce Their Engagement; Knockabout Acrobats to Wed; Hal Harvey and Helen's Heavenly Honeymoon!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1749,"[' I knew none of these artistes, nor did I linger over their stories; for in the very centre of the article there was a column of print and a 209 210 photograph from which, once I had seen it, I could not tear my eyes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1750,[' The photograph was of Kitty and Walter in their wedding-suits.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1751,"[' I gazed at it in stupefaction for a moment, then I placed my hand over the page and gave a cry - a quick, sharp, agonised cry, as if the paper was hot and had burned me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1752,"[' Soon I heard footsteps on the stairs: Mrs Best was at the door, calling my name in curiosity and fear.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1753,"[' At that I ceased my racket, and became a little calmer: I did not want her in my room, prying into my grief or offering useless words of comfort.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1754,"[' It said that Walter and Kitty had married at the end of March, and honeymooned on the Continent; that Kitty was currently resting from the stage, but was expected to return to the halls - in an entirely new act, and with Walter as her partner - in the autumn.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1755,"[' Her old partner, it said, Miss Nan King, who had been taken ill whilst playing at the Britannia Theatre, Hoxton, was busy with plans for a new career of her own.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1756,"[' I had not laughed in what seemed to be a hundred years or more; I feared more than anything to hear the sound of my own mirth now, for I knew it would be terrible.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1757,"["" The paper that was left over I did cast into the grate; but the slip of newsprint that bore Kitty and Walter's wedding-portrait I held carefully, in the palm of my hand - as carefully as if it were a moth's wing that might tarnish with too much fingering.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1758,"["" After a moment's thought I stepped to the looking-glass.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1759,[' Perhaps I was a little feverish; yet my head felt clearer than it had in a month and a half.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1760,"[' But for the first time in all those long, miserable weeks, I thought too, what a fool I had been, to let them.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1761,"[' I turned my head away, then and stepped to the door, and gave a shout for Mary.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1762,"[' She looked at me rather strangely -I had never called for such a thing before - then she ran to the basement, and soon there came the thump of the tub upon the stairs as she hauled it up behind her, and the clatter of pans and kettles in the kitchen.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1763,"["" When I explained my sudden longing to bathe she said, 'Oh Miss Astley, now is that really wise?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1764,"[""', and looked pale and shaken.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1765,"["" Instead I sat for an hour in the steaming tub, gazing into the fireplace or at Kitty's picture, gently massaging the life back into my aching limbs and joints with a piece of soap and flannel.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1766,"[' I washed my hair and cleaned the muck from my eyes; the flesh beneath my ears and behind my knees, in the crooks of my arms and between my legs, I rubbed till it was red and stinging.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1767,[' I remembered a woman from Whitstable - an old neighbour of ours - of whom I had not thought in years.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1768,"[' Save a little tiredness and breathlessness there had been no warning; the heart had worked away on its private, fatal, project, at its own secret pace - then stopped.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1769,"["" At night, in bed, we would lie trembling; we would rub and worry at our ribs with sweating fingers, conscious of the unemphatic pulse beneath, terrified that the flimsy rhythm would falter or slow, certain that - like hers, our poor, dead, unsuspecting neighbour's - our hearts were stealthily hardening, hardening, in the tender red cavities of our breasts.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1770,"["" My breast felt tight and sore - but I didn't writhe, or sweat, beneath the pain of it, rather, I crossed my arms over my ribs, and embraced my dark and thickened heart like a lover.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1771,"[' Perhaps, even as I did it, Walter and Kitty were walking together, on a street in France or Italy; perhaps he leaned to touch her, as I touched myself; perhaps they kissed; perhaps they lay in a bed .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1772,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1773,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1774,"[' I had thought such things a thousand times, and wept and bitten my lips to think them; but now I gazed at the photograph and felt my misery stiffen, as my heart had stiffened, with rage and frustration.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1775,"[' I hauled open the window of my room, and leaned out into the dark - into the never-quite-dark of the London night, with its sounds and its scents that, for so long, I had been shut from.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1776,"[' But when I walked in it before, it was with Kitty or Walter; often, indeed, we had not walked at all, but taken carriages and cabs.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1777,"["" Part of it was my nervous fear that I would turn a corner and see a face I knew, a face to remind me of my old life, or - worst of all - Kitty's face, tilted and smiling as she walked on Walter's arm.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1778,"[' This, too, had not happened in my old life; perhaps, indeed, if I had had a baby or a bundle on me now, and was walking purposefully or with my gaze fixed low, they might have let me pass untroubled.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1779,"[' But, as I have said, I walked fitfully, blinking at the traffic about me; and such a girl, I suppose, is a kind of invitation to sport and dalliance .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1780,"["" I returned to Mrs Best's and turned the key in my door; then I lay upon my rancid mattress and shivered and wept.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1781,"["" I thought then what a cruel joke it was that I, who had swaggered so many times in a gentleman's suit across the stages of London, should now be afraid to walk upon its streets, because of my own girlishness!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1782,"[' I remembered what Kitty had said, that day in Stamford Hill - that I was too much like a boy.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1783,"["" The very suit that I had worn then -the blue serge suit that Walter had given me on New Year's Eve - was here, beneath my bed, still 215 216 crumpled in the sailor's bag with all the other costumes that I'd taken from the Brit, I slid from the mattress and drew the bag free, and in a moment I had all the suits upon the floor.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1784,"[' They lay about me, impossible handsome and vivid in that colourless room: all the shades and textures of my former life, with all the scents and songs of the music hall, and my old passion, in their seams and creases.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1785,"[' I almost returned the costumes to the bag - but then I took a breath, and willed my hands to steady and my dampening eyes to dry.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1786,"["" With my hair trimmed, I thought, and a pair of proper boy's shoes upon my feet, anyone - even Kitty herself!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1787,"[' - might meet me on the streets of London, and never know me for a girl, at all.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1788,"["" Firstly, I must properly reacquaint myself with the city: it took another week of wandering every day about the streets of Farringdon and St Paul's, before I could accept the jostling and the roars, and the stares of the men, without smarting.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1789,"["" I did not want to live as a boy full-time; nor did I want, just yet, to give up my room at Mrs Best's.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1790,"[' The gay girls of the Haymarket, I believe, transformed themselves in the public lavatories of Piccadilly - put their make-up on at the wash-hand basins, and changed into their gaudy frocks while the latch on the door said Occupied.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1791,"[' I had begun to walk, each day, as far as Soho; and I had noticed there the tremendous number of houses bearing signs that advertised Beds Let By The Hour.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1793,"[' I stood one day at a coffee-stall in the mouth of an alley off Berwick Street, and 217 218 watched the entrance to one of these houses.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1796,"[' A few days later, therefore, I put my costume in a bag, presented myself at the house, and asked for a room.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1797,"[' The old woman looked me over and grinned, quite mirthlessly; then, when I gave her my shilling, she thrust a key at me, and nodded me into the darkened passageway behind her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1798,"[' The key was sticky; the handle of my chamber was sticky; indeed, the house was entirely horrible - damp and stinking, and with walls as thin as paper, so that, unpacking my bag and straightening my costume, I heard all the business from the rooms above, below, and on either side of it - all the grunts and slaps and giggles, and pounding mattresses.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1799,"["" But when I gazed at myself - there was'a looking-glass, with a crack across it, and blood in the crack - when I gazed at myself at last, I smiled, and knew my plan was a good one.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1800,"[' I left my dress and purse upon a chair, went out upon the landing, and locked the door behind me - my new dark heart, all the time, beating fast as a clock.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1801,"[' As I had expected, the old bawd on the step barely raised her eyes as I went past her; and so, a little hesitantly, I began the walk down Berwick Street.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1802,"["" With every glance that came my way, I flinched; at any moment I expected the cry to be let up: 'A girl!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1803,"["" At St Luke's Church, on the corner, a man brushed by me with a barrow, calling, 'All right, squire!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1804,"['"" Then a woman with a frizzed fringe put her hand upon my arm, and tilted her head and said: \'Well now, pretty boy, you look like a lively one.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1805,"["" Fancy payin' a visit, to a nice little place I know .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1806,"[' I became quite a regular at the Berwick Street knocking-shop - the madam kept a room there for me, three days a week.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1807,"[' She early on found out the purpose of my visits, of course - though, from a certain narrowing of her gaze when she dealt with me, I think she was never quite sure if I were a girl come to her house to pull on a pair of trousers, or a boy arrived to change out of his frock.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1808,"["" I had spent too many miserable weeks at Mrs Best's to be anything other than wretched in my room there: I was bleached of hope and colour, like the wallpaper.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1809,"[' But London, for all my weeping, could never wash dim; and to walk freely about it at last - to walk as a boy, as a handsome boy in a well-sewn suit, whom the people stared after only to envy, never to mock - well, it had a brittle kind of glamour to it, that was all I knew, just then, of satisfaction.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1810,"["" 'Let Kitty see me now,' I would think.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1811,"["" 'She would not have me when I was a girl - so let her only see me now!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1812,"[""' And I remembered a book that Mother had had once from the library, in which a woman, cast out, returned to her home to care for her children in the guise of a nurse.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1813,"[' If only I could meet Kitty once again, I thought, and woo her as a man - and then reveal myself, to break her heart, as she had broken mine!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1814,"["" Even when June came, and then July, and she must surely have returned from her gay honeymoon, I never saw her name on any poster outside any hall or theatre; and I never bought a theatrical paper, to look for it there - so never learned how she fared, as Walter's wife.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1815,"["" In those she was still sweet and lovely, still calling my name and offering me her mouth to kiss; but still, at the last, there would come Walter's arm about her freckled shoulders, and she would turn her guilty eyes from me, to him.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1816,"["" I was wearing not the blue serge suit, but the costume I had worn to sing the song called 'Scarlet Fever' - a guardsman's uniform, with a neat little cap.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1817,[' I nodded - now I did turn to glance at him - and he looked pleased.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1818,"["" 'There is something so very masculine about a tobacconist's shop - don't you think?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1819,"[""' His voice, at the last, had dipped to little more than a murmur.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1820,"["" Now he said in the same tone but very fast: 'Are you up for it, Private?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1821,"[""' His words made me blink.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1822,"["" 'Pardon?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1823,"[""' He looked about him with an eye that was quick, practised, smooth as a well-oiled castor; then he glanced back to me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1824,[' Have you a room we might go to?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1825,"[""' 'I don't know what you mean,' I said - although, to be frank, I felt the stirrings of an idea.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1826,"["" And I thought all you guardsmen fellows knew the game all right 'Not me,' I said primly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1827,[' A handsome fellow like you?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1828,"[""' I shook my head.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1829,"[' Any stranger looking on, I thought, would think us two quite unconnected fellows, lost in our own worlds.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1830,"["" In the same humouring tone as before, I said: 'How much, then, will you give me for it?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1831,"[""' At that, his face took on a cynical expression, as if he had expected no better of me; but behind the hardness, too, I caught a flash of heat - as if he wouldn't really have wanted me any other way.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1832,"["" He said, 'A sovereign, for a suck or for a Robert' - he meant, of course, a Robert Browning.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1833,"["" And when I looked again at the man's face - there was light upon it, now, from the lamp at the window - I saw that his whiskers and his hair were gingerish and thick.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1834,"[' His eyes were brown, his cheeks rather hollow; but for all that, he looked quite unmistakably like Walter.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1835,"[' Like Walter, whom Kitty lay with and kissed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1836,"[' When I stepped away I felt him linger a moment at the window, then follow.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1837,"["" I went not to my old knocking-shop - I had only the most confused sense of what I was about, but knew I oughtn't to get stuck in a 223 224 room with him, and risk having him opt for the Robert after all - but to a little court nearby, where there was a nook, above a grating, which the gay girls used as a lavatory.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1838,"[' He had a newspaper shielding the fork of his trousers, and when he took the paper away I saw a bulge there the size of a bottle.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1839,"[' I had a moment of panic; but then he came and stood before me, and looked expectant.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1840,"["" He handed me my sovereign; then, after a moment's hesitation, he stepped to me and kissed my cheek.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1841,"["" 'No,' he said, 'you don't like that, you soldier-boys, do you?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1842,"[""' His tone was strange; when I studied him, I saw that his eyes were gleaming.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1843,"["" The man had looked like Walter; I had pleasured him, in some queer way, for Kitty's sake; and the act had made me sicken.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1844,"[' His pleasure had turned, at the last, to a kind of grief; and his love was a love so fierce and so secret it must be satisfied, with a stranger, in a reeking court like this.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1845,"["" 'How thick and long it is,' I said then -I had heard that it was every man's ambition to be spoken to thus, at such moments.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1846,"["" 'Your mouth is such a perfect one - quite like a girl's.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1847,"[""' I had kept my heart-beats smothered; and had been betrayed, anyway.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1848,"[' This was one place which, in all my careless West End wanderings, I had tended to avoid or pass through swiftly: I was always mindful of the first trip I had made there, with Kitty and Walter, and it was not a memory I cared, very often, to revisit.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1849,"[' I went to the statute of Shakespeare, where we had stood that time, and I leaned before it, gazing at the view that we had looked on then.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1850,"[' I remembered Walter saying that we were at the very heart of London, and did I know what it was that made that great heart beat?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1851,"["" I had looked around me that afternoon and seen, astonished, what I thought was all the world's variety, brought together in one extraordinary place.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1852,"["" I had seen them make a vast harmonious whole, and been thrilled to think that I was about to find my own particular place in it, as Kitty's friend.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1853,"[' I had learned that London life was even stranger and more various than I had ever thought it; but I had learned too that not all its great variety was visible to the casual eye; that not all the pieces of the city sat together smoothly, or graciously, but rather rubbed and chafed and jostled one another, and overlapped; that some, out of fear, kept themselves hidden, and only exposed themselves to those upon whose sympathies they could be sure.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1854,"[' Even as I wondered it I saw one fellow gaze my way, deliberately - and then another.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1856,"["" Walking and watching, indeed, are that world's keynotes: you walk, and let yourself be looked at; you watch, until you find a face or a figure that you fancy; there is a nod, a wink, a shake of the head, a purposeful stepping to an alley or a rooming-house .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1857,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1858,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1861,"["" All this I learned, slowly but steadily, in the first few weeks of my apprenticeship, just as I had learned my music-hall trade at Kitty's side.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1862,"["" He was a very girlish type - what they call a true mary-anne - and, like many of them, he gave himself a girl's name: Alice.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1863,"["" I said I didn't know if mine was dead or not, and didn't care; and this did not surprise him.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1864,"[' He was as pretty as a girl - prettier, indeed, than most girls (including me), for he had glossy black hair and a heart-shaped face, and eye-lashes impossibly long and dark and thick.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1865,"[' He had rented, he said, since he was twelve; renting, now, was the only life he knew, but he liked it well enough.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1866,"["" 'It's better, anyway,' he said, 'than working in an office or a shop.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1867,"[' I believe that, if I had to work in the same little room all day, perched on the same little stool and staring at the same dull faces, I would go mad, just mad!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1868,"[""' When he asked for my history, I told him that I had come up to London from Kent, that I had been treated rather badly by someone, and was now forced to find my living on the streets; all of which was true enough, in its way.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1869,"["" I believe he felt sorry for me - or maybe it was just the coincidence of our sisters' names that warmed him to me - anyway, he began to look out a little for me, and to give me tips and cautions.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1870,"[' And while we talked his eyes would be darting, darting, darting all about, looking for new customers, or old ones, or for sweethearts and friends.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1871,"[' Finally, of course, his drifting gaze would settle and harden, and he would give a little nod, or wink, and hastily put down his cup.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1872,[' A thousand kisses on your marvellous eyes!'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1873,"[""' He would touch his fingertip to his lips, then lightly press it to the sleeve of my jacket; then I would see him picking his careful way 229 230 across the crowded square to the fellow who had gestured to him.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1874,"[' Never a very virile boy, I held no appeal for the kind of gentleman who liked a rough hand through the slit of his drawers, or a bit of a slap in the shadows; equally, however, I could never afford to let myself be seen as one of those lily-white lads whom the working-men go for, and make rather free with.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1875,"[' Most men, to be frank, will step aside with a renter as you or I might call into a public-house, on our way home from the market: they take their pleasure, give a belch, and think no more of it than that.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1876,"[' But still there are always some - they are gentlemen, for the most part; I learned to spot them from afar - who are fretful, or wistful, or romantic - who could, like the fellow from the Burlington Arcade, be brought to kiss me, or thank me, or even weep over me, as I was handling them.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1877,"["" Foremost amongst them, of course, were the mary-annes, the other boys like himself, who could be seen strolling up and down the Haymarket at any time of the day or night, with their lips rouged and their throats powdered, and clad in trousers as tight and revealing, almost, as a ballerina's fleshings.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1878,[' These boys took their customers to lodging-houses and hotels; their aim was to be spotted by some manly young gentleman or lord and set up as his mistress in apartments of their own.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1879,"[' Then again, there were the more ordinary-looking fellows, the clerks and shop-boys: they rather despised the mary- annes, and went with gentlemen - or so they claimed - for the money rather than for the thrill of it; some of them, I believe, even kept wives and sweethearts.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1881,"["" I was like a person who, having once been robbed of all he owns and loves, turns thief himself- not to enjoy his neighbours' chattels, but to spoil them.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1882,"[' I would gaze about me at the dim and dreary place in which my gentleman and I leaned panting, and wish the cobbles were a stage, the bricks a curtain, the scuttling rats a set of blazing footlights.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1883,"[' - to be fixed upon our couplings: a bold and knowing eye that saw how well I played my part, how gulled and humbled was my foolish, trustful partner.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1884,"["" All continued smoothly for, perhaps, six months or so: my colourless life at Mrs Best's went on, and so did my trips to the West End, and my renting.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1885,"[' My little stash of money dwindled, and finally disappeared; and now, since renting was all I knew and cared for, I began to live entirely from what I earned upon the streets.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1886,"["" Once or twice on my trips around the city I saw someone I knew, from the old days - a fellow with whom we'd shared a bill at the Paragon, a wardrobe-mistress from the Bedford, Camden Town.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1887,"["" One night I leaned against a pillar in Great Windmill Street and watched as Dolly Arnold -who had played Cinderella to Kitty's Prince, at the Britannia -made her exit from the door of the Pavilion and was helped into a carriage.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1888,"[' Perhaps she thought she knew my face; perhaps she thought I was a boy that she had worked with; perhaps she only thought I was a miserable ningle, haunting the shadows in search of a gent.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1889,"[' Anyway, she did not see Nan King in me, I know it; and if I had an urge to cross to her and reveal myself and ask for news of Kitty, it lasted for only a moment; and in that moment the driver shook his horses into life, and the carriage rumbled off.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1890,"[' I discovered that the music halls of Leicester Square - the very same halls which Kitty and I had gazed at, all hopefully, two years before - were rather famous in the renter world as posing-grounds and pick-up spots.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1891,"[' The Empire, in particular, was always thick with sods: they strolled side-by-side with the gay girls of the promenade, or stood, in little knots, exchanging gossip, comparing fortunes, greeting one another with flapping hands and high, extravagant voices.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1892,"["" They never looked at the stage, never cheered or applauded, only gazed at themselves in the mirror-glass or at each other's powdered faces, or - more covertly - at the gentlemen who, rapidly or rather lingeringly, passed them by.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1893,"[' I loved to stroll about the Empire - the handsomest hall in England, as Walter had described it, the hall to which Kitty had longed so ardently so uselessly!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1894,"[' for an invitation - I loved to stroll about it with my back to its glorious golden stage, my costume bright beneath the ungentle glare of its electric chandeliers, my hair gleaming, my trousers bulging, my lips pink, my figure and pose reeking, as the gay boys say, of lavender, their import bold and unmistakable - but false.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1895,"[' 233 234 All, as I have said, went smoothly; then, in the first few warm weeks of 1891 - that is, a year and more after my flight from Kitty - there came a bothersome interruption to my little routine.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1896,"[' I returned to the knocking-shop after an evening of rather heavy renting to find the old proprietress missing, her chair overturned, and the door to my chamber splintered and flung wide.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1897,"[' Anyway, thieves had taken advantage of her absence to steal into the house, to frighten and threaten the girls and their customers, and help themselves to anything that they could lift: the oozing mattresses and rugs, the broken looking-glasses, the few rickety bits of furniture - also my frocks, shoes, bonnet and purse.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1898,"["" The loss was not a great one to me; but it meant that I must go home in my masculine attire -I was wearing the old Oxford bags, and a boater - and attempt to reach my room at Mrs Best's without her catching me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1899,"[' It was quite late, and I walked very slowly to Smithfield, in the hope that all the Bests might be abed and sleeping by the time I got there - and, indeed, when I reached the house, the windows were dark and all seemed still.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1900,"[' I let myself in and stepped silently up the stairs - horribly mindful of the last time I had crept, noiselessly, through a slumbering house, and all that the creeping had led to.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1901,[' Perhaps it was the memory that made me blunder: for half-way up I put my hand to my head - and my hat went soaring over the banister to land with a thud in the passageway below.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1902,"[' I knew I must go down to fetch it; just as I was about to turn and begin my descent, however, I heard the creaking of a door and saw the bobbing glow of a candle.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1903,"[' With the door closed behind me I tore the jacket from my shoulders and the trousers from my legs, and stuffed them, with my shirt and drawers, into the little curtained alcove where I hung my clothes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1904,"["" I found myself a night-gown, and pulled it on; as I fastened the buttons at the throat, however, I heard what I had dreaded to hear: the sound of rapid, heavy footsteps on the stairs, followed by a hammering at my door and Mrs Best's voice, loud and shrill.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1905,"[' I have found a peculiar item in the downstairs passage, and believe that you have someone in there as you should not!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1906,"[""' 'Mrs Best,' I answered, 'what do you mean?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1907,"[""' 'You know what I mean, Miss Astley.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1908,"[' Mrs Best, clad in a night-dress and a tartan wrap, pushed past me, into the room.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1909,"[' She pulled the covers from the bed, 235 236 then stopped to look beneath it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1910,"[' It was a warm morning, and the reek of the carcases was terrible, the hum of flies about them as deep and steady as the buzz of a motor; but for all that, I felt a kind of bleak fondness for the place, which I had gazed at, so often, in my weeks of madness.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1911,"["" I had only the vaguest ideas about where I should make for, but I had heard that the streets around King's Cross were full of rooming-houses, and thought perhaps that I might try my luck up there.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1912,"["" In the window of a shop on the Gray's Inn Road I saw a little card: Respectible Lady Seeks Fe-Male Lodger, and an address.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1913,"["" 'I'm sorry, Mrs Best,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1914,"["" It was for a road named Green Street, which turned out to be wonderfully near - a narrow little street off the Gray's Inn Road itself, with a well-kept terrace on one side, and a rather grim-looking tenement on the other.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1915,"[' The number I sought was one of the houses, and 237 238 looked very pleasant, with a pot of geraniums upon the step and, beside that, a three-legged cat, washing its face.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1916,"["" I pulled on the bell, and was greeted by a kind-faced, white- haired lady in an apron and slippers; she let me in at once when I explained my visit, introduced herself as 'Mrs Milne', then spent a moment fussing over the cat.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1917,"[' Above the umbrella-stand, for example, hung a copy of that gaudy painting The Light of the World; beneath it was an Indian picture, of a slender blue god wearing spit-black on the eyes, and holding a flute.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1918,"[' When she saw me looking at the walls, however, she smiled in a most Christian-like way.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1919,"[' Its chief attraction was its window: this was long, and split down the middle to form a pair of glass doors; and these opened on to a little iron balcony, that overlooked Green Street and faced the shabby tenement.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1920,"["" 'It'll be eight shillings for the rent,' said Mrs Milne as I gazed about me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1921,"["" 'You're not the first girl that I've seen,' she went on, 'but, to be honest, I was hoping for an older lady - I thought perhaps a widow.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1922,"[' You might be thinking of getting married yourself, rather soon?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1923,"[""' 'Oh no,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1924,"["" I wouldn't like to have young fellers, coming in and out.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1925,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1926,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1927,"['"" There\'s no young man,\' I said firmly.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1928,"["" 'Might I ask - might I - why you are leaving your present address?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1929,"[""' At that I hesitated - and her smile grew smaller.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1930,"["" To be truthful,' I said, 'there was a little bit of unpleasantness with my landlady .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1931,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1932,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1933,"['"" \'Ah.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1934,"[""' She stiffened a little, and I realised that in telling the truth I had blundered.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1935,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1936,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1937,"[""' This daughter must be a beauty and a half, I thought - or else a complete erotomaniac - if the mother is so eager to keep her safe and close, away from young men's eyes.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1938,"["" She might, I thought, have been anything between seventeen and thirty; her hair, however, was as yellow and fine as flax, and hung loose about her shoulders like a girl's.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1939,"["" 'Mrs Milne,' I said, 'the fact of it is I have a curious occupation - a theatrical occupation, you could call it - that obliges me sometimes to dress in gentlemen's suits.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1940,"[' If you and Miss Milne will only not object to the sight of a girl in a pair of bags and a neck-tie now and again - well, then I think I might be the lodger you are seeking.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1942,"["" 'My eyes,' she said, folding her arms, 'he's a beauty, in' he?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1943,[' Now my little girl would like him.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1944,"[""' She gestured to the door.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1945,[' ?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1946,"[""' She stepped out on to the landing and gave a shout: 'Gracie!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1947,"[""' I heard the sound of footsteps below.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1948,"["" 'Now, she's a mote shy,' she said in a low voice, 'but don't you pay no mind to her if she starts being silly on you.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1949,"["" I asked her, 'Would you like to try it on?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1950,"[""' She nodded, then glanced at her mother: 'If I might.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1951,"[""' Mrs Milne said she might.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1952,"[' The scarlet serge and the gold trim went bizarrely well with her hair, her eyes, her dress and stockings.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1953,"["" 'You look like a lady in a circus,' I said, as her mother and I stood back to study her.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1954,"[' I could keep the hours I liked, wear the costumes I chose, and Mrs Milne said nothing.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1955,"["" I could come home in a jacket crusted, at the collar, with a man's rash spendings - and she would only pluck it from my nervous hands, and wash it at the tap: 'I never saw a girl so careless with her soup!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1956,"[""' I could wake wretched, plagued with memories, and she would pile my breakfast plate the higher, asking nothing.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1957,"["" She was as simple, in her way, as her own simple daughter; she was good to me for Grade's sake, because I liked her, and was kind to her.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1958,[' Had I only two the same .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1959,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1960,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1961,"['"" \'Now Gracie,\' said her mother, \'of course you can\'t keep it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1962,[' Miss Astley needs the costume for her theatricals.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1963,"[""' Grace pulled a face, but did not seem very seriously dismayed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1964,[' ?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1965,"[""' 'She can borrow all my suits, all at once, so far as I care,' I said; and when Grace looked up I gave her a wink, and her pale cheeks pinked a little, and her head went down.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1966,"[' You could not have spent three minutes in that house without noticing it; but after three days there I began to sense a kind of system to her mania which, if I had had routines of my own, like an ordinary girl, might have proved rather maddening.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1967,"["" When, on my first Wednesday there, I went down to breakfast in a yellow waistcoat, Mrs Milne flinched and said: 'Grade don't quite like to see yellow in the house,' she said, 'on a Wednesday.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1968,"[""' Three days later, however, we had a custard for tea: food on a Saturday, it seemed, must be yellow, or nothing .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1969,"[' Mrs Milne gave a mild tut-tut, and folded her arms complacently.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1970,"[' That first afternoon I passed in unpacking my few little things, with Gracie beside me exclaiming over them all, and Mrs Milne bringing tea, and then more tea, and cake.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1971,"["" Mrs Milne had grown so used to the fads, she had almost ceased to notice them; and in time, as I have said, I grew used to them, too - calling, 'What colour today, Grace?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1972,"[""' as I dressed in the mornings.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1973,"["" 'May I wear my blue serge suit, or must it be the Oxfords?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1974,"[""' 'Shall we have gooseberries for supper, or a Battenburg cake?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1975,"[""' I didn't mind, it came to seem a kind of game; and Grade's way was quite as valid a philosophy, I thought, as many others.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1976,"[' The cake being eaten, I changed for Soho; and when Mrs Milne saw me in my serge-and-velvet, she clapped again.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1977,"[' As I strolled about I would keep a watch for pictures and dresses that I knew that she would like, then bring them home for her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1978,"["" She had a number of huge albums, into which she pasted cuttings and scraps: I would find her magazines and little books, to worry at with her scissors; I would buy her flowers from the flower-girls' stalls: violets, carnations, lavender statice and blue forget-me-nots.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1979,"[' When I presented them to her - producing them with a flourish, from under my coat, like a conjuror - she would flush with pleasure, and perhaps dip me a playful little curtsey.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1980,"[' Mrs Milne would look on, pleased as anything, but shaking her head and pretending to chide.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1981,"["" 'You will turn that girl's head right round, one of these days, I swear it!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1982,"[""' And I would think for a second how queer it was that she - who had been so careful to keep her daughter from the covetous glances of fresh young men - should encourage Grace and me to play at sweethearts, so blithely, and with such seeming unconcern.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1983,"[' And because, since losing Kitty, thinking was the occupation I cared for least, this suited me best of all.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1984,"[' I remembered with some small, insistent portion of my brain the two gay Christmases that I had spent with Kitty; and then I thought of my family.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1985,"[' They would all be celebrating the turning of the year, today, without me -wondering, perhaps, where I was, and how I did; and Kitty and Walter might be doing the same.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1986,"[' When Mrs Milne raised her glass at the dinner-table, and wished the three of us all the luck of the Season and the New Year, I gave her a smile, and then a kiss upon the cheek.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1987,"[' What a lucky day it was for me and Grace, Nance, the day you knocked upon our door!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1988,"[""' Her eyes glistened a little; she had said this sort of thing before, but never so feelingly.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1989,"[' I knew she had begun to look upon me as a kind of daughter - as a sister, anyway, to her real daughter: a kindly older sister who might be relied upon, perhaps, to care for Grade when she herself was dead and gone .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1990,"["" 'If only everything might stay just as it is, for ever!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1991,"[""' Mrs Milne blinked her tears away and took my soft white hand in her old, hardened one.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1992,"[' Grade gazed at us, pleased, but distracted by the splendours of the day, her hair shining in the candle-light like gold.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1993,"[' The fogs and the early darkness are kind to the furtive; but no one likes unbuttoning himself when there are icicles upon the 245 246 wall - nor did I much care for kneeling on slippery cobbles, or wandering around the West End in a short jacket merely for the sake of showing off my lovely bum and the roll of the hankie at the fork of my trousers.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1994,"[' I was glad to have a home that was cosy: gay people go down like skittles in January, with fevers and influenza, or worse; Sweet Alice coughed all through that winter - said he was afraid he should do it while he knelt to a gent, a bite his cock off.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1995,"[' Now, more often than I ventured out into the streets, I kept at home in my room - not sleeping, only lying, open-eyed, half-clothed; or smoking, while the night grew thicker and still, and a candle burned low, and trembled, and died.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

1996,"["" I took to throwing wide my windows to let the voices of the city in: the clatter of cabs and vans from the Gray's Inn Road; the hoots and the rattles and hisses of steam, from King's Cross; snatches of quarrels and confidences and greetings, from passers-by - 'Well now, Jenny!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1997,"[""'; Till Tuesday, till Tuesday .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1998,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
1999,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2000,"['"" When the stifling heat of June arrived I got into the habit of placing a chair on my little balcony high above Green Street, and sitting there long into the cooling night.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2001,"[' I was wearing, I remember, plain linen trousers and a shirt left open at the neck, and a little straw sailor-hat I had put on against the strong late-afternoon sun, and forgotten to remove.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2002,"[' The room behind me I had let darken; I guessed that, apart from the occasional dancing glow of my cigarette tip, I must be quite invisible against its shadows.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2003,"[' My eyes were closed, I was thinking of nothing, when all at once I heard music.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2004,"[' I opened my eyes to find the source of the sound; it came not, as I had expected, from the street below, but from the building opposite - the old tenement that had used to be so grim and empty, and such a contrast to the pleasant little terrace in which my landlady had her house.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2005,"[' Labourers had been at work upon it for a month and more, and I had been dimly aware of them as they hammered and whistled and leaned from ladders; now the building was spruce and mended, hi all my time at Green Street the windows opposite mine had been dark.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2006,"[' The player of the instrument - it was, I now saw, a mandolin - was a handsome young woman in a well- tailored jacket, a white blouse, a neck-tie, and spectacles; I put her down at once for a lady clerk or a college girl.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2007,"[' A man, in a suit that was rather rough, sat beside her, nodding with a fixed and hopeful smile; on his knee he held a sweet little girl in a patched frock and apron, whose hands he made to clap in approximate time to the melody.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2008,"["" Behind him stood a tired-looking hard-faced woman - the man's wife, I guessed - and she held another infant listlessly at her breast.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2009,"[' Her face was hidden, but I could see her hands -which were slender and rather pale - with peculiar clarity: they held a card or a pamphlet, which they flapped in the still, warm air like a fan.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2010,"[' All of these figures were gathered around a table, upon which stood a jar of flaccid little daisies and the remains of an economical supper: tea and cocoa, cold meat and pickle, and a cake.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2011,"[' It was, I supposed, a sort of house-warming party - though I could not fathom the relationship between the lady mandolinist and the poor, drab little family to whom she played.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2012,"[' Nor was I sure about the other girl, with the pale hands; she, I thought, could have belonged in either camp.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2013,"[' I lit a cigarette and studied the scene: it was as good a thing to watch, I thought, as any.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2014,"[' Stepping carefully around the group, she approached the window: it, like my own, opened on to a little balcony, upon which she now stepped, and from which she surveyed, with a mild glance and a yawn, the quiet street beneath.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2015,"[' It streamed through her hair, which seemed curly as a corkscrew, and lent her a kind of flaming nimbus, such as a saint might have in the window of a church; her face, however, was left in darkness.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2016,"["" When the music stopped, and there was a self- conscious smattering of applause and then a bit of desultory chatter, still she kept her place on the balcony and didn't look round.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2017,"["" 'G'night, sweetheart,' I said in a low, lazy tone.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2018,[' It was the kind of thing rough fellows of the street - costers and road- menders - said to passing ladies all the time.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2019,"[' 249 250 The girl gave another twitch, then opened her mouth as if to make me some rusty reply; at that moment, however, her friend approached the window.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2020,"["" She said, 'We must go, Florence' - the name sounded very romantic, in the half- light.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2021,"["" Mr Mason says he will walk with us as far as King's Cross.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2022,"[""' The girl gave not a glance more my way then, but turned quickly into the room.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2023,"["" Here she kissed the children, shook the mother's hand, and politely took her leave; from my place on the balcony I saw her, and her friend, and their rough chaperon Mr Mason, quit the building and make their way up towards the Gray's Inn Road.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2024,[' I thought she might turn to see if I still watched but she did not; and why should I mind it?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2025,"[' I had my old plait of false hair, too: it looked wonderfully natural under the shadow of the stiff brim of a black straw hat.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2026,"[' I knew men would pester me along the way; but parks, I have found, are full of women - full of nursemaids wheeling bassinets, and governesses airing babies, and shop-girls taking their lunches on the grass.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2027,"["" Any of these, I knew, might be led into a little conversation by a girl with a smile and a handsome dress; and I had a fancy - a rather curious fancy - for women's company that day.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2028,"[' I had just let myself out of the house, and lingered for a moment on the lowest step, yawning and rubbing my eyes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2029,"[' She was emerging into the sunlight from a passageway on the other side of Green Street, a little way down on my left, and she was dressed in a jacket and skirt the colour of mustard - it was this, struck by the sun and set glowing, that had caught my eye.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2030,"[' I saw her eyes flick once towards mine, then away, and then, as she felt the persistence of my gaze, to mine again.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2031,"["" While my eyes still held her questioning, amiable gaze, I lifted my hand to 251 252 my head and raised my hat, and said in the same low tone that I had used on her before: 'G'mornin!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2033,[' It was you then - was it?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2034,"[""' I smiled again, and gave a little bow.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2035,"[' But when I raised my eyes to hers again her flush was fading, and her face showed neither contempt, nor discomfiture, but a kind of amusement.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2036,"[' In lifting my hat to her this time I had thought only, and vaguely, to correct the earlier misunderstanding; perhaps, to make her smile.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2037,"["" I said, 'I'm sorry if I frightened you the other night.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2038,"[""' She seemed embarassed at the memory, but laughed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2039,"["" 'Miss Derby,' she said with a smile.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2040,"["" I do a bit of work with a charity, finding houses for poor families that've lost their homes.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2041,"[""' She had a plain East End accent, more or less; but her voice was deep and slightly breathy.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2042,"["" 'We have been trying for ages to get our hands on some of the flats in this block here, and that night you saw me we had moved our first family in - a bit of a success for us, we are only a small affair - and Miss Derby thought we should make a party of it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2043,"[""' 'Oh yes?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2044,[' You should tell her to come and busk round here more often.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2045,"[""' 'You live there then, do you?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2046,"[""' she asked, nodding towards Mrs Milne's.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2047,[' I like to sit out on the balcony .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2048,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2049,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2050,"['"" She raised her hand to tuck away a lock of hair beneath her bonnet.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2051,"["" 'I never thought to do it,' I answered, 'before I saw you.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2052,"[""' It was the plain truth; but she laughed at it, as if to say, Oh yes.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
