2053,"[' Her teeth were even, but not perfectly white; her eyes were hazel, but the lashes not long; her hands, however, seemed graceful.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2054,"[' Her hair was the kind of hair we had all been thankful, as girls, that we did not have - for though she had bound it into a bun at her neck, the curls kept springing from it and twisting about her face.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2055,"["" And though there was something wonderfully intriguing about her tranquillity at my strange behaviour - as if women donned gents' trousers all the time; as if they made love to girls on balconies so often that she was used to it, and thought it merely naughty - I did not think I saw that trick in her, that furtive something, that I had recognised in other girls.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2056,"["" I said, 'Well, then I shall have to see you when you come again to Green Street.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2057,"["" It is better for me, since it's nearer where I live, and I know the local people; but it means I shall be spending most of my days down East.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2058,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2059,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2060,"['"" \'Oh,\' I said.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2061,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2062,"[""' I said, 'Look here, will you come to the park with me?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2063,[' I was just on my way there when I saw you.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2064,"[""' She smiled, but shook her head: 'I'm working, I couldn't.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2065,"[""' 'It's too hot for working.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2066,"[""' I only went to the theatre, now, as a renter; I wouldn't sit in a velvet seat before a stage again, even for her.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2067,[' I have a visit to make at Old Street - a lady Miss Derby knows might have some rooms for us.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2068,"[' I should be there now, really.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2069,"[""' And she frowned down at a little watch that hung from a ribbon at her breast like a medal.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2070,"["" You need a bit of ice-cream, at the least; there's an Italian lady in Kensington Gardens who sells the best ices in London, and she lets me have them at half-price .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2071,"[' The Athenaeum Hall Society Lecture Series, it said; Women and Labour: An Address by Mr- and it gave a name I now forget, followed by a little piece of explanatory text, and a date that was for four or five days ahead.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2072,"[' Else, what would happen to all our poor families?']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2073,"[""' I said, 'Lord!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2074,"[""' in an ambiguous sort of way.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2075,"["" She lifted her head, took the pamphlet back from me, and said: 'Well, 255 256 perhaps, after all, you would prefer the ice-cream cart in Kensington Gardens .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2076,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2077,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2078,"['"" There was a hint of rustiness about the words, that I found I could not bear to hear.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2079,"["" I said at once, 'Good heavens, no: this looks a treat!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2080,"[""' But I added, that if they really didn't sell ices in the hall, then I thought we ought to take some refreshment first.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2081,"["" There was, I had heard, a little public-house at the King's Cross corner of Judd Street with a ladies' room at the back of it, where they did a very nice, very inexpensive supper.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2082,"[' I said -because I thought it would please her - that I might need some instruction, in the ins and outs of the Woman Question.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2083,"[' For two days almost I had kept indoors in a kind of hot stupor, drinking endless cups of lemonade with Mrs Milne and Gracie in their darkened parlour, or dozing naked on my bed with the windows thrown open and the curtains pulled.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2084,"[' Now the promise of a night of chilly liberty on the swarming, gaudy streets of the West End drew me like a magnet.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2085,"["" I washed, and combed my hair flat and brilliant with macassar; and when I dressed I put on my favourite costume - the guardsman's uniform, with its brass buttons and its piping, its scarlet jacket and its neat little cap.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2086,"[' The military pips and buckles meant nothing to me, but I had a vague terror that some real soldier might one day recognise them, and claim me for his regiment; or else that some emergency might occur - the Queen be assaulted while I was strolling by Buckingham Palace, for instance - and I would be called upon to play some impossible role in its resolution.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2087,"["" At that she snorted, and gave me another knowing look; though what it was she thought she knew, I wasn't sure.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2088,"[' I said there was not a chance of it, held out my hand; and for a second felt her fingers, very firm and warm in their grey linen glove, clasp my own.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2089,"["" The air was cool and unnaturally clear, so that colours - the red of a painted lip, the blue of a sandwich-man's boards, the violet and the green and the yellow of a flower-girl's tray - The days that week grew ever warmer, until at last even I began to tire of the heat.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2090,"[' All London longed for a break in the weather; and on Thursday evening, when it finally came, crowds took to the streets of the city in sheer relief.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2091,"[' Girls in gay dresses walked the pavements in long, intimidating lines, or spooned with their bowler-hatted beaux on steps and benches.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2092,"[' Boys stood drinking at the doors of public-houses, their pomaded heads gleaming, in the gas-light, like silk.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2095,"[' I had ambled up and down the edges of the Square for a good ten minutes, occasionally reaching down to give a twitch to my groin - for, in the rather flamboyant spirit in which I had dressed that night, I had padded my drawers with a rolled silk cravat, instead of my usual kerchief or glove, and the material was slippery, and kept edging along my thigh.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2097,"[' I had not earned so much as a threepenny-bit: I should now have to borrow a little cash from Mrs Milne, and spend longer, more resolute, less choosy hours on the streets over the following week, until my luck turned.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2098,"[' The thought did not cheer me: renting, which had seemed such a holiday at first, had come to seem, of late, a little tiresome.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2099,"["" 259 260 It was in these spirits that I began to make my way back to Green Street - avoiding, now, the busier routes that I had trod for fun before, and taking back roads: Old Compton Street; Arthur Street; Great Russell Street, which took me by the pale, silent mass of the British Museum; and finally Guilford Street, which would lead me by the Foundling Hospital and on to the Gray's Inn Road.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2100,"[' There was a carriage moving slowly towards me out of the gloom, a private carriage with a particular, well-greased rumble I now knew for the one that had pursued me all the way from Soho, and a hunched and muffled driver I thought I recognised.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2101,"[' Its shy master, who had watched while I had posed beneath a lamppost and strolled the pavement with my fingers at my crotch, evidently fancied another look.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2102,"[' Any gent who could bring such a sense of drama to the staging of an encounter which, in the ordinary course of things, might be settled so unspectacularly - by a word, or a nod, or the fluttering of one spit-blacked lash - was clearly someone special.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2103,"[' Within, all was dark; I saw only the vague outline of a shoulder, an arm, a knee, against the lighter square of the far window.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2104,"[' Then briefly the end of a cigarette glowed bright in the blackness, and glimmered redly on a pale gloved hand, and a face.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2105,"["" 'If you won't,' she said, 'let me drive you home, then won't you, as a favour, ride with me a while?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2106,"["" I said: 'That, that's very kind of you, madam' - I sounded like a mincing shop-boy refusing a tip -'but I'm not five minutes from home, and I shall get there all the quicker if you'll let me say good- night, and pass on my way.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2108,"["" 'Look missis,' I said then, into the gloom, 'you're on the wrong track.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2110,"[""' Now I laughed: 'Believe me, I haven't got what you're after.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2112,"["" 'It's rather late,' she said, 'to be out on one's own, in streets like these.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2114,"["" I had heard stories in Soho about ladies like this - ladies who rode the darkened streets with well-paid servants, on the lookout for idle men or boys like me who'd give them a thrill for the price of a supper.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2121,"[' I felt for a second - what I had not felt, it seemed, for a hundred years - the thrill of performing with a partner at my side, someone who knew the songs, the steps, the patter, the pose .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2122,"["" She wore a dress or cloak of some sombre, heavy material, indistinguishable from the dark upholstery of the carriage's interior; her face and gloved hands, illuminated by the regular gleam of passing street-lamps, their surface fantastically marbled by the shadow of the drapes, seemed to float, pale as water- lilies, in a pool of gloom.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2126,"["" She said, 'You are, perhaps, on your way home from a costume ball?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2127,"[""' Her voice had a new, slightly arrogant drawl to it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2128,"["" I said, 'I work in a laundry, and a soldier brought this in.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2129,"[' 265 266 After the briefest of pauses her hand - as I knew it must - moved to my knee, then crept to the top of my thigh, where she let it rest.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2131,"["" Perhaps she felt me stiffen, for she removed the hand herself and said, 'I'm rather afraid that you are something of a tease.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2132,"[""' 'Oh,' I said, recovering, 'I can tease all right - if that's what you care for .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2133,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2134,"[' Why, the wait was half the pleasure!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2135,"[""' As she said it she raised the fingers of her other hand - her left hand - to my cheek.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2136,"["" I said, 'You have watched me before - before tonight!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2137,"[""' She answered: 'Well, it is rather marvellous what one may catch, from one's carriage, if one is quick and keen and patient.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2138,"["" One may follow one's quarry like a hound with a fox - and all the time the fox not know itself pursued - might think itself only about its little private business: lifting its tail, arching its eye, wiping its lips .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2144,"['"" And she turned her face to the carriage window, where the moon showed - higher and smaller than before, but still quite pink, as if ashamed to look upon the wicked world to which it was compelled to lend its light.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2146,"["" She took me to her home, in St John's Wood; and the house, as I guessed it must be, was grand - a high, pale villa in a well-swept square, with a wide front door and tall casement windows with many panes of glass.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2147,"[' In one of these a single lamp sat gleaming; the neighbouring houses, however, 267 268 presented only black, shuttered windows, and the clatter of our carriage sounded atrocious, to me, in the stillness -I was not then used to that total, unnatural hush which fills the streets and houses of the rich, when they are sleeping.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2154,['viui ^.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2156,"[' I felt a prick, now, not of desire, but of fear: her face, lit from beneath by the smoking lamp, seemed all at once macabre, grotesque.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2170,[' Beneath the wool of my uniform my nipples sprang up stiff as little sergeants; my breasts - which had grown used to being as it were put aside with my corset and chemise - seemed at her touch to rise and swell and strain against their wrappings.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2173,"["" She looked absurdly like a stage magician, producing a handkerchief or a string of flags from a fist, or an ear, or a lady's purse - and, of course, she was too clever not to know it: one dark eyebrow lifted, and her lip gave its ironical curl, and she whispered 'Presto!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2174,"[""' when the cravat was free.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2188,"[' With her hands close-pressed about my head and her legs straddling mine, she gently lowered herself upon me; then proceeded to rise and sink, rise and sink, with an ever speedier motion.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2197,"[' 275 276 And thus we clasped one another, sated and spent, our legs inelegantly straddling that elegant, high-backed chair; and as the minutes passed I thought with something like dismay of how the night would now proceed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2212,"[' To my amazement the rattle grew louder, the footsteps approached: the servant - who I thought would deposit her burden in the room next door, and discreetly take her leave - appeared in the doorway of ours, I pulled the sheet to my throat and lay quite still; neither the mistress nor the maid, however, appeared in any way discomfited by my presence there.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2220,"[' She seemed to take pleasure from seeing me eat - as last night she had liked to watch me stand, undress, light cigarettes; but, still, there was that disconcerting thoughtfulness about her, that made me long for her honest, cruel kisses of the night before.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2272,"[' When I let myself in with my house-key, therefore, it was as if I had just returned from a shopping expedition or a stroll, as I did most days; there was nothing but the length of my absence from them to hint to Mrs Milne and Gracie of my awful change of fortune.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2273,"["" I closed the door very softly; still, Grace's sharp ears must have caught the sound, for I heard her - she was in the parlour - give a cry of 'Nance!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2274,"[""', and the next moment she had come lolloping down the stairs and had me in a fierce, neck- breaking embrace.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2275,"[' \'I have other costumes,"" I said, \'at home.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2276,"[""' 'But you would rather have new ones.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2277,"[""' I frowned.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2278,"[' Gracie was fretted near half to death, poor soul, but I said to her: ""Don\'t you worry about Nancy, girl; Nancy will\'ve found some friend to take her in, or missed the last bus home, and passed the night in some rooming-house.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2279,"["" I said, 'You're right, I did meet a friend.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2280,[' It was too far to come back so late.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2281,"[""' The story sounded hollow to me, but Mrs Milne seemed pleased enough with it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2282,"["" Nancy'll be wanting a bit of tea, I don't doubt.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2283,"[""' She smiled at me again, while Gracie dutifully lumbered off; then she headed back up the stairs, and I followed.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2284,"["" 'The thing is, Mrs Milne,' I began, 'this friend of mine, she's in a bit of a state.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2285,"["" You see her room-mate up and moved out last week' - Mrs Milne checked slightly, then stepped steadily on - 'and she can't replace her; and she can't afford all the rent herself, she has only a little part-time work in a milliner's, poor thing .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2286,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2287,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2288,"['"" We had reached the parlour.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2289,"[' Mrs Milne turned to face me, and her eyes were troubled.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2290,"["" This friend of mine has asked me and, well, I said I would take the other girl's place -just to help her out, you know .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2291,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2292,[' .'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2293,"[""' 'Now don't,' I said, with an attempt at jollity, 'don't be like that; now just don't!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2294,"["" I'm not so special a boarder, heaven knows; and you'll soon find another nice girl to take my place.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2295,"[""' 'But it ain't me I'm thinking of so much,' she said, 'as Gracie.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2296,"["" You have been so good with her, Nance; there's not many as would understand her like you do; not many who would take the trouble over her little ways, the way you have.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2297,"[""' 'But I shall come back and visit,' I said reasonably.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2298,"["" 'And Grace -' I swallowed as I said it, for I knew there would never be a welcome for Gracie in the stillness and richness and elegance of Diana's villa - 'Grace can come and visit me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2299,"["" 'I know you ain't got much -' 287 288 'No, of course it ain't the money,' I said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2300,[' Not so soon?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2301,"['"" \'I did promise my friend I would,\' I said, trying to suggest by my tone that my friend might have all the blame for it.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2302,"["" 'But you'll stay for a bit of tea, at least?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2303,"[""' The thought of the dreary tea-party we would make, with Mrs Milne so ashen and disappointed, and Gracie in all probability in tears, or worse, filled me with dismay.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2304,"["" The little bits and pieces I owned, of course, could be bundled together in a second, in my sailor's bag, and a carpet-bag that Mrs Milne had once given me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2305,"[' My bedclothes I folded and placed neatly at the end of the mattress, and the rug I shook out at the open window; the few little pictures I had pinned to the wall I took down, and burned in the grate.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2306,"["" I kept only my toothbrush, and my hair-oil; these, together with an unopened tin of cigarettes and a slab of chocolate, I added to the carpet-bag - though, after a second's hesitation, I took the chocolate out again, and left it on the mantel, where I hoped Grace would find it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2307,[' In half an hour the room looked quite as it had when I had first moved in.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2308,"[' Gracie sat stiff and straight on the sofa, her face turned effortfully away, her gaze fixed unswervingly - but also, I thought, unseeingly - on the view beyond the window.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2309,"[' Mrs Milne, at lest, appeared to have reconciled herself a little to my departure, for she addressed me now with something like a smile.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2310,"["" 'Not our Gracie?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2311,"[""' I took a step towards her and reached out a hand.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2312,"[' With something like a yelp she thrust me away, and shuffled to the furthest end of the sofa, her head all the time kept at its stiff, unnatural angle.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2313,"[' I shall miss you, so; and I should hate us to part on bad terms, after all our fun together.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2314,"[""' And I went on in this fashion, half entreating, half reproachful, until Mrs Milne rose and touched my shoulder, and said quietly, 'Best leave her, Nance, and be on your way.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2315,"["" You come back and see her another day; she'll've come round by then, I don't doubt it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2316,"[""' So I had to leave, in the end, without Grace's good-bye kiss.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2317,"[' Her mother accompanied me to the front door, where we stood awkwardly before the Light of the World and the blue effeminate idol, she with her arms folded over her bosom, me hung with bags, and still clad in my scarlet duds.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2318,"[' I said that I had left my room in order; that I would send her my address (I never did, I never did!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2319,"['); and lastly that she was the best landlady in the city, and that if her next girl did not appreciate her I would make it my business to find out why.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2320,"["" 'Nance,' she said, 'don't mind me asking, but - this friend: it is a girl, ain't it?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2321,"[""' I snorted.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2322,[' Did you really think that I would - ?'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2323,"[""' That I would set up house with a man, was what she meant: me, with my trousers and my bar-bered hair!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2324,"["" 'I just thought,' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2325,"[' Two boys turning somersaults on a broken railing stopped their game to give me a playful salute: they took me for a soldier, I suppose, whose leave had all run out, and Mrs Milne for my tearful, white-haired old mother, and Gracie no doubt for my sister or my wife.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2326,"[' But for all that I waved and blew kisses, she made me no sign, simply stood with her head and her hands upon the window-pane, which pressed a whiter circle to the centre of her pale brow, and to the end of each blunt finger.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2327,"["" 'She don't love yer much,' said one of the boys; and when I had looked from him back to the house, Mrs Milne had gone.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2328,"["" Only when I had seated myself in the shadowy interior of Diana's carriage, and made fast the latch of the door, did I feel quite free of it, and secure once again on the path of my new life.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2329,"["" I had said that I would see her at the entrance to the public house at six o'clock, and it must, I thought, be past six now .""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2330,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2331,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2332,"[' Even as I thought it, the carriage slowed in the traffic and I saw her standing there, a little way along the street, waiting for me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2333,"[' The brougham crawled still slower; from behind the lace of its windows I could see her perfectly, frowning to her left and right, then bending her head to look at the watch at her bosom, then raising a hand to tuck a curl in place.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2334,"[' I had a sudden urge to tug at the latch of the door, and race down the street to her side; I could at least, I thought, call to the driver to stop his horse, so that I might shout some apology to her .']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2335,"[' But while I sat, anxious and undecided, the traffic grew swift, the carriage gave a jerk, and in a moment Judd Street and plain, kind Florence were far behind me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2336,"[' I could not bear the thought, then, of asking the forbidding Mr Shilling to turn the horse around, for all that I was his mistress for the afternoon.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2337,"["" She would be surprised, I thought, and cross, when I didn't turn up: the third woman to be disappointed by me that day.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2338,"["" The thought of that invisible linen and corsetry, which a maid's steady fingers had fastened and concealed and my own trembling hands, I guessed, would later uncover and undo, was rather thrilling.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2339,"[' I went to her, and put my hands on her, and kissed her hard upon the mouth, until she laughed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2340,[' I had woken tired and sore; I had had a dismal time at Green Street; but I did not feel dismal now - I felt limber and hot.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2341,[' We embraced for a minute or two; then she moved away and took my hand.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2342,"["" 'Come with me,' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2343,"["" 'Come with me,' she said.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2344,"["" 'I've had a room made ready for you.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2345,"[""' I was at first a little dismayed to learn that I would not be sharing Diana's chamber; but I could not stay dismayed for long.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2346,"[' The room to which she led me - it was a little way along the corridor - was hardly less imposing than her own, and quite as grand.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2347,"[' Its walls were bare and creamy-white, its carpets gold, its screen and bedstead of bamboo; its dressing-table, moreover, was crowded with goods - a cigarette-case of tortoise-shell, a pair of brushes and a comb, a button-hook of ivory, and various jars and bottles of oils and perfumes.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2348,"["" A door beside the bed led to a long, low-ceilinged closet: here, draped on a pair of wooden shoulders, was a dressing-gown of crimson silk, to match Diana's green one; and here, too, was the suit I had been promised: a handsome costume of grey worsted, terribly heavy and terribly smart.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2349,"[' I gazed at all this, then kissed Diana very hard indeed - partly, I must confess, in the hope that she would close her eyes, and thus not see how much I was in awe of her.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2350,"[' I wore my suit to supper; it looked, I knew, very well on me.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2351,"[' Diana, however, said the cut was not quite right, and that tomorrow she would have Mrs Hooper measure me properly, and send my details to a tailor.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2352,"["" I thought her faith in her housekeeper's discretion quite extraordinary; and when that lady had left us - for, as she had at lunch, she filled our plates and glasses, then stood in grave and (I thought) unnerving attendance until dismissed -I said so.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2353,"["" There's a secret to that,' she said; 'can't you guess it?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2354,"[""' 'You pay her a fortune in wages, I suppose.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2355,"[""' 'Well, perhaps.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2356,"[' After the exchange about the servants, we fell silent: I found that many of the things I said produced a kind of twitching at her lips and brow, as if my words - sensible enough to my ears - amused her; so at last I said no more, and neither did she, until the only sounds were the low hiss of the gas-jets, the steady ticking of the clock upon the mantel, and the clink of my knife and fork against my plate.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2357,"[' I thought involuntarily of those merry dinners in the Green Street parlour, with Grace and Mrs Milne.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2358,"["" 'You may go, Nancy,' she said, in exactly the tone I had heard her use on her maid and Mrs Hooper.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2359,"[' Yet I took my leave, uncomplaining, and made my way to the pale room along the hall, where my own cold bed awaited.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2360,"[' - 12 For all the strangeness of those first few days and nights at Felicity Place, it did not take me long to settle into my role there and find myself a new routine.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2361,"["" This was quite as indolent as the one I had enjoyed at Mrs Milne's; the difference, of course, was that here my indolence had a patron, a lady who paid to keep me well-fed, well-dressed and rested, and demanded only that my vanity should have herself, in return, as its larger target.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2362,"[' Often Grace would bring me tea at half-past seven or so - often, indeed, she would clamber into the warm bed beside me, and we would lie and talk till Mrs Milne called us to breakfast; later I would wash, at the great sink in the downstairs kitchen, and Grace would sometimes come and comb my hair.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2363,"[' While she was dressed I would drink my coffee and smoke a cigarette, and yawn and rub my eyes; frequently I would fall into a thin kind of slumber, and only wake again when she returned, in a coat and a hat, to slip a 297 298 gloved hand beneath the counterpane and rouse me with a pinch, or a lewd caress.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2364,"["" 'Where are you going?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2365,"[""' 'On a visit, to a friend.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2366,"[""' Take me with you!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2367,"['"" \'Not today.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2368,"[""' 'I might sit in the brougham while you make your call.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2369,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2370,['.'],Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2371,"['"" \'I would rather you were here, for me to return to.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2372,"[""' 'You are cruel!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2373,"[""' She would smile, then kiss me.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2374,"[' Now, from the crown of my head to the curve of my toe-nails, there was an unguent for every part of me - oil for my eyebrows and cream for my lashes; a jar of tooth-powder, a box of blanc- de-perle; polish for my fingernails and a scarlet stick to redden my mouth; tweezers for drawing the hairs from my nipples, and a stone to take the hard flesh from my heels.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2375,"[' It was quite like dressing for the halls again - except that then, of course, I had had to change at the side of the stage, while the band switched tempo; now, I had entire days to prink in.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2376,"["" I could not talk to the servants - to strange Mrs Hooper, with her veiled and slithering glances; or to Blake, who flustered me by curtseying to me and calling me 'miss'; or to Cook, who sent me lunch and supper, but never showed her face outside her kitchen.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2377,"["" I might hear their voices, raised in mirth or dispute, if I paused at the green baize door that led to the basement; but I knew myself apart from them, and had my own tight beat to keep to: the bedrooms, and Diana's parlour, and the drawing-room and library.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2378,"["" My mistress had said she wouldn't care to have me leave the house, unchap-eroned - indeed, she had Mrs Hooper lock the great front door: I heard her turn the key each time she stepped to close it.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2379,"[' I did not much mind my lack of liberty; as I have said, the warmth, the luxury, the kissing and the sleep made me grow stupid, and lazier than ever.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2380,"["" I might drift from room to room, soundless and thoughtless, pausing perhaps to gaze at the paintings on the walls; or at the quiet streets and gardens of St John's Wood; or at myself, in Diana's various looking-glasses.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2381,"[' I was like a spectre - the ghost, I sometimes imagined, of a handsome youth, who had died in that house and still walked its corridors and chambers, searching, searching, for reminders of the life that he had lost there.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2382,"["" 'What a scare you gave me, miss!""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2383,"[""' the maid might say, hand at her heart, after she had come upon me, lingering at a bend in the stair or in the shadows of some curtain or alcove; but when I smiled and asked what work had she to do there?""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2384,"["" she would only blush and look frightened: 'I'm sure, miss, I couldn't say.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2385,"[""' The climax of my day, the event to which my thoughts naturally tended, and which gave direction and meaning to the hours before it, was Diana's return.""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2386,"[' She might have me caress her in the library or drawing-room, heedless of the servants who passed beyond the closed door, or who knocked and, at our breathy answering silence, retired unbidden.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2387,"["" There was, of course, the dildo that I have described (though the device, or the instrument, was what I learned, following Diana, to call it: I think the unnecessary euphemism, with its particular odour of the surgery or house of correction, appealed to her; only when really heated would she call the thing by its proper name - and even then she was as likely to ask for Monsieur Dildo, or simply Moi7Sj'eur).""]",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2388,"[' Besides this there was an album of photographs of big-buttocked girls with hairless parts, bearing feathers; also a collection of erotic pamphlets and novels, all hymning the delights of what I would call tommistry but what they, like Diana, called Sapphic Passion.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
2389,"[' They were gross enough, I suppose, in their way; but I had never seen the like of them before, and would gaze at them, squirming, till Diana laughed.']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21

2390,"[' I might be weary or stupid; I might be nauseous with drink; I might be sore, at the hips, with the ache of my monthlies, but the opening of this box, as I have said, never ceased to stir me -I was like a dog twitching and slavering to hear his mistress call out Bone!']",Sarah Water,Tipping the Velvet,21
0,['Lucio and the lively Helena.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

5,[' Romeo Whose house?'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
6,[' Servant My master-s.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
7,[' Romeo Indeed I should have asked you that before.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
8,[' Servant Now I-ll tell you without asking.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
9,"[' My master is 80 the great rich Capulet; and if you be not of the house of Montagues, I pray come and crush a cup of wine.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
10,[' Rest you merry.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
11,[' [-] Benvolio At this same ancient feast of Capulet-s Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so loves; 85 With all the admired beauties of Verona.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
12,"[' Go thither, and with unattainted eye Compare her face with some that I shall show, And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

13,"[' Romeo When the devout religion of mine eye 90 Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fires; And these, who, often drowned, could never die, Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
14,[' One fairer than my love?'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
15,[' The all-seeing sun Ne-er saw her match since first the world begun.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
17,"[' Tell me, daughter Juliet, How stands your disposition to be married?']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
18,[' 65 Juliet It is an honor that I dream not of.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
19,[' Nurse An honor?'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
20,"[' Were not I thine only nurse, I would say thou hadst sucked wisdom from thy teat.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
21,"[' WifeWell, think of marriage now.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
22,"[' Younger than you, Here in Verona, ladies of esteem, 70 Are made already mothers.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
23,"[' By my count, I was your mother much upon these years That you are now a maid.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
24,[' Thus then in brief: The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
25,"[' Nurse A man, young lady!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
26,"[' lady, such a man 75 As all the world - why he-s a man of wax.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
27,[' Wife Verona-s summer hath not such a flower.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
28,"[' Nurse Nay, he-s a flower, in faith - a very flower.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
29,[' Can you love the gentleman?'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
30,[' This night you shall behold him at our feast.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

31,"[' 80 Read o-er the volume of young Paris-face, And find delight writ there with beauty-s pen, Examine every married lineament, And see how one another lends content; And what obscured in this fair volume lies 85 Find written in the margent of his eyes.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
32,"[' This precious book of love, this unbound lover, To beautify him only lacks a cover.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
33,"[' The fish lives in the sea, and -tis much pride For fair without the fair within to hide.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

34,"[' 90 That book in many-s eyes doth share the glory, That in gold clasps locks in the golden story; So shall you share all that he doth possess, By having him making yourself no less.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
35,"[' Nay, bigger!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
36,[' Women grow by men.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
37,"[' 95 Wife Speak briefly, can you like of Paris-love?']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
38,"[' Juliet I-ll look to like, if looking liking move; But no more deep will I endart mine eye Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

39,"[' [Enter Servingman] Servingman Madam, the guests are come, supper 100 served up, you called, my young lady asked for, the nurse cursed in the pantry, and everything in extremity.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
40,[' I beseech you follow straight.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
41,[' WifeWe follow thee.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
42,"[' [- Servingman] Juliet, the County stays.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

43,"[' 105 Nurse Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days The cover, of the wings of grasshoppers; 60 Her traces, of the smallest spider web; Her collars, of the moonshine-s wat-ry beams; Her whip, of cricket-s bone; the lash, of film; Her wagoner, a small grey-coated gnat, Not half so big as a round little worm 65 Pricked from the lazy finger of a maid; Her chariot is an empty hazelnut, Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub, Time out o-mind the fairies-coachmakers.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

44,"[' And in this state she gallops by night 70 Through lovers-brains, and then they dream of love; O-er courtiers-knees, that dream on curtsies straight; O-er lawyers-fingers, who straight dream on fees; O-er ladies-lips, who straight on kisses dream, Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues, 75 Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are Sometimes she gallops o-er a courtier-s nose, And then dreams he of smelling out a suit; And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig-s tail Tickling a parson-s nose as -a lies asleep, 80 Then dreams he of another benefice.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

45,"[' Sometimes she driveth o-er a soldier-s neck, And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats, Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades, Of healths five fathom deep; and then anon 85 Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes, And being thus frighted, swears a prayer or two And sleeps again.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

46,"[' This is that very Mab That plats the manes of horses in the night And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs, 90 Which once untangled much misfortune bodes.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
47,"[' This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs, That presses them and learns them first to bear, Making them women of good carriage.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
48,"[' This is she - Romeo Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
49,[' 95 Thou talk-st of nothing.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
50,"[' Mercutio True, I talk of dreams; Which are the children of an idle brain, Begot of nothing but vain fantasy; To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
51,"[' Now, by the stock and honor of my kin, To strike him dead I hold it not a sin.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
52,"[' Capulet Why, how now, kinsman?']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
53,[' Wherefore storm you so?'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
54,"['60 Tybalt Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe; A villain, that is thither come in spite To scorn at our solemnity this night.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
55,[' Capulet Young Romeo is it?'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
56,"[' Tybalt -Tis he, that villain Romeo.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

317,[' But what say you to Thursday Romeo More light and light - more dark and dark our woes.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
318,"[' [Enter NURSE, hastily] Nurse Madam!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
319,[' Juliet Nurse?'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
320,[' Nurse Your lady mother is coming to your chamber.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
321,"[' The day is broke; be wary, look about.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
322,"[' [-] 40 Juliet Then, window, let day in, and let life out.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
323,"[' Romeo Farewell, farewell!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
324,"[' One kiss, and I-ll descend.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
325,"[' [He goeth down] Juliet Art thou gone so, love-lord, ay husband-friend?']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
326,"[' I must hear from thee every day in the hour, For in a minute there are many days.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
327,"[' 45 O, by this count I shall be much in years Ere I again behold my Romeo!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
328,[' Romeo Farewell!'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
329,"[' I will omit no opportunity That may convey my greetings, love, to thee.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
330,"[' 50 Juliet O, think-st thou we shall ever meet again?']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
331,[' Romeo I doubt it not; and all these woes shall serve For sweet discourses in our times to come.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
332,"[' Juliet O God, I have an ill-divining soul!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
333,"[' Methinks I see thee, now thou art so low, 55 As one dead in the bottom of a tomb.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
334,"[' Either my eyesight fails, or thou lookest pale.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
335,"[' Romeo And trust me, love, in my eye so do you.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
336,[' Dry sorrow drinks our blood.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
337,"[' [-] Juliet O Fortune, Fortune!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
338,[' all men call thee fickle.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
339,"[' 60 If thou art fickle, what dost thou with him Capulet Peace, you mumbling fool!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
340,[' Lady You are too hot.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
341,[' Capulet God-s bread!'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
342,[' it makes me mad.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
344,"[' But, an you will not wed, I-ll pardon you!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
345,"[' Graze where you will, you shall not house with me.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
346,"[' 190 Look to-t, think on-t; I do not use to jest.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

347,"[' Thursday is near; lay hand on heart, advise: An you be mine, I-ll give you to my friend; An you be not, hang, beg, starve, die in the streets, For, by my soul, I-ll ne-er acknowledge thee, 195 Nor what is mine shall never do thee good.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
348,[' Trust to-t.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
349,[' I-ll not be forsworn.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
350,[' [-] Juliet Is there no pity in the clouds That sees into the bottom of my grief?'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
351,"[' O sweet my mother, cast me not away Friar Peace, ho, for shame!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
352,[' Confusion-s cure lives not 65 In these confusions.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
353,"[' Heaven and yourself Had part in this fair maid - now heaven hath all, And all the better is it for the maid.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
354,"[' Your part in her you could not keep from death, But heaven keeps his part in eternal life.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

355,"[' 70 The most you sought was her promotion, For -twas your heaven she should be advanced; And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
356,"[' O, in this love, you love your child so ill 75 That you run mad, seeing that she is well.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
357,"[' She-s not well married that lives married long, But she-s best married that dies married young.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

358,"[' Dry up your tears and stick your rosemary On this fair corse, and, as the custom is, 80 In all her best array bear her to church; For though fond nature bids us all lament, Yet nature-s tears are reason-s merriment.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

359,"[' Capulet All things that we ordained festival Turn from their office to black funeral - 85 Our instruments to melancholy bells, Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast; Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change; Our bridal flowers serve for buried corse; And all things change them to the contrary.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
360,"[' 90 Friar Sir, go you in; and, madam, go with him; And go, Sir Paris.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
361,[' Every one prepare To follow this fair corse unto her grave.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
364,['-[-] First Musician What a pestilent knave is this same!'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
365,"[' Second Musician Hang him, Jack!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
366,"[' Come, we-ll in here, tarry140 for the mourners, and stay dinner.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
367,"[' Romeo In faith, I will.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
368,[' Let me peruse this face.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
369,"[' Mercutio-s kinsman, noble County Paris!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
370,[' 75 What said my man when my betossed soul Did not attend him as we rode?'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
371,[' I think He told me Paris should have married Juliet.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
372,"[' Or am I mad, hearing him talk of Juliet, 80 To think it was so?']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
373,"[' O, give me thy hand, One writ with me in sour misfortune-s book!']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
374,[' I-ll bury thee in a triumphant grave.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
375,[' A grave?'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
376,"[' O, no, a lanthorn, slaught-red youth, For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes 85 This vault a feasting presence full of light.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
377,"[' Death, lie thou there, by a dead man interred.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
378,[' [Lays him in the tomb] How oft when men are at the point of death Have they been merry!'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
379,[' which their keepers call A lightning before death.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
380,"[' O, how may I 90 Call this a lightning?']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
381,[' O my love!'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
382,[' my wife!'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
383,[' my wife!'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
384,"[' Death, that hath sucked the honey of thy breath, Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
385,[' Thou art not conquered.'],William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
386,"[' Beauty-s ensign yet Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks, 95 And death-s pale flag is not advanced there.']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16
387,"[' Tybalt, liest thou there in thy bloody sheet?']",William Shakespeare,LRomeo and Juliet,16

0,"['And yet there was the dead man, and there the revolver bullet, which had mushroomed out, as soft-nosed bullets will, and so inflicted a wound which must have caused instantaneous death.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1,"[' Such were the circumstances of the Park Lane Mystery, which were further complicated by entire absence of motive, since, as I have said, young Adair was not known to have any enemy, and no attempt had been made to remove the money or valuables in the room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2,"[' All day I turned these facts over in my mind, endeavouring to hit upon some theory which could reconcile them all, and to find that line of least resistance which my poor friend had declared to be the starting-point of every investigation.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
3,"[' A group of loafers upon the pavements, all staring up at a particular window, directed me to the house which I had come to see.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

4,"[' A tall, thin man with coloured glasses, whom I strongly suspected of being a plain-clothes detective, was pointing out some theory of his own, while the others crowded round to listen to what he said.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
5,"[' As I did so I struck against an elderly deformed man, who had been behind me, and I knocked down several books which he was carrying.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
6,"[' The house was separated from the street by a low wall and railing, the whole not more than five feet high.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

7,"[' It was perfectly easy, therefore, for anyone to get into the garden, but the window was entirely inaccessible, since there was no water-pipe or anything which could help the most active man to climb it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

8,"[' To my astonishment it was none other than my strange old book-collector, his sharp, wizened face peering out from a frame of white hair, and his precious volumes, a dozen of them at least, wedged under his right arm.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
9,"[' ""You\'re surprised to see me, sir,"" said he, in a strange, croaking voice.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

10,"[' ""Well, I\'ve a conscience, sir, and when I chanced to see you go into this house, as I came hobbling after you, I thought to myself, I\'ll just step in and see that kind gentleman, and tell him that if I was a bit gruff in my manner there was not any harm meant, and that I am much obliged to him for picking up my books.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
11,"['"" ""You make too much of a trifle,"" said I.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
12,"[' ""May I ask how you knew who I was?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

13,"['"" ""Well, sir, if it isn\'t too great a liberty, I am a neighbour of yours, for you\'ll find my little bookshop at the corner of Church Street, and very happy to see you, I am sure.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
14,[' When I turned again Sherlock Holmes was standing smiling at me across my study table.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

15,"[' I rose to my feet, stared at him for some seconds in utter amazement, and then it appears that I must have fainted for the first and the last time in my life.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
16,"[' Holmes was bending over my chair, his flask in his hand.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
17,"[' ""My dear Watson,"" said the well-remembered voice, ""I owe you a thousand apologies.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
18,[' Is it possible that you succeeded in climbing out of that awful abyss?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
19,"['"" ""Wait a moment,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
20,[' I have given you a serious shock by my unnecessarily dramatic reappearance.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
21,"['"" ""I am all right, but indeed, Holmes, I can hardly believe my eyes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
22,"[' ""Well, you\'re not a spirit, anyhow,"" said I.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
23,[' Sit down and tell me how you came alive out of that dreadful chasm.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
24,"['"" He sat opposite to me and lit a cigarette in his old nonchalant manner.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

25,"[' Holmes looked even thinner and keener than of old, but there was a dead-white tinge in his aquiline face which told me that his life recently had not been a healthy one.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
26,"[' ""I am glad to stretch myself, Watson,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
27,"[' ""It is no joke when a tall man has to take a foot off his stature for several hours on end.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

28,"["" Now, my dear fellow, in the matter of these explanations we have, if I may ask for your co-operation, a hard and dangerous night's work in front of us.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
29,[' I should much prefer to hear now.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
30,"['"" ""You\'ll come with me to-night?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
31,"['"" ""When you like and where you like.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
32,"['"" ""This is indeed like the old days.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

33,[' I had little doubt that I had come to the end of my career when I perceived the somewhat sinister figure of the late Professor Moriarty standing upon the narrow pathway which led to safety.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
34,[' With my face over the brink I saw him fall for a long way.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
35,"[' Then he struck a rock, bounded off, and splashed into the water.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
36,"['"" I listened with amazement to this explanation, which Holmes delivered between the puffs of his cigarette.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
37,"[' ""I saw with my own eyes that two went down the path and none returned.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
38,"['"" ""It came about in this way.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
39,[' The instant that the Professor had disappeared it struck me what a really extraordinarily lucky chance Fate had placed in my way.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
40,[' I knew that Moriarty was not the only man who had sworn my death.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

41,"[' On the other hand, if all the world was convinced that I was dead they would take liberties, these men, they would lay themselves open, and sooner or later I could destroy them.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
42,"[' In your picturesque account of the matter, which I read with great interest some months later, you assert that the wall was sheer.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
43,"[' More than once, as tufts of grass came out in my hand or my foot slipped in the wet notches of the rock, I thought that I was gone.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

44,"[' There I was stretched when you, my dear Watson, and all your following were investigating in the most sympathetic and inefficient manner the circumstances of my death.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

45,"["" For an instant I thought that it was an accident; but a moment later, looking up, I saw a man's head against the darkening sky, and another stone struck the very ledge upon which I was stretched, within a foot of my head.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

46,[' A confederate-and even that one glance had told me how dangerous a man that confederate was-had kept guard while the Professor had attacked me.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
47,"[' ""I did not take long to think about it, Watson.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
48,"[' Again I saw that grim face look over the cliff, and I knew that it was the precursor of another stone.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
49,"[' But I had no time to think of the danger, for another stone sang past me as I hung by my hands from the edge of the ledge.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

50,"[' I took to my heels, did ten miles over the mountains in the darkness, and a week later I found myself in Florence with the certainty that no one in the world knew what had become of me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

51,"[' I owe you many apologies, my dear Watson, but it was all-important that it should be thought I was dead, and it is quite certain that you would not have written so convincing an account of my unhappy end had you not yourself thought that it was true.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

52,"[' For that reason I turned away from you this evening when you upset my books, for I was in danger at the time, and any show of surprise and emotion upon your part might have drawn attention to my identity and led to the most deplorable and irreparable results.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

53,"[' The course of events in London did not run so well as I had hoped, for the trial of the Moriarty gang left two of its most dangerous members, my own most vindictive enemies, at liberty.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

54,"[' You may have read of the remarkable explorations of a Norwegian named Sigerson, but I am sure that it never occurred to you that you were receiving news of your friend.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

55,"[' Having concluded this to my satisfaction, and learning that only one of my enemies was now left in London, I was about to return when my movements were hastened by the news of this very remarkable Park Lane Mystery, which not only appealed to me by its own merits, but which seemed to offer some most peculiar personal opportunities.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
56,"[' I came over at once to London, called in my own person at Baker Street, threw Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
57,"[' Hudson into violent hysterics, and found that Mycroft had preserved my rooms and my papers exactly as they had always been.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

58,"["" So it was, my dear Watson, that at two o'clock to-day I found myself in my old arm- chair in my own old room, and only wishing that I could have seen my old friend Watson in the other chair which he has so often adorned.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

59,"['"" Such was the remarkable narrative to which I listened on that April evening-a narrative which would have been utterly incredible to me had it not been confirmed by the actual sight of the tall, spare figure and the keen, eager face, which I had never thought to see again.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

60,"[' ""Work is the best antidote to sorrow, my dear Watson,"" said he, ""and I have a piece of work for us both to-night which, if we can bring it to a successful conclusion, will in itself justify a man\'s life on this planet.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
61,"['"" In vain I begged him to tell me more.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
62,"[' Let that suffice until half-past nine, when we start upon the notable adventure of the empty house.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

63,"['"" It was indeed like old times when, at that hour, I found myself seated beside him in a hansom, my revolver in my pocket and the thrill of adventure in my heart.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
64,[' Holmes was cold and stern and silent.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

65,"[' I knew not what wild beast we were about to hunt down in the dark jungle of criminal London, but I was well assured from the bearing of this master huntsman that the adventure was a most grave one, while the sardonic smile which occasionally broke through his ascetic gloom boded little good for the object of our quest.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
66,"[' I had imagined that we were bound for Baker Street, but Holmes stopped the cab at the corner of Cavendish Square.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

67,"[' I observed that as he stepped out he gave a most searching glance to right and left, and at every subsequent street corner he took the utmost pains to assure that he was not followed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

68,"["" Holmes's knowledge of the byways of London was extraordinary, and on this occasion he passed rapidly, and with an assured step, through a network of mews and stables the very existence of which I had never known.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
69,"[' We emerged at last into a small road, lined with old, gloomy houses, which led us into Manchester Street, and so to Blandford Street.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

70,"[' Here he turned swiftly down a narrow passage, passed through a wooden gate into a deserted yard, and then opened with a key the back door of a house.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
71,"[' The place was pitch-dark, but it was evident to me that it was an empty house.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

72,"["" Holmes's cold, thin fingers closed round my wrist and led me forwards down a long hall, until I dimly saw the murky fanlight over the door.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

73,"[' Here Holmes turned suddenly to the right, and we found ourselves in a large, square, empty room, heavily shadowed in the corners, but faintly lit in the centre from the lights of the street beyond.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
74,"[' ""Surely that is Baker Street,"" I answered, staring through the dim window.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

75,"[' Might I trouble you, my dear Watson, to draw a little nearer to the window, taking every precaution not to show yourself, and then to look up at our old rooms-the starting-point of so many of our little adventures?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
76,[' We will see if my three years of absence have entirely taken away my power to surprise you.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
77,"['"" I crept forward and looked across at the familiar window.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
78,"[' The shadow of a man who was seated in a chair within was thrown in hard, black outline upon the luminous screen of the window.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
79,"[' The face was turned half-round, and the effect was that of one of those black silhouettes which our grandparents loved to frame.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
80,[' It was a perfect reproduction of Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
81,[' So amazed was I that I threw out my hand to make sure that the man himself was standing beside me.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
82,[' The rest I arranged myself during my visit to Baker Street this afternoon.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
83,"['"" ""But why?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

84,"['"" ""Because, my dear Watson, I had the strongest possible reason for wishing certain people to think that I was there when I was really elsewhere.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
85,"['"" ""And you thought the rooms were watched?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
86,"['"" ""I KNEW that they were watched.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
87,"['"" ""By whom?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
88,"['"" ""By my old enemies, Watson.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
89,[' Sooner or later they believed that I should come back to my rooms.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
90,"[' They watched them continuously, and this morning they saw me arrive.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
91,"['"" ""How do you know?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
92,"['"" ""Because I recognised their sentinel when I glanced out of my window.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

93,"[' But I cared a great deal for the much more formidable person who was behind him, the bosom friend of Moriarty, the man who dropped the rocks over the cliff, the most cunning and dangerous criminal in London.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
94,"[' That is the man who is after me to-night, Watson, and that is the man who is quite unaware that we are after HIM.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
95,"['"" My friend\'s plans were gradually revealing themselves.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

96,"[' Holmes was silent and motionless; but I could tell that he was keenly alert, and that his eyes were fixed intently upon the stream of passers- by.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

97,"[' Once or twice it seemed to me that I had seen the same figure before, and I especially noticed two men who appeared to be sheltering themselves from the wind in the doorway of a house some distance up the street.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

98,"["" I tried to draw my companion's attention to them, but he gave a little ejaculation of impatience and continued to stare into the street.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

99,[' I was about to make some remark to him when I raised my eyes to the lighted window and again experienced almost as great a surprise as before.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
100,"["" I clutched Holmes's arm and pointed upwards.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
101,"[' ""Of course it has moved,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
102,"[' We have been in this room two hours, and Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
103,"[' Hudson has made some change in that figure eight times, or once in every quarter of an hour.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
104,"[' In the dim light I saw his head thrown forward, his whole attitude rigid with attention.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
105,"[' An instant later he pulled me back into the blackest corner of the room, and I felt his warning hand upon my lips.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
106,"[' Never had I known my friend more moved, and yet the dark street still stretched lonely and motionless before us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

107,"[' A low, stealthy sound came to my ears, not from the direction of Baker Street, but from the back of the very house in which we lay concealed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
108,"[' Holmes crouched back against the wall and I did the same, my hand closing upon the handle of my revolver.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
109,"[' Peering through the gloom, I saw the vague outline of a man, a shade blacker than the blackness of the open door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
110,"[' As he sank to the level of this opening the light of the street, no longer dimmed by the dusty glass, fell full upon his face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
111,[' His two eyes shone like stars and his features were working convulsively.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
112,"[' In his hand he carried what appeared to be a stick, but as he laid it down upon the floor it gave a metallic clang.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

113,"[' Still kneeling upon the floor he bent forward and threw all his weight and strength upon some lever, with the result that there came a long, whirling, grinding noise, ending once more in a powerful click.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

114,"[' Then, crouching down, he rested the end of the barrel upon the ledge of the open window, and I saw his long moustache droop over the stock and his eye gleam as it peered along the sights.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

115,"[' I heard a little sigh of satisfaction as he cuddled the butt into his shoulder, and saw that amazing target, the black man on the yellow ground, standing clear at the end of his fore sight.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
116,"["" At that instant Holmes sprang like a tiger on to the marksman's back and hurled him flat upon his face.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

117,"[' He was up again in a moment, and with convulsive strength he seized Holmes by the throat; but I struck him on the head with the butt of my revolver and he dropped again upon the floor.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
118,"[' ""That you, Lestrade?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
119,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
120,"[' ""Yes, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
121,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
122,"["" It's good to see you back in London, sir.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
123,"['"" ""I think you want a little unofficial help.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
124,"[' Holmes stepped up to the window, closed it, and dropped the blinds.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
125,[' I was able at last to have a good look at our prisoner.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

126,"[' With the brow of a philosopher above and the jaw of a sensualist below, the man must have started with great capacities for good or for evil.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

127,"["" But one could not look upon his cruel blue eyes, with their drooping, cynical lids, or upon the fierce, aggressive nose and the threatening, deep-lined brow, without reading Nature's plainest danger-signals.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

128,"["" He took no heed of any of us, but his eyes were fixed upon Holmes's face with an expression in which hatred and amazement were equally blended.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
129,"[' ""You clever, clever fiend!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
130,"['"" ""Ah, Colonel!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
131,"['"" said Holmes, arranging his rumpled collar; ""\'journeys end in lovers\' meetings,\' as the old play says.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

132,"["" I don't think I have had the pleasure of seeing you since you favoured me with those attentions as I lay on the ledge above the Reichenbach Fall.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
133,"['"" The Colonel still stared at my friend like a man in a trance.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
134,"[' ""I have not introduced you yet,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
135,"[' I believe I am correct, Colonel, in saying that your bag of tigers still remains unrivalled?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

136,"['"" The fierce old man said nothing, but still glared at my companion; with his savage eyes and bristling moustache he was wonderfully like a tiger himself.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
137,"[' ""I wonder that my very simple stratagem could deceive so old a shikari,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
138,[' The fury upon his face was terrible to look at.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
139,"[' ""I confess that you had one small surprise for me,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
140,"[' I had imagined you as operating from the street, where my friend Lestrade and his merry men were awaiting you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

141,"[' ""You may or may not have just cause for arresting me,"" said he, ""but at least there can be no reason why I should submit to the gibes of this person.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
142,[' If I am in the hands of the law let things be done in a legal way.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
143,"['"" ""Well, that\'s reasonable enough,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
144,"[' I commend it very specially to your attention, Lestrade, and also the bullets which fit it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
145,"['"" ""You can trust us to look after that, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
146,"[' Holmes,"" said Lestrade, as the whole party moved towards the door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
147,"[' Why, of course, the attempted murder of Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
148,[' Sherlock Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
149,"['"" ""Not so, Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
150,"[' Got whom, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
151,[' Holmes?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

152,"['"" ""The man that the whole force has been seeking in vain-Colonel Sebastian Moran, who shot the Honourable Ronald Adair with an expanding bullet from an air-gun through the open window of the second-floor front of No.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
153,"[' 427, Park Lane, upon the 30th of last month.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

154,"[' And now, Watson, if you can endure the draught from a broken window, I think that half an hour in my study over a cigar may afford you some profitable amusement.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
155,"['"" Our old chambers had been left unchanged through the supervision of Mycroft Holmes and the immediate care of Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
156,[' Hudson.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

157,"["" It stood on a small pedestal table with an old dressing-gown of Holmes's so draped round it that the illusion from the street was absolutely perfect.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
158,"[' ""I hope you preserved all precautions, Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
159,[' Hudson?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
160,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
161,[' Did you observe where the bullet went?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
162,"['"" ""Yes, sir.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
163,"["" I'm afraid it has spoilt your beautiful bust, for it passed right through the head and flattened itself on the wall.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
164,[' Here it is!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
165,"['"" Holmes held it out to me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
166,"[' And now, Watson, let me see you in your old seat once more, for there are several points which I should like to discuss with you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

167,"['"" He had thrown off the seedy frock-coat, and now he was the Holmes of old in the mouse-coloured dressing-gown which he took from his effigy.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

168,"[' ""The old shikari\'s nerves have not lost their steadiness nor his eyes their keenness,"" said he, with a laugh, as he inspected the shattered forehead of his bust.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
169,"[' ""My collection of M\'s is a fine one,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
