170,"[' ""Moriarty himself is enough to make any letter illustrious, and here is Morgan the poisoner, and Merridew of abominable memory, and Mathews, who knocked out my left canine in the waiting-room at Charing Cross, and, finally, here is our friend of to-night.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
171,"['"" He handed over the book, and I read: ""MORAN, SEBASTIAN, COLONEL.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
172,"[' Clubs: The Anglo-Indian, the Tankerville, the Bagatelle Card Club.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
173,"['"" On the margin was written, in Holmes\'s precise hand: ""The second most dangerous man in London.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
174,"['"" ""This is astonishing,"" said I, as I handed back the volume.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
175,"[' ""The man\'s career is that of an honourable soldier.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
176,"['"" ""It is true,"" Holmes answered.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

177,"[' I have a theory that the individual represents in his development the whole procession of his ancestors, and that such a sudden turn to good or evil stands for some strong influence which came into the line of his pedigree.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

178,"[' ""You may think that I read the papers with some attention during my sojourn in France, on the look-out for any chance of laying him by the heels.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
179,[' So long as he was free in London my life would really not have been worth living.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
180,"[' Night and day the shadow would have been over me, and sooner or later his chance must have come.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
181,[' He had played cards with the lad; he had followed him home from the club; he had shot him through the open window.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
182,"[' I was sure that he would make an attempt to get me out of the way AT ONCE, and would bring round his murderous weapon for that purpose.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

183,"[' I left him an excellent mark in the window, and, having warned the police that they might be needed- by the way, Watson, you spotted their presence in that doorway with unerring accuracy-I took up what seemed to me to be a judicious post for observation, never dreaming that he would choose the same spot for his attack.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
184,"[' Now, my dear Watson, does anything remain for me to explain?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
185,"['"" ""Yes,"" said I.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
186,"[' my dear Watson, there we come into those realms of conjecture where the most logical mind may be at fault.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
187,"[' Each may form his own hypothesis upon the present evidence, and yours is as likely to be correct as mine.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
188,"['"" ""You have formed one, then?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
189,"['"" ""I think that it is not difficult to explain the facts.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
190,[' It came out in evidence that Colonel Moran and young Adair had between them won a considerable amount of money.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
191,[' It is unlikely that a youngster like Adair would at once make a hideous scandal by exposing a well-known man so much older than himself.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

192,"["" He therefore murdered Adair, who at the time was endeavouring to work out how much money he should himself return, since he could not profit by his partner's foul play.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
193,[' He locked the door lest the ladies should surprise him and insist upon knowing what he was doing with these names and coins.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

194,"[' Meanwhile, come what may, Colonel Moran will trouble us no more, the famous air-gun of Von Herder will embellish the Scotland Yard Museum, and once again Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

195,[' Sherlock Holmes is free to devote his life to examining those interesting little problems which the complex life of London so plentifully presents.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
196,"['"" Ebd E-BooksDirectory.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
197,['com II.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
198,['-The Adventure of the Norwood Builder.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
199,"[' ""FROM the point of view of the criminal expert,"" said Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
200,"[' Sherlock Holmes, ""London has become a singularly uninteresting city since the death of the late lamented Professor Moriarty.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
201,"['"" ""I can hardly think that you would find many decent citizens to agree with you,"" I answered.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
202,"[' ""Well, well, I must not be selfish,"" said he, with a smile, as he pushed back his chair from the breakfast-table.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
203,"["" With that man in the field one's morning paper presented infinite possibilities.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
204,"[' Petty thefts, wanton assaults, purposeless outrage-to the man who held the clue all could be worked into one connected whole.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

205,"[' At the time of which I speak Holmes had been back for some months, and I, at his request, had sold my practice and returned to share the old quarters in Baker Street.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

206,"["" A young doctor, named Verner, had purchased my small Kensington practice, and given with astonishingly little demur the highest price that I ventured to ask-an incident which only explained itself some years later when I found that Verner was a distant relation of Holmes's, and that it was my friend who had really found the money.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

207,"[' Our months of partnership had not been so uneventful as he had stated, for I find, on looking over my notes, that this period includes the case of the papers of Ex-President Murillo, and also the shocking affair of the Dutch steamship FRIESLAND, which so nearly cost us both our lives.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
208,[' Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

209,"[' Sherlock Holmes was leaning back in his chair after his whimsical protest, and was unfolding his morning paper in a leisurely fashion, when our attention was arrested by a tremendous ring at the bell, followed immediately by a hollow drumming sound, as if someone were beating on the outer door with his fist.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

210,"[' As it opened there came a tumultuous rush into the hall, rapid feet clattered up the stair, and an instant later a wild-eyed and frantic young man, pale, dishevelled, and palpitating, burst into the room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
211,"[' ""I\'m sorry, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
212,"[' Holmes,"" he cried.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
213,[' Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
214,"[' Holmes, I am the unhappy John Hector McFarlane.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

215,"['"" He made the announcement as if the name alone would explain both his visit and its manner; but I could see by my companion\'s unresponsive face that it meant no more to him than to me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
216,"[' ""Have a cigarette, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
217,"[' McFarlane,"" said he, pushing his case across.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
218,"[' ""I am sure that with your symptoms my friend Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
219,[' Watson here would prescribe a sedative.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

220,"[' Now, if you feel a little more composed, I should be glad if you would sit down in that chair and tell us very slowly and quietly who you are and what it is that you want.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

221,"[' You mentioned your name as if I should recognise it, but I assure you that, beyond the obvious facts that you are a bachelor, a solicitor, a Freemason, and an asthmatic, I know nothing whatever about you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

222,"['"" Familiar as I was with my friend\'s methods, it was not difficult for me to follow his deductions, and to observe the untidiness of attire, the sheaf of legal papers, the watch-charm, and the breathing which had prompted them.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
223,"[' ""Yes, I am all that, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
224,"[' Holmes, and in addition I am the most unfortunate man at this moment in London.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
225,"["" For Heaven's sake don't abandon me, Mr.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
226,[' Holmes!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
227,"[' If they come to arrest me before I have finished my story, make them give me time so that I may tell you the whole truth.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
228,[' I could go to gaol happy if I knew that you were working for me outside.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
229,"['"" ""Arrest you!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
230,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
231,[' On what charge do you expect to be arrested?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
232,"['"" ""Upon the charge of murdering Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
233,"[' Jonas Oldacre, of Lower Norwood.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
234,"['"" My companion\'s expressive face showed a sympathy which was not, I am afraid, entirely unmixed with satisfaction.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
235,"[' ""Dear me,"" said he; ""it was only this moment at breakfast that I was saying to my friend, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
236,"[' Watson, that sensational cases had disappeared out of our papers.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
237,"['"" Our visitor stretched forward a quivering hand and picked up the DAILY TELEGRAPH, which still lay upon Holmes\'s knee.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
238,"[' ""If you had looked at it, sir, you would have seen at a glance what the errand is on which I have come to you this morning.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
239,"["" I feel as if my name and my misfortune must be in every man's mouth.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
240,"['"" He turned it over to expose the central page.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
241,"[' Listen to this, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
242,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
243,[' A Clue to the Criminal.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
244,"[""' That is the clue which they are already following, Mr.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
245,"[' Holmes, and I know that it leads infallibly to me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
246,"[' I have been followed from London Bridge Station, and I am sure that they are only waiting for the warrant to arrest me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
247,"[' I looked with interest upon this man, who was accused of being the perpetrator of a crime of violence.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
248,"[' ""We must use what time we have,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
249,"[' ""Watson, would you have the kindness to take the paper and to read me the paragraph in question?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

250,"['"" Underneath the vigorous head-lines which our client had quoted I read the following suggestive narrative:- Late last night, or early this morning, an incident occurred at Lower Norwood which points, it is feared, to a serious crime.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
251,[' Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
252,"[' Oldacre is a bachelor, fifty-two years of age, and lives in Deep Dene House, at the Sydenham end of the road of that name.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
253,"[' For some years he has practically withdrawn from the business, in which he is said to have amassed considerable wealth.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

254,"["" A small timber-yard still exists, however, at the back of the house, and last night, about twelve o'clock, an alarm was given that one of the stacks was on fire.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

255,"[' Surprise was expressed at the absence of the master of the establishment from the scene of the fire, and an inquiry followed, which showed that he had disappeared from the house.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

256,"[' An examination of his room revealed that the bed had not been slept in, that a safe which stood in it was open, that a number of important papers were scattered about the room, and, finally, that there were signs of a murderous struggle, slight traces of blood being found within the room, and an oaken walking-stick, which also showed stains of blood upon the handle.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
257,[' It is known that Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

258,"[' Jonas Oldacre had received a late visitor in his bedroom upon that night, and the stick found has been identified as the property of this person, who is a young London solicitor named John Hector McFarlane, junior partner of Graham and McFarlane, of 426, Gresham Buildings, E.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
259,['C.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

260,"[' The police believe that they have evidence in their possession which supplies a very convincing motive for the crime, and altogether it cannot be doubted that sensational developments will follow.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

261,"[' Besides the signs of a struggle in the room of the unfortunate builder it is now known that the French windows of his bedroom (which is on the ground floor) were found to be open, that there were marks as if some bulky object had been dragged across to the wood-pile, and, finally, it is asserted that charred remains have been found among the charcoal ashes of the fire.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

262,"[' The conduct of the criminal investigation has been left in the experienced hands of Inspector Lestrade, of Scotland Yard, who is following up the clues with his accustomed energy and sagacity.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
263,[' Sherlock Holmes listened with closed eyes and finger-tips together to this remarkable account.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
264,"[' ""The case has certainly some points of interest,"" said he, in his languid fashion.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
265,"[' ""May I ask, in the first place, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
266,"[' McFarlane, how it is that you are still at liberty, since there appears to be enough evidence to justify your arrest?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
267,"['"" ""I live at Torrington Lodge, Blackheath, with my parents, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
268,"[' Holmes; but last night, having to do business very late with Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
269,"[' Jonas Oldacre, I stayed at an hotel in Norwood, and came to my business from there.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
270,"[' I knew nothing of this affair until I was in the train, when I read what you have just heard.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
271,"[' I at once saw the horrible danger of my position, and I hurried to put the case into your hands.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
272,"[' A man followed me from London Bridge Station, and I have no doubt- Great Heaven, what is that?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
273,"['"" It was a clang of the bell, followed instantly by heavy steps upon the stair.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
274,[' A moment later our old friend Lestrade appeared in the doorway.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
275,"[' ""Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
276,[' John Hector McFarlane?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
277,"['"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
278,"[' ""I arrest you for the wilful murder of Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
279,"[' Jonas Oldacre, of Lower Norwood.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
280,"['"" McFarlane turned to us with a gesture of despair, and sank into his chair once more like one who is crushed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
281,"[' ""One moment, Lestrade,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

282,"[' ""Half an hour more or less can make no difference to you, and the gentleman was about to give us an account of this very interesting affair, which might aid us in clearing it up.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
283,"['"" ""I think there will be no difficulty in clearing it up,"" said Lestrade, grimly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
284,"[' ""None the less, with your permission, I should be much interested to hear his account.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
285,"['"" ""Well, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

286,"[' Holmes, it is difficult for me to refuse you anything, for you have been of use to the force once or twice in the past, and we owe you a good turn at Scotland Yard,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

287,"[' ""At the same time I must remain with my prisoner, and I am bound to warn him that anything he may say will appear in evidence against him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
288,"['"" ""I wish nothing better,"" said our client.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
289,"[' ""All I ask is that you should hear and recognise the absolute truth.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
290,"['"" Lestrade looked at his watch.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
291,"[' ""I\'ll give you half an hour,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
292,"[' ""I must explain first,"" said McFarlane, ""that I knew nothing of Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
293,[' Jonas Oldacre.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
294,"[' He had in his hand several sheets of a note-book, covered with scribbled writing- here they are-and he laid them on my table.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

295,"[' He was a strange little, ferret-like man, with white eyelashes, and when I looked up at him I found his keen grey eyes fixed upon me with an amused expression.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

296,"[' I could hardly believe my own senses as I read the terms of the will; but he explained that he was a bachelor with hardly any living relation, that he had known my parents in his youth, and that he had always heard of me as a very deserving young man, and was assured that his money would be in worthy hands.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

297,"[' He said that his mind would not be easy until the whole thing was settled, and he begged me to come out to his house at Norwood that night, bringing the will with me, and to arrange matters.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
298,"[' ""You can imagine, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
299,"[' Holmes, that I was not in a humour to refuse him anything that he might ask.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

300,"[' I sent a telegram home, therefore, to say that I had important business on hand, and that it was impossible for me to say how late I might be.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
301,"[' I found him-"" ""One moment!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
302,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
303,"[' ""Who opened the door?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
304,"['"" ""A middle-aged woman, who was, I suppose, his housekeeper.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
305,"['"" ""And it was she, I presume, who mentioned your name?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
306,"['"" ""Exactly,"" said McFarlane.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
307,"[' He showed me out through his own French window, which had been open all this time.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
308,"['"" ""Was the blind down?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
309,"['"" asked Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
310,"[' Yes, I remember how he pulled it up in order to swing open the window.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

311,"["" I could not find my stick, and he said, 'Never mind, my boy; I shall see a good deal of you now, I hope, and I will keep your stick until you come back to claim it.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
312,"[""' I left him there, the safe open, and the papers made up in packets upon the table.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

313,"[' It was so late that I could not get back to Blackheath, so I spent the night at the Anerley Arms, and I knew nothing more until I read of this horrible affair in the morning.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
314,"['"" ""Anything more that you would like to ask, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
315,[' Holmes?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
316,"['"" said Lestrade, whose eyebrows had gone up once or twice during this remarkable explanation.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
317,"[' ""Not until I have been to Blackheath.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
318,"['"" ""You mean to Norwood,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
319,"[' ""Oh, yes; no doubt that is what I must have meant,"" said Holmes, with his enigmatical smile.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
320,"[' ""I think I should like to have a word with you presently, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
321,"[' Sherlock Holmes,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
322,"[' ""Now, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
323,"[' McFarlane, two of my constables are at the door and there is a four-wheeler waiting.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
324,"['"" The wretched young man arose, and with a last beseeching glance at us walked from the room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

325,"[' Holmes had picked up the pages which formed the rough draft of the will, and was looking at them with the keenest interest upon his face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
326,"[' ""There are some points about that document, Lestrade, are there not?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
327,"['"" said he, pushing them over.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

328,"[' Those are as clear as print,"" said he; ""but the writing in between is very bad, and there are three places where I cannot read it at all.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
329,"['"" ""What do you make of that?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
330,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

331,"[' Granting that his whole journey was occupied in drawing up the will, then the train was an express, only stopping once between Norwood and London Bridge.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
332,"['"" Lestrade began to laugh.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
333,"[' ""You are too many for me when you begin to get on your theories, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
334,"[' Holmes,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
335,"[' ""How does this bear on the case?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
336,"['"" ""Well, it corroborates the young man\'s story to the extent that the will was drawn up by Jonas Oldacre in his journey yesterday.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
337,[' If a man drew up a will which he did not intend ever to be effective he might do it so.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
338,"['"" ""Well, he drew up his own death-warrant at the same time,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
339,"[' ""Oh, you think so?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
340,"['"" ""Don\'t you?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
341,"['"" ""Well, it is quite possible; but the case is not clear to me yet.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
342,"['"" ""Not clear?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

343,"["" He says nothing to anyone, but he arranges that he shall go out on some pretext to see his client that night; he waits until the only other person in the house is in bed, and then in the solitude of a man's room he murders him, burns his body in the wood-pile, and departs to a neighbouring hotel.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

344,"[' It is probable that he imagined his crime to be a bloodless one, and hoped that if the body were consumed it would hide all traces of the method of his death-traces which for some reason must have pointed to him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
345,[' Is all this not obvious?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
346,"['"" ""It strikes me, my good Lestrade, as being just a trifle too obvious,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

347,"[' ""You do not add imagination to your other great qualities; but if you could for one moment put yourself in the place of this young man, would you choose the very night after the will had been made to commit your crime?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
348,"[' Confess, Lestrade, that all this is very unlikely.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
349,"['"" ""As to the stick, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
350,"[' Holmes, you know as well as I do that a criminal is often flurried and does things which a cool man would avoid.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
351,[' Give me another theory that would fit the facts.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
352,"['"" ""I could very easily give you half-a-dozen,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
353,[' The older man is showing documents which are of evident value.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
354,"[' He seizes a stick, which he observes there, kills Oldacre, and departs after burning the body.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
355,"['"" ""Why should the tramp burn the body?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
356,"['"" ""For the matter of that why should McFarlane?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
357,"['"" ""To hide some evidence.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
358,"['"" ""Possibly the tramp wanted to hide that any murder at all had been committed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
359,"['"" ""And why did the tramp take nothing?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
360,"['"" ""Because they were papers that he could not negotiate.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
361,"['"" Lestrade shook his head, though it seemed to me that his manner was less absolutely assured than before.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
362,"[' ""Well, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
363,"[' Sherlock Holmes, you may look for your tramp, and while you are finding him we will hold on to our man.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
364,"[' Just notice this point, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

365,"[' Holmes: that so far as we know none of the papers were removed, and that the prisoner is the one man in the world who had no reason for removing them, since he was heir-at-law and would come into them in any case.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
366,"['"" My friend seemed struck by this remark.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
367,"[' ""I don\'t mean to deny that the evidence is in some ways very strongly in favour of your theory,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
368,[' I dare say that in the course of the day I shall drop in at Norwood and see how you are getting on.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

369,"['"" When the detective departed my friend rose and made his preparations for the day\'s work with the alert air of a man who has a congenial task before him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
370,"[' ""My first movement, Watson,"" said he, as he bustled into his frock-coat, ""must, as I said, be in the direction of Blackheath.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
371,"['"" ""And why not Norwood?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
372,"['"" ""Because we have in this case one singular incident coming close to the heels of another singular incident.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

373,"[' But it is evident to me that the logical way to approach the case is to begin by trying to throw some light upon the first incident-the curious will, so suddenly made, and to so unexpected an heir.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
374,"["" No, my dear fellow, I don't think you can help me.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

375,[' I trust that when I see you in the evening I will be able to report that I have been able to do something for this unfortunate youngster who has thrown himself upon my protection.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

376,"['"" It was late when my friend returned, and I could see by a glance at his haggard and anxious face that the high hopes with which he had started had not been fulfilled.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
377,"[' I kept a bold face before Lestrade, but, upon my soul, I believe that for once the fellow is on the right track and we are on the wrong.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

378,"["" All my instincts are one way and all the facts are the other, and I much fear that British juries have not yet attained that pitch of intelligence when they will give the preference to my theories over Lestrade's facts.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
379,"['"" ""Did you go to Blackheath?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
380,"['"" ""Yes, Watson, I went there, and I found very quickly that the late lamented Oldacre was a pretty considerable black-guard.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

381,"[' On the contrary, she spoke of him with such bitterness that she was unconsciously considerably strengthening the case of the police, for, of course, if her son had heard her speak of the man in this fashion it would predispose him towards hatred and violence.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
382,"["" 'He was more like a malignant and cunning ape than a human being,' said she, 'and he always was, ever since he was a young man.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
383,"['\' ""\'You knew him at that time?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
384,"[""' said I.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
385,"[' Thank Heaven that I had the sense to turn away from him and to marry a better, if a poorer, man.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
386,"[' I was engaged to him, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

387,"[' Holmes, when I heard a shocking story of how he had turned a cat loose in an aviary, and I was so horrified at his brutal cruelty that I would have nothing more to do with him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
388,"[""' She rummaged in a bureau, and presently she produced a photograph of a woman, shamefully defaced and mutilated with a knife.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
389,"["" 'That is my own photograph,' she said.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
390,"["" 'He sent it to me in that state, with his curse, upon my wedding morning.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
391,"['\' ""\'Well,\' said I, \'at least he has forgiven you now, since he has left all his property to your son.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
392,"['\' ""\'Neither my son nor I want anything from Jonas Oldacre, dead or alive,\' she cried, with a proper spirit.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
393,"["" 'There is a God in Heaven, Mr.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

394,"["" Holmes, and that same God who has punished that wicked man will show in His own good time that my son's hands are guiltless of his blood.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

395,"['\' ""Well, I tried one or two leads, but could get at nothing which would help our hypothesis, and several points which would make against it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
396,"["" This window on the left is the one which opens into Oldacre's room.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
397,"[' I examined the contents of the safe, most of which had been taken out and left on the table.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

398,"["" This, of course, if we could definitely prove it, would turn Lestrade's argument against himself, for who would steal a thing if he knew that he would shortly inherit it?""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
399,[' Mrs.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
400,"[' Lexington is her name, a little, dark, silent person, with suspicious and sidelong eyes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
401,"[' Her room was at the other end of the house, and she could hear nothing of what passed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
402,"[' Her poor, dear master had certainly been murdered.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
403,"[' Well, every man had enemies, but Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
404,"[' Oldacre kept himself very much to himself, and only met people in the way of business.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
405,"[' It burned like tinder, and by the time she reached the spot nothing could be seen but flames.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
406,"[' There is something that has not come out, and that housekeeper knows it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

407,"["" However, there's no good talking any more about it, Watson; but unless some lucky chance comes our way I fear that the Norwood Disappearance Case will not figure in that chronicle of our successes which I foresee that a patient public will sooner or later have to endure.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
408,"['"" ""Surely,"" said I, ""the man\'s appearance would go far with any jury?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
409,"['"" ""That is a dangerous argument, my dear Watson.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
410,"[' By the way, there is one curious little point about those papers which may serve us as the starting-point for an inquiry.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

411,[' On looking over the bank-book I found that the low state of the balance was principally due to large cheques which have been made out during the last year to Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
412,[' Cornelius.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

413,"[' But I fear, my dear fellow, that our case will end ingloriously by Lestrade hanging our client, which will certainly be a triumph for Scotland Yard.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

414,"['"" I do not know how far Sherlock Holmes took any sleep that night, but when I came down to breakfast I found him pale and harassed, his bright eyes the brighter for the dark shadows round them.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
415,[' The carpet round his chair was littered with cigarette-ends and with the early editions of the morning papers.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
416,"[' ""What do you think of this, Watson?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
417,"['"" he asked, tossing it across.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
418,"[' It was from Norwood, and ran as follows:- ""IMPORTANT FRESH EVIDENCE TO HAND.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
419,"[' ""It is Lestrade\'s little cock-a-doodle of victory,"" Holmes answered, with a bitter smile.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

420,"[' After all, important fresh evidence is a two-edged thing, and may possibly cut in a very different direction to that which Lestrade imagines.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
421,[' I feel as if I shall need your company and your moral support to-day.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

422,"['"" My friend had no breakfast himself, for it was one of his peculiarities that in his more intense moments he would permit himself no food, and I have known him presume upon his iron strength until he has fainted from pure inanition.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
423,"[' ""Well, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
424,"[' Holmes, have you proved us to be wrong yet?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

425,"[' ""But we formed ours yesterday, and now it proves to be correct; so you must acknowledge that we have been a little in front of you this time, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
426,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
427,"['"" ""You certainly have the air of something unusual having occurred,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
428,"[' ""You don\'t like being beaten any more than the rest of us do,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
429,"[' ""A man can\'t expect always to have it his own way, can he, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
430,[' Watson?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
431,"[' Step this way, if you please, gentlemen, and I think I can convince you once for all that it was John McFarlane who did this crime.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
432,"['"" He led us through the passage and out into a dark hall beyond.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
433,"[' ""This is where young McFarlane must have come out to get his hat after the crime was done,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
434,"[' ""Now, look at this.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
435,"['"" With dramatic suddenness he struck a match and by its light exposed a stain of blood upon the whitewashed wall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
436,"[' ""Look at that with your magnifying glass, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
437,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
438,"['"" ""Yes, I am doing so.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
439,"['"" ""You are aware that no two thumb marks are alike?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
440,"['"" ""I have heard something of the kind.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

441,"['"" ""Well, then, will you please compare that print with this wax impression of young McFarlane\'s right thumb, taken by my orders this morning?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

442,"['"" As he held the waxen print close to the blood-stain it did not take a magnifying glass to see that the two were undoubtedly from the same thumb.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
443,"[' ""That is final,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
444,"[' ""It is final,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
445,[' An extraordinary change had come over his face.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
446,[' Dear me!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
447,"['"" he said at last.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
448,[' Such a nice young man to look at!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
449,"[' It is a lesson to us not to trust our own judgment, is it not, Lestrade?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
450,"['"" ""Yes, some of us are a little too much inclined to be cocksure, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
451,"[' Holmes,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
452,"[' ""What a providential thing that this young man should press his right thumb against the wall in taking his hat from the peg!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
453,"[' Such a very natural action, too, if you come to think of it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
454,"['"" Holmes was outwardly calm, but his whole body gave a wriggle of suppressed excitement as he spoke.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
455,"[' ""By the way, Lestrade, who made this remarkable discovery?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
456,"['"" ""It was the housekeeper, Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
457,"["" Lexington, who drew the night constable's attention to it.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
458,"['"" ""Where was the night constable?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
459,"['"" ""He remained on guard in the bedroom where the crime was committed, so as to see that nothing was touched.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
460,"['"" ""But why didn\'t the police see this mark yesterday?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
461,"['"" ""Well, we had no particular reason to make a careful examination of the hall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
462,[' I suppose there is no doubt that the mark was there yesterday?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
463,"['"" Lestrade looked at Holmes as if he thought he was going out of his mind.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

464,"[' ""I don\'t know whether you think that McFarlane came out of gaol in the dead of the night in order to strengthen the evidence against himself,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
465,"[' ""I leave it to any expert in the world whether that is not the mark of his thumb.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
466,"['"" ""It is unquestionably the mark of his thumb.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
467,"['"" ""There, that\'s enough,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
468,"[' ""I am a practical man, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
469,"[' Holmes, and when I have got my evidence I come to my conclusions.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
470,[' If you have anything to say you will find me writing my report in the sitting-room.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
471,"['"" Holmes had recovered his equanimity, though I still seemed to detect gleams of amusement in his expression.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
472,"[' ""Dear me, this is a very sad development, Watson, is it not?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
473,"['"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
474,"[' ""And yet there are singular points about it which hold out some hopes for our client.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
475,"['"" ""I am delighted to hear it,"" said I, heartily.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
476,"[' ""I was afraid it was all up with him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
477,"['"" ""I would hardly go so far as to say that, my dear Watson.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
478,[' The fact is that there is one really serious flaw in this evidence to which our friend attaches so much importance.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
479,"['"" ""Indeed, Holmes!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
480,[' What is it?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
481,"['"" ""Only this: that I KNOW that that mark was not there when I examined the hall yesterday.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
482,"[' And now, Watson, let us have a little stroll round in the sunshine.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

483,"['"" With a confused brain, but with a heart into which some warmth of hope was returning, I accompanied my friend in a walk round the garden.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
484,[' Holmes took each face of the house in turn and examined it with great interest.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
485,"[' Most of the rooms were unfurnished, but none the less Holmes inspected them all minutely.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
486,"[' ""There are really some very unique features about this case, Watson,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
487,"[' ""I think it is time now that we took our friend Lestrade into our confidence.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
488,"[' Yes, yes; I think I see how we should approach it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
489,"['"" The Scotland Yard inspector was still writing in the parlour when Holmes interrupted him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
490,"[' ""I understood that you were writing a report of this case,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
491,"["" I can't help thinking that your evidence is not complete.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
492,"['"" Lestrade knew my friend too well to disregard his words.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
493,"[' ""What do you mean, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
494,[' Holmes?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
495,"['"" ""Only that there is an important witness whom you have not seen.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
496,"['"" ""Can you produce him?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
497,"['"" ""I think I can.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
498,"['"" ""Then do so.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
499,"['"" ""I will do my best.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
500,[' How many constables have you?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
501,"['"" ""There are three within call.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
502,"['"" ""Excellent!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
503,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
504,"[' ""May I ask if they are all large, able-bodied men with powerful voices?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
505,"['"" ""I have no doubt they are, though I fail to see what their voices have to do with it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
506,"['"" ""Perhaps I can help you to see that and one or two other things as well,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
507,"[' ""In the outhouse you will find a considerable quantity of straw,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
508,"[' Now, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
509,"[' Lestrade, I will ask you all to accompany me to the top landing.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
510,"['"" As I have said, there was a broad corridor there, which ran outside three empty bedrooms.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

511,"[' At one end of the corridor we were all marshalled by Sherlock Holmes, the constables grinning and Lestrade staring at my friend with amazement, expectation, and derision chasing each other across his features.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
512,[' Holmes stood before us with the air of a conjurer who is performing a trick.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
513,[' Now I think that we are all ready.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
514,"['"" Lestrade\'s face had begun to grow red and angry.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
515,"[' ""I don\'t know whether you are playing a game with us, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
516,"[' Sherlock Holmes,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
517,"[' ""If you know anything, you can surely say it without all this tomfoolery.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
518,"['"" ""I assure you, my good Lestrade, that I have an excellent reason for everything that I do.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
519,"[' Might I ask you, Watson, to open that window, and then to put a match to the edge of the straw?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
520,"['"" I did so, and, driven by the draught, a coil of grey smoke swirled down the corridor, while the dry straw crackled and flamed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

521,"[' A door suddenly flew open out of what appeared to be solid wall at the end of the corridor, and a little, wizened man darted out of it, like a rabbit out of its burrow.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
522,"[' ""Capital!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
523,"['"" said Holmes, calmly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
524,"[' Lestrade, allow me to present you with your principal missing witness, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
525,[' Jonas Oldacre.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
526,"['"" The detective stared at the new-comer with blank amazement.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
527,"[' ""What have you been doing all this time, eh?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
528,"['"" Oldacre gave an uneasy laugh, shrinking back from the furious red face of the angry detective.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
529,[' Take him down and keep him in the sitting-room until I come.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
530,[' Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
531,"[' Holmes,"" he continued, when they had gone, ""I could not speak before the constables, but I don\'t mind saying, in the presence of Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
532,"[' Watson, that this is the brightest thing that you have done yet, though it is a mystery to me how you did it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

533,"["" You have saved an innocent man's life, and you have prevented a very grave scandal, which would have ruined my reputation in the Force.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
534,"['"" Holmes smiled and clapped Lestrade upon the shoulder.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

535,"[' Just make a few alterations in that report which you were writing, and they will understand how hard it is to throw dust in the eyes of Inspector Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
536,"['"" ""And you don\'t want your name to appear?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
537,"['"" ""Not at all.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
538,"[' Well, now, let us see where this rat has been lurking.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
539,"['"" A lath-and-plaster partition had been run across the passage six feet from the end, with a door cunningly concealed in it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
540,"[' ""There\'s the advantage of being a builder,"" said Holmes, as we came out.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

541,"[' ""He was able to fix up his own little hiding-place without any confederate-save, of course, that precious housekeeper of his, whom I should lose no time in adding to your bag, Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
542,"['"" ""I\'ll take your advice.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
543,"[' But how did you know of this place, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
544,[' Holmes?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
545,"['"" ""I made up my mind that the fellow was in hiding in the house.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

546,"[' We could, of course, have gone in and taken him, but it amused me to make him reveal himself; besides, I owed you a little mystification, Lestrade, for your chaff in the morning.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
547,"['"" ""Well, sir, you certainly got equal with me on that.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
548,[' But how in the world did you know that he was in the house at all?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
549,"['"" ""The thumb-mark, Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
550,"[' You said it was final; and so it was, in a very different sense.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

551,"[' I pay a good deal of attention to matters of detail, as you may have observed, and I had examined the hall and was sure that the wall was clear.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
552,[' It would be done so quickly and so naturally that I dare say the young man himself has no recollection of it.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

553,"[' Brooding over the case in that den of his, it suddenly struck him what absolutely damning evidence he could make against McFarlane by using that thumb-mark.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

554,"[' It was the simplest thing in the world for him to take a wax impression from the seal, to moisten it in as much blood as he could get from a pin-prick, and to put the mark upon the wall during the night, either with his own hand or with that of his housekeeper.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

555,[' If you examine among those documents which he took with him into his retreat I will lay you a wager that you find the seal with the thumb-mark upon it.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
556,"['"" ""Wonderful!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
557,"['"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
558,"[' But what is the object of this deep deception, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
559,[' Holmes?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

560,"['"" It was amusing to me to see how the detective\'s overbearing manner had changed suddenly to that of a child asking questions of its teacher.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
561,"[' He intended to change his name altogether, draw this money, and vanish, starting life again elsewhere.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
562,"['"" ""Well, that\'s likely enough.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

563,"['"" ""It would strike him that in disappearing he might throw all pursuit off his track, and at the same time have an ample and crushing revenge upon his old sweetheart, if he could give the impression that he had been murdered by her only child.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

564,"[' ""I assure you, sir, that I simply concealed myself in order to see the effect of my disappearance, and I am sure that you would not be so unjust as to imagine that I would have allowed any harm to befall poor young Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
565,[' McFarlane.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
566,"['"" ""That\'s for a jury to decide,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
567,"[' ""Anyhow, we shall have you on a charge of conspiracy, if not for attempted murder.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
568,"['"" ""And you\'ll probably find that your creditors will impound the banking account of Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
569,"[' Cornelius,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
570,[' The little man started and turned his malignant eyes upon my friend.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
571,"[' ""I have to thank you for a good deal,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
572,"[' ""Perhaps I\'ll pay my debt some day.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
573,"['"" Holmes smiled indulgently.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
574,"[' ""I fancy that for some few years you will find your time very fully occupied,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
575,"[' If ever you write an account, Watson, you can make rabbits serve your turn.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
576,"['"" Ebd E-BooksDirectory.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
577,['com III.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
578,['-The Adventure of the Dancing Men.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

579,"[' HOLMES had been seated for some hours in silence with his long, thin back curved over a chemical vessel in which he was brewing a particularly malodorous product.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

580,"[' His head was sunk upon his breast, and he looked from my point of view like a strange, lank bird, with dull grey plumage and a black top-knot.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
581,"[' ""So, Watson,"" said he, suddenly, ""you do not propose to invest in South African securities?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
582,"['"" I gave a start of astonishment.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
583,"["" Accustomed as I was to Holmes's curious faculties, this sudden intrusion into my most intimate thoughts was utterly inexplicable.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
584,"[' He wheeled round upon his stool, with a steaming test-tube in his hand and a gleam of amusement in his deep-set eyes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
585,"[' ""Now, Watson, confess yourself utterly taken aback,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
586,"[' ""I am.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
587,"['"" ""I ought to make you sign a paper to that effect.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
588,"['"" ""Why?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
589,"['"" ""Because in five minutes you will say that it is all so absurdly simple.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
590,"['"" ""I am sure that I shall say nothing of the kind.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

591,"['"" ""You see, my dear Watson""-he propped his test-tube in the rack and began to lecture with the air of a professor addressing his class-""it is not really difficult to construct a series of inferences, each dependent upon its predecessor and each simple in itself.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

592,"[' Now, it was not really difficult, by an inspection of the groove between your left forefinger and thumb, to feel sure that you did NOT propose to invest your small capital in the goldfields.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
593,"['"" ""I see no connection.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
594,"['"" ""Very likely not; but I can quickly show you a close connection.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
595,"[' ""Quite so!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
596,"['"" said he, a little nettled.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
597,"[' See what you can make of that, friend Watson.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
598,"['"" He tossed a sheet of paper upon the table and turned once more to his chemical analysis.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
599,[' I looked with amazement at the absurd hieroglyphics upon the paper.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
600,"[' ""Why, Holmes, it is a child\'s drawing,"" I cried.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
601,"[' This little conundrum came by the first post, and he was to follow by the next train.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
602,[' I should not be very much surprised if this were he.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

603,"['"" A heavy step was heard upon the stairs, and an instant later there entered a tall, ruddy, clean-shaven gentleman, whose clear eyes and florid cheeks told of a life led far from the fogs of Baker Street.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

604,"[' Having shaken hands with each of us, he was about to sit down when his eye rested upon the paper with the curious markings, which I had just examined and left upon the table.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
605,"[' ""Well, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
606,"[' Holmes, what do you make of these?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
607,"['"" he cried.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
608,"[' ""Well, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
609,"[' Holmes, what do you make of these?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
610,"['"" he cried.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
611,[' I sent the paper on ahead so that you might have time to study it before I came.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
612,"['"" ""It is certainly rather a curious production,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
613,[' It consists of a number of absurd little figures dancing across the paper upon which they are drawn.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
614,[' Why should you attribute any importance to so grotesque an object?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
615,"['"" ""I never should, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
616,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
617,"["" That's why I want to sift the matter to the bottom.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
618,"['"" Holmes held up the paper so that the sunlight shone full upon it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

619,"[' The markings were done in pencil, and ran in this way:- GRAPHIC Holmes examined it for some time, and then, folding it carefully up, he placed it in his pocket-book.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
620,"[' ""This promises to be a most interesting and unusual case,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
621,"[' ""You gave me a few particulars in your letter, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
622,"[' Hilton Cubitt, but I should be very much obliged if you would kindly go over it all again for the benefit of my friend, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
623,[' Watson.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
624,"['"" ""I\'m not much of a story-teller,"" said our visitor, nervously clasping and unclasping his great, strong hands.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

625,"["" I'll begin at the time of my marriage last year; but I want to say first of all that, though I'm not a rich man, my people have been at Ridling Thorpe for a matter of five centuries, and there is no better known family in the County of Norfolk.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

626,"[' Last year I came up to London for the Jubilee, and I stopped at a boarding-house in Russell Square, because Parker, the vicar of our parish, was staying in it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
627,"[' In some way we became friends, until before my month was up I was as much in love as a man could be.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
628,"["" You'll think it very mad, Mr.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

629,"[' Holmes, that a man of a good old family should marry a wife in this fashion, knowing nothing of her past or of her people; but if you saw her and knew her it would help you to understand.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
630,"["" 'I have had some very disagreeable associations in my life,' said she; 'I wish to forget all about them.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

631,"[' If you take me, Hilton, you will take a woman who has nothing that she need be personally ashamed of; but you will have to be content with my word for it, and to allow me to be silent as to all that passed up to the time when I became yours.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
632,"[' If these conditions are too hard, then go back to Norfolk and leave me to the lonely life in which you found me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
633,"[""' It was only the day before our wedding that she said those very words to me.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
634,"[' But about a month ago, at the end of June, I saw for the first time signs of trouble.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
635,"[' Mind you, she is a truthful woman, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
636,"[' Holmes, and whatever trouble there may have been in her past life it has been no fault of hers.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

637,"[' About a week ago-it was the Tuesday of last week-I found on one of the window-sills a number of absurd little dancing figures, like these upon the paper.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
638,"[' Anyhow, they had come there during the night.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
639,"[' To my surprise she took it very seriously, and begged me if any more came to let her see them.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
640,"[' None did come for a week, and then yesterday morning I found this paper lying on the sun-dial in the garden.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
641,"[' Since then she has looked like a woman in a dream, half dazed, and with terror always lurking in her eyes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
642,"[' It was then that I wrote and sent the paper to you, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
643,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
644,[' I am not a rich man; but if there is any danger threatening my little woman I would spend my last copper to shield her.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

645,"['"" He was a fine creature, this man of the old English soil, simple, straight, and gentle, with his great, earnest blue eyes and broad, comely face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
646,"[' Holmes had listened to his story with the utmost attention, and now he sat for some time in silent thought.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
647,"[' ""Don\'t you think, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

648,"[' Cubitt,"" said he, at last, ""that your best plan would be to make a direct appeal to your wife, and to ask her to share her secret with you?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
649,"['"" Hilton Cubitt shook his massive head.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
650,"[' ""A promise is a promise, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
651,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

652,"[' I would suggest that you return to Norfolk, that you keep a keen look-out, and that you take an exact copy of any fresh dancing men which may appear.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
653,[' If there are any pressing fresh developments I shall be always ready to run down and see you in your Norfolk home.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

654,"['"" The interview left Sherlock Holmes very thoughtful, and several times in the next few days I saw him take his slip of paper from his note-book and look long and earnestly at the curious figures inscribed upon it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
655,[' I gather from his wire that there have been some new incidents of importance.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
656,"['"" We had not long to wait, for our Norfolk squire came straight from the station as fast as a hansom could bring him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
657,"[' ""It\'s getting on my nerves, this business, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
658,"[' Holmes,"" said he, as he sank, like a wearied man, into an arm-chair.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
659,"["" She's wearing away under it- just wearing away before my eyes.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
660,"['"" ""Has she said anything yet?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
661,"['"" ""No, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
662,"[' Holmes, she has not.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

663,"[' She has spoken about my old family, and our reputation in the county, and our pride in our unsullied honour, and I always felt it was leading to the point; but somehow it turned off before we got there.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
664,"['"" ""But you have found out something for yourself?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
665,"['"" ""A good deal, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
666,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
667,"[' I have several fresh dancing men pictures for you to examine, and, what is more important, I have seen the fellow.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
668,"['"" ""What, the man who draws them?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
669,"['"" ""Yes, I saw him at his work.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
670,"[' When I got back after my visit to you, the very first thing I saw next morning was a fresh crop of dancing men.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

671,"[' They had been drawn in chalk upon the black wooden door of the tool-house, which stands beside the lawn in full view of the front windows.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
672,"[' Here is a copy of the hieroglyphics:- GRAPHIC ""Excellent!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
673,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
674,[' Pray continue.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
675,"['"" ""When I had taken the copy I rubbed out the marks; but two mornings later a fresh inscription had appeared.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
676,"[' I have a copy of it here"":- GRAPHIC Holmes rubbed his hands and chuckled with delight.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
677,"[' ""Three days later a message was left scrawled upon paper, and placed under a pebble upon the sun-dial.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

678,"[' About two in the morning I was seated by the window, all being dark save for the moonlight outside, when I heard steps behind me, and there was my wife in her dressing-gown.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
679,"[' ""\'If it really annoys you, Hilton, we might go and travel, you and I, and so avoid this nuisance.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
680,"['\' ""\'What, be driven out of our own house by a practical joker?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
681,"[""' said I.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
682,"["" 'Why, we should have the whole county laughing at us.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
683,"['\' ""\'Well, come to bed,\' said she, \'and we can discuss it in the morning.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
684,"['\' ""Suddenly, as she spoke, I saw her white face grow whiter yet in the moonlight, and her hand tightened upon my shoulder.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
685,"[' I saw a dark, creeping figure which crawled round the corner and squatted in front of the door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
686,"[' At last I got clear, but by the time I had opened the door and reached the house the creature was gone.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

687,"[' He had left a trace of his presence, however, for there on the door was the very same arrangement of dancing men which had already twice appeared, and which I have copied on that paper.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

688,"[' And yet the amazing thing is that he must have been there all the time, for when I examined the door again in the morning he had scrawled some more of his pictures under the line which I had already seen.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
689,"['"" ""Have you that fresh drawing?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
690,"['"" ""Yes; it is very short, but I made a copy of it, and here it is.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
691,"['"" Again he produced a paper.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

692,"[' The new dance was in this form:- GRAPHIC ""Tell me,"" said Holmes-and I could see by his eyes that he was much excited- ""was this a mere addition to the first, or did it appear to be entirely separate?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
693,"['"" ""It was on a different panel of the door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
694,"['"" ""Excellent!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
695,"[' Now, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
696,"[' Hilton Cubitt, please continue your most interesting statement.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
697,"['"" ""I have nothing more to say, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
698,"[' Holmes, except that I was angry with my wife that night for having held me back when I might have caught the skulking rascal.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
699,[' She said that she feared that I might come to harm.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

700,"[' For an instant it had crossed my mind that perhaps what she really feared was that HE might come to harm, for I could not doubt that she knew who this man was and what he meant by these strange signals.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
701,"["" But there is a tone in my wife's voice, Mr.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
702,"[' Holmes, and a look in her eyes which forbid doubt, and I am sure that it was indeed my own safety that was in her mind.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

703,"[' My own inclination is to put half-a-dozen of my farm lads in the shrubbery, and when this fellow comes again to give him such a hiding that he will leave us in peace for the future.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
704,"['"" ""I fear it is too deep a case for such simple remedies,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
705,"[' ""How long can you stay in London?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
706,"['"" ""I must go back to-day.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

707,"[' Meanwhile you will leave me these papers, and I think that it is very likely that I shall be able to pay you a visit shortly and to throw some light upon your case.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

708,"['"" Sherlock Holmes preserved his calm professional manner until our visitor had left us, although it was easy for me, who knew him so well, to see that he was profoundly excited.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

709,"["" The moment that Hilton Cubitt's broad back had disappeared through the door my comrade rushed to the table, laid out all the slips of paper containing dancing men in front of him, and threw himself into an intricate and elaborate calculation.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
