710,"[' For two hours I watched him as he covered sheet after sheet of paper with figures and letters, so completely absorbed in his task that he had evidently forgotten my presence.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
711,"[' Finally he sprang from his chair with a cry of satisfaction, and walked up and down the room rubbing his hands together.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
712,"[' ""If my answer to this is as I hope, you will have a very pretty case to add to your collection, Watson,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

713,"[' ""I expect that we shall be able to go down to Norfolk to-morrow, and to take our friend some very definite news as to the secret of his annoyance.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

714,"['"" I confess that I was filled with curiosity, but I was aware that Holmes liked to make his disclosures at his own time and in his own way; so I waited until it should suit him to take me into his confidence.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

715,"[' But there was a delay in that answering telegram, and two days of impatience followed, during which Holmes pricked up his ears at every ring of the bell.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
716,[' On the evening of the second there came a letter from Hilton Cubitt.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

717,"[' He inclosed a copy of it, which is here reproduced:- GRAPHIC Holmes bent over this grotesque frieze for some minutes, and then suddenly sprang to his feet with an exclamation of surprise and dismay.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
718,"[' ""We have let this affair go far enough,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
719,"[' ""Is there a train to North Walsham to-night?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
720,"['"" I turned up the time-table.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
721,"[' ""Then we shall breakfast early and take the very first in the morning,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

722,"[' This message makes it even more essential that we should not lose an hour in letting Hilton Cubitt know how matters stand, for it is a singular and a dangerous web in which our simple Norfolk squire is entangled.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

723,"['"" So, indeed, it proved, and as I come to the dark conclusion of a story which had seemed to me to be only childish and bizarre I experience once again the dismay and horror with which I was filled.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

724,"[' Would that I had some brighter ending to communicate to my readers, but these are the chronicles of fact, and I must follow to their dark crisis the strange chain of events which for some days made Ridling Thorpe Manor a household word through the length and breadth of England.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
725,"[' ""I suppose that you are the detectives from London?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
726,"['"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
727,"["" A look of annoyance passed over Holmes's face.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
728,"[' ""What makes you think such a thing?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
729,"['"" ""Because Inspector Martin from Norwich has just passed through.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
730,[' You may be in time to save her yet-though it be for the gallows.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
731,"['"" Holmes\'s brow was dark with anxiety.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
732,"[' Dear, dear, one of the oldest families in the County of Norfolk, and one of the most honoured.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
733,"['"" Without a word Holmes hurried to a carriage, and during the long seven miles\' drive he never opened his mouth.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

734,"[' He had been uneasy during all our journey from town, and I had observed that he had turned over the morning papers with anxious attention; but now this sudden realization of his worst fears left him in a blank melancholy.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

735,"[' Yet there was much around to interest us, for we were passing through as singular a country-side as any in England, where a few scattered cottages represented the population of to-day, while on every hand enormous square-towered churches bristled up from the flat, green landscape and told of the glory and prosperity of old East Anglia.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

736,"[' As we drove up to the porticoed front door I observed in front of it, beside the tennis lawn, the black tool-house and the pedestalled sun-dial with which we had such strange associations.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
737,"[' A dapper little man, with a quick, alert manner and a waxed moustache, had just descended from a high dog-cart.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
738,"[' ""Why, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
739,"[' Holmes, the crime was only committed at three this morning.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
740,[' I came in the hope of preventing it.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
741,"['"" ""Then you must have important evidence of which we are ignorant, for they were said to be a most united couple.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
742,"['"" ""I have only the evidence of the dancing men,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
743,"[' Will you associate me in your investigation, or will you prefer that I should act independently?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
744,"['"" ""I should be proud to feel that we were acting together, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
745,"[' Holmes,"" said the inspector, earnestly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
746,"[' ""In that case I should be glad to hear the evidence and to examine the premises without an instant of unnecessary delay.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

747,"['"" Inspector Martin had the good sense to allow my friend to do things in his own fashion, and contented himself with carefully noting the results.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
748,"[' The local surgeon, an old, white-haired man, had just come down from Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
749,"["" Hilton Cubitt's room, and he reported that her injuries were serious, but not necessarily fatal.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
750,"[' ""Has he been moved?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
751,"['"" asked Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
752,[' We could not leave her lying wounded upon the floor.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
753,"['"" ""How long have you been here, doctor?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
754,"['"" ""Since four o\'clock.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
755,"['"" ""Anyone else?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
756,"['"" ""Yes, the constable here.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
757,"['"" ""And you have touched nothing?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
758,"['"" ""Nothing.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
759,"['"" ""You have acted with great discretion.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
760,[' Who sent for you?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
761,"['"" ""The housemaid, Saunders.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
762,"['"" ""Was it she who gave the alarm?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
763,"['"" ""She and Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
764,"[' King, the cook.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
765,"['"" ""Where are they now?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
766,"['"" ""In the kitchen, I believe.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
767,"['"" ""Then I think we had better hear their story at once.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
768,"['"" The old hall, oak-panelled and high-windowed, had been turned into a court of investigation.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
769,"[' Holmes sat in a great, old-fashioned chair, his inexorable eyes gleaming out of his haggard face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
770,[' The door of the study was open and a candle was burning upon the table.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
771,[' Their master lay upon his face in the centre of the room.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
772,"[' Near the window his wife was crouching, her head leaning against the wall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

773,"[' In answer to Inspector Martin they were clear that every door was fastened upon the inside, and that no one could have escaped from the house.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

774,[' In answer to Holmes they both remembered that they were conscious of the smell of powder from the moment that they ran out of their rooms upon the top floor.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
775,"[' ""I commend that fact very carefully to your attention,"" said Holmes to his professional colleague.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
776,"[' ""And now I think that we are in a position to undertake a thorough examination of the room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

777,"['"" The study proved to be a small chamber, lined on three sides with books, and with a writing-table facing an ordinary window, which looked out upon the garden.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
778,"[' According to the country surgeon the lady had stains upon her face, but none upon her hand.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
779,"[' ""The absence of the latter means nothing, though its presence may mean everything,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
780,"[' Two have been fired and two wounds inflicted, so that each bullet can be accounted for.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
781,"['"" ""So it would seem,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
782,"[' ""Perhaps you can account also for the bullet which has so obviously struck the edge of the window?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

783,"['"" He had turned suddenly, and his long, thin finger was pointing to a hole which had been drilled right through the lower window-sash about an inch above the bottom.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
784,"[' ""How ever did you see that?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
785,"['"" ""Because I looked for it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
786,"['"" ""Wonderful!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
787,"['"" said the country doctor.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
788,[' But who could that have been and how could he have got away?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
789,"['"" ""That is the problem which we are now about to solve,"" said Sherlock Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

790,"[' ""You remember, Inspector Martin, when the servants said that on leaving their room they were at once conscious of a smell of powder I remarked that the point was an extremely important one?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
791,"['"" ""Yes, sir; but I confess I did not quite follow you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
792,"['"" ""It suggested that at the time of the firing the window as well as the door of the room had been open.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
793,"[' Both door and window were only open for a very short time, however.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
794,"['"" ""How do you prove that?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
795,"['"" ""Because the candle has not guttered.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
796,"['"" ""Capital!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
797,"['"" cried the inspector.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
798,"[' ""Capital!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

799,"['"" ""Feeling sure that the window had been open at the time of the tragedy I conceived that there might have been a third person in the affair, who stood outside this opening and fired through it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
800,"[' I looked, and there, sure enough, was the bullet mark!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
801,"['"" ""But how came the window to be shut and fastened?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
802,"['"" ""The woman\'s first instinct would be to shut and fasten the window.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
803,[' Holmes opened it and turned the contents out.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
804,"[' ""This must be preserved, for it will figure in the trial,"" said Holmes, as he handed the bag with its contents to the inspector.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

805,"[' ""It is now necessary that we should try to throw some light upon this third bullet, which has clearly, from the splintering of the wood, been fired from inside the room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
806,"[' When you said that, did you mean that it seemed to you to be louder than the second one?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
807,"['"" ""Well, sir, it wakened me from my sleep, and so it is hard to judge.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
808,[' But it did seem very loud.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
809,"['"" ""You don\'t think that it might have been two shots fired almost at the same instant?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
810,"['"" ""I am sure I couldn\'t say, sir.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
811,"['"" ""I believe that it was undoubtedly so.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
812,"[' I rather think, Inspector Martin, that we have now exhausted all that this room can teach us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
813,"[' If you will kindly step round with me, we shall see what fresh evidence the garden has to offer.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
814,"['"" A flower-bed extended up to the study window, and we all broke into an exclamation as we approached it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
815,[' Holmes hunted about among the grass and leaves like a retriever after a wounded bird.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
816,"[' ""I thought so,"" said he; ""the revolver had an ejector, and here is the third cartridge.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
817,"[' I really think, Inspector Martin, that our case is almost complete.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
818,"['"" The country inspector\'s face had shown his intense amazement at the rapid and masterful progress of Holmes\'s investigation.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

819,[' At first he had shown some disposition to assert his own position; but now he was overcome with admiration and ready to follow without question wherever Holmes led.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
820,"[' Now that I have got so far I had best proceed on my own lines, and then clear the whole matter up once and for all.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
821,"['"" ""Just as you wish, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
822,"[' Holmes, so long as we get our man.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
823,"['"" ""I have no desire to make mysteries, but it is impossible at the moment of action to enter into long and complex explanations.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
824,"["" First of all I wish to know whether there is any inn in this neighbourhood known as 'Elrige's'?""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
825,"['"" The servants were cross-questioned, but none of them had heard of such a place.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

826,[' The stable-boy threw a light upon the matter by remembering that a farmer of that name lived some miles off in the direction of East Ruston.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
827,"[' ""Is it a lonely farm?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
828,"['"" ""Very lonely, sir.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
829,"['"" ""Perhaps they have not heard yet of all that happened here during the night?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
830,"['"" ""Maybe not, sir.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
831,"['"" Holmes thought for a little and then a curious smile played over his face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
832,"[' ""I shall wish you to take a note to Elrige\'s Farm.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
833,"['"" He took from his pocket the various slips of the dancing men.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
834,[' With these in front of him he worked for some time at the study-table.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

835,"[' Finally he handed a note to the boy, with directions to put it into the hands of the person to whom it was addressed, and especially to answer no questions of any sort which might be put to him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
836,"["" I saw the outside of the note, addressed in straggling, irregular characters, very unlike Holmes's usual precise hand.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

837,"[' ""I think, inspector,"" Holmes remarked, ""that you would do well to telegraph for an escort, as, if my calculations prove to be correct, you may have a particularly dangerous prisoner to convey to the county gaol.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

838,"[' If there is an afternoon train to town, Watson, I think we should do well to take it, as I have a chemical analysis of some interest to finish, and this investigation draws rapidly to a close.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
839,"['"" When the youth had been dispatched with the note, Sherlock Holmes gave his instructions to the servants.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
840,[' If any visitor were to call asking for Mrs.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
841,"[' Hilton Cubitt no information should be given as to her condition, but he was to be shown at once into the drawing-room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

842,"[' Finally he led the way into the drawing-room with the remark that the business was now out of our hands, and that we must while away the time as best we might until we could see what was in store for us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

843,"[' ""I think that I can help you to pass an hour in an interesting and profitable manner,"" said Holmes, drawing his chair up to the table and spreading out in front of him the various papers upon which were recorded the antics of the dancing men.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
844,"[' ""As to you, friend Watson, I owe you every atonement for having allowed your natural curiosity to remain so long unsatisfied.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
845,[' I must tell you first of all the interesting circumstances connected with the previous consultations which Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
846,[' Hilton Cubitt has had with me in Baker Street.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
847,"['"" He then shortly recapitulated the facts which have already been recorded.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
848,"["" Now, in the single word I have already got the two E's coming second and fourth in a word of five letters.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

849,"["" It occurred to me that if these appeals came, as I expected, from someone who had been intimate with the lady in her early life, a combination which contained two E's with three letters between might very well stand for the name 'ELSIE.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
850,"[""' On examination I found that such a combination formed the termination of the message which was three times repeated.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
851,"["" Surely the word must be 'COME.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
852,"[""' I tried all other four letters ending in E, but could find none to fit the case.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

853,"[' ""Now the first letter CAN only be A, which is a most useful discovery, since it occurs no fewer than three times in this short sentence, and the H is also apparent in the second word.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

854,"[' Here I could only make sense by putting T and G for the missing letters, and supposing that the name was that of some house or inn at which the writer was staying.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

855,"['"" Inspector Martin and I had listened with the utmost interest to the full and clear account of how my friend had produced results which had led to so complete a command over our difficulties.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
856,"["" The lady's allusions to her past and her refusal to take her husband into her confidence both pointed in that direction.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
857,[' Working with known letters it took this form:- ELSIE .'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
858,['RE.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
859,['ARE TO MEET THY GO.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
860,"[' I at once came to Norfolk with my friend and colleague, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
861,"[' Watson, but, unhappily, only in time to find that the worst had already occurred.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
862,"['"" ""It is a privilege to be associated with you in the handling of a case,"" said the inspector, warmly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
863,[' He will not try to escape.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
864,"['"" ""How do you know?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
865,"['"" ""To fly would be a confession of guilt.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
866,"['"" ""Then let us go to arrest him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
867,"['"" ""I expect him here every instant.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
868,"['"" ""But why should he come?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
869,"['"" ""Because I have written and asked him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
870,"['"" ""But this is incredible, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
871,[' Holmes!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
872,[' Would not such a request rather rouse his suspicions and cause him to fly?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
873,"['"" ""I think I have known how to frame the letter,"" said Sherlock Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
874,"[' ""In fact, if I am not very much mistaken, here is the gentleman himself coming up the drive.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
875,"['"" A man was striding up the path which led to the door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
876,"[' ""I think, gentlemen,"" said Holmes, quietly, ""that we had best take up our position behind the door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
877,[' Then the door opened and the man stepped in.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
878,[' In an instant Holmes clapped a pistol to his head and Martin slipped the handcuffs over his wrists.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
879,[' But I came here in answer to a letter from Mrs.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
880,[' Hilton Cubitt.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
881,"["" Don't tell me that she helped to set a trap for me?""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
882,"['"" ""Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
883,"["" Hilton Cubitt was seriously injured and is at death's door.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
884,"['"" The man gave a hoarse cry of grief which rang through the house.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
885,[' Say that she is not hurt!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
886,"['"" ""She was found badly wounded by the side of her dead husband.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
887,"['"" He sank with a deep groan on to the settee and buried his face in his manacled hands.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
888,"[' ""I have nothing to hide from you, gentlemen,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
889,"[' ""If I shot the man he had his shot at me, and there\'s no murder in that.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
890,"["" But if you think I could have hurt that woman, then you don't know either me or her.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
891,[' I tell you there was never a man in this world loved a woman more than I loved her.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
892,"[' I tell you that I had the first right to her, and that I was only claiming my own.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
893,"['"" ""She broke away from your influence when she found the man that you are,"" said Holmes, sternly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
894,[' You have ended by bringing about the death of a noble man and driving his wife to suicide.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
895,"[' That is your record in this business, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
896,"[' Abe Slaney, and you will answer for it to the law.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
897,"['"" ""If Elsie dies I care nothing what becomes of me,"" said the American.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
898,[' He opened one of his hands and looked at a note crumpled up in his palm.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
899,[' How came you to write it?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
900,"['"" ""What one man can invent another can discover,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
901,[' Are you aware that Mrs.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

902,"[' Hilton Cubitt has herself lain under grave suspicion of the murder of her husband, and that it was only my presence here and the knowledge which I happened to possess which has saved her from the accusation?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

903,"[' The least that you owe her is to make it clear to the whole world that she was in no way, directly or indirectly, responsible for his tragic end.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
904,"['"" ""I ask nothing better,"" said the American.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
905,"[' ""I guess the very best case I can make for myself is the absolute naked truth.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

906,"['"" ""It is my duty to warn you that it will be used against you,"" cried the inspector, with the magnificent fair-play of the British criminal law.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
907,"[' ""I\'ll chance that,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

908,"["" Well, Elsie learned some of our ways; but she couldn't stand the business, and she had a bit of honest money of her own, so she gave us all the slip and got away to London.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
909,"[' After that I came over, and, as letters were no use, I put my messages where she could read them.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
910,"[' She sent me a letter then, imploring me to go away and saying that it would break her heart if any scandal should come upon her husband.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

911,"[' She said that she would come down when her husband was asleep at three in the morning, and speak with me through the end window, if I would go away afterwards and leave her in peace.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
912,"[' I made away across the garden, and as I went I heard the window shut behind me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

913,"["" That's God's truth, gentlemen, every word of it, and I heard no more about it until that lad came riding up with a note which made me walk in here, like a jay, and give myself into your hands.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
914,"['"" A cab had driven up whilst the American had been talking.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
915,[' Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
916,"[' Sherlock Holmes, I only hope that if ever again I have an important case I shall have the good fortune to have you by my side.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
917,"['"" We stood at the window and watched the cab drive away.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
918,[' As I turned back my eye caught the pellet of paper which the prisoner had tossed upon the table.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
919,[' It was the note with which Holmes had decoyed him.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
920,"[' ""See if you can read it, Watson,"" said he, with a smile.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

921,"[' It contained no word, but this little line of dancing men:- GRAPHIC ""If you use the code which I have explained,"" said Holmes, ""you will find that it simply means \'Come here at once.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

922,"[""' I was convinced that it was an invitation which he would not refuse, since he could never imagine that it could come from anyone but the lady.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

923,"[' And so, my dear Watson, we have ended by turning the dancing men to good when they have so often been the agents of evil, and I think that I have fulfilled my promise of giving you something unusual for your note-book.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
924,[' Of Mrs.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

925,"["" Hilton Cubitt I only know that I have heard she recovered entirely, and that she still remains a widow, devoting her whole life to the care of the poor and to the administration of her husband's estate.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
926,[' FROM the years 1894 to 1901 inclusive Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
927,[' Sherlock Holmes was a very busy man.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

928,"[' As I have preserved very full notes of all these cases, and was myself personally engaged in many of them, it may be imagined that it is no easy task to know which I should select to lay before the public.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

929,"[' It is true that the circumstances did not admit of any striking illustration of those powers for which my friend was famous, but there were some points about the case which made it stand out in those long records of crime from which I gather the material for these little narratives.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

930,"[' On referring to my note-book for the year 1895 I find that it was upon Saturday, the 23rd of April, that we first heard of Miss Violet Smith.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

931,"[' Her visit was, I remember, extremely unwelcome to Holmes, for he was immersed at the moment in a very abstruse and complicated problem concerning the peculiar persecution to which John Vincent Harden, the well-known tobacco millionaire, had been subjected.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

932,"[' My friend, who loved above all things precision and concentration of thought, resented anything which distracted his attention from the matter in hand.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

933,"[' And yet without a harshness which was foreign to his nature it was impossible to refuse to listen to the story of the young and beautiful woman, tall, graceful, and queenly, who presented herself at Baker Street late in the evening and implored his assistance and advice.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

934,"[' It was vain to urge that his time was already fully occupied, for the young lady had come with the determination to tell her story, and it was evident that nothing short of force could get her out of the room until she had done so.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

935,"[' With a resigned air and a somewhat weary smile, Holmes begged the beautiful intruder to take a seat and to inform us what it was that was troubling her.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
936,"[' ""At least it cannot be your health,"" said he, as his keen eyes darted over her; ""so ardent a bicyclist must be full of energy.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

937,"['"" She glanced down in surprise at her own feet, and I observed the slight roughening of the side of the sole caused by the friction of the edge of the pedal.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
938,"[' ""Yes, I bicycle a good deal, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
939,"[' Holmes, and that has something to do with my visit to you to-day.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

940,"['"" My friend took the lady\'s ungloved hand and examined it with as close an attention and as little sentiment as a scientist would show to a specimen.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
941,"[' It is my business,"" said he, as he dropped it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
942,[' This lady is a musician.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
943,"['"" ""Yes, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
944,"[' Holmes, I teach music.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
945,"['"" ""In the country, I presume, from your complexion.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
946,"['"" ""Yes, sir; near Farnham, on the borders of Surrey.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
947,"['"" ""A beautiful neighbourhood and full of the most interesting associations.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
948,"[' Now, Miss Violet, what has happened to you near Farnham, on the borders of Surrey?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
949,"['"" The young lady, with great clearness and composure, made the following curious statement:- ""My father is dead, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
950,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

951,"[' My mother and I were left without a relation in the world except one uncle, Ralph Smith, who went to Africa twenty- five years ago, and we have never had a word from him since.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

952,"[' When father died we were left very poor, but one day we were told that there was an advertisement in the TIMES inquiring for our whereabouts.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

953,"[' They said that my uncle was a friend of theirs, that he died some months before in great poverty in Johannesburg, and that he had asked them with his last breath to hunt up his relations and see that they were in no want.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

954,"[' It seemed strange to us that Uncle Ralph, who took no notice of us when he was alive, should be so careful to look after us when he was dead; but Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
955,"[' Carruthers explained that the reason was that my uncle had just heard of the death of his brother, and so felt responsible for our fate.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
956,"['"" ""Excuse me,"" said Holmes; ""when was this interview?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
957,"['"" ""Last December-four months ago.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
958,"['"" ""Pray proceed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
959,"['"" ""Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
960,[' Woodley seemed to me to be a most odious person.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

961,"[' He was for ever making eyes at me-a coarse, puffy-faced, red-moustached young man, with his hair plastered down on each side of his forehead.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
962,[' I thought that he was perfectly hateful-and I was sure that Cyril would not wish me to know such a person.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
963,"['"" ""Oh, Cyril is his name!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
964,"['"" said Holmes, smiling.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
965,"[' ""Yes, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
966,"[' Holmes; Cyril Morton, an electrical engineer, and we hope to be married at the end of the summer.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
967,[' What I wished to say was that Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
968,"[' Woodley was perfectly odious, but that Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
969,"[' Carruthers, who was a much older man, was more agreeable.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

970,"[' He inquired how we were left, and on finding that we were very poor he suggested that I should come and teach music to his only daughter, aged ten.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

971,"[' I said that I did not like to leave my mother, on which he suggested that I should go home to her every week-end, and he offered me a hundred a year, which was certainly splendid pay.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
972,[' Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
973,"[' Carruthers was a widower, but he had engaged a lady-housekeeper, a very respectable, elderly person, called Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
974,"[' Dixon, to look after his establishment.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

975,"[' He made odious love to me, boasted of his wealth, said that if I married him I would have the finest diamonds in London, and finally, when I would have nothing to do with him, he seized me in his arms one day after dinner-he was hideously strong-and he swore that he would not let me go until I had kissed him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
976,[' Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
977,"[' Carruthers came in and tore him off from me, on which he turned upon his own host, knocking him down and cutting his face open.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
978,"[' ""And now, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
979,"[' Holmes, I come at last to the special thing which has caused me to ask your advice to-day.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

980,"[' Two weeks ago I was passing this place when I chanced to look back over my shoulder, and about two hundred yards behind me I saw a man, also on a bicycle.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
981,"[' He seemed to be a middle-aged man, with a short, dark beard.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
982,"[' I looked back before I reached Farnham, but the man was gone, so I thought no more about it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
983,"[' But you can imagine how surprised I was, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
984,"[' Holmes, when on my return on the Monday I saw the same man on the same stretch of road.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
985,[' I mentioned it to Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

986,"[' Carruthers, who seemed interested in what I said, and told me that he had ordered a horse and trap, so that in future I should not pass over these lonely roads without some companion.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

987,"[' You can think that I looked out when I came to Charlington Heath, and there, sure enough, was the man, exactly as he had been the two weeks before.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
988,"[' He always kept so far from me that I could not clearly see his face, but it was certainly someone whom I did not know.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
989,"[' There is a sharp turning of the road, and I pedalled very quickly round this, and then I stopped and waited.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
990,[' Then I went back and looked round the corner.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
991,"[' To make it the more extraordinary, there was no side road at this point down which he could have gone.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
992,"['"" Holmes chuckled and rubbed his hands.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
993,"[' ""This case certainly presents some features of its own,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
994,"[' ""How much time elapsed between your turning the corner and your discovery that the road was clear?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
995,"['"" ""Two or three minutes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
996,"['"" ""Then he could not have retreated down the road, and you say that there are no side roads?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
997,"['"" ""None.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
998,"['"" ""Then he certainly took a footpath on one side or the other.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
999,"['"" ""It could not have been on the side of the heath or I should have seen him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1000,"['"" ""So by the process of exclusion we arrive at the fact that he made his way towards Charlington Hall, which, as I understand, is situated in its own grounds on one side of the road.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1001,[' Anything else?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1002,"['"" ""Nothing, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1003,"[' Holmes, save that I was so perplexed that I felt I should not be happy until I had seen you and had your advice.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1004,"['"" Holmes sat in silence for some little time.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1005,"[' ""He is in the Midland Electrical Company, at Coventry.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1006,"['"" ""He would not pay you a surprise visit?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1007,"['"" ""Oh, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1008,[' Holmes!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1009,[' As if I should not know him!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1010,"['"" ""Have you had any other admirers?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1011,"['"" ""Several before I knew Cyril.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1012,"['"" ""And since?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1013,"['"" ""There was this dreadful man, Woodley, if you can call him an admirer.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1014,"['"" ""No one else?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1015,"['"" Our fair client seemed a little confused.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1016,[' But a girl always knows.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1017,"['"" ""Ha!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1018,"['"" Holmes looked grave.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1019,[' He is deeply interested in South African gold shares.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1020,"['"" ""You will let me know any fresh development, Miss Smith.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1021,"[' I am very busy just now, but I will find time to make some inquiries into your case.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1022,"[' Good-bye, and I trust that we shall have nothing but good news from you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1023,"['"" ""It is part of the settled order of Nature that such a girl should have followers,"" said Holmes, as he pulled at his meditative pipe, ""but for choice not on bicycles in lonely country roads.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1024,"[' But there are curious and suggestive details about the case, Watson.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1025,"['"" ""That he should appear only at that point?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1026,"['"" ""Exactly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1027,"[' And now, Watson, not another word of the matter until we have a few solid stepping-stones on which we may hope to get across to our solution.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1028,"['"" We had ascertained from the lady that she went down upon the Monday by the train which leaves Waterloo at 9.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1029,"['50, so I started early and caught the 9.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1030,['13.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1031,"["" It was impossible to mistake the scene of the young lady's adventure, for the road runs between the open heath on one side and an old yew hedge upon the other, surrounding a park which is studded with magnificent trees.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1032,"[' Behind one of these clumps I took up my position, so as to command both the gateway of the Hall and a long stretch of the road upon either side.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1033,"[' It had been deserted when I left it, but now I saw a cyclist riding down it from the opposite direction to that in which I had come.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1034,[' This time it was the young lady coming from the station.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1035,[' I saw her look about her as she came to the Charlington hedge.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1036,"[' An instant later the man emerged from his hiding-place, sprang upon his cycle, and followed her.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1037,"[' In all the broad landscape those were the only moving figures, the graceful girl sitting very straight upon her machine, and the man behind her bending low over his handle-bar, with a curiously furtive suggestion in every movement.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1038,"[' Presently she came back up the road again, her head haughtily in the air, not deigning to take any further notice of her silent attendant.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1039,"[' I remained in my hiding-place, and it was well that I did so, for presently the man reappeared cycling slowly back.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1040,"[' Far away I could catch glimpses of the old grey building with its bristling Tudor chimneys, but the drive ran through a dense shrubbery, and I saw no more of my man.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1041,"["" However, it seemed to me that I had done a fairly good morning's work, and I walked back in high spirits to Farnham.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1042,"[' The local house-agent could tell me nothing about Charlington Hall, and referred me to a well-known firm in Pall Mall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1043,[' Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1044,"[' Sherlock Holmes listened with attention to the long report which I was able to present to him that evening, but it did not elicit that word of curt praise which I had hoped for and should have valued.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1045,[' She thinks she does not know the man; I am convinced she does.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1046,[' You come to a London house-agent!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1047,"['"" ""What should I have done?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1048,"['"" I cried, with some heat.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1049,"["" If he is an elderly man he is not this active cyclist who sprints away from that athletic young lady's pursuit.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1050,"["" Well, well, my dear sir, don't look so depressed.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1051,"[' We can do little more until next Saturday, and in the meantime I may make one or two inquiries myself.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1052,"['"" Next morning we had a note from Miss Smith, recounting shortly and accurately the very incidents which I had seen, but the pith of the letter lay in the postscript:- ""I am sure that you will respect my confidence, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1053,"[' Holmes, when I tell you that my place here has become difficult owing to the fact that my employer has proposed marriage to me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1054,"[' You can understand, however, that the situation is a little strained.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1055,"['"" ""Our young friend seems to be getting into deep waters,"" said Holmes, thoughtfully, as he finished the letter.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1056,"[' ""The case certainly presents more features of interest and more possibility of development than I had originally thought.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1057,"[' I should be none the worse for a quiet, peaceful day in the country, and I am inclined to run down this afternoon and test one or two theories which I have formed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1058,"['"" Holmes\'s quiet day in the country had a singular termination, for he arrived at Baker Street late in the evening with a cut lip and a discoloured lump upon his forehead, besides a general air of dissipation which would have made his own person the fitting object of a Scotland Yard investigation.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1059,"[' ""I get so little active exercise that it is always a treat,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1060,"[' To-day, for example, I should have come to very ignominious grief without it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1061,"['"" I begged him to tell me what had occurred.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1062,"[' Williamson is a white-bearded man, and he lives alone with a small staff of servants at the Hall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1063,"[' I have already made some inquiries at a clerical agency, and they tell me that there WAS a man of that name in orders whose career has been a singularly dark one.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1064,"["" The landlord further informed me that there are usually week-end visitors-'a warm lot, sir'-at the Hall, and especially one gentleman with a red moustache, Mr.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1065,"[' Woodley by name, who was always there.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1066,"[' We had got as far as this when who should walk in but the gentleman himself, who had been drinking his beer in the tap-room and had heard the whole conversation.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1067,"[' So ended my country trip, and it must be confessed that, however enjoyable, my day on the Surrey border has not been much more profitable than your own.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1068,"['"" The Thursday brought us another letter from our client.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1069,"[' ""You will not be surprised, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1070,"[' Holmes,"" said she, ""to hear that I am leaving Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1071,"["" Carruthers's employment.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1072,"[' ""As to the special cause of my leaving, it is not merely the strained situation with Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1073,"[' Carruthers, but it is the reappearance of that odious man, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1074,[' Woodley.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1075,"[' However, all my troubles will be over on Saturday.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1076,"['"" ""So I trust, Watson; so I trust,"" said Holmes, gravely.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1077,"[' I think, Watson, that we must spare time to run down together on Saturday morning, and make sure that this curious and inconclusive investigation has no untoward ending.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1078,"['"" I confess that I had not up to now taken a very serious view of the case, which had seemed to me rather grotesque and bizarre than dangerous.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1079,"[' That a man should lie in wait for and follow a very handsome woman is no unheard-of thing, and if he had so little audacity that he not only dared not address her, but even fled from her approach, he was not a very formidable assailant.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1080,"[' The ruffian Woodley was a very different person, but, except on one occasion, he had not molested our client, and now he visited the house of Carruthers without intruding upon her presence.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1081,[' The man on the bicycle was doubtless a member of those week-end parties at the Hall of which the publican had spoken; but who he was or what he wanted was as obscure as ever.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1082,"["" It was the severity of Holmes's manner and the fact that he slipped a revolver into his pocket before leaving our rooms which impressed me with the feeling that tragedy might prove to lurk behind this curious train of events.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1083,"[' A rainy night had been followed by a glorious morning, and the heath-covered country-side with the glowing clumps of flowering gorse seemed all the more beautiful to eyes which were weary of the duns and drabs and slate-greys of London.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1084,"[' Holmes and I walked along the broad, sandy road inhaling the fresh morning air, and rejoicing in the music of the birds and the fresh breath of the spring.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1085,"[' Holmes pointed down the long tract of road which wound, a reddish yellow band, between the brown of the heath and the budding green of the woods.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1086,[' Holmes gave an exclamation of impatience.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1087,"[' ""I had given a margin of half an hour,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1088,"[' I fear, Watson, that she will be past Charlington before we can possibly meet her.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1089,"['"" From the instant that we passed the rise we could no longer see the vehicle, but we hastened onwards at such a pace that my sedentary life began to tell upon me, and I was compelled to fall behind.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1090,"[' Holmes, however, was always in training, for he had inexhaustible stores of nervous energy upon which to draw.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1091,"[' His springy step never slowed until suddenly, when he was a hundred yards in front of me, he halted, and I saw him throw up his hand with a gesture of grief and despair.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1092,"[' At the same instant an empty dog-cart, the horse cantering, the reins trailing, appeared round the curve of the road and rattled swiftly towards us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1093,"[' ""Too late, Watson; too late!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1094,"['"" cried Holmes, as I ran panting to his side.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1095,"[' Now, jump in, and let us see if I can repair the consequences of my own blunder.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1096,"['"" We had sprung into the dog-cart, and Holmes, after turning the horse, gave it a sharp cut with the whip, and we flew back along the road.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1097,[' As we turned the curve the whole stretch of road between the Hall and the heath was opened up.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1098,"["" I grasped Holmes's arm.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1099,"[' Suddenly he raised his bearded face, saw us close to him, and pulled up, springing from his machine.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1100,[' Then a look of amazement came over his face.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1101,"[' Pull up, man!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1102,"['"" he yelled, drawing a pistol from his side pocket.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1103,"[' ""Pull up, I say, or, by George, I\'ll put a bullet into your horse.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1104,"['"" Holmes threw the reins into my lap and sprang down from the cart.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1105,[' Where is Miss Violet Smith?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1106,"['"" he said, in his quick, clear way.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1107,[' We drove back to help the young lady.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1108,"['"" ""Good Lord!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1109,"[' Come, man, come, if you really are her friend.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1110,"["" Stand by me and we'll save her, if I have to leave my carcass in Charlington Wood.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1111,"['"" He ran distractedly, his pistol in his hand, towards a gap in the hedge.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1112,"[' ""This is where they came through,"" said he, pointing to the marks of several feet upon the muddy path.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1113,"["" Let him lie; we can't do him any good, but we may save her from the worst fate that can befall a woman.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1114,"['"" We ran frantically down the path, which wound among the trees.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1115,[' We had reached the shrubbery which surrounded the house when Holmes pulled up.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1116,"[' Opposite her stood a brutal, heavy- faced, red-moustached young man, his gaitered legs parted wide, one arm akimbo, the other waving a riding-crop, his whole attitude suggestive of triumphant bravado.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1117,"[' Between them an elderly, grey-bearded man, wearing a short surplice over a light tweed suit, had evidently just completed the wedding service, for he pocketed his prayer-book as we appeared and slapped the sinister bridegroom upon the back in jovial congratulation.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1118,"[' ""Come on!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1119,"['"" cried our guide; ""come on!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1120,"['"" He rushed across the glade, Holmes and I at his heels.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1121,"[' Well, you and your pals have just come in time for me to be able to introduce you to Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1122,[' Woodley.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1123,"['"" Our guide\'s answer was a singular one.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1124,"[' He snatched off the dark beard which had disguised him and threw it on the ground, disclosing a long, sallow, clean- shaven face below it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1125,"[' Then he raised his revolver and covered the young ruffian, who was advancing upon him with his dangerous riding-crop swinging in his hand.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1126,"[' ""Yes,"" said our ally, ""I AM Bob Carruthers, and I\'ll see this woman righted if I have to swing for it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1127,"[' He spun round with a scream and fell upon his back, his hideous red face turning suddenly to a dreadful mottled pallor.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1128,"["" The old man, still clad in his surplice, burst into such a string of foul oaths as I have never heard, and pulled out a revolver of his own, but before he could raise it he was looking down the barrel of Holmes's weapon.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1129,"[' ""Enough of this,"" said my friend, coldly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1130,"[' Come, hand it over!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1131,"['"" ""Who are you, then?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1132,"['"" ""My name is Sherlock Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1133,"['"" ""Good Lord!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1134,"['"" ""You have heard of me, I see.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1135,[' Until he comes I must detain you all under my personal custody.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1136,"['"" The strong, masterful personality of Holmes dominated the tragic scene, and all were equally puppets in his hands.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1137,"[' Williamson and Carruthers found themselves carrying the wounded Woodley into the house, and I gave my arm to the frightened girl.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1138,"["" The injured man was laid on his bed, and at Holmes's request I examined him.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1139,"[' Do you tell me that that girl, that angel, is to be tied to Roaring Jack Woodley for life?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1140,"['"" ""You need not concern yourself about that,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1141,"[' In the first place, we are very safe in questioning Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1142,"["" Williamson's right to solemnize a marriage.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1143,"['"" ""I have been ordained,"" cried the old rascal.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1144,"["" You'll have time to think the point out during the next ten years or so, unless I am mistaken.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1145,"[' As to you, Carruthers, you would have done better to keep your pistol in your pocket.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1146,"['"" ""I begin to think so, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1147,"[' Holmes; but when I thought of all the precaution I had taken to shield this girl-for I loved her, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1148,"[' Holmes, and it is the only time that ever I knew what love was-it fairly drove me mad to think that she was in the power of the greatest brute and bully in South Africa, a man whose name is a holy terror from Kimberley to Johannesburg.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1149,"[' Why, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1150,"["" Holmes, you'll hardly believe it, but ever since that girl has been in my employment I never once let her go past this house, where I knew these rascals were lurking, without following her on my bicycle just to see that she came to no harm.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1151,"["" I kept my distance from her, and I wore a beard so that she should not recognise me, for she is a good and high- spirited girl, and she wouldn't have stayed in my employment long if she had thought that I was following her about the country roads.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1152,"['"" ""Why didn\'t you tell her of her danger?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1153,"['"" ""Because then, again, she would have left me, and I couldn\'t bear to face that.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1154,"["" Even if she couldn't love me it was a great deal to me just to see her dainty form about the house, and to hear the sound of her voice.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1155,"['"" ""Well,"" said I, ""you call that love, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1156,"[' Carruthers, but I should call it selfishness.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1157,"['"" ""Maybe the two things go together.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1158,[' Then when the cable came I knew they were bound to make a move.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1159,"['"" ""What cable?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1160,"['"" Carruthers took a telegram from his pocket.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1161,"[' It was short and concise:- ""The old man is dead.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1162,"['"" ""Hum!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1163,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1164,"[' ""I think I see how things worked, and I can understand how this message would, as you say, bring them to a head.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1165,"[' ""By Heaven,"" said he, ""if you squeal on us, Bob Carruthers, I\'ll serve you as you served Jack Woodley.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1166,"["" You can bleat about the girl to your heart's content, for that's your own affair, but if you round on your pals to this plain-clothes copper it will be the worst day's work that ever you did.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1167,"['"" ""Your reverence need not be excited,"" said Holmes, lighting a cigarette.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1168,"[' In the first place, three of you came from South Africa on this game-you Williamson, you Carruthers, and Woodley.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1169,"['"" ""Lie number one,"" said the old man; ""I never saw either of them until two months ago, and I have never been in Africa in my life, so you can put that in your pipe and smoke it, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1170,[' Busybody Holmes!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1171,"['"" ""What he says is true,"" said Carruthers.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1172,"[' ""She was next-of-kin, no doubt, and you were aware that the old fellow would make no will.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1173,"['"" ""Couldn\'t read or write,"" said Carruthers.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1174,"[' He left you in a rage, and began to make his own plans independently of you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1175,"['"" ""It strikes me, Williamson, there isn\'t very much that we can tell this gentleman,"" cried Carruthers, with a bitter laugh.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1176,[' I found that they had set up house-keeping together at this place on the line that she had to pass for the station.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1177,"[' Two days ago Woodley came up to my house with this cable, which showed that Ralph Smith was dead.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1178,"[' She was leaving me this week-end, and I had got a trap to take her to the station, but I was so uneasy in my mind that I followed her on my bicycle.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1179,[' The first thing I knew about it was when I saw you two gentlemen driving back in her dog-cart.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1180,"['"" Holmes rose and tossed the end of his cigarette into the grate.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1181,"[' ""I have been very obtuse, Watson,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1182,"[' ""When in your report you said that you had seen the cyclist as you thought arrange his necktie in the shrubbery, that alone should have told me all.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1183,"["" I perceive three of the county constabulary in the drive, and I am glad to see that the little ostler is able to keep pace with them; so it is likely that neither he nor the interesting bridegroom will be permanently damaged by their morning's adventures.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1184,"["" I think, Watson, that in your medical capacity you might wait upon Miss Smith and tell her that if she is sufficiently recovered we shall be happy to escort her to her mother's home.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1185,"[' There is my card, sir, and if my evidence can be of help to you in your trial it shall be at your disposal.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1186,"['"" In the whirl of our incessant activity it has often been difficult for me, as the reader has probably observed, to round off my narratives, and to give those final details which the curious might expect.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1187,"[' I find, however, a short note at the end of my manuscripts dealing with this case, in which I have put it upon record that Miss Violet Smith did indeed inherit a large fortune, and that she is now the wife of Cyril Morton, the senior partner of Morton & Kennedy, the famous Westminster electricians.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1188,"[' Of the fate of Carruthers I have no record, but I am sure that his assault was not viewed very gravely by the Court, since Woodley had the reputation of being a most dangerous ruffian, and I think that a few months were sufficient to satisfy the demands of justice.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1189,"[' And yet his first action when the door had closed behind him was to stagger against the table, whence he slipped down upon the floor, and there was that majestic figure prostrate and insensible upon our bearskin hearthrug.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1190,"[' We had sprung to our feet, and for a few moments we stared in silent amazement at this ponderous piece of wreckage, which told of some sudden and fatal storm far out on the ocean of life.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1191,[' Then Holmes hurried with a cushion for his head and I with brandy for his lips.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1192,"[' The heavy white face was seamed with lines of trouble, the hanging pouches under the closed eyes were leaden in colour, the loose mouth drooped dolorously at the corners, the rolling chins were unshaven.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1193,"[' ""What is it, Watson?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1194,"['"" asked Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1195,"[' ""Absolute exhaustion-possibly mere hunger and fatigue,"" said I, with my finger on the thready pulse, where the stream of life trickled thin and small.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1196,"[' ""Return ticket from Mackleton, in the North of England,"" said Holmes, drawing it from the watch-pocket.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1197,[' He has certainly been an early starter.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1198,"['"" The puckered eyelids had begun to quiver, and now a pair of vacant, grey eyes looked up at us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1199,"[' An instant later the man had scrambled on to his feet, his face crimson with shame.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1200,"[' ""Forgive this weakness, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1201,[' Holmes; I have been a little overwrought.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1202,"[' I came personally, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1203,"[' Holmes, in order to ensure that you would return with me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1204,"[' I wish you, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1205,"[' Holmes, to come to Mackleton with me by the next train.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1206,"['"" My friend shook his head.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1207,"[' ""My colleague, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1208,"[' Watson, could tell you that we are very busy at present.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1209,"[' I am retained in this case of the Ferrers Documents, and the Abergavenny murder is coming up for trial.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1210,[' I thought it might have reached your ears.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1211,"['"" Holmes shot out his long, thin arm and picked out Volume ""H"" in his encyclopaedia of reference.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1212,"[' I am aware, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1213,"["" Holmes, that you take a very high line in professional matters, and that you are prepared to work for the work's sake.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1214,"[' I may tell you, however, that his Grace has already intimated that a cheque for five thousand pounds will be handed over to the person who can tell him where his son is, and another thousand to him who can name the man, or men, who have taken him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1215,"['"" ""It is a princely offer,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1216,"[' ""Watson, I think that we shall accompany Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1217,[' Huxtable back to the North of England.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1218,"[' And now, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1219,"[' Huxtable, when you have consumed that milk you will kindly tell me what has happened, when it happened, how it happened, and, finally, what Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1220,"[' Thorneycroft Huxtable, of the Priory School, near Mackleton, has to do with the matter, and why he comes three days after an event-the state of your chin gives the date-to ask for my humble services.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1221,"['"" Our visitor had consumed his milk and biscuits.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1222,[' The light had come back to his eyes and the colour to his cheeks as he set himself with great vigour and lucidity to explain the situation.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1223,"[' But I felt that my school had reached its zenith when, three weeks ago, the Duke of Holdernesse sent Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1224,"[' James Wilder, his secretary, with the intimation that young Lord Saltire, ten years old, his only son and heir, was about to be committed to my charge.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1225,"["" It is an open secret that the Duke's married life had not been a peaceful one, and the matter had ended in a separation by mutual consent, the Duchess taking up her residence in the South of France.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1226,"[' These boys saw and heard nothing, so that it is certain that young Saltire did not pass out that way.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1227,"[' There were no signs that anyone had entered the room, and it is quite certain that anything in the nature of cries, or a struggle, would have been heard, since Caunter, the elder boy in the inner room, is a very light sleeper.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1228,"["" His room was on the second floor, at the farther end of the building, facing the same way as Lord Saltire's.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
