1229,"[' ""He had been with me for two years, and came with the best references; but he was a silent, morose man, not very popular either with masters or boys.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1230,"[' It is only a few miles away, and we imagined that in some sudden attack of home- sickness he had gone back to his father; but nothing had been heard of him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1231,"[' ""You have been very remiss in not coming to me sooner,"" said he, severely.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1232,"[' It is inconceivable, for example, that this ivy and this lawn would have yielded nothing to an expert observer.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1233,"['"" ""I am not to blame, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1234,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1235,"[' An apparent clue was at once obtained, since a boy and a young man were reported to have been seen leaving a neighbouring station by an early train.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1236,"[' Only last night we had news that the couple had been hunted down in Liverpool, and they prove to have no connection whatever with the matter in hand.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1237,"[' Then it was that in my despair and disappointment, after a sleepless night, I came straight to you by the early train.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1238,"['"" ""I suppose the local investigation was relaxed while this false clue was being followed up?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1239,"['"" ""It was entirely dropped.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1240,"['"" ""So that three days have been wasted.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1241,[' Have you been able to trace any connection between the missing boy and this German master?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1242,"['"" ""None at all.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1243,"['"" ""Was he in the master\'s class?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1244,"['"" ""No; he never exchanged a word with him so far as I know.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1245,"['"" ""That is certainly very singular.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1246,[' Had the boy a bicycle?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1247,"['"" ""No.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1248,"['"" ""Was any other bicycle missing?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1249,"['"" ""No.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1250,"['"" ""Is that certain?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1251,"['"" ""Quite.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1252,"['"" ""Well, now, you do not mean to seriously suggest that this German rode off upon a bicycle in the dead of the night bearing the boy in his arms?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1253,"['"" ""Certainly not.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1254,"['"" ""Then what is the theory in your mind?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1255,"['"" ""The bicycle may have been a blind.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1256,[' Did anyone call to see the boy on the day before he disappeared?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1257,"['"" ""No.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1258,"['"" ""Did he get any letters?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1259,"['"" ""Yes; one letter.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1260,"['"" ""From whom?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1261,"['"" ""From his father.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1262,"['"" ""Do you open the boys\' letters?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1263,"['"" ""No.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1264,"['"" ""How do you know it was from the father?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1265,"['"" ""The coat of arms was on the envelope, and it was addressed in the Duke\'s peculiar stiff hand.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1266,[' In the latter case you would expect that some prompting from outside would be needed to make so young a lad do such a thing.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1267,"[' His only correspondent, so far as I know, was his own father.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1268,"['"" ""Who wrote to him on the very day of his disappearance.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1269,[' But he was always kind to the boy in his own way.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1270,"['"" ""But the sympathies of the latter were with the mother?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1271,"['"" ""Yes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1272,"['"" ""Did he say so?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1273,"['"" ""No.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1274,"['"" ""The Duke, then?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1275,"['"" ""Good heavens, no!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1276,"['"" ""Then how could you know?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1277,"['"" ""I have had some confidential talks with Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1278,"["" James Wilder, his Grace's secretary.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1279,"["" By the way, that last letter of the Duke's-was it found in the boy's room after he was gone?""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1280,"['"" ""No; he had taken it with him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1281,"[' I think, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1282,"[' Holmes, it is time that we were leaving for Euston.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1283,"['"" ""I will order a four-wheeler.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1284,"[' In the meantime I will do a little quiet work at your own doors, and perhaps the scent is not so cold but that two old hounds like Watson and myself may get a sniff of it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1285,"['"" That evening found us in the cold, bracing atmosphere of the Peak country, in which Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1286,"["" Huxtable's famous school is situated.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1287,"[' A card was lying on the hall table, and the butler whispered something to his master, who turned to us with agitation in every heavy feature.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1288,"[' ""The Duke is here,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1289,"[' Come, gentlemen, and I will introduce you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1290,"['"" I was, of course, familiar with the pictures of the famous statesman, but the man himself was very different from his representation.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1291,"[' He was a tall and stately person, scrupulously dressed, with a drawn, thin face, and a nose which was grotesquely curved and long.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1292,"[' Beside him stood a very young man, whom I understood to be Wilder, the private secretary.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1293,[' I learned that your object was to invite Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1294,[' Sherlock Holmes to undertake the conduct of this case.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1295,"[' His Grace is surprised, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1296,"[' Huxtable, that you should have taken such a step without consulting him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1297,"['"" ""When I learned that the police had failed--"" ""His Grace is by no means convinced that the police have failed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1298,"['"" ""But surely, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1299,"[' Wilder--"" ""You are well aware, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1300,"[' Huxtable, that his Grace is particularly anxious to avoid all public scandal.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1301,[' He prefers to take as few people as possible into his confidence.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1302,"['"" ""The matter can be easily remedied,"" said the brow-beaten doctor; ""Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1303,[' Sherlock Holmes can return to London by the morning train.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1304,"['"" ""Hardly that, Doctor, hardly that,"" said Holmes, in his blandest voice.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1305,"[' Whether I have the shelter of your roof or of the village inn is, of course, for you to decide.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1306,"['"" I could see that the unfortunate doctor was in the last stage of indecision, from which he was rescued by the deep, sonorous voice of the red-bearded Duke, which boomed out like a dinner-gong.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1307,[' But since Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1308,"[' Holmes has already been taken into your confidence, it would indeed be absurd that we should not avail ourselves of his services.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1309,"[' Far from going to the inn, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1310,"[' Holmes, I should be pleased if you would come and stay with me at Holdernesse Hall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1311,"['"" ""I thank your Grace.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1312,[' For the purposes of my investigation I think that it would be wiser for me to remain at the scene of the mystery.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1313,"['"" ""Just as you like, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1314,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1315,[' Any information which Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1316,"[' Wilder or I can give you is, of course, at your disposal.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1317,"['"" ""It will probably be necessary for me to see you at the Hall,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1318,"[' ""I do not think so,"" he said, at last.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1319,[' But he received it on that day?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1320,"['"" ""Yes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1321,"['"" ""Was there anything in your letter which might have unbalanced him or induced him to take such a step?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1322,"['"" ""No, sir, certainly not.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1323,"['"" ""Did you post that letter yourself?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1324,"['"" The nobleman\'s reply was interrupted by his secretary, who broke in with some heat.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1325,"[' ""His Grace is not in the habit of posting letters himself,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1326,"[' ""This letter was laid with others upon the study table, and I myself put them in the post-bag.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1327,"['"" ""You are sure this one was among them?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1328,"['"" ""Yes; I observed it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1329,"['"" ""How many letters did your Grace write that day?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1330,"['"" ""Twenty or thirty.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1331,[' But surely this is somewhat irrelevant?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1332,"['"" ""Not entirely,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1333,"[' I have already said that I do not believe that the Duchess would encourage so monstrous an action, but the lad had the most wrong-headed opinions, and it is possible that he may have fled to her, aided and abetted by this German.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1334,"[' I think, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1335,"[' Huxtable, that we will now return to the Hall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1336,"['"" I could see that there were other questions which Holmes would have wished to put; but the nobleman\'s abrupt manner showed that the interview was at an end.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1337,"[' It was evident that to his intensely aristocratic nature this discussion of his intimate family affairs with a stranger was most abhorrent, and that he feared lest every fresh question would throw a fiercer light into the discreetly shadowed corners of his ducal history.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1338,"[' In his case a trailer of ivy had given way under his weight, and we saw by the light of a lantern the mark on the lawn where his heels had come down.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1339,"[' Sherlock Holmes left the house alone, and only returned after eleven.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1340,"[' He had obtained a large ordnance map of the neighbourhood, and this he brought into my room, where he laid it out on the bed, and, having balanced the lamp in the middle of it, he began to smoke over it, and occasionally to point out objects of interest with the reeking amber of his pipe.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1341,"[' ""This case grows upon me, Watson,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1342,[' If these two folk passed away by road it was THIS road.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1343,"['"" ""Exactly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1344,"['"" ""By a singular and happy chance we are able to some extent to check what passed along this road during the night in question.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1345,"[' The people at the inn were alert all night, awaiting his coming, and one or other of them seems to have continually had an eye upon the road.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1346,"[' If their evidence is good, then we are fortunate enough to be able to block the west, and also to be able to say that the fugitives did NOT use the road at all.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1347,"['"" ""But the bicycle?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1348,"['"" I objected.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1349,"[' ""Well, well!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1350,"['"" said Holmes, impatiently.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1351,[' what is this?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1352,"['"" There was an agitated knock at the door, and an instant afterwards Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1353,[' Huxtable was in the room.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1354,"["" Either the fear of the law or the Duke's purse will certainly get out of them all that they know.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1355,"['"" ""So far, so good,"" said Holmes, when the doctor had at last left the room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1356,"[' Look here, Watson!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1357,[' It is vain to look elsewhere for tracks in this dry weather; but at THAT point there is certainly a chance of some record being left.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1358,"[' I will call you early to-morrow morning, and you and I will try if we can throw some little light upon the mystery.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1359,"['"" The day was just breaking when I woke to find the long, thin form of Holmes by my bedside.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1360,"[' ""I have done the lawn and the bicycle shed,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1361,"[' I must beg you to hurry, for we have a great day before us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1362,"['"" His eyes shone, and his cheek was flushed with the exhilaration of the master workman who sees his work lie ready before him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1363,"[' A very different Holmes, this active, alert man, from the introspective and pallid dreamer of Baker Street.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1364,"[' With high hopes we struck across the peaty, russet moor, intersected with a thousand sheep paths, until we came to the broad, light-green belt which marked the morass between us and Holdernesse.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1365,"[' ""Check number one,"" said Holmes, looking gloomily over the rolling expanse of the moor.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1366,"[' ""We have it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1367,"['"" But Holmes was shaking his head, and his face was puzzled and expectant rather than joyous.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1368,"[' ""A bicycle, certainly, but not THE bicycle,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1369,"[' This track, as you perceive, was made by a rider who was going from the direction of the school.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1370,"['"" ""Or towards it?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1371,"['"" ""No, no, my dear Watson.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1372,"[' It may or may not be connected with our inquiry, but we will follow it backwards before we go any farther.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1373,"['"" We did so, and at the end of a few hundred yards lost the tracks as we emerged from the boggy portion of the moor.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1374,[' Holmes sat down on a boulder and rested his chin in his hands.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1375,"[' ""It is, of course, possible that a cunning man might change the tyre of his bicycle in order to leave unfamiliar tracks.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1376,[' A criminal who was capable of such a thought is a man whom I should be proud to do business with.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1377,"[' We will leave this question undecided and hark back to our morass again, for we have left a good deal unexplored.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1378,"['"" We continued our systematic survey of the edge of the sodden portion of the moor, and soon our perseverance was gloriously rewarded.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1379,[' Holmes gave a cry of delight as he approached it.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1380,"[' ""Here is Herr Heidegger, sure enough!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1381,"['"" cried Holmes, exultantly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1382,"[' ""My reasoning seems to have been pretty sound, Watson.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1383,"['"" ""I congratulate you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1384,"['"" ""But we have a long way still to go.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1385,[' I fear that it will not lead very far.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1386,"['"" We found, however, as we advanced that this portion of the moor is intersected with soft patches, and, though we frequently lost sight of the track, we always succeeded in picking it up once more.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1387,"[' ""Do you observe,"" said Holmes, ""that the rider is now undoubtedly forcing the pace?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1388,[' Holmes held up a crumpled branch of flowering gorse.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1389,"[' ""Bad!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1390,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1391,"[' Suddenly, as I looked ahead, the gleam of metal caught my eye from amid the thick gorse bushes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1392,[' That he could have gone on after receiving such an injury said much for the vitality and courage of the man.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1393,"[' Holmes turned the body over reverently, and examined it with great attention.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1394,"[' He then sat in deep thought for a time, and I could see by his ruffled brow that this grim discovery had not, in his opinion, advanced us much in our inquiry.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1395,"[' ""It is a little difficult to know what to do, Watson,"" said he, at last.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1396,"["" On the other hand, we are bound to inform the police of the discovery, and to see that this poor fellow's body is looked after.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1397,"['"" ""I could take a note back.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1398,"['"" ""But I need your company and assistance.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1399,"[' Bring him over here, and he will guide the police.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1400,"['"" I brought the peasant across, and Holmes dispatched the frightened man with a note to Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1401,[' Huxtable.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1402,"[' ""Now, Watson,"" said he, ""we have picked up two clues this morning.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1403,"[' Before we start to investigate that, let us try to realize what we DO know so as to make the most of it, and to separate the essential from the accidental.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1404,"['"" ""First of all I wish to impress upon you that the boy certainly left of his own free will.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1405,[' The natural action of a man in pursuing a little boy would be to run after him.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1406,[' Nor were there any human footmarks.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1407,"['"" ""Holmes,"" I cried, ""this is impossible.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1408,"['"" ""Admirable!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1409,"['"" he said.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1410,[' Can you suggest any fallacy?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1411,"['"" ""He could not have fractured his skull in a fall?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1412,"['"" ""In a morass, Watson?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1413,"['"" ""I am at my wit\'s end.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1414,"['"" ""Tut, tut; we have solved some worse problems.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1415,"[' Come, then, and, having exhausted the Palmer, let us see what the Dunlop with the patched cover has to offer us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1416,"['"" We picked up the track and followed it onwards for some distance; but soon the moor rose into a long, heather-tufted curve, and we left the watercourse behind us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1417,"[' At the spot where we saw the last of the Dunlop tyre it might equally have led to Holdernesse Hall, the stately towers of which rose some miles to our left, or to a low, grey village which lay in front of us, and marked the position of the Chesterfield high road.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1418,"[' As we approached the forbidding and squalid inn, with the sign of a game-cock above the door, Holmes gave a sudden groan and clutched me by the shoulder to save himself from falling.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1419,"[' With difficulty he limped up to the door, where a squat, dark, elderly man was smoking a black clay pipe.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1420,"[' ""How are you, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1421,[' Reuben Hayes?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1422,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1423,"["" It's easy to see a man who is master of his own house.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1424,"["" I suppose you haven't such a thing as a carriage in your stables?""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1425,"['"" ""No; I have not.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1426,"['"" ""I can hardly put my foot to the ground.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1427,"['"" ""Don\'t put it to the ground.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1428,"['"" ""But I can\'t walk.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1429,"['"" ""Well, then, hop.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1430,"['"" Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1431,"["" Reuben Hayes's manner was far from gracious, but Holmes took it with admirable good-humour.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1432,"[' ""Look here, my man,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1433,"[' ""Where do you want to go?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1434,"['"" ""To Holdernesse Hall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1435,"['"" ""Pals of the Dook, I suppose?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1436,"['"" said the landlord, surveying our mud-stained garments with ironical eyes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1437,[' Holmes laughed good-naturedly.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1438,[' They expect to get him every hour.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1439,"['"" Again a swift change passed over the heavy, unshaven face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1440,"[' ""I\'ve less reason to wish the Dook well than most men,"" said he, ""for I was his head coachman once, and cruel bad he treated me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1441,"["" But I'm glad to hear that the young lord was heard of in Liverpool, and I'll help you to take the news to the Hall.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1442,"['"" ""Thank you,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1443,[' Then you can bring round the bicycle.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1444,"['"" ""I haven\'t got a bicycle.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1445,"['"" Holmes held up a sovereign.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1446,"[' ""I tell you, man, that I haven\'t got one.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1447,"["" I'll let you have two horses as far as the Hall.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1448,"['"" ""Well, well,"" said Holmes, ""we\'ll talk about it when we\'ve had something to eat.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1449,"['"" When we were left alone in the stone-flagged kitchen it was astonishing how rapidly that sprained ankle recovered.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1450,"[' Holmes was lost in thought, and once or twice he walked over to the window and stared earnestly out.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1451,"[' Holmes had sat down again after one of these excursions, when he suddenly sprang out of his chair with a loud exclamation.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1452,"[' ""By Heaven, Watson, I believe that I\'ve got it!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1453,"['"" he cried.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1454,"[' Watson, do you remember seeing any cow-tracks to-day?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1455,"['"" ""Yes, several.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1456,"['"" ""Where?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1457,"['"" ""Well, everywhere.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1458,[' Holmes raised the hind leg of one of them and laughed aloud.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1459,"["" I saw Holmes's eye darting to right and left among the litter of iron and wood which was scattered about the floor.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1460,"[' Suddenly, however, we heard a step behind us, and there was the landlord, his heavy eyebrows drawn over his savage eyes, his swarthy features convulsed with passion.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1461,"[' He held a short, metal-headed stick in his hand, and he advanced in so menacing a fashion that I was right glad to feel the revolver in my pocket.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1462,"[' ""What are you doing there?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1463,"['"" ""Why, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1464,"[' Reuben Hayes,"" said Holmes, coolly, ""one might think that you were afraid of our finding something out.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1465,"['"" The man mastered himself with a violent effort, and his grim mouth loosened into a false laugh, which was more menacing than his frown.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1466,"[' ""But look here, mister, I don\'t care for folk poking about my place without my leave, so the sooner you pay your score and get out of this the better I shall be pleased.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1467,"['"" ""All right, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1468,"[' Hayes-no harm meant,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1469,"[' ""We have been having a look at your horses, but I think I\'ll walk after all.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1470,"["" We did not go very far along the road, for Holmes stopped the instant that the curve hid us from the landlord's view.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1471,"["" No, no; I can't possibly leave it.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1472,"['"" ""I am convinced,"" said I, ""that this Reuben Hayes knows all about it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1473,[' I think we shall have another look at it in an unobtrusive way.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1474,"['"" A long, sloping hillside, dotted with grey limestone boulders, stretched behind us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1475,"[' We had turned off the road, and were making our way up the hill, when, looking in the direction of Holdernesse Hall, I saw a cyclist coming swiftly along.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1476,"[' ""Get down, Watson!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1477,"['"" cried Holmes, with a heavy hand upon my shoulder.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1478,[' We had hardly sunk from view when the man flew past us on the road.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1479,"[' Amid a rolling cloud of dust I caught a glimpse of a pale, agitated face-a face with horror in every lineament, the mouth open, the eyes staring wildly in front.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1480,[' It was like some strange caricature of the dapper James Wilder whom we had seen the night before.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1481,"[' ""The Duke\'s secretary!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1482,"['"" cried Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1483,"[' ""Come, Watson, let us see what he does.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1484,"['"" We scrambled from rock to rock until in a few moments we had made our way to a point from which we could see the front door of the inn.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1485,"[' No one was moving about the house, nor could we catch a glimpse of any faces at the windows.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1486,"[' Then in the gloom we saw the two side-lamps of a trap light up in the stable yard of the inn, and shortly afterwards heard the rattle of hoofs, as it wheeled out into the road and tore off at a furious pace in the direction of Chesterfield.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1487,"[' ""What do you make of that, Watson?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1488,"['"" Holmes whispered.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1489,"[' ""It looks like a flight.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1490,"['"" ""A single man in a dog-cart, so far as I could see.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1491,"[' Well, it certainly was not Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1492,"[' James Wilder, for there he is at the door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1493,"['"" A red square of light had sprung out of the darkness.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1494,"[' In the middle of it was the black figure of the secretary, his head advanced, peering out into the night.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1495,"[' Then at last there were steps in the road, a second figure was visible for an instant against the light, the door shut, and all was black once more.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1496,[' Five minutes later a lamp was lit in a room upon the first floor.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1497,"[' ""It seems to be a curious class of custom that is done by the Fighting Cock,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1498,"[' Now, what in the world is Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1499,"[' James Wilder doing in that den at this hour of night, and who is the companion who comes to meet him there?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1500,"[' Come, Watson, we must really take a risk and try to investigate this a little more closely.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1501,"['"" Together we stole down to the road and crept across to the door of the inn.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1502,"[' Holmes struck a match and held it to the back wheel, and I heard him chuckle as the light fell upon a patched Dunlop tyre.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1503,"[' If you bend your back and support yourself upon the wall, I think that I can manage.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1504,"['"" An instant later his feet were on my shoulders.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1505,"[' ""Come, my friend,"" said he, ""our day\'s work has been quite long enough.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1506,"["" It's a long walk to the school, and the sooner we get started the better.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1507,"['"" He hardly opened his lips during that weary trudge across the moor, nor would he enter the school when he reached it, but went on to Mackleton Station, whence he could send some telegrams.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1508,[' Late at night I heard him consoling Dr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1509,"["" Huxtable, prostrated by the tragedy of his master's death, and later still he entered my room as alert and vigorous as he had been when he started in the morning.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1510,"[' ""All goes well, my friend,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1511,"[' ""I promise that before to-morrow evening we shall have reached the solution of the mystery.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1512,"['"" At eleven o\'clock next morning my friend and I were walking up the famous yew avenue of Holdernesse Hall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1513,[' There we found Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1514,"[' James Wilder, demure and courtly, but with some trace of that wild terror of the night before still lurking in his furtive eyes and in his twitching features.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1515,[' We received a telegram from Dr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1516,"[' Huxtable yesterday afternoon, which told us of your discovery.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1517,"['"" ""I must see the Duke, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1518,[' Wilder.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1519,"['"" ""But he is in his room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1520,"['"" ""Then I must go to his room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1521,"['"" ""I believe he is in his bed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1522,"['"" ""I will see him there.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1523,"['"" Holmes\'s cold and inexorable manner showed the secretary that it was useless to argue with him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1524,"[' ""Very good, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1525,[' Holmes; I will tell him that you are here.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1526,"['"" After half an hour\'s delay the great nobleman appeared.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1527,"[' His face was more cadaverous than ever, his shoulders had rounded, and he seemed to me to be an altogether older man than he had been the morning before.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1528,"["" But my friend's eyes were fixed upon the secretary, who stood by his master's chair.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1529,"[' ""I think, your Grace, that I could speak more freely in Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1530,"["" Wilder's absence.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1531,"['"" The man turned a shade paler and cast a malignant glance at Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1532,"[' Now, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1533,"[' Holmes, what have you to say?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1534,"['"" My friend waited until the door had closed behind the retreating secretary.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1535,"[' ""The fact is, your Grace,"" said he, ""that my colleague, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1536,"[' Watson, and myself had an assurance from Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1537,[' Huxtable that a reward had been offered in this case.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1538,[' I should like to have this confirmed from your own lips.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1539,"['"" ""Certainly, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1540,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1541,"['"" ""It amounted, if I am correctly informed, to five thousand pounds to anyone who will tell you where your son is?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1542,"['"" ""Exactly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1543,"['"" ""And another thousand to the man who will name the person or persons who keep him in custody?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1544,"['"" ""Exactly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1545,"['"" ""Under the latter heading is included, no doubt, not only those who may have taken him away, but also those who conspire to keep him in his present position?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1546,"['"" ""Yes, yes,"" cried the Duke, impatiently.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1547,"[' ""If you do your work well, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1548,"[' Sherlock Holmes, you will have no reason to complain of niggardly treatment.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1549,"['"" My friend rubbed his thin hands together with an appearance of avidity which was a surprise to me, who knew his frugal tastes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1550,"[' ""I fancy that I see your Grace\'s cheque-book upon the table,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1551,"[' The Capital and Counties Bank, Oxford Street branch, are my agents.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1552,"['"" His Grace sat very stern and upright in his chair, and looked stonily at my friend.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1553,"[' ""Is this a joke, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1554,[' Holmes?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1555,"[' I know where your son is, and I know some, at least, of those who are holding him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1556,"['"" The Duke\'s beard had turned more aggressively red than ever against his ghastly white face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1557,"[' ""And whom do you accuse?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1558,"['"" Sherlock Holmes\'s answer was an astounding one.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1559,"[' ""And now, your Grace, I\'ll trouble you for that cheque.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1560,"['"" Never shall I forget the Duke\'s appearance as he sprang up and clawed with his hands like one who is sinking into an abyss.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1561,"[' Then, with an extraordinary effort of aristocratic self-command, he sat down and sank his face in his hands.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1562,"[' ""How much do you know?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1563,"['"" he asked at last, without raising his head.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1564,"[' ""I saw you together last night.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1565,"['"" ""Does anyone else besides your friend know?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1566,"['"" ""I have spoken to no one.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1567,"['"" The Duke took a pen in his quivering fingers and opened his cheque-book.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1568,"[' ""I shall be as good as my word, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1569,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1570,[' When the offer was first made I little thought the turn which events might take.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1571,"[' I think twelve thousand pounds is the sum that I owe you, is it not?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1572,"['"" But Holmes smiled and shook his head.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1573,[' It was the work of this brutal ruffian whom he had the misfortune to employ.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1574,"['"" ""I must take the view, your Grace, that when a man embarks upon a crime he is morally guilty of any other crime which may spring from it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1575,"['"" ""Morally, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1576,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1577,"[' A man cannot be condemned for a murder at which he was not present, and which he loathes and abhors as much as you do.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1578,[' I tell you that you must save him!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1579,"['"" The Duke had dropped the last attempt at self-command, and was pacing the room with a convulsed face and with his clenched hands raving in the air.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1580,"[' ""I appreciate your conduct in coming here before you spoke to anyone else,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1581,"[' ""At least, we may take counsel how far we can minimize this hideous scandal.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1582,"['"" ""Exactly,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1583,[' I am disposed to help your Grace to the best of my ability; but in order to do so I must understand to the last detail how the matter stands.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1584,[' I realize that your words applied to Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1585,"[' James Wilder, and that he is not the murderer.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1586,"['"" ""No; the murderer has escaped.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1587,"['"" Sherlock Holmes smiled demurely.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1588,"[' ""Your Grace can hardly have heard of any small reputation which I possess, or you would not imagine that it is so easy to escape me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1589,[' I had a telegram from the head of the local police before I left the school this morning.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1590,"['"" The Duke leaned back in his chair and stared with amazement at my friend.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1591,"[' ""You seem to have powers that are hardly human,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1592,"[' I am right glad to hear it, if it will not react upon the fate of James.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1593,"['"" ""Your secretary?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1594,"['"" ""No, sir; my son.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1595,"['"" It was Holmes\'s turn to look astonished.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1596,"[' When I was a very young man, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1597,"[' Holmes, I loved with such a love as comes only once in a lifetime.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1598,"[' I could not acknowledge the paternity to the world; but I gave him the best of educations, and since he came to manhood I have kept him near my person.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1599,"["" I answer that it was because I could see his mother's face in his, and that for her dear sake there was no end to my long-suffering.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1600,"[' ""James came into contact with this fellow Hayes because the man was a tenant of mine, and James acted as agent.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1601,"[' Well, James opened the letter and inserted a note asking Arthur to meet him in a little wood called the Ragged Shaw, which is near to the school.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1602,"["" He used the Duchess's name, and in that way got the boy to come.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1603,"[' That evening James bicycled over-I am telling you what he has himself confessed to me-and he told Arthur, whom he met in the wood, that his mother longed to see him, that she was awaiting him on the moor, and that if he would come back into the wood at midnight he would find a man with a horse, who would take him to her.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1604,"[' It appears-though this James only heard yesterday-that they were pursued, that Hayes struck the pursuer with his stick, and that the man died of his injuries.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1605,"[' Hayes brought Arthur to his public-house, the Fighting Cock, where he was confined in an upper room, under the care of Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1606,"[' Hayes, who is a kindly woman, but entirely under the control of her brutal husband.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1607,"[' ""Well, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1608,"[' Holmes, that was the state of affairs when I first saw you two days ago.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1609,"[' In deference to my promise, and much against my will, I consented to leave him there for three days under the charge of Mrs.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1610,"[' Hayes, since it was evident that it was impossible to inform the police where he was without telling them also who was the murderer, and I could not see how that murderer could be punished without ruin to my unfortunate James.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1611,"[' You asked for frankness, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1612,"[' Holmes, and I have taken you at your word, for I have now told you everything without an attempt at circumlocution or concealment.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1613,[' Do you in turn be as frank with me.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1614,"['"" ""I will,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1615,"["" You have condoned a felony and you have aided the escape of a murderer; for I cannot doubt that any money which was taken by James Wilder to aid his accomplice in his flight came from your Grace's purse.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1616,"['"" The Duke bowed his assent.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1617,[' It is that you ring for the footman and let me give such orders as I like.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1618,"['"" Without a word the Duke pressed the electric bell.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1619,"[' ""You will be glad to hear,"" said Holmes, ""that your young master is found.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1620,"[' ""Now,"" said Holmes, when the rejoicing lackey had disappeared, ""having secured the future, we can afford to be more lenient with the past.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1621,"[' I am not in an official position, and there is no reason, so long as the ends of justice are served, why I should disclose all that I know.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1622,"[' I would warn your Grace, however, that the continued presence of Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1623,[' James Wilder in your household can only lead to misfortune.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1624,"['"" ""I understand that, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1625,"[' Holmes, and it is already settled that he shall leave me for ever and go to seek his fortune in Australia.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1626,"['"" ""In that case, your Grace, since you have yourself stated that any unhappiness in your married life was caused by his presence, I would suggest that you make such amends as you can to the Duchess, and that you try to resume those relations which have been so unhappily interrupted.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1627,"['"" ""That also I have arranged, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1628,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1629,[' I wrote to the Duchess this morning.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1630,"['"" ""In that case,"" said Holmes, rising, ""I think that my friend and I can congratulate ourselves upon several most happy results from our little visit to the North.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1631,[' Was it from Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1632,[' Wilder that he learned so extraordinary a device?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1633,"['"" The Duke stood in thought for a moment, with a look of intense surprise on his face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1634,[' Then he opened a door and showed us into a large room furnished as a museum.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1635,"[' He led the way to a glass case in a corner, and pointed to the inscription.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1636,[' They are supposed to have belonged to some of the marauding Barons of Holdernesse in the Middle Ages.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1637,"['"" Holmes opened the case, and moistening his finger he passed it along the shoe.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1638,"[' ""It is the second most interesting object that I have seen in the North.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1639,"['"" ""And the first?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1640,"['"" Holmes folded up his cheque and placed it carefully in his note-book.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1641,"[' ""I am a poor man,"" said he, as he patted it affectionately and thrust it into the depths of his inner pocket.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1642,"["" Holmes, however, like all great artists, lived for his art's sake, and, save in the case of the Duke of Holdernesse, I have seldom known him claim any large reward for his inestimable services.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1643,"[' So unworldly was he-or so capricious-that he frequently refused his help to the powerful and wealthy where the problem made no appeal to his sympathies, while he would devote weeks of most intense application to the affairs of some humble client whose case presented those strange and dramatic qualities which appealed to his imagination and challenged his ingenuity.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1644,"["" In this memorable year '95 a curious and incongruous succession of cases had engaged his attention, ranging from his famous investigation of the sudden death of Cardinal Tosca-an inquiry which was carried out by him at the express desire of His Holiness the Pope-down to his arrest of Wilson, the notorious canary- trainer, which removed a plague-spot from the East-End of London.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1645,"["" Close on the heels of these two famous cases came the tragedy of Woodman's Lee, and the very obscure circumstances which surrounded the death of Captain Peter Carey.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1646,[' No record of the doings of Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1647,[' Sherlock Holmes would be complete which did not include some account of this very unusual affair.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1648,[' During the first week of July my friend had been absent so often and so long from our lodgings that I knew he had something on hand.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1649,[' The fact that several rough-looking men called during that time and inquired for Captain Basil made me understand that Holmes was working somewhere under one of the numerous disguises and names with which he concealed his own formidable identity.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1650,"[' He said nothing of his business to me, and it was not my habit to force a confidence.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1651,"[' He had gone out before breakfast, and I had sat down to mine, when he strode into the room, his hat upon his head and a huge barbed-headed spear tucked like an umbrella under his arm.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1652,"[' ""Good gracious, Holmes!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1653,"['"" I cried.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1654,[' Come and join us.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1655,"['"" Our visitor was an exceedingly alert man, thirty years of age, dressed in a quiet tweed suit, but retaining the erect bearing of one who was accustomed to official uniform.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1656,"[' I recognised him at once as Stanley Hopkins, a young police inspector for whose future Holmes had high hopes, while he in turn professed the admiration and respect of a pupil for the scientific methods of the famous amateur.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1657,"[' I spent the night in town, for I came up yesterday to report.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1658,"['"" ""And what had you to report?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1659,"['"" ""Failure, sir; absolute failure.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1660,"['"" ""You have made no progress?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1661,"['"" ""None.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1662,"['"" ""Dear me!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1663,[' I must have a look at the matter.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1664,"['"" ""I wish to heavens that you would, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1665,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1666,"["" For goodness' sake come down and lend me a hand.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1667,"['"" ""Well, well, it just happens that I have already read all the available evidence, including the report of the inquest, with some care.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1668,"[' ""It was the man\'s own pouch, sir.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1669,"[' However, my friend Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1670,"[' Watson knows nothing of this matter, and I should be none the worse for hearing the sequence of events once more.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1671,"[' ""I have a few dates here which will give you the career of the dead man, Captain Peter Carey.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1672,"[' ""There were some most singular points about the man.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1673,"[' He has been known to drive his wife and his daughter out of doors in the middle of the night, and flog them through the park until the whole village outside the gates was aroused by their screams.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1674,"[' In short, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1675,"[' Holmes, you would go far before you found a more dangerous man than Peter Carey, and I have heard that he bore the same character when he commanded his ship.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1676,"[' ""You must have read in the account of the inquest about the man\'s cabin, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1677,[' Holmes; but perhaps your friend here has not heard of it.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1678,"[' There are small windows on each side, which were covered by curtains and never opened.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1679,"[' One of these windows was turned towards the high road, and when the light burned in it at night the folk used to point it out to each other and wonder what Black Peter was doing in there.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1680,"["" That's the window, Mr.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1681,"[' Holmes, which gave us one of the few bits of positive evidence that came out at the inquest.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1682,"[' ""You remember that a stonemason, named Slater, walking from Forest Row about one o\'clock in the morning-two days before the murder-stopped as he passed the grounds and looked at the square of light still shining among the trees.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1683,"["" He swears that the shadow of a man's head turned sideways was clearly visible on the blind, and that this shadow was certainly not that of Peter Carey, whom he knew well.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1684,"[' It was that of a bearded man, but the beard was short and bristled forwards in a way very different from that of the captain.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1685,"[' So he says, but he had been two hours in the public-house, and it is some distance from the road to the window.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1686,"[' He roamed about the house, and the women ran for it when they heard him coming.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1687,"["" About two o'clock the following morning his daughter, who slept with her window open, heard a most fearful yell from that direction, but it was no unusual thing for him to bawl and shout when he was in drink, so no notice was taken.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1688,"[' On rising at seven one of the maids noticed that the door of the hut was open, but so great was the terror which the man caused that it was midday before anyone would venture down to see what had become of him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1689,[' Peeping into the open door they saw a sight which sent them flying with white faces into the village.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1690,"[' ""Well, I have fairly steady nerves, as you know, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1691,"[' Holmes, but I give you my word that I got a shake when I put my head into that little house.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1692,"["" There was a bunk at one end, a sea-chest, maps and charts, a picture of the SEA UNICORN, a line of log-books on a shelf, all exactly as one would expect to find it in a captain's room.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1693,"[' And there in the middle of it was the man himself, his face twisted like a lost soul in torment, and his great brindled beard stuck upwards in his agony.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1694,"[' Before I permitted anything to be moved I examined most carefully the ground outside, and also the floor of the room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1695,[' There were no footmarks.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1696,"['"" ""Meaning that you saw none?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1697,"['"" ""I assure you, sir, that there were none.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1698,"['"" ""My good Hopkins, I have investigated many crimes, but I have never yet seen one which was committed by a flying creature.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1699,"[' ""I was a fool not to call you in at the time, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1700,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1701,"["" On the stock was engraved 'Ss.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1702,"[' SEA UNICORN, Dundee.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1703,"[""' This seemed to establish that the crime had been done in a moment of fury, and that the murderer had seized the first weapon which came in his way.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1704,"[' The fact that the crime was committed at two in the morning, and yet Peter Carey was fully dressed, suggested that he had an appointment with the murderer, which is borne out by the fact that a bottle of rum and two dirty glasses stood upon the table.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1705,"['"" ""Yes,"" said Holmes; ""I think that both inferences are permissible.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1706,"[' It is of no importance to us, however, since the decanters were full, and it had therefore not been used.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1707,"['"" ""For all that its presence has some significance,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1708,"[' ""However, let us hear some more about the objects which do seem to you to bear upon the case.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1709,"['"" ""There was this tobacco-pouch upon the table.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1710,"['"" ""What part of the table?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1711,"['"" ""It lay in the middle.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1712,"[' On the first page were written the initials ""J.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1713,['H.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1714,['N.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1715,"['"" and the date ""1883.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1716,"['"" Holmes laid it on the table and examined it in his minute way, while Hopkins and I gazed over each shoulder.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1717,"["" I thought that 'J.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1718,['H.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1719,['N.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1720,"[""' were the initials of a broker, and that 'C.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1721,['P.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1722,['R.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1723,"[""' may have been his client.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1724,"['"" ""Try Canadian Pacific Railway,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1725,"[' I have already examined the old Stock Exchange lists, and I can find no one in 1883 either in the House or among the outside brokers whose initials correspond with these.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1726,"[' You will admit, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1727,"[' Holmes, that there is a possibility that these initials are those of the second person who was present-in other words, of the murderer.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1728,[' I would also urge that the introduction into the case of a document relating to large masses of valuable securities gives us for the first time some indication of a motive for the crime.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1729,"['"" Sherlock Holmes\'s face showed that he was thoroughly taken aback by this new development.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1730,"[' ""I must admit both your points,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1731,[' Have you endeavoured to trace any of the securities here mentioned?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1732,"['"" ""Inquiries are now being made at the offices, but I fear that the complete register of the stockholders of these South American concerns is in South America, and that some weeks must elapse before we can trace the shares.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1733,"['"" Holmes had been examining the cover of the note-book with his magnifying lens.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1734,"[' ""Surely there is some discolouration here,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1735,[' I told you that I picked the book off the floor.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1736,"['"" ""Was the blood-stain above or below?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1737,"['"" ""On the side next the boards.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1738,"['"" ""Which proves, of course, that the book was dropped after the crime was committed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1739,"['"" ""Exactly, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1740,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1741,[' It lay near the door.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1742,"['"" ""I suppose that none of these securities have been found among the property of the dead man?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1743,"['"" ""No, sir.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1744,"['"" ""Have you any reason to suspect robbery?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1745,"['"" ""No, sir.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1746,[' Nothing seemed to have been touched.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1747,"['"" ""Dear me, it is certainly a very interesting case.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1748,[' It lay at the feet of the dead man.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1749,[' Mrs.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1750,"["" Carey has identified it as being her husband's property.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1751,"['"" Holmes was lost in thought for some time.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1752,"[' ""Well,"" said he, at last, ""I suppose I shall have to come out and have a look at it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1753,"['"" Stanley Hopkins gave a cry of joy.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1754,[' That will indeed be a weight off my mind.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1755,"['"" Holmes shook his finger at the inspector.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1756,"[' If you will call a four-wheeler, Hopkins, we shall be ready to start for Forest Row in a quarter of an hour.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1757,"['"" Alighting at the small wayside station, we drove for some miles through the remains of widespread woods, which were once part of that great forest which for so long held the Saxon invaders at bay-the impenetrable ""weald,"" for sixty years the bulwark of Britain.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1758,"[' Here in a clearing upon the green slope of a hill stood a long, low stone house, approached by a curving drive running through the fields.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1759,"[' Nearer the road, and surrounded on three sides by bushes, was a small outhouse, one window and the door facing in our direction.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1760,"[' Stanley Hopkins led us first to the house, where he introduced us to a haggard, grey-haired woman, the widow of the murdered man, whose gaunt and deep-lined face, with the furtive look of terror in the depths of her red-rimmed eyes, told of the years of hardship and ill-usage which she had endured.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1761,"[' With her was her daughter, a pale, fair-haired girl, whose eyes blazed defiantly at us as she told us that she was glad that her father was dead, and that she blessed the hand which had struck him down.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1762,"[' It was a terrible household that Black Peter Carey had made for himself, and it was with a sense of relief that we found ourselves in the sunlight again and making our way along a path which had been worn across the fields by the feet of the dead man.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1763,"[' Stanley Hopkins drew the key from his pocket, and had stooped to the lock, when he paused with a look of attention and surprise upon his face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1764,[' Holmes had been examining the window.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1765,[' He must have been a very poor burglar.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1766,"['"" ""This is a most extraordinary thing,"" said the inspector; ""I could swear that these marks were not here yesterday evening.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1767,"['"" ""Some curious person from the village, perhaps,"" I suggested.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1768,"[' Few of them would dare to set foot in the grounds, far less try to force their way into the cabin.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1769,"[' What do you think of it, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1770,[' Holmes?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1771,"['"" ""I think that fortune is very kind to us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1772,"['"" ""You mean that the person will come again?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1773,"['"" ""It is very probable.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1774,[' He came expecting to find the door open.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1775,[' What would he do?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1776,"['"" ""Come again next night with a more useful tool.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1777,"['"" ""So I should say.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1778,"[' Meanwhile, let me see the inside of the cabin.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1779,"['"" The traces of the tragedy had been removed, but the furniture within the little room still stood as it had been on the night of the crime.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1780,"[' For two hours, with most intense concentration, Holmes examined every object in turn, but his face showed that his quest was not a successful one.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1781,"[' Let us walk in these beautiful woods, Watson, and give a few hours to the birds and the flowers.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1782,"[' We shall meet you here later, Hopkins, and see if we can come to closer quarters with the gentleman who has paid this visit in the night.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1783,"['"" It was past eleven o\'clock when we formed our little ambuscade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1784,"[' Hopkins was for leaving the door of the hut open, but Holmes was of the opinion that this would rouse the suspicions of the stranger.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1785,"[' Holmes also suggested that we should wait, not inside the hut, but outside it among the bushes which grew round the farther window.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1786,"[' In this way we should be able to watch our man if he struck a light, and see what his object was in this stealthy nocturnal visit.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1787,"[' It was a long and melancholy vigil, and yet brought with it something of the thrill which the hunter feels when he lies beside the water pool and waits for the coming of the thirsty beast of prey.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1788,"[' At first the steps of a few belated villagers, or the sound of voices from the village, lightened our vigil; but one by one these interruptions died away and an absolute stillness fell upon us, save for the chimes of the distant church, which told us of the progress of the night, and for the rustle and whisper of a fine rain falling amid the foliage which roofed us in.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1789,"[' Half-past two had chimed, and it was the darkest hour which precedes the dawn, when we all started as a low but sharp click came from the direction of the gate.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1790,"[' Again there was a long silence, and I had begun to fear that it was a false alarm, when a stealthy step was heard upon the other side of the hut, and a moment later a metallic scraping and clinking.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1791,"[' The nocturnal visitor was a young man, frail and thin, with a black moustache which intensified the deadly pallor of his face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1792,[' Leaning on the table he rapidly turned over the leaves of this volume until he came to the entry which he sought.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1793,"[' Then, with an angry gesture of his clenched hand, he closed the book, replaced it in the corner, and put out the light.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1794,"["" He had hardly turned to leave the hut when Hopkins's hand was on the fellow's collar, and I heard his loud gasp of terror as he understood that he was taken.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1795,"[' ""Now, my fine fellow,"" said Stanley Hopkins, ""who are you, and what do you want here?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1796,"['"" The man pulled himself together and faced us with an effort at self-composure.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1797,[' I assure you that I am innocent.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1798,"['"" ""We\'ll see about that,"" said Hopkins.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1799,"[' ""First of all, what is your name?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1800,"['"" ""It is John Hopley Neligan.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1801,"['"" I saw Holmes and Hopkins exchange a quick glance.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
