1802,"[' ""What are you doing here?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1803,"['"" ""Can I speak confidentially?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1804,"['"" ""No, certainly not.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1805,"['"" ""Why should I tell you?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1806,"['"" ""If you have no answer it may go badly with you at the trial.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1807,"['"" The young man winced.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1808,"[' ""Well, I will tell you,"" he said.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1809,[' Did you ever hear of Dawson and Neligan?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1810,"['"" I could see from Hopkins\'s face that he never had; but Holmes was keenly interested.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1811,[' Neligan was my father.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1812,"['"" At last we were getting something positive, and yet it seemed a long gap between an absconding banker and Captain Peter Carey pinned against the wall with one of his own harpoons.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1813,"["" We all listened intently to the young man's words.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1814,"[' I was only ten years of age at the time, but I was old enough to feel the shame and horror of it all.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1815,"[' He left us a list of the securities he was taking, and he swore that he would come back with his honour cleared, and that none who had trusted him would suffer.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1816,"[' We had a faithful friend, however, who is a business man, and it was he who discovered some time ago that some of the securities which my father had with him have reappeared on the London market.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1817,"["" In any case, if I could prove from Peter Carey's evidence how these securities came on the market it would be a proof that my father had not sold them, and that he had no view to personal profit when he took them.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1818,"[' I tried last night to get at these log-books, but was unable to open the door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1840,"[""' There, Watson, this infernal case has haunted me for ten days.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1900,[' The next instant Holmes and the seaman were rolling on the ground together.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1901,"[' He was a man of such gigantic strength that, even with the handcuffs which Holmes had so deftly fastened upon his wrists, he would have very quickly overpowered my friend had Hopkins and I not rushed to his rescue.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1902,"[' ""I must really apologize, Hopkins,"" said Sherlock Holmes; ""I fear that the scrambled eggs are cold.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1903,"[' However, you will enjoy the rest of your breakfast all the better, will you not, for the thought that you have brought your case to a triumphant conclusion.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1904,"['"" Stanley Hopkins was speechless with amazement.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1905,"[' ""I don\'t know what to say, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1906,"[' Holmes,"" he blurted out at last, with a very red face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1907,"["" Even now I see what you have done, but I don't know how you did it, or what it signifies.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1908,"['"" ""Well, well,"" said Holmes, good-humouredly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1909,"[' You were so absorbed in young Neligan that you could not spare a thought to Patrick Cairns, the true murderer of Peter Carey.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1910,"['"" The hoarse voice of the seaman broke in on our conversation.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1911,"[' ""See here, mister,"" said he, ""I make no complaint of being man-handled in this fashion, but I would have you call things by their right names.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1912,[' Maybe you think I am just slinging you a yarn.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1913,"['"" ""Not at all,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1914,"["" Anyhow, I'd as soon die with a rope round my neck as with Black Peter's knife in my heart.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1915,"['"" ""How came you there?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1916,"['"" asked Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1917,"["" We were coming out of the ice-pack on our way home, with head winds and a week's southerly gale, when we picked up a little craft that had been blown north.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1918,"[' Well, we took him on board, this man, and he and the skipper had some long talks in the cabin.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1919,"["" So far as I know, the man's name was never mentioned, and on the second night he disappeared as if he had never been.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1920,"[' Only one man knew what had happened to him, and that was me, for with my own eyes I saw the skipper tip up his heels and put him over the rail in the middle watch of a dark night, two days before we sighted the Shetland lights.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1921,"[' ""I found out where he was through a sailor man that had met him in London, and down I went to squeeze him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1922,"[' We sat down and we drank and we yarned about old times, but the more he drank the less I liked the look on his face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1923,"[' Then at last he broke out at me, spitting and cursing, with murder in his eyes and a great clasp-knife in his hand.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1924,"[' I stood there, with his blood splashing round me, and I waited for a bit; but all was quiet, so I took heart once more.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1925,"[' I had hardly got outside the hut when I heard someone coming, and I hid among the bushes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1926,"[' A man came slinking along, went into the hut, gave a cry as if he had seen a ghost, and legged it as hard as he could run until he was out of sight.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1927,"[' ""Well, when I came to examine the box I found there was no money in it, and nothing but papers that I would not dare to sell.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1928,"["" That's all I know, and I say again that if I killed Black Peter the law should give me thanks, for I saved them the price of a hempen rope.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1929,"['"" ""A very clear statement,"" said Holmes, rising and lighting his pipe.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1930,"[' ""I think, Hopkins, that you should lose no time in conveying your prisoner to a place of safety.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1931,"[' This room is not well adapted for a cell, and Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1932,[' Patrick Cairns occupies too large a proportion of our carpet.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1933,"['"" ""Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1934,"[' Holmes,"" said Hopkins, ""I do not know how to express my gratitude.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1935,"[' It is very possible if I had known about this note-book it might have led away my thoughts, as it did yours.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1936,"[' Yes, I was certain it was a seaman.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1950,"[' For a long time, even with the utmost discretion and reticence, it would have been impossible to make the facts public; but now the principal person concerned is beyond the reach of human law, and with due suppression the story may be told in such fashion as to injure no one.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1951,[' It records an absolutely unique experience in the career both of Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1952,[' Sherlock Holmes and of myself.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1953,"["" We had been out for one of our evening rambles, Holmes and I, and had returned about six o'clock on a cold, frosty winter's evening.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1954,[' As Holmes turned up the lamp the light fell upon a card on the table.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1957,"[' Heaven help the man, and still more the woman, whose secret and reputation come into the power of Milverton.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1958,[' His method is as follows: He allows it to be known that he is prepared to pay very high sums for letters which compromise people of wealth or position.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1959,"[' I happen to know that he paid seven hundred pounds to a footman for a note two lines in length, and that the ruin of a noble family was the result.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1960,"[' No one knows where his grip may fall, for he is far too rich and far too cunning to work from hand to mouth.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1961,[' He will hold a card back for years in order to play it at the moment when the stake is best worth winning.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1962,"[' I have said that he is the worst man in London, and I would ask you how could one compare the ruffian who in hot blood bludgeons his mate with this man, who methodically and at his leisure tortures the soul and wrings the nerves in order to add to his already swollen money-bags?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1963,"['"" I had seldom heard my friend speak with such intensity of feeling.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1964,"[' ""But surely,"" said I, ""the fellow must be within the grasp of the law?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1965,"['"" ""Technically, no doubt, but practically not.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1966,"[' If ever he blackmailed an innocent person, then, indeed, we should have him; but he is as cunning as the Evil One.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1967,"[' No, no; we must find other ways to fight him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1968,"['"" ""And why is he here?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1969,"['"" ""Because an illustrious client has placed her piteous case in my hands.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1970,"[' A footman opened the door, and a small, stout man in a shaggy astrachan overcoat descended.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1971,"[' Charles Augustus Milverton was a man of fifty, with a large, intellectual head, a round, plump, hairless face, a perpetual frozen smile, and two keen grey eyes, which gleamed brightly from behind broad, golden-rimmed glasses.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1972,"[' His voice was as smooth and suave as his countenance, as he advanced with a plump little hand extended, murmuring his regret for having missed us at his first visit.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1973,[' Holmes disregarded the outstretched hand and looked at him with a face of granite.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1986,"['"" ""Seven thousand pounds.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1987,"['"" ""And the alternative?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1988,"['"" ""My dear sir, it is painful for me to discuss it; but if the money is not paid on the 14th there certainly will be no marriage on the 18th.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1989,"['"" His insufferable smile was more complacent than ever.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1990,[' Holmes thought for a little.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1991,"[' ""You appear to me,"" he said, at last, ""to be taking matters too much for granted.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1992,"[' ""You evidently do not know the Earl,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1993,"["" From the baffled look upon Holmes's face I could see clearly that he did.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1994,"[' If you think that it is in the best interests of your client that these letters should be placed in the hands of the Earl, then you would indeed be foolish to pay so large a sum of money to regain them.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1995,"['"" He rose and seized his astrachan coat.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1996,"[' ""Wait a little,"" he said.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1997,"[' ""At the same time,"" Holmes continued, ""Lady Eva is not a wealthy woman.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

1998,"[' I beg, therefore, that you will moderate your demands, and that you will return the letters at the price I indicate, which is, I assure you, the highest that you can get.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
1999,"['"" Milverton\'s smile broadened and his eyes twinkled humorously.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2000,"[' ""I am aware that what you say is true about the lady\'s resources,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2001,"[' ""At the same time, you must admit that the occasion of a lady\'s marriage is a very suitable time for her friends and relatives to make some little effort upon her behalf.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2002,[' Let me assure them that this little bundle of letters would give more joy than all the candelabra and butter-dishes in London.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2003,"['"" ""It is impossible,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2004,[' Look at this!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2005,"['"" He held up a little note with a coat-of-arms upon the envelope.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2006,"["" But at that time it will be in the hands of the lady's husband.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2007,"["" Surely it is better for you to take the substantial sum which I offer than to ruin this woman's career, which can profit you in no way?""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2008,"['"" ""There you make a mistake, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2009,[' Holmes.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2010,[' You see my point?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2011,"['"" Holmes sprang from his chair.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2012,"[' Now, sir, let us see the contents of that note-book.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2013,"['"" Milverton had glided as quick as a rat to the side of the room, and stood with his back against the wall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2014,"[' ""Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2015,"[' Holmes, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2016,"[' Holmes,"" he said, turning the front of his coat and exhibiting the butt of a large revolver, which projected from the inside pocket.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2017,"[' And now, gentlemen, I have one or two little interviews this evening, and it is a long drive to Hampstead.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2018,"['"" He stepped forward, took up his coat, laid his hand on his revolver, and turned to the door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2019,"[' I picked up a chair, but Holmes shook his head and I laid it down again.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2020,"[' With bow, a smile, and a twinkle Milverton was out of the room, and a few moments after we heard the slam of the carriage door and the rattle of the wheels as he drove away.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2021,"[' Holmes sat motionless by the fire, his hands buried deep in his trouser pockets, his chin sunk upon his breast, his eyes fixed upon the glowing embers.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2022,"[' Then, with the gesture of a man who has taken his decision, he sprang to his feet and passed into his bedroom.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2023,[' A little later a rakish young workman with a goatee beard and a swagger lit his clay pipe at the lamp before descending into the street.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2024,"[' ""I\'ll be back some time, Watson,"" said he, and vanished into the night.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2025,"[' For some days Holmes came and went at all hours in this attire, but beyond a remark that his time was spent at Hampstead, and that it was not wasted, I knew nothing of what he was doing.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2026,"[' At last, however, on a wild, tempestuous evening, when the wind screamed and rattled against the windows, he returned from his last expedition, and having removed his disguise he sat before the fire and laughed heartily in his silent inward fashion.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2027,"[' ""You would not call me a marrying man, Watson?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2028,"['"" ""No, indeed!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2029,"['"" ""You\'ll be interested to hear that I am engaged.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2030,"['"" ""My dear fellow!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2031,"[' I congrat--"" ""To Milverton\'s housemaid.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2032,"['"" ""Good heavens, Holmes!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2033,"['"" ""I wanted information, Watson.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2034,"['"" ""Surely you have gone too far?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2035,"['"" ""It was a most necessary step.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2036,"["" I know Milverton's house as I know the palm of my hand.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2037,"['"" ""But the girl, Holmes?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2038,"['"" He shrugged his shoulders.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2039,"["" Watson, I mean to burgle Milverton's house to-night.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2040,"['"" I had a catching of the breath, and my skin went cold at the words, which were slowly uttered in a tone of concentrated resolution.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2041,"[' As a flash of lightning in the night shows up in an instant every detail of a wide landscape, so at one glance I seemed to see every possible result of such an action-the detection, the capture, the honoured career ending in irreparable failure and disgrace, my friend himself lying at the mercy of the odious Milverton.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2042,"[' ""For Heaven\'s sake, Holmes, think what you are doing,"" I cried.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2043,[' To burgle his house is no more than to forcibly take his pocket-book-an action in which you were prepared to aid me.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2044,"['"" I turned it over in my mind.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2045,"[' ""Yes,"" I said; ""it is morally justifiable so long as our object is to take no articles save those which are used for an illegal purpose.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2046,"['"" ""Exactly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2047,[' Surely a gentleman should not lay much stress upon this when a lady is in most desperate need of his help?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2048,"['"" ""You will be in such a false position.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2049,"['"" ""Well, that is part of the risk.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2050,"[' To-morrow is the last day of grace, and unless we can get the letters to-night this villain will be as good as his word and will bring about her ruin.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2051,"[' He had, as you saw, the best of the first exchanges; but my self-respect and my reputation are concerned to fight it to a finish.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2052,"['"" ""Well, I don\'t like it; but I suppose it must be,"" said I.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2053,"[' ""When do we start?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2054,"['"" ""You are not coming.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2055,"['"" ""Then you are not going,"" said I.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2056,"[' ""I give you my word of honour-and I never broke it in my life-that I will take a cab straight to the police-station and give you away unless you let me share this adventure with you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2057,"['"" ""You can\'t help me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2058,"['"" ""How do you know that?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2059,[' Other people beside you have self-respect and even reputations.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2060,"['"" Holmes had looked annoyed, but his brow cleared, and he clapped me on the shoulder.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2061,"["" You know, Watson, I don't mind confessing to you that I have always had an idea that I would have made a highly efficient criminal.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2062,[' See here!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2063,"['"" He took a neat little leather case out of a drawer, and opening it he exhibited a number of shining instruments.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2064,"["" With any luck we should be back here by two, with the Lady Eva's letters in my pocket.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2065,"['"" Holmes and I put on our dress-clothes, so that we might appear to be two theatre-goers homeward bound.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2066,"[' ""It\'s a business that needs delicate treatment,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2067,"[' On the other hand, like all these stout, little men who do themselves well, he is a plethoric sleeper.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2068,"[' You see, there is not a glimmer of light in any of the windows, and everything is working splendidly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2069,"['"" With our black silk face-coverings, which turned us into two of the most truculent figures in London, we stole up to the silent, gloomy house.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2070,"["" There's a greenhouse which opens into the drawing-room.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2071,"['"" The place was locked, but Holmes removed a circle of glass and turned the key from the inside.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2072,"[' An instant afterwards he had closed the door behind us, and we had become felons in the eyes of the law.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2073,[' He seized my hand in the darkness and led me swiftly past banks of shrubs which brushed against our faces.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2074,"[' Holmes had remarkable powers, carefully cultivated, of seeing in the dark.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2075,"[' Still holding my hand in one of his he opened a door, and I was vaguely conscious that we had entered a large room in which a cigar had been smoked not long before.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2076,"[' He felt his way among the furniture, opened another door, and closed it behind us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2077,"[' We passed along it, and Holmes very gently opened a door upon the right-hand side.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2078,"[' Holmes entered on tiptoe, waited for me to follow, and then very gently closed the door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2079,"[' Near the door I saw the gleam of an electric switch, but it was unnecessary, even if it had been safe, to turn it on.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2080,[' Holmes stole across and looked at it.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2081,"[' I touched Holmes on the arm, and he turned his masked face in that direction.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2082,"[' Anyhow, we have no time to lose.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2083,"['"" ""Can I do anything?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2084,"['"" ""Yes; stand by the door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2085,"[' If you hear anyone come, bolt it on the inside, and we can get away as we came.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2086,"[' If they come the other way, we can get through the door if our job is done, or hide behind these window curtains if it is not.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2087,"[' With a glow of admiration I watched Holmes unrolling his case of instruments and choosing his tool with the calm, scientific accuracy of a surgeon who performs a delicate operation.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2088,"[' I knew that the opening of safes was a particular hobby with him, and I understood the joy which it gave him to be confronted with this green and gold monster, the dragon which held in its maw the reputations of many fair ladies.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2089,"[' I stood at the centre door with my eyes glancing at each of the others, ready for any emergency; though, indeed, my plans were somewhat vague as to what I should do if we were interrupted.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2090,"[' For half an hour Holmes worked with concentrated energy, laying down one tool, picking up another, handling each with the strength and delicacy of the trained mechanic.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2091,"[' Finally I heard a click, the broad green door swung open, and inside I had a glimpse of a number of paper packets, each tied, sealed, and inscribed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2092,"[' Holmes picked one out, but it was hard to read by the flickering fire, and he drew out his little dark lantern, for it was too dangerous, with Milverton in the next room, to switch on the electric light.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2093,"[' Suddenly I saw him halt, listen intently, and then in an instant he had swung the door of the safe to, picked up his coat, stuffed his tools into the pockets, and darted behind the window curtain, motioning me to do the same.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2094,"["" From the pressure of Holmes's shoulder against mine I knew that he was sharing my observations.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2095,"[' It was evident that we had entirely miscalculated his movements, that he had never been to his bedroom, but that he had been sitting up in some smoking or billiard room in the farther wing of the house, the windows of which we had not seen.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2096,"[' He was leaning far back in the red leather chair, his legs outstretched, a long black cigar projecting at an angle from his mouth.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2097,"[' In his hand he held a long legal document, which he was reading in an indolent fashion, blowing rings of tobacco smoke from his lips as he did so.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2098,"["" I felt Holmes's hand steal into mine and give me a reassuring shake, as if to say that the situation was within his powers and that he was easy in his mind.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2099,"[' I was not sure whether he had seen what was only too obvious from my position, that the door of the safe was imperfectly closed, and that Milverton might at any moment observe it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2100,"[' In my own mind I had determined that if I were sure, from the rigidity of his gaze, that it had caught his eye, I would at once spring out, throw my great-coat over his head, pinion him, and leave the rest to Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2101,"[' He was languidly interested by the papers in his hand, and page after page was turned as he followed the argument of the lawyer.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2102,"[' At least, I thought, when he has finished the document and the cigar he will go to his room; but before he had reached the end of either there came a remarkable development which turned our thoughts into quite another channel.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2103,"[' Several times I had observed that Milverton looked at his watch, and once he had risen and sat down again, with a gesture of impatience.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2104,"[' ""Well,"" said he, curtly, ""you are nearly half an hour late.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2105,"['"" So this was the explanation of the unlocked door and of the nocturnal vigil of Milverton.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2106,"["" I had closed the slit between the curtains as Milverton's face had turned in our direction, but now I ventured very carefully to open it once more.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2107,"[' In front of him, in the full glare of the electric light, there stood a tall, slim, dark woman, a veil over her face, a mantle drawn round her chin.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2108,"[' ""Well,"" said Milverton, ""you\'ve made me lose a good night\'s rest, my dear.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2109,"[' It was a dark, handsome, clear-cut face which confronted Milverton, a face with a curved nose, strong, dark eyebrows shading hard, glittering eyes, and a straight, thin-lipped mouth set in a dangerous smile.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2110,"[' ""It is I,"" she said; ""the woman whose life you have ruined.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2111,"['"" Milverton laughed, but fear vibrated in his voice.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2112,[' You would not pay.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2113,"['"" ""So you sent the letters to my husband, and he-the noblest gentleman that ever lived, a man whose boots I was never worthy to lace-he broke his gallant heart and died.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2114,"[' You remember that last night when I came through that door I begged and prayed you for mercy, and you laughed in my face as you are trying to laugh now, only your coward heart cannot keep your lips from twitching?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2115,"[' Well, Charles Milverton, what have you to say?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2116,"['"" ""Don\'t imagine that you can bully me,"" said he, rising to his feet.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2117,"[' Leave the room at once as you came, and I will say no more.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2118,"['"" The woman stood with her hand buried in her bosom, and the same deadly smile on her thin lips.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2119,[' The woman looked at him intently and ground her heel into his upturned face.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2120,"[' I heard a sharp rustle, the night air blew into the heated room, and the avenger was gone.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2121,"["" No interference upon our part could have saved the man from his fate; but as the woman poured bullet after bullet into Milverton's shrinking body I was about to spring out, when I felt Holmes's cold, strong grasp upon my wrist.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2122,"[' But hardly had the woman rushed from the room when Holmes, with swift, silent steps, was over at the other door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2123,[' At the same instant we heard voices in the house and the sound of hurrying feet.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2124,"[' With perfect coolness Holmes slipped across to the safe, filled his two arms with bundles of letters, and poured them all into the fire.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2125,[' Holmes looked swiftly round.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2126,"[' The letter which had been the messenger of death for Milverton lay, all mottled with his blood, upon the table.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2127,[' Holmes tossed it in among the blazing papers.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2128,"[' ""This way, Watson,"" said he; ""we can scale the garden wall in this direction.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2129,"['"" I could not have believed that an alarm could have spread so swiftly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2130,"[' Looking back, the huge house was one blaze of light.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2131,"[' The whole garden was alive with people, and one fellow raised a view-halloa as we emerged from the veranda and followed hard at our heels.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2132,"[' Holmes seemed to know the ground perfectly, and he threaded his way swiftly among a plantation of small trees, I close at his heels, and our foremost pursuer panting behind us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2133,[' As I did the same I felt the hand of the man behind me grab at my ankle; but I kicked myself free and scrambled over a glass-strewn coping.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2134,"[' I fell upon my face among some bushes; but Holmes had me on my feet in an instant, and together we dashed away across the huge expanse of Hampstead Heath.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2135,"[' We had run two miles, I suppose, before Holmes at last halted and listened intently.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2136,[' We had breakfasted and were smoking our morning pipe on the day after the remarkable experience which I have recorded when Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2137,"[' Lestrade, of Scotland Yard, very solemn and impressive, was ushered into our modest sitting-room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2138,"[' ""Good morning, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2139,"[' Holmes,"" said he; ""good morning.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2140,[' May I ask if you are very busy just now?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2141,"['"" ""Not too busy to listen to you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2142,"['"" ""I thought that, perhaps, if you had nothing particular on hand, you might care to assist us in a most remarkable case which occurred only last night at Hampstead.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2143,"['"" ""Dear me!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2144,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2145,"[' No article of value was taken, as it is probable that the criminals were men of good position, whose sole object was to prevent social exposure.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2146,"['"" ""Criminals!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2147,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2148,"[' The first fellow was a bit too active, but the second was caught by the under-gardener and only got away after a struggle.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2149,"[' He was a middle-sized, strongly-built man-square jaw, thick neck, moustache, a mask over his eyes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2150,"['"" ""That\'s rather vague,"" said Sherlock Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2151,"[' ""Why, it might be a description of Watson!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2152,"['"" ""It\'s true,"" said the inspector, with much amusement.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2153,"[' ""It might be a description of Watson.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2154,"['"" ""Well, I am afraid I can\'t help you, Lestrade,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2155,"[' ""The fact is that I knew this fellow Milverton, that I considered him one of the most dangerous men in London, and that I think there are certain crimes which the law cannot touch, and which therefore, to some extent, justify private revenge.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2156,"[' My sympathies are with the criminals rather than with the victim, and I will not handle this case.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2157,"['"" Holmes had not said one word to me about the tragedy which we had witnessed, but I observed all the morning that he was in his most thoughtful mood, and he gave me the impression, from his vacant eyes and his abstracted manner, of a man who is striving to recall something to his memory.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2158,[' Here on the left hand there stands a shop window filled with photographs of the celebrities and beauties of the day.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2159,"["" Holmes's eyes fixed themselves upon one of them, and following his gaze I saw the picture of a regal and stately lady in Court dress, with a high diamond tiara upon her noble head.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2160,"[' I looked at that delicately-curved nose, at the marked eyebrows, at the straight mouth, and the strong little chin beneath it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2161,[' Then I caught my breath as I read the time-honoured title of the great nobleman and statesman whose wife she had been.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2162,"[' My eyes met those of Holmes, and he put his finger to his lips as we turned away from the window.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2163,[' IT was no very unusual thing for Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2164,"[' Lestrade, of Scotland Yard, to look in upon us of an evening, and his visits were welcome to Sherlock Holmes, for they enabled him to keep in touch with all that was going on at the police head- quarters.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2165,"[' In return for the news which Lestrade would bring, Holmes was always ready to listen with attention to the details of any case upon which the detective was engaged, and was able occasionally, without any active interference, to give some hint or suggestion drawn from his own vast knowledge and experience.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2166,[' Holmes looked keenly at him.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2167,"[' ""Oh, no, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2168,"[' Holmes, nothing very particular.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2169,"['"" ""Then tell me about it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2170,"['"" Lestrade laughed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2171,"[' ""Well, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2172,"[' Holmes, there is no use denying that there IS something on my mind.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2173,[' But in my opinion it comes more in Dr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2174,"["" Watson's line than ours.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2175,"['"" ""Disease?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2176,"['"" said I.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2177,"["" You wouldn't think there was anyone living at this time of day who had such a hatred of Napoleon the First that he would break any image of him that he could see.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2178,"['"" Holmes sank back in his chair.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2179,"[' But then, when the man commits burglary in order to break images which are not his own, that brings it away from the doctor and on to the policeman.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2180,"['"" Holmes sat up again.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2181,[' Let me hear the details.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2182,"['"" Lestrade took out his official note-book and refreshed his memory from its pages.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2183,"[' ""The first case reported was four days ago,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2184,"[' The assistant had left the front shop for an instant when he heard a crash, and hurrying in he found a plaster bust of Napoleon, which stood with several other works of art upon the counter, lying shivered into fragments.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2185,"[' He rushed out into the road, but, although several passers-by declared that they had noticed a man run out of the shop, he could neither see anyone nor could he find any means of identifying the rascal.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2186,"[' ""In Kennington Road, and within a few hundred yards of Morse Hudson\'s shop, there lives a well-known medical practitioner, named Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2187,"[' Barnicot, who has one of the largest practices upon the south side of the Thames.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2188,"[' Some little time ago he purchased from Morse Hudson two duplicate plaster casts of the famous head of Napoleon by the French sculptor, Devine.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2189,"[' One of these he placed in his hall in the house at Kennington Road, and the other on the mantelpiece of the surgery at Lower Brixton.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2190,"[' Well, when Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2191,"[' Barnicot came down this morning he was astonished to find that his house had been burgled during the night, but that nothing had been taken save the plaster head from the hall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2192,"[' It had been carried out and had been dashed savagely against the garden wall, under which its splintered fragments were discovered.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2193,"['"" Holmes rubbed his hands.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2194,[' Dr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2195,"["" Barnicot was due at his surgery at twelve o'clock, and you can imagine his amazement when, on arriving there, he found that the window had been opened in the night, and that the broken pieces of his second bust were strewn all over the room.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2196,"[' Now, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2197,"[' Holmes, you have got the facts.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2198,"['"" ""They are singular, not to say grotesque,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2199,"[' ""May I ask whether the two busts smashed in Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2200,"["" Barnicot's rooms were the exact duplicates of the one which was destroyed in Morse Hudson's shop?""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2201,"['"" ""They were taken from the same mould.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2202,"['"" ""Such a fact must tell against the theory that the man who breaks them is influenced by any general hatred of Napoleon.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2203,"[' Considering how many hundreds of statues of the great Emperor must exist in London, it is too much to suppose such a coincidence as that a promiscuous iconoclast should chance to begin upon three specimens of the same bust.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2204,"['"" ""Well, I thought as you do,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2205,"[' ""On the other hand, this Morse Hudson is the purveyor of busts in that part of London, and these three were the only ones which had been in his shop for years.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2206,"[' What do you think, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2207,[' Watson?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2208,"['"" ""There are no limits to the possibilities of monomania,"" I answered.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2209,"["" A man who had read deeply about Napoleon, or who had possibly received some hereditary family injury through the great war, might conceivably form such an 'idee fixe' and under its influence be capable of any fantastic outrage.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2210,"['"" ""That won\'t do, my dear Watson,"" said Holmes, shaking his head; ""for no amount of \'idee fixe\' would enable your interesting monomaniac to find out where these busts were situated.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2211,"['"" ""Well, how do YOU explain it?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2212,"['"" ""I don\'t attempt to do so.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2213,"[' For example, in Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2214,"["" Barnicot's hall, where a sound might arouse the family, the bust was taken outside before being broken, whereas in the surgery, where there was less danger of an alarm, it was smashed where it stood.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2215,"[' You will remember, Watson, how the dreadful business of the Abernetty family was first brought to my notice by the depth which the parsley had sunk into the butter upon a hot day.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2216,"["" I can't afford, therefore, to smile at your three broken busts, Lestrade, and I shall be very much obliged to you if you will let me hear of any fresh developments of so singular a chain of events.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2217,"['"" The development for which my friend had asked came in a quicker and an infinitely more tragic form than he could have imagined.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2218,"[' I was still dressing in my bedroom next morning when there was a tap at the door and Holmes entered, a telegram in his hand.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2219,"[' He read it aloud:- ""Come instantly, 131, Pitt Street, Kensington.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2220,['-Lestrade.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2221,"['"" ""What is it, then?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2222,"['"" I asked.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2223,"["" There's coffee on the table, Watson, and I have a cab at the door.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2224,"['"" In half an hour we had reached Pitt Street, a quiet little backwater just beside one of the briskest currents of London life.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2225,"["" Well, well, there's Lestrade at the front window, and we shall soon know all about it.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2226,"['"" The official received us with a very grave face and showed us into a sitting- room, where an exceedingly unkempt and agitated elderly man, clad in a flannel dressing-gown, was pacing up and down.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2227,"[' ""It\'s the Napoleon bust business again,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2228,"[' ""You seemed interested last night, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2229,"[' Holmes, so I thought perhaps you would be glad to be present now that the affair has taken a very much graver turn.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2230,"['"" ""What has it turned to, then?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2231,"['"" ""To murder.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2232,[' Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2233,"[' Harker, will you tell these gentlemen exactly what has occurred?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2234,"['"" The man in the dressing-gown turned upon us with a most melancholy face.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2235,"[' ""It\'s an extraordinary thing,"" said he, ""that all my life I have been collecting other people\'s news, and now that a real piece of news has come my own way I am so confused and bothered that I can\'t put two words together.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2236,"[' As it is I am giving away valuable copy by telling my story over and over to a string of different people, and I can make no use of it myself.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2237,"["" However, I've heard your name, Mr.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2238,"["" Sherlock Holmes, and if you'll only explain this queer business I shall be paid for my trouble in telling you the story.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2239,"['"" Holmes sat down and listened.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2240,"[' ""It all seems to centre round that bust of Napoleon which I bought for this very room about four months ago.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2241,"[' I picked it up cheap from Harding Brothers, two doors from the High Street Station.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2242,"[' A great deal of my journalistic work is done at night, and I often write until the early morning.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2243,"[' Then suddenly, about five minutes later, there came a most horrible yell-the most dreadful sound, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2244,"[' Holmes, that ever I heard.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2245,"[' When I entered this room I found the window wide open, and I at once observed that the bust was gone from the mantelpiece.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2246,"[' ""You can see for yourself that anyone going out through that open window could reach the front doorstep by taking a long stride.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2247,"[' This was clearly what the burglar had done, so I went round and opened the door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2248,[' Stepping out into the dark I nearly fell over a dead man who was lying there.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2249,"[' I ran back for a light, and there was the poor fellow, a great gash in his throat and the whole place swimming in blood.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2250,"[' I had just time to blow on my police-whistle, and then I must have fainted, for I knew nothing more until I found the policeman standing over me in the hall.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2251,"['"" ""Well, who was the murdered man?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2252,"['"" asked Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2253,"[' ""There\'s nothing to show who he was,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2254,"[' ""There\'s nothing to show who he was,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2255,"[' Whether it was the weapon which did the deed, or whether it belonged to the dead man, I do not know.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2256,"[' It represented an alert, sharp-featured simian man with thick eyebrows, and a very peculiar projection of the lower part of the face like the muzzle of a baboon.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2257,"[' ""And what became of the bust?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2258,"['"" asked Holmes, after a careful study of this picture.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2259,[' I must just take one look round.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2260,"['"" He examined the carpet and the window.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2261,"[' ""The fellow had either very long legs or was a most active man,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2262,"[' Are you coming with us to see the remains of your bust, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2263,[' Harker?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2264,"['"" The disconsolate journalist had seated himself at a writing-table.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2265,"[' ""I must try and make something of it,"" said he, ""though I have no doubt that the first editions of the evening papers are out already with full details.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2266,"["" And now I'll be too late with a murder done on my own doorstep.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2267,"['"" As we left the room we heard his pen travelling shrilly over the foolscap.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2268,"[' For the first time our eyes rested upon this presentment of the great Emperor, which seemed to raise such frantic and destructive hatred in the mind of the unknown.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2269,[' Holmes picked up several of them and examined them carefully.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2270,"[' ""We have a long way to go yet,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2271,[' But I wish to call your attention very particularly to the position of this house in the garden of which the bust was destroyed.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2272,"['"" Lestrade looked about him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2273,"[' ""It was an empty house, and so he knew that he would not be disturbed in the garden.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2274,"['"" ""Yes, but there is another empty house farther up the street which he must have passed before he came to this one.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2275,"[' Why did he not break it there, since it is evident that every yard that he carried it increased the risk of someone meeting him?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2276,"['"" ""I give it up,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2277,[' Holmes pointed to the street lamp above our heads.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2278,"[' ""Now that I come to think of it, Dr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2279,"["" Barnicot's bust was broken not far from his red lamp.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2280,"[' Well, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2281,"[' Holmes, what are we to do with that fact?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2282,"['"" ""To remember it-to docket it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2283,"[' What steps do you propose to take now, Lestrade?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2284,"['"" ""The most practical way of getting at it, in my opinion, is to identify the dead man.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2285,"[' When we have found who he is and who his associates are, we should have a good start in learning what he was doing in Pitt Street last night, and who it was who met him and killed him on the doorstep of Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2286,[' Horace Harker.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2287,"["" Don't you think so?""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2288,"['"" ""No doubt; and yet it is not quite the way in which I should approach the case.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2289,"['"" ""What would you do, then?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2290,"['"" ""Oh, you must not let me influence you in any way!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2291,"[' We can compare notes afterwards, and each will supplement the other.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2292,"['"" ""Very good,"" said Lestrade.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2293,"[' Tell him from me that I have quite made up my mind, and that it is certain that a dangerous homicidal lunatic with Napoleonic delusions was in his house last night.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2294,"[' ""You don\'t seriously believe that?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2295,"['"" Holmes smiled.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2296,"["" Now, Watson, I think that we shall find that we have a long and rather complex day's work before us.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2297,"["" Until then I should like to keep this photograph found in the dead man's pocket.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2298,"[' It is possible that I may have to ask your company and assistance upon a small expedition which will have be undertaken to-night, if my chain of reasoning should prove to be correct.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2299,"[' Until then, good-bye and good luck!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2300,"['"" Sherlock Holmes and I walked together to the High Street, where he stopped at the shop of Harding Brothers, whence the bust had been purchased.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2301,"["" Holmes's face showed his disappointment and annoyance.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2302,"[' ""Well, well, we can\'t expect to have it all our own way, Watson,"" he said, at last.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2303,"[' I am, as you have no doubt surmised, endeavouring to trace these busts to their source, in order to find if there is not something peculiar which may account for their remarkable fate.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2304,[' Let us make for Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2305,"[' Morse Hudson, of the Kennington Road, and see if he can throw any light upon the problem.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2306,"['"" A drive of an hour brought us to the picture-dealer\'s establishment.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2307,"[' He was a small, stout man with a red face and a peppery manner.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2308,"[' On my very counter, sir,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2309,"[' ""What we pay rates and taxes for I don\'t know, when any ruffian can come in and break one\'s goods.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2310,"[' Well, if you really want to know, I got them from Gelder and Co.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2311,"[', in Church Street, Stepney.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2312,"[' He was a kind of Italian piece-work man, who made himself useful in the shop.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2313,[' He was gone two days before the bust was smashed.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2314,"['"" ""Well, that\'s all we could reasonably expect to get from Morse Hudson,"" said Holmes, as we emerged from the shop.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2315,"["" I shall be surprised if we don't get some help down there.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2316,"['"" In rapid succession we passed through the fringe of fashionable London, hotel London, theatrical London, literary London, commercial London, and, finally, maritime London, till we came to a riverside city of a hundred thousand souls, where the tenement houses swelter and reek with the outcasts of Europe.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2317,"["" The manager, a big blond German, received us civilly, and gave a clear answer to all Holmes's questions.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2318,"["" A reference to his books showed that hundreds of casts had been taken from a marble copy of Devine's head of Napoleon, but that the three which had been sent to Morse Hudson a year or so before had been half of a batch of six, the other three being sent to Harding Brothers, of Kensington.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2319,"[' He knifed another Italian in the street, and then he came to the works with the police on his heels, and he was taken here.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2320,[' Serve me right for engaging a man with such a face.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2321,"[' But he was a good workman, one of the best.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2322,"['"" ""What did he get?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2323,"['"" ""The man lived and he got off with a year.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2324,"[' We have a cousin of his here, and I dare say he could tell you where he is.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2325,"['"" ""No, no,"" cried Holmes, ""not a word to the cousin-not a word, I beg you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2326,"[' ""Yes,"" he continued, after some turning over of pages, ""he was paid last on May 20th.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2327,"['"" ""Thank you,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2328,"[' ""I don\'t think that I need intrude upon your time and patience any more.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2329,"['"" With a last word of caution that he should say nothing as to our researches we turned our faces westward once more.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2330,"[' Murder by a Madman,"" and the contents of the paper showed that Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2331,[' Horace Harker had got his account into print after all.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2332,[' Holmes propped it against the cruet-stand and read it while he ate.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2333,"[' ""This is all right, Watson,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2334,"[' ""Listen to this: \'It is satisfactory to know that there can be no difference of opinion upon this case, since Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2335,"[' Lestrade, one of the most experienced members of the official force, and Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2336,"[' Sherlock Holmes, the well-known consulting expert, have each come to the conclusion that the grotesque series of incidents, which have ended in so tragic a fashion, arise from lunacy rather than from deliberate crime.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2337,[' No explanation save mental aberration can cover the facts.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2338,"[""' The Press, Watson, is a most valuable institution if you only know how to use it.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2339,"[' And now, if you have quite finished, we will hark back to Kensington and see what the manager of Harding Brothers has to say to the matter.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2340,"['"" The founder of that great emporium proved to be a brisk, crisp little person, very dapper and quick, with a clear head and a ready tongue.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2341,"[' ""Yes, sir, I have already read the account in the evening papers.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2342,"["" Well, well, it's a very strange business, and I hope that you'll let me know if anything comes of your inquiries.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2343,"['"" Holmes had taken several notes during Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2344,"["" Harding's evidence, and I could see that he was thoroughly satisfied by the turn which affairs were taking.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2345,"["" His look of importance showed that his day's work had not been in vain.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2346,"[' ""What luck, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2347,[' Holmes?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2348,"['"" ""We have had a very busy day, and not entirely a wasted one,"" my friend explained.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2349,"[' ""Well, well, you have your own methods, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2350,"["" Sherlock Holmes, and it is not for me to say a word against them, but I think I have done a better day's work than you.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2351,[' I have identified the dead man.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2352,"['"" ""You don\'t say so?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2353,"['"" ""And found a cause for the crime.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2354,"['"" ""Splendid!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2355,"['"" ""We have an inspector who makes a specialty of Saffron Hill and the Italian quarter.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2356,"[' Well, this dead man had some Catholic emblem round his neck, and that, along with his colour, made me think he was from the South.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2357,"[' Probably the photograph we found in his pocket is the man himself, so that he may not knife the wrong person.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2358,"[' He dogs the fellow, he sees him enter a house, he waits outside for him, and in the scuffle he receives his own death-wound.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2359,"[' It is the murder that we are really investigating, and I tell you that I am gathering all the threads into my hands.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2360,"['"" ""And the next stage?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2361,"['"" ""Is a very simple one.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2362,"[' I shall go down with Hill to the Italian quarter, find the man whose photograph we have got, and arrest him on the charge of murder.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2363,"[' But I have great hopes-in fact, the betting is exactly two to one-that if you will come with us to-night I shall be able to help you to lay him by the heels.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2364,"['"" ""In the Italian quarter?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2365,"['"" ""No; I fancy Chiswick is an address which is more likely to find him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2366,"["" If you will come with me to Chiswick to-night, Lestrade, I'll promise to go to the Italian quarter with you to-morrow, and no harm will be done by the delay.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2367,"["" And now I think that a few hours' sleep would do us all good, for I do not propose to leave before eleven o'clock, and it is unlikely that we shall be back before morning.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2368,"[' In the meantime, Watson, I should be glad if you would ring for an express messenger, for I have a letter to send, and it is important that it should go at once.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2369,"['"" Holmes spent the evening in rummaging among the files of the old daily papers with which one of our lumber-rooms was packed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2370,"[' When at last he descended it was with triumph in his eyes, but he said nothing to either of us as to the result of his researches.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2371,"[' For my own part, I had followed step by step the methods by which he had traced the various windings of this complex case, and, though I could not yet perceive the goal which we would reach, I understood clearly that Holmes expected this grotesque criminal to make an attempt upon the two remaining busts, one of which, I remembered, was at Chiswick.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2372,"[' No doubt the object of our journey was to catch him in the very act, and I could not but admire the cunning with which my friend had inserted a wrong clue in the evening paper, so as to give the fellow the idea that he could continue his scheme with impunity.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2373,[' I was not surprised when Holmes suggested that I should take my revolver with me.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2374,"[' A short walk brought us to a secluded road fringed with pleasant houses, each standing in its own grounds.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2375,"[' The occupants had evidently retired to rest, for all was dark save for a fanlight over the hall door, which shed a single blurred circle on to the garden path.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2376,"[' ""I fear that you\'ll have a long wait,"" Holmes whispered.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2377,"["" However, it's a two to one chance that we get something to pay us for our trouble.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2378,"['"" It proved, however, that our vigil was not to be so long as Holmes had led us to fear, and it ended in a very sudden and singular fashion.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2379,"[' In an instant, without the least sound to warn us of his coming, the garden gate swung open, and a lithe, dark figure, as swift and active as an ape, rushed up the garden path.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2380,[' We saw it whisk past the light thrown from over the door and disappear against the black shadow of the house.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2381,[' We saw the sudden flash of a dark lantern inside the room.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2382,[' As he came out into the glimmering patch of light we saw that he carried something white under his arm.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2383,[' The man was so intent upon what he was doing that he never heard our steps as we stole across the grass plot.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2384,"[' With the bound of a tiger Holmes was on his back, and an instant later Lestrade and I had him by either wrist and the handcuffs had been fastened.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2385,"[' As we turned him over I saw a hideous, sallow face, with writhing, furious features, glaring up at us, and I knew that it was indeed the man of the photograph whom we had secured.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2386,"[' Squatted on the doorstep, he was engaged in most carefully examining that which the man had brought from the house.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2387,"[' It was a bust of Napoleon like the one which we had seen that morning, and it had been broken into similar fragments.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2388,"[' Carefully Holmes held each separate shard to the light, but in no way did it differ from any other shattered piece of plaster.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2389,"[' He had just completed his examination when the hall lights flew up, the door opened, and the owner of the house, a jovial, rotund figure in shirt and trousers, presented himself.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2390,"[' ""Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2391,"[' Josiah Brown, I suppose?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2392,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2393,"[' ""Yes, sir; and you, no doubt, are Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2394,[' Sherlock Holmes?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2395,"[' I hope, gentlemen, that you will come in and have some refreshment.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2396,"['"" However, Lestrade was anxious to get his man into safe quarters, so within a few minutes our cab had been summoned and we were all four upon our way to London.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2397,"[' Not a word would our captive say; but he glared at us from the shadow of his matted hair, and once, when my hand seemed within his reach, he snapped at it like a hungry wolf.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2398,"[' We stayed long enough at the police-station to learn that a search of his clothing revealed nothing save a few shillings and a long sheath knife, the handle of which bore copious traces of recent blood.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2399,"[' ""That\'s all right,"" said Lestrade, as we parted.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2400,"["" But I'm sure I am exceedingly obliged to you, Mr.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2401,"[' Holmes, for the workmanlike way in which you laid hands upon him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2402,"["" I don't quite understand it all yet.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2403,"['"" ""I fear it is rather too late an hour for explanations,"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2404,"["" If you will come round once more to my rooms at six o'clock to-morrow I think I shall be able to show you that even now you have not grasped the entire meaning of this business, which presents some features which make it absolutely original in the history of crime.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2405,"[' If ever I permit you to chronicle any more of my little problems, Watson, I foresee that you will enliven your pages by an account of the singular adventure of the Napoleonic busts.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2406,"['"" When we met again next evening Lestrade was furnished with much information concerning our prisoner.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2407,"[' He had once been a skilful sculptor and had earned an honest living, but he had taken to evil courses and had twice already been in gaol-once for a petty theft and once, as we had already heard, for stabbing a fellow-countryman.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2408,"[' His reasons for destroying the busts were still unknown, and he refused to answer any questions upon the subject; but the police had discovered that these same busts might very well have been made by his own hands, since he was engaged in this class of work at the establishment of Gelder and Co.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2409,"[' To all this information, much of which we already knew, Holmes listened with polite attention; but I, who knew him so well, could clearly see that his thoughts were elsewhere, and I detected a mixture of mingled uneasiness and expectation beneath that mask which he was wont to assume.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2410,"[' A minute later we heard steps upon the stairs, and an elderly, red-faced man with grizzled side- whiskers was ushered in.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2411,"[' In his right hand he carried an old-fashioned carpet-bag, which he placed upon the table.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2412,"[' ""Is Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2413,[' Sherlock Holmes here?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2414,"['"" My friend bowed and smiled.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2415,"[' ""Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2416,"[' Sandeford, of Reading, I suppose?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2417,"['"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
