2418,"[' ""Yes, sir, I fear that I am a little late; but the trains were awkward.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2419,"["" You said, 'I desire to possess a copy of Devine's Napoleon, and am prepared to pay you ten pounds for the one which is in your possession.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2420,"[""' Is that right?""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2421,"['"" ""Certainly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2422,"['"" ""I was very much surprised at your letter, for I could not imagine how you knew that I owned such a thing.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2423,"['"" ""Of course you must have been surprised, but the explanation is very simple.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2424,[' Mr.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2425,"[' Harding, of Harding Brothers, said that they had sold you their last copy, and he gave me your address.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2426,"['"" ""Oh, that was it, was it?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2427,"[' I only gave fifteen shillings for the bust, and I think you ought to know that before I take ten pounds from you.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2428,"['"" ""I am sure the scruple does you honour, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2429,[' Sandeford.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2430,[' Here it is!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2431,"['"" He opened his bag, and at last we saw placed upon our table a complete specimen of that bust which we had already seen more than once in fragments.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2432,[' Holmes took a paper from his pocket and laid a ten-pound note upon the table.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2433,"[' I am a methodical man, you see, and you never know what turn events might take afterwards.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2434,"[' Thank you, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2435,"[' Sandeford; here is your money, and I wish you a very good evening.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2436,"['"" When our visitor had disappeared Sherlock Holmes\'s movements were such as to rivet our attention.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2437,"[' The figure broke into fragments, and Holmes bent eagerly over the shattered remains.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2438,"[' Next instant, with a loud shout of triumph, he held up one splinter, in which a round, dark object was fixed like a plum in a pudding.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2439,"[' ""Gentlemen,"" he cried, ""let me introduce you to the famous black pearl of the Borgias.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2440,"['"" Lestrade and I sat silent for a moment, and then, with a spontaneous impulse, we both broke out clapping as at the well-wrought crisis of a play.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2441,"["" A flush of colour sprang to Holmes's pale cheeks, and he bowed to us like the master dramatist who receives the homage of his audience.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2442,[' The same singularly proud and reserved nature which turned away with disdain from popular notoriety was capable of being moved to its depths by spontaneous wonder and praise from a friend.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2443,"[' ""Yes, gentlemen,"" said he, ""it is the most famous pearl now existing in the world, and it has been my good fortune, by a connected chain of inductive reasoning, to trace it from the Prince of Colonna\'s bedroom at the Dacre Hotel, where it was lost, to the interior of this, the last of the six busts of Napoleon which were manufactured by Gelder and Co.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2444,"[', of Stepney.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2445,"[' You will remember, Lestrade, the sensation caused by the disappearance of this valuable jewel, and the vain efforts of the London police to recover it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2446,"["" The maid's name was Lucretia Venucci, and there is no doubt in my mind that this Pietro who was murdered two nights ago was the brother.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2447,"[' I have been looking up the dates in the old files of the paper, and I find that the disappearance of the pearl was exactly two days before the arrest of Beppo for some crime of violence, an event which took place in the factory of Gelder and Co.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2448,"[', at the very moment when these busts were being made.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2449,"[' There he was dogged by his confederate, who held Beppo responsible for the loss of the pearl, and he stabbed him in the scuffle which followed.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2450,"['"" ""If he was his confederate why should he carry his photograph?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2451,"['"" I asked.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2452,"[' I had not even concluded for certain that it was the pearl; but it was evident to me that he was looking for something, since he carried the bust past the other houses in order to break it in the garden which had a lamp overlooking it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2453,"[' By that time, of course, I knew for certain that it was the Borgia pearl that we were after.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2454,"[' ""Well,"" said Lestrade, ""I\'ve seen you handle a good many cases, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2455,"["" Holmes, but I don't know that I ever knew a more workmanlike one than that.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2456,"["" No, sir, we are very proud of you, and if you come down to-morrow there's not a man, from the oldest inspector to the youngest constable, who wouldn't be glad to shake you by the hand.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2457,"['"" ""Thank you!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2458,"['"" said Holmes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2459,"[' ""Thank you!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2460,"['"" and as he turned away it seemed to me that he was more nearly moved by the softer human emotions than I had ever seen him.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2461,"[' ""Put the pearl in the safe, Watson,"" said he, ""and get out the papers of the Conk- Singleton forgery case.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2462,"[' If any little problem comes your way I shall be happy, if I can, to give you a hint or two as to its solution.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2463,"['"" Ebd E-BooksDirectory.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2464,['com IX.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2465,['-The Adventure of the Three Students.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2466,"["" IT was in the year '95 that a combination of events, into which I need not enter, caused Mr.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2467,"[' Sherlock Holmes and myself to spend some weeks in one of our great University towns, and it was during this time that the small but instructive adventure which I am about to relate befell us.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2468,[' We were residing at the time in furnished lodgings close to a library where Sherlock Holmes was pursuing some laborious researches in early English charters-researches which led to results so striking that they may be the subject of one of my future narratives.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2469,"[' ""I trust, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2470,"[' Holmes, that you can spare me a few hours of your valuable time.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2471,[' We have had a very painful incident at St.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2472,"["" Luke's, and really, but for the happy chance of your being in the town, I should have been at a loss what to do.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2473,"['"" ""I am very busy just now, and I desire no distractions,"" my friend answered.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2474,"[' ""I should much prefer that you called in the aid of the police.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2475,"['"" ""No, no, my dear sir; such a course is utterly impossible.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2476,"[' Your discretion is as well known as your powers, and you are the one man in the world who can help me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2477,"[' I beg you, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2478,"[' Holmes, to do what you can.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2479,"['"" My friend\'s temper had not improved since he had been deprived of the congenial surroundings of Baker Street.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2480,"[' ""I must explain to you, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2481,"[' Holmes, that to-morrow is the first day of the examination for the Fortescue Scholarship.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2482,"["" I had, however, promised to take tea in a friend's rooms, so I left the proof upon my desk.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2483,"[' ""You are aware, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2484,"[' Holmes, that our college doors are double-a green baize one within and a heavy oak one without.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2485,"[' For an instant I imagined that I had left my own there, but on feeling in my pocket I found that it was all right.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2486,"[' The only duplicate which existed, so far as I knew, was that which belonged to my servant, Bannister, a man who has looked after my room for ten years, and whose honesty is absolutely above suspicion.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2487,"[' I found that the key was indeed his, that he had entered my room to know if I wanted tea, and that he had very carelessly left the key in the door when he came out.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2488,"[' ""The moment I looked at my table I was aware that someone had rummaged among my papers.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2489,"[' Now, I found that one of them was lying on the floor, one was on the side table near the window, and the third was where I had left it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2490,"['"" Holmes stirred for the first time.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2491,"[' ""The first page on the floor, the second in the window, the third where you left it,"" said he.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2492,[' How could you possibly know that?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2493,"['"" ""Pray continue your very interesting statement.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2494,"['"" ""For an instant I imagined that Bannister had taken the unpardonable liberty of examining my papers.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2495,"[' The alternative was that someone passing had observed the key in the door, had known that I was out, and had entered to look at the papers.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2496,"[' A large sum of money is at stake, for the scholarship is a very valuable one, and an unscrupulous man might very well run a risk in order to gain an advantage over his fellows.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2497,[' I gave him a little brandy and left him collapsed in a chair while I made a most careful examination of the room.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2498,[' I soon saw that the intruder had left other traces of his presence besides the rumpled papers.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2499,"[' Evidently the rascal had copied the paper in a great hurry, had broken his pencil, and had been compelled to put a fresh point to it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2500,"['"" ""Excellent!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2501,"['"" said Holmes, who was recovering his good-humour as his attention became more engrossed by the case.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2502,"[' Not only this, but on the table I found a small ball of black dough, or clay, with specks of something which looks like sawdust in it.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2503,[' I am convinced that these marks were left by the man who rifled the papers.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2504,"["" I was at my wits' ends, when suddenly the happy thought occurred to me that you were in the town, and I came straight round to put the matter into your hands.""]",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2505,"[' Either I must find the man or else the examination must be postponed until fresh papers are prepared, and since this cannot be done without explanation there will ensue a hideous scandal, which will throw a cloud not only on the college, but on the University.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2506,[' Above all things I desire to settle the matter quietly and discreetly.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2507,"['"" ""I shall be happy to look into it and to give you such advice as I can,"" said Holmes, rising and putting on his overcoat.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2508,[' Had anyone visited you in your room after the papers came to you?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2509,"['"" ""Yes; young Daulat Ras, an Indian student who lives on the same stair, came in to ask me some particulars about the examination.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2510,"['"" ""For which he was entered?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2511,"['"" ""Yes.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2512,"['"" ""And the papers were on your table?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2513,"['"" ""To the best of my belief they were rolled up.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2514,"['"" ""But might be recognised as proofs?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2515,"['"" ""Possibly.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2516,"['"" ""No one else in your room?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2517,"['"" ""No.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2518,"['"" ""Did anyone know that these proofs would be there?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2519,"['"" ""No one save the printer.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2520,"['"" ""Did this man Bannister know?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2521,"['"" ""No, certainly not.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2522,[' I was in such a hurry to come to you.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2523,"['"" ""You left your door open?']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2524,"['"" ""I locked up the papers first.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2525,"['"" ""Then it amounts to this, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2526,"[' Soames, that unless the Indian student recognised the roll as being proofs, the man who tampered with them came upon them accidentally without knowing that they were there.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2527,"['"" ""So it seems to me.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2528,"['"" Holmes gave an enigmatic smile.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2529,"[' ""Well,"" said he, ""let us go round.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2530,"[' Now, Mr.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2531,[' Soames-at your disposal!'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2532,"['"" The sitting-room of our client opened by a long, low, latticed window on to the ancient lichen-tinted court of the old college.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2533,[' Holmes halted and looked earnestly at the window.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2534,"[' Then he approached it, and, standing on tiptoe with his neck craned, he looked into the room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2535,"[' There is no opening except the one pane,"" said our learned guide.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2536,"[' ""Dear me!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2537,"['"" said Holmes, and he smiled in a singular way as he glanced at our companion.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2538,"[' ""Well, if there is nothing to be learned here we had best go inside.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2539,"['"" The lecturer unlocked the outer door and ushered us into his room.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2540,[' We stood at the entrance while Holmes made an examination of the carpet.'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2541,"[' The man entered and took the papers, sheet by sheet, from the central table.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2542,"[' He carried them over to the window table, because from there he could see if you came across the courtyard, and so could effect an escape.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2543,"['"" ""As a matter of fact he could not,"" said Soames, ""for I entered by the side door.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2544,"['"" ""Ah, that\'s good!']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

2545,"[' He was in the midst of that when your return caused him to make a very hurried retreat-VERY hurried, since he had not time to replace the papers which would tell you that he had been there.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2546,[' You were not aware of any hurrying feet on the stair as you entered the outer door?'],Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2547,"['"" ""No, I can\'t say I was.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19
2548,"['"" ""Well, he wrote so furiously that he broke his pencil, and had, as you observe, to sharpen it again.']",Arthur Conan Doyle,The Return of Sherlock Holmes,19

40,"[' Then, just as happens on a terrace in the moonlight, when one person begins to feel ashamed that he is already bored, and yet as the other sits silent, very quiet, sadly looking at the moon, does not like to speak, moves his foot, clears his throat, notices some iron scroll on a table leg, stirs a leaf, but says nothing- so Peter Walsh did 64 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf now.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
41,"[' For why go back like this to the past, he thought.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

42,"[' For she was a child, throwing bread to the ducks, between her parents, and at the same time a grown woman coming to her parents who stood by the lake, holding her life in her arms which, as she neared them, grew larger and larger in her arms, until it became a whole life, a complete life, which she put down by them and said, ""This is what I have made of it!']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

111,"["" All India lay behind him; plains, mountains; epidemics of cholera; a district'6 twice as big as Ireland; decisions he had come to alone - he, Peter Walsh; who was now really for the first time in his life, in love.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

127,"["" Margaret's glides into the recesses of the heart and buries itself in ring after ring of sound, like something alive which wants to confide itself, to disperse itself, to be, with a tremor of delight, at rest -like Clarissa herself, thought Peter Walsh, coming downstairs on the stroke of the hour in white.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

128,"[' It is Clarissa herself, he thought, with a deep emotion, and an extraordinarily clear, yet puzzling, recollection of her, as if this bell had come into the room years ago, where they sat at some moment of great inti- macy, and had gone from one to the other and had left, like a bee with honey, laden with the moment.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

129,"[' It was her heart, he remembered; and the sudden loudness of the final stroke tolled for death that surprised in the midst of life, Clarissa falling where she stood, in her drawing-room.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

130,"["" As for caring what they said of him - the Dalloways, the Whitbreads, and their set, he cared not a straw - not a straw (though it was true he would have, some time or other, to see whether Richard couldn't help him to some job).""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
131,"[' He had 70 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf been a Socialist, in some sense a failure - true.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

132,"[' Still the future of civilisation lies, he thought, in the hands of young men like that; of young men such as he was, thirty years ago; with their love of abstract principles; getting books sent out to them all the way from London to a peak in the Himalayas; reading science; reading phi- losophy.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
133,"[' The future lies in the hands of young men like that, he thought.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

134,"[' A patter like the patter of leaves in a wood came from behind, and with it a rustling, regular thudding sound, which as it overtook him drummed his thoughts, strict in step, up Whitehall, without his doing.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

135,"[' Boys in uniform, carrying guns, marched with their eyes ahead of them, marched, their arms stiff, and on their faces an expression like the letters of a legend written round the base of a statue praising duty, gratitude, fidelity, love of England.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
136,"[' It is, thought Peter Walsh, beginning to keep step with them, a very fine training.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

137,"["" I can't keep up with them, Peter Walsh thought, as they marched up Whitehall, and sure enough, on they marched, past him, past every one, in their steady way, as if one will worked legs and arms uniformly, and life, with its varieti~s, its irreticences, had been laid under a pavement of monuments and wreaths and drugged into a stiff yet staring corpse by discipline.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

138,"[' There they go, thought Peter Walsh, pausing at the edge of the pavement; and all the exalted statues, Nelson, Gordon, Havelock,50 the black, the spectacular images of great soldiers stood looking ahead of them, as if they too had made the same renunciation (Peter Walsh felt he, too, had made it, the great renunciation), trampled under the same temptations, and achieved at length a marble stare.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
139,[' But the stare Peter Walsh did not want for himself in the least; though he could respect it in others.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

140,"["" They don't know the troubles of the flesh yet, he thought, as the marching boys dis- appeared in the direction of the Strand- all that I've been through, he thought, crossing the road, and standing under Gordon's statue, Gordon whom as a boy he had worshipped; Gordon standing lone- Mrs.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
141,"[' Dalloway 71 ly with one leg raised and his arms crossed, - poor Gordon, he thought.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

142,"[' And just because nobody yet knew he was in London, except Clarissa, and the earth, after the voyage, still seemed an island to him, the strangeness of standing alone, alive, unknown, at half-past eleven in Trafalgar Square overcame him.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

143,"[' And down his mind went flat as a marsh, and three great emotions bowled over him; understanding; a vast philanthropy; and finally, as if the result of the others, an irrepressible, exquisite delight; as if inside his brain by another hand strings were pulled, shutters moved, and he, having nothing to do with it, yet stood at the opening of endless avenues, down which if he chose he might wander.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
144,"[' was utterly free - as happens in the downfall of habit when the mind, like an unguarded flame, bows and bends and seems about to blow from its holding.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

145,"[' thought Peter, escaping (only of course for an hour or so) from being precisely what he was, and feeling like a child who runs out of doors, and sees, as he runs, his old nurse waving at the wrong window.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

146,"["" But she's extraordinarily attractive, he thought, as, walking across Trafalgar Square in the direction of the Haymarket, came a young woman who, as she passed Gordon's statue, seemed, Peter Walsh thought (susceptible as he was), to shed veil after veil, until she became the very woman he had always had in mind; young, but stately, merry, but discreet; black, but enchanting.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

147,"[' Straightening himself and stealthily fingering his pocket-knife he started after her to follow this woman, this excitement, which seemed even with its back turned to shed on him a light which connected them, which singled him out, as if the random uproar of the traffic had whispered through hollowed hands his name, not Peter, but his private name which he called himself in his own thoughts.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
148,"[' \'\'You,"" she said, only ""you"", saying it with her white gloves and her shoul- ders.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

149,"["" Then the thin long cloak which the wind stirred as she walked past Dent's shop in Cockspur Street blew out with an enveloping kindness, a mournful tenderness, as of arms that would open and take the tired -- But she's not married; she's young; quite young, thought Peter, the red carnation he had seen her wear as she came across Trafalgar Square burning again in his eyes and making her lips red.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
150,"[' She was not 72 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf worldly, like Clarissa; not rich, like Clarissa.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
151,"[' Still if she stopped he would say ""Come and have an ice,"" he would say, and she would answer, perfectly simply, ""Oh yes.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
152,"['"" But other people got between them in the street, obstructing him, blotting her out.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

153,"[' There was colour in her cheeks; mockery in her eyes; he was an adventurer, reckless, he thought, swift, daring, indeed (landed as he was last night from India) a romantic buccaneer, careless of all these damned proprie- ties, yellow dressing-gowns, pipes, fishing-rods, in the shop win- dows; and respectability and evening parties and spruce old men wearing white slips beneath their waistcoats.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

154,"[' On and on she went, across Piccadilly, and up Regent Street, ahead of him, her cloak, her gloves, her shoulders combining with the fringes and the laces and the feather boas in the windows to make the spirit of finery and whimsy which dwindled out of the shops on to the pavement, as the light of a lamp goes wavering at night over hedges in the darkness.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

155,"[' Laughing and delightful, she had crossed Oxford Street and Great Portland Street and turned down one of the little streets, and now, and now, the great moment was approaching, for now she slack- ened, opened her bag, and with one look in his direction, but not at him, one look that bade farewell, summed up the whole situation and dismissed it triumphantly, for ever, had fitted her key, opened the door, and gone!']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
156,"["" Clarissa's voice saying, Remember my party, Remember my party, sang in his ears.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
157,"["" Well, I've had my fun; I've had it, he thought, looking up at the swinging baskets of pale geraniums.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

158,"[' And it was smashed to atoms - his fun, for it was half made up, as he knew very well; invented, this escapade with the girl; made up, as one makes up the better part of life, he thought - making oneself up; making her up; creating an exquisite amusement, and something more.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
159,"["" He turned; went up the street, thinking to find somewhere to sit, till it was time for Lincoln's Inn- for Messrs.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
160,"[' Like the pulse of a perfect heart, life struck straight through the streets.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

161,"[' Admi- rable butlers, tawny chow dogs, halls laid in black and white loz- enges with white blinds blowing, Peter saw through the opened door and approved of.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

162,"["" Coming as he did from a re- spectable Anglo-Indian family which for at least three generations had administered the affairs of a continent (it's strange, he thought, what a sentiment I have about that, disliking India, and empire, and army as he did), there were moments when civilisation, even of this sort, seemed dear to him as a personal possession; moments of pride in England; in butlers; chow dogs; girls in their security.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

163,"["" And the doctors and men of business and capable women all going about their business, punc- tual, alert, robust, seemed to him wholly admirable, good fellows, to whom one would entrust one's life, companions in the art of living, who would see one through.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
164,[' Yes.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

165,"["" As a child he had walked in Re- gent's Park - odd, he thought, how the thought of childhood keeps coming back to me - the result of seeing Clarissa, perhaps; for women live much more in the past than we do, he thought.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
166,"[' Bourton was a nice place, a very nice place, but I could never get on with the old man, he thought.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

167,"["" Yes, he remembered Regent's Park; the long straight walk; the little house where one bought air-balls to the left; an absurd statue with an inscription somewhere or other.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
168,[' He did not want to be bothered (feeling a little drowsy as he did) by people asking him the time.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

169,"[' An elderly grey nurse, with a baby asleep in its perambulator - that was the 74 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf best he could do for himself; sit down at the far end of the seat by that nurse.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
170,"["" She's a queer-looking girl, he thought, suddenly remembering Elizabeth as she came into the rooin and stood by her mother.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

173,"[' The rich benignant cigar smoke eddied coolly down his throat; he puffed it out again in rings which breasted the air bravely for a moment; blue, circular - I shall try and get a word alone with Elizabeth to-night, he thought - then began to wobble into hour- glass shapes and taper away; odd shapes they take, he thought.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

176,"[' The grey nurse resumed her knitting as Peter Walsh, on the hot seat beside her, began snoring.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

177,"[' In her grey dress, moving her hands indefatigably yet quietly, she seemed like_ the champion of the rights of sleepers, like one of those spectral presences which rise in twilight in woods made of sky and branches.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

178,"[' The solitary traveller, haunter of lanes, disturber of ferns, and devastator of great hemlock plants, looking up suddenly, sees the giant figure at the end of the ride.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

179,"[' But if he can conceive of her, then in some sort she exists, he thinks, and advancing down the path with his eyes upon sky and branches he rapidly endows them with woman- hood; sees with amazement how grave they become; how majes- tically, as the breeze stirs them, they dispense with a dark flutter of the leaves charity, comprehension, absolution, and then, flinging Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
180,"[' Dalloway 75 themselves suddenly aloft, confound the piety of their aspect with a wild carouse.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

181,"[' Such are the visions which proffer great cornucopias full of fruit to the solitary traveller, or murmur in his ear like sirens lolloping away on the green sea waves, or are dashed in his face like bunches of roses, or rise to the surface like pale faces which fishermen floun- der through floods to embrace.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

182,"[' Such are the visions which carelessly float up, pace beside, put their faces in front of, the actual thing; often overpowering the solitary traveller and taking away from him the sense of the earth, the wish to return, and giving him for substitute a general peace, as if (so he thinks as he advances down the forest ride) all this fever of living were simplicity itself; and myriads of things merged in one thing; and this figure, made of sky and branches as it is, had risen from the troubled sea (he is elderly, past fifty now) as a shape might be sucked up out of the waves to shower down from her magnificent hands compassion, comprehension, absolution.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
183,"[' So, he thinks, may I never go back to the lamplight; to the sitting-room; never finish my book; never knock out my pipe; never ring for Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

184,"[' Turner to clear away; rather let me walk straight on to this great figure, who will, with a toss of her head, mount me on her streamers and let me blow to nothingness with the rest.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

185,"[' The solitary traveller is soon beyond the wood; and there, coming to the door with shaded eyes, possibly to look for his return, with hands raised, with white apron blowing, is an elderly woman who seems (so powerful is this infirmity) to seek, over the desert, a lost son; to search for a rider destroyed; to be the figure of the mother whose sons have been killed in the battles of the world.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

186,"[' So, as the solitary traveller advances down the village street where the women stand knitting and the men dig in the garden, the evening seems ominous; the figures still; as if some august fate, known to them, awaited without fear, were about to sweep them into complete annihilation.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

187,"[' Indoors among ordinary things, the cupboard, the table, the win- dow-sill with its geraniums, suddenly the outline of the landlady, bending to remove the cloth, becomes soft with light, an adorable emblem which only the recollection of cold human contacts forbids us to embrace.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
188,"["" 76 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf So the elderly nurse knitted over the sleeping baby in Regent's Park.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
189,"["" He woke with extreme suddenness, saying to himself, ''The death of the soul.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
190,"['"" ""Lord, Lord!']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

192,"["" ''The death of the soul.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
193,"['"" The words attached themselves to some scene, to some room, to some past he had been dreaming of.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
194,"["" It was at Bourton that summer, early in the 'nineties, when he was so passionately in love with Clarissa.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

195,"[' There were a great many people there, laughing and talking, sitting round a table after tea, and the room was bathed in yellow light and full of cigarette smoke.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
196,"[' She was absurdly overdressed, ""like a cockatoo,"" Clarissa had said, imitating her, and she never stopped talking.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

205,"["" (She was Clarissa's greatest friend, always about the place, an attractive creature, hand- some, dark, with the reputation in those days of great daring, and he used to give her cigars, which she smoked in her bedroom, and she had either been engaged to somebody or quarrelled with her family, and old Parry disliked them both equally, which was a great bond.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

210,"['"" They had always this queer power of communicating without words.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

219,"[' There she sat in her white Cashmere shawl, with her head against the window - a formidable old lady, but kind to him, for he had found her some rare flower, and she was a great botanist, marching off in thick boots with a black tin collecting box slung between her shoulders.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

246,"[' But somehow as they watched him start, jumping on to his bicycle to ride twenty miles through the woods, wobbling off down the drive, waving his hand and disappearing, he obviously did feel, instinctively, tremendously, strongly, all that; the night; the romance; Clarissa.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
