251,"["" The final scene, the terrible scene which he believed had mattered more than anything in the whole of his life (it might be an exagge- ration- but still, so it did seem now), happened at three o'clock in the afternoon of a very hot day.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

252,"[' It was a trifle that led up to it- Sally at lunch saying something about Dalloway, and calling him ""My name is Dalloway""; whereupon Clarissa suddenly stiffened, col- oured, in a way she had, and rapped out sharply, ""We\'ve had enough of that feeble joke.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
253,"['"" That was all; but for him it was as if she had said, ""I\'m only amusing myself with you; I\'ve an under- standing with Richard Dalloway.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
254,"['"" So he took it.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
255,[' He had not slept for 80 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf nights.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
256,"[' ""It\'s got to be finished one way or the other,"" he said to himself.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
257,[' He sent a note to her by Sally asking her to meet him by the fountain at three.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
258,"[' The fountain was in the middle of a little shrubbery, far from the house, with shrubs and trees all round it.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
259,"[' There she came, even before the time, and they stood with the fountain between them, the spout (it was broken) dribbling water incessantly.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
260,"[' \'\'Tell me the truth,"" he repeated, when suddenly that old man Breitkopf popped his head in carrying the Times; stared at them; gaped; and went away.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
261,"[' And when she said, ""It\'s no use.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
262,"[' ""Clarissa!']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
263,"['"" But she never came back.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

264,"["" Still, he thought, yawning and beginning to take notice- Regent's Park had changed very little since he was a boy, except for the squirrels- still, presumably there were compen- sations- when little Elise Mitchell, who had been picking up pebbles to add to the pebble collection which she and her brother were making on the nursery mantelpiece, plumped her handful down on the nurse's knee and scudded off again full tilt into a lady's legs.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
265,[' Peter Walsh laughed out.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

266,"["" No; I can't stand it any longer, she was saying, having left Septimus, who wasn't Septimus any longer, to say hard, cruel, wicked things, to talk to himself, to talk to a dead man, on the seat over there; when the child ran full tilt into her, fell flat, and burst out crying.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
267,[' Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
268,[' Dalloway 81 That was comforting rather.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

269,"[' But· for herself she had done nothing wrong; she had loved Septimus; she had been happy; she had had a beautiful home, and there her sister lived still, making hats.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

270,"[' The child ran straight back to its nurse, and Rezia saw her scolded, comforted, taken up by the nurse who put down her knitting, and the kind-looking man gave her his watch to blow open to comfort her - but why should she be exposed?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
271,"[' Slightly waved by tears the broad path, the nurse, the man in grey, the perambulator, rose and fell before her eyes.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
272,[' She must go back again to Septimus since it was almost time for them to be going to Sir William Bradshaw.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

273,"[' She must go back and tell him, go back to him sitting there on the green chair under the tree, talking to himself, or to that dead man Evans, whom she had only seen once for a moment in the shop.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
274,"["" He had seemed a nice quiet man; a great friend of Septimus's, and he had been killed in the War.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
275,[' But such things happen to every one.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
276,"[' But Septimus let himself think about horrible things, as she could too, if she tried.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
277,[' He said people were talking behind the bedroom walls.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
278,[' Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
279,[' Filmer thought it odd.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
280,"["" He saw things too - he had seen an old woman's head in the middle of a fern.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
281,"[' All the little red and yellow flowers were out on the grass, like floating lamps he said, and talked and chattered and laughed, making up stories.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

282,"[' Suddenly he said, ""Now we will kill ourselves,"" when they were standing by the river, and he looked at it with a look which she had seen in his eyes when a train went by, or a:n omnibus- a look as if something fascinated him; and she felt he was going from her and she caught him by the arm.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

283,[' 82 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf He would argue with her about killing themselves; and explain how wicked people were; how he could see them making up lies as they passed in the street.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
284,"[' He knew all their thoughts, he said; he knew everything.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
285,"[' He knew the meaning of the world, he said.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
286,"[' He lay on the sofa and made her hold his hand to prevent him from falling down, down, he cried, into the flames!']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
287,"[' and saw faces laughing at him, calling him horrible disgusting names, from the walls, and hands pointing round the screen.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
288,"[' But he began to talk aloud, answering people, arguing, laughing, crying, getting very excited and making her write things down.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

289,"[' What, then, had happened - why had he gone, then, why, when she sat by him, did he start, frown at her, move away, and point at her hand, take her hand, look at it terrified?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
290,"[' ""My hand has grown so thin,"" she said; ""I have put it in my purse,"" she told him.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

291,"[' The rope was cut; he mounted; he was free, as it was decreed that he, Septimus, the lord of men, should be free; alone (since his wife had thrown away her wedding ring; since she had left him), he, Septimus, was alone, called forth in advance of the mass of men to hear the truth, to learn the meaning, which now at last, after all the toils of civilisation - Greeks, Romans, Shakespeare, Darwin, and now himself- was to be given whole to .']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
292,['.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
293,['.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
294,['.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

295,"[' The supreme secret must be told to the Cabinet; first, that trees are alive; next, there is no crime; next, love, universal love, he muttered, gasping, trembling, painfully drawing out these profound truths which needed, so deep were they, so difficult, an immense effort to speak out, but the world was entirely changed by them for ever.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
296,[' Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
297,"[' Dalloway 83 Heaven was divinely merciful, infinitely benignant.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

298,"["" It is a motor hom down in the street, he muttered; but up here it cannoned from rock to rock, divided, met in shocks of sound which rose in smooth columns (that music should be visible was a discovery) and became an anthem, an anthem twined round now by a shepherd boy's piping (Thaf s an old man playing a penny whistle by the public-house, he muttered) which, as the boy stood still, came bubbling from his pipe, and then, as he climbed higher, made its exquisite plaint while the traffic passed beneath.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
299,"["" This boy's elegy is played among the traffic, thought Septimus.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
300,"[' I have been dead, and yet am now alive, but let me rest still, he begged (he was talking to himself again - it was awful, awful!']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

301,"['); and as, before waking, the voices of birds and the sound of wheels chime and chatter in a queer harmony, grow louder and louder, and the sleeper feels himself drawing to the shores of life, so he felt himself drawing towards life, the sun growing hotter, cries sounding louder, something tremendous about to happen.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
302,"["" He strained; he pushed; he looked; he saw Regent's Park before him.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

303,"[' And as if to prove it (scien- tifically) wherever he looked, at the houses, at the railings, at the 84 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf antelopes stretching over the palings, beauty sprang instantly.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

304,"[' Up in the sky swallows swooping, swerving, flinging themselves in and out, round and round, yet always with perfect control as if elastics52 held them; and the flies rising and falling; and the sun spotting now this leaf, now that, in mockery, dazzling it with soft gold in pure good temper; and now and again some chime (it might be a motor hom) tinkling divinely on the grass stalks - all of this, calm and reasonable as it was, made out of ordinary things as it was, was the truth now; beauty, that was the truth now.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
305,"[' ""It is time,"" said Rezia.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
306,"[' There they waited till the War was over, and now the dead, now Evans himself- ""For God\'s sake don\'t come!']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
307,"[""'' Septimus cried out.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

308,"[' I must tell the whole world, Septimus cried, rais- ing his hand (as the dead man in the grey suit carne nearer), raising his hand like some colossal figure who has lamented the fate of man for ages in the desert alone with his hands pressed to his forehead, furrows of despair on his cheeks, and now sees light on the desert\'s edge which broadens and strikes the iron-black figure (and Septimus half rose from his chair), and with legions of men prostrate behind him he, the giant mourner, receives for one moment on his face the whole- ""But I am so unhappy, Septimus,"" said Rezia, trying to make him sit down.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

309,"[' He would tum round, he would tell them in a few moments, only a few moments more, of this relief, of this joy, of this astonishing revela- tion- ""The time, Septimus,"" Rezia repeated.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
310,"[' ""What is the time?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
311,"['"" He was talking, he was starting, this man must notice him.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
312,[' Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
313,"[' Dalloway 85 ""I will tell you the time,"" said Septimus, very slowly, very drow- sily, smiling mysteriously at the dead man in the grey suit.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
314,"[' And that is being young, Peter Walsh thought as he passed them.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
315,[' To be having an awful scene - the poor girl looked absolutely des- perate - in the middle of the morning.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

316,"[' But what was it about, he wondered; what had the young man in the overcoat been saying to her to make her look like that; what awful fix had they got them- selves mto, both to look so desperate as that on .']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
317,['a fine summer morning?'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

318,"[' The amusing thing about coming back to England, after five years, was the way it made, anyhow the first days, things stand out as if one had never seen them before; lovers squabbling under a tree; the domestic family life of the parks.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

319,"[' Never had he seen London look so enchanting - the softness of the distances; the richness; the greenness; the civilisation, after India, he thought, strolling across the grass.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

320,"[' Still at his age he had, like a boy or a girl even, these alternations of mood; good days, bad days, for no reason whatever, happiness from a pretty face, downright misery at the sight of a frump.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
321,[' After India of course one fell in love with every woman one met.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

322,[' There was a freshness about them; even the poorest dressed better than five years ago surely; and to his eye the fashions had never been so becoming; the long black cloaks; the slimness; the elegance; and then the deli- cious and apparently universal habit of paint.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

323,"[' Every woman, even the most respectable, had roses blooming under glass; lips cut with a knife; curls of Indian ink; there was design, art, everywhere; a change of some sort had undoubtedly taken place.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
324,[' What did the young people think about?'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
325,[' Peter Walsh asked himself.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
326,[' People looked different.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

327,"[' On board ship coming home there were lots of young men and girls - Betty and Bertie he remembered in particular- carrying on quite openly; the old mother sitting and watching them with her knitting, cool as a cucumber.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
328,"["" 86 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf And they weren't engaged; just having a good time; no feelings hurt on either side.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
329,[' She would make a very good wife at thirty - she would marry when it suited her to marry; marry some rich man and live in a large house near Manchester.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
330,"[' Peter Walsh asked himself, turning into the Broad Walk - married a rich man and lived in a large house near Manchester?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
331,"[' It was seeing blue hydrangeas that made her think of him and the old days - Sally Seton, of course!']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

332,"[' It was Sally Seton - the last person in the world one would have expected to marry a rich man and live in a large house near Manchester, the wild, the daring, the romantic Sally!']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
333,"["" But of all that ancient lot, Clarissa's friends - Whitbreads, Kindersleys, Cunninghams, Kinloch-Joneses - Sally was probably the best.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
334,[' She tried to get hold of things by the right end anyhow.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
335,[' She saw through Hugh Whitbread anyhow - the admirable Hugh - when Clarissa and the rest were at his feet.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
336,"[' He thought of nothing but his own appearance, she said.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

337,"[' And of course Hugh had the most extraordinary, the most natural, the most sublime respect for the British aristocracy of any human being he had ever come across.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

338,"["" One of the things he remembered best was an argument one Sunday morning at Bourton about women's rights (that antediluvian topic), when Sally sud- denly lost her temper, flared up, and told Hugh that he represented all that was most detestable in British middle-class life.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
339,"[' She did it on purpose, she said afterwards (for they used to get together in the vegetable garden and compare notes).']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

340,"[' ""He\'s read nothing, thought nothing, felt nothing,"" he could hear her saying in that very emphatic voice which carried so much farther than she knew.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
341,[' The stable boys had more life in Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
342,"[' Dalloway 87 them than Hugh, she said.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
343,"[' He was a perfect specimen of the public school type, she said.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

344,"["" And he'd found his job - married his Honourable Evelyn; got some little post at Court, looked after the King's cellars, polished the Imperial shoe-buckles, went about in knee-breeches and lace ruffles.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

345,"["" He had married this lady, the Honourable Evelyn, and they lived hereabouts, so he thought (looking at the pompous houses overlook- ing the Park), for he had lunched there once in a house which had, like all Hugh's possessions, something that no other house could possibly have - linen cupboards it might have been.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

346,"[' You had to go and look at them - you had to spend a great deal of time always admiring whatever it was - linen cupboards, pillow-cases, old oak furniture, pictures, which Hugh had picked up for an old song.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
347,[' But Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
348,[' Hugh sometimes gave the show away.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
349,[' She was one of those obscure mouse-like little women who admire big men.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

350,"[' And so there they lived, with their linen cupboards and their old masters and their pillow-cases fringed with real lace, at the rate of five or ten thousand a year presumably, while he, who was two years older than Hugh, cadged for a job.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

351,"["" At fifty-three he had to come and ask them to put him into some secretary's office, to find him some usher's job teaching little boys Latin, at the beck and call of some mandarin in an office, something that brought in five hundred a year; for if he married Daisy, even with his pension, they could never do on less.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
352,"["" He didn't mind what he asked Dalloway.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
353,[' 88 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf He was a thorough good sort; a bit limited; a bit thick in the head; yes; but a thorough good sort.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

354,"["" He was at his best out of doors, with horses and dogs - how good he was, for instance, when that great shaggy dog of Clarissa's got caught in a trap and had its paw half torn off, and Clarissa turned faint and Dalloway did the whole thing; bandaged, made splints; told Clarissa not to be a fool.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
355,"[' Hold this -fetch that,"" all the time talking to the dog as if it were a human being.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

356,"["" Seriously and sol- emnly Richard Dalloway got on his hind legs and said that no decent man ought to read Shakespeare's sonnets because it was like listen- ing at keyholes (besides, the relationship55 was not one that he ap- proved).""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

357,"["" But Clarissa sucked it all in; thought it so honest of him; so independent of him; Heaven knows if she didn't think him the most original mind she'd ever met!""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

358,"[' There was a garden where they used to walk, a walled-in place with rose- bushes and giant cauliflowers - he could remember Sally tearing off a rose, stopping to exclaim at the beauty of the cabbage leaves in the moonlight (it was extraordinary how vividly it all came back to him, things he hadn\'t thought of for years), while she implored him, half laughing of course, to carry off Clarissa, to save her from the Hughs and the Dalloways and all the other ""perfect gentlemen"" who would ""stifle her soul"" (she wrote reams of poetry in those days), make a mere hostess of her, encourage her worldliness.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

359,"["" Beneath, she was very shrewd - a far better judge of character than Sally, for instance, and with it all, purely feminine; with that extraordinary gift, that woman's gift, of making a world of her own wherever she happened to be.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
360,"[' She came into a room; she stood, as he had often seen her, in a doorway with lots of people round her.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
361,[' Not that she was Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

362,"[' Dalloway 89 striking; not beautiful at all; there was nothing picturesque about her; she never said anything specially clever; there she was, how- ever; there she was.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

363,"[' He only felt, after seeing her that morning, among her scissors and silks, making ready for the party, unable to get away from the thought of her; she kept coming back and back like a sleeper57 jolting against him in a railway carriage; which was not being in love, of course; it was thinking of her, criticising her, starting again, after thirty years, trying to explain her.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

364,[' The obvious thing to say of her was that she was worldly; cared too much for rank and society and getting on in the world - which was true in a sense; she had admitted it to him.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
365,[' (You could always get her to own up if you took the trouble; she was honest.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

366,"[') What she would say was that she hated frumps, fogies, failures, like himself presumably; thought people had no right to slouch about with their hands in their pockets; must do something, be something; and these great swells, these Duchesses, these hoary old Countesses one met in her drawing-room, unspeakably remote as he felt them to be from anything that mattered a straw, stood for something real to her.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

367,"[' Lady Bexborough, she said once, held herself upright (so did Clarissa herself; she never lounged in any sense of the word; she was straight as a dart, a little rigid in fact).']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
368,[' She said they had a kind of courage which the older she grew the more she respected.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
369,"[' With twice his wits, she had to see things through his eyes - one of the tragedies of married life.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

370,"["" With a mind of her own, she must always be quoting Richard- as if one couldn't know to a tittle what Richard thought by reading the Morning Post59 of a morning!""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

371,"[' And behind it all was that network of visiting, leaving cards, being kind to people; running about with bunches of flowers, little presents; So-and-so was going to France - must have an air-cushion; a real drain on her strength; all that 90 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf interminable traffic that women of her sort keep up; but she did it genuinely, from a natural instinct.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

372,"[' Oddly enough, she was one of the most thorough-going sceptics he had ever met, and possibly (this was a theory he used to make up to account for her, so transparent in some ways, so inscrutable in others), possibly she said to herself, As we are a doomed race, chained to a sinking ship (her favourite reading as a girl was Huxley and Tyndall,60 and they were fond of these nautical metaphors), as the whole thing is a bad joke, let us, at any rate, do our part; mitigate the sufferings of our fellow-prisoners (Huxley again); decorate the dungeon with flowers and air-cushions; be as decent as we possibly can.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

373,"["" Those ruffians, the Gods, shan't have it all their own way- her notion being that the Gods, who never lost a chance of hurting, thwarting and spoiling human lives, were seriously put out if, all the same, you behaved like a lady.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

374,"["" To see your own sister killed by a falling tree (all Justin Parry's fault- all his carelessness) before your very eyes, a girl too on the verge of life, the most gifted of them, Clarissa always said, was enough to tum one bitter.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

375,"[' It was her nature to enjoy (though, goodness only knows, she had her reserves; it was a mere sketch, he often felt, that even he, after all these years, could make of Clarissa).']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

376,"[' If you walked with her in Hyde Park now it was a bed of tulips, now a child in a perambulator, now some absurd little drama she made up on the spur of the moment.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
377,"[' (Very likely she would have talked to those lovers, if she had thought them unhappy.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

378,"["") She had a sense of comedy that was really exquisite, but she needed people, always people, to bring it out, with the inevitable result that she frittered her time away, lunching, dining, giving these incessant parties of hers, talking nonsense, saying things she didn't mean, blunting the edge of her mind, losing her discrimination.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

379,[' There she would sit at the head of the table taking infinite pains with some old buffer who might be useful to Dalloway - they knew the most appalling bores in Europe - or in came Elizabeth and every thing must give way to her.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
380,"[' She was at a High School, at the inarticu- late stage last time he was over, a round-eyed, pale-faced girl, with Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

381,"[' Dalloway 91 nothing of her mother in her, a silent stolid creature, who took it all a:; a matter of course, let her mother make a fuss of her, and then said ""May I go now?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

382,"['"" like a child of four; going off, Clarissa explained, with that mixture of amusement and pride which Dalloway himself seemed to rouse in her, to play hockey.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
383,"[' And now Elizabeth was ""out"", presumably; thought him an old fogy, laughed at her moth- er\'s friends.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

384,"["" The compensation of growing old, Peter Walsh thought, coming out of Regent's Park, and holding his hat in hand, was simply this; that the passions remain as strong as ever, but one has gained - at last!""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
385,"[' For hours at a time (pray God that one might say these things without being overheard), for hours and days he never thought of Daisy.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
386,"[' Could it be that he was in love with her, then, remembering the misery, the torture, the extraordinary passion of those days?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

387,"[' And that perhaps was the reason why, when the ship actually sailed, he felt an extraor- dinary relief, wanted nothing so much as to be alone; was annoyed to find all her little attentions - cigars, notes, a rug for the voyage - in his cabin.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

388,"["" Every one if they were honest would say the same; one doesn't want people after fifty; one doesn't want to go on telling women they are pretty; that's what most men of fifty would say, Peter Walsh thought, if they were honest.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
389,[' What could Clarissa have thought of him?'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
390,"[' thought him a fool presumably, not for the first time.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

391,"["" It was jealousy that was at the bottom of it - jealousy which survives every other passion of mankind, Peter Walsh thought, holding his pocket-knife at arm's length.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

392,"[' She had been meeting 92 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf Major Orde, Daisy said in her last letter; said it on purpose, he knew; said it to make him jealous; he could see her wrinkling her forehead as she wrote, wondering what she could say to hurt him; and yet it made no difference; he was furious!']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

393,"[' That was what tortured him, that was what came over him when he saw Clarissa so calm, so cold, so intent on her dress or whatever it was; realising what she might have spared him, what she had reduced him to - a whimpering, snivel- ling old ass.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
394,"["" But women, he thought, shutting his pocket-knife, don't know what passion is.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
395,"[' There she would sit on the sofa by his side, let him take her hand, give him one kiss on the cheek- Here he was at the crossing.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

396,"["" A sound interrupted him; a frail quivering sound, a voice bub- bling up without direction, vigour, beginning or end, running weakly and shrilly and with an absence of all human meaning into ee urn fah urn so foo swee too eern oo - the voice of no age or sex, the voice of an ancient spring spouting from the earth; which issued, just opposite Regent's Park Tube Sta- tion, from a tall quivering shape, like a funnel, like a rusty pump, like a wind-beaten tree for ever barren of leaves which lets the wind run up and down its branches singing ee urn fah urn so foo swee too eern oo, and rocks and creaks and moans in the eternal breeze.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

397,"["" Through all ages - when the pavement was grass, when it was swamp, through the age of tusk and mammoth, through the age of silent sunrise - the battered woman - for she wore a skirt - with her right hand exposed, her left clutching at her side, stood singing of love- love which has lasted a million years, she sang, love which prevails, and millions of years ago, her lover, who had been dead these centuries, had walked, she crooned, with her in May; but in the course of ages, long as summer days, and flaming, she remembered, with nothing but red asters, he had gone; death' s enormous sickle had swept those tremendous hills, and when at last she laid her Mrs.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

398,"[' Dalloway 93 hoary and immensely aged head on the earth, now become a mere cinder of ice, she implored the Gods to lay by her side a bunch of purple heather, there on her high burial place which the last rays of the last sun caressed; for then the pageant of the universe would be over.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

399,"["" As the ancient song bubbled up opposite Regent's Park Tube Station, still the earth seemed green and flowery; still, though it issued from so rude a mouth, a mere hole in the earth, muddy too, matted ·with root fibres and tangled grasses, still the old bubbling burbling song, soaking through the knotted roots of infinite ages, and skeletons and treasure, streamed away in rivulets over the pave- ment and all along the Marylebone Road, and down towards Euston, fertilising, leaving a damp stain.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

400,"[' Still remembering how once in some primeval May she had walked with her lover, this rusty pump, this battered old woman with one hand exposed for coppers, the other clutching her side, would still be there in ten million years, remembering how once she had walked in May, where the sea flows now, with whom it did not matter- he was a man, oh yes, a man who had loved her.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

401,"[' But the passage of ages had blurred the clarity of that ancient May day; the bright petalled flowers were hoar and silver frosted; and she no longer saw, when she implored him (as she did now quite clearly) ""look in my eyes with thy sweet eyes intently,"" she no longer saw brown eyes, black whiskers or sunburnt face, but only a looming shape, a shadow shape, to which, with the bird-like freshness of the very aged, she still twittered ""give me your hand and let me press it gently""61 (Peter Walsh couldn\'t help giving the poor creature a coin as he stepped into his taxi), ""and if some one should see, what matter they?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

402,"['"" she demanded; and her fist clutched at her side, and she smiled, pocket- ing her shilling, and all peering inquisitive eyes seemed blotted out, and the passing generations - the pavement was crowded with bustling middle-class people - vanished, like leaves, to be trodden under, to be soaked and steeped and made mould of by that eternal spring- ee urn fah urn so foo swee too eern oo.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
403,"[' ""Poor old woman,"" said Rezia Warren Smith.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
404,"[' she said, waiting to cross.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
405,[' 94 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf Suppose it was a wet night?'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
406,"["" Suppose one's father, or somebody who had known one in better days had happened to pass, and saw one standing there in the gutter?""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

407,"[' Cheerfully, almost gaily, the invincible thread of sound wound up into the air like the smoke from a cottage chimney, winding up clean beech trees and issuing in a tuft of blue smoke among the topmost leaves.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
408,"[' ""And if some one should see, what matter they?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

409,"['"" Since she was so unhappy, for weeks and weeks now, Rezia had given meanings to things that happened, almost felt sometimes that she must stop people in the street, if they looked good, kind people, just to say to them ""I am unhappy""; and this old woman singing in the street ""if some one should see, what matter they?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
410,"['"" made her suddenly quite sure that everything was going to be right.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
411,[' They were going to Sir William Bradshaw; she thought his name sounded nice; he would eure Septimus at once.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
412,"[' So they crossed, Mr.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
413,[' and Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

414,"[' Septimus Warren Smith, and was there, after all, anything to draw attention to them, anything to make a passer-by suspect here is a young man who carries in him the greatest message in the world, and is, moreover, the happiest man in the world, and the most miserable?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

415,"["" Perhaps they walked more slowly than other people, and there was something hesitating, trailing, in the man's walk, but what more natural for a clerk, who has not been in the West End on a week-day at this hour for years, than to keep looking at the sky, looking at this, that and the other, as if Portland Place were a room he had come into when the family are away, the chandeliers being hung in holland bags, and the caretaker, as she lets in long shafts of dusty light upon deserted, queer-looking arm- chairs, lifting one comer of the long blinds, explains to the visitors what a wonderful place it is; how wonderful, but at the same time, he thinks, how strange.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

416,"[' To look at, he might have been a clerk, but of the better sort; for he wore brown boots; his hands were educated; so, too, his profile- his angular, big-nosed, intelligent, sensitive profile; but not his lips alto- gether, for they were loose; and his eyes (as eyes tend to be), eyes merely; hazel, large; so that he was, on the whole, a border case, neither one thing nor the other; might end with a house at Purley and a motor car, or continue renting apartments in back streets all his life; one of those half-educated, self-educated men whose educa- Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

417,"["" Dalloway 95 tion is all learnt from books borrowed from public libraries, read in the evening after the day's work, on the advice of well-known au- thors consulted by letter.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

418,"[' As for the other experiences, the solitary ones, which people go through alone, in their bedrooms, in their offices, walking the fields and the streets of London, he had them; had left home, a mere boy, because of his mother; she lied; because he came down to tea for the fiftieth time with his hands unwashed; because he could see no future for a poet in Stroud; and so, making a confidant of his little sister, had gone to London leaving an absurd note behind him, such as great men have written, and the world has read later when the story of their struggles has become famous.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

419,[' London has swallowed up many millions of young men called Smith; thought nothing of fantastic Christian names like Septimus with which their parents have thought to distinguish them.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

420,"[' But of all this what could themost observant of friends have said except what a gardener says when he opens the conservatory door in the morning and finds a new blossom on his plant: - It has flowered; flowered from vanity, ambition, idealism, passion, loneliness, courage, laziness, the usual seeds, which all muddled up (in a room off the Euston Road), made him shy, and stammering, made him anxious to improve himself, made him fall in love with Miss Isabel Pole, lecturing in the Waterloo Road62 upon Shakespeare.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

421,"[' she asked; and reflected how she might give him a taste of Antony and Cleopatra and the rest; lent him books; wrote him scraps of letters; and lit in him such a fire as burns only once in a lifetime, without heat, flickering a red gold flame infinitely ethereal and insubstantial over Miss Pole; Antony and Cleopatra; and the Waterloo Road.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

422,"[' He thought her beautiful, believed her impecca- bly wise; dreamed of her, wrote poems to her, which, ignoring the subject, she corrected in red ink; he saw her, one summer evening, walking in a green dress in a square.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

423,"[' ""It has flowered,"" the gardener might have said, had he opened the door; had he come in, that is to say, any night about this time, and found him writing; found him tearing up his writing; found him finishing a masterpiece at three o\'clock in the morning and running out to pace the streets, and visiting churches, and fasting one day, drinking another, devouring Shakespeare, Darwin, The History ofCivilisation,63 and Bernard Shaw.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
424,"[' 96 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf Something was up, Mr.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
425,[' Brewer knew; Mr.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

426,"[' Brewer, managing clerk at Sibleys and Arrowsmiths, auctioneers, valuers, land and estate agents; something was up, he thought, and, being paternal with his young men, and thinking very highly of Smith\'s abilities, and prophesying that he would, in ten or fifteen years, succeed to the leather arm-chair in the inner room under the skylight with the deed-boxes round him, ""if he keeps his health,"" said Mr.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

427,"[' Brewer, and that was the danger - he looked weakly; advised football, in- vited him to supper and was seeing his way to consider recommend- ing a rise of salary, when something happened which threw out many of Mr.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

428,"["" Brewer's calculations, took away his ablest young fel- lows, and eventually, so prying and insidious were the fingers of the European War, smashed a plaster cast of Ceres, ploughed a hole in the geranium beds, and utterly ruined the cook's nerves at Mr.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
429,"["" Brewer's establishment at Muswell Hill.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

430,"["" He went to France to save an England which consisted almost entirely of Shakespeare's plays and Miss Isabel Pole in a green dress walking in a square.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

431,"["" It was a case of two dogs playing on a hearth-rug; one worrying a paper screw, snarling, snapping, giving a pinch, now and then, at the old dog's ear; the other lying somno- lent, blinking at the fire, raising a paw, turning and growling good- temperedly.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

432,"[' But when Evans (Rezia, who had only seen him once, called him ""a quiet man"", a sturdy red- haired man, undemonstrative in the company of women), when Evans was killed, just before the Armistice, in Italy, Septimus, far from showing any emotion or recognising that here was the end of a friendship, congratulated himself upon feeling very little and very reasonably.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

433,"[' When peace came he was in Milan, billeted in the house of an innkeeper with a courtyard, flowers in tubs, little tables in the open, daughters making hats, and to Lucrezia, the younger daughter, he became engaged one evening when the panic was on him - that he could not feel.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
434,[' Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
435,"[' Dalloway 97 For now that it was all over, truce signed, and the dead buried, he had, especially in the evening, these sudden thunder-claps of fear.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

436,"[' As he opened the door of the room where the Italian girls sat making hats, he could see them; could hear them; they were rubbing wires among coloured beads in saucers; they were turning buckram shapes this way and that; the table was all strewn with feathers, spangles, silks, ribbons; scissors were rapping on the table; but something failed him; he could not feel.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

437,"[' He asked Lucrezia to marry him, the younger of the two, the gay, the frivolous, with those little artist\'s fingers that she would hold up and say ""It is all in them.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
438,"['"" Silk, feathers, what not were alive to them.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
439,"[' Every hat that passed, she would examine; and the cloak and the dress and the way the woman held herself.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

440,"[' Ill-dress- ing, over-dressing she stigmatised, not savagely, rather with impa- tient movements of the hands, like those of a painter who puts from him some obvious well-meant glaring imposture; and then, gener- ously, but always critically, she would welcome a shop-girl who had turned her little bit of stuff gallantly, or praise, wholly, with enthu- siastic and professional understanding, a French lady descending from her carriage, in chinchilla, robes, pearls.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
441,"[' Even taste (Rezia liked ices, chocolates, sweet things) had no relish to him.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
442,"[' He looked at people outside; happy they seemed, collecting in the middle of the street, shouting, laugh- ing, squabbling over nothing.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
443,[' In the tea-shop among the tables and the chattering waiters the appalling fear came over him- he could not feel.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

444,"[' He could reason; he could read, Dante for example, quite easily (""Septimus, do put down your book,"" said Rezia, gently shutting the Inferno), he could add up his bill; his brain was perfect; it must be the fault of the world then - that he could not feel.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
445,"[' ""The English are so silent,"" Rezia said.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
446,"[' She liked it, she said.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

447,"[' She respected these Englishmen, and wanted to see London, and the English horses, and the tailor-made suits, and could remember hear- 98 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf ing how wonderful the shops were, from an aunt who had married and lived in Soho.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

448,"[' It might be possible, Septimus thought, looking at England from the train window, as they left Newhaven; it might be possible that the world itself is without meaning.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
449,"[' She looked pale, mysterious, like a lily, drowned, under water, he thought.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
450,[' Love between man and woman was repulsive to Shakespeare.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

452,"[' She must have a son like Septimus, she said.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

454,[' For the truth is (let her Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
455,"[' Dalloway 99 ignore it) that human beings have neither kindness, nor faith, nor charity beyond what serves to increase the pleasure of the mo- ment.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

456,"["" There was Brewer at the office, with his waxed moustache, coral tie-pin, white slip, and pleasurable emotions - all coldness and clamminess within - his geraniums ruined in the War - his cook's nerves destroyed; or Amelia Whatshername, handing round cups of tea punctually at five - a leering, sneering obscene little harpy; and the Toms and Berties in their starched shirt fronts oozing thick drops of vice.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
457,[' At tea Rezia told him that Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
458,"["" Filmer's daughter was expecting a baby.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

459,"[' His wife was crying, and he felt nothing; only each time she sobbed in this profound, this silent, this hopeless way, he descended another step into the pit.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
460,[' She sent for a doctor- Mrs.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

472,"[' Holmes, tapping the wall, are often full of very fine panelling, which the landlords have the folly to paper 100 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf over.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

473,"['66 Only the other day, visiting a patient, Sir Somebody Some- thing, in Bedford Square - So there was no excuse; nothing whatever the matter, except the sin for which human nature had condemned him to death; that he did not feel.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

474,"[' He had not cared when Evans was killed; that was worst; but all the other crimes raised their heads and shook their fingers and jeered and sneered over the rail of the bed in the early hours of the morning at the prostrate body which lay realising its degradation; how he had married his wife without loving her; had lied to her; seduced her; outraged Miss Isabel Pole, and was so pocked and marked with vice that women shuddered when they saw him in the street.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

475,"[' Large, fresh-coloured, handsome, flick- ing his boots, looking in the glass, he brushed it all aside - head- aches, sleeplessness, fears, dreams - nerve symptoms and nothing more, he said.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
476,"[' Some hobby, said Dr.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

477,"[' Holmes, for did he not owe his own excellent health (and he worked as hard as any man in London) to the fact that he could always switch off from his patients on to old furniture?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
478,"[' And what a very pretty comb, if he might say so, Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

482,"[' Really he had to give that charming little lady, Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
483,"["" Smith, a friendly push before he could get past her into her husband's bedroom.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
484,"[' ""So you\'re in a funk,"" he said agreeably, sitting down by his patient\'s side.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
485,"["" For he had had forty years' experience behind him; and Septimus could take Dr.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

512,"["" It was precisely twelve o'clock; twelve by Big Ben; whose stroke was wafted over the northern part of London; blent with that of other clocks, mixed in a thin ethereal way with the clouds and wisps of smoke and died up there among the seagulls- twelve o'clock struck as Clarissa Dalloway laid her green dress on her bed, and the War- ren Smiths walked down Harley Street.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
513,"["" Probably, Rezia thought, that was Sir William Bradshaw's house with the grey motor car in front of it.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
514,[' (The leaden circles dissolved in the air.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

515,"["") Indeed it was- Sir William Bradshaw's motor car; low, powerful, grey with plain initials interlocked on the panel, as if the pomps of heraldry were incongru.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

516,"['ous, this man b~ing the ghostly helper, the priest of science; and, as the motor car was grey, so to match its sober suavity, grey furs, silver grey rugs were heaped in it, to keep her ladyship warm while she waited.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

517,"[' Her ladyship waited with the rugs about her knees an hour or more, leaning back, thinking sometimes of the patient, sometimes, excusably, of the wall of gold, mounting minute by minute while she waited; the wall of gold that was mount- ing between them and all shifts and anxieties (she had borne them bravely; they had had their struggles) until she felt wedged on a calm ocean, where only spice winds blow; respected, admired, en- vied, with scarcely anything left to wish for, though she regretted her stoutness; large dinner-parties every Thursday night to the pro- fession; an occasional bazaar to be opened; Royalty greeted; too little Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

518,"[' Dalloway 103 time, alas, with her husband, whose work grew and grew; a boy doing well at Eton; she would have liked a daughter too; interests she had, however, in plenty; child welfare; the after-care of the epileptic, and photography, so that if there was a church building, or a church decaying, she bribed the sexton, got the key and took photographs, which were scarcely to be distinguished from the work of professionals, while she waited.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

519,"[' He had worked very hard; he had won his position by sheer ability (being the son of a shopkeeper); loved his profession; made a fine figurehead at cere- monies and spoke well - all of which had by the time he was knighted given him a heavy look, a weary look (the stream of pa- tients being so incessant, the responsibilities and privileges of his profession so onerous), which weariness, together with his grey hairs, increased the extraordinary distinction of his presence and gave him the reputation (of the utmost importance in dealing with nerve cases) not merely of lightning skill and almost infallible accu- racy in diagnosis, but of sympathy; tact; understanding of the hu- man soul.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

520,[' He could see the first moment they came into the room (the Warren Smiths they were called); he was certain directly he saw the man; it was a case of extreme gravity.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
521,[' Said there was nothing the matter?'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
522,"[' \'\'Yes, he served with the greatest distinction,"" Rezia assured the doctor; ""he was promoted.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
523,"['"" ""And they have the very highest opinion of you at your office?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
524,"['"" Sir William murmured, glancing at Mr.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
525,"["" Brewer's very generously 104 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf worded letter.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
526,[' If Mr.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

528,[' Smith in the next room.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

530,"[' But he did not mean it, she said.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
531,"[' It was merely a question of rest, said Sir William; of rest, rest, rest; a long rest in bed.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
532,[' There was a delightful home down in the country where her husband would be perfectly looked after.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

537,"[' So they returned to the most exalted of mankind; the criminal who faced his judges; the victim exposed on the heights; the fugitive; the drowned sailor; the poet of the immortal ode; the Lord who had gone from life to death; to Septimus Warren Smith, who sat in the arm-chair under the skylight staring at a photograph of Lady Bradshaw in Court dress, muttering messages about beauty.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
538,"[' \'\'We have had our little talk,"" said Sir William.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
539,"[' ""We have been arranging that you should go into a home,"" said Sir William.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

540,"[' For there was in Sir William, whose father had been a tradesman, a natural respect for breeding and clothing, which shabbiness nettled; again, more pro- foundly, there was in Sir William, who had never had time for reading, a grudge, deeply buried, against cultivated people who Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
541,"[' Dalloway 105 came into his room and intimated that doctors, whose profession is a constant strain upon all the highest faculties, are not educated men.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
542,"[' ""One of my homes, Mr.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
543,"[' Warren Smith,"" he said, ""where we will teach you to rest.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
544,"['"" And there was just one thing more.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
545,"[' ""We all have our moments of depression,"" said Sir William.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
546,"[' ""Impulses came upon him sometimes?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
