1517,"[' Under the influence of that extraor- To the Lighthouse 189 dinary emotion which had been growing all the walk, had begun in the garden when he had wanted to take her bag, had increased in the town when he had wanted to tell her everything about himself, he was coming to see himself and everything he had ever known gone crooked a little.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1518,"[' There he stood in the parlour of the poky little house where she had taken him, waiting for her, while she went upstairs a moment to see a woman.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1519,"[' He heard her quick step above; heard her voice cheer- ful, then low; looked at the mats, tea-caddies, glass shades; waited quite impatiently; looked forward eagerly to the walk home, deter- mined to carry her bag; then heard her come out; shut a door; say they must keep the windows open and the doors shut, ask at the house for anything they wanted (she must be talking to a child), when, suddenly, in she came, stood for a moment silent (as if she had been pretending up there, and for a moment let herself be now), stood quite motionless for a moment against a picture of Queen Victoria wearing the blue ribbon of the Garter;10 and all at once he realized that it was this: it was this: -she was the most beautiful person he had ever seen.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1520,[' Stepping through fields of flowers and tak- ing to her breast buds that had broken and lambs that had fallen; with the stars in her eyes and the wind in her hair - he took her bag.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1521,"[' ""Good-bye, Elsie,"" she said, and they walked up the street, she holding her parasol erect and walking as if she expected to meet someone round the corner, while for the first time in his life Charles Tansley felt an extraordinary pride; a man digging in a drain stopped digging and looked at her; let his arm fall down and looked at her; Charles Tansley felt an extraordinary pride; felt the wind and the cyclamen and the violets for he was walking with a beautiful woman for the first time in his life.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1522,"[' 2 ""No going to the Lighthouse, James,"" he said, as he stood by the window, speaking awkwardly, but trying in deference to Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1523,[' Ramsay to soften his voice into some semblance of geniality at least.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1524,"[' Odious little man, thought Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1525,"[' Ramsay, why go on saying that?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1526,"[' 190 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf 3 ""Perhaps you will wake up and find the sun shining and the birds singing,"" she said compassionately, smoothing the little boy\'s hair, for her husband, with his caustic saying that it would not be fine, had dashed his spirits she could see.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1527,"[' This going to the Lighthouse was a passion of his, she saw, and then, as if her husband had not said enough, with his caustic saying that it would not be fine to- morrow, this odious little man went and rubbed it in all over again.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1528,"[' All she could do now was to admire the refrigerator, and tum the pages of the Stores list in the hope that she might come upon some- thing like a rake, or a mowing-machine, which, with its prongs and its handles, would need the greatest skill and care in cutting out.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1529,"[' The gruff murmur, irregularly broken by the taking out of pipes and the putting in of pipes which had kept on assuring her, though she could not hear what was said (as she sat in the window), that the men were happily talking; this sound, which had lasted now half an hour and had taken its place soothingly in the scale of sounds pressing on top of her, such as the tap of balls upon bats, the sharp, sudden bark now and then, ""How\'s that?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1530,"["" How's that?""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1531,"['"" 11 of the children playing cricket, had ceased; so that the monotonous fall of the waves on the beach, which for the most part beat a measured and soothing tattoo to her thoughts and seemed consolingly to repeat over and over again as she sat with the children the words of some old cradle song, murmured by nature, ""I am guarding you - I am your support"", but at other times suddenly and unexpectedly, espe- cially when her mind raised itself slightly from the task actually in hand, had no such kindly meaning, but like a ghostly roll of drums remorselessly beat the measure of life, made one think of the de- struction of the island and its engulfment in the sea, and warned her whose day had slipped past in one quick doing after another that it was all ephemeral as a rainbow - this sound which had been ob- scured and concealed under the other sounds suddenly thundered hollow in her ears and made her look up with an impulse of terror.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1532,"["" One moment more, with her head raised, she listened, as if she waited for some habitual sound, some regular mechanical sound; and then, 'hearing something rhythmical, half said, half chanted, beginning in the garden, as her husband beat up and down the terrace, something between a croak and a song, she was soothed once more, assured again that all was well, and looking down at the book on her knee found the picture of a pocket knife with six blades which could only be cut out if James was very careful.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1533,"["" But the sight of the girl stand- ing on the edge of the lawn painting reminded her; she was sup- posed to be keeping her head as much in the same position as possible for Lily's picture.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1534,"[' With her little Chinese eyes and her puckered-up face she would never marry; one could not take her painting very seriously; but she was an independent little creature, Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1535,"[' Ramsay liked her for it, and so remembering her promise, she bent her head.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1536,"[' 4 Indeed, he almost knocked her easel over, coming down upon her with his hands waving, shouting out ""Boldly we rode and well"" ,13 but, mercifully, he turned sharp, and rode off, to die gloriously she supposed upon the heights of Balaclava.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1537,"[' But so long as he kept like that, waving, shouting, she was safe; he would not stand still and look at her picture.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1538,"[' Even while she looked at the mass, at the line, at the colour, at Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1539,"[' 192 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf Ramsay sitting in the window with James, she kept a feeler on her surroundings lest someone should creep up, and suddenly she should find her picture looked at.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1540,"[' But now, with all her senses quickened as they were, looking, straining, till the colour of the wall and the jacmanna 14 beyond burnt into her eyes, she was aware of someone coming out of the house, coming towards her; but somehow di- vined, from the footfall, William Bankes, so that though her brush quivered, she did not, as she would have done had it been Mr.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1541,"[' Tansley, Paul Rayley, Minta Doyle, or practically anybody else, tum her canvas upon the grass, but let it stand.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1542,"[' They had rooms in the village, and so, walking in, walking out, parting late on door-mats, had said little things about the soup, about the children, about one thing and another which made them allies; so that when he stood beside her now in his judicial way (he was old enough to be her father too, a botanist, a widower, smelling of soap, very scrupulous and clean) she just stood there.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1543,"[' Lodging in the same house with her, he had noticed too, how orderly she was, up be- fore breakfast and off to paint, he believed, alone: poor, presumably, and without the complexion or the allurement of Miss Doyle cer- tainly, but with a good sense which made her in his eyes superior to that young lady.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1544,"[' Now, for instance, when Ramsay bore down on them, shouting, gesticulating, Miss Briscoe, he felt certain, under- stood.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1545,"[' So, Lily thought, it was probably an excuse of his for moving, for getting out of earshot, that made Mr.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1546,[' Bankes almost immediately say something about its being chilly and suggest taking a stroll.'],Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1547,"[' She would not have considered it honest to tamper with the bright violet and the staring white, since she saw them like that, fashionable though it was, since Mr.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1548,"["" Paunceforte's visit, to see everything pale, elegant, To the Lighthouse 193 semi-transparent.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1549,"[' She could see it all so clearly, so commandingly, when she looked: it was when she took her brush in hand that the whole thing changed.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1550,"[' And it was then too, in that chill and windy way, as she began to paint, that there forced themselves upon her other things, her own inadequacy, her insignificance, keeping house for her father off the Brompton Road,16 and had much ado to control her impulse to fling herself (thank Heaven she had always resisted so far) at Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1551,"["" Ramsay's knee and say to her- but what could one say to her?""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1552,"[' ""I\'m in love with this all"", waving her hand at the hedge, at the house, at the children?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1553,"[' So now she laid her brushes neatly in the box, side by side, and said to William Bankes: ""It suddenly gets cold.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1554,"[' The sun seems to give less heat,"" she said, looking about her, for it was bright enough, the grass still a soft deep green, the house starred in its greenery with purple passion flowers, and rooks dropping cool cries from the high blue.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1555,"[' So off they strolled down the garden in the usual direction, past the tennis lawn, past the pampas grass, to that break in the thick hedge, guarded by red-hot pokers like brasiers of clear burning coal, between which the blue waters of the bay looked bluer than ever.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1556,"[' It was as if the water floated off and set sailing thoughts which had grown stagnant on dry land, and gave to their bodies even some sort of physical relief.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1557,"[' Then, up behind the great black rock, almost every evening spurted irregularly, so that one had to watch for it and it was a delight when it came, a fountain of white water; and then, while one waited for that, one watched, on the pale semicircular 194 Collected Novels of Virginia Woolf beach, wave after wave shedding again and again smoothly a film of mother-of-pearl.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1558,"[' They both felt a common hilar- ity, excited by the moving waves; and then by the swift cutting race of a sailing boat, which, having sliced a curve in the bay, stopped; shivered; let its sail drop down; and then, with a natural instinct to complete the picture, after this swift movement, both of them looked at the dunes far away, and instead of merriment felt come over them some sadness- because the thing was completed partly, and partly because distant views seem to outlast by a million years (Lily thought) the gazer and to be communing already with a sky which beholds an earth entirely at rest.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1559,"[' Looking at the far sandhills, William Bankes thought of Ramsay: thought of a road in Westmorland, thought of Ramsay striding along a road by himself hung round with that solitude which seemed to be his natural air.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1560,"[' But this was suddenly interrupted, William Bankes remembered (and this must refer to some actual incident), by a hen, straddling her wings out in protection of a covey of little chicks, upon which Ramsay, stopping, pointed his stick and said ""Pretty - pretty,"" an odd illumination into his heart, Bankes had thought it, which showed his simplicity, his sympathy with humble things; but it seemed to him as if their friendship had ceased, there, on that stretch of road.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1561,"[' But in this dumb colloquy with the sand dunes he maintained that his affection for Ramsay had in no way diminished; but there, like the body of a young man laid up in peat for a century, with the red fresh on his lips, was his friendship, in its acuteness and reality laid up across the bay among the sandhills.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1562,"[' He was anxious for the sake of this friendship and perhaps too in order to clear himself in his own mind from the imputation of having dried and shrunk- for Ramsay lived in a welter of children, whereas Bankes was childless and a widower- he was anxious that Lily Briscoe should not disparage Ramsay (a great man in his own way) yet should understand how things stood between them.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1563,"["" Begun long years ago, their friendship had petered out on a Westmorland road, where the hen spread her wings before her chicks; after which Ramsay had married, and their paths lying different ways, there had been, certainly for no one's fault, some tendency, when they met, to repeat.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1564,"[' And, turning to walk back the other way, up the drive, Mr.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1565,"["" Bankes was alive to things which would not have struck him had not those sandhills revealed to him the body of his friendship lying with the red on its lips laid up in peat - for instance, Cam,17 the little girl, Ramsay's youngest daughter.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1566,"["" Here was another of them, Jasper this time, strolling past, to have a shot at a bird, he said, nonchalantly, swinging Lily's hand like a pump-handle as he passed, which caused Mr.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1567,"[' Bankes to say, bitterly, how she was a favourite.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1568,"[' There was education now to be considered (true, Mrs.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1569,"[' Ramsay had something of her own perhaps) let alone the daily wear and tear of shoes and stockings which those ""great fellows"", all well grown, angular, ruthless youngsters, must require.']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1570,"[' He called them privately after the Kings and Queens of England; Cam the Wicked,19 James the Ruthless, Andrew the Just, Prue the Fair- for Prue would have beauty, he thought, how could she help it?']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1571,"["" While he walked up the drive and Lily Briscoe said yes and no and capped his comments (for she was in love with them all, in love with this world) he weighed Ramsay's case, commiserated him, envied him, as if he had seen him divest himself of all those glories of isolation and austerity which crowned him in youth to cumber himself definitely with fluttering wings and clucking domesticities.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

1572,"["" They gave him something- William Bankes acknowledged that; it would have been pleasant if Cam had stuck a flower in his coat or clambered over his shoulder, as over her father's, to look at a picture of Vesuvius in eruption; but they had also, his old friends could not but feel, de- stroyed something.""]",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19
1573,"[' ""Oh but,"" said Lily, ""think of his work!']",Virginia Woolf,To the Light house,19

7,"[' Since she has failed to embody great art, the man whom she knows as Prince Charming promptly deserts her, embarking on yet another of his nocturnal excursions through -dimly-lit streets, past gaunt black-shadowed archways-9 (p.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

8,[' The implication is that with conscience Dorian Gray would have a more ective and controlled approach to a world in which there are clear distinctions not just between right and wrong but also-as the portrait instructively reveals-between art and reality.'],Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
9,"[' In some respects, it would appear that Lord Henry and Dorian Gray share the same aesthetic attitude toward life.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

10,"[' This is a life in which the only emotions that matter take place not in the everyday world but in noble works of art, such as Robert Schumann-9s Forest Scenes, Richard Wagner-9s Lohengrin, and the music played by the eminent pianist Anton Rubinstein-all of which feature in the novel.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

11,"[' Moreover, this is a life in which beauty exists solely in aesthetic objects, such as the Louis-Quinze toilet-set and gilt Spanish leather screen that count among the opulent furnishings that adorn Dorian Gray-9s home.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

12,"[' Yet the more Lord Henry encourages Dorian Gray to explore how various art forms can arouse exquisite emotions, the more the young man-9s passions are attracted to sensations and ideas whose pleasures are taboo-though in ways inconceivable to the aristocrat who is seldom seen venturing outside his world of domestic luxury.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
13,[' The decisive shift occurs when Dorian Gray reads the morally questionable -yellow book that Lord Henry had sent him-9 (p.'],Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
14,"[' (The -yellow-9 implicitly refers to the covers of disreputable French novels, which were notorious for telling tales of sexual intrigue.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
15,"[') Once again, this gift might seem to suggest that Lord Henry is deliberately striving to corrupt rather than amuse his young friend.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
16,"[' But, as we soon gather, Dorian Gray subjects this work of literature to a very narrow interpretation.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
17,"[' (At one point, Des Esseintes delights in plating the shell of a live tortoise with gold and encrusting it with jewels.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
18,"[') In many respects, Wilde modelled the long eleventh - of his novel on aspects of A rebours.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
20,"[' With its -curious jewelled style-9 and its -metaphors as monstrous as orchids-9, the story exerts on him a charm similar to Lord Henry-9s aphorisms.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
21,[' Such phrasing suggests that Dorian Gray has once more traded ethical existence for aes- thetic experience.'],Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

22,[' - XI describes the tedious extent to which Dorian Gray ceaselessly searches -for sensations that would be at once new and delightful-9 but which involve adopting -modes of thought that he knew to be really alien to his nature-9 (p.'],Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

25,[' Dorian Gray dismisses his individual responsibility so much that he assumes that his sins can be attributed not only to his family but also Introduction xvi to literary writings from the past.'],Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
26,[' Dorian Gray thus becomes absorbed in stories about the Roman Empire-9s worst rulers whose tyranny is chronicled in Suetonius-9 Lives of the Caesars.'],Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

27,"[' Not surpris- ingly, the pivotal - XI concludes that Dorian Gray had now reached a point where -he looked on evil simply as a mode through which he could realize his conception of the beautiful-9 (p.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

28,"[' Lacking conscience of any kind, this living work of art will have no qualms whatsoever about committing the kind of homicide familiar to legendary despots.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

33,"['-9 -It is-9, Dorian Gray corrects him, -the face of my soul-9 (p.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

34,"[' All that the despairing Basil Hallward can do in the circum- stances is pray, suggesting that Christianity contains precisely those words of wisdom that the young man should know in order to save his soul.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
35,"[' Having savagely murdered Hallward, Dorian Gray blackmails an acquaintance into helping to dispose of the body.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

37,"[' On the other hand, Dorian Gray visits an opium den in London-9s docklands.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

366,"[' -I am quite sure I shall under- stand it,-9 he replied, gazing intently at the little golden white- feathered disk, -and as for believing things, I can believe anything, provided that it is quite incredible.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
367,"['-9 The wind shook some blossoms from the trees, and the heavy lilac-blooms, with their clustering stars, moved to and fro in the languid air.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
368,"[' Lord Henry felt as if he could hear Basil Hallward-9s heart beating, and wondered what was coming.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
369,"[' -The story is simply this,-9 said the painter after some time.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

378,[' Then--but I don-9t know how to explain it to you.'],Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
379,[' Something seemed to tell me that I was on the verge of a terrible crisis in my life.'],Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
380,[' I had a strange feeling that Fate had in store for me exquisite joys and exquisite sorrows.'],Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
381,"['* I grew afraid, and turned to quit the room.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
382,[' I take no credit to myself for trying to escape.'],Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

386,['-d she screamed out.'],Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

389,"[' I believe some picture of mine had made a great success at the time, at least had been chattered about in the penny newspapers,* which is the nineteenth-century standard of immortality.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

2143,"[' He never knew-never indeed, had any cause to know-that some- what grotesque dread of mirrors, and polished metal surfaces, and still water,* which came upon the young Parisian so early in his life, and was occasioned by the sudden decay of a beauty that had once, apparently, been so remarkable.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19

2144,"[' It was with an almost cruel joy-and perhaps in nearly every joy, as certainly in every pleasure, cruelty has its place-that he used to read the latter part of the book, with its really tragic, if somewhat over-emphasized, account of the sorrow and despair of one who had himself lost what in others, and in the world, he had most dearly valued.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
2145,"[' For the wonderful beauty that had so fascinated Basil Hallward, and many others besides him, seemed never to leave him.']",Oscar Wild,The picture of Durian Gary,19
